Member-only story
Rest in Peace David Lynch
Loren Kantor
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Picture Palace
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
4 days ago
5.2K
93
Woodcut of David Lynch (artwork by author).
During the 1980s, David Lynch was a ubiquitous presence in Los Angeles. He gave talks at the American Film Institute, his movies Eraserhead and Elephant Man were continually screened at revival theaters, his paintings and photos were featured at local art galleries and he scrawled a weekly comic for the LA Reader called ‚ÄúThe Angriest Dog in the World.‚Äù Twice I saw him having pie and coffee at Bob‚Äôs Big Boy in Burbank.
In 1986, Lynch released his cinematic masterpiece Blue Velvet. The opening sequence features a blue sky, red roses and a white picket fence ‚Äî an obvious metaphor for America. We see an old fire truck, kids walking to school, a man watering his front lawn. Suddenly, the man has a stroke and falls to the ground. The man‚Äôs dog licks the squirting hose poised over the man‚Äôs groin while Lynch‚Äôs camera sifts through the uncut blades of grass until we see a horde of devilish beetles devouring a pile of dung.
Lynch was exploring America‚Äôs shadow side. He was showing us the nasty underbelly of our nation behind the white picket fences and oversized flags. Blue Velvet was an antidote to the blind patriotism of Reaganism. Critics either loved the movie or called it sick and depraved.
During this period, I worked as a script reader for Paramount Pictures. I drove to the studio on Monday mornings and picked up five to ten screenplays to read, synopsize and critique by Friday afternoon. Most were awful. There were so many retreads of Lethal Weapon and Beverly Hills Cop I began to despise reading screenplays (including my own).
One day I encountered a screenplay that was amazing and bizarre. It was called One Saliva Bubble. The screenwriters were Mark Frost and David Lynch. I was confused. Why was one of the era‚Äôs great American auteurs suffering the indignity of a low-level script reading? Were studio heads leaving it to a minion like me to influence whether or not another David Lynch movie was made?
I sat down at a coffee house and read the script. By the middle of page one, I was smiling. By page ten, I was laughing hysterically. When I finished the script 90 minutes later I was in love with screenwriting again. The story had a slapstick feel, a Coen Brothers rhythm with the silliness of Monty Python.
The script begins when a single saliva bubble floats from the mouth of a laughing security guard onto exposed copper wire inside a Pentagon control center. This causes an electrical short activating a space satellite. An ominous countdown begins. We meet the offbeat citizens of Newtonville, Kansas. They include a Swiss scientist, an assassin, Chinese acrobats, attendees at a Heinz 57 convention and the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs stupidest man.‚Äù When the satellite ticks to zero, it emits a laser burst that strikes Newtonville causing the characters to change personalities (and clothes). The assassin becomes the car salesman, the scientist becomes the village idiot, a black jazz musician becomes a white floozy and so on. Strangely, no one notices the personality changes except the Pentagon Generals who try in vain to fix the problem.
Lynch called the script an ‚Äúout and out wacko dumb comedy.‚Äù He wanted to make the film with Steve Martin and Martin Short but couldn‚Äôt obtain financing. Lynch and Frost abandoned the project and went on to write and produce Twin Peaks.
I made a copy of One Saliva Bubble and passed it among my screenwriter friends. That‚Äôs how I learned of another dormant Lynch screenplay with mythic status. It was called Ronnie Rocket. A friend at Propaganda Pictures (who represented Lynch at the time) smuggled me the script. Ronnie Rocket is difficult to synopsize. Lynch described the script as ‚Äúan American smokestack industrial thing having to do with coal, oil and electricity‚Ä¶ and a three-foot guy with red hair.‚Äù
The story takes place in a post-apocalyptic city (similar to Eraserhead) plagued by electrical mayhem involving a mercurial, demon-like figure named Hank Bartells. Bartells alters the city‚Äôs electrical grid and sends black-coated Donut Men to assault people with cattle prods. The resulting upheaval causes people to pulsate, have seizures, eat their hands and have hemorrhages.
Enter the protagonist, the midget Ronnie Rocket. Ronnie tries to solve the city‚Äôs problems when he‚Äôs kidnapped by two mad scientists who recreate him in their lab with bright red hair and a body pulsing with electrical current. The resurrected Ronnie must plug himself into the wall every 15 minutes to rejuvenate. Ronnie joins a rock band and becomes a teen idol, but the evil Bartells electrocutes Ronnie every time he performs causing his life essence to slip away.
In some ways Ronnie Rocket is a dramatic version of One Saliva Bubble. Both rely on interruptions to an electrical grid wreaking havoc on the status quo. It‚Äôs the dark tone that makes Ronnie Rocket unforgettable. At one point the Donut Men burst into flames upon being told their shoes are untied (a broken circuit). The mad scientists celebrate their reanimation of Ronnie by going out for milkshakes.
Like many of Lynch‚Äôs movies, Ronnie Rocket explores themes of idealized 1950s culture, industrial design and physical deformity. Lynch began writing the script in 1978. For the next two decades, he attempted to get the movie made.
Potential backers included Dino De Laurentis Entertainment (they went bankrupt) and Francis Ford Coppola‚Äôs American Zoetrope (they also went bankrupt). Studios and financiers had a hard time getting their heads around the film. Lynch said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not really a violent film. But it‚Äôs completely abstract, like Eraserhead. I need to work with people who are not looking for a tremendous commercial return.‚Äù
Lynch stopped actively pursuing Ronnie Rocket in 1990 but never officially abandoned the project. Other unmade Lynch ideas include a film version of Kafka‚Äôs Metamorphosis, a script about Marilyn Monroe called Venus Descending, a story called Dream of the Bovine about three guys who were once cows and Antelope Don‚Äôt Run No More about space aliens and a struggling rocker named Pinky.
Lynch made ten feature films in his life plus the mind-blowing tv series Twin Peaks. He was first and foremost a painter. He believed in the creative power of dreams and embraced all forms of creativity. When film students sought his advice, Lynch said the key to crafting movies is a comfortable chair to sit in while you wait for inspiration.
On August 7, 2024, David Lynch released a message to his fans on Instagram.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Yes, I have emphysema from my many years of smoking. I have to say that I enjoyed smoking very much, and I do love tobacco ‚Äî the smell of it, lighting cigarettes on fire, smoking them ‚Äî but there is a price to pay for this enjoyment, and the price for me is emphysema. I have now quit smoking for over two years. Recently I had many tests and the good news is that I am in excellent shape except for emphysema. I am filled with happiness, and I will never retire.
I want you all to know that I really appreciate your concern.
Love,
David
David Lynch died on January 16, 2025. His family issued a press release with the words: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a big hole in the world now that he‚Äôs no longer with us. But as he would say, ‚ÄòKeep your eye on the donut and not on the hole.‚Äô‚Äù<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

Swearing-In Through the Lens: Lessons from Inaugural Photos
A lot has changed, but some things remain the same
Betsy Denson
¬∑
Follow

All photos credited to the Library of Congress (public domain); Clockwise from upper left: Woodrow Wilson giving inaugural address, Jimmy Carter and family walking down Pennsylvania Avenue during the parade, photographers at President Taft‚Äôs inauguration, President Teddy Roosevelt leaving for the parade, President Ronald Reagan‚Äôs inauguration, the crowd at Lincoln‚Äôs second inauguration, President Bush Sr‚Äôs swearing-in
T
he first Presidential Inauguration happened well before the advent of photography. In 1789, George Washington got the word that he‚Äôd won more than a week after the votes were counted.¬π He saddled up the horse, and headed for the capitol ‚Äî New York City ‚Äî where he took the oath in April of that year which is still used today:
‚ÄúI do solemnly swear that I will faithfully execute the Office of President of the United States, and will to the best of my Ability, preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.‚Äù
The first actual Inauguration photo (below), was taken in 1857 by Capitol architect assistant John Wood.¬≤ It depicts President James Buchanan being sworn in at the nation‚Äôs new capital, Washington, D.C. Because the zoom lens did not exist in the 1850s, we can‚Äôt see the pale face of the president himself, who was very ill ‚Äî probably with cholera.¬≥
Photo credit: Montgomery C. Meigs Papers ‚Äî Library of Congress
John Wood is also credited for the shot below, taken in 1861, of Abraham Lincoln‚Äôs First Inauguration.‚Å¥ Either cameras have improved, or the photographer has, because this is a much clearer image. I was struck by the crowd size, but couldn‚Äôt find a record of how many people were in attendance.
Photo credit: Montgomery C. Meigs Papers ‚Äî Library of Congress
It‚Äôs worth noting what they saw was a work in progress, which is an apt metaphor for the country at the time. Check out the unfinished dome.
Photo credit: Montgomery C. Meigs Papers ‚Äî Library of Congress
Gardner, Alexander, 1821‚Äì1882, photographer, Library of Congress
The photo above of Lincoln‚Äôs second inauguration resembles his first, but I was more intrigued by the crowd shot below. Once thought to be from a Grand Review or Grant‚Äôs inauguration, it‚Äôs a view of the grounds beyond the East Portico at Lincoln‚Äôs second swearing-in. I look at the men in their uniforms with their Muzzleloaders and think about all they must have endured to get from 1861 to 1865.
Gardner, Alexander, 1821‚Äì1882, photographer, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
Compare that with the below shot from the National Park Service of the crowd at Obama‚Äôs 2009 inauguration, 144 years later. Would the men with muzzleloaders ever have believed America would elect an African American president?
National Park Service, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
U
ntil the 1980s, the view of the President being sworn in was pretty standard. Here‚Äôs President Teddy Roosevelt‚Äôs big day in 1905 (it‚Äôs been colorized):
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
And Benjamin Harrison in 1889.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
And Woodrow Wilson in 1913.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
And John F. Kennedy in 1961:
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
Things changed with President Ronald Reagan in 1981. He wanted to accommodate a larger crowd, so the ceremony moved from the East portico to the West portico facing the National Mall.‚Åµ Where it has stayed to the present day.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
T
he oath of office, of course, is a precursor to the speech and the rest of the festivities. Here‚Äôs Chief Justice William Howard Taft administering the oath to Herbert Hoover in 1929.
Fun fact: Taft, once president himself, is remembered for flubbing the oath to Hoover, saying ‚Äúpreserve, maintain, and defend‚Äù instead of ‚Äúpreserve, protect and defend.‚Äù
A 13-year-old girl listening on the radio wrote to tell him of the mistake.‚Å∂ He said he didn‚Äôt make one ‚Äî but was disproved by the playback.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
I
wondered if every President had to swear on a Bible. Turns out it‚Äôs not mandatory but most do.‚Å∑ Nixon swore on two of them. Insert your punchline here.
Many presidents also have their Bible open to a specific verse.‚Å∏ This was Nixon‚Äôs choice in 1969 (chosen I‚Äôm guessing because his job was to get us out of Vietnam):
‚ÄúAnd he shall judge among the nations, and shall rebuke many people: and they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruninghooks: nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore.‚Äù ‚Äî Isaiah 2:4
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
Bush Sr. and his son used Washington‚Äôs 1767 King James Bible. Obama and Trump used Lincoln‚Äôs.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
A
fter the swearing-in, the inaugural parade follows ‚Äî a tradition that started as a simple escort to the new digs a.k.a, the White House, but has evolved with time. Grover Cleveland (below in 1885) was the first to have parade stands set up to watch the troops go by.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
The parade for Teddy Roosevelt (below) included the Apache leader Geronimo who was a prisoner of war. He was only permitted to leave Ft. Sill in Oklahoma to participate in Wild West shows ‚Äî and inaugurations.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
In later years, the parade became a little less formal and included plenty of civilians, including this guy on roller skates at Jimmy Carter‚Äôs inauguration.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
T
he way Presidents travel down Pennsylvania Avenue is different, too, thanks to Jimmy Carter. Previous to 1977, Presidents went by buggy, and then by car. But after Carter and his family walked for more than a mile, it‚Äôs become a tradition for presidents to walk ‚Äî at least a little while.‚Åπ
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
Photo Credit: National Archives Catalog
In
today‚Äôs vitriolic political climate, I was interested in photographic evidence of people getting along. Throughout history, U.S. presidents have supported the president-elect by attending the inauguration, sharing lunch before heading to the Capitol, and leaving a letter of advice in the Oval Office, among other traditions.¬π‚Å∞
I saw President Taft in 1909 entering the Capitol to take the oath of office with Teddy Roosevelt, which isn‚Äôt surprising since Taft was hand-picked to succeed Roosevelt.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
What is more impressive is Taft riding in a carriage with Woodrow Wilson at Wilson‚Äôs Inauguration four years later. Especially since Wilson had just beat him in a landslide.
Photo Credit: Library of Congress
The examples don‚Äôt need to be a century old. I look at this picture from 2017 and think ‚Äî this is what tradition means.
Doing something because everyone did it before you. Because of the comfort in continuity that there is for the rest of us.
A much-needed grounding in a very uncertain world.
Staff Sgt. Marianique Santos, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Techniques for Chat Data Analytics with Python
Part II: Topic Extraction with BERTopic
Robin von Malottki
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Towards Data Science
¬∑
10 min read
¬∑
Nov 15, 2024
278
5
Photo by Mikechie Esparagoza
and obtained from Pexels.com
In the first part of this series, I introduced you to my artificially created friend John, who was nice enough to provide us with his chats with five of the closest people in his life. We used just the metadata, such as who sent messages at what time, to visualize when John met his girlfriend, when he had fights with one of his best friends and which family members he should write to more often. If you didn‚Äôt read the first part of the series, you can find it here.
What we didn‚Äôt cover yet but we will dive deeper into now is an analysis of actual messages. Therefore, we will use the chat between John and Maria to identify the topics they discuss. And of course, we will not go through the messages one by one and classify them ‚Äî no, we will use the Python library BERTopic to extract the topics that the chats revolve around.
What is BERTopic?
BERTopic is a topic modeling technique introduced by Maarten Grootendorst that uses transformer-based embeddings, specifically BERT embeddings, to generate coherent and interpretable topics from large collections of documents. It was designed to overcome the limitations of traditional topic modeling approaches like LDA (Latent Dirichlet Allocation), which often struggle to handle short texts or produce consistent topics across different document collections.
In this blog, I will not dive into the theoretical background of BERTopic ‚Äî if you are interested in this, I highly recommend the following articles by the BERTopic legend himself:
Topic Modeling with BERT
Interactive Topic Modeling with BERTopic
Using Whisper and BERTopic to model Kurzgesagt‚Äôs videos
If you want to follow along, you should install BERTopic using pip, along with the sentence-transformers package, which we will use for the model.
pip install sentence-transformers
pip install bertopic
The Data
We will use chat data artificially created by ChatGPT. If you‚Äôd like to extract your own chats from WhatsApp and follow the topic extraction process, you can read this blog for how I did it. I won‚Äôt go into detail about the transformation steps, but you can find the Python code here and my structured example data here. After applying the transformations, we will arrive at the following data structure:
Image by Author
Date: When the message has been sent
Chat: Which chat ‚Äî In our case always maria
Author: The individual who delivered the respective message.
Message: The content of what was said.
Topic Extraction
The amazing thing about BERTopic is that not much data preprocessing is necessary. The idea is to keep it as easy as possible, allowing users to focus on extracting meaningful insights without getting bogged down.
import pandas as pd
from bertopic import BERTopic


data = pd.read_excel(r"") #load your data
In the next step we load our model and apply it to our data.
topic_model = BERTopic(embedding_model="all-MiniLM-L6-v2")
topics, probs = topic_model.fit_transform(data['Message'])
To get a first impression, I will start with an overview of the topics generated. This includes how many topics have been created, which words represent these topics and which sentences are included in each. Here, we also touch on the important core idea behind topic creation: it is not the case that each topic returns exactly one word. Instead, topics usually consist of a collection of words because a single word cannot capture all the nuances of a topic. This approach allows users more opportunities to interpret each cluster.
Input:
topic_model.get_topic_info().head(5)
Output:
Image by Author
Each topic is labeled with a number, with the label ‚Äú-1‚Äù indicating outliers that can‚Äôt be assigned to any specific topic. Currently, I am displaying only the first five topics. My analysis identified a total of 23 topics based on 1090 messages, with around 30% of all messages classified as outliers. We could dive deeper into these outliers to determine whether they truly don‚Äôt fit any topic or if they contain content irrelevant to the identified topics. However, since 70% of the messages are clearly assigned to topics , I will focus on those.
From topics 0 through 4, we can already glean some initial insights into the clusters. For instance, Topic 1 appears to focus on cocktails, while Topic 3 seems to involve discussions about teachers and students. This provides a preliminary impression of what the messages in each topic might entail, though it‚Äôs too early to draw any firm conclusions. On the other hand, Topic 0 and Topic 2 appear to contain more generic terms that might be considered stopwords rather than topic-specific words. While Topic 0 could perhaps be categorized as ‚ÄúPlans,‚Äù Topic 2 lacks any clear keywords that suggest a specific topic. So simply looking at the first 5 rows Topics gives us already some relevant insights:
70% of the Messages are assigned to a topic.
Topic 1 and 3 gives already a good impression of their focus. (Cocktails & Teachers)
Topic 0 might relate to planning, but no clear topic stands out otherwise.
Topic 2 requires further inspection, as no clear topic can be assigned to it.
We can keep these initial insights in mind as we continue with our analysis. While I won‚Äôt be doing it right now, it could be interesting to create a sorted bar chart based on the count of messages assigned to each topic, along with the topics themselves. This would give you an impression of whether the topics are equally important in the conversation, or if the distribution is skewed, with just a few topics dominating the discussion with your friend. I‚Äôll skip this analysis for now and move directly to examining the topics themselves.
As you may have noticed, the ‚Äúname‚Äù column contains the topic number followed by underscores and several words. The order of these words generally reflects their significance to the topic. While the first word may carry substantial weight, in some cases, the significance is more evenly distributed across the first few words. To analyze this, we‚Äôll use some visualization functions integrated into BERTopic.
Let‚Äôs start with simple bar charts:
Input:
topic_model.visualize_barchart(topics=list(range(23)))
Output:
Image by Author
This visualization helps to identify how the importance of various words differs within each topic cluster. In some topics, we can clearly see that certain words have a higher importance than others. This indicates that these words should be central to labeling the topics. The following topics appear to have one or two significant keywords:
Topic 3: Teachers
Topic 8: family
Topic 10: Church
Topic 12: Our Baby
Topic 13: Travel & Trips
Topic 15: Exactly
Topic 16: Proposal
Topic 17: Parents
Topic 19: Marriage
Topic 20: We
These are already quite strong topics that you could connect to specific groups of sentences, although Topics 15 (exactly) and 20 (We) are still unclear.
Another observation from the bar chart is that some topics help form a clearer picture of what John and Maria are writing about. What‚Äôs particularly interesting is not only whether a single word dominates a cluster, but also when multiple words belong to the same logical family. For example, the following topics could likely be grouped together:
Topic 1: Cocktails
Topic 5: Car Accident
Topic 7: Extreme Sport
Topic 11: Communication
Topic 22: Outgoing with friends
As you review the clusters, you may notice a common challenge with topic extraction: it will never be perfect or entirely automated. While many topics make sense ‚Äî such as Church, Marriage, Family, and Travel ‚Äî there are also topics that require further investigation, like Topics 15 and 20. These may represent stopwords that were frequently used.
Now, let‚Äôs recap the insights we generated from the bar charts and the Topic Word Scores analysis:
A group of topics is dominated by one or two words within their clusters, and most of them make logical sense.
A group of topics provides a clear indication of what the conversation is about because many of the words in these clusters belong to a logical context.
Some topics still don‚Äôt make sense because they do not form a clear cluster.
With this in mind, let‚Äôs proceed by visualizing the entire landscape of messages assigned to their respective categories.
Input:
topic_model.visualize_documents(data['Message'], topics=list(range(23)), custom_labels=True, height=600)
Output:
Image by Author
Each bubble in this visualization represents a message spoken by either John or Maria. The colors correspond to their respective topics. The axes are labeled with values obtained from dimensionality reduction, so they don‚Äôt have direct interpretations. When topics are positioned close to each other, it indicates semantic similarity between them. This proximity suggests that the topics share related themes, vocabulary, or contextual meanings within the messages.
As you can see, this static view doesn‚Äôt provide much insight on its own. However, when created in Python, the visualization allows for interactive exploration of the message universe, enabling you to view the individual messages. From there, you can decide what to do with certain clusters ‚Äî such as merging them with others or removing them entirely.
For simplicity, I will select a few clusters to make the visualization clearer and further group the topics.
Input:
# Specify the topics you want to visualize
selected_topics = [1,3,5,7,8,10,12,13,16,17,19]

# Visualize only the selected topics
topic_model.visualize_documents(data['Message'], topics=selected_topics, custom_labels=True, height=600)
Output:
Image by Author
To make the topics even more accessible, I will now label them.
Input:
#Label Topics
topic_model.set_topic_labels({1:"Cocktails", 3: "Teacher", 5: "Car Accident",7: "Extreme Sport",8: "Family",10: "Church",12: "Our Baby",13: "Travel",16: "Proposal",17: "Parents",19: "Marriage"})

# Specify the topics you want to visualize
selected_topics = [1,3,5,7,8,10,12,13,16,17,19]

# Visualize only the selected topics
topic_model.visualize_documents(data['Message'], topics=selected_topics, custom_labels=True, height=600)
Output:
Image by Author
Now, we‚Äôve clearly identified a portion of what John and Maria are discussing. Remember, the closer the topics are to each other, the higher their semantic similarity.
Let‚Äôs try clustering the topics. One group of topics seems to revolve around Family, Marriage, Proposal, and Their Baby. This strongly suggests that John and Maria are a married couple with children or they are planning to get children. This appears to be a significant theme in their lives.
The second major theme seems to center around their leisure activities. They‚Äôre discussing topics such as Church, Traveling, Extreme Sports and Car Accident. If we want to dive deeper into this, we could perform further analyses, such as sentiment analysis on the messages within these topics. For example, the Extreme Sports topic might have a more negative tone for Maria compared to John and she could be trying to convince him to stop. Understanding how each person feels about certain topics could offer valuable insights into the nature of their discussions. However for now this would be just speculation.
Finally, I would categorize the Teacher and Cocktails topics as separate clusters, as they don‚Äôt seem to fit well with the others. It‚Äôs interesting that the Teacher cluster stands out so clearly , cause after reading the messages, we can see that John and Maria were actually discussing the shortage of teachers in schools.
Conclusion
In this blog post, we used the Python library BERTopic to analyze John‚Äôs chat with Maria. By applying the model to their conversation, we identified clear and personal topics they discussed. While we cannot draw definitive conclusions without deeper exploration of their communication, we can already infer several things. For example, it seems that one of them is religious or at least has a connection to the church. We also observed that their relationship appears to be intense, likely indicating they are married or have children, or perhaps planning to start a family. Additionally, we uncovered that their hobbies include extreme sports, and even a car accident was part of their conversation.
Through this analysis, we‚Äôve shown that by applying topic modeling to their chat, it‚Äôs not necessary to read through all 1,000 messages to get a clear sense of the key topics they are discussing. This approach provides a quick and effective way to understand the central themes in a conversation.
However, we have only scratched the surface of topic extraction by identifying just a portion of what John and Maria were talking about. There are many more avenues to explore:
Correlation Heatmap: Which topics are worth merging?
Topics Over Time: Did the topics evolve as the series progressed?
Topic Hierarchy: Is there a hierarchy among the topics?
Thanks for joining me on this journey through chat analysis! If you enjoyed exploring the intricacies of John and Maria‚Äôs conversations, I‚Äôd appreciate a clap or a follow ‚Äî your support fuels my creativity!
If you didn‚Äôt read it, check out the first part of the series to see what happens when you apply the model to your own WhatsApp chats about your relationships with family and friends! The codes an analysis of this Blog you can find on my Github profile.

Techniques for Chat Data Analytics with Python
Part I: Communication Density Analysis
Robin von Malottki
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Towards Data Science
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Oct 25, 2024
113
1
Photo by Mikechie Esparagoza
and obtained from Pexels.com
For many years now, our communication has become increasingly digital. Whether through quick text messages via chat applications or sending emails, digital messaging has firmly embedded itself in our daily lives.
This leads to an increase in the amount of digitally produced data.
Since communication involves at least two individuals, it can reveal a lot of insights about the participants and their relationship with each other.
This article will be the first part of a series where I will show you the cool things you can do with your chats and the personal insights you can gain from them. You can always find the Python code and any Tableau files I create for visualizations on my GitHub profile.
The Goal
Since this is the first article of the series, I would like to start with a high-level analysis of the metadata from WhatsApp chats. I have named the upcoming analysis Communication Density Analysis because the main feature of the visualization emerges from the density of the sent messages.
Image by Author
This event plot shows the communication between an artificially created person, let‚Äôs call him John, and five of his closest chat partners, whom we will initially refer to as A, B, C, D, and E. Later, I will reveal the identities of these five individuals and explain the relationships John has with each of them.
In the event plot, each line represents a message. The different rows display the respective chats. The darker the green, the more messages have been exchanged between the individuals in the chat. If the lines turn golden, it indicates that there was communication, but only a few messages were sent.
The interesting aspect of this type of analysis is that it can provide insights into the person whose chats you are examining. For example, we see that the chat with Person A only started around February 2022 and quickly became quite intensive. There are no gaps or whitespace in this chat, so we can assume there is intensive daily communication. Could it be that John started dating someone who has become a very special person in his life?
Not only can you gain insights into who might be someone‚Äôs potential girlfriend or boyfriend and identify when people meet, but you can also detect conflicts between individuals. For instance, Person B regularly communicated with John, but the intensity decreased until February 2022, when suddenly the digital contact ceased. Could it be that John was involved in a serious conflict with Person B around this time? Perhaps it‚Äôs just a coincidence that he started to communicate more intensively with Person A during this period ‚Äî was the conflict perhaps related to Person A? Of course, there could be many explanations for gaps in communication, but we can definitely see that something happened in the data, and possible relationships can be identified.
However, about a year later, John and Person B experienced another communication gap, followed by intensive and frequent communication. Person C seems to have always engaged in frequent and high-intensity communication, which has also increased over time. There are some gaps in their communication, suggesting that it may not be daily but rather regular and frequent ‚Äî perhaps resembling communication with a best friend.
Persons D and E exhibit a similar pattern regarding the intensity of communication with John. When they do communicate, they tend to send more messages. However, communication with Person D appears to happen less frequently, although both could be good friends or family members.
Now that we‚Äôve examined the data, let‚Äôs unveil the identities of the individuals hiding behind A, B, C, D, and E:
Image by Author
Indeed, Person A was actually John‚Äôs girlfriend, whom he met for the first time in February 2022. Person B was his best friend, with whom he lost contact after spending more time with his new girlfriend and rebuilding their relationship. Around February 2023, they had a fight and lost contact again for a while. It seems that John communicates regularly with his mom but has less frequent communication with his sister. Finally, Person E was his old school friend, with whom there are sometimes communication gaps, but they always find their way back to each other.
Now that you‚Äôve seen the insights you can generate, I recommend trying it with your own messages. I tested this with some of my WhatsApp chats, and it is fascinating to see what emerges from the analysis. To make it easier for you, I will now show you how to create the visualization with your own data.
How to create the event plot?
The first step is of course to get the data. I personally did it with Whatsapp. For that you can find here an easy and fast instruction how to get your data. If you have downloaded it you get text files that could look like this
16.01.24, 15:13 - John Snow is a contact.
16.01.24, 15:13 - John Snow: <Media Excluded>
16.01.24, 15:13 - John Snow: Hi! How are you?üòÄ
16.01.24, 15:16 - Maria: Hey, I‚Äôm doing well, thanks! How about you?
16.01.24, 15:17 - John Snow: I‚Äôm good too, just been busy with work lately.
16.01.24, 15:19 - Maria: I can relate! Anything exciting going on?
16.01.24, 15:21 - John Snow: Not much, just trying to catch up with everything. What about you?
To create an event plot, we need to extract the messages, the date, the author, and the chat to generate the visualization. As you can see, there are also texts saved that say ‚ÄúX is a contact‚Äù or ‚Äú<Media Excluded>‚Äù. We will need to filter out these rows in the future. Note that since your messenger may be set to a different language, it might use different expressions that also need to be filtered out. I will explain where in the upcoming code you can enter your expressions if needed. But first, let‚Äôs check the table structure to see how it should look to create the event plot.
Image by Author
We have the Date column, which includes the hours and minutes when the message was sent. In our example, we are chatting in the Maria chat, and the authors are John and Maria. If you apply this to groups, there may be more than two authors. In the Message column, the messages will be collected, which enables incredible analysis possibilities. However, those will be explored in the upcoming parts of this series.
To start with the transformation and move from the text files to a structured format, we first need to load the data.
import pandas as pd
import glob
import os

folder_path = r"C:\Users\Robin\Whatsapp_chats"  #Enter your folderpath Folder path here

# Returns a list with all file_paths in the folder with .txt ending
all_files = glob.glob(os.path.join(folder_path, "*.txt"))

# Create empty list for DataFrames
dfs = []
Therefore we start by importing the nececarry libraries and we define the folder path, where our chats are safed in text files. Then we would like to have a list with all file paths to the respective chats in the folder that contain the txt endings. Therefore we create the all_files variable. In the third step we create an empty list for the dataframes that we will collect.
# Read all filed, add the file name as column and append these to the list dfs
for file in all_files:
    df = pd.read_csv(file, sep='\t', engine='python', header=None, names=['Text'], on_bad_lines='warn', encoding='utf-8')
    df['Filename'] = os.path.basename(file)  # Dateiname hinzuf√ºgen
    dfs.append(df)

# Combine all DataFrames with the concat command.
chat = pd.concat(dfs, ignore_index=True)
Now that we have loaded all the chat data into one DataFrame, there are two more things to do:
Filter out rows that do not include messages.
Split the data into Date, Chat, Author, and Message columns.
For filtering, we will use a simple regex, a string match function, and a specific string contains function.
# Define Pattern for Message rows
pattern = r'\d{2}\.\d{2}\.\d{2}, \d{2}:\d{2} - .+: .*'

# Filter the rows
chat = chat[chat['Text'].str.match(pattern)]
chat = chat[~chat['Text'].str.contains(r'(<Media Excluded>|null)')]
The first filter excludes all rows that do not match the pattern defined by the regex. This way, we eliminate lines like ‚ÄúJohn Snow is a contact.‚Äù
The second filter removes all rows that contain expressions such as ‚Äúnull‚Äù or ‚Äú<Media Excluded>.‚Äù In fact, all messages that are voice messages will be replaced with ‚Äúnull.‚Äù I find these messages uninteresting, but if you are interested in them, you can simply remove the ‚Äúnull‚Äù expression from the filter. If there are other rows that you would like to exclude, please add them to the str.contains expression.
In the second step, we only need to split the columns. To do this, we will use some split operations and then filter to the columns of interest.
# Extract Date
chat['Date'] = chat['Text'].str.split(' - ').str[0]

# Extract Author
chat['Author']=  chat.apply(lambda row: row['Text'].replace(row['Date'] + ' - ', ''), axis=1)

# Extract Chat - Adjust "WhatsApp-Chat mit " with your filename pattern
chat['Chat'] = chat['Filename'].str.replace('WhatsApp-Chat mit ', '').str.replace('.txt', '')

# Split Author column to Author and Message
chat[['Author', 'Message']] = chat['Author'].str.split(': ', n=1, expand=True)

# Filter relevant columns
chat = chat[['Date','Author','Message','Chat']]
One point I would like to mention here: When I extract my WhatsApp chats, the filename is saved with a German pattern. In my case, it is ‚ÄúWhatsApp-Chat mit Maria.txt‚Äù. To create the Chat column, I simply extracted the filename as an extra column and removed the left and right parts of ‚ÄúMaria.‚Äù You will likely need to adjust this based on your language.
After this, you will have your chats in a tabular form. You only need to download my Tableau file from my GitHub profile, edit the data source, and replace it with yours.
In my other article, The Transparent Human, I already demonstrated how dangerous specific data can be when used to answer personal questions about an individual, potentially leading to manipulation. If you apply the techniques from this blog to analyze specific chats, please ensure you obtain the other person‚Äôs consent, as this analysis can reveal insights they may not want you to know. In this way, we must respect the privacy of others.
Conclusion
In this first part of our series, we have explored the fascinating world of WhatsApp chat analysis, highlighting how even the metadata can reveal significant insights about interpersonal relationships. By examining communication density and patterns, we can uncover dynamics such as the emergence of new connections, potential conflicts, and the ebb and flow of friendships over time.
As you embark on your own journey of chat analysis, I encourage you to approach it with curiosity and responsibility. Download the provided Tableau file, apply the techniques discussed, and see what stories your chats tell.
Thanks for sticking around to the end! If you enjoyed this wild ride through chat analysis, give a clap or hit that follow button ‚Äî your support keeps me caffeinated and inspired! In the next article, I‚Äôll dive deeper into topic extraction: What were you and your friends writing about the most? Get ready for some exciting insights! Until then, happy chatting!<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
The Transparent Human
How data can reveal the true nature of anyone
Robin von Malottki
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Towards Data Science
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Oct 11, 2024
112
Image by zahtris from pixabay.
In 2014, a German data scientist started to collect data about articles from the German digital newspaper magazine ‚ÄúDer Spiegel.‚Äù For 2.5 years, he scraped over 100,000 articles as well as the associated metadata, such as publishing time, section, and author. After collecting the data, he began to analyze it. One of his findings was that he was able to predict which authors of ‚ÄúDer Spiegel‚Äù had intimate relationships with each other. Furthermore, his results provided insights into the internal personnel structure of the company itself.
This example already reveals the true danger of the transparent human. With only a small amount of data that may not seem particularly dangerous, you can gain highly personal insights about an individual. While I wouldn‚Äôt assume any bad intentions on the part of David Kriesel, the German data scientist mentioned above, there are groups that may view everything differently and want to have an impact on you. They seek to change behavior and would like to manipulate individuals for their own advantage.
One of these groups was Cambridge Analytica ‚Äî a British consulting company that was allegedly involved in the political campaigns for Brexit and the Trump presidential campaign of 2016. Their basic concept was to use data from Facebook activities to build psychographic profiles and utilize this information for micro-targeting techniques that would display different advertisements to different groups of users. Potential swing voters ‚Äî those who are not quite sure who to vote for ‚Äî would receive a more personalized message than those who were already convinced Trump supporters.
Of course, we don‚Äôt know how significant the impact of Cambridge Analytica truly was on Trump‚Äôs success in 2016, but we definitely know that their mere existence shows there are groups and organizations out there that would like to use your data to achieve their own goals. If a single German data scientist already has the means to reveal highly sensitive information about the authors of a major magazine, these groups and organizations are much larger, able to access more data, and possess far greater capabilities to retrieve and evaluate personal data for their profit.
In this blog, I aim to explain the concept of the ‚Äútransparent human,‚Äù highlighting how organizations can derive extensive insights about individuals from minimal information. I will also discuss the potential dangers associated with this transparency and suggest measures we can take to mitigate its impact.
What Is the Transparent Human?
The transparent human metaphorically describes a situation where people become transparent and easily traceable in their privacy due to extensive data collection. While there may not be a single end state of being transparent, it can be perceived more as a process. The more questions you can answer about an individual and the more information you have, the greater insights you are able to generate.
Please recognize that the relationship between the data and the amount and value of insights you generate defines the value of the data itself. Therefore, a large organization does not necessarily need big data to create big insights. Instead, they can use tools to impact your behavior. If they consistently collect just a few features about an individual, they can already generate remarkably strong insights. Three of the most powerful features to collect are who, where, and when.
When someone possesses detailed information about you, they can generate a multitude of insights, potentially leveraging them in various ways. I‚Äôm referring to sensitive insights like the following:
Financially Insights: How much money do you earn? Do you have financial problems?
Health: Do you have a serious diseases or do you use a therapy?
Marital Status and Relationships: Do you have children? Are you married? How is your relationship going?
Sexuality: What are your sexual preferences? Have you ever had an affair?
Political Beliefs: Who are you voting for?
Mental Health: Do you feel lonely or isolated? Have you ever had depression?
Job Satisfaction: Are you happy with your job choice?
There are certainly many more insights that can be generated from this data. While there is no 100% certainty, and many insights are often merely estimations, the ‚Äúwho, where, and when‚Äù data provides a substantial analytical foundation. This information can be used to classify individuals, create detailed profiles, and render them transparent to those interested in their transparency.
So What? ‚Äî I Have Nothing to Hide
These profiles can help various groups identify your deepest needs and desires ‚Äî what makes you happy or what you believe can lead to happiness. For example, consider a person burdened by high debts, seeking money to free themselves from this financial cage, or someone who is perpetually single but believes that a partner can fill the void of their unhappiness.
During my time at one of the largest pharmaceutical companies in the world, I encountered an advertisement for a drug that treats Crohn‚Äôs disease (or Morbus Crohn). In the ad, a patient expressed their innermost desire: to walk through the streets without the fear of not having a toilet nearby. A common symptom of this disease is fecal incontinence. By identifying this deep-seated wish, marketing and sales teams can implement their strategies more effectively, gaining a better understanding of how to connect with their target audience.
Please don‚Äôt misunderstand me ‚Äî identifying needs and wishes is not inherently negative. Optimizing communication with patients can be beneficial, as some individuals may not recognize that a particular treatment aligns with their needs and desires. Similarly, in other areas of our lives, having an advisor to guide our decisions can be immensely helpful. For instance, when we consult a real estate agent, they identify our true needs and wishes for the perfect property and assist us in finding our dream home. However, the key difference lies in whether you actively approach someone and share aspects of your inner needs or unconsciously reveal significant parts of your true self to the world with just a click of a button.
Once your true nature has been revealed, these groups can identify the triggers that motivate you. Are you an extroverted person who quickly adapts to group behavior? Are there emotional buttons that can swiftly activate your responses and spur you into action? How susceptible are you to misinformation, nudging, and gamification techniques? Once they understand how to engage with you, it becomes significantly easier for them to influence the decisions they want you to make.
Who Can Possess Your Who, Where, When Data?
The first major players in data collection are governments and public institutions. The most obvious examples include collecting data about your birthplace and current residence at specific times. A more indirect case is the increasing use of public surveillance through cameras. For instance, when passing through a central station, each step may be monitored ‚Äî yet many people are likely unaware that they are essentially live on camera while walking through the station.
However, these are not the only examples of systematic data collection by governments. In 2013, whistleblower Edward Snowden revealed documents about the National Security Agency‚Äôs (NSA) global surveillance program, known as the NSA affair. Many people around the world, especially in the U.S. and Europe, were shocked and outraged by the extent of the NSA‚Äôs monitoring. The revelations that ordinary citizens, not just suspected terrorists or foreign adversaries, were being surveilled led to feelings of betrayal by their governments. However, this shock did not last long. Within a few weeks, and after some bread and circuses, the majority of people had largely forgotten about it.
It‚Äôs not only public institutions that are collecting your data. More and more companies employ entire teams of data engineers, data scientists, and data analysts to gather information and transform it into customer insights. These insights are then utilized by marketing teams and designers to create products that better fulfill your needs. In the realm of social media, designers leverage these insights to introduce more addictive elements to their platforms. A thorough exploration of this topic can be found in the Netflix documentary ‚ÄúThe Social Dilemma.‚Äù
While it may be expected that companies, governments, and public institutions collect your data, the reality is that anyone can access it. With minimal technological skills, anyone can search for you online. They can see which platforms you are active on, and many individuals can use scraping technologies to automatically track your activities and predict your next moves.
What Can You Do to Protect Yourself?
If it were easy and cost-free, I would recommend simply stopping the production of data. However, in an age where smartphones are an integral part of our life, this is quite unrealistic. Moreover, you would have to give up many conveniences, including all digital products and mobility options, and even then, you would still generate data.
Instead, there are still actions we can take. While we may be limited in the data we produce, we can minimize our susceptibility to manipulation. We have control over whether we subscribe to newsletters or receive push notifications from certain applications. Utilizing ad blockers and creating separate folders for newsletters can help us manage incoming information. While seeking new offers from companies can be beneficial, we should always approach it with mindfulness to minimize the potential for manipulation.
If you feel that something is prompting you to make an impulsive decision, such as impulse buying, take a moment for a cooling-off period. After 24 hours, you can reassess whether it would still be a good decision.
Use your Rights: In the EU, under the GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), you have the right to request information about the data collected about you and to have that data deleted. This means you can inquire about what data has been accessed and how it has been stored.
One of the most important points is to act consciously with the data you share. It‚Äôs crucial to understand that once we send our data into the world, we lose control over it, and it is up to others how to use it. This is especially true for photos posted on social media, which are often shared unconsciously ‚Äî sometimes resulting in millions of images ending up on the dark web. If you would like to read about many other data breaches, you can find more information here.
Conclusion
In a world where data is continually being collected and analyzed, it is essential to recognize the implications of our digital footprints. By understanding who can access our personal information and how it can be used, we can take proactive steps to protect our privacy. From exercising our rights under the GDPR to being mindful of the data we share, every action contributes to safeguarding our identities in the digital landscape. Awareness and intentionality in our online behavior are key to minimizing the risks of manipulation and ensuring that we maintain control over our personal information. By staying informed and vigilant, we can navigate the complexities of data usage and mitigate the potential threats that come with living in an interconnected world.
Wow, thank you for making it this far! If you‚Äôre on the lookout for more exciting content, don‚Äôt hesitate to hit that follow button. And if you‚Äôre not racing off to the next blog post just yet, I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts: Do you think we need stricter regulations on data collection and usage? Why or why not? Please share your opinions.

IN THE KITCHEN
Buy Once, Cry Once: The $2,000 Kitchen Knife Lesson
How I Learned the Hard Way That Cheap Knives Cost More in the Long Run
Mark Laflamme
¬∑
Follow
Published in
At Home
¬∑
10 min read
¬∑
Jan 3, 2025
6.3K
173
Five out of Six ‚ÄúDream‚Äù knives ‚Äî image courtesy of the author
When my partner and I got married, one of the gifts we received was a set of kitchen knives. They came in plastic cases that were meant to keep them sharp. They looked decent enough, and, as far as we could tell, they were sharp. Those knives served us well during the first many years of our married life. They weren‚Äôt exceptional, but they got the job done ‚Äî they worked. Or so we thought.
Something changed. I started to enjoy cooking. Not just the day-to-day chore of putting dinner on the table. I enjoyed the art, the science, the process, the creativity, and the satisfaction of making a dish that wowed family and friends. With that growing passion came the desire for better tools, including knives.
Little did I know my desire for better knives would take me on a journey that wasted over $2,000. I could have saved so much money if I‚Äôd made a smarter decision at the start.
The Starter Knives
The first set of knives I owned was a beginner‚Äôs set. It wasn‚Äôt anything fancy, but the knives seemed perfectly adequate for slicing tomatoes, chopping onions, and occasionally cutting through the stubborn rind of a cantaloupe. As someone who didn‚Äôt cook much more than basic meals then, I didn‚Äôt give much thought to their performance, especially since I got them as a gift!
These Wiltshire Staysharp knives were gifted to us on our wedding day. Image courtesy of the author.
But as my interest in cooking grew, so did my discontentment with these knives. The blades dulled quickly despite the ‚Äúmiracle case‚Äù that was supposed to sharpen them. The handles were slippery and uncomfortable, and worst of all, the shape of the knives was all wrong ‚Äî it was so difficult to cut certain things.
Still, I stuck with them. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre good enough,‚Äù I told myself. Besides, a professional-grade set of knives seemed like a luxury for someone just starting to experiment in the kitchen.
The Better Knives
Before ‚ÄúYouTube‚Äù and ‚ÄúFoodTV‚Äù existed, cooking shows were on Saturday afternoons, often on Public Broadcasting Services. I remember a few shows where Jacques P√©pin would talk about the importance of sharp and comfortable knives. Mine were neither sharp nor comfortable, and I had come close to cutting my fingers off occasionally.
I talked with my wife, and we agreed that buying a knife or two would be good. I was a Post-Doctoral Fellow at this point in my life. A post-doc is a fancy way for a company or university to say, ‚ÄúWe have a great researcher here, and we‚Äôve found a way to keep him with little to no pay.‚Äù
So, while we wanted knives, they would not be expensive. But I hoped they could be functional. I found what looked like a good set of knives in a large grocery store.
Despite being heavy and bulky, the knives we got were noticeably better, and I was thrilled with how they performed. I felt like I had ‚Äúlevelled up‚Äù in the kitchen for a time. Chopping, slicing, and dicing became more enjoyable. My cooking improved, and I thought my knife troubles were behind me.
The only knife left from this set is a meat cleaver I rarely use. Image courtesy of the author.
But as the months turned into years, I noticed the same problems creeping in. The blades dulled faster than I expected, the handles weren‚Äôt as ergonomic as I had hoped, and some knives didn‚Äôt hold up to the tasks I was putting them to. Once again, I found myself looking for an upgrade.
One of the problems was that when I bought these knives, I hadn‚Äôt thought about my cooking style or what I wanted to do with the knives. My only concern had been cost. If you‚Äôve ever tried boning a chicken with a steak knife, you know it‚Äôs possible but unpleasant. This is how I felt all the time.
The ‚ÄúAlmost Great‚Äù Knives
By this point, I was fully immersed in my love for cooking. I spent weekends testing new recipes, hosting dinner parties, and reading food blogs. I wanted tools that could keep up with my passion.
I was making more money now, so I decided to spend a little more on this set of knives. And that was the problem. I was thinking about a ‚ÄúSet of Knives.‚Äù
For some reason, I still assumed that I needed a ‚Äúset.‚Äù In other words, I needed a matched assemblage that came together in one box.
I‚Äôve kept the block, utility knife and shears, but everything else was donated. Image courtesy of the author.
I had a friend who was selling ‚ÄúThe Pampered Chef‚Äù products. She told me I should buy a knife set from her. I knew well enough that The Pampered Chef couldn‚Äôt possibly make their own knives, so I searched online to see who made them.
The suppliers change frequently, but it seemed like Henckel made that year‚Äôs The Pampered Chef knives. Henckel is, still today, an excellent knife brand. So I thought, why not‚Ä¶
These were pricier than anything I‚Äôd bought before. The knives were sleek, well-designed, and highly rated by professional chefs like Gordon Ramsay, who said he loved his Henckels. However, the problem with buying a complete set of knives from The Pampered Chef was twofold.
Firstly, The Pampered Chef sells mainly to people who dislike cooking and spend lots of time looking for tips and tricks to make cooking ‚ÄúLess of a chore.‚Äù As such, their target audience likes things that look good, but they may never really put these knives to the test. And the company knows this!
The second problem is that a complete set of these knives cost about $700 in 2003. While not the $ 100,000 blades used by some sushi chefs, they were by no means cheap. They were expensive enough that they could only be mail-ordered. Even the party organizer didn‚Äôt have them on-site, so she couldn‚Äôt show them to me.
I decided to get them anyway. They felt good when I held them for the first time. Well-balanced and razor-sharp. I wasn‚Äôt disappointed with my purchase.
Those knives were not for me, and I should have realized it.
Despite being endorsed by many chefs, I hadn‚Äôt stopped to wonder if those chefs used their knives the way I did. You see, while there are many different types of knives, there are only two main knife styles. German and Japanese.
I won‚Äôt go into all the differences here, but briefly, neither is better than the other. They offer different feelings for differing styles of cutting. German knives are heavier and have thicker edges. They can be handled with strong arms and cut through root vegetables and even small bones without problem.
Japanese knives are thinner, and the steel is significantly harder than their German counterparts. Japanese knives are extremely sharp, and the harder steel keeps its edge longer. They feel much lighter in your hands, encouraging proper technique over brute force.
It became apparent that everything in the way I used knives would have benefitted from using Japanese-style knives. The Pampered Chef / Henckel knives, as the name gives away, were very much the German style. While I kept them for quite some time, they were never wholly ‚Äúmine.‚Äù
The wand chooses the wizard, Mr. Potter. It‚Äôs not always clear why.
At some point while on a business trip, I saw a knife store and meandered in. After a very short discussion with the salesperson, I was chopping celery. The knife was incredible. It felt like an extension of my hand. It was so sharp I thought it was chopping the celery all on its own. It was as if the knife had chosen me!
Yes, it was expensive, but not ridiculously so. I felt like buying the knife immediately, but it wasn‚Äôt possible since I was flying with only a carry-on the next day. I thanked the salesperson, who gave me his card and the address for their website.
I thought about that knife the entire flight home. I wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúdreaming‚Äù of getting the knife but instead asking myself if this was something I wanted. Was it the ‚Äúright‚Äù knife? How would it fit in my set?
And that‚Äôs when something finally clicked: Why would I need a set? Shouldn‚Äôt I be able to have a mixed group of knives, each ideally suited to its use?
Later that week, I emailed the salesperson and asked what he thought. While it‚Äôs impossible to judge tone of voice in an email, I really got the impression he was laughing at me. ‚ÄúWhy would you need matching knives? Are you sponsored by the company? Buy what works for you,‚Äù he wrote back.
So, after years of settling for ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù knives, I decided to splurge on one high-end knife.
This was the knife I had wanted for years, even if I wasn‚Äôt aware of it. When I started using it, I knew this knife was different. It glided through food effortlessly and required minimal maintenance. It fit perfectly in my hand and felt like it would last a lifetime. Spoiler alert ‚Äî it still looks and cuts like new!
I‚Äôve since bought a few more knives, but I ensured they were exactly what I wanted.
Recently, as I stood in my kitchen, slicing effortlessly through a pile of potatoes, a sobering realization hit me: I had spent well over $2,000 on lesser knives over the years before finally buying the ones I truly wanted. If I had just studied, waited and saved up for the right knives in the first place, I could have avoided the frustration and expense of constantly upgrading.
Want to save $2000? Buy Once, Cry Once.
Looking back, my biggest mistake was underestimating the importance of quality tools that fit my style. I thought I was saving money by starting with cheaper knives and working my way up, but in reality, I was wasting money on knives that didn‚Äôt work for me.
If I were to do it all again, here‚Äôs how it would go:
I‚Äôd use the Wiltshire wedding gift knives as long as I could, at least until I understood how to use knives and what my cutting style was.
I would save up and buy one great knife ‚Äî a chef‚Äôs knife. Great knives don‚Äôt have to be expensive. The chef‚Äôs knife I still use today is the Victorinox 9-inch Fibrox Pro Chef‚Äôs Knife. This $60 CAD knife is peculiar. It uses a softer, more German-like steel blade, but the edge is sharpened aggressively in a more Japanese style. It has a cheap-looking plastic handle, but it grips nicely and is quite ergonomic.
The Victorinox 9-inch Fibrox Pro Chef‚Äôs Knife ‚Äî image courtesy of the author.
3. I would build slowly from here, adding the knives I knew I would use and love. My next knife would be a Santoku knife. San is the Japanese word for the number three. Santoku means three virtues, emphasizing the knife‚Äôs ability to slice, cut and chop, and do this on meat, fish and vegetables (does that count as two holy trinities?). This is the knife I discovered while on a business trip, and it is still my favourite knife today.
The Miyabi 5000 FC-D 7-inch, Santoku knife ‚Äî image courtesy of the author.
4. You don‚Äôt need anything else, but in my case, there are four more knives that I would want. Firstly, a serrated blade knife for slicing bread, a pankiri b≈çch≈ç. Crusty breads with soft interiors are no match for this beauty!
The Miyabi 5000 FC-D 9.5-inch Pankiri b≈çch≈ç ‚Äî image courtesy of the author.
5. A Shotoh or paring knife is a great addition. Shotoh is roughly translated as ‚Äúlittle knife‚Äù and is perfect for working on smaller vegetables, like shallots.
The Miyabi 5000 FC-D 4.5-inch, Shotoh ‚Äî Image courtesy of the author.
6. This next knife is an absolute luxury. There is no way for me to say I needed a Nakiri knife, but after having tried it, I really wanted it. Are you looking to get through a ton of hard fruits or root veggies? This is the knife you want.
The Shun Premier (TDM0742) 5.5" Nakiri knife ‚Äî image courtesy of the author.
7. Finally, I want a good boning knife or Honesuki. Again, this is much more a want than a need, but I save tons of money by buying whole poultry or larger cuts of meat and breaking them down. At least here in Canada, I can buy a whole, large chicken for the same price as two small, boneless, skinless chicken breasts. Fifteen minutes of work saves me $25.
I can break down the chicken without a boning knife or Honesuki, but I‚Äôm doing it often enough now that it would be worth getting one. But which knife? I‚Äôll have to take another trip to a good knife shop!
Save yourself a lot of money!
Good kitchen knives are some of the most essential tools in your home. It may not seem obvious, but having a great set of knives you love and enjoy using will save you money in the long run. They make the difference between a frustrating cooking experience and a joyful one.
If you‚Äôre serious about cooking, I encourage you to save for the knives you truly want and ensure you try them before buying! It might take time, but the payoff is worth it.
While I‚Äôve learned the hard way, you can save over $2,000 by not chasing incremental upgrades. Take your time, and then look for the knives that inspire you to create culinary magic for years.
Let me know if you would like to see more about how to use kitchen knives and cutting techniques and how knowing these things can save you lots of money.
I hope everyone has a great 2025 in their kitchens.

Two Titans and Me in the Middle: A Guide to Managing Conflict
Would you like to know how I accidentally became a referee between two tech titans? Here‚Äôs how I survived that battle.
Daria Kowalski
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Product Coalition
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
13 hours ago
101
6
It
was creeping up on 10 PM ‚Äî the hour when most normal people are cocooned in blankets, savoring hot chocolate, flipping through the pages of a good book, or chuckling at the latest reality TV drama.
Me? I was nowhere near cozy.
Instead, I was trapped in a dimly lit virtual meeting room, caught between two bickering forces of nature.
If I squinted, it felt like being a kid stuck at the dinner table, except these ‚Äúparents‚Äù weren‚Äôt debating bedtime routines or allowances. They were:
Ryan, the Stakeholder Extraordinaire, was a self-proclaimed ‚Äúvisionary‚Äù who thrives on not writing things down. His disdain for documentation was matched only by his knack for conjuring big ideas ‚Äî often as scrappy proof-of-concepts no one asked for.
Charismatic as a rock star. Within five minutes of meeting him, you‚Äôd probably sign up for his cult. But give it ten minutes, and he‚Äôll transform into an ‚Äúenergy vampire,‚Äù siphoning every last ounce of your patience.
Maurice, the Software Manager, was the embodiment of meticulous precision ‚Äî polite, brilliant, and unwavering in his commitment to doing things ‚Äúthe right way,‚Äù even if it meant refactoring half the codebase before shipping the smallest feature.
Normally soft-spoken and composed, Maurice‚Äôs frustration added a cinematic flair to his tone, his accent sharpening into the ominous cadence of a classic movie villain warning, ‚ÄúThis‚Ä¶ will not‚Ä¶ end well.‚Äù
And there I was, the wide-eyed Product Owner, thinking, Is hiding under the virtual conference table an option?
‚ÄúI Did a POC in One Day‚Ä¶ Why Can‚Äôt You?‚Äù
It all started with Ryan‚Äôs unrelenting passion for a ‚Äúshiny AI feature‚Äù he was convinced would obliterate the competition.
Beaming with enthusiasm, he declared, ‚ÄúI whipped up a working prototype in a single day using ChatGPT, even though I‚Äôd never touched React before! Why can‚Äôt your team ship the final product in a month? I see the solution clearly!‚Äù
He said it like he‚Äôd just cracked the code to eternal youth.
But while Ryan was riding high on his burst of creative energy, the dev team was tangled in the real-world complexities of release processes, DevOps dependencies, and invisible constraints ‚Äî none of which magically disappeared just because ChatGPT had written some code.
Maurice, ever the perfectionist, stepped in with his trademark patience.
‚ÄúBefore we add new features,‚Äù he said carefully, ‚Äúwe need to address the‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs say creative coding decisions from last quarter. If we skip refactoring, the system might break under the new AI load.‚Äù
He wasn‚Äôt wrong. Building on a shaky foundation is like stacking bricks on quicksand ‚Äî it might look fine for a moment, but collapse is inevitable.
Ryan, however, wasn‚Äôt one to be slowed down by warnings. With a dramatic wave of his hand, as if parting the Red Sea, he dismissed Maurice‚Äôs concerns.
‚ÄúWhy worry about maybe failing? Let‚Äôs ship now!‚Äù
The Late-Night Showdown
So, we scheduled a ‚Äúconflict resolution‚Äù meeting for 10 PM ‚Äî because, clearly, nothing says ‚Äúgreat decision-making‚Äù like discussing heated topics when everyone‚Äôs running on fumes.
Five minutes in, I realized what we really needed were emotional support animals for every attendee.
Ryan kicked things off with all the flourish of a TED Talk. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the thing,‚Äù he said, leaning into the camera for dramatic effect.
‚ÄúOur competitors already launched something similar. We have to move fast. If we keep refactoring, we‚Äôll fall behind. My vision just won‚Äôt wait.‚Äù
Maurice, unimpressed, narrowed his eyes and shot back, ‚ÄúRyan, I am telling you, if we do not fix the data handling logic, our entire system could‚Ä¶ collapse.‚Äù
Cue the ominous thunderclaps. I half expected Maurice to raise a pinky to his lips and demand, ‚ÄúOne million dollars,‚Äù next.
Meanwhile, I was sitting there thinking, Somebody pass the popcorn‚Ä¶ or maybe a fire extinguisher.
As the minutes ticked by, business etiquette steadily unraveled. Ryan, usually smooth and charming, grew uncharacteristically snappy. Maurice‚Äôs accent, on the other hand, took a sinister turn, each word dripping with foreboding.
And then, as if rehearsed, they both turned to me and asked in near-perfect unison, ‚ÄúDaria, whose side are you on?‚Äù
Step 1: Hit the Pause Button
Nothing productive ever comes from two strong-willed people talking over each other in the heat of the moment. So, I did the only sensible thing I could think of:
‚ÄúTime out, guys,‚Äù I said, holding up my hands like a referee calling a foul. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all on the same team, even if it doesn‚Äôt feel that way right now. Let‚Äôs take a breath.‚Äù
Ryan let out a loud, exaggerated sigh, complete with a theatrical flourish, while Maurice, ever composed, calmly sipped what I assumed was his eighth cup of coffee for the day.
I pressed on, keeping my voice level. ‚ÄúWe all want the same thing: a successful, scalable AI product, right?‚Äù
They both nodded, though their expressions made it clear they were thinking the same thing: Sure ‚Äî but only if it‚Äôs done my way.
Step 2: Let Each Side Air It Out‚Ä¶ Without Interruption
I‚Äôd learned long ago that heated debates are rarely about the surface arguments. The ‚Äústuff‚Äù people argue over is often just the tip of the iceberg ‚Äî beneath it lies something deeper, driving their frustration.
For Ryan, it was the fear of missing the hype train. He was convinced that if we didn‚Äôt launch our AI features immediately, we‚Äôd be old news, overshadowed by competitors.
To him, time spent refactoring code was time wasted ‚Äî a delay that threatened his vision of being the bold innovator.
For Maurice, it was the fear of everything crashing down. He knew that one bug buried in a messy codebase could snowball into a catastrophic failure.
In his eyes, quick ‚Äúband-aid‚Äù solutions weren‚Äôt just shortcuts ‚Äî they were ticking time bombs waiting to blow up in our faces.
By calling out these underlying fears directly, I managed to deflate some of the tension in the room. After all, it‚Äôs much harder to stay combative when someone names the real concern behind your frustration.
Step 3: Translate the Emotional Subtext
It hit me. Ryan wasn‚Äôt just excited ‚Äî he was terrified. The thought of being outpaced in the market consumed him. To Ryan, the POC wasn‚Äôt just a prototype. It was a magic bullet ‚Äî a flashy win to impress the higher-ups and prove how innovative we were.
Maurice, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt simply ‚Äúbeing stubborn.‚Äù He genuinely cared about the system‚Äôs long-term health and the sanity of his dev team. He saw rushed decisions as an open invitation for chaos.
So, I cut to the chase and asked them both, point-blank. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the worst that could happen if we do it your way?‚Äù
Ryan conceded that launching with half-baked code could lead to issues, but he was willing to take that risk in the name of speed.
Maurice countered with a grim reality check ‚Äî one overlooked memory leak could crash the system entirely when scaled.
Now we were getting somewhere ‚Äî a face-off between the fear of losing time and the fear of losing the product altogether.
Step 4: Propose a ‚ÄúMiddle Path‚Äù (While Keeping a Sense of Humor)
When you can‚Äôt fully commit to either side‚Äôs approach, the best option is to carve out a middle ground. Think of it like dividing chores between siblings ‚Äî one scrubs the kitchen, the other vacuums the living room. Nobody‚Äôs thrilled, but at least the house doesn‚Äôt fall into chaos.
To ease the tension, I lightened the mood with a quick joke: ‚ÄúI know ChatGPT is amazing, but it can‚Äôt fix our entire codebase and run our production environment for us‚Ä¶ yet. Maybe give it a year?‚Äù
That drew a few chuckles ‚Äî or at least some half-smiles ‚Äî which was enough to reset the tone.
Then, I outlined a solution that addressed both Ryan‚Äôs urgency and Maurice‚Äôs caution:
Short-Term Stabilization: Dedicate two weeks to tackling the top three riskiest ‚Äúhackiest hacks‚Äù in the code. For example, we focused on a poorly optimized data-handling script that threatened to bottleneck performance and patched a memory leak in the AI‚Äôs training module. These quick wins ensured the foundation could handle the new feature without collapsing.
Parallel POC Development: Form a small tiger team ‚Äî one developer and Ryan as the stakeholder ‚Äî to refine the POC without touching the production environment. This allowed Ryan to see progress on his shiny feature while keeping the main codebase stable.
Milestone Checkpoint: Set a hard deadline at the two-week mark to evaluate progress. If the refactor was solid, we‚Äôd proceed to integrate the AI feature. If not, we‚Äôd scale back its scope ‚Äî perhaps launching it as a beta feature instead of rolling it out platform-wide.
This approach gave both sides a tangible path forward, balancing speed with stability.
Step 5: Assign Clear Ownership and Deadlines
To avoid the classic ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs on first?‚Äù fiasco:
Ryan: Document detailed specs for the shiny AI feature, plus realistic acceptance criteria (not just ‚Äúit‚Äôs in my head‚Äù).
Maurice: Oversee the critical refactor, focusing on the scariest bits first.
Me: Keep everyone honest on timelines, ensuring no magical 24-hour illusions from ‚ÄúChatGPT land.‚Äù
And yes, we wrote it all down, because a handshake at 10 PM is worthless if people forget it by 9 AM.
Step 6: Follow Up, Even When It‚Äôs Painfully Late
By 11 PM, we finally had a plan. I felt like I‚Äôd just crossed the finish line of a triathlon ‚Äî mentally drained but relieved. Of course, the real marathon was still ahead: implementing that plan.
Right after the meeting, I fired off a quick summary to ensure everyone was aligned:
What we decided: Two weeks for a partial refactor + parallel POC.
Who‚Äôs responsible: Names and tasks clearly assigned.
When we check in again: Tentative date and time for the next meeting.
I wrapped it up with a quick note of appreciation:
‚ÄúThanks, everyone, for staying up late to work through this. I‚Äôm confident we can tackle the refactor and deliver a stable feature. Let‚Äôs do this!‚Äù
Corny? Maybe. But it‚Äôs amazing what a little gratitude can do.
It helps soften the tension so no one wakes up the next morning thinking, Did we just have a fight?
Did the Plan Actually Work?
A few weeks later, the results were in:
The dev team had cleaned up the worst of the spaghetti code, ensuring the AI module wouldn‚Äôt bring the entire system crashing down under scale.
Meanwhile, Ryan got his ‚Äúshiny feature‚Äù polished ‚Äî essentially the POC with stronger architecture and far fewer ChatGPT-coded mysteries lurking in the background.
And me? I finally stopped feeling like a human shield caught in the crossfire between two warring factions ‚Äî at least for a little while.
Of course, in the world of AI projects, conflict is never truly over. There‚Äôs always another storm brewing on the horizon.
But that night taught me a valuable lesson:
When unstoppable enthusiasm collides with immovable caution, the best place to stand is right in the middle ‚Äî guiding both sides toward a realistic, workable compromise.
If You‚Äôre Ever the ‚ÄòKid‚Äô Caught in a Conflict
1. Stay Neutral (at Least at First)
Don‚Äôt immediately side with one party. Hear them both out to show you‚Äôre genuinely trying to find a balanced approach.
2. Identify the Core Fear or Motivation
Is it market competition? Technical debt? Budget constraints? People often argue over the details, but the real conflict stems from deeper anxieties.
3. Propose a Third Path
Look for partial compromises or phased approaches. Can you break big tasks into sprints? Can you test a quick prototype in a safe environment?
4. Bring Humor‚Ä¶ Carefully
A light joke can diffuse tension, but don‚Äôt downplay the seriousness of the conflict. If someone‚Äôs borderline furious, a random joke might feel dismissive. Time it right.
5. Document Agreements
A quick follow-up email or Slack message ensures no one ‚Äúforgets‚Äù what was decided in the heat of the moment.
Looking back, I wish I‚Äôd known how normal conflict is in any high-stakes project. People who care passionately about results will butt heads ‚Äî that‚Äôs the price of ambition.
The key is channeling that energy into a solution rather than a stand-off. In conflict resolution terms, you‚Äôre helping each side see the other‚Äôs ‚Äúinterests, not positions.‚Äù
Interests are deeper motivations (like not wanting the product to fail).
Positions are the surface arguments (like ‚ÄúWe need this done in a week‚Äù).
Focus on shared interests, and you‚Äôll often find a sweet spot for compromise.
Your Turn. What‚Äôs Your Wildest War Story?
Ever found yourself caught between a ‚ÄúShip It Now!‚Äù stakeholder and a ‚ÄúWait, We‚Äôll All Die!‚Äù team lead? It‚Äôs like being the rope in an especially intense game of corporate tug-of-war.
So, how did you keep the project ‚Äî and your sanity ‚Äî from unraveling? Share your best (or worst) conflict resolution stories below. We‚Äôre all ears (and popcorn at the ready).
Because let‚Äôs be real ‚Äî those late-night meetings can feel like a mix between a horror movie and a reality show.
But with the right mix of strategy, empathy, and just the right amount of humor, they can also become the kind of war stories you laugh about later.
So, fellow conflict wranglers, good luck out there.
Here‚Äôs to keeping the peace, one tense meeting at a time!
