Wildlife Photography Techniques and Equipment
A beginner‚Äôs experience in Costa Rica
Michael Alford
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Live View
¬∑
10 min read
¬∑
12 hours ago
94
4
I‚Äôve never considered myself a wildlife photographer. Never aspired to it. The equipment seemed too specialized and expensive, and the techniques too complex. Wildlife photography required more dedication and investment than I felt I could muster.
After a week at a workshop in Costa Rica with Derrick Story and Rob Knight, however, I‚Äôve changed my attitude. Yes, this was billed as primarily a wildlife excursion, but the recommended equipment didn‚Äôt seem daunting: (1) a capable general-purpose camera, (2) a long telephoto lens, (3) a close-up (macro) lens, and (4) some sort of light for night photography, preferably a small LED panel rather than a flash. I had all that.
About half the participants showed up with what I brought: Micro Four Thirds (MFT) equipment. My OM-Systems OM-1 turned out to be the camera of choice for this part of the group. At roughly half the price of equivalent full-frame cameras, it has more useful functionality for wildlife than most full-frames. It is the high end of MFT.
MFT cameras have small sensors, which are not only relatively inexpensive, they‚Äôre great for telephoto work. Every lens gives you twice the magnification you would get on a full-frame camera. A 150mm lens on MFT is the same as a 300mm lens on a considerably more expensive Sony, Canon, or Nikon full-frame.
The OM-1 body, the Olympus 1.4x teleconverter, and the 40‚Äì150 mm f/2.8 Olympus zoom, all of which I already owned.
Here‚Äôs an example of what this lens can do even without a tele-converter with birds seen from the water. (150mm on MFT is a six-times magnification.)
A juvenile Frigate bird lands on top of a tree near the shore. Olympus 40‚Äì150 at 130mm, f/4.5, 1/1000 sec, ISO 200.
MFT also excels at macro photography, since the small sensor also means more depth of field. When you are photographing a 1-inch tree frog, you are in great shape. My 60mm macro was excellent here, though I found that, in a pinch, I could have come without it. My extremely versatile 12‚Äì100mm zoom lens ‚Äî the one that is on my camera about 90% of the time ‚Äî focuses down to a little less than 6 inches.
The 60mm Macro lens (left) will reach up to 1:1 magnification, but I never got close enough for that. I could have made do with the 12‚Äì100mm (right), which magnifies to about 1:3.
The last necessary part of the kit (and the least expensive) was a light for night photography. I already had a small LED panel ($50-$100). I could have hand-held that, but Rob recommended a versatile little extension arm and Arca Swiss clamp: total, $40. These were the only pieces of equipment I bought especially for the trip. I attached them with a generic L-bracket.
The close-up configuration many of us used: a camera with amacro lens and an LED panel attached to an extension arm.
Using the LED on an extension arm is perfect for photographing Costa Rica‚Äôs famous tree frogs. The light can come from the side, not straight on.
Tree frog, taken with the 60mm macro and the LED panel; f/2.8, 1/200 sec., ISO 800
The 60mm macro is wonderfully sharp and provides enough reach to stay far enough away to not alarm the subject. Continuous light is less stressful on the animals than using a flash.
At night at the Villa Blanca Nature Reserve. Some had camera-mounted lights, but the extension arm (upper right) gives more flexibility and control.
Additional equipment included, for me, an extra camera body (a small Olympus EM-5iii), two short prime lenses for street photography (a 15mm f/1.7 and 25mm f/1.4), a monopod, and a Peak Design PROpad belt clip (invaluable). Derrick and Rob had suggested a monopod or a tripod, and some brought both.
I used my monopod at the beginning, but could have done without it. These days, most cameras have internal image stabilization, and the Olympus/OM-Systems‚Äô stabilization is particularly good. I put the 12‚Äì100mm on the extra body and clipped it to my belt. It was extremely convenient. The primes were nice to have and tiny to pack, but I could have done without them too.
I photographed this butterfly using the Olympus 12‚Äì100mm lens at 100mm, f/4.5, 1/3200 sec., ISO 200.
The only things left to add were camera bags ‚Äî in my case, a full-size Shimoda backpack to haul everything down there, and a small Mindshift sling to carry selected gear in the field. Everyone brought a similar pair.
My point is that most amateur enthusiasts already have all the gear they need for a trip like this, or at least most of it. What separates the wildlife photographer from the rest of us mortals turns out not to be the equipment, it‚Äôs technique. That‚Äôs what I learned in Costa Rica.
As I recounted in a previous article, our first day out was a frustrating disappointment. I made every mistake in the book. My pictures were blurry and poorly exposed.
My preconceptions kicked in: I should have had a Sony or a Nikon or a Canon with a multi-thousand-dollar lens.
Which was wrong, of course. The truth was, I didn‚Äôt know how to use the equipment I had. By the second day, I was shooting adequately, but it took the entire week to learn the following lessons.
Lesson 1: Set up your programmable buttons and custom modes
Wildlife photographers must respond instantly to surprise events and changing conditions ‚Äî a rare bird landing nearby, the sun suddenly emerging from behind a cloud.
Today‚Äôs cameras are highly programmable. You can assign buttons to any function you want. You can program Custom Modes that instantly switch many functions at once, such as for rapid continuous fire, high dynamic range (HDR) multiple exposures, focus stacking sequences, or whatever other specialty your camera provides. Each Custom Mode includes the whole suite of settings you want to use ‚Äî ISO, shutter speed, even a preferred color profile, it that‚Äôs appropriate.
I had tried a few custom settings before, but never with an overall plan.
Well, now was the time. For assigning a function to a button, there is a place in the menus where you select a button and then see all the functions you can assign to it. Just pick one and set it to the function you need. For a Custom Mode, set the camera up for what you want, then use the menu to select a Custom Mode slot (C1, C2, C3, etc.) and click ‚ÄúAssign.‚Äù From then on, turning the dial to a C-Mode will instantly change everything to your choices for that mode.
I programmed two buttons on the front to turn Face Recognition and Subject Recognition (Bird, Animal, Bicycle, etc.) on and off. I programmed a button on top for the OM-1‚Äôs Live Neutral Density filter. This allows you, for instance, to blur water in a flowing stream. You don‚Äôt have to take a set of physical ND filters with you.
Then the Custom Modes. For me it was:
C1: Rapid Continuous. ISO at 800, shutter at 1/500, continuous shooting at 10 frames per second.
C2: High Dynamic Range: 3 exposures at +/- 2 EV (used for the Butterfly above)
C3: Focus Stacking: 10 images at close focus increments for macro shots
C4: Pro Capture: the OM-1, like some other cameras, can continuously take pictures before you press the shutter so that you don‚Äôt miss a bird leaping into the air. It saves the last half-second or so from before the shutter press. It also tends to add dozens of extra frames to your catalog. It turned out I didn‚Äôt use this feature.
The essence here is to carefully choose your settings, write them down so you don‚Äôt forget, and practice. It‚Äôs not hard, and it‚Äôs worth it. But practice.
Lesson 2: Don‚Äôt be afraid of high ISOs
Before coming to Costa Rica, I was deathly afraid of high ISOs, especially on small-sensor MFT cameras, which are not supposed to handle noise well. But as both Derrick and Rob emphasized, you can fix noise, but you can‚Äôt sharpen a blur.
Before I left, my AUTO-ISO setting peaked at 1600 ISO. By day three, I was freely using 6400, 8000, even 12800. Today‚Äôs processing allows you to eliminate most noise and sharpen the image using AI.
Left: Spectacle owl.
Upper right: Original image: 300mm lens (150mm +2x teleconverter); f/5.6, 1/800 sec., 3200 ISO
Lower right: Image as processed with noise reduction (Lightroom Classic) and AI sharpening (Topaz Photo AI)
Another lesson: don‚Äôt use AUTO-ISO, even if the high end of the range is one of those ultra settings. Pick what the lighting conditions need, then change if the light changes. You get more consistent results. More on this in Lesson 4.
Lesson 3: Back-button focus
Back-button focus is standard for most wildlife photographers. It‚Äôs a huge change if you are used to auto-focusing with a half-press of the shutter, as 99% of all photographers do. But it‚Äôs worth it for anything with fast action, like wildlife or sports.
To set it up, you disable the shutter half-press (that already made me nervous), then set a button on the back of the camera to turn on auto-focus. In the past, you often had to reuse a button already set for another purpose, losing whatever that other button happened to do. With the OM-1 and many recent cameras, there is a dedicated button labeled ‚ÄúAF On‚Äù or equivalent.
So: press and release the AF On button, and it locks focus on your selected point. Hold the button down and you have continuous focus until you release it.
All I can say is that I‚Äôve set my OM-1 for BBF and I‚Äôm practicing. For most people, it‚Äôs all or nothing. But they say that once you learn, you never go back. Derrick maintains he can switch back and forth. I‚Äôll see what works for me.
The advantage? Predictability and speed. Imagine you‚Äôre waiting for a bird to land on a branch. You focus on the branch and wait. When the bird arrives, click. If you use shutter-half-press, when the bird finally lands and you press the shutter, the camera may jump unpredictably to the background or shift focus to a closer object, like a stray branch. You miss the shot. With BBF, you can be confident about where the focus will be.
In fact, the minority in our group who do use BBF swear by it. I‚Äôm willing to be inducted into the cognoscenti. I will practice. They say it takes two weeks before it‚Äôs natural.
TIP: If you lend your camera to friend, let them know how it‚Äôs set up or they will think the focus is broken.
Lesson 4: All-manual photography
This is seriously hardcore. Rob taught me the technique while we were shooting hummingbirds on our last morning.
First, you set the PASM dial to M, which I have virtually never used before. Then you switch ISO to a fixed setting, not AUTO-ISO, which I had been using almost all the time.
The front camera dial changes aperture, the rear changes shutter speed (or whichever way you want it). A conveniently-located ISO button lets you set the ISO, which you adjust as the light changes.
A variation is to leave the ISO on AUTO-ISO: pick a fixed aperture and shutter speed, and let the ISO float to adjust exposure. They say that‚Äôs useful for street photography.
It was all baffling at first. Nothing made sense. Suddenly, the camera I‚Äôd used for two years was unfamiliar. I was all thumbs. What I saw in the viewfinder might as well have been a fighter pilot‚Äôs heads-up display.
But after half an hour, I was elated. For the rest of the day, I felt like I had been given the inner secrets of the guru. It was liberating.
Full manual mode gives you maximum awareness. For the first time, I was always aware of the ISO and shutter speed I was using. Before, using Aperture Priority, I was aware of the f-stop but nothing else. Many a blurry image followed.
Using back button focus and manual mode on those tiny hummingbirds, I got my best photos of the entire trip. It was like I had just gotten the knack of juggling‚Äî the complexity suddenly made sense. These pictures were partly luck, but a lot was thanks to what I had just been taught.
My two best shots of the week came on the last morning, the day I started using all manual operation.
Final thoughts
I can‚Äôt be sure that I will succeed with lessons 3 and 4. I hope and intend to use both for my regular photography. Lessons 1 and 2 are safely under my belt.
This workshop has been an intense learning experience. Good teachers make all the difference. Rob is the expert wildlife photographer. Derrick helps you recognize and enhance the best of what you have. I am lucky to have worked with them both.
Wildlife photography seemed like a black art before Costa Rica. Now that I‚Äôve learned some of the essential secrets, it has lost much of its mystery. But knowing what it entails, I am all the more in awe of those who have mastered it.

Photographers at Work
Field Report: Costa Rica
Michael Alford
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Live View
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
Jan 14, 2025
541
12
Serious amateur photographers shoot pictures in three situations: by themselves, on vacation, or in a class or workshop. Or so says Derrick Story, co-leader of a workshop for ten such serious photographers in the wilds of Costa Rica. And he‚Äôs pretty much right.
Photographing by oneself provides complete autonomy, to be sure. But no feedback. You are on your own to learn from your mistakes, assuming you have that self-awareness. Option two, photographing on vacation, also means no feedback, but it means far less autonomy in addition. In fact, it usually comes with negotiations, apologies, and considerable frustration. I know that firsthand.
Photography in a workshop, however, lets you indulge your obsessions and share them, at maximum geekiness, with your geeky peers. Others can diagnose and correct your mistakes. You may even have the pleasure of correcting someone else‚Äôs.
And that is where I find myself tonight, in Derrick‚Äôs workshop on top of a mountain, surrounded by fog, having just returned from a walk in the mist to encounter tree frogs, spiders, lizards, and snakes. Our little band has wandered through the mud carrying thousands of dollars of gear, lighting up the night with searchlights and LED panels like hovering UFOs. We swarmed around each hapless tree frog as if it were one of the crown jewels of England.
A group of us in pursuit of frogs at the Villa Blanco, Costa Rica
Honestly, I‚Äôd prefer to be here than in the Tower of London surrounded by a thousand other tourists, all gawking at jewels in glass cases under the stare of surveillance cameras.
The next stop was the bar and dinner. No spouses or significant others can attend these workshops unless they are fellow photographers. It‚Äôs all shop talk and reminiscences about cameras we‚Äôve owned, places we‚Äôve been, and famous photographers we‚Äôve bumped into. One Mai Tai leads to another.
The ten of us met Derrick and Rob Knight, our other co-instructor, in San Jose, Costa Rica. We had flown from all parts of the U.S., most of us escaping the Arctic snowstorm that was blanketing most of the country. Introductions and instructions followed. We all knew at least two or three of our companions already, so the group settled in easily.
Motives and expectations
Over the next few days, I asked the members what motivated them to come. A few had specific goals, such as learning how to do macro photography or follow birds in flight. But most had no intentions other than to be there ‚Äî to see Costa Rica and be with this group. It was one variation or another of Derrick‚Äôs explanation of the benefits of workshops. This was an opportunity to pursue the craft ‚Äî and perhaps the art ‚Äî of photography with others of like mind.
That was also my rationale. Costa Rica itself was the main attraction. I was curious about this environment and especially curious about how I would photograph it. Each workshop I‚Äôve attended has been different ‚Äî different locations, different eco-systems. Some, like the Sedona desert, seemed familiar and direct. Others, like the redwood forest, were photographic conundrums: visually fantastic, but maddening to photograph.
I suspected Costa Rica would fall into the second category, and sometimes it did.
The road from San Jose
Our first day was our transit from city to country. On the way to the Villa Lapas, a beautiful but simple retreat in the heart of the forest, we passed the Crocodile River. True to its name, there were any number of crocs lazing on the muddy banks exposed by low tide near the river‚Äôs mouth. It was the right time to be there. All you had to do was walk onto the sidewalks of the bridge and look down.
Left: Lauren, Derrick, and Trishia on the bridge
Right: The crocodiles below
At the near end of the bridge was the car park, a restaurant, and various souvenir stands. All, of course, crocodile-themed. Teeth, jaws, cartoons, and even jewelry made of fangs. We joined local tourist families and foreigners with backpacks on the bridge looking down.
I don‚Äôt know yet what our group came away with photographically. I do know that many were zooming down with long lenses to get close-ups of eyes and teeth. Crocodiles cool themselves by opening their mouths, so the display was impressive. I was more interested, however, in the patterns of their bodies on the little islands of mud exposed by the tide. The aerial view was a collage of water, mud, and crocodile.
I saw then that the group was divided into two points of view. Those who want to collect the animals individually, in all their beauty and detail. And those who, like me, are more interested in the animals in context ‚Äî animals seen in relation to the landscape.
A most frustrating day
Our first whole day of photography was endlessly frustrating, at least for me. We were in pursuit of small birds, black bats hiding in holes, and howler monkeys high in the branches. My camera was actually pretty good at this, had I known how to use it properly. But I didn‚Äôt. Those of us with the highest-end gear had a telling advantage, and the ones who had it knew how to use it.
Rob and Eric with their long telephotos. I didn‚Äôt realize what a difference this equipment could make, but ultimately, I did pretty well with what I brought ‚Äî an OM-1 camera with a lens with about 2/3 the power of these two.
Cameras built for wildlife photography are like cars built for the Indianapolis 500. They don‚Äôt do you much good on the street but put them on a track and‚Ä¶zowie. Such as cameras with computerized tracking that can pick out a bug in a pile of twigs and then follow it as it scutters off. Sensors and lenses that can separate a monkey‚Äôs eyelashes at 50 paces. Stuff like that.
So the Zen masters in our group had a field day. They zeroed in on tiny rare birds hopping around behind bushes 100 feet away. They could render the texture of a monkey‚Äôs fur in the treetops.
That first day, all I got were grainy, out-of-focus shots of the tail feathers of said rare birds sticking out from behind trees. My howler monkeys were fuzzy black blobs. My bats were a disaster.
Small birds sometimes play near the forest surface. This was the best I could do on my first day ‚Äî hardly worth a 2,000 mile flight. But I got better.
Back at the lab
We had a lab session that afternoon. Derrick‚Äôs workshops always include them. That‚Äôs when we sit around a table with our laptops to process the day‚Äôs crop of Raw files. Derrick and Rob are both experts in this craft. Both have good eyes for composition and useful corrections. And, of course, we kibitz with each other too. On the whole, labs are a major thing I come to workshops for.
So, as I had little or nothing worth working on, I did what any self-respecting photographer would do: I blamed my equipment. If only I had the set-up that so-and-so uses. That would have made all the difference.
In reality, it was my ignorance of how to set things up, how to use what I had, and how to keep track of the details as conditions changed. Great equipment helps, but user error torpedoes even the best.
All I can say about this picture is that now I‚Äôve seen a howler monkey in the wild. Gear designed for this type of shot can focus in on the monkey‚Äôs eyes. I did better with my equipment as I learned more, especially after I decided not to attempt more than I could handle.
Nightstalking
Before I came here, I didn‚Äôt know that those beautiful tropical tree frogs are basically nocturnal. That‚Äôs why you always see their pictures against dramatic black backgrounds. And I didn‚Äôt know that most of them are only about the size of a Brazil nut.
So when Rob said over dinner that we could go out to get pictures of tree frogs, I had no idea what that meant. In fact, all we had to do was walk out of the restaurant and over to the decorative ponds by the reception area. Armed with macro lenses and small LED light panels, it was pretty much like finding a diamond ring on the show floor at Tiffany‚Äôs ‚Äî essentially, drop-dead easy.
That is what‚Äôs amazing about this country. The exotic is all around. All you need to do is look around.
There is a tree frog in the bushes next to Villa Lapas's reception area. My camera is perfectly suited for this type of shot, but a macro (close-up) lens is essential.
At our current location, high in the cloud forest, our night explorations have been more dramatic and fruitful. The property is an eco-reserve, and our guides are resident naturalists. Here‚Äôs where we found the famous red-eyed tree frog ‚Äî mascot of the rain forest ‚Äî posing for the camera. It‚Äôs three times the size of its brethren and garishly colored in deep blue, brilliant scarlet, and green. For several of us, photographing one was the Holy Grail of the trip. And here we were with several days to go.
A red-eyed tree frog (Agalychnis callidryas) in the forest at Villa Blanca. Honesty, this is about the worst picture of a red-eyed tree frog I‚Äôve ever seen, but at least it is my own.
Some very good days
After the frustrations of day one, our other days more than made up for it.
Our second-day destination was the Rio Grande de Tarcolas ‚Äî the same ‚ÄúCrocodile River‚Äù we had seen from the bridge but just another few miles downstream. The twelve of us set out on a flat-bottom boat big enough for 75, so we could wander at will.
There were a number of crocs to be seen, mostly lying on the muddy shore. They were as large as the ones we saw from the bridge. Seeing them from the side, lying on the shore in the distance, was nothing like the aerial view from the bridge. We saw one huge one in the water, but just the top of the snout.
Tricia, Derrick, and Linda shooting from the comfort of our riverboat
The birds were the drama. Thousands of them. Egrets, hawks, all sorts of local birds whose names I did not learn, and pelicans. Hundreds of them swooping in sinuous lines over the water, standing in formation on logs, or perching at the tops right at the water‚Äôs edge.
Two frigate birds argue in the treetops along the shore. On the left is a juvenile, on the right a mature male.
At various times, every bird in the area would jump into the sky and swarm together en masse. This was what I had come for ‚Äî the animals in context, seen against their environment rather than singly in separate picture frames.
Lab that day was fun for me.
The cloud forest
The days have been busy, filled with more experiences than it‚Äôs possible to recount here. But in brief, we left the Pacific coast and drove north into the hills toward San Ramon. Here we arrived at the Villa Blanca, an ecological preserve and vacation retreat far up in the cloud forest.
This area lies on the continental divide, with the cool winds of the Pacific encountering the warm air of the Caribbean. Despite its relatively low altitude (3700 feet), it is high enough for clouds to blanket it frequently, especially now, in January.
The landscape is rolling hills with alternating patches of farmland and forest.
The view from the road leading to Villa Blanca
Parcels of land are separated by ‚Äúliving fences,‚Äù stakes cut from trees and driven into the ground connected by barbed wire. The stakes quickly root and sprout little sprigs of green on top. They are quick and easy to put up and good for the land. The roots put down by the stakes help stabilize the soil. They last longer than regular wooden fences because they don‚Äôt rot‚Äîthey actually self-heal.
Our group photographing along a stretch of living fence bordering a field. Note the sprouting leaves at the top of each stake.
With Villa Blanca as a base, we have gone north to La Fortuna, with its remarkable ecological parks.
A basilisk or‚ÄúJesus Lizard,‚Äù so named because of its ability to run across the water. We encountered this one along a path at the Danaus Ecocenter near La Fortuna.
There will be more
There is more to come, including the final presentations each of us must give to the rest of the group. We must pick six pictures out of the thousands we have taken here. These will be chosen to represent not just our best work, but what we will take away from our stay here. I have not begun to pick my six yet ‚Äî there are simply too many choices, from too many entirely different encounters with nature.
The gardens of Villa Blanca at night. They really look primeval.
All photographs copyright by the author.

I‚Äôm a Professional Editor and These Phrases Tell Me You Used ChatGPT
AI chatbots were trained on novice writing, and it shows
Maria Cassano
¬∑
Follow
Published in
The Writing Cooperative
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Jan 3, 2025
11.9K
275
Photo by Viralyft on Unsplash
Once upon a time, I was the editor-in-chief of a corrupt publication.
I didn‚Äôt know it when I took the job, but within days of starting my new role, the secrets began pouring out: The product review articles were fake, the CEO didn‚Äôt care that his business practices were illegal, and the writers were all using ChatGPT.
In my opinion, large language models like ChatGPT are not inherently evil.
AI can be an incredible tool for writers
I use it myself to brainstorm ideas, enhance clarity, streamline formatting, and polish my writing. It‚Äôs also a sanity-saver when I can‚Äôt think of a particular word. (Pro-tip: Write your sentence, use an underscore as a placeholder, and ask ChatGPT to fill in the blank with the correct term.)
That said, there‚Äôs a huge difference between using AI as a supplement and abusing it to churn out content. The former boosts quality and efficiency. The latter insults the intelligence of your reader and causes your reputation to plummet.
The writers on my newly acquired team were using AI to generate entire articles, and it was painfully obvious.
Their content was repetitive, boring, and poorly written, not to mention factually incorrect.
Because AI wants to answer your prompt but may not have the necessary data to do so, chatbots often produce ‚Äúhallucinations,‚Äù or information that‚Äôs nonsensical and inaccurate. They may pull quotes, stats, or ideas out of thin air, and unless you fact-check your work, you‚Äôll never know it.
Misinformation was the first red flag, but AI-generated content also contains the same phrases over and over again.
These phrases make it extremely obvious that you used ChatGPT
‚ÄúTreasure trove‚Äù
‚ÄúIntricate tapestry‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to note that‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs essential to consider‚Äù
‚ÄúWhile navigating the complexities of‚Äù
‚ÄúA testament to‚Äù
‚ÄúFurthermore‚Äù
‚ÄúConsequently‚Äù
‚ÄúIn the world of‚Äù
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs delve into‚Äù
‚ÄúLook no further than‚Äù
‚ÄúWhether you‚Äôre‚Ä¶ or‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúA plethora of‚Äù
‚ÄúIn conclusion‚Äù
What do most of these phrases have in common?
They‚Äôre low-effort transition phrases that don‚Äôt mean much of anything. They‚Äôre fluff. Place-holders. Wasted word-count. Bad writing.
But why would ChatGPT spit out bad writing if language is supposed to be its specialty?
Large language models like ChatGPT are primarily trained on publically available text from the internet. Yes, that includes some good writing ‚Äî but for every high-quality piece, you‚Äôll find hundreds of generic listicles, crappy blog posts, spammy articles, keyword-stuffed nonsense, and amateur essays with no views.
In other words, ChatGPT learned how to write by studying content from novice writers.
Real writers do use the above phrases
But that doesn‚Äôt mean they make for good writing.
In fact, if you removed those phrases entirely, most of your sentences wouldn‚Äôt lose any meaning. But it would result in a clearer, more concise, and more confident article.
Beginners believe that fancy, wordy language impresses readers. Professionals know that writing is a form of communication, and communication should be as straightforward as possible.
A few of these phrases won‚Äôt make or break your work, but when most of them are present in the same article, it tells your editor two things: You used ChatGPT as a shortcut (not a springboard), and you have no interest in mastering your craft as a writer.
As for me?
I got fired from that corrupt publication because I refused to let AI replace passionate, competent writers, and I wear that job termination like a badge of honor.
I just signed with a literary agent to represent my memoir, ‚ÄúNumb, Party of One‚Äù ‚Äî check it out at www.mariacassano.com/numb.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

Would I Still Have Been Fired if I Were a Man?
Science says no, probably not

¬∑

Photo by MART PRODUCTION
In October of 2022, a small publication recruited me to be their editor-in-chief. I accepted the role, excited to share my decade of e-commerce experience and lead my third team of writers ‚Äî but by week one, I had already realized how much fuckery was afoot.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not using affiliate disclaimers, which is technically illegal,‚Äù I told the two male CEOs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre also trying to pass off paid articles as honest reviews, which could get you sued, and I‚Äôm pretty sure your writers are using ChatGPT.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not too worried about the legality of it,‚Äù the stubborn one said.
‚ÄúOkay, but I am. You hired me to fix it and now my name‚Äôs on this project. My reputation is on the line.‚Äù
A few months later, after fighting tooth and nail to do things morally and legally, I was ‚Äúlet go‚Äù so they could ‚Äúredirect my salary into hiring a [male] growth specialist.‚Äù
The old me would‚Äôve had an existential crisis. The new me hung up the phone, breathed a sigh of relief, and pumped my fist in the air Breakfast-Club style.
Thanks to years of extensive trauma therapy, I was no longer the complacent woman who stayed quiet to make everyone else comfortable. I did what I was hired to do, and now it wasn‚Äôt my problem anymore. But the question remained:
If I was a man, would they have listened to me instead of firing me?
I‚Äôm not sure. Short of quantum-jumping to an alternate reality where I have a penis, there‚Äôs no way of knowing ‚Äî but anecdotally and scientifically speaking, it seems probable.
Women are all too familiar with the experience of saying something, being ignored, hearing a man say the same thing, and then watching with shock and incredulity as everyone suddenly agrees. Sometimes, it‚Äôs so glaringly obvious that other men notice it, too.
Robert K Starr recently told me about the time his ex-wife was in the hospital: Although she was the one feeling and expressing her own symptoms in her own body, the doctor only sprung into action after Robert reiterated what his ex-wife had said. Then he experienced the same thing again, this time with complete strangers, when a belligerent man at Petco wouldn‚Äôt leave a female technician alone until Robert stepped in.
The evidence isn‚Äôt just anecdotal, either.
Science proves that people don‚Äôt listen to women.
According to a 2020 study in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, men are more likely than women to be considered ‚Äúbrilliant‚Äù solely due to their gender.
In another study, researchers played audio recordings of both men and women voicing ideas for improving business processes. The men were perceived as knowledgeable, high-status leaders, while the women received no increase in credibility.
From farming villages in Malawi to the United States Senate, people simply pay less attention when women speak ‚Äî even when they‚Äôre more qualified than the men around them. But in my experience, men aren‚Äôt just dismissive when I speak up‚Ä¶
Sometimes, they‚Äôre downright threatened.
When I reiterated that those marketing tactics were illegal and we should stop using them, that CEO became defensive and irritated.
When I set clear-cut boundaries with men I didn‚Äôt want to date, some of them got offended and aggressive before resorting to harassment.
When I wrote about my honest, first-hand experiences as a woman, men commented that I was a ‚Äúbitter man-hater‚Äù who was fueling the ‚Äúgender communist cult that is feminism.‚Äù (???)
And yet again, science validates my experiences.
A study from the Journal of Social Issues found that women‚Äôs ascent up the ladder of success is often hindered by a descriptive and prescriptive bias caused by gender expectations.
Translation: Society expects women to act a certain way, and when they don‚Äôt, people dislike them because of it.
Women are expected to be warm, nurturing, and soft-spoken ‚Äî so when we‚Äôre direct, assertive, and confident (qualities often associated with leadership), we‚Äôre perceived as ‚Äúunfeminine‚Äù and ‚Äúbitchy.‚Äù As a result, we can either remain agreeable at the bottom, or claw our way to the top in exchange for our likability.
But why are powerful women seen as such a threat?
Because women are expected to ease other people‚Äôs discomfort ‚Äî
Not add to it with logic, honesty, criticism, and boundaries.
We litter our text messages and emails with smiley faces and exclamation points, so people don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre angry.
We start sentences with ‚ÄúSorry‚Ä¶‚Äù and end them with ‚Äú‚Ä¶but that‚Äôs just what I think,‚Äù so we don‚Äôt ruffle any feathers with our confidence.
We awkwardly smile when someone says something inappropriate, so we‚Äôre not responsible for disrupting the peace.
We downplay our achievements so we seem humble and we avoid negotiations so we don‚Äôt come across as argumentative.
Personally, I‚Äôm done with it. All of it. I‚Äôm no longer concerned that people will dislike me for being the most powerful version of myself I can be.
When that same company published fake review articles under my name long after I‚Äôd left, I wrote them an e-mail ‚Äî not as a courtesy, but as a paper trail. And guess what? It didn‚Äôt contain one single fucking exclamation point.

Relearning Programming to Ride the Coming Quantum Tsunami
Leaving behind the old way of thinking about programming
Jose Crespo, PhD
¬∑
Follow
Published in
AI Advances
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
1 day ago
159
Image Created by the Author with Stable Diffusion Image Generator
The Call of Quantum: Bye Bye, Von Neumann?
The golden days of our beloved von Neumann architecture ‚Äî what we‚Äôve casually called ‚Äúcomputers‚Äù for decades ‚Äî are ticking down. For over 75 years, it‚Äôs been the star of the tech show: a single bus, a shared memory, and that neat fetch‚Äìdecode‚Äìexecute cycle running everything from mainframes to smartphones. You know the routine ‚Äî move data, juggle addresses, rinse, repeat. But the opening act can‚Äôt last forever, and the next headliner is already knocking: quantum devices. And they aren‚Äôt just a shinier upgrade; they‚Äôre the kind of paradigm shift that‚Äôll have you questioning everything you thought you knew about programming and computation
For programmers, this might feel like staring down the barrel of obsolescence ‚Äî and, let‚Äôs be real, it kind of is. But at the same time, it‚Äôs also the biggest opportunity we‚Äôve seen in decades, especially compared to the current dumpster fire that is today‚Äôs oversaturated tech job market. Since 2022, layoffs have become the depressing ‚Äúnew normal,‚Äù and job conditions have gone from cushy perks to ‚Äújust be grateful we still have free coffee.‚Äù‚Äô
The situation is even beyond worse for the new masses of traditional coders as AI tools rapidly transform the coding industry into something resembling an automatic assembly line without the need of coders: this time, the robots aren‚Äôt building cars; they‚Äôre writing your functions.
But let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äî if you‚Äôre a seasoned programmer with that classic software engineering vibe, your job was never just about cranking out code. It‚Äôs always been about connecting the dots, bridging a mishmash of technologies, and turning someone‚Äôs wild business idea into something tangible. This craft of engineering ‚Äî the ability to make sense of obscure tech and shape it into practical solutions ‚Äî isn‚Äôt dying out. In fact, it‚Äôs thriving like never before.
And let‚Äôs face it ‚Äî those impossible problems you thought could never become powerful tech ideas are now within reach. The fun doesn‚Äôt stop, even after the tech layoff bloodbath. Quantum computing isn‚Äôt here to make your life easier ‚Äî it‚Äôs here to make it more interesting, and maybe even more profitable. Sure, wrapping your head around superposition, entanglement, and probabilistic outcomes might feel like trying to solve a puzzle with half the pieces missing. But isn‚Äôt that the whole point? Tackling the puzzles no one else dares to touch ‚Äî and turning them into your next big gig with the right quantum stack.
Making the Quantum Leap: What to Reset and Relearn
If you‚Äôve always thought being an engineer makes you naturally enjoy programming ‚Äî something I‚Äôll admit happens to me ‚Äî then you‚Äôve probably clocked years in C++, Java, Python, JavaScript, and even welcomed newer players like Go and Rust. But now you‚Äôre likely wondering: what‚Äôs next? How do we confront these new opportunities and industries head-on without tossing out the tools we‚Äôve spent years mastering?
For the newcomers, congrats ‚Äî you‚Äôre stepping into a brand-new playground. No baggage, just potential. Enjoy the ride.
For the rest of us, here‚Äôs the deal: you don‚Äôt need to toss away your old tools. They still matter. But you do need two new things: an understanding of how quantum physics translates to computing and a more functional mindset for problem-solving.
The good news? The tools are already here. Modern C++ (from version 11 onward) is adapting beautifully to cutting-edge hardware, while languages inspired by Haskell are built for addressing quantum logic. And now, we‚Äôre seeing the rise of hybrid quantum programming languages ‚Äî blending the power and familiarity of modern C++ with the mathematical richness of Haskell.
Fig 1. Like orchid hybrids, Q++ combines the strengths of its parents, C++ and Haskell, to create a programming language uniquely superior and tailored for quantum computing. Sources for the original orchid pictures: Courtesy of Sunset Valley Orchids, Fred Clarke (photographer), and William P. Rogerson (photographer).
It‚Äôs a lot like how orchid breeders create hybrids (Fig 1). They cross parent plants with specific traits ‚Äî stronger fragrance, better resilience ‚Äî and produce offspring that not only inherit those qualities but sometimes amplify them or create something entirely new. Quantum programming languages are doing the same, combining the best of what we already know with what‚Äôs needed to address the challenges ahead.
Rewiring Your Programming Mind for Quantum Computing
What should the hypothetic but expected Q++ as a new hybrid from the parents C++ and Haskell?
Something like Table 1 lays out mapping the classical to quantum computers for functional comparable concepts tough in a total completely new hardware. As you see clearly: the rules we‚Äôve lived by in the Von Neumann architecture are fundamentally different in the quantum world. Memory addresses are replaced by qubit states and entanglement graphs, CPUs give way to QPUs leveraging quantum gates, and even core concepts like stacks, heaps, and binary encoding vanish entirely.
To transition smoothly, you‚Äôll need to reframe how you think about programming:
forget fixed memory: Start visualizing data as connections in a graph, shaped by entanglement rather than addresses.
Embrace parallelism: Learn to think in terms of quantum circuits that explore all possibilities simultaneously, rather than executing step by step.
Adapt to dynamic states: Recognize that quantum registers evolve probabilistically, making uncertainty a feature, not a bug.
Redefine control flow: Shift from sequential instructions to designing circuits that guide qubits through operations.
The key is learning to see computation probabilistically, as patterns and relationships, not binary certainty. Start with tools like Qiskit or Cirq to ease into the quantum paradigm, and focus on small experiments to reshape your thinking. Quantum programming may feel alien at first, but with time, the new analogs will start to feel second nature.
Table 1 highlights the core differences between classical Von Neumann computing and quantum computing, showing how foundational concepts like memory, processing, and data representation transform in the quantum paradigm. These shifts require a fundamental rethinking of programming approaches. Sources: IBMquantum, AzureQuantum, and Quantum Country
From Concept to Code: Bridging the Old and New Worlds
If quantum programming feels like an alien language, don‚Äôt worry ‚Äî you‚Äôre not alone. Transitioning from classical computing to quantum is more about shifting how you think than memorizing technical jargon. Table 2 shows how familiar concepts from classical programming (like C++) evolve in the quantum world with Q++.
Table 2 shows a detailed look at how familiar features of classical C++ transform in a quantum programming context. It shows the abstractions and tools required to adapt seasoned programming knowledge to the probabilistic, circuit-driven, and entanglement-aware nature of quantum computing. Sources: Qiskit, GoogleCirq and Quipper
And here‚Äôs how to make sense of it
1. Forget Memory Addresses ‚Äî Think Relationships
In classical programming, pointers are like street addresses ‚Äî specific locations in memory where data lives. In Q++, there are no fixed addresses. Instead, you‚Äôre working with qubits connected in webs called entanglement graphs. You‚Äôre not asking, ‚ÄúWhere is the data?‚Äù but ‚ÄúHow is this data related to others?‚Äù
2. Bye-Bye Bit Manipulation ‚Äî Hello Quantum Gates
In classical code, you tweak bits with logical operations like AND, OR, and XOR. In Q++, you use quantum gates ‚Äî like Hadamard, Pauli, or CNOT ‚Äî to flip, twist, or combine qubit states. Think of these gates as kinda of an expanded set of classical bit operators that let you mess with probabilities instead of just flipping zeros to ones.
3. Registers Hold Probabilities, Not Values
Classical registers store intermediate results, like holding numbers while a calculation runs. Quantum registers hold qubits that can exist in multiple states simultaneously (thanks to superposition). Instead of fixed numbers, you‚Äôre juggling probabilities that change as the computation evolves.
4. Branching Isn‚Äôt Just If-Else Anymore
In classical programming, you use if-else statements to make decisions. In Q++, branching happens with controlled quantum gates, like the CCNOT gate, which decides actions based on the state of specific qubits. It‚Äôs not binary , it‚Äôs conditional operations tied to quantum states.
5. No Step-by-Step Flow ‚Äî Think Circuits
In classical programming, the flow of a program is step-by-step, guided by an instruction pointer. Quantum circuits, on the other hand, are like flowcharts where all the gates act on the qubits simultaneously. You‚Äôre designing an entire circuit, not writing a sequence of steps.
6. Libraries, But Make Them Quantum
Just as traditional C++ uses libraries like STL for utilities, Q++ relies on quantum libraries. These provide pre-built gates, quantum algorithms (like Grover‚Äôs or Shor‚Äôs), and tools to correct errors. Debugging? Forget stepping through code ‚Äî quantum simulators show probabilities, not exact values.
Summing Up: When Lines of Code Are No Longer the Star of the Show
The quantum era isn‚Äôt coming ‚Äî it‚Äôs already here. For seasoned programmers, this means letting go of deterministic logic and embracing probabilities, superposition, and entanglement. Your skills in problem-solving and abstraction still matter, but now you‚Äôll use them to design circuits and manipulate qubits instead of bits.
For newcomers, it‚Äôs a clean slate. Dive in, explore, and don‚Äôt overthink the strangeness ‚Äî it‚Äôs all part of the game. Here‚Äôs a cheat sheet to orient yourself:
Table 3. Essential Key Concepts to position yourself at the starting square in quantum programming.
Sooner rather than later, we‚Äôll find ourselves grabbing our tools, firing up quantum simulators, and building what once seemed impossible. And if Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs cat happens to escape its box, don‚Äôt worry you can always coax it back in with some clever AI neural networks and a bit of the new quantum magic.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

7 Cool Python Tricks I Use In My Day-To-Day Programming
Liu Zuo Lin
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Sep 11, 2024
1.1K
7
1) (variable or default_variable).something
Let‚Äôs say we have the following code that calls dog.bark()
from somewhere import get_dog

dog = get_dog()

dog.bark()
If the get_dog function has a 5% chance of returning None, there is a 5% chance that dog.bark() raises an error ‚Äî we will get an error stating that None has no attribute ‚Äòbark‚Äô
In this case, we can use the variable or default_variable syntax.
from somewhere import get_dog
from elsewhere import create_default_dog

dog = get_dog()  # 5% chance of returning None instead of a Dog object

(dog or create_default_dog()).bark()
^ here, let‚Äôs assume that create_default_dog will always return a Dog object.
In (dog or create_default_dog()):
if dog is originally None, create_default_dog() is ran
if dog is not originally None, create_default_dog() is ignored
As such, we can use this syntax to elegantly protect our code against the case where dog ends up being None ‚Äî this chunk of code will automatically replace it with a default value.
2) a = b = c = value
Let‚Äôs say we want to initialize a b and c to 0. We might do this:
a = 0 
b = 0
c = 0
But we can do it a lot more elegantly like this:
a = b = c = 0
^ this does the same as the code block above ‚Äî a b and c are all initialized to 0
Note that this only works if we want to initialize multiple variables to the exact same value.
3) a, b, c = a+1, b+1, c+1
When we do leetcode style problems relating to pointers, chances are that we need to increment (or decrement) our variables quite a bit.
Here‚Äôs some code that increments multiple variables a b and c
# assume a, b & c already exists

a += 1
b += 2
c += 3
But with the tuple unpacking syntax, we can actually do this in one line of code:
# assume a, b & c already exists

a, b, c = a+1, b+2, c+3
4) list/dict/set comprehension
This allows us to create lists/dicts/sets elegantly in one line of code.
List comprehension:
ls = [1, 2, 3, 4]

ls2 = [i*10 for i in ls]

# ls2 = [10, 20, 30, 40]
Dict comprehension:
ls = [1, 2, 3, 4]

d = {i:i*10 for i in ls}

# d = {1:10, 2:20, 3:30, 4:40}
Set comprehension:
ls = [1, 2, 3, 4]

s = {i*10 for i in ls}

# s = {10, 20, 30, 40}
5) f strings (formatting strings)
When we define strings, we can add an f in front of the string to turn it into a formatted string. Which unlocks powerful functionality for us.
name = "tom"
age = 60

s = f"my name is {name} and my age is {age}"
print(s)

# my name is tom and my age is 60
^ we can pass in variables directly into strings ‚Äî notice that we no longer have to manually convert our variables into strings for this to work
name = "tom"
age = 60

s = f"{name=} {age=} {age+1=}"
print(s)

# name='tom' age=60 age+1=61
^ we can also add = behind our variables to also print it in our string ‚Äî which is useful for debugging.
n = 123.456789

print(f'number is {n:.3f} to 3 decimal places')
print(f'number is {n:.3g} to 3 significant figures')

# number is 123.457 to 3 decimal places
# number is 123 to 3 significant figures
^ we can even do stuff like printing numbers to a certain number of decimal places or significant figures.
6) Combining strings using brackets
If we have long strings, we need not keep using + to combine them (this gets really annoying over time)
s = "this is the first sentence. " + \
  "this is the second sentence. " + \
  "this is the third sentence. " + \
  "this is the fourth sentence. "

print(s)
# this is the first sentence. this is the second sentence. this is the third sentence. this is the fourth sentence.
We can actually join multiple strings together over multiple lines by placing them in a bracket.
s = (
  "this is the first sentence. " 
  "this is the second sentence. "
  "this is the third sentence. " 
  "this is the fourth sentence. "
)

print(s)
# this is the first sentence. this is the second sentence. this is the third sentence. this is the fourth sentence.
^ notice that this is much neater and elegant (imo at least)
7) Ternary operator
Here‚Äôs a simple for loop that assigns values to the variable dessert depending on what fruit is.
fruit = "apple"

if fruit == "apple":
  dessert = "pie"

elif fruit == "orange":
  dessert = "juice"

else:
  dessert = "idk"
Did you know that we can actually do this in one line of code using the ternary operator?
fruit = "apple"

dessert = "pie" if fruit=="apple" else "juice" if fruit=="orange" else "idk"
^ a lot more elegant + it saves a lot more space
Conclusion
Hopefully this was clear and easy to understand

7 Productivity Hacks I Stole From a Principal Software Engineer
Golden tips and tricks that can make you unstoppable
Nidhi Jain üë©‚Äçüíª
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Code Like A Girl
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Oct 15, 2024
4.8K
100
Photo by Domenico Loia on Unsplash
Have you ever crossed paths with a senior or principal software engineer whose work style seems almost magical?
Imagine someone who effortlessly transforms complex challenges into elegant solutions with just a click, brainstorms ideas at lightning speed, or writes code as if their mind is seamlessly integrated with an intelligent assistant.
Witnessing such mastery in action can be inspiring and enlightening, revealing the secrets behind their exceptional performance. Discover what makes these top-tier engineers stand out and how you can harness their techniques to elevate your career.
I was lucky to work alongside a few such great people, and I did not miss the golden opportunity to observe and figure out their secret sauce. Believe me, it was like a masterclass in productivity.
Here are the seven hacks I learnt from the ones who operate on a whole different level:
1. The Art of Saying No
Image by Andrew Martin from Pixabay
One of their biggest strengths? Context switching with purpose.
They don‚Äôt get sucked into every little task. They know when to focus, when to shift gears, and, most importantly, when to say ‚Äúno.‚Äù
With 13 Slack channels buzzing for their attention, they don‚Äôt let the noise dictate their day. Instead, they prioritize like pros.
When something doesn‚Äôt need immediate attention, it goes on their to-do list. But if it‚Äôs quick and important, they knock it out right then and there.
It‚Äôs all about choosing when to engage and when to move on.
2. The Perfect Setup
Ever notice how they never seem to struggle with development setup issues?
Photo by Nubelson Fernandes on Unsplash
That‚Äôs because they‚Äôve invested time into creating the perfect environment. Their IDE, terminal, note-taking tools‚Äîeverything is custom-tailored to their workflow. It's like sharpening their saw and keeping it ready to cut the wood in a shot.
They don‚Äôt run into setup errors or linting problems. Why? Because they spent an extra few minutes configuring everything perfectly from the start.
It‚Äôs that upfront effort that saves them hours down the line. Not only that, but even their setup, like the mouse, the keyboard, the number of secondary monitors, the orientation of each monitor, and all the other extra peripherals, everything would have been carefully tailored by them to make their mind and body work the best. It‚Äôs not about using the most expensive or the best. It‚Äôs about using and keeping what works best for them.
3. Shortcuts Are King
Auto-generated by Bing
We all love shortcuts, but these engineers take it to the next level, optimizing everything ‚Äî from keyboard shortcuts to custom command-line aliases. Even small tasks like:
Having 100+ aliases for simple commands like :
git status to --> gs
or 
kubectl get pods to -> kgp
2. Or assign a meaningful name to each new bookmark you add.
3. Or instead of bookmarking every new page that comes to you, understand the pattern and bookmark the main one. Instead of 50 bookmarks, they rely on five core ones and have a system to find the rest when needed
4. Or having the shortcuts of your favourite IDE on tips.
5. Even using a Keyboard instead of a mouse/trackpad.
6. Regarding recurring queries or tasks, they don‚Äôt rely on memory ‚Äî they rely on patterns.
All these habits seem pretty trivial, but this is where the difference lies. Most engineers stay stuck in this daily mundane chaos and lose time and energy, which slows them down. However, shaving off a few seconds and a few joules of mental energy from every action you take compounds very well over time.
4. Building a second brain
Photo by GoodNotes 5 on Unsplash
Every senior engineer I‚Äôve worked with has a solid note-taking system, and while their choice of app varies, the app itself isn‚Äôt the key‚Äîit‚Äôs the framework they‚Äôve built. I have seen people using Apple Notes, OneNote, Obsidian, Google Keep, and even a Git repo. They all have one thing in common: a structured system that makes searching and adding notes effortless.
It‚Äôs not about the tool but the method. Their notes aren‚Äôt random scribbles ‚Äî they‚Äôre organized, categorized, and easily searchable. Need to find something from a meeting last month? It‚Äôs right there, ready to be retrieved in seconds.
This structured note-taking becomes their second brain. Whether it‚Äôs brainstorming or problem-solving, their notes are the backbone of their productivity. The secret isn‚Äôt just writing things down; it‚Äôs building a framework that makes finding and using those notes quick and efficient.
5. Automate Everything
Auto-Generated by the author using Dall-E
If there‚Äôs a task that can be automated, trust me, they‚Äôve probably already done it. They hate manual work.
Whether it‚Äôs deployments, testing, or even sending routine emails ‚Äî automation is their default mode of thinking. Their brains constantly keep asking, ‚ÄúHow can I make this take less effort?‚Äù
I once met someone who took this to an unexpected level ‚Äî he automated receiving the daily snack and lunch menu emails at the office. Why? Just to avoid a few extra clicks to get the same information. Yes, they‚Äôre that committed to cutting down effort.
You might even sit down for coffee with them, and they‚Äôll suggest ways you could automate your coffee-making workflow. That‚Äôs the level of thinking they operate at.
And it‚Äôs not just for fun ‚Äî precisely this mindset makes them so effective at work. They see automation opportunities everywhere, from the most minor tasks to the most extensive systems. Once they get an idea, their lightning-fast operational speed ensures they can execute it, often before you‚Äôve even figured out how to do it the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù way.
6. Seamless Multi-tasking
Auto-generated by the author using Dall-E
Time is precious for everyone, but it's like gold dust for a principal software engineer. As you climb the career ladder, so does the count of meetings on your calendar. And let‚Äôs not forget about the 13 buzzing Slack conversations, quarterly planning meetings, and the occasional fire to put out. That‚Äôs the daily battlefield of a principal engineer.
I had a glimpse at the calendar of one such legend, and ‚Äî it looked like an a buffet of back-to-back meetings. Finding a full day where all those meetings could actually be attended? Impossible. In this scenario, squeezing multiple tasks into a rare one-hour free window can only be a superpower. But wait, isn‚Äôt multitasking overrated? How do they manage to stay so productive?
Here‚Äôs where the secret sauce lies: multi-screen setups.
I once scheduled a quick call with a senior staff engineer to discuss an issue. As I awkwardly toggled between my terminal, IDE, and browser window, one by one, he casually dropped a bomb of wisdom:
‚ÄúHow do you even work like that? It‚Äôs so inefficient!‚Äù
Confused, I watched him seamlessly pull up multiple windows side-by-side, working in parallel on the same screen. No more flipping back and forth, wasting time and mental energy. It was like unlocking a new level of efficiency ‚Äî saving me seconds, cognitive bandwidth, and probably the rest of my life from unnecessary frustration.
7. Decluttered Digital Space
Photo by James McKinven on Unsplash
One thing I‚Äôve learned about people and their habits is that how they handle minute-to-minute tasks reflects their mental state. One key attribute that sets senior engineers apart is their exceptional mental clarity.
But here‚Äôs the thing: that mental clarity doesn‚Äôt magically appear overnight; it‚Äôs honed over years of practice.
How do they achieve it? By keeping a close watch on everything that could cause mental clutter.
Got 100+ Chrome tabs open? Not on their watch! It‚Äôs like having a hundred open mental threads that constantly force the subconscious mind to switch context. They start a task, open only the necessary tabs, and quickly close them once they‚Äôre done. This way, they maintain control over context switching with their conscious mind.
Whenever they download a new document or file, it meets its fate within minutes. It either gets neatly classified and stored or swiftly sent to the digital bin.
And then there‚Äôs their inbox ‚Äî clean and organized. I‚Äôve seen multiple staff and senior engineers who prioritize keeping their emails in check. Unread emails? Rare. Important ones? Starred and tackled immediately. Everything else? Archived or deleted without a second thought.
In their digital world, less truly is more.
Key Takeaway:
What we can learn from these engineers is not something that can be found in any book.
It‚Äôs a skill personally created by every one of them through trial and error. It‚Äôs a mindset of clarity, focus, and efficiency.
They‚Äôve mastered the art of staying productive by relying on systems, not memory. They don‚Äôt just work smarter ‚Äî they work in a way that preserves their energy for the tasks that truly matter.
‚ÄúRemember, productivity is not a gift you receive ‚Äî it is a skill you craft with every intentional choice you make. ‚öôÔ∏è‚Äù

5 Modern Python Tools Every Developer Should Master in 2024
Sangeeth Joseph - The AI dev
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Sep 12, 2024
503
7
Introduction
Python continues to dominate the programming world in 2024, thanks to its versatility across web development, data science, automation, and machine learning. But the language itself isn‚Äôt enough ‚Äî what really boosts your productivity are the right tools that enhance your workflow. In this blog, I‚Äôm going to introduce you to six essential Python tools every developer should master this year. These tools will help you code faster, cleaner, and smarter.
Let‚Äôs dive into tools that actually make a difference in your coding life. Here we go!
1. FastAPI
What is FastAPI?
FastAPI is, without a doubt, one of the fastest-growing web frameworks for building APIs. It‚Äôs not only lightning-fast but also incredibly intuitive. If you‚Äôre familiar with Flask, think of FastAPI as its async, turbocharged cousin. And it even generates documentation for you automatically!
Why You Should Care
In a world where speed is crucial, FastAPI stands out. Whether you‚Äôre building microservices, serverless functions, or full-blown APIs, FastAPI‚Äôs simplicity and speed make it an essential tool. Plus, the async support ensures your APIs are scalable and modern.
Code to Get Started:
First, install FastAPI and Uvicorn (a server for running your FastAPI app):
pip install fastapi uvicorn
Here‚Äôs a simple example:
from fastapi import FastAPI
app = FastAPI()
@app.get("/")
def read_root():
    return {"Hello": "World"}
# Run it with: uvicorn filename:app --reload
Boom! You‚Äôve got a high-performance API up and running.
2. Pytest
What is Pytest?
Let‚Äôs face it ‚Äî testing isn‚Äôt always fun. But Pytest changes that. It‚Äôs a powerful yet simple testing framework that makes it easy to write and run tests for your Python code. Whether you‚Äôre writing unit tests or functional tests, Pytest can handle it all with style.
Why You Should Care
Testing your code is essential for catching bugs before they become real problems. Pytest‚Äôs flexibility and ease of use make it one of the best testing frameworks out there. With its minimal boilerplate and powerful features, you‚Äôll spend more time writing meaningful tests and less time setting things up.
Code to Get Started:
Install Pytest:
pip install pytest
Here‚Äôs a quick test example:
# test_sample.py
def test_addition():
    assert 1 + 1 == 2
# Run it with: pytest test_sample.py
Pytest makes testing so straightforward, there‚Äôs no excuse not to test your code anymore.
3. Black
What is Black?
Black is a Python code formatter with an attitude. It automatically formats your Python code according to PEP 8 standards. You don‚Äôt have to worry about whether your code is consistently formatted ‚Äî Black does it for you. And it does it without compromise. Think of it as the ultimate tool for making sure all your code looks clean and uniform.
Why You Should Care
Consistency is key, especially when you‚Äôre working with teams. Black eliminates any discussions or debates over code formatting in pull requests. Just run Black, and your code gets formatted automatically, ensuring everyone‚Äôs code is in sync.
Code to Get Started:
Install Black:
pip install black
To format a Python file, run:
black yourfile.py
Done! Your code is now perfectly formatted with zero arguments over whether to use spaces or tabs.
4. venv
What is venv?
If you‚Äôre working on multiple Python projects, you need isolated environments to keep dependencies separate. That‚Äôs where venv comes in. It‚Äôs Python‚Äôs built-in tool for creating virtual environments, which allows you to work on different projects without messing up your global Python environment.
Why You Should Care
Managing different projects with their own dependencies is crucial. Without virtual environments, you risk installing conflicting packages. venv solves that problem, letting you keep each project‚Äôs dependencies isolated in its own environment. Plus, it's simple to use, no need for external tools.
Code to Get Started:
First, create a virtual environment:
python -m venv myenv
Activate it:
On macOS/Linux:
source myenv/bin/activate
On Windows:
.\myenv\Scripts\activate
Now, you can install packages in this environment without affecting your global setup. To deactivate:
deactivate
5. Pyright
What is Pyright?
Pyright is a static type checker for Python, developed by Microsoft. Now, I know Python is dynamically typed, but trust me ‚Äî using type hints and a type checker like Pyright can save you hours of debugging by catching issues before you even run your code.
Why You Should Care
As Python projects grow, they can get complex. Type hints make your code more readable and maintainable, especially when collaborating with teams. Pyright is blazing fast and integrates smoothly with editors like VSCode, giving you real-time feedback on potential type errors.
Code to Get Started:
Install Pyright via npm:
npm install -g pyright
To check your Python file for type errors, run:
pyright yourfile.py
And just like that, you‚Äôve got a type-checking safety net for your Python code.
6. BeautifulSoup
What is BeautifulSoup?
BeautifulSoup is a library for web scraping purposes. It allows you to extract data from HTML and XML files with ease. Whether you‚Äôre pulling data from a website, parsing HTML, or scraping content, BeautifulSoup is your go-to tool. It‚Äôs user-friendly and integrates well with requests, making web scraping a breeze.
Why You Should Care
In 2024, data scraping remains a valuable skill for collecting data from the web. BeautifulSoup simplifies the process of extracting data from web pages, allowing you to focus on what you want to do with that data. If you‚Äôre working on projects that involve data collection or content aggregation, BeautifulSoup is a must-have tool.
Code to Get Started:
First, install BeautifulSoup and requests:
pip install beautifulsoup4 requests
Here‚Äôs a simple example to scrape a webpage:
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
url = 'https://example.com'
response = requests.get(url)
soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')
# Extract and print the title of the page
title = soup.title.string
print(f'Title of the page: {title}')
With BeautifulSoup, extracting data is as simple as pie.
Conclusion
There you have it ‚Äî six modern Python tools that every developer should master in 2024. From building high-speed APIs with FastAPI to scraping web data with BeautifulSoup, these tools will elevate your Python development game. Each tool brings something unique to the table, enhancing productivity and streamlining workflows.
Start experimenting with these tools, integrate them into your projects, and see how they transform your development process. Happy coding!
This updated blog now includes BeautifulSoup as a valuable tool for web scraping, with practical insights and code snippets for each tool.

7 Python Function Things I Regret Not Knowing Earlier
Liu Zuo Lin
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Aug 3, 2024
1.6K
10
1) Type hinting in functions
I started off learning Python without using type hints at all. And so for the first few years of writing Python, I never wrote a single type hint.
As a simple example, let‚Äôs say we want to write a function that finds the average of 2 integer numbers. How I used to write my function:
How I write my functions now at work (adding type hints and docstring):
a: int means that a should ideally be an integer
b: int means that b should ideally be an integer
-> float means that the function should ideally return a float value
However, do note that type hints hint, but do not enforce. If we pass in strings or other data types into a and b, Python is actually ok with that (until it attempts to divide a string by 2 which causes error)
The purpose of type hinting is more of 1) making code readable for humans and 2) enabling your IDE eg. PyCharm or VSCode to do checks for you.
As much as possible, try to add type hints into your functions so that other programmers (or even future you) will have an easier time understanding the function.
2) Default arguments
^ in the above function, greeting=‚Äòhi‚Äô is a default argument.
if we decide to not pass anything to greeting, it is automatically assigned ‚Äòhi‚Äô
if we decide to pass something to greeting, it takes that value
In greet(‚Äòtom‚Äô) , we don‚Äôt pass anything into greeting. Which means it defaults to ‚Äòhi‚Äô
In greet(‚Äòtom‚Äô, greeting=‚Äòhello‚Äô) , we pass ‚Äòhello‚Äô into greeting. Which means that we override the default argument, and assign greeting = ‚Äòhello‚Äô
This is useful if we have a large number of parameters in a function, and do not wish to have to pass in every single parameter each time we call the function.
3) Arguments VS Parameters
In my first few years of learning Python, I thought they meant the same thing.
But not really. There‚Äôs a slight difference.
Let‚Äôs say we have a simple function that takes in (a, b) and returns their average.
A parameter is a variable written inside the brackets when we define our function. Here, a and b are parameters.
An argument is the value that we actually pass into our function when calling it. Here, when we call the avg(a, b) function, 3 and 5 are arguments.
4) Positional VS Keyword Arguments
A simple trivial function just to show an example.
Let‚Äôs call this function by passing in some positional arguments.
^ here, 4 and 7 are positional arguments. Positional arguments need to be in order ‚Äî 4 is passed into a, while 7 is passed into b.
Next, let‚Äôs call our function by passing in some keyword arguments.
^ here, b=5 and a=8 are keyword arguments. Keyword arguments do not need to be in order, but we must pass them in using a key=value format.
5) Arbitrary Positional Arguments (*args)
Arbitrary positional arguments in a function, also known as *args, allow the function to accept any number of positional arguments.
^ here, the test function takes in *args ‚Äî which allows test to take in any number of positional arguments, which will all be caught in a tuple named args.
We can combine this with normal parameters too (the *args must be behind)
Additional note ‚Äî we don‚Äôt have the name it *args. We can name it whatever as long as we add the * in front of it.
6) Arbitrary keyword arguments (**kwargs)
Arbitrary keyword arguments, also known as **kwargs, allow our functions to take in any number of keyword arguments.
^ here, the test function takes in **kwargs ‚Äî which allows test to take in any number of keyword arguments, will be caught in a dictionary named kwargs
We can also combine this with normal parameters (**kwargs must be behind too)
Additional note ‚Äî we don‚Äôt have to name it kwargs if we don‚Äôt want to. We can name it whatever we want as long as it has ** in front of it.
Quick Pause
I recently wrote a book ‚Äî 101 Things I Never Knew About Python
Check it out here if you wish to support me as a writer!
Link: https://payhip.com/b/vywcf
7) Using * and ** to pass list/dict into function
Here‚Äôs a trivial function that simply prints out its arguments.
Instead of calling this function the normal way ie hi(1, 2) , we could:
1) use * to pass a list containing positional arguments
^ here, the * in front of nums unpacks its contents into the function call as positional arguments. This is the same as hi(100, 200)
2) use ** to pass a dict containing keyword arguments
^ here, the ** in front of d unpacks its key-value pairs into the function call as keyword arguments. This is the same as hi(a=100, b=100)
