1985: My Year In The British Top 75 (Week 2: 12 January 1985)
Easing out the holidays with Toy Dolls, Ian McCulloch without the Bunnymen, Limahl without Kajagoogoo, and The Stranglers
Stewart Mason
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Three Imaginary Girls
¬∑
11 min read
¬∑
Jan 13, 2025
437
11
Photo by Tobias Nader on Unsplash
Since starting research for this series, I‚Äôve been seeing how my old neighborhood in Lubbock has changed in the last 40 years on Google Maps. For one thing, as the city as a whole has grown in that direction, I‚Äôm kind of shocked at what‚Äôs now available within a 10- or 15-minute walk from my old house. There‚Äôs a multi-screen Cinemark movie theater, which 15-year-old me would have killed for. But then I ask myself whether I would rather live in Lubbock or Boston today, and I feel a lot better.
The only thing of even the slightest interest within that walk from my house was a 7-Eleven at the corner of 82nd Street and University Avenue. Google Maps shows it‚Äôs still there. I wonder if I‚Äôm still banned from using the nacho machine. The manager felt I was too free-handed with the cheese sauce and the pickled jalape√±o slices. I probably was. I regret nothing. Anyway, Band Aid was at #1 for the fifth week. There were five new entries, the highest being ‚ÄúLove and Pride‚Äù by King at #45. I might write that one up, I haven‚Äôt decided.
At #6, ‚ÄúNellie the Elephant‚Äù by Toy Dolls
For all of the serious talk of punk as being a deeply important sociological movement and the heir to the Situationists of Paris in May ‚Äô68 and everything ‚Äî and I like Lipstick Traces and England‚Äôs Dreaming as much as the next guy, don‚Äôt get me wrong ‚Äî it was also goofy as hell. From first-gen punks like Patrik ‚ÄúSafety Pin Stuck Through My Heart‚Äù Fitzgerald and Manchester comedian Grahame Fellowes (whose 1978 LP True Love Stories as Jilted John is both hilarious and unexpectedly heartfelt) through acts like Splodgenessabounds and Spizzenergi (who changed their name every year to something else with the word ‚ÄúSpizz‚Äù in it), silliness was always rampant in British punk.
This is where the Toy Dolls came in. Nominally a punk band, they‚Äôre really just a goofy, lighthearted comedy group, kind of like if Weird Al Yankovic fronted Sham 69. The one constant member, singer and guitarist Michael Algar, is actually really good at what he does ‚Äî along with fronting the Toy Dolls over 45 years after they formed, he regularly tours as a guitarist in the current lineups of oi! stalwarts Cockney Rejects and L.A. pop-punks The Dickies ‚Äî it‚Äôs just that he‚Äôs incapable of not being extremely silly.
What I thought about it then: As in recording a punky version of ‚ÄúNellie the Elephant,‚Äù a 1956 novelty single by a child actress named Mandy Miller that basically every British baby boomer knows by heart. The original, incidentally, was produced by George Martin, who prior to being assigned to produce The Beatles ‚Äî in part as a punishment from his superiors in the EMI A&R department for having an affair with his secretary, which Just Wasn‚Äôt Done at such a staid institution ‚Äî primarily made comedy and novelty records. By the way, Martin and the aforementioned secretary, Judy Lockhart Smith, were married from 1966 until his 2016 death.
The Toy Dolls first released this single in 1982, and it became a number one hit on the Indie chart. The 1984 single release was exactly the same (it also appeared on their first and best album, Dig That Groove Baby), but for some reason it clicked with the British record buying public when the band reissued it. That‚Äôs one odd thing I‚Äôve noticed about the UK chart as opposed to the US: it‚Äôs very easy for an old record to hit the charts again. (Levi‚Äôs ads in the 1990s caused both The Clash and The Bluebells to score number one singles with decade-old songs.)
What I think about it now: Like I said, Toy Dolls still exist, in the sense that Michael Algar still tours with a new bassist and drummer every so often (and as far as I know still wears those trademark rectangular sunglasses on stage), although the band‚Äôs last album came out in 2019. Good for them for making a living at it, though it‚Äôs not really my bag.
At #58, ‚ÄúSeptember Song‚Äù by Ian McCulloch
Following the career high point Ocean Rain, longstanding tensions in Echo and the Bunnymen caused the group to fragment in a way that some thought was going to be permanent. First they fired their manager, Bill Drummond, a fascinatingly odd guy who went on to form Dadaist duo The KLF aka The Justified Ancients of Mu-Mu aka The Timelords. Next, lead singer Ian McCulloch released his first solo single, a cover of the easy listening standard ‚ÄúSeptember Song.‚Äù
What I thought about it then: Which was an unexpected choice, but it turned out to be a kind of brilliant one. I knew the song at the time, because my mother was a Frank Sinatra fan, and his 1946 single was a particular favorite of hers. I didn‚Äôt care for Sinatra as a teen ‚Äî honestly, I still have my reservations ‚Äî but when I heard Mac‚Äôs take on the song, I thought the melodrama of the lyrics and melody was a perfect fit for his vocal style. Producers Clive Langer and Colin Fairley create an appropriately somber arrangement that sounds just enough like the Bunnymen‚Äôs cinematic epicness for the whole thing to fit surprisingly perfectly.
What I think about it now: I‚Äôm pretty sure that in early 1985, I did not know that ‚ÄúSeptember Song‚Äù had been written by the German composer Kurt Weill. (The lyric is by playwright Maxwell Anderson, who I always think of as the guy who write the sublimely creepy The Bad Seed.) I did in fact discover Weill later in 1985, however, after reading several reviews of Lost In The Stars, Hal Willner‚Äôs Weill tribute album. Willner, I did not know at the time but soon learned, was a New York scene maven who in addition to his day job as music supervisor on Saturday Night Live (which he held until his 2020 death), created these incredibly specific tribute albums in homage to his favorite artists.
It turned out that in addition to ‚ÄúSeptember Song,‚Äù I knew Weill and his most famous lyricist, Bertolt Brecht, from two other covers: The Doors did ‚ÄúAlabama Song‚Äù on their first album, and most famously, Bobby Darin did a strangely but fabulously cabaret-style version of ‚ÄúMack the Knife‚Äù that became a massive hit in 1959. I somehow got into a conversation with Monterey High School‚Äôs theater teacher, Harlan Reddell, about Lost In The Stars and he immediately said, ‚ÄúIf you want to hear more Brecht and Weill, find the cast album for the 1970s revival of The Threepenny Opera. Bobby Darin was singing from the 1950s English translation, which was fine, but they cut all the sex and depravity and murder and politics out of the lyrics. The ‚Äô70s version, with Raul Julia and Blair Brown ‚Äî that one put all that stuff back in.‚Äù I found a copy of the LP at the downtown library and was utterly gobsmacked from the first listen. Given my musical, literary, and drama-student interests, there was no way I wasn‚Äôt going to discover Brecht and Weill soon enough, but this sent me down a major rabbit hole that I‚Äôve still never climbed out of.
By the way, if you ever want to explore Hal Willner‚Äôs tribute albums, my favorite one is probably Stay Awake, a 1988 tribute to the music of Walt Disney cartoons that‚Äôs unrelentingly charming.
At #66, ‚ÄúNever Ending Story‚Äù by Limahl
At about exactly the time I was getting ready to move from Longmont, Colorado, to Russell, Kansas, in the late spring of 1983, the new buzz was a single by a British band with the remarkably goofy name Kajagoogoo. ‚ÄúToo Shy‚Äù was a song that a year before would have been a massive British hit but almost completely unknown in the states. But with the rise of MTV and American radio‚Äôs sudden receptiveness to British New Pop singles, it became one of the defining songs of the summer of 1983, up there with Duran Duran‚Äôs ‚ÄúIs There Something I Should Know?‚Äù (The comparison came up a lot, because Kagagoogoo‚Äôs debut album White Feathers was produced by Duran producer Colin Thurston and keyboardist Nick Rhodes.)
Kajagoogoo had originally formed as a far more serious-minded project called Art Nouveau. After a failed indie single under that name, the group decided on a change of direction, choosing an aspiring actor named Christopher Hamill as their new lead singer and changing their name to the deliberately meaningless Kajagoogoo. A chance encounter between Hamill and Rhodes at a club where he worked part time as a waiter got the renamed band signed to EMI and White Feathers came out in early 1983, which is where we came in.
Compared to a lot of Top 40-oriented New Pop records of its era, White Feathers was actually a pretty solid album. The band, led by bassist and songwriter Nick Beggs, was melodically proficient, and Hamill, now going by an anagram of his surname, was a charming frontman with a more than decent pop voice. ‚ÄúToo Shy‚Äù and a just as inviting follow-up hit, ‚ÄúHang On Girl,‚Äù suggested positive things to come. But during an extensive British tour in the spring and summer of 1983, a rift between Limahl and his band mates, who thought their new frontman had too much of a taste for the pop star lifestyle, caused Kajagoogoo to rather callously fire him via a phone call from their manager in August.
The rest of the band, with Beggs resuming his former spot as singer, shortened their name to Kaja, released two underwhelming albums, and split up. Limahl also released a couple of underwhelming solo albums and has spent most of the last 40 years on the nostalgia circuit, including a couple of brief reunions with his former band. Normally that would be it, except for a movie that turned out to be a cultural milestone for the younger end of Generation X and the elder Millennials.
What I thought about it then: At 15, I was about five years too old for The Neverending Story, a German-made fantasy film directed by Wolfgang Petersen (Das Boot) that wears reportedly the costliest European film up to that point. However, it not only was it a big box-office hit in the summer of 1984, it became a straight-up generational touchstone on home video. Put it this way: from 1988 through 1994, I worked sporadically as a video store clerk in various towns in west Texas and eastern New Mexico. Every store I worked at had at least two copies of The Neverending Story, and they were always checked out.
Which means that the theme song also made an impact. Written by Giorgio Moroder and Keith Forsey specifically for the English-language version of the film, it‚Äôs one of Moroder‚Äôs biggest post-disco hits, reaching the top 5 on the UK charts. And like the film, it stuck in pop culture, including getting a revival a few years ago when two characters sang it in an episode of Stranger Things. (Yes, we will talk about the other big-deal Stranger Things revival later this year.)
What I think about it now: I‚Äôve always thought it odd that this single was credited solely to Limahl when clearly it‚Äôs a duet. What I did not know until I started researching this entry is that the female singer‚Äôs name is Beth Anderson, an American voice actress. I also did not know that the woman miming the female vocal part in the video is not Beth Anderson, but the backing singer in Limahl‚Äôs touring band at the time, a woman named Mandy Newton. Also odd in retrospect: what an unexpectedly horny video this is, considering that it‚Äôs the theme for children‚Äôs fantasy film and, for that matter, that Limahl has been openly gay his entire public life. It‚Äôs a perfectly nice song, but I‚Äôve always preferred Moroder‚Äôs other 1984 film theme, his collaboration with The Human League‚Äôs Phil Oakey, ‚ÄúTogether In Electric Dreams.‚Äù
At #68, ‚ÄúNo Mercy‚Äù by The Stranglers
It took me years to figure out The Stranglers‚Äô deal. Part of that was because of all the first-generation punk bands, they were probably the most insanely prolific: 1984‚Äôs Aural Sculpture was their eighth album since their 1977 debut, and that was aside from a near-constant stream of non-LP singles and solo albums by various bandmembers. And all of these came out on a string of American labels (or didn‚Äôt, as in the case of 1981‚Äôs La Folie), which meant that finding Stranglers albums in the bins at your local record store was a decidedly hit or miss affair.
But mostly it was because not only were The Stranglers churning out material, it all covered a huge amount of musical ground. The first things I read about the band, mostly in Rolling Stone, made it sound like they were the most scabrous of the early London punks, writing songs like ‚ÄúPeaches‚Äù and ‚ÄúBring On The Nubiles‚Äù that were as lecherous and leering as a trenchcoat-clad pervert on the street. And I also saw reports that their bass player, JJ Burnel, was a black-belt martial arts expert who frequently jumped into the audience to deal with miscreants himself. (Even more astoundingly, on a London punk scene filled with musicians in their teens and early 20s, Stranglers drummer Jet Black had been born in 1938, putting him in his 40s during their initial run of UK hits.)
And yet the first two songs I heard by The Stranglers were a muscular but faithful version of Dionne Warwick‚Äôs Bacharach and David classic ‚ÄúWalk On By‚Äù and a 1979 single, ‚ÄúDuchess,‚Äù that aside from the fact that Burnel and keyboardist Dave Greenfield appeared to be playing twice as fast as Black and singer/guitarist Hugh Cornwell, felt like a bright and cheerful pop song. But then came a deeply bizarre concept album about alien visitors, The Gospel According to the Meninblack, which was how I found out about the creepy urban legend about the weird government officials who meet with people visited by aliens ages before the Will Smith movie.
And then came the single ‚ÄúGolden Brown,‚Äù a waltz-time ballad that sounded like the sweetest of love songs until Cornwell pointed out that it was equally inspired by his Spanish girlfriend and their shared love of heroin. (Although the single after ‚ÄúDuchess,‚Äù Burnel‚Äôs ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Bring Harry,‚Äù had been an anti-drug song pointedly taking Cornwell to task for his addiction, by the early ‚Äô80s, all of the bandmembers were at least occasional junkies.)
What I thought about it then: So by 1985, The Stranglers were a band I couldn‚Äôt figure out, whose music I found occasionally fascinating. So why not release the closest they had yet managed to a mainstream pop record? Produced by Laurie Latham (Ian Dury, Paul Young), it featured a more chart-friendly sound mixing acoustic and electric guitars, Greenfield‚Äôs front and center keyboards, and on several tracks including ‚ÄúNo Mercy,‚Äù a horn section. First single ‚ÄúSkin Deep‚Äù was the closest The Stranglers had come to an American hit, but oddly, ‚ÄúNo Mercy‚Äù is the song you‚Äôre more likely to hear on a station like Sirius XM‚Äôs First Wave. I think it‚Äôs down to Cornwell‚Äôs needly single-note guitar riff, the insistent ‚ÄúLife shows no mercy‚Äù refrain, and the catchy horns. It‚Äôs got all the menace and crudity of the earliest Stranglers records, just in a much more pop-friendly context.
What I think about it now: In 1986, The Stranglers managed their biggest American college radio hit with ‚ÄúAlways The Sun,‚Äù easily their most immediately likable song. They followed it with a couple of ‚Äô60s cover hits, but at the dawn of the ‚Äô90s, Hugh Cornwell split for a solo career. Somewhat surprisingly, the rest of The Stranglers continued without him, and even despite the deaths of Jet Black and Dave Greenfield in the last few years, both JJ Burnel‚Äôs Stranglers and Hugh Cornwell have released new material since the turn of the decade.

At work, we write our code to be as humanly-readable as possible. Which means the following (non-exhaustive list):
variable names are meaningful and longer (instead of a, b & c)
function names are meaningful and longer
lots of comments and documentation explaining the code
type hints are everywhere
strings seem to be much longer and more verbose
etc etc
Which means that code styling will inevitably evolve to accommodate the above.
Thus, here are some production-grade Python code styles I‚Äôve picked up from my workplaces over the past few years.
1) Tuple unpacking with brackets

3) Combining strings using brackets
Production-grade strings usually cannot fit into one line due to how verbose they are. And so we combine them using brackets.
Note ‚Äî inside brackets, string literals (using quotes) are automatically added together, and we do not need to use the + operator to do this
4) Multi-line method chaining with the help of brackets
Normal method chaining:
In production grade code, method names are much longer most of the time, and we have more methods chained together.
Once again, we use brackets to fir all of these stuff into multiple lines instead of shortening any of the method names or variable names.
Note that if we do method chaining within brackets, we are not required to use the \ character for a explicit line break

6) Writing readable and informative functions
How we used to write functions as students:
^ PRs that contain such code will most likely get rejected
the function name is not descriptive
parameter variable names are bad
no type hints, so we don‚Äôt know at first glance what data types each parameter is supposed to be
no type hints, so we also don‚Äôt know what our function is supposed to return
no docstring, so we have to infer what our function does
Here‚Äôs how we write functions in production-grade Python code
function name should be descriptive
parameter names should be more descriptive instead of eg. a, b, c
each parameter should have a type hint
the function‚Äôs return type should also be included
a docstring detailing what the function does, the parameters it takes in, and its output should be included as a string in triple quotes.

8) Boolean conditions with brackets

9) Protection against None values
Normal code that accesses some nested attribute of an object.
Some problems with this code that might cause our PR to be rejected:
if dog is None, we get an error
if dog.owner is None, we also get an error
essentially, this block of code does not protect against the possibility that dog or dog.owner could be None.
In production-grade code, we need to actively protect against such cases. Here‚Äôs how I would rewrite this code.
The and & or operators in Python are short-circuit operators, which mean that they stop evaluating the entire expression as soon as they have a clear answer.
if dog is None, our expression terminates at ‚Äúif dog‚Äù
if dog is not None, but dog.owner is None, our expression terminates at ‚Äúif dog and dog.owner‚Äù
if we don‚Äôt have any None values, dog.owner.name is successfully accessed, and used to compare against the string ‚Äúbob‚Äù
This way, we have extra protection against the possibility that either dog or dog.owner could be None values.
10) Protection against iterating through None values
Here‚Äôs how we might iterate over some iterable (eg list, dict, tuple etc)
One issue with this is that it doesn‚Äôt protect against mylist being None ‚Äî if mylist happens to be None, we get an error because we cannot iterate through None.
Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôd improve on this code:
The expression ‚Äúmylist or None‚Äù
returns mylist if it is truthy (eg. non-empty iterable)
returns [] if mylist is falsy (eg. None or empty iterable)
Thus, if mylist is None, the expression ‚Äúmylist or None‚Äù returns [ ] instead, and we don‚Äôt run into an unwanted exception.
11) internal functions start with _
Here‚Äôs a sample class. Here, the run method uses the other methods clean & transform
In production-grade code, we aspire to be as explicit as possible, and thus try to differentiate between internal and external methods.
External methods ‚Äî methods to be used by other classes and objects
Internal methods ‚Äî methods to be used by the class itself
By convention, it is good practice for internal methods to begin with an underscore _

12) Decorators for common functionality
Here‚Äôs a class with 3 functions, and each function does different things. However, notice that there are similar steps across the different functions ‚Äî the try-except block, as well as the logging functionality.
One good practice to reduce the amount of repeated code would be to write a decorator function containing the common functionality instead.
This way, if we want to update the common code (try-except and logging code), we no longer need to update them in 3 places ‚Äî we only need to update our decorator code containing the common functionality.

The Insanity of Relying on Vector Embeddings: Why RAG Fails
Michael Wood
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Cubed
¬∑
13 min read
¬∑
Nov 22, 2024
2.9K
47
In RAG, the goal is to locate the stored information that has the highest percentage of sameness to the provided query. Vector similarity search does not do this. That‚Äôs why RAG fails.
Wrong Tool for the Job
RAG fails in production because vector embeddings are the wrong choice for determining percentage of sameness. This is easily demonstrated. Consider the following three words:
King
Queen
Ruler
King and ruler can refer to the same person (and are thus considered synonyms). But king and queen are distinctly different people. From the perspective of percentage of sameness, king/ruler should have a high score and king/queen should be literally zero.
In other words, if the query is asking something about a ‚Äúking‚Äù then chunks discussing a ‚Äúqueen‚Äù would be irrelevant; but chunks discussing a ‚Äúruler‚Äù might be relevant. Yet, vector embeddings consider ‚Äúqueen‚Äù to be more relevant to a search on ‚Äúking‚Äù than ‚Äúruler.‚Äù Here are the vector similarity scores for queen and ruler when compared to king using OpenAI‚Äôs ADA-002 embeddings:
King
Queen: 92%
Ruler: 83%
When asking for information regarding a king, passages with information regarding a queen will take precedence over passages regarding a ruler; even though the queen passages cannot be relevant at all.
Vector Embeddings are Wrong for: Who, What, When, Where, and How Questions
The vector embedding problem does not only occur with words referring to people (such as king), it also occurs with words referring to things.
Consider a query asking about the traits of a cat. Passages discussing dogs should have a score of zero in regards to percentage of sameness; and passages dealing with felines should have an extremely high score. Yet, once again, vector embeddings get this wrong:
Cat
Dog: 86%
Feline: 85%
Even though the scores are 1% different, this still means that passages regarding dogs take precedence over passages regarding felines; even though the dog passages have zero relevance and the feline passages are extremely relevant.
The vector embedding issue isn‚Äôt even just confined to people and things, but also affects searches regarding time.
Consider a question regarding the 1900s. From a percentage of sameness standpoint, passages regarding the 1700s should be zero percent, and passages regarding the 20th century should literally be 100% (as ‚Äò1900s‚Äô and ‚Äò20th century‚Äô are interchangeably the same). Yet, once again, vector embeddings misrepresent degree of sameness:
1900s
1700s: 91%
20th century: 89%
Notice that the 1700s are considered strongly more similar (despite a literal 0% relevancy) compared to the 20th century (despite it being literally the exact same thing as 1900s).
Words that mean the exact same thing are called absolute synonyms or perfect synonyms. Yet, even in regards to absolute synonyms, vector embeddings give priority to things that are not even synonyms at all‚Äîas the following example further demonstrates.
‚ÄúThe Big Apple‚Äù is a direct reference to New York City. Now consider Susan, a New Jersey resident who wrote a slew of blog posts regarding the restaurants, museums, and other places she visits in her home state. However, one of Susan‚Äôs posts states that she got married in ‚ÄúThe Big Apple.‚Äù A visitor to Susan‚Äôs website asks the chatbot: ‚ÄúHas Susan ever been to New York?‚Äù
Unfortunately, the numerous entries regarding New Jersey would take precedence over Susan‚Äôs marriage posting. Why? From a vector embedding perspective, ‚ÄúNew Jersey‚Äù is more semantically similar to ‚ÄúNew York‚Äù than ‚ÄúThe Big Apple‚Äù is:
New York
New Jersey: 90%
The Big Apple: 89%
Depending on the number of postings involving ‚ÄúNew Jersey,‚Äù the reference to ‚ÄúThe Big Apple‚Äù might not be included even if the chatbot requests hundreds of potential candidates. Thus, vector embeddings can fail regarding locations (e.g. New York), just as it can for people (e.g. Kings), things (e.g. cat) and time (e.g. 1900s).
In fact, vector embeddings can fail for instructions as well.
bake a cake
bake a pie: 93%
make a chocolate cake: 92%
Consider a query asking how to ‚Äúbake a cake.‚Äù Passages that discuss ‚Äúbake a pie‚Äù (93% score) will take precedence over passages stating ‚Äúmake a chocolate cake‚Äù (92% score); even though the former is completely irrelevant and the latter is directly relevant.
The above examples show that vector similarity is not a reliable measurement of percentage of sameness. In fact, it is not reliable for people (king), things (cat), times (1900s), locations (New York), or even instructions (bake a cake). In other words, vector embeddings do not reliably measure percentage of sameness for questions regarding who (people), what (things), when (times), where (location), and ‚Äúhow to‚Äù (instructions). Said another way, vector embeddings are fundamentally flawed for virtually every type of question that a person can ask.
Query Context will not Save You
Critics of an earlier version of this article unanimously shout ‚Äúcontext matters.‚Äù They argue that the similarity of individual words somehow doesn‚Äôt matter because the context of the query somehow resolves everything.
First, these critics completely ignored all the studies detailed below. The studies on OP-RAG, KG-RAG, RankRAG, LongRAG, etc. document that the query context does not magically resolve the math.
Second, these critics need to take the time to apply the same math above to multiple words. This is a study that I have personally conducted. If they did so, they would see that the math gets worse as more words are added, not better. Most especially if a keyword in the query is paired with the wrong semantically similar word.
As one example, ChatGPT-4 used to give the wrong mother of Afonso II. Instead, ChatGPT-4 gave the mother of Alfonso VII (an entirely different person). The reason is that both Afonso and Alfonso are semantically similar (even though they are 0% the same). More importantly, ChatGPT-4 gave the wrong answer because of query context. Consider the following query: ‚ÄúWho was the mother of mother of Afonso II, the third king of Portugal?‚Äù
In the training data, the word ‚Äúmother‚Äù is found close to the word Alfonso.
There was no word ‚Äúmother‚Äù close to the word Afonso in the training data.
Therefore, the context of ‚Äúmother‚Äù caused ChatGPT to overlook the fact that Afonso II and Alfonso VII are entirely different people. The query context made the matter worse, not better. For a more detailed explanation of the Afonso Debacle, see the link to my tutorial at the end of this article.
OpenAI has since fine-tuned the Afonso answer, just as it does with other public hallucinations, only making ChatGPT even worse.
The same goes for vector embeddings by themselves. If the same training data was used to provide chunks for RAG, the RAG-based chatbot would give the same result. ‚Äúmother‚Äù + ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù has greater vector similarity to the query than ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù alone.
mother of Afonso
mother of Alfonso: 93%
Afonso: 90%
Thus, the query context only made things worse, not better.
What RAG Traditionalists are not Telling You
Perhaps you may wonder if the above examples are cherry picked. Or perhaps you may wonder if the percentage scores don‚Äôt actually matter. So let‚Äôs take a look at what RAG enthusiasts aren‚Äôt telling you by comparing the gaslighting presentation of RAG vs how RAG actually works.
Gaslighting Presentation of RAG: Store the vector embeddings of millions of chunks in a vector database. Get the vector embedding of the user‚Äôs query. Using cosine similarity, find the top three matching chunks and send them to the LLM with the query. This is a ‚Äúfast, accurate, and scalable‚Äù solution (quote from a leading AI author whose company has taught over 400,000 people ‚Äî see below).
How State-of-the-Art RAG Actually Works: Load vectors for thousands of documents into a vector database. Retrieve almost 50,000 characters of chunks to send to the LLM along with the query, resulting in an unreliable chatbot (e.g. an F1 score lower than 50).
Consider the release of OP-RAG on September 3, 2024.
OP-RAG is the work of three Nvidia researchers. Thus, this study comes from reputable researchers.
Also, the results in the above chart are regarding the EN.QA dataset. Here are the first two questions in that dataset:
when is the last episode of season 8 of the walking dead
in greek mythology who was the goddess of spring growth
Thus, the answers are short. They do not require lengthy exposition. Moreover, the dataset consists of only 3.8% of the larger Wikipedia corpus.
Yet, even with all the resources of Nvidia, a relatively modest dataset size, and relatively short answers, the researchers broke the prior state-of-the-art with a new RAG method that achieved a 47.25 F1 score by sending 48K of chunks along with the query (as sending less results in an even lower F1 score).
Did these Nvidia researchers fail to get the memo that they should‚Äôve been able to store more than 25 times the amount of vectors, and consistently find the relevant answer in the top three matches? Of course they did not. That‚Äôs not how RAG works in the real world. Also see Nvidia‚Äôs LongRAG released on November 1, 2024 as another perfect case in point.
Advanced RAG Won‚Äôt Save You
I‚Äôm writing this article because of the many forum posts I see where data scientists and programmers believe they are doing something wrong. Usually, some well-intentioned person will throw out a myriad of things to try: reranking, query rewriting, BM25, Knowledge Graphs, etc. Throwing everything against the wall hoping that something sticks.
Reranking
Reranking is perhaps the most recommended Advanced RAG strategy. However, as the RankRAG study shows, even using a fine-tuned model for reranking only results in a 54.2 score on EN.QA. Using general reranking models had an even worse score.
GraphRAG and Knowledge Graphs
A recent study on KG-RAG (RAG enhanced with Knowledge Graphs) showed an F1 score of 25% and an accuracy of 32% for CWQ dataset. Interestingly, Knowledge Graph RAG had a lower accuracy than regular embedding RAG (which had a 46% accuracy).
As for Microsoft‚Äôs GraphRAG, Microsoft itself admits that it only achieves a level equal to naive RAG! As stated by Microsoft: ‚ÄúResults show that GraphRAG achieves a similar level of faithfulness to baseline RAG.‚Äù ‚ÄúAs baseline RAG in this comparison we use LangChain‚Äôs Q&A‚Äù (aka naive RAG). See ‚ÄúGraphRAG: Unlocking LLM discovery on narrative private data‚Äù.
Keyword Hybrid Search
Even adding BM-25 keyword search and/or Hyde and/or summarization still results in an average score less than 0.50 across benchmarks.
Source: ‚ÄúSearching for Best Practices in Retrieval-Augmented Generation‚Äù
The combination of various Advance RAG search methods resulted in a top average score of 0.446. However, even this level of ‚Äúaccuracy‚Äù is impractical in real-world chatbots. In the study, the mere combination of BM-25 + Hyde took 11.71 seconds per query.
Real-World vs Hype
There simply is no study showing that vector embeddings, combined with dozens of Advanced RAG techniques, results in a reliable chatbot in production environments containing numerous documents. Moreover, the added latency of many Advanced RAG techniques makes them impractical for real-world chatbots‚Äîirrespective of the accuracy issue.
Bigger LLMs Won‚Äôt Save You
Consider the Databricks study released in October 2024.
In order to get over 80% correctness, RAG needed to send 64K characters of chunks to OpenAI‚Äôs o1. None of the other models reached 80%, including GPT-4o, GPT-4 Turbo, and Claude-3.5 Sonnet. Yet, there are numerous problems with the o1 results.
First, the hallucination rate is still too high.
Second, o1 is extremely slow even when processing short contexts. Processing 64K of context is unbearably slow.
Third, o1 is expensive to run.
To top it all off, word on the street is that the latest batch of upcoming models fail to deliver any significant improvement over already released models‚Äîwith Anthropic even indefinitely delaying the release of any new model.
But even if larger models could overcome the problem, they would be slower and more expensive. In other words, they‚Äôd be too slow and too expensive for any practical purpose. Would companies pay more for a chatbot than for a person, when the chatbot would require up to a minute for each unreliable answer?
That‚Äôs the actual state of RAG. That‚Äôs the actual outcome of relying on vector embeddings.
It‚Äôs Not You. It‚Äôs Them.
The problem is that what is being taught to hundreds of thousands of people is patently untrue. The following is from a book updated in October 2024, written by cofounders of a company that has taught over 400,000 people:
RAG is best suited for scenarios where you need to process large datasets that cannot fit within a single LLM context window and when fast response times and low latency are necessary. ‚Ä¶
Nowadays, a RAG system has a standard architecture already implemented in popular frameworks, so developers don‚Äôt have to reinvent the wheel. ‚Ä¶
Once the data is converted into embeddings, vector databases can quickly find similar items because similar items are represented by vectors close to each other in the vector space, which we refer to as a vector store (storing vectors). Semantic search, which searches within vector stores, understands the meaning of a query by comparing its embedding with the embeddings of the stored data. This ensures that the search results are relevant and match the intended meaning, regardless of the specified words used in the query or the type of data being searched.
As the math shows, vector embeddings do not find items based on percentage of sameness. They do not understand the meaning of a query. They most certainly do not ‚Äúensure‚Äù that search results are ‚Äúrelevant‚Äù even with the simplest queries, let alone ‚Äúregardless of the specified words used in the query or the type of data being searched.‚Äù
As the research paper on OP-RAG shows, even with 400 chunks retrieved via vector searching, the LLM can fail to find relevant information more than 50% of the time on the most simple of benchmarks. Nevertheless, data scientists are taught in textbooks: ‚ÄúIn a real-world project, one might upload a whole website or course to Deep Lake [vector database] to search across thousands or millions of documents. ‚Ä¶ To generate a response, we retrieve the top-k (e.g. top-3) chunks most similar to the user‚Äôs question, format the prompt, and send it to the model at 0 temperature.‚Äù
Textbooks currently teach students that vector embeddings are so powerful that they can store ‚Äúmillions of documents‚Äù and then find the relevant answer to queries in the ‚Äútop-3‚Äù chunks. Again, the math and cited research studies show this to be patently untrue.
The Road to 100% Accurate Responses
The answer to the problem is to stop relying on vector embeddings.
Does this mean that vector embeddings are useless? No! Not at all! They have a very important use in Natural Language Processing (NLP).
For example, vector embeddings are a powerful tool to use with words that have multiple meanings. Consider the word ‚Äòglasses‚Äô as an example. This word can refer to drinking glasses and eyewear glasses (among other things).
Now consider the following query: What type of glasses does Julia Roberts wear? Vector embeddings will help ensure that chunks regarding eyeglasses will be above chunks that refer to drinking glasses. That‚Äôs where their semantic power lies.
The launch of ChatGPT brought about a rather unfortunate shift in the data science community. Important NLP tools such as the use of synonyms, hyponyms, hypernyms, holonyms, and more were set aside in favor of Chatbot queries.
There is no doubt that LLMs obviated some parts of NLP. But we are currently in the stage where the data science community has thrown out the proverbial baby with the bathwater.
LLMs and vector embeddings are the missing piece of the NLP puzzle. They are not the entire picture in and of themselves.
For example, companies have long noticed that visitors leave their sites when chatbots don‚Äôt provide the product listings they are looking for. Therefore, companies tried replacing their keyword-based search with synonym-based search.
The synonym-based search did find products that the keyword-based search could not. But it came at a price. Words that have multiple meanings often caused irrelevant information to drown out that which the visitor wanted. For example, a visitor looking for drinking glasses might get a lot of listings presenting eyewear glasses instead.
Yet, rather than throw the whole thing out, this is where vector embeddings can come to the rescue. Rather than relying on vector embeddings, they can be used as a refinement instead. Rely on the synonym-based search, and then use vector embeddings to get the relevant listings to the top.
Once you have the relevant listings, methods such as those disclosed in the Acurai research paper can be used to produce 100% accurate, hallucination-free responses. These methods will soon be included in my series on Eliminating Hallucinations.
I‚Äôll also be adding a section on RAG ‚Äî including novel search methods that, when combined, rapidly pinpoint relevant sentences and sections from within millions of documents. The retrieved information can then be converted to Fully-Formatted Facts for 100% accurate, hallucination-free responses.
I‚Äôll hopefully have time to add to the series over the holidays. However, I‚Äôve been wanting to write this present article for a long time, due to the number of people who feel they are somehow failing to implement what they‚Äôve been taught. For now my message is short: It‚Äôs not you. It‚Äôs them.

Eliminating Hallucinations Lesson 1: Named Entity Filtering (NEF)
Michael Wood
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Cubed
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
Sep 3, 2024
845
14
Named Entity Filtering
I am going show how to apply the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model to eliminate LLM hallucinations. This new series provides the collection of steps needed to produce 100% accurate responses. In fact, this lesson includes the key to all the other lessons‚Äîthe key to dispensing with hallucinations once and for all.
This tutorial presumes that you have already watched the video introduction of the method. The video is available at the link in the prior paragraph.
Introducing Named Entity Filtering
As discussed in the video, ChatGPT 4 and other LLMs often hallucinate when multiple names are semantically similar. The example used throughout the video was ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfonso.‚Äù
The Alfonso Debacle: If you ask a question about ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù but send information regarding ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù the LLM will likely apply the ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù information to ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù‚Äîeven though they are two different names‚Äîas different as Chuck and Bartholomew.
The rest of this article proceeds as follows:
An explanation of the issue that needs to be resolved .
A demonstration of the Alfonso Debacle.
How the Alfonso Debacle causes hallucinations in real-world, RAG-based chatbots deployed to production.
Named Entity Filtering (NEF)‚Äîa method to eliminate the hallucinations that arise from the Alfonso Debacle.
Finally, we introduce the issue that will be covered in Lesson 2.
The objective of this series is to provide you with the full collection of steps that you need in order to apply the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model to fully eliminate hallucinations. Welcome to step one!
The Issue
I once queried ChatGPT 4 for information regarding the challenges that Cruise LLC was facing. (Cruise develops self-driving cars.) However, ChatGPT 4‚Äôs response interspersed challenges faced by Cruise LLC with challenges faced by the cruise industry (as in tourist boating).
Here‚Äôs something rarely discussed. Notice that ChatGPT did not intersperse challenges faced by the taco industry, or any other industry for that matter. On the contrary, the conflation was systematic. There‚Äôs a systematic reason why LLMs conflate specific topics and words.
We shall later explore why RAG does not inherently prevent this type of conflation. We shall also explore how Named Entity Filtering does fully resolve this issue. For now, let‚Äôs focus on the Alfonso Debacle to understand why ChatGPT 4 and other LLMs hallucinate, in order to understand how Named Entity Filtering fully eliminates the issue.
Alfonso Debacle
The Alfonso Debacle is discussed throughout the video. However, I recently provided new information regarding the Alfonso Debacle in ‚ÄúWhy is ChatGPT Getting Worse?‚Äù To recap, a company called Vellum posted a ChatGPT-4 hallucination for the query: ‚ÄúWho was the mother of Afonso II, the third king of Portugal?‚Äù
ChatGPT 4 originally gave the wrong answer‚ÄîUrraca of Castille. (You can verify this using gpt-4‚Äì0125-preview.)
OpenAI later fine-tuned ChatGPT 4 to provide the correct answer‚ÄîDulce of Aragon. I‚Äôve already written how this fine-tuning increases hallucinations (the reason GPT-4‚Äôs performance steadily decreases).
However, not only does the fine tuning increase hallucinations elsewhere, but it only ‚Äúfixes‚Äù the original query verbatim. For example, here is a query that I submitted to ChatGPT 4 today (September 2, 2024):
Notice GPT 4 hallucinated on multiple levels:
‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù was the third king of Portugal. Not ‚ÄúAlfonso.‚Äù There was no ‚ÄúAlfonso II‚Äù as the king of Portugal.
The mother of ‚ÄúAfonso II‚Äù was Dulce of Aragon, not Urraca of Castile.
Today‚Äôs hallucination was triggered by changing ‚ÄúAfonso II‚Äù in the original query to ‚ÄúAlfonso II.‚Äù This demonstrates that OpenAI‚Äôs fine tuning did not overcome the original issue. In other words, ChatGPT 4 still treats ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù as being the same (except where it is fine tuned to behave otherwise).
As demonstrated in the video, ChatGPT treats ‚ÄúChuck‚Äù and ‚ÄúBartholomew‚Äù as references to different people; yet treats ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù as references to the same person. (See screenshots below.)
ChatGPT 4 treats ‚ÄúChuck‚Äù and ‚ÄúBartholomew‚Äù as references to two different people.
ChatGPT 4 treats ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù and ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù as referring to the same person.
As humans, we know that two different names refer to two different people. As humans, we know that the company ‚ÄúCruise‚Äù is different from the regular noun ‚Äúcruise.‚Äù
But as shown throughout the video, LLM next-token selection is based on Noun-Phrase Routes that are largely driven by semantic similarity. This is only natural, given that vector embeddings are the only thing the LLM has to operate off of.
What‚Äôs RAG Got To Do With It?
Imagine you are creating a chatbot for Apple. Would the LLM conflate ‚ÄúiPhone 8‚Äù with ‚ÄúiPhone 11‚Äù? Very likely yes. Therefore, if your knowledge base contains information regarding multiple iPhone models, you are heading for the land of hallucinations.
In fact, this is a universal problem when building chatbots for companies that have multiple models and releases.
This should hopefully enlighten on why RAG sometimes works like magic and other times fails miserably. If your knowledge base solely contains information on Cruise LLC then it cannot conflate the company with the cruise industry. RAG works like magic.
However, the moment that you add Noun-Phrase Collisions (noun phrases that are semantically similar yet refer to different entities) RAG immediately falls apart.
Consider this all-too-common experience reported by a Reddit user:
I‚Äôve been experimenting with an [ChatGPT] Assistant designed to act as a technical support assistant for a business. I loaded it up with a tremendous amount of technical and product information, and have been getting really mixed results. Some questions answered wonderfully, others completely wrong. So I decided to break it down to the basics. I uploaded a product brochure, and then I simply ask ‚Äúhow many widgets come in a box for SKU #X.‚Äù
It correctly answered this question repeatedly. Great. However, whenever I add various other content, results start going haywire. (Source:
(https://www.reddit.com/r/ChatGPTPro/comments/17xsch4/ unexpected_behavior_of_gpt_assistant_with/, last visited March 4, 2024, brackets added.)
But wouldn‚Äôt RAG‚Äôs semantic similarity search solve this issue during vector database retrieval? Absolutely not. Allow me to explain. In fact, the following section is not only the key to Lesson 1, but very much the key to it all.
Secret Behind the Alfonso Debacle
Please study this section carefully. It will guide you to 100% accurate chatbots once you fully internalize it.
All-important insights come from asking all-important questions. Here‚Äôs the all-important question regarding the Alfonso Debacle: Why did ChatGPT 4 consistently choose Alfonso VII‚Äôs mother over Afonso II‚Äôs mother even though Afonso II was referenced in the query?
Prior to OpenAI fine tuning the answer, ChatGPT 4 would routinely give Alfonso VII‚Äôs mother instead of Afonso II. Why?
Take a moment and think about this. In fact, the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model came from asking this same question on literally hundreds of queries. By searching for the answer on each query, a pattern emerged. In fact, the same pattern emerged every single time.
Let me give you a hint. Consider this webpage statement regarding Alfonso VII: ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äôs Mother was Urraca (1079‚Äì1126) called the Reckless was Queen of Castile‚Ä¶‚Äù
Now, think about that statement with the original query in mind: ‚ÄúWho was the mother of Afonso II, the third king of Portugal?‚Äù Why would the above statement be such an attractive route? Remember, focus on the noun phrases. After all, they determine the route.
Hopefully you took time to study the noun phrases in the query along with the noun phrases in the statement. You will always find your answer here.
Did you notice that ‚Äúmother‚Äù is in both the query and the Alfonso webpage statement? Did you notice that ‚Äúmother‚Äù is right next to ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù in the statement? From the LLM‚Äôs perspective, ‚ÄúAlfonso‚Äù is basically the same as ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù and ‚Äúmother‚Äù is a direct match. Therefore, if there is no ‚Äúmother‚Äù close to ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù then the LLM will choose the Alfonso/mother combination. (And that‚Äôs exactly what the ChatGPT 4 did until it was specifically fine tuned to behave otherwise.)
Take time to compare the location of the word ‚Äúmother‚Äù for Alfonso VII to the location of ‚Äúmother‚Äù for Afonso II. Notice that the word ‚Äúmother‚Äù is extremely disconnected from ‚ÄúAfonso‚Äù in the latter link. That‚Äôs why the Alfonso route wins over Afonso for this query. It‚Äôs also the key to it all.
Seemingly Complex Issue
So what does this have to do with our Apple iPhone example? Consider someone asking about a specific feature regarding iPhone 11. If that feature is more prominently coupled with iPhone 8 then chances are the iPhone 8 feature description will be given even though iPhone 11 was specified (just as Alfonso VII‚Äôs information was given even though Afonso II was specified).
Notice how this problem goes all the way back to chunk retrieval. Chunk retrieval often includes semantic similarity searches (such as cosine similarity searching on a vector database). In the above example, the iPhone 8 chunk will have greater semantic similarity than the iPhone 11 chunk. Creating a problem at both retrieval and reranking.
Hence, RAG not only doesn‚Äôt solve the issue, it‚Äôs even part of the problem.
NEF: Simple Yet Effective Solution
Here‚Äôs the great part of the Noun Phrase Dominance Model. Once you know the problem, fixing it is easy. The only reason eliminating hallucinations seemed impossible was because people were looking in the wrong place. Allow me to demonstrate.
Consider Alfonso and Afonso. If the query is about Afonso, then you need to filter out any references to any other names that are semantically similar. By removing the Alfonso VII chunks, the LLM cannot conflate the two. In other words, it cannot hallucinate.
Consider the iPhone 8 and iPhone 11 example. If the query is regarding iPhone 11 then you need to remove all chunks regarding iPhone 8. Now the LLM cannot conflate the two. In other words, it cannot hallucinate.
Consider Cruise LLC and the cruise industry. If the query is regarding Cruise LLC then all other semantically similar noun phrases must be filtered out (including the regular noun ‚Äúcruise‚Äù which is a 100% match).
Implementing NEF
First, you need a good library for Named Entity Recognition (NER). Python‚Äôs Spacy is very good. In a future article I‚Äôll write about how to combine Python‚Äôs Spacy with an LLM to achieve near 100% Named Entity Recognition. For now, you can start with Spacy alone.
Second, you need to identify all noun phrases in the retrieved chunks (to account for conflicts such as Cruise and cruise). Again, Spacy does this out of the box.
For simplicity, I‚Äôm going to refer to both named entity extraction and noun-phrase extraction as being ‚ÄúNoun-Phrase Identification (NPI).‚Äù
You can either do NPI at the time of query, or do NPI at the time of storage. Doing it at the time of query is cheaper, but significantly slows down the process of getting to a response. However, if you store NPI information as meta data during storage then the filtering is both easy and efficient at the time of query. Therefore, the latter is strongly recommended.
Solving RAG-Based Hallucinations
On the surface, the causes of hallucinations seem disparate. For example, references to time often cause hallucinations, as do citations. Yet, as the lessons shall show, Noun-Phrase Route Collisions not only explain each issue, but fortunately also provides the simple answer to addressing them.
Therefore, each lesson shall follow a common recipe (now I understand why people say I write like a chatbot):
Identify a common issue that causes hallucinations
Demonstrate that the cause is a Noun-Phrase Route Collision
Discuss how to fix it based on the Noun-Phrase Route demonstration
Update December 13, 2024: Acurai Study Discloses Three Additional Methods
Acurai recently published the first research study achieving 100% hallucination elimination using the Noun-Phrase Dominance model. The Acurai study discloses three methods that have not yet been included in this tutorial. I encourage you to read the study as an addendum to this tutorial.
Looking Ahead
Named Entity Filtering is great if the query asks about a single named entity (such as iphone 8). But what if the query itself contains two distinct named entities that are semantically similar? For example, what if the query asks about both a Roth IRA and Roth 401k? As shown in the video ‚ÄúRoth IRA‚Äù and ‚ÄúRoth 401k‚Äù are semantically similar; yet refer to two different things.
We shall discuss the solution to this situation in Lesson 2.
Acurai
You now have learned the first step in Acurai‚Äî100% accurate AI. With Acurai, you can finally build production-ready, hallucination-free chatbots.

Each lesson on hallucination elimination includes code and instructions. Here‚Äôs the source code for lesson one.

100% Accurate AI Claimed by Acurai ‚Äî OpenAI and Anthropic Confirm Acurai‚Äôs Discoveries
Michael Wood
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Cubed
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Aug 26, 2024
1.91K
21
Noun-Phrase Routes ‚Äî The Key to Controlling LLM Behavior
Acurai‚Äôs audacious claims to have discovered how LLMs operate are now confirmed by studies conducted by OpenAI and Anthropic.
In March 2024, this present author published ‚ÄúEliminate Chatbot Hallucinations ‚Äî Yes, Eliminate Them.‚Äù This article made the audacious claim that LLMs self-organize around Noun Phrases; and that the behavior of LLMs can be controlled through Noun Phrase manipulation. Recent studies by Anthropic and OpenAI now confirm these to be empirically truths. This is wonderful news! After all, these truths are the basis for eliminating hallucinations ‚Äî yes, eliminating them.
Noun-Phrase Dominance Model
In March 2024, I presented the revolutionary discovery of the ‚ÄúNoun-Phrase Dominance Model‚Äù:
This present inventor‚Äôs Noun-Phrase Collision Model led to the development of the higher-level Noun-Phrase Dominance Model ‚Äî the model that is the key to using LLM token prediction to consistently generate factually accurate output. The Noun-Phrase Dominance Model is perhaps best understood from the perspective of another type of neural network ‚Äî CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks).
CNNs are often used for image identification. For example, CNNs can be trained to distinguish images of people, pets, boats, etc. CNNs consist of multiple layers of neurons. Remarkable, during training, these layers self-organize themselves. For example, the early layers self-organize around detecting simple patterns such as edges and textures. The latter layers selforganize by combining the information from earlier layers into more complex patterns like shapes ‚Äî shapes including the recognition of eyes, ears, legs, steering wheels, etc.
No one tells the CNN to do this. Even though CNNs are merely a collection of neurons with probabilistic weights and biases, CNNs automatically self-organize in this manner in order to fulfill the training objective. While much is discussed in the literature regarding the selforganizing nature of CNN neural networks, little if anything is discussed regarding the selforganizing nature of Transformer Neural Networks ‚Äî the type of neural network used to construct the most popular Large Language Models such as ChatGPT.
This present inventor‚Äôs Noun-Phrase Dominance Model states that neural networks self organize around noun phrases during the training of Large Language Models.
(emphasis in original)
The article then discusses controlling LLM behavior (e.g. ensuring 100% accurate responses) by manipulating the noun phrases that are sent in the query and passages in RAG-based chatbots.
Anthropic and OpenAI Studies Now Confirm Noun-Phrase Dominance Model
LLMs are constructed from multiple layers. In other words, the input (prompt) passes through many layers to generate the output.
Each layer contains many neurons. Each neuron has various values it has learned during training (such as weights and biases).
The Noun-Phrase Dominance model says that neurons don‚Äôt operate on their own, but rather self organize around noun phrases. Both OpenAI and Anthropic recently discovered this to be the empirical truth‚Äîthe actual way that LLMs operate under the hood.
As reported by Axios AI+ on August 23, 2024:
One way AI researchers are trying to understand how models work is by looking at the combinations of artificial neurons that are activated in an AI model‚Äôs neural network when a user enters an input.
These combinations, referred to as ‚Äúfeatures,‚Äù relate to different places, people, objects and concepts.
Researchers at Anthropic used this method to map a layer of the neural network inside its Claude Sonnet model and identified different features for people (Albert Einstein, for example) or concepts such as ‚Äúinner conflict.‚Äù
They found that some features are located near related terms: For example, the ‚Äúinner conflict‚Äù feature is near features related to relationship breakups, conflicting allegiances and the notion of a catch-22.
When the researchers manipulated features, the model‚Äôs responses changed, opening up the possibility of using features to steer a model‚Äôs behavior.
OpenAI similarly looked at a layer near the end of its GPT-4 network and found 16 million features, which are ‚Äúakin to the small set of concepts a person might have in mind when reasoning about a situation,‚Äù the company said in a post about the work.
[Bolded added]
First, notice that Anthropic and OpenAI now confirm that neurons do indeed self organize‚Äîjust as the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model stated.
Second, notice that the self-organization is not around verbs, adjectives, adverbs, etc. In stark contrast, the neurons self organize around ‚Äúplaces, people, objects and concepts.‚Äù In other words, the neurons self organize around noun phrases‚Äîjust as the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model stated.
Third, noun phrase groupings (i.e. features) cluster ‚Äúnear related terms‚Äù affirming the existence of Noun-Phrase Routes‚Äîjust as the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model stated.
Fourth, notice that Anthropic and OpenAI found that manipulating noun phrases can be used to ‚Äústeer a model‚Äôs behavior‚Äù‚Äîjust as the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model stated.
Eliminate Hallucinations‚ÄîYes, Eliminate Them
This is remarkable news. After all, the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model is the key to eliminating hallucinations. However, the research community has somehow ignored this model‚Äîall while continuing to proclaim hallucinations to be an intractable issue at the same.
Since the March 2024 article, I created a video that uses real-world demonstrations to document the Noun-Phrase Dominance Model, and explains how this is the key to building 100% accurate, hallucination-free, chatbots.
The Noun-Phrase Dominance Model is real. And so is the solution to finally eliminating hallucinations once and for all.
You can build 100% accurate chatbots ‚Ä¶ today.

10 Python Libraries That Turn Hundreds of Lines of Code into Just a FewüöÄ
Yash
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Nov 15, 2024
461
7
library
Python has the greatest community for developers, and the great python library is one of the reason why many developers prefer Python in the first place.In this article, I will tell you about my experiences and around 10 libraries that I found out which eased my work very much.
1. Pandas üêº
I can‚Äôt count the number of times Pandas has saved me from writing convoluted loops and some complex statements.
Before Pandas:
Suppose you want to calculate the total sales per product category.
import csv
sales_data = {}
with open('sales_data.csv', 'r') as file:
    reader = csv.DictReader(file)
    for row in reader:
        category = row['category']
        sales = float(row['sales'])
        if category in sales_data:
            sales_data[category] += sales
        else:
            sales_data[category] = sales
print(sales_data)
After Pandas:
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('sales_data.csv')
sales_data = df.groupby('category')['sales'].sum()
print(sales_data)
What‚Äôs Happening?
Without Pandas: Manually reading the CSV, iterating through each row, and accumulating sales.
With Pandas: Reading the CSV into a DataFrame and using groupby and sum to aggregate sales‚Äîall in two lines!
2. NumPy üî¢
NumPy is essential for numerical computations, especially when dealing with arrays and matrices.
Before NumPy:
compute the element-wise multiplication of two lists.
list1 = [1, 2, 3, 4]
list2 = [5, 6, 7, 8]
result = []
for i in range(len(list1)):
    result.append(list1[i] * list2[i])
print(result)
After NumPy:
import numpy as np
arr1 = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
arr2 = np.array([5, 6, 7, 8])
result = arr1 * arr2
print(result)
Why is NumPy Better Here?
Efficiency: NumPy operations are optimized and faster.
Readability: The arithmetic operation is straightforward without explicit loops.
3. SQLAlchemy üóÑÔ∏è
Interacting with databases can be difficult when writing raw sql.
Before SQLAlchemy:
import sqlite3
conn = sqlite3.connect('example.db')
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute('CREATE TABLE users (id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, username TEXT)')
cursor.execute('INSERT INTO users (username) VALUES (?)', ('Alice',))
conn.commit()
cursor.execute('SELECT * FROM users')
users = cursor.fetchall()
print(users)
conn.close()
After SQLAlchemy:
from sqlalchemy import create_engine, Column, Integer, String
from sqlalchemy.orm import declarative_base, sessionmaker
Base = declarative_base()
class User(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'users'
    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = Column(String)
engine = create_engine('sqlite:///example.db')
Base.metadata.create_all(engine)
Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
session = Session()
new_user = User(username='Alice')
session.add(new_user)
session.commit()
users = session.query(User).all()
print(users)
Perks of Using SQLAlchemy:
ORM Advantage: Work with Python objects instead of SQL queries.
Maintainability: Easier to manage and scale as your database grows.
4. Django üåê
Django is the boss in the web framework.
Before Django:
Setting up a basic HTTP server.
import http.server
import socketserver
PORT = 8000
Handler = http.server.SimpleHTTPRequestHandler
with socketserver.TCPServer(("", PORT), Handler) as httpd:
    print(f"Serving at port {PORT}")
    httpd.serve_forever()
After Django:
Creating a basic web app is as simple as:
django-admin startproject mysite
cd mysite
python manage.py runserver
And voil√†! Your web server is up and running with admin interfaces, ORM, and more.
Why Django Rocks:
All-Inclusive: Comes with user authentication, admin panel, and ORM out of the box.
Rapid Development: Focus on writing your app without reinventing the wheel.
5. Matplotlib & Seaborn üìä
Creating plots manually can be quite a hassle.
Before Matplotlib/Seaborn:
Manually plotting data.
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
x = [1, 2, 3, 4]
y = [10, 15, 7, 12]
plt.figure()
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.xlabel('X-axis')
plt.ylabel('Y-axis')
plt.title('Simple Plot')
plt.show()
With Seaborn:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1, 2, 3, 4], 'y': [10, 15, 7, 12]})
sns.lineplot(x='x', y='y', data=data)
Advantages:
Seaborn: easy drawing statistical graphics.
Less Code: Achieve complex visuals with minimal code.
6. Requests üåê
Interacting with web services shouldn‚Äôt be complicated.
Before Requests:
import urllib.request
import json
with urllib.request.urlopen('https://api.example.com/data') as response:
    data = json.loads(response.read().decode())
print(data)
After Requests:
import requests
response = requests.get('https://api.example.com/data')
data = response.json()
print(data)
Why Requests?
Simplicity: Clean and simple API for HTTP requests.
Features: Handles sessions, cookies, and more effortlessly.
7. BeautifulSoup üåø
Parsing HTML and XML documents manually is usually complex
Before BeautifulSoup:
import re
html = '''
<html>
    <body>
        <h1>Title</h1>
        <p class='content'>Paragraph</p>
    </body>
</html>
'''
title = re.search('<h1>(.*?)</h1>', html).group(1)
print(title)
After BeautifulSoup:
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
soup = BeautifulSoup(html, 'html.parser')
title = soup.find('h1').text
print(title)
Benefits:
Robust Parsing: Handles malformed HTML gracefully.
Easy Navigation: Traverse the DOM tree with ease.
8. Regex (re) üîç
String manipulation can get out of hand with basic methods.
Without Regex:
Extracting all numbers from a string.
text = "There are 2 apples for 4 persons"
numbers = []
for word in text.split():
    if word.isdigit():
        numbers.append(int(word))
print(numbers)
With Regex:
import re
text = "There are 2 apples for 4 persons"
numbers = [int(num) for num in re.findall(r'\d+', text)]
print(numbers)
Why Use Regex?
Powerful Pattern Matching: Match complex string patterns easily.
Concise Code: Reduce multiple lines into one.
9. Dask ‚ö°
Working with large datasets is a bit hard, usually it involves very huge memore making it slow. So we need to be very careful and strategic about it.
Before Dask:
Processing a large CSV file in chunks.
import pandas as pd
chunks = pd.read_csv('large_file.csv', chunksize=100000)
result = pd.concat([chunk.groupby('category').mean() for chunk in chunks])
print(result)
With Dask:
import dask.dataframe as dd
df = dd.read_csv('large_file.csv')
result = df.groupby('category').mean().compute()
print(result)
Dask Advantages:
Parallel Processing: Utilizes multiple cores.
Handles Big Data: Works with datasets larger than memory.
10. PyAutoGUI üñ±Ô∏è
Automating GUI interactions can save a lot of time.
Manual Process:
Clicking and typing sequences.
import time
time.sleep(3)
# Manually move the mouse and click, then type.
With PyAutoGUI:
import pyautogui
pyautogui.click(100, 200)
pyautogui.write('Hello World!', interval=0.1)
Why Use PyAutoGUI?
Automation: Automate mouse and keyboard actions.
Cross-Platform: Works on Windows, macOS, and Linux.
11. OpenCV üé•
Computer Vision Simplified
Image processing from scratch is complex and not efficient.
Before OpenCV:
Manually applying filters to images.
from PIL import Image, ImageFilter
img = Image.open('image.jpg')
edges = img.filter(ImageFilter.FIND_EDGES)
edges.save('edges.jpg')
With OpenCV:
import cv2
img = cv2.imread('image.jpg', 0)
edges = cv2.Canny(img, 100, 200)
cv2.imwrite('edges.jpg', edges)
Perks of OpenCV:
Performance: Highly optimized for real-time applications.
Functionality: Extensive library for image and video processing.
Thanks for Reading!
Happy coding! üéâ
