Forget LangChain, CrewAI and AutoGen ‚Äî Try This Framework and Never Look Back
Kenny Vaneetvelde
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Generative AI
¬∑
11 min read
¬∑
Oct 21, 2024
2.2K
34
Photo by Xavi Cabrera on Unsplash
Frameworks like LangChain, CrewAI, and AutoGen have gained popularity by offering high-level abstractions to build AI systems. However, many developers, myself included, have found these tools to be more of a hindrance than a help, often introducing unnecessary complexity and frustration into the development process.
Enter Atomic Agents ‚Äî a modular, streamlined framework designed to eliminate the headaches associated with existing AI development tools. Built on solid programming paradigms like the Input‚ÄìProcess‚ÄìOutput (IPO) model and the concept of atomicity, Atomic Agents offers a fresh approach that prioritizes simplicity, flexibility, and developer control.
In this article, we‚Äôll delve deep into why Atomic Agents was created, the programming paradigms it embraces, and how it stands out from the crowd. We‚Äôll also share code samples and practical examples to illustrate its effectiveness. If you‚Äôve ever felt overwhelmed or constrained by the complexities of frameworks like LangChain, read on ‚Äî you might just find the solution you‚Äôve been searching for.
The Problem with Existing AI Frameworks
When I first started experimenting with LangChain, I was excited by its promise to simplify the development of AI agents. However, it didn‚Äôt take long for the excitement to wane. The framework is riddled with layers upon layers of abstraction, making it incredibly challenging to understand what‚Äôs happening under the hood.
Simple tasks that should have been straightforward became convoluted nightmares. I found myself navigating through a maze of classes, chains, and utilities, often without clear documentation to guide me. Debugging issues felt like trying to untangle a ball of yarn ‚Äî pulling on one thread just tightened the knots elsewhere.
Moreover, LangChain seemed to be built not by developers who understand the practical challenges of AI development, but perhaps by those more interested in theoretical elegance over real-world usability. The excessive abstraction didn‚Äôt just make development harder; it made it frustratingly opaque.
The Illusion of Magic in CrewAI and AutoGen
Similarly, frameworks like CrewAI and AutoGen attempt to offer ‚Äúmagic‚Äù solutions by automating complex tasks. The idea of deploying swarms of AI agents to handle everything autonomously is alluring, but in practice, these tools often don‚Äôt work right half the time. They overpromise and underdeliver, leaving developers to grapple with unpredictable behaviors and a lack of control.
These frameworks obscure the underlying processes, making it difficult to debug or customize functionalities. The result is a tool that‚Äôs more of a black box than a helpful framework ‚Äî a situation that‚Äôs less than ideal when developing applications that need to be reliable and maintainable.
Overpromising Capabilities: A Common Theme
A recurring issue with these frameworks is the tendency to overpromise capabilities. Companies and tools claim to offer near-AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) solutions, but as someone with 15 years of experience in AI development, I know we‚Äôre just not there yet. The hype often leads to unrealistic expectations, and when the tools inevitably fall short, developers are left dealing with the fallout.
The Need for a Better Approach
After wrestling with these frustrations, it became clear that there was a need for a framework that:
Eliminates unnecessary complexity and abstraction layers.
Provides full control to developers without hiding critical functionalities behind opaque interfaces.
Follows solid, time-tested programming paradigms that promote maintainability and scalability.
Is built by developers, for developers, understanding the real challenges faced in AI development.
This realization led to the creation of Atomic Agents.
Introducing Atomic Agents
Atomic Agents is an open-source framework designed to be as lightweight, modular, and composable as possible. It embraces the principles of the Input‚ÄìProcess‚ÄìOutput (IPO) model and atomicity, ensuring that every component is single-purpose, reusable, and interchangeable.
If you just want to dive into the code straight away, I suggest checking out the quickstart video below:
Why Does Atomic Agents Exist?
Atomic Agents was born out of the necessity to address the shortcomings of existing frameworks. It aims to:
Streamline AI development by providing clear, manageable components.
Eliminate redundant complexity and unnecessary abstractions that plague other frameworks.
Promote flexibility and consistency, allowing developers to focus on building effective AI applications rather than wrestling with the framework itself.
Encourage best practices by gently nudging developers toward modular, maintainable code structures.
By adhering to these principles, Atomic Agents empowers developers to build AI agents and applications that are both powerful and manageable.
The Programming Paradigms Behind Atomic Agents
The Input‚ÄìProcess‚ÄìOutput (IPO) Model
At the core of Atomic Agents lies the Input‚ÄìProcess‚ÄìOutput (IPO) model, a fundamental programming paradigm that structures programs into three distinct phases:
Input: Data is received from the user or another system.
Process: The data is manipulated or transformed.
Output: The processed data is presented as a result.
This model promotes clarity and simplicity, making it easier to understand and manage the flow of data through an application.
In Atomic Agents, this translates to:
Input Schemas: Define the structure and validation rules for incoming data using Pydantic.
Processing Components: Agents and tools perform operations on the data.
Output Schemas: Ensure that the results are structured and validated before being returned.
Atomicity: Building Blocks of Functionality
The concept of atomicity involves breaking down complex systems into their smallest functional parts, or ‚Äúatoms.‚Äù Each atom:
Has a single responsibility, making it easier to understand and maintain.
Is reusable, allowing for components to be used across different parts of an application or even in different projects.
Can be combined with other atoms to build more complex functionalities.
By focusing on atomic components, Atomic Agents promotes a modular architecture that enhances flexibility and scalability.
How Atomic Agents Works
The Anatomy of an Agent
In Atomic Agents, an AI agent is composed of several key components:
System Prompt: Defines the agent‚Äôs behavior and purpose.
Input Schema: Specifies the expected structure of input data.
Output Schema: Defines the structure of the output data.
Memory: Stores conversation history or state information.
Context Providers: Inject dynamic context into the system prompt at runtime.
Tools: External functions or APIs the agent can utilize.
Each component is designed to be modular and interchangeable, adhering to the principles of separation of concerns and single responsibility.
Modularity and Composability
Modularity is at the heart of Atomic Agents. By designing components to be self-contained and focused on a single task, developers can:
Swap out tools or agents without affecting the rest of the system.
Fine-tune individual components, such as system prompts or schemas, without unintended side effects.
Chain agents and tools seamlessly by aligning their input and output schemas.
This modular approach not only makes development more manageable but also enhances the maintainability and scalability of AI applications.
Context Providers: Enhancing Flexibility
Context Providers allow agents to include dynamic data in their system prompts, enhancing their responses based on the latest information.
Example:
from atomic_agents.lib.components.system_prompt_generator import SystemPromptContextProviderBase

class SearchResultsProvider(SystemPromptContextProviderBase):
    def __init__(self, title: str, search_results: List[str]):
        super().__init__(title=title)
        self.search_results = search_results
    def get_info(self) -> str:
        return "\n".join(self.search_results)
# Register the context provider with the agent
agent.register_context_provider("search_results", search_results_provider)
By injecting real-time data into the agent‚Äôs context, you can create more dynamic and responsive AI applications.
Chaining Schemas and Agents
Atomic Agents simplifies the process of chaining agents and tools by aligning their input and output schemas.
Example: Suppose you have a query generation agent and a web search tool. By setting the output schema of the query agent to match the input schema of the search tool, you can directly chain them.
from web_search_agent.tools.searxng_search import SearxNGSearchTool

# Initialize the query agent
query_agent = BaseAgent(
    BaseAgentConfig(
        # ... other configurations ...
        output_schema=SearxNGSearchTool.input_schema,  # Align output schema
    )
)
This design promotes reusability and flexibility, allowing you to easily switch out components or extend functionality.
Why Atomic Agents Is Better Than the Rest
Eliminating Unnecessary Complexity
Unlike frameworks that introduce multiple layers of abstraction, Atomic Agents keeps things straightforward. Each component serves a clear purpose, and there‚Äôs no hidden magic to decipher.
Transparent Architecture: You have full visibility into how data flows through your application.
Easier Debugging: With less complexity, identifying and fixing issues becomes more manageable.
Reduced Learning Curve: Developers can get up to speed quickly without needing to understand convoluted abstractions.
Built by Developers, for Developers
Atomic Agents is designed with real-world development challenges in mind. It embraces time-tested programming paradigms and prioritizes developer experience.
Solid Programming Foundations: By following the IPO model and atomicity, the framework encourages best practices.
Flexibility and Control: Developers have the freedom to customize and extend components as needed.
Community-Driven: As an open-source project, it invites contributions and collaboration from the developer community.
Standalone and Reusable Components
Each part of Atomic Agents can be run independently, promoting reusability and modularity.
Testable in Isolation: Components can be individually tested, ensuring reliability before integration.
Reusable Across Projects: Atomic components can be used in different applications, saving development time.
Easier Maintenance: Isolating functionality reduces the impact of changes and simplifies updates.
Building a Simple AI Agent
We‚Äôll build an AI agent that responds to user queries and suggests follow-up questions.
Step 1: Define Custom Input and Output Schemas
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
from typing import List
from atomic_agents.agents.base_agent import BaseIOSchema

class CustomInputSchema(BaseIOSchema):
    chat_message: str = Field(..., description="The user's input message.")

class CustomOutputSchema(BaseIOSchema):
    chat_message: str = Field(..., description="The agent's response message.")
    suggested_questions: List[str] = Field(..., description="Suggested follow-up questions.")
Step 2: Set Up the System Prompt
from atomic_agents.lib.components.system_prompt_generator import SystemPromptGenerator

system_prompt_generator = SystemPromptGenerator(
    background=[
        "You are a knowledgeable assistant that provides helpful information and suggests follow-up questions."
    ],
    steps=[
        "Analyze the user's input to understand the context and intent.",
        "Provide a relevant and informative response.",
        "Generate 3 suggested follow-up questions."
    ],
    output_instructions=[
        "Ensure clarity and conciseness in your response.",
        "Conclude with 3 relevant suggested questions."
    ]
)
Step 3: Initialize the Agent
from atomic_agents.agents.base_agent import BaseAgent, BaseAgentConfig
import instructor
import openai

# Initialize the agent
agent = BaseAgent(
    config=BaseAgentConfig(
        client=instructor.from_openai(openai.OpenAI(api_key='YOUR_OPENAI_API_KEY')),
        model="gpt-4",
        system_prompt_generator=system_prompt_generator,
        input_schema=CustomInputSchema,
        output_schema=CustomOutputSchema
    )
)
Step 4: Use the Agent
user_input = "Can you explain the benefits of using Atomic Agents?"
input_data = CustomInputSchema(chat_message=user_input)
response = agent.run(input_data)

print(f"Agent: {response.chat_message}")
print("Suggested questions:")
for question in response.suggested_questions:
    print(f"- {question}")
Expected Output:
Agent: Atomic Agents simplifies AI development by providing modular, reusable components based on solid programming paradigms like the IPO model and atomicity.
Suggested questions:
- How does Atomic Agents compare to other AI frameworks?
- Can you provide an example of building an agent with Atomic Agents?
- What are the key features of Atomic Agents that enhance productivity?
Integrating Tools and Context Providers
Suppose we want our agent to perform web searches based on user queries.
Step 1: Download and Set Up the SearxNGSearchTool
Using the Atomic Assembler CLI, we can download the search tool:
atomic
Select the SearxNGSearchTool from the menu and follow the instructions to install dependencies.
Step 2: Integrate the Search Tool
from web_search_agent.tools.searxng_search import SearxNGSearchTool, SearxNGSearchToolConfig

# Initialize the search tool
search_tool = SearxNGSearchTool(config=SearxNGSearchToolConfig(base_url="http://localhost:8080"))
Step 3: Update the Agent to Use the Tool
We can modify the agent to decide when to use the search tool based on the user‚Äôs input.
from typing import Union

class OrchestratorOutputSchema(BaseModel):
    tool: str = Field(..., description="The tool to use: 'search' or 'chat'")
    parameters: Union[SearxNGSearchTool.input_schema, CustomInputSchema] = Field(..., description="Parameters for the selected tool.")
# Modify the agent's logic to output the OrchestratorOutputSchema
# ...
# Execute the selected tool
if response.tool == "search":
    search_results = search_tool.run(response.parameters)
    # Process search results...
else:
    # Use the chat agent as before
    pass
Step 4: Use Context Providers to Include Search Results
class SearchResultsProvider(SystemPromptContextProviderBase):
    def __init__(self, search_results):
        super().__init__(title="Search Results")
        self.search_results = search_results

def get_info(self) -> str:
        return "\n".join(self.search_results)
# After obtaining search results
context_provider = SearchResultsProvider(search_results)
agent.register_context_provider("search_results", context_provider)
This integration allows the agent to provide responses based on real-time web search data.
The Atomic Assembler CLI: Managing Tools Made Easy
One of the standout features of Atomic Agents is the Atomic Assembler CLI, a command-line tool that simplifies the management of tools and agents.
Inspired by some modern tailwind libraries such as shadcn, where you don‚Äôt install the components as dependencies, but rather take ownership over them in your own source code, we do something similar for tools.
What this means is that we will not install the tools as dependencies, using pip, but rather copy them into our project. This can be done in one of two ways:
Manually download the tools or copy/paste their source code from the Atomic Agents GitHub repository and place them in the atomic-forge folder.
The option we will use, the Atomic Assembler CLI to download the tools.
Key Features
Download and Manage Tools: Easily add new tools to your project without manual copying or dependency issues.
Avoid Dependency Clutter: Install only the tools you need, keeping your project lean.
Modify Tools Effortlessly: Each tool is self-contained with its own tests and documentation.
Access Tools Directly: If you prefer, you can manage tools manually by accessing their folders.
Conclusion
Atomic Agents brings a much-needed shift in the AI development landscape by prioritizing simplicity, modularity, and developer control. By embracing solid programming paradigms like the Input‚ÄìProcess‚ÄìOutput model and atomicity, it addresses the frustrations many developers face with existing frameworks like LangChain, CrewAI, and AutoGen.
With Atomic Agents, you can:
Eliminate unnecessary complexity and focus on building effective AI applications.
Gain full control over every component of your system.
Easily swap out or modify components without disrupting the entire application.
Leverage modularity and reusability to enhance productivity and maintainability.
If you‚Äôre tired of wrestling with overcomplicated frameworks that overpromise and underdeliver, it‚Äôs time to give Atomic Agents a try.

Six Years With a Distraction-Free iPhone
(and how to try your own low-stress experiment)
Jake Knapp
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Make Time
¬∑
11 min read
¬∑
Nov 27, 2018
53K
189
All illustrations: Jake Knapp
In 2012, I realized I had a problem. My iPhone made me twitchy. It called to me from my pocket, the way the Ring called Bilbo Baggins.
My moment of clarity happened in my living room. I was sitting on the floor one evening, building train tracks with my kids, when my older son said:
He wasn‚Äôt trying to make me feel bad or anything. He was just curious. But I didn‚Äôt have a good answer. So why was I looking at my iPhone? I didn‚Äôt even remember taking it out ‚Äî it had sort of materialized in my hand. All day, I‚Äôd been looking forward to spending time with my kids, and now that it was finally happening, I wasn‚Äôt really there at all.
I froze for a second. I thought back.
When the iPhone came out, in 2007, it was shiny and beautiful and cool and I flat-out wanted one. But I needed a justification, so I convinced myself that I needed it for work. After all, the iPhone had email, a web browser, and even a stocks app ‚Äî this was a serious tool for serious people!
So I got an iPhone, and just like that, I signed myself up to check and respond to email wherever, whenever. No pay raise, no new job title, not even a request from my boss. For me, this was a 100% self-inflicted responsibility because I wanted a shiny object.
Over the years, as new apps came out ‚Äî Facebook, Instagram, news, games, etc ‚Äî I installed them. They were shiny, they were free, and they helped me ‚Äúget my money‚Äôs worth‚Äù out of my phone. Every app created new responsibilities. More inboxes to check and more feeds to read. Every app latched onto my brain, tethering my phone to my skull with invisible string.
It was all self-inflicted. I was just giving my attention away. If I found it difficult to pay attention to what should have been the highlight of my day, playing with my kids‚Ä¶ I had only myself to blame.
Why exactly did I have an iPhone, anyway?
I‚Äôd never thought about that question before, but the answer was simple: I wanted the iPhone to make my life better. I wanted a futuristic tool and I wanted to be in control of it.
I was angry with myself. I was angry at the phone. I‚Äôd felt guilty about it before‚Äîbut this time I decided to stop feeling guilty and actually do something about it.
With my pulse pounding in my temples, I mashed the screen till the icons wiggled. Then I started deleting those goddamned apps.
I began with the obvious attention thieves. I deleted Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook. I deleted YouTube, ESPN, and all my games. Then I went into the settings and removed Safari. I was like David Bowman in 2001, shutting down the psychotic computer HAL so I could fly the spaceship by myself.
The only thing left was email.
I love email. I‚Äôve loved it ever since I sent my first message back in the early 1990s. I‚Äôd even worked on the Gmail team at Google.
And yet‚Ä¶ I had to admit that email was the very worst distraction on my phone. Hiding behind a guise of necessity, email was an infinite hamster wheel powered by other people‚Äôs priorities.
So I gritted my teeth and deleted Gmail. I even went into settings and deleted my Google account to disable Apple‚Äôs Mail app.
That was it. Just sixty seconds after I‚Äôd begun, HAL was offline and I was on my own.
Revenge was sweet, but after the thrill of destruction, I felt nervous. My iPhone was a shell of its former self. Without my apps, I expected to feel anxiety and isolation. So I told myself it was just an experiment. I would try it for a week ‚Äî after that, I could always re-install my apps.
The first few days were strange. I‚Äôd unlock my phone, only to remember there was nothing to check. Before, getting up-to-date on my apps provided a small sense of accomplishment. Unlock the phone, tap, boom! It was like a sugar rush. Now, the candy was gone.
It was weird, but it was also weirdly‚Ä¶ peaceful. My attention span lengthened. Time slowed down, in a good way. My head was free. Untethered.
I enjoyed having my brain back so much that I didn‚Äôt even notice when the week was up. A month went by, then another, and another. In 2013, a few months into my experiment, I wrote a story about the distraction-free phone, and a year later, in 2014, I wrote another. People seemed really interested ‚Äî a few hundred thousand folks read those posts, by far the most popular thing I‚Äôve ever written before or since.
Some of those readers pointed out‚Äîperhaps rightfully‚Äîthat I‚Äôm a self-righteous moron with no self-control. But many others wrote encouragement. Lots of people actually tried the experiment themselves. Even if they only deleted a few apps, they said it felt great.
It felt great to me too. For me, an iPhone without distracting apps is an amazing device. Mine still has music and podcasts. It has tools straight out of Harry Potter: The Knight Bus (Uber, Lyft) and the Weasleys‚Äô clock (Find Friends). I can read foreign languages with Google Translate. I can talk to Siri, and she (often) understands me. My phone still has fantastic maps and a kick-ass camera. It even has a flashlight!
In short, if you had handed me this device when I was a kid, in the 1980s, I would‚Äôve lost my freaking mind with joy. A distraction-free iPhone is a futuristic tool that I control. It‚Äôs what I really wanted all along.
I‚Äôve had a distraction-free iPhone for six years now. And there have been costs. I lost my reputation for instant email response and immediate task turnaround. Without the tug of my phone, I drifted off of Facebook and lost touch with some friends.
But there were rewards as well. Without infinite friends, I paid better attention to moments with my wife and kids. This, for me, was and is the most important reason to redesign my relationship with my phone. It‚Äôs also very personal and specific to me, so I‚Äôm not going to linger on it.
It‚Äôs the second benefit I want to focus on ‚Äî a very unexpected benefit.
Distraction-Free Is a Competitive Advantage
I‚Äôll be honest with you. As great as it is for me, I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre likely to try a distraction-free phone. And I get it. It sounds nuts to remove functionality from our phones, especially when we‚Äôve all grown accustomed to nonstop connectivity over the last decade.
Still, I really want you to try it. So at the risk of getting preachy (well, what the hell, I probably blew past that a while ago) I‚Äôll give you another reason to delete those apps from your phone.
Here‚Äôs the thing: When I stopped instantly reacting to everyone else‚Äôs priorities, I got better at making time for the projects I believed were most important‚Äîeven if they weren‚Äôt urgent or nobody was asking for them. I invested effort in documenting and promoting my design sprint process. And, after a lifetime of putting it off till ‚Äúsomeday,‚Äù I finally started writing, eventually publishing two books.
How much of my improved output can I attribute to the distraction-free iPhone? A lot, I think. Doing big projects takes many sessions of focused work, added up over time. It‚Äôs like building a pyramid, and every work session is like cutting a block of stone and stacking it on the foundation.
Suppose I‚Äôm in a pyramid-building race with Bizarro Jake, who still has all the apps on his phone. He‚Äôs faster on email and has more Instagram followers, but it‚Äôs harder for him to focus.
Bizarro Jake is reacting to small stuff. Every time I eke out one or two extra blocks of focus, I get ahead. Every time he stops to check his phone, he shatters a block. Research says it takes an average of 23 minutes to get back on task after an interruption ‚Äî that number sounds crazy, but experience tells me it‚Äôs about right.
Bizarro Jake can‚Äôt put his own priorities first. But if I can focus, I can make progress on blog posts, illustrations, slide decks, and book chapters ‚Äî projects that matter to me, even if nobody is asking for them.
This was the biggest difference in my work the last six years. I didn‚Äôt suddenly acquire willpower or self-control. I‚Äôm far from perfect. But without those apps in my pocket, I have a competitive advantage over my prior self.
Don‚Äôt Wait for Big Tech to Solve It For You
Hold on. Apple, Google, and Facebook are all rolling out tools to help us control our screen time. Is the problem already fixed?
I don‚Äôt think so. In my expert opinion as an iPhone addict, these new app timers are too hard to set up and too easy to dismiss, with default time caps that are much too long.
So what if Bizarro Jake cuts his YouTube time from two hours to one, or gets a reminder after 15 minutes on Instagram? He‚Äôll still hear the Ring calling. He‚Äôll keep shattering the blocks of his pyramid. Turning down the firehose a few percent does not create freedom.
If your phone gets in the way of whoever and whatever is important to you, don‚Äôt accept the compromise. Take matters into your own hands and design the phone you want.
Try a Two-Hour Experiment
You don‚Äôt have to make a permanent commitment to a distraction-free phone. Just experiment to see how it feels. I recommend you go all the way and delete every distracting app, so you can feel the simplicity and clarity that comes from having absolutely nothing pulling you towards your phone. Remember‚Äîit is very easy to reinstall all of these apps.
Here‚Äôs what to do:
1. Decide WHY you want more attention.
My reason was paying better attention to my kids. Your reason might be giving more attention to people you care about, or making time for a work project or hobby. Whatever you choose, it helps to have a reason because deleting apps is tough!
2. Set expectations.
Tell colleagues and friends, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm slow to respond because I‚Äôm focusing on something important. Call me if it‚Äôs urgent.‚Äù
3. Delete social media apps.
Keep in mind that you can always check in on another device (laptop, tablet, etc) or reinstall if you really have to.
4. Delete news apps.
It feels like ‚Äúthe responsible thing‚Äù to stay up to date on the nonstop breaking news ‚Äî but we can and should step back.
5. Delete streaming video apps and games.
You can still watch a show or play a game, just add the barrier of installing the app each time (or do it on another device instead).
6. Remove web browsers.
You‚Äôll have to dig for the option in your phone settings. On the iPhone, go into Settings ‚Üí Screen Time ‚Üí Content & Privacy Restrictions ‚Üí Allowed Apps and switch off Safari.
7. Delete email and other ‚Äúproductivity‚Äù messaging apps.
This can be the hardest step (it was for me!) because these apps are tied to work. Yes, some percentage of people ‚Äî on-call doctors, technicians, and so forth ‚Äî actually must respond immediately. But the rest of us should ask: Can it wait till tomorrow? Read about this study which shows you‚Äôll be more efficient (and less stressed!) if you check messages less often.
Give It Two Hours and See How You Feel
Two hours is enough to experience the feeling of freedom. But if you like, try it overnight, or for one day, or even a whole week. However long your experiment is, spend some time on the focal point you chose above (#1) and notice the quality of your attention. I think you‚Äôll find it easier to focus, but I‚Äôm me and you‚Äôre you.
Or, if all of this sounds too intense, start small and just delete the one or two apps that bother you the most, and see how long you can go.
Whatever you try, for however long you try it, a distraction-free phone is not a monastic vow. If you don‚Äôt like it, go back. If you really need an app to do something, just reinstall it ‚Äî it only takes a few moments, and you can always delete it again when you‚Äôre done (or keep it if it doesn‚Äôt bother you). I‚Äôve certainly reinstalled these apps for one reason or another. Each time, I enjoy the app for a few minutes, then feel a wave of relief when I delete it and get my attention back.
That‚Äôs what really matters in the end: being the boss of my attention. Over the last six years, I‚Äôve been able to pay attention to more moments with my wife and kids. More often, I feel like I‚Äôm being the dad I want to be.
Again, in no way do I have it all figured out. It‚Äôs a distracting world out there, and every moment is a battle to focus on what matters. Still, without infinity in my pocket, the odds are in my favor.
You may have more self-control than I do, but if you ever feel bossed around by your phone, don‚Äôt just accept a compromise from the settings panel. Delete those apps and take control.
If
you try a distraction-free experiment, I‚Äôd love to hear about it. Or, hey, if you think I‚Äôm a self-righteous moron, that‚Äôs cool too. Either way, post your comments below. Do Randomly Picked Portfolios Consistently Outperform the Market?
Understanding Why Randomly Generated Stock Portfolios Often Perform Well
Henrique Centieiro & Bee Lee
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Limitless Investor
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Jun 11, 2024
225
3
In
this article, I will cover the effects of variability and randomness on your investments and how you can benefit from them.
In my previous experiments, I‚Äôve shown that my cat Bunbun created 10 random portfolios ‚Äî 6 performed better than the index, and the top random portfolios returned 229%, 187%, and 147% in a 5-year period tested.
But that‚Äôs odd, isn‚Äôt it?
Why do random stock portfolios often outperform both Wall Street fund managers and the S&P 500 index?
How can random portfolios generate such impressive profits? Should we all start making random investments?
And is the popular quote from Burton Malkiel true?
‚ÄúA blindfolded monkey throwing darts at a newspaper‚Äôs financial pages could select a portfolio that would do just as well as one carefully selected by experts.‚Äù
‚Äî Burton Malkiel in the book A Random Walk Down Wall Street
I wanted to test that, but instead of using blindfolded monkeys, I have used my cat.
10 randomly generated portfolios by my cat. Image by the author.
I've created a spreadsheet for you to use if you want to test the random stock portfolios yourself.
But how is it possible that random portfolios often perform so well? Should we all add randomness to our investments?
Why Did Our Random Portfolios Perform So Well?
There are 2 reasons why our randomly picked portfolio performed well:
Randomness doesn‚Äôt care about mental biases. I covered these biases in the previous article.
The second reason is mathematics, which I will cover in this article.
The Mathematics of Exponential Returns Versus Linear Risk
The more random something is, the more it divorces from the average. In this case, randomness in stock picking drives us away from the average returns of the stock market.
Nassim Taleb extensively explored this idea in his book Antifragile‚ÄîThings that Gain from Disorder. You can also check his article Understanding is a Poor Substitute for Convexity.
Someone with a random convex payoff doesn‚Äôt need to be right the majority of the time, as the payoffs are convex, and the upside is higher than the average.
What do I mean by payoffs/returns being convex?
Let me explain with charts.
Portfolio returns increase in an exponential or convex manner with added variability. Image by the author.
The chart above illustrates that portfolio returns will increase with variability‚Äîby adding randomness, such as picking random stocks.
Risk increases linearly as a function of variability; that is, greater variability corresponds to higher risk.
R = aV + b      
Where:
R: risk
V: variability
a: slope of the linear function
b: y-intercept of the linear function
However, the payoff follows a convex function of variability, meaning that as variability increases, the payoff accelerates at a higher rate.
P = x^(yV) 
Where:
P: payoff
V: variability
x: base value
y: exponent
In other words, as variability grows, the payoff grows faster than the risk, leading to potentially higher returns for the same level of increased risk.
For each new unit of risk added to the portfolio, the payoff can increase in a more exponential manner. This is because of the way convex functions work. For each unit of risk, the payout increases by x^yV.
Uncertainty increases the upside more than it increases the downside.
As you can see in the chart above, the least uncertain portfolio would be investing in the S&P 500. Successful fund managers who outperform the index add more upside than risk. However, a random portfolio can often have asymmetric payoffs.
This is what I mean by ‚ÄúThe more random something is, the more it divorces from the average.‚Äù
Embracing Variability: The Mathematical Advantage of Random Portfolios
If you add some randomness to a portfolio, you might have a higher upside, as this variability gets you away from the average ‚Äî in this case, the S&P 500.
The Convex Function of Variability. Image by the author.
Convex Payoffs Benefit from Uncertainty and Disorder
As we saw above, payoffs can accelerate with variability. I‚Äôve simulated 300 random portfolios to show that these asymmetric gains can be very high while the ‚Äúpain‚Äù is always limited.
In my simulations, the worst portfolio returned was -67%, but the best portfolio returned 1,188%. This is what I mean by ‚Äúpain is limited‚Äù while the gains can eventually be high.
This further proves that ‚Äúthe more random something is, the more it divorces from the average,‚Äù as a 1,188% return is far from the S&P 500 average.
Return distribution of 300 randomly generated portfolios. Image by the author.
The convex payoffs also prove that the downside brought by variability is limited while the upside is uncapped.
We can also look at the distribution histogram below to see how the convex distribution plays. While it seems that there‚Äôs a large concentration of random portfolios in the 0% to 25% range and the 25% to 50% range, the reality is that the long distribution across all the other ranges show that 60% of all the 300 portfolios outperformed the S&P 500 index.
Histogram with the 300 portfolio return distribution. Image by the author.
This convex upside can also be explained by Jensen‚Äôs Inequality, which suggests that if the portfolio return is a convex function of the individual asset returns, the expected return of the portfolio will be greater than or equal to the weighted average of the expected returns of the individual assets.
Note that I‚Äôm not saying that a random portfolio will always outperform the index. Please don‚Äôt go all in investing in random portfolios. What I‚Äôm saying is that adding variability to a portfolio has certain mathematical advantages.
Can the Law of Large Numbers Counteract Convex Payoffs?
Individual random portfolios can outperform, but‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs a but.
As we increase the number of random portfolios, their average return will converge towards the index's return.
For example, if we generate 200 random portfolios, their average return would be closer to the index‚Äôs return of 50%. If we further increase the number to 400 random portfolios, the average return would be even closer to the index.
This phenomenon can be explained by the Law of Large Numbers, which states that as the number of observations increases, the average of the results will converge towards the true average. In the context of investing, too many stocks will ‚Äúkill randomness‚Äù by being too diversified, causing the average return to converge to the market average.
The key takeaway is that introducing randomness in stock selection can mitigate the biases often present in traditional stock-picking methods. It is possible to outperform the index by doing so, but the Law of Large Numbers limits this.
In this case, chance stops being chance when you try it hundreds of times.
Conclusion
The analysis of randomly picked portfolios reveals interesting data regarding the role of variability and randomness in investing. Individual random portfolios can outperform the market index, but we need to understand the mathematical principles behind them.
The convex payoff structure of random portfolios allows for potentially higher returns compared to the linear risk increase. This means that as variability grows, the payoff can grow faster than the risk, leading to asymmetric gains.
If you want to play around with random stock portfolio generation, use my Random Stock Portfolio Simulator Google spreadsheet. You might need to request permission, but I will approve it ASAP.

My Cat‚Äôs Randomly Picked Stocks Outshine Wall Street with a 226% Return
How Can Randomly Generated Portfolios Outperform Wall Street?
Henrique Centieiro & Bee Lee
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Limitless Investor
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Jun 4, 2024
343
6
A
fter working in finance for the last 18 years, I finally realized that putting my hard-earned money into actively managed funds isn‚Äôt worth it.
I‚Äôve switched from actively managed funds to index ETFs. These are completely passively managed but still outperform most professional funds.
Staggeringly, 88% of professional fund managers in the US underperform the S&P 500, while 92% of European funds underperform the S&P 350 Europe.
I don‚Äôt understand how big fund managers justify their fees. It‚Äôs baffling why people continue to invest in actively managed funds instead of choosing index ETFs or even randomly picking stocks!
Look, you can hire my cat, Bunbun, to pick your stocks, and she is more likely to perform better than those professional fund managers ‚Äî even though she doesn‚Äôt even have an MBA.
Bunbun is a 2-year-old cat with an extraordinary origin story. We discovered her as a kitten, just a few weeks old, abandoned and dodging cars on one of the busiest streets in Hong Kong, while we were passing by in a taxi.
Now, prepare to be amazed as you see how she has evolved from a vulnerable kitten into a remarkable stock investor ‚Äî her investing skills will blow your mind.
Here‚Äôs Bunbun. Photo by the author.
Here‚Äôs How We Pick Random Stocks
To assist my cat Bunbun in picking stocks, I created a spreadsheet simulator that randomly selects 5 out of 3,524 stocks from the New York Stock Exchange.
The simulator then generates a chart showing each stock‚Äôs performance and another chart comparing the random portfolio to the S&P 500 over a five-year period.
Later, I will show you how to try it yourself, but first, look at these amazing results. I will also explain the mental biases and the mathematics justifying how totally random portfolios can significantly outperform the benchmark.
Bunbun, press the button!
Random Portfolio 1: 173% Return
Incredibly, the first random portfolio generated by Bunbun yielded a 173% return over the tested five-year period, more than tripling our benchmark ‚Äî the S&P 500, which only returned 50%.
Here are the 5 randomly picked stocks. As you can see, these stocks are not the most popular:
Screenshot by the author.
The 5-year portfolio performance of this first simulation is also very impressive. The chart on the left shows the 5 random companies and the S&P 500 (SPY) in navy blue. The chart on the right shows the portfolio performance:
Screenshot by the author.
Pretty impressive, huh? Is this just luck? Or can we replicate it?

The second random portfolio generated by the random tool that BunBun used is a bit lower than the first, returning ‚Äúonly‚Äù 43% and underperforming the index.
I guess the Bank of New York Mellon screws the returns of the portfolio.
Screenshot by the author.
The stocks picked can perform extremely well, around the average, or very poorly. Consequently, the return distribution of our random portfolios is a convex curve.
In this case, as the chart below shows, the portfolio's performance was quite close to the SPY average:
Screenshot by the author.
My dear kitten, can you do better picking the next stocks?
Random Portfolio 3: 226% Return ü§ë
Well done, little kitten! 226% return versus 50% on the S&P 500 is a remarkable result.
If my cat were a Wall Street fund manager, she would have a very nice end-of-year compensation, perhaps something close to $1 million. However, because our stock picker is a cat, and the stocks were picked randomly, she will only get a small dried fish snack. üòø
Screenshot by the author.
Two of the five randomly picked stocks performed extremely well. Howmet Aerospace increased by 205%, and Tesla increased by 855% during the 5-year period.
This, of course, reflects on the total portfolio return:
Screenshot by the author.
I have to promote this kitten to Senior Portfolio Manager of the fund!
Now, let‚Äôs take the random stock simulations a bit further and analyze 10 random portfolios. Let‚Äôs see how they perform.
Simulating 10 Randomly Generated Portfolios
We conducted a simulation to generate 10 random portfolios, comparing their returns to the S&P 500 index. Surprisingly, 6 out of the 10 portfolios outperformed the index, with the 10 portfolios giving us an average return of 92%.
Recall that only 20% of professional fund managers outperform the S&P index. However, 60% of our totally random portfolios have outperformed the index:
Screenshot by the author.
This raises the question:
Can randomly selected portfolios consistently outperform the market index and Wall Street funds?
How can random portfolios perform so well?
There are 2 main reasons:
Randomness doesn‚Äôt care about mental biases.
It‚Äôs mathematical ‚Äî the more random something is, the more it divorces from the average.
Someone with a random convex payoff doesn‚Äôt need to be right the majority of the time, as the payoffs are convex, and the upside is higher than the average.
I will write another article detailing the mathematical reasons why a random portfolio outperforms the average. It will include interesting concepts like the law of large numbers, convex functions, and Jensen‚Äôs Inequality.
For now, let‚Äôs look at the psychological aspect of it.
Why Does My Cat‚Äôs Random Portfolio Perform Better than Wall Street Funds?
Behavioral biases explain well why a randomly picked stock portfolio selected by my cat performs better. A random portfolio is the least biased portfolio anyone can achieve.
Awareness of these 5 biases can make you a better investor:
1. Herd Mentality
Fund managers are pressured to invest in popular stocks with lower growth potential. ‚ÄúNobody Gets Fired For Buying IBM‚Äù is a Wall Street phrase that illustrates this. They should rephrase it to ‚ÄúNobody Gets Fired For Buying IBM, but they should.‚Äù
Conversely, lesser-known stocks can perform better as they are overlooked by stock analysts. This is called the Neglected Firm Effect. Our randomly selected portfolio includes lesser-known stocks that have performed exceptionally well.
2. Loss Aversion
Loss aversion can hurt because investors miss out on potential opportunities by being too risk-averse. As Omar Aguilar, CEO of Charles Schwab Asset Management, mentioned, Investors end up prioritizing losses over earning gains.
A randomly picked portfolio is not subject to this bias, as it does not involve active decision-making.
3. Anchoring
Professional fund managers tend to ‚Äúanchor‚Äù to certain information or a sector or stock analysis. This is what Charlie Munger called the liking/loving tendency: people are likely to invest in companies or industries that they personally like.
The solution to this bias is to be aware that anchoring to certain information or liking something or someone might distort your logic.
4. Doubt-Avoidance Tendency
Fund managers will stick with conventional wisdom and consensus opinions ‚Äî for example, Modern Portfolio Theory and the 60/40 portfolio ‚Äî which leads to a lack of contrarian thinking and failure to identify opportunities that a random portfolio might capture.
Often, to be at the top, you need to be a contrarian.
5. Overconfidence Tendency
Overconfidence is a cognitive bias that can lead fund managers to excessive trading or buying/selling stocks too often. This leads to investors' illusion of control and sub-optimal decision-making.
On the other hand, our randomly chosen portfolio was simply held for 5 years, just like Sleeping Beauty would do.
In simple terms, by removing human emotions from the equation and increasing randomness, we increased the profitability of our investments and the upside of the portfolio.
You Can Also Try My Random Stock Portfolio Simulator!
If you feel like playing around with my random portfolio tool, here‚Äôs how you can do it:
Open my Random Stock Portfolio Simulator Google spreadsheet. You might need to request permission, but I will approve it ASAP.
The first box with stocks generates the random stocks.
You need to copy/paste these stocks to the yellow box. Make sure you use ‚Äúpaste special‚Äù and ‚Äúvalues only.‚Äù See the screenshot below.
After pasting, it takes up to 20 seconds to collect the data and update the charts.
The 2 random stock pickers on the right side don‚Äôt generate any charts but provide you with the random portfolio performance immediately.
Screenshot by the author.
Conclusion
Even if it is not consistently right, a random portfolio can outperform the average, thanks to convex payoffs that move away from averages and mental biases. I will definitely detail this in the next article.
Note that I don‚Äôt advocate for a purely random approach to investing ‚Äî the goal here is to highlight the importance of being aware of behavioral biases and the potential benefits of incorporating elements of randomness in investment strategies.
By understanding these concepts and playing with my Random Stock Portfolio Simulator, you can gain some insights into why randomness improves a portfolio and become a better investor. üèÜ

BE LIMITLESS. HONOR CHALLENGES.
Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, J.K. Rowling: Strategies for Their Top 1% Status
The contrarian strategies that propel the elite to astronomical success.
Henrique Centieiro & Bee Lee
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Be Limitless.
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑

AI image created on MidJourney V6 by the author
M
any motivational gurus overlook a crucial point: success isn‚Äôt solely about productivity and ambition. If you follow the common path, you will likely arrive at the most common of destinations ‚Äî mediocrity.
True innovation and exceptional success often demand a contrarian mindset ‚Äî a willingness to challenge the status quo and take on the road less travelled.
In this article, we‚Äôll explore the three fundamental principles embraced by the top 1% that pave the way to greatness by veering away from the herd mentality. Ambitions are plentiful, but when everyone is mirroring each other‚Äôs actions, uniqueness and excellence become elusive.
Discover how to distinguish yourself as part of the top 1% and break free from the crowd, carving out your own path to extraordinary achievement.
1. The crowd is usually wrong
The first axiom to embrace is that the majority often gets it wrong, so distancing yourself from common ideas is essential.
Consider this: if the majority of people were consistently making optimal health choices, we would see a far greater number of people living to 100. Similarly, if everyone excelled at financial decisions and investing, wealth would be the norm, not the exception.
I once believed that popular choices were inherently good, but that‚Äôs a fallacy.
If most people do XYZ, then you should go against it.
Here‚Äôs why:
The quality of our work and thoughts is shaped by our inputs. Unique inputs are necessary to create something new and achieve what most only dream of. Exceptional results stem from exceptional inputs, while following the crowd only results in mediocrity.
People watch the same TV shows, read the same media, go through the same educational system, and get interested in the same subjects.
It‚Äôs a herd of sheep; they will all have the same average output.
You must refuse to watch TV shows, the latest big Hollywood movie, and the best-selling books. Refuse to eat according to the food pyramid and refuse anything that is considered ‚Äúaverage‚Äù and ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù
Refuse to be part of the crowd.
Instead, embrace the edges and the fringe.
To create something outstanding ‚Äî outstanding health, content, business, and relationships ‚Äî you need to engage with unconventional ideas and cultivate a unique set of habits tailored to success.
Image created by the author with imgflip.
Look around you. Why do you want to be the average? You want to be in the top 1%!
Be divergent!
2. We can control what we can control
The second axiom to being a contrarian is to only spend time with what you can control ‚Äî Focusing on what you can control maximizes your impact by channelling energy into actionable areas rather than on the uncontrollable.
In your life, there must be a very sharp segregation between things you can and cannot control.
‚úÖ 8 things you can control ‚Äî Focus your time here:
Your Actions: Life is a game. Play it the best way possible.
Your Attitude: You are the director of your mind.
Your Beliefs and Values: You are the gardener of your value system. Plant the best seeds only.
Your Virtue: You are the sculpture of the values that guide you.
Your Effort: You are the athlete of this Olympic game called life.
Your Decisions: You are the captain navigating your ship across life‚Äôs ocean.
Your Desires: You are the master of your desires. Not the other way around.
Your Judgments: You are the Sheriff of your mind.
‚ùå8 things you cannot control ‚Äî Don‚Äôt spend time here:
Other People‚Äôs Actions: They might be unpredictable like the wind.
Other People‚Äôs Opinions: They are like a raindrop. They can bother you only if you allow it to bother you.
The Past: Past events are like a history book. Learn with them, but put it back on the shelf.
The Future: A horizon always in motion, never to be caught until it becomes the present.
The Outcome of Your Efforts: You‚Äôre in a partnership with fate; you bring the dedication, and fate brings the results.
Global Events: The economy, natural disasters, and other large-scale events.
The Weather: Daily weather and natural circumstances. You can adapt to it but never control it.
Aging and Death: You can‚Äôt beat death, but you can beat death in life.
You should spend 99% of your time in things YOU CAN CONTROL;
and 1% of the time with things you can‚Äôt control.
3. The majority of very successful people are contrarians
Look at the most successful people you know about. The people who achieved the most in any area of life are definitely not doing the same as the majority.
But being a contrarian doesn‚Äôt mean being different for difference‚Äôs sake.
It‚Äôs about having the courage to pursue a vision regardless of its popularity.
It‚Äôs about critical thinking and having the conviction to follow through on your ideas, even when they go against the crowd.
Elon Musk challenged the auto industry with electric vehicles at Tesla when electric cars were considered impractical and persisted with SpaceX, even when experts didn‚Äôt believe him.
Marie Curie pioneered radioactivity, co-inventing the X-ray and risking her life at a time when women were excluded from scientific research.
Steve Jobs envisioned personal computers when they were only seen as tools for business, and he introduced the iPhone when all mobile phones had a physical keyboard.
Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger practised long-term stock market investing even during periods of widespread market depression.
J.K. Rowling persisted with her idea of a children‚Äôs book about a young wizard, Harry Potter, even after tons of rejection.
Richard Branson started a record label from a church and signed controversial artists like the Rolling Stones. He also entered the airline industry with Virgin Atlantic, challenging established giants.
Oprah Winfrey became the first Black woman billionaire in the media landscape by creating brand new talk show formats.
Mark Zuckerberg launched Facebook as a new social network when social media was not a mainstream concept.
Jeff Bezos started an online bookstore ‚Äî Amazon ‚Äî when e-commerce was in its infancy and no one used to buy books from the internet.
Tim Westergren, Pandora (jewellery brand) founder, was rejected by over 300 investors until he finally got someone to support his business.
None of these people followed the crowd.
None of them settled for the average.
None of them chased climbing the corporate ladder.
None of them followed the advice of the majority.
Contrarianism is about more than just being different ‚Äî it‚Äôs about being right at times when everyone else is convinced you‚Äôre wrong.
It‚Äôs about having the foresight to see where the world is heading, not just where it‚Äôs been. It‚Äôs about holding a deep conviction in your own ideas, even when the world is telling you you‚Äôre mistaken.
The people who change the world are the ones who see a different world than the one that currently exists.
They are the ones willing to take the risks that others avoid and commit to their vision for the long haul.
You will be met with resistance, doubt, haters, and naysayers, but you MUST ignore them.
Conclusion
Contrarianism is a must. If you are reading this, I beg you to look around you.
You have this one and only life ‚Äî what do you want to make of it? Will you settle into the comfort of average, or will you strive to distinguish yourself in the top 1%?
To unlock greatness within yourself, you must understand:
Embrace Uniqueness: Most people have grand ambitions, yet they follow the same path as others, leading to mediocrity. Dare to be different to achieve greatness.
Question the Majority: If the majority were always right, everyone would live exceptional lives, which is not the reality. Always question whatever the majority does.
Focus on Control: Concentrate your energy on what you can influence and let go of what you cannot. This will result in a more effective and fulfilling approach to life and work.
Prepare yourself for resistance and critique, as they are the inevitable companions of a path less travelled. Yet, if you have faith in your vision and persevere, you are paving your way not just to extraordinary accomplishments but also to leaving a legacy that might one day be chronicled in the annals of history ‚Äî or, at the very least, on a lengthy Wikipedia page.
‚Äî Henrique Centieiro üï∫üèª

8 Python Performance Tips I Discovered After Years of Coding in Python
Yash
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Oct 12, 2024
831
8
Hey Everyone!! I wanted to share these Python Performance tips, that i feel that everyone should be aware of, since it took a lot of effort and mistakes for me to learn it. So, here are eight performance tips that have made a real difference in my projects. Dont forget to bookmark them for further reference.
link
1) Use Generators to Save Memory
You know how sometimes you need to process a huge list of items? Like, say, a million records from a database. Many a times, storing and retreiving all this memory might be very resource intensive for our usecase, thats when we can use generators that help us to generate items and hence allocate memory without the need of loading everything at once.
Instead of:
data = [process(item) for item in big_list]
Try:
def data_generator(big_list):
    for item in big_list:
        yield process(item)
for item in data_generator(big_list):
    # Do something with item
I remember the first time I switched to generators ‚Äî it felt like magic. Suddenly, my script wasn‚Äôt hogging all the RAM, and everything just ran smoother.
Pro Tip: Use generator expressions when you can. They‚Äôre like list comprehensions but lazier (in a good way):
data = (process(item) for item in big_list)
2) Utilize Built-in Functions and Libraries
Python‚Äôs standard library is like a treasure chest. Functions like map(), filter(), and modules like itertools and collections are optimized in C and can be faster than custom code.
For example, instead of:
cubed = [x*x*x for x in my_list]
You can use:
import itertools
cubed = map(lambda x: x*x*x, my_list)
You really get to feel the results, when the data that you are processing becomes huge, this will really give you a comfort of writing clean and efficient code
Random Thought: I used to avoid built-ins because I thought writing it myself was cooler. Now I realize that less code means fewer bugs. Go figure.
3) Avoid Global Variables
One key point to understand is that Local Variables are much more flexible, in the sense it difficults to track which module is using the global variables, and it also makes the testing part bit difficult, since for testing, we need to seperate out the responsibilities
Instead of:
counter = 0
def increment():
    global counter
    counter += 1
Try passing variables:
def increment(counter):
    return counter + 1
counter = 0
counter = increment(counter)
I know, globals are tempting for quick scripts, but in larger applications, they can become a performance bottleneck (and a headache).
4) Use List Comprehensions Wisely
List comprehensions are neat, but they can be overused. If you‚Äôre creating a list just to loop over it once, consider using a generator instead.
Bad:
results = [process(x) for x in data]
for result in results:
    # Do something
Better:
for result in (process(x) for x in data):
    # Do something
This way, you don‚Äôt store the entire results list in memory.
Side Note: There was a project where we ran out of memory because of a massive list comprehension. Switching to a generator fixed it.
5) Profile Your Code
I can‚Äôt stress this enough ‚Äî use profiling tools to find bottlenecks. The cProfile module is built into Python and gives you detailed reports.
import cProfile
def main():
    # Your code here
cProfile.run('main()')
By profiling, I found out that a sorting function I wrote was ridiculously inefficient. Replacing it with Python‚Äôs built-in sorted() function saved a ton of time.
6) Opt for Set and Dictionary Lookups
Sets and dictionaries in Python have average-case O(1) lookup time. If you‚Äôre checking for the existence of items, they‚Äôre much faster than lists.
Instead of:
if item in my_list:
    # Do something
Use:
my_set = set(my_list)
if item in my_set:
    # Do something
I had a script that was taking forever, and converting a list to a set reduced the runtime from minutes to seconds.
7) Be Careful with String Concatenation
Building strings in a loop using + or += can be slow because strings are immutable, and each concatenation creates a new string.
Instead of:
result = ''
for s in strings:
    result += s
Use:
result = ''.join(strings)
Or, if you‚Äôre building it piece by piece:
result = []
for s in strings:
    result.append(s)
final_string = ''.join(result)
Trust me, this makes a big difference with large strings.
8) Use Multiple Assignments
This one‚Äôs a small but neat trick. Python can swap variables without a temporary variable, and multiple assignments are faster.
Instead of:
temp = a
a = b
b = temp
Just do:
a, b = b, a
Similarly, unpacking can make your code cleaner and faster:
data = (1, 2, 3)
x, y, z = data
Wrapping Up
These are some tips that I gained over the years after making lots of mistakes. I acknowledge that every project is a bit different, and you really your solution addressing your problem and be mindful of these things whenever you are facing some kind of bottleneck.
Oh, and before I forget: always make sure to test and profile your code after making changes. Sometimes, what we think is an optimization might not have the desired effect.
If you‚Äôve got any cool Python tricks up your sleeve,Please mention in the comments
Happy coding!

How Discord Reduced WebSocket Traffic by half
Lessons in Real-Time Optimization
Yash
¬∑
Follow
Published in
No Nonsense Backend
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Nov 25, 2024
342
3
discord
This weekend, I was reading through one of the tech pages in discord trying to checkout how Discord managed to reduce it‚Äôs websocket traffic by almost half. In this article, I will help to list down my findings and the smart techniques that they used and the lessons that we as a developer can learn to implement in our regular code base.
The Problem
As Discord‚Äôs user base grew, their WebSocket bandwidth usage ballooned, particularly affecting users on mobile devices or slower connections.
The team identified several bottlenecks:
High Bandwidth Usage: JSON, their data format of choice, added unnecessary overhead to WebSocket messages.
Redundant Data Transmission: Full snapshots of data were sent, even when only small parts had changed.
Limited Mobile Performance: Users on restricted networks experienced delays or higher data costs.
Faced with these challenges, Discord‚Äôs engineers set out to optimize WebSocket traffic while maintaining a high-quality user experience.
Discord‚Äôs Approach
Discord tackled these inefficiencies using a multi-pronged strategy:
Switching to Binary Data Formats
Implementing Message Compression
Optimizing Data Synchronization
Utilizing Delta Updates
Let‚Äôs explore each of these steps in detail.
1. Switching to Binary Data Formats
The Problem: JSON, while human-readable, is verbose and increases message sizes.
The Solution: Discord evaluated various binary formats to reduce overhead and landed on MessagePack. It offered a balance of compactness, ease of integration, and speed.
Why MessagePack?
message pack
Compact message sizes compared to JSON.
Easy to integrate with Discord‚Äôs existing tech stack.
Minimal serialization/deserialization performance impact.
Implementation Highlights
On the server-side, Discord used libraries like msgpack-lite to encode messages before sending them over WebSockets. On the client side, decoding these binary messages was straightforward using MessagePack-compatible libraries.
Results:
Message sizes were reduced by 35%.
Serialization and deserialization were efficient, with negligible latency introduced.
2. Implementing Message Compression
The Problem: Even with binary formats, some messages were still too large, particularly those with repetitive structures or data.
The Solution: Discord applied per-message Deflate compression, a widely supported WebSocket extension.
Why Per-Message Deflate?
It compresses WebSocket messages individually.
Supported across most modern WebSocket libraries and browsers.
Discord configured the server and client WebSocket implementations to use this feature, reducing the size of each message sent.
Results:
Bandwidth usage was further reduced by an additional 25%.
Slight increases in CPU usage for compression and decompression were deemed acceptable for the bandwidth gains.
3. Optimizing Data Synchronization
The Problem: Sending full data snapshots meant transmitting large amounts of unchanged data, wasting bandwidth.
The Solution: Discord adopted a more selective synchronization strategy:
Clients cached data locally.
The server sent updates only for fields that had changed.
Example:
Instead of sending an entire user object when only the status changed:
Before Optimization:
{
  "id": 123,
  "name": "Alice",
  "status": "online",
  "lastActive": "2023-10-12T08:00:00Z"
}
After Optimization:
{
  "id": 123,
  "status": "away"
}
Results:
Reduced message frequency and size.
Ensured client data was always up-to-date without unnecessary transmissions.
4. Utilizing Delta Updates
The Problem: Even with selective updates, some structures (e.g., lists of items) were too large to transmit efficiently.
The Solution: Discord implemented delta updates, which transmit only the differences between the current and previous state.
Example with JSON Patch:
Original data: { items: [1, 2, 3, 4] }
Updated data: { items: [1, 2, 4, 5] }
The delta:
[
  { "op": "replace", "path": "/items/2", "value": 4 },
  { "op": "add", "path": "/items/3", "value": 5 }
]
Clients applied these deltas to reconstruct the full data on their side.
Results:
Minimized data transfer.
Faster client-side updates.
Challenges and Their Solutions
1. Increased Complexity
Issue: Moving to binary formats and delta updates increased code complexity.
Solution:
Discord abstracted the serialization/deserialization logic into reusable modules.
Rigorous testing ensured reliability and prevented regressions.
2. Compatibility with Older Clients
Issue: Some older clients couldn‚Äôt support new features like MessagePack or compression.
Solution:
Discord introduced version negotiation during the WebSocket handshake.
Older clients defaulted to JSON or uncompressed data.
3. Debugging Binary Data
Issue: Binary formats aren‚Äôt human-readable, complicating debugging.
Solution:
Discord built internal tools to decode and log binary messages in a readable format.
They used JSON during development for easier inspection.
The Results
Discord‚Äôs optimizations led to remarkable results:
50% Reduction in WebSocket Traffic: Bandwidth usage was cut in half.
Improved Mobile Experience: Faster updates and lower data usage for mobile users.
Cost Savings: Lower bandwidth costs and reduced server load.
Lessons for Real-Time Applications
Discord‚Äôs experience offers valuable lessons for any real-time system:
Data Format Matters: Choosing a more efficient format like MessagePack or Protobuf can significantly reduce message sizes.
Compression Pays Off: Even small gains from compression can add up in high-traffic systems.
Selective Updates Are Essential: Avoid sending redundant data ‚Äî send only what‚Äôs necessary.
Backward Compatibility Is Crucial: Always consider older clients when making protocol changes.
Profiling and Testing Are Key: Analyze your system‚Äôs traffic patterns to identify the biggest bottlenecks.
Conclusion
For developers working on real-time systems, Discord‚Äôs journey serves as both a blueprint and an inspiration. With the right tools, techniques, and mindset, significant improvements are within reach.
If you‚Äôre tackling similar challenges, take a page from Discord‚Äôs playbook ‚Äî you might just uncover optimizations that transform your application.
Thanks for sticking with me till the end! If you enjoyed this content and want to support my work, the best ways are:
Follow me here on Medium.
Connect with me on LinkedIn.<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
Why Your Phone‚Äôs Old Tech Is Perfect For The Moon
Earth‚Äôs ‚Äúoutdated‚Äù technology is about to power humanity‚Äôs next giant leap ‚Äî and as someone in telecom, I couldn‚Äôt be more excited about why this makes perfect sense.
Anu
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Code Like A Girl
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
4 hours ago
56
1
Photo by Ryan Loughlin on Unsplash
Scrolling through The Economist today, I came across an article on 2025 implausible possible reality ‚Äî Installing 4G networks on the moon. Working in telecom, I found the news particularly intriguing.
From Fiction to Reality
Following my first instinct, I googled to check how much of this was true. I mean, could we really use terrestrial comms for the moon? Turns out yes. Nokiaand NASA have partnered to bring connectivity to our terrestrial neighbour ‚Äî 4G deployment is expected to happen on the moon in 2025. This is part of NASA‚Äôs ambitious Artemis plan to establish a sustainable human presence on the moon.
The more I dug into this, the more fascinated I became with the pragmatism behind what initially seemed like an outlandish idea. Why 4G, I wondered? We are deep into 5G on Earth and are talking about 6G, but on the moon, a new frontier, we are talking about not a custom tech but almost yesterday‚Äôs technology.
As with most things in life, the answer lies in the wisdom of choosing reliable over flashy.
Currently, lunar communications rely on direct radio links with Earth‚Äôs Deep Space Network, which limits bandwidth and requires massive power. The Artemis missions need something more robust and Earth-like.
4G works ‚Äî it is battle-tested, reliable and has proven itself at almost all corners including the remotest parts of the earth. The core job needed is M2M connectivity and 4G is more than enough for it. It will even happily support the video and picture feeds from the rover.
Building The Moon‚Äôs First Network
The actual deployment plan reads like science fiction translated into engineering specs. Nokia and NASA are essentially creating cellular neighbourhoods on the moon, much like how we set up new network towers on Earth.
The base station, specially hardened to handle the moon‚Äôs brutal temperature swings (-173¬∞C to +127¬∞C), will provide coverage for about 5 kilometres around the landing site. Solar arrays with robust battery systems will keep everything powered, even during the long lunar nights.
The communication chain itself is beautifully simple yet mind-bogglingly complex. Earth‚Äôs Deep Space Network ‚Äî think of it as a cosmic version of those old TV antennas but exponentially more sophisticated ‚Äî will talk directly to a hardened base station on the moon. No satellite middle-man needed. It‚Äôs like having a very, very long-distance Wi-Fi connection, where Earth‚Äôs giant radio dishes act as our router and the lunar base station as the moon‚Äôs receiver.
The Physics We Can‚Äôt Escape
But here‚Äôs the humbling part ‚Äî despite all our technological prowess, we can‚Äôt escape the fundamental rules of physics. Light (and therefore our radio signals) takes about 1.3 seconds to travel from Earth to the moon. That means a minimum round-trip time of 2.6 seconds for any communication.
It is nature‚Äôs way of gently reminding us that while we can build networks across space, some distances will always remain.
Looking Up
Perhaps what fascinates me most is how this project reveals our species‚Äô constant drive to make the alien familiar. We‚Äôre not just exploring the moon anymore, we‚Äôre making it accessible. Soon, the moon will be just another ‚Äòlocation‚Äô on our social media feeds, lunar sunset photos casually mixed with Earth-bound vacation shots.
As I sit in my balcony tonight, looking across the darkening sky, I can‚Äôt help but marvel at this intersection of mundane and extraordinary.
We‚Äôre using the same technology that helps us order groceries to establish humanity‚Äôs first permanent presence beyond Earth. There‚Äôs something both humbling and inspiring about that.
How far do you think we will see humanity progress in our lifetime?<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
Stop ‚ÄòCracking‚Äô Interviews: An Unexpected Leadership Lesson
The difference between performing in interviews and building a vision for the future
Anu
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Career Paths
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Dec 24, 2024
27
1
Photo by Magnet.me on Unsplash
Over years of school and then subsequent job hunts, we start internalising that job interviews are performances ‚Äî carefully choreographed to match the rhythm of the organisation we seek to join.
Like an actor preparing for a movie, it starts off by polishing the resume, rehearsing the script of our achievements and strategising how to present our best selves. This keeps getting reinforced through countless LinkedIn posts and career advice articles.
But sometimes wisdom finds you in unexpected ways. Recently, watching my mentor navigate his job search shattered this long-held notion.
The Quiet Confidence of Experience: Rewriting the Rules
While I expected to see the familiar preparation ritual ‚Äî the mock interviews, the company research, the case study presentations, the carefully crafted responses ‚Äî what I witnessed instead was something entirely different.
I found myself helping him prepare for a case study presentation. He needed to present an analysis of the industry context and recommend the way forward for the organization. It involved an industry outside his immediate expertise, a situation that would‚Äôve sent me into a spiral of frantic research and anxious preparation.
Yet his approach was almost jarringly calm. I was worried about his need to master industry trends and metrics and saw gaps in knowledge that needed to be filled, he saw spaces where vision could flourish.
‚ÄòThe trends will change,‚Äô he said, picking up just enough to understand the landscape. ‚ÄòWhat matters is what we build with them.‚Äô
My mentor approached each conversation not as an examination to ace, but as an architect approaching a new site ‚Äî with vision, curiosity, and a blueprint for what could be built there.
Legacy vs Performance: The Long Game of Career Building
My mentor was not focused on proving his worth ‚Äî decades of impactful work had already done that. Each interview to him was less about answering questions and more about exploring if his blueprint for the future aligned with the canvas the company offered.
It reminds me of the difference between a traveler checking into a hotel and an architect surveying land for a home. The traveler focuses on making a good impression to secure a comfortable room for the night. The architect, however, looks deeper ‚Äî at the soil, the surroundings, the potential for what could be built there over years.
What this really taught me is the evolution needed as we progress in our careers.
Early in our careers, when we‚Äôre looking to join teams where the vision and direction are already set, approach 1 i.e. treating the interview as a test makes sense ‚Äî we need to show we can execute what needs to be done.
However, as we evolve our role changes. We need to evolve into architects who can present their own blueprints. The conversation thus is about future possibilities.
When we focus solely on ‚Äòcracking‚Äô interviews, we might land roles that look good on paper but don‚Äôt align with our deeper aspirations. We might find ourselves in buildings we didn‚Äôt design, trying to make homes in spaces that weren‚Äôt meant for our dreams.
The mirror of growth: reflecting on my own journey
As I sit here writing this, preparing for my own upcoming performance review, I find myself pausing. How many times have I approached career conversations focusing on proving what I‚Äôve done rather than sharing what I dream of building? How often have I let the need to appear expert overshadow the power of being a visionary?
Perhaps the true measure of professional growth isn‚Äôt in how well we can perform in these moments of evaluation, but in how confidently we can share our vision for the future. In watching my mentor, I realized that the most compelling story we can tell isn‚Äôt about our past achievements, but about the futures we can imagine and help create.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight
