A Python Library that Changed Everything
Write less error-prone code
Mohammed Ayar
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Sep 16, 2024
755
8
Image credits: Ideogram
Table of Content:

  Intro
  Dynamic Typing
  Different Opinions
  Type Checkers
  Setup
    #1. VS Code
  Configuration
    #Tip 1. Enable strict mode
    #Tip 2. Detect incorrect flags
    #Tip 3. Suppressing errors
  Recap
Intro
Python is often hailed as one of the most beginner-friendly programming languages.
I used to believe that Python is less error-prone. Some folks said otherwise.
‚ÄúExcuse me, what? Dynamically typed languages are less error-prone than statically-typed? Sorry, but, not in my 21 years of software development.‚Äù
NB: For anyone not familiar with statically and dynamically typed languages, hold your horses, I will come back to this later.
At the time, I didn‚Äôt agree.
Not anymore.
Work that falls in my lap now is at a completely different scale and complexity than what it was before. Or rather wasn‚Äôt.
When you start dealing with large codebases that have hundreds or thousands of dependencies, tracking down error sources is tantamount to eating glass.
Perhaps that‚Äôs why some daddy programmers might consider Python a toy language. A bit of an exaggerated statement if you ask me. Yet there‚Äôs some truth to it.
So what‚Äôs the problem?
Dynamic Typing
I read somewhere that Python's strengths are also its weaknesses.
I agree with that.
Here we‚Äôre talking about dynamic typing.
Without getting too technical, dynamic typing is a language feature that allows a variable type to change during its lifetime.
For example, in Python we can do:
name = "Alex"
name = 1
All is fine and dandy!
In C# however, if we do:
string name = "Alex";
name = 1; 
The compiler will shout and throw:
‚ÄúCannot implicitly convert type ‚Äòint‚Äô to ‚Äòstring‚Äô ‚Äô‚Äô
In this scenario type mutation is strictly prohibited, which is what we call static typing.
Different Opinions
Static typing vs. dynamic typing is what polarizes the audience.
The right says:
‚ÄúAnother error! No way. Keep it to yourself! It‚Äôs too restrictive. Not only will I end up with a ton of errors but also more lines of code as I create new variables to accommodate for the type change.‚Äù
The left argues:
‚Äú I want to have full control over my code. I want to be yelled at the smallest error‚Äù.
Which to follow depends on your coding style, preference, or simply what makes your life easier.
I, personally, used to be a righty, but now I'm a proud lefty ‚Äî I‚Äôd like to have more control over the code I write.
I now spend more time writing statically typed code. But that‚Äôs okay because I get that back in spades during debugging.
The question now becomes, Python is no C#. It is dynamically typed by design. How do I use it like a statically typed language?
Type Checkers
To make Python behave like a statically typed language, use a type checker.
A type checker is a helper tool that allows developers to write correctly typed code by issuing warnings when variables and functions contain incorrect types.
My type checker of choice is mypy.
Out-of-the-box mypy acts as a linter.
Linting highlights semantic and stylistic problems in your Python source code, which often helps you identify and correct subtle programming errors or coding practices that can lead to errors.
This provides a similar development experience to that of statically typed languages except that this behavior is not enforced by the Python runtime.
This means that mypycan shout as loud as it can and the code would, unlike a compiler, still run like nothing happened.
For example, with type hints, the following function:
def greeting(name):
    return 'Hello ' + name
Becomes this:
def greeting(name: str) -> str:
    return 'Hello ' + name
While the second is verbose, it spells out more info (the expected argument types and the return type) about the function.
Say, for example, you wind up returning an integer instead of a string, which was part of your design, mypy will complain.
The question now becomes, how to set mypy up?
Setup
The process of setting up mypy in your IDE is pretty straightforward:
First, run the following pip cmd:
pip install mypy
Then depending on your IDE, select mypy as your default Python linter.
From here on out, I‚Äôd have to show you the rest of the configuration through the lens of VS Code ‚Äî excuse my limited exposure to the other IDEs.
1#. VS Code
In VS Code, Microsoft‚Äôs Python extension used to provide linting capabilities compatible with mypy.
However, as of April 2022, the team slightly changed release course and decided to start shipping some of the tools that were previously offered as part of the global Python extension separately.
The new extension that provides support mypy is the following:
Mypy Type Checker Extension
Once the above extension and mypy are installed, you‚Äôre all set up to receive warnings for incorrect usage of types.
But before jumping to code, a little tweaking is needed.
Configuration
The good news about mypy is that it‚Äôs very configurable.
mypy supports reading configuration settings from a file with the following precedence order:
1. ./mypy.i

2. ./.mypy.ini

3. ./pyproject.toml

4. ./setup.cfg

5. $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/mypy/config

6. ~/.config/mypy/config

7. ~/.mypy.ini
NB: Be careful, the syntax of .ini and .toml files varies slightly.
All you need to do is create the config file. In most cases, creating a mypy.ini file in your project directory is enough to get the job done.
Then you can refer to mypy config docs to have mypy behave however you want.
But in case you don‚Äôt have time or reading docs causes you a headache, here are a few tips for mypy before writing your first line of code.
#Tip 1. Enable strict mode
The main feature you‚Äôd want to make sure your type checker handles is swinging warnings your way when you don‚Äôt use type hints altogether.
For this, enable strict mode in your config file:
[mypy]
strict = true
#Tip 2. Detect incorrect flags
You‚Äôd also want to be alerted if you use a config incorrectly.
This line does the job.
[mypy]
warn_unused_configs = True
#Tip 3. Suppressing errors
mypy is not quite there yet in terms of type inferences for language features such as list comprehension making suppressing errors, though not recommended, inevitable.
This can be done simply by adding this comment at the end of the problematic line:
# type: ignore
Recap
Python has gone a long way ever since it was first introduced in 1991. Type hinting/checking is one of those innovations that aim to close the gap between Python development experience and that of the likes of C# and C++.
While using a type checker such as mypy may initially seem like a waste of time due to its verbosity, the potential gains in terms of readability, maintainability, and debugging make that a well-invested time instead.
So add mypyto your toolbox so that you stop coding like a kid, and start coding like the big dogs!

Last month, I had to change my credit card that made me miss my payment for OpenAI. I had seen a promotion to activate Gemini Advanced at the same time for half the price for two months. If you are not able to visualise the content until the end, I invite you to take a look here to catch-up, bookmark the page and subscribe to Jonathan Mondaut for more!
My usage of Gemini presented here is my everyday life usage, I am an Engineering Manager that is working in a Digital Business Transformation agency working on AI and big companies productivity optimisation. User Interface
First impression for me when I got on Gemini was that the interface does not seem very comfortable for me probably because I am too used to ChatGPT. It looks clean, but chunky and empty to me especially when I compare mobile versions of ChatGPT and Gemini.

Gemini model list

With ChatGPT, making Custom GPT to extend the possibilities with custom instructions and tools that the model can use, and you can even implement an interface to an API. You even have a Custom GPT Builder chat to help you make them instinctively.
Gems are the equivalent of Custom GPTs. They feel quite limited and not very intuitive to make. It is integrated in Gmail and Google Drive, but so far it didn‚Äôt helped me much because the actions it can take and what I expected to do with it didn‚Äôt match. I expected I could manage all my mails with a prompt to tidy up my 10 000+ unread mails, but all I got was a prompt to filter by name, and it was not very accurate.
Gemini can‚Äôt help sorting mail in Gmail
Goodbye Gemini
So far, Gemini is not up to what I expected. Maybe I am too biased from using ChatGPT extensively. I will be back on the other side while watching it improve. GAMING | ART | BOOKS
Artpunk Will Save Your Doomed Soul
M√∂rk Borg, H≈çL, and the savage subversion of tabletop roleplaying games
Oscar
¬∑
Follow
Published in
The Ugly Monster
¬∑
20 min read
¬∑
1 day ago
72
Credits: Rowan, Rook, and Decard; Stockholm Kartell; Momatoes
What the Hell is ‚ÄúArtpunk‚Äù?
If Ralph Steadman had illustrated and laid out the Dungeons & Dragons core rulebooks, you‚Äôd have something resembling artpunk. Artpunk roleplaying games shamelessly defy most design conventions by prioritizing presentation over procedures and mood over mechanics. They‚Äôre often about the end of the world.
Artpunk games are normally art-heavy, rules-light, and anti-tradition. They rely on visuals more than text to set the stage. Illustrations and fonts and layout convey mood and setting and lore. A picture is worth a thousand words.
The rules are usually lean and mean and stats are fairly minimalistic. They are also staunchly anti-simulationist. The designers are not at all interested in simulating the real world, or even a fictional world. Verisimilitude in make-believe isn‚Äôt worth the hassle.
This anti-simulationism makes starting up a game a joy instead of a chore. Artpunk games are neither math- or procedure-heavy, and they‚Äôre low-prep and low-commitment. You‚Äôre not going to play an artpunk game for years on end, and the game master is not going to waste hours prepping for each session. Nobody‚Äôs got time for that anymore.
Artpunk is mostly in the eye of the beholder. If the art is freakish, the layout is exciting, and the rules are simple, it‚Äôs probably artpunk. But those conventions are not set in stone. Some spell out their setting like a traditional roleplaying game. Some are rules-medium ‚Äî although I‚Äôve yet to see a rules-heavy artpunk game. And some aren‚Äôt even gonzo studies in nihilism.
Credit: Stockholm Kartell
M√∂rk Borg ‚Äî Artpunk is Born
There are one or two older games that can be retroactively called artpunk, but M√∂rk Borg coined the term as a TTRPG style. This grimdark medieval fantasy game ‚Äî with its visually sadistic illustrations, jarring color schemes, erratic page layout, and seemingly arbitrary fonts ‚Äî turned the TTRPG scene on its head.
Black and sickly yellow make up a lot of M√∂rk Borg‚Äôs color pallet, along with a shade of pink that is neither warm nor sexy. Blues and reds occasionally invade a page here or there, but it will always come back to poison-yellow and a lot of black.
The fonts are ALL over the place, from plain type to messy paintbrush to cracked old-timey lettering. Any death metal band would be proud to include the monster illustrations on their album cover. There‚Äôs one photo, and it‚Äôs of an actual heart.
Credit: Stockholm Kartell
The entire book is abhorrently beautiful and if you aren‚Äôt either repulsed or engrossed by it, you don‚Äôt have a soul. But it doesn‚Äôt matter if you love it or hate it because you won‚Äôt have to endure this pitch black world for long.
‚ÄúThe world trembles. One can feel it in ways sharp and subtle, mysterious and clear. One by one, inevitable events demand their place.
Illustrating this, the Game Master (GM) rolls a die each dawn. A result of 1 activates one Misery. The die used is determined by the GM and the group.
The GM then rolls d66 to determine which Misery occurs. The same Misery will not befall the world twice.
The seventh Misery will always be 7:7, and the world finally dies. The seventh seal is broken for the seventh and final time.
The game and your lives end here. Burn the book.‚Äù
‚Äî M√∂rk Borg, page 16
M√∂rk Borg is meant to end sooner than later. This departs drastically from traditional roleplaying games. Most games either go on until they fizzle out or end with a proper finale. But M√∂rk Borg just ends, regardless of what the player-characters were doing or what the GM had in store for the future.
M√∂rk Borg straight up mollywhopped the 2020 field of ENnie Award contenders, and fascinated and offended the TTRPG space in equal measure. A lot of trad gamers hated M√∂rk Borg with an impotent fury that was both shocking and cringe. This included OSR gamers, even though the rules were very much in the OSR style.
One of the many complaints about M√∂rk Borg was how much space the art took up, as if the art robbed the book of rules. These critics felt that the aesthetics out-shined what makes a roleplaying game a roleplaying game. Unless I totally missed it, Stockholm Kartell ‚Äî the studio that birthed this ludic monstrosity ‚Äî never felt the need to defend their creative choices. Nor should they. Life is too short to waste on philistines.
M√∂rk Borg‚Äôs kind of world-ending mechanics were unheard of in TTRPGs. A story‚Äôs potential no longer mattered. A character‚Äôs development no longer mattered. A game master‚Äôs plans no longer mattered. A player‚Äôs expectations no longer mattered. Gamers were used to having their characters die or fail in whatever grand mission they were on, but never did the world end without at least some kind of battle with some evil-doer. But in this game, defeating the bad guy means nothing. The world of M√∂rk Borg doesn‚Äôt care. It is going to end whether you like it or not.
But the game wasn‚Äôt joyless or miserable. Far from it. The inevitable cataclysm was freeing, and the doom-metal-ness of it all was an absolute hoot. Regardless of whether players took the game seriously or as a big joke, M√∂rk Borg‚Äôs embedded nihilism provided a whole new kind of sandbox to play in.
Credit: Momatoes
ARC: Doom Roleplaying ‚Äî Every Spread is a Painting
If M√∂rk Borg looks like a metal album, then ARC is an art show. The dreamlike artwork points to fantasy or mythic settings, but there‚Äôs no default setting. Every campaign is stand-alone.
ARC isn‚Äôt as art-heavy as M√∂rk Borg, and the type is fairly consistent. Still, the illustrations are bold and wildly wondrous. The art frames the text without overtaking it, yet still refuses to be cordoned-off completely ‚Äî except in the appendices.
The color palette is best described as ‚Äúlush‚Äù. Deep blues, reds, and yellows are common. These are used both in the art and occasionally as background, mostly to frame key text. The whole color scheme has an earthy vibe to it.
Credit: Momatoes
ARC‚Äôs aesthetic is disturbing and enchanting. There‚Äôs an unstated fragility to everything represented in the artwork. This fragility reinforces the game‚Äôs overarching message: we‚Äôre running out of time.
‚ÄúThe DOOMSDAY CLOCK charts the apocalypse‚Äôs inevitable approach, advancing at set time intervals. Once it reaches its end the DOOM is unleashed.
The DOOMSDAY CLOCK is made up of discrete intervals called MOMENTS. Its speed and number depend on how long you intend to run the game.‚Äù
‚Äî ARC: Doom Roleplaying, page 32
ARC‚Äôs primary mechanical gimmick is a sorta-real-time Doomsday Clock that counts down to the end of the world. The typical Doomsday Clock has nine Moments. Every half-hour of real time, the players lose at least one moment ‚Äî maybe more, depending on how many apocalyptic Omens haven‚Äôt been resolved by the player-characters. If you run out of Moments without resolving all the Omens, the Doom arrives. Most roleplaying games have no such mechanics. Normally, time passes at whatever rate the game master says it does.
Because of the themes of immediacy and the clock mechanics, ARC never overstays its welcome. Campaigns are short and rarely last more than three sessions.
ARC is technically a ‚Äúuniversal‚Äù system ‚Äî a ruleset that works just as well with science fiction or horror or whatever, but the surreal, fairy tale-ish vibe gently shoves the GM and the players towards more fantastical worlds.
Both M√∂rk Borg and ARC elevate the craft of game design and illustration. But while M√∂rk Borg is brutally ‚Äî almost comically ‚Äî fatalistic, ARC celebrates hope in the face of world-ending disaster. With enough skill and luck, players can cancel their world‚Äôs apocalypse.
Credit: Stockholm Kartell
Cy_Borg ‚Äî M√∂rk Borg Goes Cyberpunk
‚ÄúConstantly in flux; shifting, distorting, always reborn as something worse. Destruction by ecological catastrophes, the fallout of history‚Äôs belligerence; by modern man-made Miseries or the blood spilled by the reckless machine of capitalist supremacy. Mankind‚Äôs greatest ability truly is to destroy itself in creative ways. Designer demise, consumer customized death, endlessly on repeat.‚Äù
‚Äî Cy_Borg, page 3
Cy_Borg ‚Äî the cyberpunk followup to M√∂rk Borg ‚Äî is visually and textually brutal. It is staggeringly, exquisitely nihilistic and may be the single most aesthetically striking artpunk game so far.
Cy_Borg has a slightly more diverse color scheme than its predecessor, but the same sickly yellow is still a major part of the palette, particularly inside the front and back covers.
The game‚Äôs fonts are a bit more consistent than M√∂rk Borg‚Äôs. Key text is often highlighted in bold colors, although the designer switches text colors often.
Cy_Borg‚Äôs illustrations are decidedly cyberpunk but not at all glamorous or titillating. The city of Cy is uncomfortably hard and wet and dirty. Everything and everyone hurts.
Credit: Stockholm Kartell
The art and lore hammer home the fact that corporations ruined everything and everyone is just waiting for the end. This is furthered by the horror elements, like alien bacteria-infested nanobots that infect so many.
Cy_Borg is ridiculously pessimistic and cynical. The vast amounts of Debt every character begins the game with primes the player to enter survival mode from the get-go. It‚Äôs unlikely you‚Äôll crawl out from under it, so that burden is ever-present.
Then there‚Äôs the game‚Äôs existential dread. Cy_Borg includes the same apocalypse countdown as M√∂rk Borg, now in the form of future-news headlines. What‚Äôs different is that you‚Äôre not told to burn the book at the end. Like some video games, Cy_Borg reboots as a ‚Äúnew game plus‚Äù. Same hellhole, new possibilities. It‚Äôs implied that this all takes place inside a computer simulation.
But Cy_Borg‚Äôs real-world implications top off everything else. According to my head-canon, the setting‚Äôs out-of-control global warming was due to trying to power useless AI tools. This gets uncomfortably meta when you consider that at least one third-party Cy_Borg supplement was both written and illustrated by AI.
Credit: Rowan, Rook, and Decard
Eat the Reich ‚Äî Artpunk is Antifascist
‚ÄúThis game includes: death, violence, grievous injury to player characters and non-player characters, blood, vampirism, mental domination, guns, animated corpses, werewolves, occult magic, fascism, nazis, and Adolf Hitler. Some of these can be worked around; the vampires, the nazis, fascism and Hitler, not so much.‚Äù
‚Äî Eat the Reich, page 7
Vampire commandos are coffin-dropped into Paris to kill Hitler in a World War II that never happened. Fuchsia blood is smeared over diegetic dossiers. Fun.
I already covered this anti-fascist masterpiece, but it‚Äôs worth repeating that Eat the Reich‚Äôs art is beyond magnificent. Most of it is presented as a mission dossier or other documents. Fonts are consistent and key text is highlighted for easy reference, but faux water-stains and blood-spatters and scribbles in the margins maintain the in-world presentation. The colors are similar to ARCs, but the hard, sharp, aggressive illustrations create a far more hostile effect.
The vampires charged with draining the life out of Hitler are varying degrees of inhuman and badass. The boss-monsters are dangerous and horrific, and more than worthy of being shot, stabbed, and blown up a lot. Because they‚Äôre nazis, and nazis are bad.
Credit: Rowan, Rook, and Decard
Eat the Reich‚Äôs potentially calamity is the continuation of the war if you fail to devour Hitler. But dying in the attempt has a silver lining in the form of a Last Stand ability, which ensures that going down early is satisfying and glorious.
Eat the Reich might be the ultimate convention game. The pre-generated characters, lightweight mechanics, and focused mission structure make it easy to set up and play. Plus, the game‚Äôs themes filter out people you wouldn‚Äôt want to game with anyway.
Credit: JV West
GOZR ‚Äî Fugly-Fun Adventure
‚ÄúThis is an adventure roleplaying game in which you play weirdos called gooz in a broken future world. The long-dead pretty people left ruins to explore where you may steal great riches or discover ways to save the earth (whichever comes first)‚Äù
‚Äî GOZR, page 0
GOZR is straight-up fugly, but in a fun way. The creatures are greasy, lumpy, gross, and magnificent. Every page is written, drawn, and laid-out by hand. The colors are gorgeous. The fantasy-meets-counter-culture aesthetic is to die for.
GOZR‚Äôs overall art style is a mashup of Sunday comic strips and Ralph Bakshi‚Äôs Wizards. It‚Äôs funky and bizarre but not unpleasant, as the illustrations are so cartoon-ish.
Other than the general aesthetic, NOTHING is consistent. Layout changes from page to page, and text color often changes within the same table. And it‚Äôs almost all tables or bullet-pointed game rules. Prose are scarce. Aside from some text near the front, the entire setting is conveyed by the art and references in the tables. It‚Äôs a mess, but a glorious one.
The plethora of tables cover everything from the symbols on an enemy‚Äôs shield to the shape of your character‚Äôs ears. So while the mechanics are fairly straightforward, these tables introduce heaps of absurd delight.
But its the gooz that make GOZR memorable. No two are alike, and each is its own flavor of proud degeneracy. And in a world where everyone is a freak, no one is.
Credit: JV West
While the game describes the setting as a dying world, there are no end-of-the-world mechanics. Some apocalyptic events are mentioned in a couple of random tables, but they lack details so they only end the world if the GM says they do. In that sense, along with the OSR-ish ruleset, GOZR is a fairly traditional TTRPG. But some trad gamers are likely to bounce off of GOZR‚Äôs deliberately unpolished art and disordered layout.
Like every human-made endeavor, it‚Äôs not perfect. Some rules are not explained well. Still, GOZR is obviously a labor of love. AI can‚Äôt emulate that.
Credit: The Cabil
H≈çL: Human Occupied Landfill ‚Äî The Grandfather of Artpunk?
While M√∂rk Borg coined the term, H≈çL might have been the first artpunk roleplaying game.
‚ÄúWe know that look. That ‚ÄúIf I have to check for traps one more time, I‚Äôm going to sneak a spoonfull of drain cleaner into the GM‚Äôs Yoo-Hu and start screaming ‚ÄòGuess you missed your save on that one, Mr. ten-by-ten stone corridor!!‚Äô‚Äù look. You need help. You need HOL. Science Fiction roleplaying for gamers who‚Äôve had a bad day. Get it before you hurt somebody.‚Äù
‚Äî H≈çL: Human Occupied Landfill, back cover
H≈çL was a giant middle finger to D&D and the rest of the roleplaying game scene as it existed in the mid-90s. A lot of the creators‚Äô grievances still apply.
H≈çL exemplifies the word ‚Äúsketchy‚Äù. Like GOZR, the entire book was written and drawn freehand, at an IHOP if the rumors are true. It reads like it was scrawled as one stream of thought, and the text is often crooked. Its thick black lines are an homage to Jhonen Vasquez and the texture channels R. Crumb, although to a lesser degree. H≈çL‚Äôs black-and-white scribble style seethes with contempt for the reader and the entire TTRPG space.
Credit: The Cabil
H≈çL was published under White Wolf‚Äôs adults-only imprint, Black Dog Game Factory, and that ‚Äúmaturity‚Äù is seen throughout the book. The resolution mechanic riffs off of craps. The text features the word ‚Äúfuck‚Äù a lot.
It‚Äôs naughty by today‚Äôs standards ‚Äî sexual assault is lamp-shaded at least once ‚Äî but it did feature one progressive trait: there were no women on H≈çL. This wasn‚Äôt done for gatekeeper-y reasons. By declaring that all women criminals were smart enough to avoid being sentenced to H≈çL, the designers removed the possibility of a chainmail bikini.
Veteran nerds will recognize bits of Warhammer 40,000, Rifts, Marvel Comics, and a spatter of other sci-fi and pop culture references in the setting. These references include Dungeons & Dragons, and H≈çL screams its disdain for Gary Gygax‚Äôs creation.
‚ÄúAnd the orcs. Yes, orcs! Bunches of ‚Äôem. Simply hordes and hordes of murderous, uncopyrighted orcs!!! Ha ha ha! No elves or any of that stupid shit!! JUST 100% FIENDISH, FOUL, FETID, FAT, FUCKING ORCS THAT LIVE ENTIRELY WITHIN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN!!! Ha ha!! Eat me, Gary!‚Äù
‚Äî H≈çL: Human Occupied Landfill, page ??? (H≈çL has no page numbers)
This messy and mean game takes a giant dump on the entire TTRPG space. Through its pre-built player-characters, adversaries, and lore, this proto-edgelord game posits that gamers are gross losers who are desperate to be special but lack any modicum of self-awareness. Further, complex rules are dumb, fantasy is dumb, Gygax is not Jesus, and game masters are petty tyrants.
I thought this game was out of print, but I was wrong. H≈çL and its lone supplement are alive and well, with new cover art, thanks to The Cabil. I have no idea what that word means or how to pronounce it, but I know that the core book has four new pages.
H≈çL‚Äôs set-up is fairly trad: you play until the game fizzles out. There are no mechanics or lore that even hint at escaping the Human Occupied Landfill. You‚Äôre stuck there. You might as well embrace the horror.
Credit: Wannabe Games
Moonpunk ‚Äî A Primer on Direct Action
‚ÄúThe Moon is the most efficient prison labor facility of all time. The resources taken from The Moon funnel more power and money to the rich and influential both here and on Earth. Meanwhile, the working class is kept in debt to those that control the resources. We‚Äôre promised that, if we work hard, we can succeed, but that‚Äôs a lie. The system is built to fight against us. When we speak out and push back, The Authority tightens its grip. So, we have started digging out small enclaves of power to eventually control our own destiny. You need to as well.‚Äù
‚Äî Moonpunk, page 6
Moonpunk‚Äôs zine aesthetic manages to be antagonistic while remaining comfortably legible. Its visual style changes completely from section to section.
The early pages are in-universe brochures, some of which are defaced. Later, cut-out pictures of retro-style rockets and satellites are pasted onto pages haphazardly, along with torn-out fragments of plain text on printer paper. This constant change-up continues throughout the book, giving way to more traditional ‚Äî albeit zine-like ‚Äî roleplaying game design, a diegetic leaflet on direct action, and so on.
This refusal to pick a style accentuates the game‚Äôs themes of DIY resistance and rebellion. But regardless of the style in question, the illustrations, layout, scant colors, and font choices scream ‚Äúfight the power‚Äù.
Credit: Wannabe Games
I covered Moonpunk WAY back when, but it‚Äôs still top-of-mind. Like many artpunk games, Moonpunk is explicitly anti-capitalist and anti-oligarch. Adventures are structured as radical activism, which hammers home its themes of direct action and mutual aid. The included adventures address police violence, classism, censorship and other problems that oligarchs either don‚Äôt care about or actively endorse. And none of these adventures can be won by simply killing the villains. The villains are the system.
Or, maybe the system is the villain. This obviously leads to discussions about the ‚ÄúA-word‚Äù. Anarchism is a political philosophy of last resort, but it‚Äôs a damn sight better than oligarchical fascism.
Mechanically, Moonpunk isn‚Äôt particularly nihilistic. There‚Äôs no built-in fail state. Then again, there‚Äôs no built-in win state either.
Credit: Madness Heart Games
Odd Gobs ‚Äî Gig Work is Hell
‚ÄúThe Goblins (that‚Äôs you) have to make ends meet in the CITY, a cyberpunk dystopia, by using the GigL app to find strange and dangerous gigs to work, all the while injecting every situation and encounter with as much chaos as Goblinlly possible.‚Äù
‚Äî Odd Gobs, page 1
This anti-capitalist, pro-goblin game asks the burning question, ‚ÄúWhat if Mega-City One had TaskRabbit‚Äù? Odd Gobs is about gig workers trying to survive in a nightmarish cyberpunk city. Yeah, goblins are traditionally a fantasy species, but they‚Äôre better when they‚Äôre sci-fi because EVERYTHING is better when it‚Äôs sci-fi.
Because rulebooks are overrated, the game folds up like a map. One side features the actual map of The City, surrounded by ‚Äúscreengrabs‚Äù of an app providing details on its eight districts and routes between them, all helpfully color coded.
The other side is crammed with charts and random tables covering everything from character generation to gig creation. Combined, the chaotic layout, graffiti-on-brick-walls background, and toxic/tech color scheme are migraine-inducing ‚Äî so you know it‚Äôs art.
Credit: Madness Heart Games
While the game‚Äôs text encourages players to have fun as chaos-inducing miscreants trying to get the job done, the game‚Äôs garish design communicates the theme of structural violence and worker abuse. Gig work kills you slowly. Gig work grinds people to death.
The game‚Äôs dice mechanics are unabashedly heretical. Players can use any three dice to determine success or failure.
Odd Gobs isn‚Äôt as apocalyptic as other artpunk games, but the fail state is more personal and more familiar. If a gob‚Äôs Stressors ‚Äî qualitative injuries or setbacks ‚Äî are greater than their Benefits ‚Äî gear, skills, and whatnot ‚Äî at the end of a session, they break under the stress of hellish gig work and delete the app. That‚Äôs far from the end of the world, but that app was the gob‚Äôs only employment opportunity. The world will go on but that gob is doomed.
Credit: Tin Hat Games
The True OSR ‚Äî Artpunk Turns Inward
Spikes! Chains! Tendrils! Laser eyes! The True OSR‚Äôs illustrations are littered with the detritus of Heavy Metal comics. The color schemes are beyond villainous. The layout flies in the face of old school design philosophies and a lot of the text is tilted. The number of d100 tables this game sports is ludicrous, and some of them spread out to half-a-dozen pages. It‚Äôs a dumb, obnoxious, tacky, brilliant game. Also, the book is square.
Color schemes and fonts vary wildly. It‚Äôs not that every two-page spread is a painting, but a lot of them would make decent posters. Each chapter and each of the enormous tables has its own style and color scheme and background and whatnot; you can tell at a glance where one ends and another begins.
The Locations table has a Jules Verne pulp aesthetic. The Personality table looks like one of John Doe‚Äôs journals from Se7en. The Furniture table apes Ikea‚Äôs blue-and-yellow scheme. Even if everything looks like the cover of a metal album, the various sections look like distinct metal albums.
Credit: Tin Hat Games
Compared to other artpunk games, The True OSR is more legible than some and less legible than others (especially page 192). But this game needed another edit, possibly because English is not the creators‚Äô first language. There‚Äôs at least one rule I‚Äôm not sure I interpreted right. That said, nothing is unintelligible. And if you feel like you‚Äôre playing it wrong, call it a hack.
OSR normally stands for ‚Äúold-school roleplay‚Äù (or renaissance, or revival), but here it stands for ‚ÄúObsolete Shitty Rules‚Äù. The True OSR is basically H≈çL for millennials, but I can‚Äôt tell if it‚Äôs a love letter or a break-up text to the OSR scene. It could be either one. It might be both.
‚ÄúTHE GOLDEN RULE (for Players)
Show no respect for authority!
The GM has no absolute power; her words are nothing but the narrator‚Äôs voice of what the book you are holding establishes by its rules. You can check the manual at any time to see whether the GM is following the rules and results of her rolls, which must always be shown publicly.
YOU ARE the protagonist, not your Master!!‚Äù
‚ÄúTHE GOLDEN RULE (for the Master)
Have no mercy!
The players are nothing but pretentious and whining souls who have been given the task of playing the main role in YOUR story. During the narrative you will have to stick to the rules by using your flair to provide exhilarating descriptions of what the tables determine by rolling the dice, putting the PCs to the test, and sometimes directly challenging them.
YOU ARE the real protagonist, not the Players!‚Äù
‚Äî The True OSR, page 13
What makes The True OSR truly extra is that the Master is trying to kill the Players and the Players are trying to kill the Master right back. OSR fans will claim that‚Äôs not what the OSR is about, but they forget that a lot of GMs back in the day were sadistic tyrants who tried to ‚Äúwin‚Äù roleplaying games.
The above examples are just the tip of the artpunk iceberg. Vast Grimm brings the pitch-black fun to outer space. Inf√¶rnum attempts to out-M√∂rk Borg M√∂rk Borg with a whole new ruleset but equally grimdark design. Ragnarok: Fate of the Norns ‚Äî set during a mythic-historical viking end-time ‚Äî predates M√∂rk Borg by several years. Orbital Blues tones down the artpunk noise to tell stories of sad space cowboys. Lichoma bills itself as ‚Äúmeatpunk‚Äù.
These games WANT to be played, and they want to be played now. That‚Äôs one of the reasons the rules are so lightweight. Most people have little time for hobbies or games or self-care. We certainly don‚Äôt have the time for traditional roleplaying games. Dungeons & Dragons, Traveller, Call of Cthulhu, and other heavy games are not even close to an option anymore. Those games are for the time-rich or the very lucky.
The creators of M√∂rk Borg and ARC and GOZR don‚Äôt seem to care about their games being played ‚Äúright‚Äù, and they certainly don‚Äôt care about canon. They care about absurdity and beauty and violence and hope and dread.
Artpunk embraces joyous nihilism. These games made of shocking art, emotionally savage themes, and inventive mechanics scream at you to appreciate life right now, because it doesn‚Äôt last. Play today because everything could end tomorrow.
Nihilism is liberating. Milquetoast mainstream escapism, with its happy endings and triumphant victories, just doesn‚Äôt cut it when you‚Äôre surrounded by wildfires and floods and wars and genocides and criminals in high office. Embracing the madness and horror ‚Äî if only fictionally ‚Äî will save your soul.<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
Story of Open Source AI.
When ‚ÄúOpen AI‚Äù is no longer Open. Why Open-Source AI Isn‚Äôt Always Free, and Closed Source Isn‚Äôt Always Greedy.
Jing Hu
¬∑
Follow
Published in
AI Advances
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
5 days ago
330
4
Image Shutterstock licensed, tailored by Jing
There is no such thing as a free lunch.
Except‚Ä¶ it seems, in the AI world, some of the most expensive models are surprisingly offered for free.
Like Llama can be downloaded at no cost, even with a training price tag in the range of a dozen million. Not to mention the top-tier models. That‚Äôs a whole lot of capital being ‚Äúdonated‚Äù to humanity, making you wonder if Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk are vying for sainthood.
On the other hand, there‚Äôs OpenAI, whose very name suggests ‚Äúopenness‚Äù, yet it refuses to disclose much about GPT -4 and onwards. The question of ‚Äúopen source‚Äù vs. ‚Äúclosed source‚Äù has turned both perplexing and heated in the AI community.
Let‚Äôs not jump to conclusions; I want to walk you through the drama and then my analysis.
The Concept of Open Source
What does ‚Äúopen source‚Äù really mean?
A little bit of history.
The early software days were dominated by academics who valued publicizing research findings. In that era, there was no notion of ‚Äúclosed-source‚Äù software.
Source code was shared freely for most software.
As personal computers caught on, so did the demand for all sorts of new functionalities. Then, this massive software market was born. Copyright laws kicked in, and software evolved into a paid commodity.
Today, we see paying for software as standard. Even for those who pirate software (like a lot did years ago in Asia), they at least recognize that software generally isn‚Äôt free.
Still, older tech enthusiasts remember a time when everything was shared ‚Äî so they were upset to see their open code later sold for profit.
Each new contributor stands on the shoulders of those who came before and is expected to pay it forward. Over the years, open-source communities have produced mind-blowing feats of collaboration, e.g., Linux (Mac OS is a pretty UI on top of Linux). Nearly 8000 developers from about 80 countries contributed code; many were hobbyists.
The consensus was that the fruits of shared knowledge should remain accessible to all.
A group of ‚Äúcyber-traditionalists‚Äù split off to uphold the creed of shared knowledge even after close source software became mainstream.
Note: ‚Äúopen source‚Äù doesn‚Äôt just mean ‚Äúfree‚Äù or ‚Äúpirated.‚Äù
The question I want to explore here with you:
Is the same selflessness open-source spirit still alive in today‚Äôs AI gold rush?
OpenAI‚Äôs Early Idealism
Back in 2015, Google dominated AI by gathering top talent and acquiring DeepMind, the creators of AlphaGo.
This was when Sam Altman joined forces with Elon Musk. They founded OpenAI, which was initially established on high-minded merit.
Sam Altman has long believed in the inevitability of artificial general intelligence (AGI), the almost mythical AI that‚Äôs all-knowing and all-powerful. He used to ask job applicants, ‚ÄúDo you believe in AGI?‚Äù and would only hire those who said ‚Äúyes.‚Äù
Musk, however, was worried about AI running amok and dooming humanity.
How did these two collaborate?
FOMO!
‚ÄúFear of Missing Out.‚Äù describes the anxiety or fear that one might miss an exciting opportunity or experience.
They felt threatened by what DeepMind had achieved.
Musk mentioned that he repeatedly warned Google cofounder Larry Page about AI risks, only to find that Page wasn‚Äôt that concerned. Meanwhile, Sam Altman wanted to ensure that if AGI did emerge, it wouldn‚Äôt be under the sole control of Google. According to him, it should be shared globally so as not to catch humanity off guard. So Musk handed over the money pod; Altman handled operations, and OpenAI was born in late 2015.
Of course, we can‚Äôt leave out Ilya Sutskever. He was OpenAI‚Äôs Chief Scientist, a prot√©g√© of Geoffrey Hinton. At one point, he told Geoffrey Hinton he needed a brand-new programming language for his research. Hinton warned him not to waste months writing one from scratch, but Ilya replied that he had already done it.
With a Chief Scientist like this, OpenAI was well-positioned to chase the holy grail of AGI.
When Google‚Äôs AI team published Attention Is All You Need in 2017, it didn‚Äôt immediately cause a sensation. However, Ilya saw its significance immediately and called it the key to the next AI wave.
In plain English, the Transformers focus on the important details, process data quickly, and scale up easily.
Starting with GPT‚Äë1 (100 million+ parameters) in 2018, OpenAI moved fast to GPT‚Äë2 (1.5 billion parameters, expanded at an unprecedented scale) in 2019. That gamble paid off. GPT‚Äë2 shocked the AI circle with its human-like sentence generation.
GPT‚Äë2 was open-sourced and built on Google‚Äôs open research plus OpenAI‚Äôs own engineering. Here‚Äôs the latest OpenAI blog post justifying its for-profit structure: Why OpenAI‚Äôs Structure Must Evolve To Advance Our Mission.
The early days of large language models exemplify open-source synergy at its best. But the utopian story hit turbulence sooner than everyone would think.
Growing model sizes feed on massive funding, bringing corporate interests, power struggles, and shifting priorities. Unlike Meta, there is simply no way OpenAI would be competitive if they opened their model, given that this is their only source of income.
Musk-OpenAI Split, Then xAI
OpenAI started small, like training AI to play video games. Costly, but nothing compared to building massive language models.
At first, Elon Musk was the benefactor, aiming to counter Google‚Äôs dominance. But when OpenAI‚Äôs open-source breakthroughs started catching attention, Musk‚Äôs tune changed. He worried the work would only help Google, ignoring that GPT relied heavily on Google‚Äôs open research.
Classic Musk move: he wanted control.
So Musk proposed folding OpenAI into Tesla and SpaceX, completely ignoring its open-source mission. When that didn‚Äôt happen, he walked away and pulled his funding.
That happened in 2018, and OpenAI was in trouble. No funding, no clear path forward. Sam Altman came up with a bold solution: create a for-profit subsidiary controlled by the nonprofit parent. This let them raise money while capping excessive profits (anything over 100√ó would return to the nonprofit).
The move worked. In 2019, Microsoft invested $1 billion, later bringing the total to $13 billion. With this backing, OpenAI launched GPT‚Äë3 in 2020, followed by GPT‚Äë3.5 and ChatGPT.
But this deal came with a cost. GPT‚Äë3 wasn‚Äôt fully open-sourced ‚Äî no weights, no architecture. Here‚Äôs when the general population realized that OpenAI‚Äôs ideals had been lost to commercialization.
In early 2024, Musk sued OpenAI, claiming it violated earlier agreements, demanded his money back, and pushed for the tech to be open-sourced. Was it altruism? Or revenge?
Ironically, Musk once agreed with Ilya Sutskever that key tech should remain confidential as they approached AGI. But after ChatGPT‚Äôs success, Musk became a vocal open-source advocate ‚Äî conveniently for a man building his own AI company.
Musk‚Äôs xAI launched ‚ÄúGrok‚Äù in 2024, along with a 3,000 billion+ parameter model. xAI secured $6 billion in funding, making their ‚Äúopen-source stance‚Äù seem more strategic than selfless. Impressive? Sure.
Practical to open source community? Not really.
xAI is technically still open source, but it does not yet have models for individual antithesis.
Meta, The New Torchbearer for Open Source AI?
So does that mean the once-idealistic AI open-source path is a dead end?
Not‚Ä¶ yet.
Meta has an extensive open-source track record.
For instance, PyTorch. This is one of the most used machine learning frameworks, and it originated from Meta‚Äôs AI labs. When LLM fever took off, Meta made waves in early 2023 by open-sourcing LLaMA (65 billion parameters). A flood of LLaMA-based variants popped up afterward, including many ‚Äúre-skinned‚Äù versions. Since then, over 7,000 derivative models have been created worldwide.
But Meta must also deal with commercial realities, just as OpenAI does.
However, there are reasons for me to think Meta could balance the act better for open knowledge and profit.
Meta had their success with the Open Compute Project (open-sourced server and data center designs). Other companies adopted them, hardware got cheaper, and Meta ultimately saved billions of dollars.
Now, Meta hopes to replicate that success with LLaMA. If more developers build on LLaMA, and more services adopt LLaMA-based models, the industry norms might coalesce around it. The ‚Äúfreeing‚Äù of LLaMA could lead to an ecosystem that‚Äôs actually profitable for Meta in the long run. Shareholders agree; since Meta shifted from ‚Äúmetaverse hype‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI altruism,‚Äù the stock has doubled in a year.
LLaMA‚Äôs license restricts how you can use the model, particularly for training competing systems. Large companies with over 700 million users need explicit permission from Meta.
It‚Äôs business, after all.
Be the friend who actually gets AI. Subscribe now!
Personal View on Open Source AI.
There is no right or wrong running open-source or proprietary AI.
As a more business-oriented person, I see open vs. closed-source AI models as less about morality and business strategy. Companies like OpenAI, Meta, and xAI have adopted approaches aligned with their unique goals, funding realities, and market positions.
Meta and xAI use open-source models like LLaMA to foster innovation and grow an ecosystem, balancing openness with business restrictions.
OpenAI and Anthropic prioritize closed-source to sustain their business, relying on licensing and partnerships.
If I can only use one image to summarize this article.
On a personal level, my partner and I put our bet on Meta. We believe it‚Äôs poised to become one of the most influential AI companies in the long run. Reasons:
Open Source Strategy. Despite the licenses and caveats, Llama is open-source enough to be practical, especially the smaller models that individuals and small businesses can actually use. (Compare that to xAI, which offers massive models with no workable small-scale alternatives.)
Massive Built-In User Base. Before Musk‚Äôs xAI, Meta was practically the only major AI player with direct access to massive networks of everyday consumers who already spend a lot of time on their platforms ‚Äî 30 minutes per day on Facebook vs. around 6 minutes on ChatGPT.
Proven Revenue Engine. Meta‚Äôs advertising network and business partnerships allow it to integrate AI seamlessly, creating a synergy that competitors may struggle to replicate.
I believe this is a debate worth having. Share your thoughts in the comments or private chat.
As AI evolves, companies make choices aligned with their commercial goals. It‚Äôs easy to focus on the surface and overlook how these decisions profoundly impact people like you and me.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

You Are Smart. This Is How You Can Learn Anything Fast
Embrace effective learning
Axel Casas, PhD Candidate
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Cogni.tiva
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Nov 18, 2024
1.3K
9
Photo by Jametlene Reskp on Unsplash
Not a Medium Member? Click here to read the full article
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt learn this; I‚Äôm not smart enough.‚Äù
If you feel like this, you‚Äôre not alone. When I was studying Psychology, I was an average student. Most of my friends and classmates always got better grades than me.
Worse still, some of them never stressed.
They were super-people.
I Concluded I Wasn‚Äôt Good Enough
See the problem?
This view creates barriers to success. The difference between ‚Äúsmart‚Äù and ‚Äúnot-smart‚Äù people is that the latter don‚Äôt know how to learn or study effectively.
Everyone can learn anything and ace their exams, for real.
Learning means linking information to long-term memory; science has discovered which study techniques are better for accomplishing this. It is all about how you study.
This is how you can start your learning revolution.
1. The Problem: They Never Taught Us How To Learn And Study
And it‚Äôs not our fault.
No one taught us how to study effectively. The default method is:
Attend to lectures.
Take notes.
Study (choose your method).
Do your exam.
The problem is how you study.
If I ask my students, most will say they study by rereading and highlighting information. However, science has shown that these are ineffective strategies (Brown et al., 2014).
The key is replacing those with effective methods.
Based on Weinstein et al. 2018, better learning strategies include:
Retrieval.
Interleaving.
Spaced Practice.
Elaboration.
Concrete examples.
Dual coding.
Have you ever heard of them?
Well, most students don‚Äôt.
They keep studying using rereading and highlighting as their holy-grail strategies and get fooled by the illusion of learning (thinking they learned something when they didn‚Äôt).
However, techniques alone would not make the impact you are looking for.
A learning system will.
Photo by JESHOOTS.COM on Unsplash
2. Build An Effective Learning System
A simple but good learning system includes the following:
A plan: to define clear goals and organize time and resources.
Science-proven study strategies: mentioned previously.
Focus: eliminate distractions.
Flexibility: to transfer what you learn to the real world.
Motivation: fuel for learning.
Do this:
Learn how to learn your target. Look for advice, resources, etc.
Use retrieval, spaced practice, interrogative elaboration, etc., to study.
Use the Pomodoro Technique to focus and manage time.
Work on projects. Learn by doing. This will help you transfer what you studied to real-world scenarios.
Track progress to motivate you. Reward yourself.
Example: Learning Machine Learning As An Absolute Beginner
As a psychologist, I knew nothing about math and programming.
However, I knew that learning is a process and there is always a way to learn anything effectively. So, I did the following:
I built a roadmap based on other‚Äôs experience (experts and people who learned machine learning from 0).
When studying, I used retrieval and spaced practice. To study abstract concepts, I used chat GPT to learn with analogies. Then, I combined everything in coding projects.
To avoid procrastination, I studied in short sessions of 25 minutes (Pomodoro) and focused using the Focus Keeper app (free).
To motivate myself, I tracked my progress (skills I learned, what I found more challenging, self-test marks, etc.).
I coded projects outside my comfort zone to apply what I learned so far in real-world scenarios.
This is how I learned machine learning.
At my own pace and for free.
3. You Are Smart
Stop saying you are not smart enough.
Because you are very bright, my friend. Learning is a process of linking information to your long-term memory. To do this, you need to use the right tools.
Anyone can do this.
Of course, some will have prior knowledge, more working memory, or more resources. That‚Äôs why you should be careful when comparing yourself with others.
But with the right system, you can learn anything, anytime.
So ‚Ä¶ ready to learn effectively?
Ways I can help you:
Subscribe to my new free newsletter The Super Learning Lab.
And get my free eBook ‚ÄúRocket Learning: 7 Hacks To Survive University, Ace Exams, And Learn Anything.‚Äù

8 Python Decorator Things I Regret Not Knowing Earlier

1) The @ syntax equivalent
add_exclamation is a decorator function.
greet is the function being decorated (I‚Äôll call it the decoratee)
We use the @ symbol to decorate a function using a decorator function. This @ syntax is the exact same as the code below:
^ this is what happens behind the scenes when we decorate greet using the decorator function add_exclamation.
2) Why we use decorators
A decorator function is a function itself ‚Äî a function that modifies the behaviour of its decoratee without having to change the decoratee‚Äôs source code.
^ once again, add_exclamation is the decorator function, and greet is the decoratee.
add_exclamation modifies greet‚Äôs behaviour
it adds an additional exclamation mark after greet‚Äôs return value
greet(‚Äòtom‚Äô) will return ‚Äòhello tom!‚Äô after being decorated
Here, notice that we don‚Äôt actually add an exclamation mark inside the greet function.
This is important as a decorator is meant to decorate multiple functions, and bring additional functionality to each of the functions being decorated.
^ a trivial example that illustrates how add_exclamation ought to be used.
3) An easy way to understand decorators
Once again, we need to keep in mind that using the @ syntax is the same as using func = decorator(func)
Which means that our decorator function add_exclamation takes in a function, and returns a modified function.
With that in mind, let‚Äôs attempt to implement the add_exclamation decorator function, which adds one exclamation mark after the decoratee‚Äôs return value.
greet = add_exclamation(greet)
the variable func is assigned to our function greet
an inner function wrapper is created. wrapper takes in the same input as greet
wrapper returns whatever greet returns, but with an additional exclamation mark
wrapper itself is returned by the function call add_exclamation(greet)
the variable greet is assigned to this new returned function
As such, greet now has an additional exclamation mark in its return value, without us having to manually edit greet‚Äôs source code.
Quick Pause
I recently wrote a book ‚Äî 101 Things I Never Knew About Python
Here I‚Äôve compiled 101 cool Python tricks and facts that many (if not most) do not know about. Check it out if you wish to level up your Python knowledge!
Link: https://payhip.com/b/vywcf
4) Advanced decorators with 2 inner functions
But what if we wish to add different symbols eg. question mark, comma etc? Do we need to create one decorator function for each?
Good news: No. We can make our decorator more general like this:
Once again, the @ syntax here is the exact same as:
This means that our add_symbol decorator function needs to have 2 inner functions. Let‚Äôs now implement our decorator function:
This way, we can make our decorators more reusable and general:
5) Classes can be decorators
If you don‚Äôt wish to deal with advanced decorators containing 2 inner functions, there is another way ‚Äî we use classes as decorators.
And to do this, we need to implement the __call__ magic method, which defines behaviour when we call an object like we call functions.
Here, we‚Äôve rewritten our previous example using a class rather than a function with 2 inner functions.
Once again, using the @ symbol is the same as doing this:
the first set of brackets initializes our object and invokes __init__
the second set of brackets call our object and invokes __call__, which returns an inner wrapper function like a normal decorator.
6) functools.wraps
Let‚Äôs say we have a simple decorator that adds one exclamation mark after a function‚Äôs return value
But when we print greet‚Äôs function metadata, we get this:
This is because in greet = add_exclamation(greet)
add_exclamation(greet) returns its inner function wrapper
greet is assigned to the inner function wrapper
as such, greet loses its function metadata eg. name and docstring
We can preserve this function metadata by using the built-in functools.wraps
Note ‚Äî the only change here is that we decorate wrapper with @wraps(func). This change alone forces func‚Äôs metadata to be passed onto wrapper
And now, our metadata is preserved.
7) __wrapped__ to undecorate
When we decorate a function, our function is changed forever, and we kinda lose access to the original function.
^ here, greet‚Äôs return value will now have an additional exclamation mark.
But if we wish to obtain the original undecorated greet without the additional exclamation mark, we‚Äôre out of luck. Unless ‚Ä¶
we use functools.wraps to decorate our wrapper function in our decorator
2. we use .__wrapped__ to access the original undecorated function
This can be useful during unit testing, where we might need to extract original undecorated functions
8) Decorators to decorate classes
Decorators can be used for decorating both functions and classes. Of course, a decorator meant to decorate a class would differ significantly from one meant to decorate a function.
Let‚Äôs say we want to create a class decorator that adds a common function hello to every single class it decorates.
In the decorator function add_hello, we simply assign one function to the class, and return the class itself.
And if we decorate multiple classes with add_hello, each of these classes will contain the hello method by default.
Conclusion
Hope you learnt at least one new thing about Python decorators today

How I Use v0 and Cursor AI to Build Web Apps in Minutes
Jim Clyde Monge
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Generative AI

9 min read

Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Building full-stack web applications in 2024 is now possible without writing a single line of code.
You only need two AI-powered programming assistants: one to handle the frontend and the other for the backend.
Here are the tools I recommend for this process:
v0 by Vercel: It‚Äôs an assistant that specializes in web technologies and frameworks to help you generate functional code and user interfaces with simple text prompts.
Cursor AI: This tool enhances the coding experience by understanding your code, suggesting improvements, and even writing code for you.
In this article, I‚Äôll walk you through my personal workflow on how I use these AI programming assistants to quickly build functional and deployable web applications.
Let‚Äôs get started.
How to access v0
Head over to v0.dev/chat and sign up for free.
I recommend using your GitHub account for smoother integration, especially if you plan to deploy your apps on Vercel using GitHub integration.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Once you‚Äôre in the chat dashboard, you can start describing the web app you‚Äôre trying to build.
v0 doesn‚Äôt have many customization options, which may appeal to some but could frustrate more advanced engineers who prefer more control.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
All the background settings ‚Äî such as language model and token count ‚Äî are handled automatically. The only things you can adjust are the theme and the language.
Here‚Äôs how I integrate v0 into my workflow:
Generate front-end code in v0.
Copy the code and instruct Cursor to integrate it into my app.
Refine the codes either on v0 or Cursor.
Let me show you an example.
Generate Front-End Code with v0
I‚Äôm currently working on a web app that displays a grid of videos on the dashboard with a collapsible left sidebar for navigation.
To help v0 understand what I wanted, I uploaded a screenshot of a similar website as inspiration.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Then I described every detail of the user interface that I want.
Prompt: Using the attached reference image, generate a bento style grid of an AI video generator SaaS with a collapsible left section for the menu. Make sure it‚Äôs responsive. The header section includes the user‚Äôs name, profile icon, remaining credits, and the app logo and name on the upper left. Make sure to make each thumbnail interactive. When user hovers on the video, it autoplays and the description will be shown on the lower part with black faded background for readability. when user clicks on the video, it expands and shows a bigger video player with the video details on the right side.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
You might not get the exact result that you want on the first try, so it‚Äôs essential to refine the prompt by describing the changes in the chat field.
In the example above, I was aiming for a masonry-style layout instead of fixed, so I had to do a follow up modification.
Prompt: Looks great! Now can you make sure there are no empty spaces in the grid? revise how you arrange the grid such that they all fit together regardless of the aspect ratios
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
The design looks good to me. Here‚Äôs a snippet of the Typescript code:
import { useState, useEffect, createContext, useContext } from 'react'
import { Menu, ChevronLeft, ChevronRight, Play, Sun, Moon } from 'lucide-react'
import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"
import { Input } from "@/components/ui/input"
import { Avatar, AvatarFallback, AvatarImage } from "@/components/ui/avatar"
import { ScrollArea } from "@/components/ui/scroll-area"
import { Sheet, SheetContent, SheetDescription, SheetHeader, SheetTitle, SheetTrigger } from "@/components/ui/sheet"
import { Tabs, TabsContent, TabsList, TabsTrigger } from "@/components/ui/tabs"

const ThemeContext = createContext({
  theme: 'light',
  toggleTheme: () => {},
})

const aspectRatios = [
  { className: 'aspect-square', width: 1, height: 1 },
  { className: 'aspect-video', width: 16, height: 9 },
  { className: 'aspect-[4/3]', width: 4, height: 3 },
  { className: 'aspect-[3/2]', width: 3, height: 2 },
  { className: 'aspect-[3/4]', width: 3, height: 4 }
]

const categories = [
  "Music Videos",
  "Trailers",
  "Commercials",
  "Random",
  "Top Picks"
]

const generateVideos = (category) => {
  return Array(12).fill(null).map((_, index) => {
    const aspectRatio = aspectRatios[Math.floor(Math.random() * aspectRatios.length)]
    return {
      id: `${category}-${index + 1}`,
      title: `${category} ${index + 1}`,
      description: `This is a ${category.toLowerCase()} video description`,
      thumbnail: `/placeholder.svg?height=${aspectRatio.height * 100}&width=${aspectRatio.width * 100}`,
      aspectRatio: aspectRatio.className
    }
  })
}

const videosByCategory = categories.reduce((acc, category) => {
  acc[category] = generateVideos(category)
  return acc
}, {})

const MasonryGrid = ({ children }) => {
  const [columns, setColumns] = useState(4)

  useEffect(() => {
    const updateColumns = () => {
      const width = window.innerWidth
      if (width < 640) setColumns(1)
      else if (width < 768) setColumns(2)
      else if (width < 1024) setColumns(3)
      else setColumns(4)
    }

    updateColumns()
    window.addEventListener('resize', updateColumns)
    return () => window.removeEventListener('resize', updateColumns)
  }, [])

  // rest of the code here
}

const ThemeProvider = ({ children }) => {
  const [theme, setTheme] = useState('light')

  const toggleTheme = () => {
    const newTheme = theme === 'light' ? 'dark' : 'light'
    setTheme(newTheme)
    document.documentElement.classList.toggle('dark')
  }

 // rest of the code here
}

const ThemeToggle = () => {
  const { theme, toggleTheme } = useContext(ThemeContext)

  return (
    <Button
      variant="outline"
      size="icon"
      onClick={toggleTheme}
      className="fixed bottom-4 left-4 z-50"
    >
      {theme === 'light' ? <Moon className="h-[1.2rem] w-[1.2rem]" /> : <Sun className="h-[1.2rem] w-[1.2rem]" />}
      <span className="sr-only">Toggle theme</span>
    </Button>
  )
}

export default function VideoGenerator() {
  const [sidebarOpen, setSidebarOpen] = useState(true)
  const [isPlaying, setIsPlaying] = useState({})

  const toggleSidebar = () => setSidebarOpen(!sidebarOpen)

  const handleVideoHover = (id) => {
    setIsPlaying(prev => ({ ...prev, [id]: true }))
  }

  const handleVideoLeave = (id) => {
    setIsPlaying(prev => ({ ...prev, [id]: false }))
  }

  return (
    <ThemeProvider>
      // rest of the code here
    </ThemeProvider>
  )
}
You can also share chat with the public or publish the web app with a unique URL for the selected block. You can unpublish a block at any time.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Integrating v0 Codes to Cursor AI
To integrate the code generated by v0 into my project using Cursor AI, start by creating a file for the page or component.
While you can ask Cursor to create the page for you, I find it‚Äôs often better to do it manually since the AI sometimes places files in the wrong directory.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Next, instead of pasting the code directly into a blank file, open Cursor‚Äôs composer and ask the AI to integrate the code into your project. This way, Cursor knows which existing elements (like headers and footers) should be included.
Prompt: In the explore page, can you add the header and footer? Also please implement this user interface with shadcn
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Here‚Äôs the result of the code I generated with v0 integrated into my project:
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Pretty cool, right?
I also asked Cursor to use temporary YouTube videos for the thumbnails, which helped me visualize the production environment. Additionally, I requested dark mode support.
I plan to continue improving this interface by adding more features like pagination, more menus, modal video player, etc.
To give you an idea of what‚Äôs possible with these two AI tools, take a look at the web app called Flux Labs AI I built and deployed a couple of weeks ago.
Flux Labs
Train Flux image models for your custom images.

How Much Do They Cost?
Now let‚Äôs talk about the pricing of v0 and Cursor AI.
v0 by Vercel offers a free plan which allows you to access and try out generating content for a limited number of messages. If you need to upgrade to a higher message limit, you can upgrade to either of the following subscriptions:
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Premium ($20 per month): this plan includes everything in the Free plan plus 10‚Äì20x higher messaging limits, custom subdomains on published Blocks, and support for multiple projects.
Team ($30 per user per month): this plan is designed for collaborative teams that require even more messaging limits. It adds centralized billing, shared access to chats, Blocks, and Projects, making it perfect for fast-moving teams.
Enterprise: For companies needing more robust security and performance, the Enterprise plan offers features like Single Sign-On (SSO), the ability to opt out of data training, and priority access for enhanced performance. Pricing for this plan requires contacting Vercel‚Äôs sales team.
Cursor AI Pricing
One of the great things about Cursor AI is the generous free credits it offers when you sign up. Upon joining, you gain access to Pro features for two weeks, which includes:
2,000 completions
50 slow premium requests
200 cursor-small uses
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
These free credits provide ample room to test out all the features and build basic web apps. However, if you‚Äôre looking to work on more complex projects, upgrading to a paid tier is recommended:
Pro ($20 per month): this plan includes unlimited completions, 500 fast premium requests per month, unlimited slow premium requests, unlimited cursor-small uses, and 10 Claude Opus uses per day. It‚Äôs perfect for individuals building more advanced apps.
Business ($40 per user per month): this plan is designed for teams and includes all the features of the Pro plan, along with centralized billing, an admin dashboard, enforced privacy mode, and policies to ensure zero-data retention with providers like OpenAI and Anthropic.
Final Thoughts
As much as AI-assisted development tools like v0 by Vercel and Cursor AI have revolutionized how quickly we can build web apps, it‚Äôs important to maintain a balanced approach.
AI-generated code can save a lot of time, but it‚Äôs far from perfect. These tools are still evolving, and the code they produce often requires a careful review, refinement, and, in some cases, significant rewriting.
I strongly recommend adopting a hybrid workflow. AI can handle the repetitive, boilerplate tasks, while you focus on the more nuanced aspects of development ‚Äî especially error handling, optimization, and ensuring the code meets your quality standards.
In my experience, I‚Äôve found it‚Äôs best to let AI handle the bulk of the coding but always ensure you‚Äôre providing clear instructions and thoroughly reviewing the output.
If you‚Äôre not an expert on the language or framework, at least take time to analyze the codes and check for possible errors. You can also ask someone with more expertise to review the project before you deploy them.
As someone who has been programming for over a decade, I‚Äôve seen firsthand how development tools have evolved, and the recent shift toward AI-assisted coding is remarkable. Moving from tools like GitHub Copilot to trying out Cursor with Claude 3.5 Sonnet has been an eye-opening experience.
I truly believe this is the future of programming. More and more, my workflow revolves around writing in English ‚Äî prompting the AI, reviewing its output, and refining the generated code.
The role of a developer is evolving from just writing code to guiding and collaborating with AI.

The Future of Technology: Top 5 Skills to Learn in 2025
Blend Visions
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Dec 8, 2024
71
5
Future of Technology
Looking at the year 2025, it is clear that the rate of technological advancement is increasing rapidly. With advancements in artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and immersive technologies, understanding these emerging trends is crucial for anyone looking to stay relevant in the job market. This blog post is going to introduce the five most important technologies to learn in 2025 and provide links for more information. When you adopt these skills fully, you stand a better chance of being perceived as being at the top of the technological careers ladder.
üöÄ‚≠ïFor non-members, üìú please read. üìñ
1. Multimodal AI Development
Photo by Jona on Unsplash
What is Multimodal AI?
Multimodal AI refers to systems that can process and understand multiple types of data simultaneously ‚Äî such as text, images, and audio ‚Äî much like the human brain. This technology is already in play in different fields to develop customer experiences and optimize user satisfaction.
Real-World Applications
A prime example of multimodal AI in action is BMW‚Äôs innovative system that monitors vehicle performance. This AI does not only monitor images from cameras but also listens for any suspicious noise and reads a log of maintenance activities. Combined with these data streams, it provides an accurate prognosis of mechanical failures, thus minimizing the annual losses of millions of dollars for the company. Such applications demonstrate how multimodal AI can enhance operational efficiency across various sectors.
Why Learn Multimodal AI?
As the big players in the tech world (for instance, Google, Facebook, and Spotify) are paying more and more attention to multimodal AI, it will increase your potential in the job market if you know it. The computer vision course taught by Stanford University, CS231n (Computer Vision), and the course in Practical Deep Learning, Fast.ai, are really good starting points for those who are interested in this field, by the way. On top of that, conversion of multimodal AI is a skill that can lead you to positions like AI developer or data scientist, where you can take part in the development of more advanced and intuitive systems.
2. Quantum-Ready Programming
Photo by Nicolas Arnold on Unsplash
Understanding Quantum Computing
Quantum computing is a groundbreaking technological development that has come a long way from classical computing. Quantum computers are machines that use quantum mechanics to solve problems that are otherwise very difficult for classical computers, giving them the ability to work with huge amounts of data in a short time. By doing so, they give new life to creating codes, understanding, and improving drug development, and solving problems related to climate change that used to be difficult.
Applications in Industry
Companies like Moderna are already harnessing quantum computing to accelerate vaccine development by simulating protein folding processes that traditional computers struggle with. One thing it does, on top of speeding up research, is to increase security in the face of potential cyber attacks from quantum hackers. For example, the same quantum algorithms that can perform these analyses more easily also enable breakthroughs in analyzing large datasets that were not possible before.
Learning Resources
When first learning to program with quantum, explore IBM‚Äôs Quantum Learning Path or Microsoft‚Äôs Quantum Development Kit. The hands-on experience with quantum algorithms and their applications is captured in these resources. Furthermore, Qiskit provides a community-driven portal for learning quantum programming by means of tutorials and projects.
Why Learn Quantum Computing?
Companies will be ramping up for the day that quantum computers become mainstream (usually called ‚ÄòQ day‚Äô), and a growing number of developers will be needed to understand quantum algorithms and what they mean for security and data processing. Quantum software and quantum research scientists will be sought-after roles.
3. Extended Reality (XR)
Photo by julien Tromeur on Unsplash
What is Extended Reality?
Extended reality encompasses virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR), and mixed reality (MR). By blending digital content with the real world, these technologies are creating immersive environments in which we interact with technology.
Impact on Industries
AR has changed the way people shop for things, especially furniture, which they could view as they would in their homes with IKEA‚Äôs AR. Not only do customers find it to be a great experience, but also, it drastically lowers return rates. Like Walmart, companies use VR for employee training simulations, such as staff practicing real-life scenarios in a safe environment.
Getting Started with XR
To dive into XR development, check out Unity‚Äôs Learn XR Development Path or Apple‚Äôs Vision Pro Development Course. They provide both general and sector-specific training on how to really create immersive experiences.
Why Learn XR Technologies?
XR development skills will become of great value as businesses from various industries (from sales to education) are becoming increasingly dependent on spatial computing. Jobs like XR developer and AR/VR designer are now the most important at tech companies that want to change customer engagement strategies.
4. Edge AI and Tiny Machine Learning
Photo by h heyerlein on Unsplash
Defining Edge AI
Artificial intelligence algorithms that process data locally (on devices) instead of relying on a central cloud server are called edge AI algorithms. Such an approach reduces latency while at the same time providing privacy since some sensitive data is kept on-device.
Real-World Examples
In its tractors, John Deere is using Edge AI to detect crop diseases and operate wirelessly. In that case, this innovation not only increases agricultural efficiency but also slashes pesticide usage by 30 percent, of course both for farmers and for consumers. The real-time processing of massive amounts of data by edge devices enables industries like manufacturing and agriculture to drastically optimize their operations.
Learning Opportunities
If you want to learn more about this field and are interested in the development of edge AI applications, the resources that I can suggest to you are Edge Impulse‚Äôs Foundation Course and Google‚Äôs TensorFlow Lite tutorial. Coursera also offers specialized courses on Tiny Machine Learning, covering topics of building helpful models for lagging devices. With edge AI becoming a necessity, we can expect over 7 billion IoT devices by 2025, each of which requires efficient AI processing; skills in edge AI will be critical to future-proofing your career.
Why Learn Edge AI?
With predictions suggesting that there will be over 7 billion IoT devices by 2025 ‚Äî each requiring efficient AI processing ‚Äî skills in Edge AI will be crucial for future-proofing your career. Roles such as Edge AI Engineer or IoT Solutions Architect are expected to grow significantly as industries adopt smarter technologies.
5. Advanced LLM Operations
Photo by Jona on Unsplash
What are Large Language Models (LLMs)?
Large language models are complex AI systems that can learn and write like a human, but they‚Äôre predicated on terabytes of data. Published in 2015, these models have inspired transformation in all kinds of sectors, such as healthcare, where they help doctors summarize patient information and a brand new treatment.
Significance of Customization
A Mayo Clinic LLM that has been rolled out in the healthcare company has already been deployed, which reduced the documentation time down for the healthcare professionals by many folds. By customizing the model, more accurate and also more explicit outputs can be made than are possible with general-purpose models. With organizations looking for more specialized LLM uses like chatbots or automated report generation, demand for expertise around tailoring those models is soaring.
Resources for Learning LLMs
If you want to learn more about LLM operations, look into OpenAI‚Äôs fine-tuning courses and Hugging Face‚Äôs LLM Engineering course. Practical knowledge needed to take advantage of LLMs exists on these platforms.
Why Learn About LLMs?
When companies incorporate LLMs in their customer service automation and content generation, one of the most useful skills to have will be the ability to customize LLMs ‚Äî just like you would code. Machine learning engineer or NLP specialist-type careers will be important in how organizations use language-based AI technologies.
Conclusion: Preparing for the Future
Seeing 2025, it is evident that whoever wants to survive in the tech industry should master these five things: i.e., the development of multimodal AI, quantum-ready programming, extended reality, edge AI, and much more advanced operations with LLMs. Knowing the skills now and spending time learning them ensures you are competitive and relevant to working in an ever-changing job market.
Sign up for courses about these fields to embrace the future of technology right now! There are endless opportunities and infinite potential for innovation.

9 GitHub Projects That Surprised Me
GitHub Repositories Simplified for You
C. L. Beard
¬∑
Follow
Published in

¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Jan 12, 2025
