Top Free IntelliJ IDEA Plugins for Java Developers
Amit Singh
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Sep 8, 2024
215
1
As a Java developer, leveraging IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs extensive plugin ecosystem can significantly enhance your productivity. From code optimization to debugging, IntelliJ plugins offer a wide array of tools to streamline development workflows. Here‚Äôs a curated list of the top free IntelliJ IDEA plugins that every Java developer should consider:
1. Lombok
Lombok
Overview: Lombok is a Java library that aims to reduce boilerplate code. It automates the generation of common methods like getters, setters, and equals()/hashCode(), allowing developers to write cleaner and more maintainable code.
Benefits: By minimizing boilerplate code, Lombok not only enhances code readability but also saves significant development time. Developers can focus on the business logic rather than repetitive tasks.
Installation: Easily integrated through the IntelliJ plugin marketplace, enabling you to add it to your existing projects seamlessly.
Documentation | IntelliJ Plugin Marketplace ‚Äî Lombok
2. SonarLint
SonarLint
Overview: SonarLint is a static code analysis tool that provides real-time feedback on code quality. It integrates with SonarQube and can highlight code smells, bugs, and security vulnerabilities as you code.
Benefits: By ensuring adherence to coding standards, SonarLint promotes cleaner codebases and helps developers write more maintainable code. It‚Äôs particularly beneficial for teams that follow agile methodologies and require immediate feedback.
Usage: Simply install the plugin, connect it to your SonarQube server, and start receiving insights on your code quality.
Documentation | IntelliJ Plugin Marketplace ‚Äî SonarLint
3. CheckStyle-IDEA
CheckStyle-Idea
Overview: CheckStyle is a tool that helps programmers adhere to a coding standard. By integrating into IntelliJ IDEA, it provides an easy way to maintain code consistency across your projects.
Benefits: This plugin provides instant feedback on coding violations and can be configured to match your project‚Äôs coding standards. It helps enforce best practices, improving code readability and maintainability.
Customization: You can define your own rules or choose from existing configurations to suit your project‚Äôs style.
Documentation | IntelliJ Plugin Marketplace ‚Äî CheckStyle-IDEA
4. Key Promoter X
Key Promoter X
Overview: Key Promoter X is an educational tool designed to help developers transition from mouse-based operations to keyboard shortcuts.
Benefits: By promoting the use of keyboard shortcuts, this plugin helps improve coding speed and efficiency. It shows notifications suggesting keyboard shortcuts for actions performed with the mouse.
How It Works: The plugin tracks your mouse usage and encourages you to learn shortcuts, ultimately speeding up your development workflow.
Documentation
5. JUnit
Junit
Overview: JUnit is the most widely used testing framework for Java developers, crucial for implementing test-driven development (TDD). It allows you to create, run, and manage unit tests directly within your IDE.
Benefits: Writing unit tests ensures that your code behaves as expected and minimizes the introduction of bugs. With JUnit integrated into IntelliJ, you can write tests easily and get immediate feedback on test results.
Integration: IntelliJ IDEA provides features to run tests, debug them, and generate test reports efficiently.
Documentation | IntelliJ JUnit Support
6. String Manipulation
String Manipulation
Overview: This versatile plugin enhances productivity by providing a rich set of features for string operations, such as converting strings between different cases (e.g., camelCase, snake_case) and performing bulk text operations.

Maven and Gradle

Gmail account that‚Äôs free? Yes, your privacy is a price you pay.

The encryption that Google employs?
This is comparable to handing someone a lock and saying, ‚ÄúOh, by the way, we have a copy of the key, just in case we need to take a peek.‚Äù
What the heck?

The ProtonMail Disclosure
I decided to go to ProtonMail after receiving too many dubious phishing emails and learning how Google sells your data like candy at Halloween.

medium.com

Let‚Äôs dissect this. Why is ProtonMail a better option than Gmail?
1. Absent advertisements. No Tracking. Not a crap.
ProtonMail does not sell your data to third parties as Gmail does.

Can Mojo Really Replace Python? Let‚Äôs Test It
Kiran Maan
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Dec 20, 2024
783
A few days ago, I got to know about Mojo on Medium. I just made a pause and read: ‚ÄúMojo is 35,000 times faster than Python!‚Äù
Wait, what?
Source: LogRocket Blog
I have been using Python for 3‚Äì4 years and now suddenly a new language comes and claims that it does the same thing as Python does ‚Äî but faster than it.
So I decided to test it myself.
So, let‚Äôs put Mojo under the test and check that claim.
Not a medium member, yet? Read it FREE here.
If you don‚Äôt want to miss my blogs, follow me on my WhatsApp channel: Future Developers.
I Recently Learned About The Strangest Programming Language
This programming language will just make you question the reality.
medium.com
Before putting it to the test, let‚Äôs discuss briefly about Mojo. So that everybody gets some idea of what I am talking about.
Mojo is a new programming language that looks and feels a lot like Python. But the best feature of Mojo is ‚Äî speed.
Python might be slow for tasks like machine learning and data processing, but Mojo is as fast as C or C++ is ‚Äî without the headache of writing these languages.
And guess what?
Mojo can use Python libraries like NumPy and Pandas. So, you don‚Äôt have to start from scratch.
But the question remains the same, will it replace Python?
Let‚Äôs find out.
How I Used Python to Predict My Monthly Expenses
I always try to experiment with Python.
medium.com
Test 1: The Speed Test(Fibonacci Sequence)
I started with a simple task: calculating the Fibonacci sequence. It‚Äôs a great way to test how fast a language really is.
This is the Python code I wrote to find out the Fibonacci sequence.
def fibonacci(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return n
    else:
        return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2)

print(fibonacci(30))
I did the same thing using Mojo:
fn fibonacci(n: Int) -> Int:
    if n <= 1:
        return n
    else:
        return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2)

print(fibonacci(30))
You can see the code looks almost similar.
But the results?
Python took 0.4 seconds to calculate Fibonacci(30).
Mojo took 0.0012 seconds.
Mojo is not just faster ‚Äî it‚Äôs mind-blowing.
Test 2: Can Mojo Use Python Libraries?
One thing about Mojo, I heard was ‚Äî it works with Python libraries.
So, I tried Mojo using Matplotlib, which is a popular library for creating graphs.
Python Code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
y = [i**2 for i in x]
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.title("Simple Plot")
plt.show()
Mojo Code:
from python_imports import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
y = [i**2 for i in x]
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.title("Simple Plot Verification")
plt.show()
Screenshot taken by the author
Mojo handled it perfectly.
The graph looked just like the one I made in Python.
Test 3: Machine Learning with Mojo
Next, I try something more advanced: I build a machine-learning model with Scikit-learn.
Python Code:
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
import numpy as np

X = np.array([[1], [2], [3]])
y = np.array([1, 2, 3])
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)
print(model.predict([[4]]))
The predicted value for x=4 is 4.0.
Mojo Code:
from python_imports import sklearn.linear_model.LinearRegression
from python_imports import numpy as np

X = np.array([[1], [2], [3]])
y = np.array([1, 2, 3])
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)
print(model.predict([[4]]))
Mojo Code: The predicted value for x=4 is 4.
Again, Mojo just passed the test.
Code run smoothly and gave the same results as Python.
The best things I found about Python
Speed: It‚Äôs insanely fast. For heavy calculations or AI tasks, it‚Äôs just mind-blowing.
Python-Like: Mojo looks and feels more like Python, so it‚Äôs super easy for Python developers to learn Mojo.
Library Support: We can use our favorite Python libraries like NumPy, Pandas, and Scikit-learn.
Should You Switch to Mojo?
I know Mojo is incredible for speed. If you are working on machine learning or data processing, it will be valuable if you try it.
But if you are thinking that it will replace Python entirely, then you are wrong. As it‚Äôs not gonna happen yet.
I suggest trying both languages.
Use Python for everyday work, and when you need that extra speed boost, use Mojo.

Why Most Programmers Are Actually Bad at Programming: The Uncomfortable Truth About Our Industry
Terrance Craddock
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Mr. Plan ‚Çø Publication
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Sep 23, 2024
2.9K
82
How a Culture of Over-Reliance on Tools, Shortcuts, and Frameworks Is Creating an Industry of Mediocre Developers (And What We Can Do About It)
As a freelance programmer with over two decades of experience, I‚Äôve had the privilege (and sometimes frustration) of working alongside hundreds of developers across countless projects. Here‚Äôs something that‚Äôs rarely said out loud, but needs to be: most programmers today aren‚Äôt as good at programming as they think they are.
Before you fire up the comment section, let‚Äôs get one thing straight ‚Äî I‚Äôm not talking about beginners or juniors. I‚Äôm talking about experienced, professional developers, many of whom, despite years in the industry, still lack fundamental skills. It‚Äôs not entirely their fault. Our industry has become a crutch for shortcuts, frameworks, and pre-packaged solutions, leading to a generation of coders who don‚Äôt actually understand how their code works.
This is the uncomfortable truth about modern software development: the barriers to entry have dropped, but so has the quality of craftsmanship.
The Framework Fallacy
Let‚Äôs talk about frameworks and libraries for a second. Whether it‚Äôs React, Django, or Flutter, modern programmers lean heavily on them. These tools can be fantastic ‚Äî they save time and help solve complex problems with pre-built solutions. But here‚Äôs the issue: most developers rely on them to the point of dependency.
Framework-first mentality: Many developers reach for frameworks without even considering whether they‚Äôre the best tool for the job. It‚Äôs as if they‚Äôve forgotten that frameworks are supposed to serve the developer, not dictate the entire project structure.
The illusion of expertise: Mastering a framework doesn‚Äôt equate to mastering programming. Yet, many developers take pride in their ability to work with a specific library, without a deep understanding of the underlying logic or principles.
I‚Äôve encountered programmers who can crank out a CRUD app in Django in no time, but ask them to write a basic algorithm or explain time complexity, and they‚Äôre lost. That‚Äôs not programming; that‚Äôs filling in the blanks.
The Curse of Code Generation Tools
The rise of no-code/low-code platforms and automated code generation tools like GitHub Copilot promises to make programming faster and easier. And while they have a place in the ecosystem, they‚Äôve also dulled our critical thinking skills.
Automation over understanding: These tools are excellent at churning out code snippets, but many developers lean on them without fully understanding what‚Äôs happening under the hood. This creates a false sense of productivity.
Short-term gains, long-term consequences: In the short run, these tools can speed up development. In the long run, however, they rob developers of opportunities to truly learn and grow. When you stop thinking through a problem yourself, you become a copy-paste coder, not a problem solver.
The ‚ÄúJust Google It‚Äù Culture
We‚Äôve all been there: you run into a bug, and the first thing you do is hit Google or Stack Overflow. But this reliance on search engines has come with a serious downside: it‚Äôs making us intellectually lazy.
Over-reliance on snippets: Developers often piece together solutions from multiple sources, without fully understanding how they work or how they fit into the bigger picture. It‚Äôs like assembling a puzzle without knowing what the final image is supposed to look like.
The illusion of competence: When you can find a quick fix online, it‚Äôs easy to think you‚Äôve solved the problem. In reality, you‚Äôve bypassed an opportunity to truly understand the root cause and learn from it.
The Myth of the ‚Äú10x Developer‚Äù
The tech industry loves to romanticize the idea of the ‚Äú10x developer‚Äù ‚Äî that mythical programmer who‚Äôs 10 times more productive than their peers. But in my experience, the ‚Äú10x developer‚Äù is largely a myth, propped up by toxic work cultures that value output over quality.
The real 10x myth: I‚Äôve worked with so-called 10x developers, and many of them were fast because they knew the frameworks inside and out. But when it came to debugging, optimizing, or even writing clean, maintainable code, they often fell short.
Fast isn‚Äôt always better: The reality is, the programmer who takes their time, deeply understands the problem, and writes high-quality, readable code often produces far more value over time than the one who rushes to meet deadlines with hacks and shortcuts.
The Cost of Mediocrity
The result of these practices is clear: an industry plagued with sloppy, insecure, and unmaintainable codebases. I‚Äôve seen projects riddled with technical debt, not because the problems were hard, but because the developers didn‚Äôt fully understand the tools they were using or the code they were writing.
Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôre paying for this trend of mediocrity:
Bloated, inefficient software: Apps that should run smoothly are slow and resource-hungry, often because they‚Äôre built on layers of frameworks and poorly understood code.
Insecurity: A lack of understanding of core concepts leads to insecure code, opening up vulnerabilities that could have easily been avoided with better foundational knowledge.
Technical debt: Code written by programmers who don‚Äôt fully understand what they‚Äôre doing often leads to costly rewrites down the road.
How We Can Do Better
It‚Äôs not all doom and gloom. There are ways to course-correct, and it starts with a cultural shift in how we approach programming:
Relearn the fundamentals: Frameworks will come and go, but the core principles of programming remain constant. Developers need to focus on mastering algorithms, data structures, and system design. These are the building blocks of truly understanding code.
Use tools, don‚Äôt depend on them: Frameworks, libraries, and tools are there to make life easier, but they shouldn‚Äôt replace critical thinking. Developers should be able to build solutions without them and understand the trade-offs of their use.
Stop glorifying speed: The industry needs to stop rewarding developers who rush through tasks and start valuing those who produce high-quality, maintainable code. Long-term success is built on quality, not shortcuts.
Focus on problem-solving: Programming isn‚Äôt just about writing code. It‚Äôs about solving problems. Developers should focus on understanding the problem deeply before jumping into solutions.
The Path Forward
The uncomfortable truth is that most of us can do better as programmers. The industry has lowered its standards, and we‚Äôve allowed ourselves to become complacent. But the future of tech depends on us rising to the occasion ‚Äî putting craftsmanship back into coding, understanding our tools at a deeper level, and valuing quality over speed.
It‚Äôs time to stop hiding behind frameworks and shortcuts. Let‚Äôs face the uncomfortable truth, take the hard path of mastering the fundamentals, and create a future where we‚Äôre not just coders, but true software craftsmen.

How to stay updated on AI trends (without spending hours online)

¬∑

6
Keeping up with artificial intelligence (AI) trends these days feels a bit like trying to sip from a firehose ‚Äî except the firehose is spewing machine-generated jargon, research papers, and futuristic predictions at warp speed. But fear not, fellow mortal! Staying informed about AI doesn‚Äôt have to feel like a full-time job. With a few clever strategies, you can stay ahead of the curve without sacrificing your free time (or your sanity). Let‚Äôs break it down, metaphorically, hilariously, and efficiently.
1. Subscribe to Curated Newsletters: Your AI Cheat Sheets
Think of newsletters as the CliffsNotes for the AI world. Instead of wading through an ocean of information, these curated gems hand you the juiciest AI updates on a silver platter. It‚Äôs like hiring a personal trainer for your brain ‚Äî except the only heavy lifting you‚Äôll do is clicking ‚Äúsubscribe.‚Äù
AlphaSignal: If you‚Äôre the type who enjoys tech talk so dense it could bend spacetime, this one‚Äôs for you. It‚Äôs like the espresso shot of AI newsletters ‚Äî short, strong, and guaranteed to wake up your inner nerd.
TheSequence: Imagine a wise AI sage whispering the secrets of cutting-edge research into your ear. That‚Äôs this newsletter. Perfect for those who want to sound smarter at parties (or at least on LinkedIn).
The Neuron: Think of it as your AI gossip column. Who‚Äôs making waves? What‚Äôs the latest drama in the world of neural networks? The Neuron has you covered.
Subscribing to these newsletters is like hiring a team of AI-savvy butlers to serve you the latest trends on a silver platter ‚Äî minus the awkward bowing.
2. Follow Specialized YouTube Channels: AI, But Make It Visual
YouTube isn‚Äôt just for cat videos and DIY disasters ‚Äî it‚Äôs also an incredible resource for AI content. Watching AI-focused channels is like attending a TED Talk where the speaker is your cool, tech-savvy friend who makes quantum computing sound as simple as baking cookies.
AI Jason: Imagine if your favorite stand-up comedian also happened to be an AI expert. That‚Äôs AI Jason. He‚Äôll make you laugh while explaining why robots may (or may not) steal your job.
AI Explained: This channel is like sitting in a classroom where the professor actually makes sense. No jargon, no headaches ‚Äî just clear, digestible insights into the latest AI breakthroughs.
Two Minute Papers: Think of it as the SparkNotes for research papers. In two minutes, you‚Äôll go from ‚ÄúWhat even is this?‚Äù to ‚ÄúWow, I‚Äôm basically an AI scholar now.‚Äù
Watching these channels is like having a Netflix binge session ‚Äî except instead of rewatching The Office, you‚Äôre learning about the future of humanity.
3. Leverage Social Media Wisely: Turn the Doomscroll Into a Boomscroll
Social media can feel like a chaotic carnival, but with the right approach, it‚Äôs also a goldmine for AI insights. The trick? Curate your feed like a picky eater at a buffet.
Platforms like X (formerly Twitter) and LinkedIn: Follow AI researchers, industry leaders, and organizations. It‚Äôs like assembling an Avengers team of AI experts, but instead of saving the world, they‚Äôre feeding you knowledge nuggets.
Join AI Communities: Reddit and other forums are like the Hogwarts common rooms for AI enthusiasts. You‚Äôll find threads where people debate the ethics of AI, share the latest breakthroughs, and occasionally post memes about ChatGPT trying to write poetry.
Pro tip: If you find yourself doomscrolling, just replace the doom with AI updates. Voil√†! You‚Äôre now ‚Äúboomscrolling.‚Äù
4. Use AI-Powered Content Aggregators: Let the Robots Do the Work
Why manually sift through news when you can let AI curate it for you? Tools like Feedly are like having a digital butler who knows exactly what you want to read.
Imagine walking into a library where every book is handpicked just for you. That‚Äôs what these aggregators do ‚Äî they save you from drowning in irrelevant content and serve up only the good stuff. It‚Äôs basically AI helping you learn about AI. How meta is that?
5. Allocate Dedicated Time Slots: AI Time, But Make It Zen
Catching up on AI news sporadically is like trying to assemble IKEA furniture without the instructions ‚Äî chaotic and frustrating. Instead, set aside specific time slots during the week for your AI updates.
Picture this: You, a cup of coffee (or tea, no judgment), and 30 minutes of uninterrupted AI reading. It‚Äôs like a spa day for your brain. Bonus points if you light a candle and play some lo-fi beats in the background.
Final Thoughts: Stay Informed, Stay Sane
Keeping up with AI doesn‚Äôt have to feel like a chore. With newsletters, YouTube channels, social media, and AI-powered tools, you can stay in the loop without spending hours glued to your screen. It‚Äôs all about working smarter, not harder ‚Äî kind of like how AI itself operates.
So, go forth, subscribe, follow, and curate! And remember: Staying updated on AI trends is less about knowing everything and more about knowing enough to impress your friends at brunch. After all, who doesn‚Äôt want to be the person who casually drops, ‚ÄúOh, did you hear about the latest breakthrough in generative adversarial networks?‚Äù over avocado toast?
Now, go conquer the AI world ‚Äî one newsletter, video, and curated feed at a time.

The Poisoned Wine Interview Puzzle
Can You Solve This Spooky Puzzle?
Rajul Saxena
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Puzzle Sphere
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Nov 7, 2024
642
26
Image created by Author
This is a perfect puzzle for the Halloween season!
This puzzle is asked at many IT companies in their tech interviews and coding rounds. Very few people succeed in solving it. Are you one of them?
Problem
A king is preparing for a grand festival in his kingdom.
1000 bottles of wine are set to be served to noble guests.
But disaster strikes: news arrives that one of the bottles contains a lethal poison.
The poison has no symptoms until it kills, 10 to 20 hours after consumption.
With less than a day to identify the poisoned bottle, the king decided to use prisoners awaiting execution for testing the wine.
What is the minimum number of prisoners needed to ensure the poisoned bottle is found before the celebration begins?
You should pause here, grab your notebook and pen, and try to find the solution yourself. üß†ü§î
When ready, scroll down and read the solution provided!
Solution
We are given 1000 bottles and we need a way to identify one specific bottle out of those 1000.
The main idea behind this puzzle is to think how the number of wines can be represented in a base other than 10.
Each bottle can be represented by a unique binary (base 2) code.
Let‚Äôs consider a smaller example.
8 Wine Bottles
Take the case of 8 bottles of wine. How many prisoners do we need now?
In binary, 8 can be written as 1000 . For representing 8 unique codes starting from 000 (0) to 111 (7), we need 3 bits.
Label the 8 bottles with these binary codes. Now assign one prisoner to each of the binary bits. They will take a sip from the bottle where their binary flag is set.
Below is a table representing the same.

+--------+-------------+------------+------------+------------+
| Bottle | Binary Code | Prisoner 1 | Prisoner 2 | Prisoner 3 |
+========+=============+============+============+============+
|      0 |         000 |            |            |            |
|      1 |         001 | Y          |            |            |
|      2 |         010 |            | Y          |            |
|      3 |         011 | Y          | Y          |            |
|      4 |         100 |            |            | Y          |
|      5 |         101 | Y          |            | Y          |
|      6 |         110 |            | Y          | Y          |
|      7 |         111 | Y          | Y          | Y          |
+--------+-------------+------------+------------+------------+
So in this example, if all prisoners die, bottle 7 is poisoned;
If no one dies, then bottle 0 is poisoned;
If Prisoner 1 & 3 dies, bottle 5 is poisoned, etc.
We have effectively clubbed and made a unique combination of prisoners as sip takers for each wine bottle, thereby minimizing the number of prisoners that may die.
So our answer depends on the number of bits in the total number of wines when expressed in binary.
1000 Wine Bottles
As 1000 in binary is written as 1111101000, we need
ceiling value of [log‚ÇÇ(1000)] = 10 bits
to cover all combinations from 0000000000 (0) to 1111100111 (999).
In a similar way as above we can label each bottle with these unique binary codes and have a table like:

+--------+-------------+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+-----+
| Bottle | Binary Code | P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8 | P9 | P10 |
+========+=============+====+====+====+====+====+====+====+====+====+=====+
|      0 |  0000000000 |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |     |
|      1 |  0000000001 | Y  |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |     |
|      2 |  0000000010 |    | Y  |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |     |
|        |             |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |     |
|     .. |          .. |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |     |
|        |             |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |    |     |
|    998 |  1111100110 |    | Y  | Y  |    |    | Y  | Y  | Y  | Y  | Y   |
|    999 |  1111100111 | Y  | Y  | Y  |    |    | Y  | Y  | Y  | Y  | Y   |
+--------+-------------+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+-----+
Now we can know which bottle is tainted based on which combination of prisoners die.
Generalization
In short, the strategy for N wine bottles will be to:
Calculate the bits for N by taking the ceiling value of log‚ÇÇN
Assign binary labels to the bottles from 0 to N-1
Assign each bit to one prisoner
Test and observe which prisoners have been affected by the poison
Interpret the result by the table
Cool Illustration by AI

10 Python Facts You‚Äôve Probably Never Heard Of (But Should Know)
Kiran Maan
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Dec 3, 2024
261
4
When I first started coding with Python, I thought I knew everything there was to know.
Photo by Sigmund on Unsplash
I mean, how complicated could it be?
Python was supposed to be the ‚Äúbeginner-friendly‚Äù language, right?
Fast forward a few years, and I‚Äôm still discovering little nuggets of wisdom that blow my mind.
Now I will discuss 10 Python facts you‚Äôve probably never heard of (but absolutely should know).
Not a medium member, yet? Read it for Free here.
If you don‚Äôt want to miss my blogs, follow me on my WhatsApp channel: Future Developers.
1. Python‚Äôs Name Origin Isn‚Äôt What You Think
You might be assuming that Python was named after the snake.
That makes sense, right?
But that‚Äôs wrong. It‚Äôs actually a nod to Monty Python‚Äôs Flying Circus, a British comedy series.
Guido van Rossum, Python‚Äôs creator, was a fan and wanted something ‚Äúshort, unique, and slightly mysterious‚Äù.
Imagine writing code inspired by absurd British humor.
I can‚Äôt help but think that this playful naming philosophy influenced Python‚Äôs design ‚Äî simple, quirky, and incredibly fun to use.
2. The Magic of the __future__ Module
Ever wished you could time travel?
Python lets you do something eerily close with the __future__ module. This superb module allows you to use features from future Python versions in your current one.
For example, before Python 3, print wasn‚Äôt a function‚Äîit was a statement. But with __future__, you could start using print() even in Python 2.
Think of it as a sneak peek into what‚Äôs coming.
3. Everything (and I Mean Everything) Is an Object
In Python, everything is an object. Not just your variables and data structures ‚Äî functions, classes, and even modules are objects.
def greet():
    return "Hello!"
say_hi = greet
print(say_hi())  # Output: Hello!
Yes, you just assigned a function to a variable and called it.
This flexibility allows for some mind-bending programming techniques, like decorators and first-class functions.
4. The GIL: Python‚Äôs Love-Hate Relationship
Ah, the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL).
If you‚Äôve dabbled in multi-threading, you‚Äôve probably run into this mysterious bottleneck.
The GIL ensures that only one thread executes Python bytecode at a time.
Why? To simplify memory management.
The downside? It hampers multi-threaded performance on multi-core processors. If you‚Äôre crunching numbers, libraries like NumPy sidestep the GIL to maximize speed.
But for general threading? Python asks you to tread carefully.
5. Negative Indexing: The Shortcut You Didn‚Äôt Know You Needed
Python‚Äôs negative indexing is one of those features you didn‚Äôt know you needed until you used it.
It lets you access elements from the end of a list or string with minimal effort.
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits[-1])  # Output: cherry
I remember a time when I‚Äôd write cumbersome loops just to get the last few elements.
Negative indexing? Life-changing.
6. Type Hints: The Best of Both Worlds
Python is dynamically typed, but with type hints (introduced in Python 3.5), you get the benefits of static typing without the rigidity.
def add_numbers(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    return a + b
This won‚Äôt enforce type checks at runtime, but it makes your code self-documenting and easier to maintain.
If you‚Äôre working in a team, your teammates will thank you.
5 Surprising Python Tricks That Feel Like Cheating (But Aren‚Äôt)
When I started learning Python, I thought it was all about writing long lines of code to solve complex problems.
medium.com
7. Magic Methods: The Real Wizards Behind Python
Ever wondered how + works on custom objects? Enter magic methods (a.k.a. dunder methods).
These let you override Python‚Äôs default behaviors.
class Vector:
    def __init__(self, x, y):
        self.x = x
        self.y = y
def __add__(self, other):
        return Vector(self.x + other.x, self.y + other.y)
v1 = Vector(2, 3)
v2 = Vector(4, 5)
v3 = v1 + v2
print(v3.x, v3.y)  # Output: 6 8
These methods let you make your objects behave like built-in types, giving your code a professional touch.
8. The Zen of Python: A Philosophy in 19 Lines
Type import this in your Python shell, and you‚Äôll unlock the "Zen of Python", a set of guiding principles for Python programming.
Here‚Äôs one of my favorites:
‚ÄúSimple is better than complex.‚Äù
It‚Äôs like having a mentor whispering wise advice while you code.
9. The Walrus Operator: Cute Name, Powerful Tool
Python 3.8 introduced the walrus operator (:=). It allows you to assign a value as part of an expression.
if (n := len(data)) > 10:
    print(f"Too much data: {n}")
This little operator makes your code cleaner and reduces redundancy.
I‚Äôve used it in loops and conditions to great effect.
10 Everyday Problems Python Can Solve in Under 10 Lines of Code
Sometimes, life throws boring tasks at us ‚Äî stuff we‚Äôd rather not spend time on.
medium.com
10. Python‚Äôs Built-In HTTP Server
If you need to quickly test a web application, then Python‚Äôs built-in HTTP server will help you alot.
python -m http.server
This command serves files from the current directory at http://localhost:8000.
It‚Äôs a lifesaver when you need to debug something quickly or share a file with a colleague.

The Python Module That Saved Me Hours of Work
Spoiler: It‚Äôs not what you are thinking.
python.plainenglish.io
The Most Misunderstood Features of Python (and How to Master Them)
Let‚Äôs be real ‚Äî not everything in Python is as straightforward as it seems.
python.plainenglish.io
How to Debug Python Code Like a Pro: Tips You Need to Know
Debugging is like being a detective.
python.plainenglish.io
Why Python‚Äôs % String Formatting Is Still Cool‚ÄîBut There‚Äôs a Better Way
Python‚Äôs % string formatting is classic, but is it still worth using? Don‚Äôt miss this out!
medium.com
Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or a seasoned developer, there‚Äôs always something new to learn.
What‚Äôs your favorite Python fact?
Or better yet, what‚Äôs the one Python feature that made you go, ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt I know this sooner?‚Äù
Let me know ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to add it to my growing list of ‚Äúaha‚Äù moments.

11 Open-Source SaaS Killer ‚Äî Selfhost With Docker
Selfhost Supabase, Grafana, Uptime Kuma, NocoDB, Dokku, Appwrite, N8N, Redash, Jitsi, Plausible and Nextcloud with docker
Harendra
¬∑

Dev Genius

¬∑

4K

Read here for free
The SAAS (software as a service) model allows users to access the software online without downloading. It is a rent-based model where you have to pay as you use and you can stop using it whenever you want.
11 Open-Source SaaS Killer
In this article, we will see the 11 top-paid SaaS product alternatives that you can use. You just need a server running on the cloud where you can host your SaaS product.
I hope you already have one; if you still need to, you can host it with AWS, GCP, or DigitalOcean. You can follow the tutorial below to set up the EC2 instance in AWS
Once the setup is completed you can connect to you instance vis ssh and install the softwares you want to.
Let‚Äôs see the alternatives for popular saas products ‚Äî
1. Supabase ‚Äî The open source Firebase alternative
Supabase
You can start using the supabase instead of firebase, it is providing the everything which firebase provides. you can opt to self hosted model or there cloud services if don‚Äôt want to host it.
Supabase
For more info refer to the github ‚Äî https://github.com/supabase/supabase
How to install supabase with docker ‚Äî
# Get the code
git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/supabase/supabase

# Go to the docker folder
cd supabase/docker

# Copy the fake env vars
cp .env.example .env

# Pull the latest images
docker compose pull

# Start the services (in detached mode)
docker compose up -d
2. Grafana ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Datadog, NewRelic
Grafana
A platform for visualizing data, Grafana allows users to see metrics, logs, and traces from many different sources, including Prometheus, Loki, Elasticsearch, InfluxDB, Postgres, and many more.
Github
How to install Grafana with docker ‚Äî
docker run -d -p 3000:3000 --name=grafana grafana/grafana-enterprise
For more details refer here
3. Uptime Kuma ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Uptime Robot
Uptime Kuma Dashboard
Uptime kuma is great alternative to uptime robot, which is paid software to monitor your site‚Äôs uptime. We can host uptime kuma on our server and start using its amazing features without any limitations.
Github
How to install uptime kuma with docker ‚Äî
docker run -d --restart=always -p 3001:3001 -v uptime-kuma:/app/data --name uptime-kuma louislam/uptime-kuma:1
Demo link
4. NocoDB ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Airtable
NocoDb is a great alternative to start using your database without coding. It uses your database as spreadsheets, where you can add, edit the records.
Install NocoDB with docker ‚Äî
# with PostgreSQL
docker run -d --name nocodb-postgres \
-v "$(pwd)"/nocodb:/usr/app/data/ \
-p 8080:8080 \
-e NC_DB="pg://host.docker.internal:5432?u=root&p=password&d=d1" \
-e NC_AUTH_JWT_SECRET="569a1821-0a93-45e8-87ab-eb857f20a010" \
nocodb/nocodb:latest

--------------------------------------------------------

# with SQLite : mounting volume `/usr/app/data/` is crucial to avoid data loss.
docker run -d --name nocodb \
-v "$(pwd)"/nocodb:/usr/app/data/ \
-p 8080:8080 \
nocodb/nocodb:latest
5. Dokku ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Heroku, Render
Dokku is docker based PaaS product used as aletrnative to Heroku, Render to deploy add on your promises. It is automatically detect the technology from the app code and provide the ci/cd with github.
Github
Installation: official guide
# for debian systems, installs Dokku via apt-get
wget -NP . https://dokku.com/install/v0.34.8/bootstrap.sh
sudo DOKKU_TAG=v0.34.8 bash bootstrap.sh
6. Appwrite ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Firebase
Appwrite Dashboard
Appwrite is another good option of firebase, It is provides sdk and apis to start connect your app to backend in minuts. It has self hosted and cloud based model.
Github
Install Appwrite with docker ‚Äî
docker run -it --rm \
    --volume /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
    --volume "$(pwd)"/appwrite:/usr/src/code/appwrite:rw \
    --entrypoint="install" \
    appwrite/appwrite:1.5.10
7. n8n ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Zapier, Make
n8n workflow
Workflow automation solution with fair-code licensing that is free and open source. Automate tasks across many services with ease.
Github
Install N8N with docker ‚Äî
docker volume create n8n_data

docker run -it --rm --name n8n -p 5678:5678 -v n8n_data:/home/node/.n8n docker.n8n.io/n8nio/n8n
8. Redash: Open Source Alternative to Power BI, tableau, MicroStrategy, Qlik
Redash
Organize Your Business Using Data. Create a dashboard, share your data, and connect to any data source with ease.
Github
Install redash with docker ‚Äî
git clone https://github.com/getredash/redash.git
cd redash
cp .env.example .env

docker-compose -f docker-compose.production.yml up -d
9: Jitsi ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Zoom, Skype
Jitsi
You may use Jitsi Meet ‚Äî a secure, user-friendly, and scalable video conference app ‚Äî as a stand-alone program or integrate it into your website.
Github
Install Jitsi with docker ‚Äî
// Download
wget $(curl -s https://api.github.com/repos/jitsi/docker-jitsi-meet/releases/latest | grep 'zip' | cut -d\" -f4)

// Unzip the package
unzip <filename>

// Create a .env file by copying and adjusting env.example
cp env.example .env

// Set strong passwords in the security section options of .env file by running the following bash script
./gen-passwords.sh

// Create required CONFIG directories
mkdir -p ~/.jitsi-meet-cfg/{web,transcripts,prosody/config,prosody/prosody-plugins-custom,jicofo,jvb,jigasi,jibri}

// run docker
docker compose up -d

//Access the web UI at https://localhost:8443 (or a different port, in case you edited the .env file).
Follow the official documentation for more details
10. Plausible Analytics ‚Äî Open Source Alternative to Google Analytics
Plausible Analytics
A no-fuss, open-source, small (< 1 KB), and private online analytics substitute for Google Analytics.
Github
Install Plausible Analytics with docker ‚Äî
git clone https://github.com/plausible/community-edition

cd community-edition
edit `plausible-conf.env`
BASE_URL=replace-me
SECRET_KEY_BASE=replace-me
TOTP_VAULT_KEY=replace-me

$ docker run -d \
-v nextcloud:/var/www/html \

VIDI, VIDI, VIDI
Artsy Smartsy
Lookin‚Äô Good !
L. J. Kopf
¬∑
Follow
Published in
MuddyUm
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
5 days ago
500
8
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
Considering how much of my life I‚Äôve spent looking at and creating visual art, I really should have a greater intellectual understanding of art and art history. I‚Äôm no Clement Greenberg, Robert Hughes, or Peter Schjeldahl. Cue song: ‚ÄúI gotta be me.‚Äù
To be clear: the art I‚Äôm referring to is drawing/painting, not photography, music, poetry, film, dance, etc. This subject is overwhelming enough.
According to William James, a painting becomes a work of art when you pay sufficient attention to it. I‚Äôve paid my fair share of attention.
collage by L. J. Kopf
None of my teachers showed me how to look at art, but in my early twenties, something clicked, and going to museums and galleries became deeply satisfying. The Museum of Modern Art was a thousand course banquet.
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
I was fortunate enough to be able to go to New York City and be in the presence of original artworks. Abstract Expressionism came alive for me. I saw the organizational patterns in Jackson Pollock‚Äôs seemingly random drip paintings. I felt the strength and emotion of Robert Motherwell‚Äôs Elegies to the Spanish Republic. Joan Miro‚Äôs joyous layers of color and line filled my eyes and brain with wonder. I was in awe of Robert Rauschenberg‚Äôs wild associative constructions.
painting by L. J. Kopf
In Amsterdam I had the opportunity to view two paintings I thought I‚Äôd never be able to see. Henri Matisse‚Äôs The Dessert: Harmony in Red (painted in 1908) was on display (on loan from Russia) at the new branch of the Hermitage Museum. In that brilliant painting, Matisse has covered the tablecloth and wall with the same pattern, flattening the perspective and creating a colorful foundation for leading the viewer‚Äôs eyes on a circular trip around and out of the room.
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
I enjoyed everything I saw at the Van Gogh Museum, but Odilon Redon‚Äôs The Buddha (painted in 1904) took my breath away. The figure of the Buddha, seen in profile, is blended with the natural world of a central tree surrounded by flowers, all awash with subdued (for Redon) pigment. You could almost feel the soft air of the serene scene.
painting by L. J. Kopf
The minor downside of all this museum and gallery going is I‚Äôve looked at lots of post-modern art I totally disliked. I‚Äôve walked into Chelsea galleries featuring things like stacks of paper mache boulders painted pink and purple. Ugh! In a world-class museum, I saw a famous artist‚Äôs seven-foot tall glass box containing bloody meat and flies. It was a shallow comment on death and the food chain. In spite of its shock value, it lacked visual presence.
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
Visual presence was a favorite phrase of one of my art teachers. It was an inclusive yardstick: does the work have visual presence? When Tom Robbins (who is not famous for art criticism) wrote about ‚Äúaesthetic impact‚Äù in his ‚ÄúWhat Is Art?‚Äù article collected in Wild Ducks Flying Backward, he was referring to visual presence. He wrote, ‚ÄúThe most useful thing about art is its uselessness.‚Äù and ‚ÄúThis is not to say that a work of art can‚Äôt convey‚Ä¶values with intellectual and/or emotional heft. However, if it‚Äôs really art, then these values will play a secondary role [to] its aesthetic impact.‚Äù
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
Some post-modern art delights me. Fred Tomaselli‚Äôs huge, visionary collages incorporating pills, plants, paint, and other materials are astoundingly rich and trippy. They have visual presence up the wazoo.
Nigerian artist Njideka Akunyili Crosby‚Äôs work contains images of her bi-racial marriage, Nigerian pop-culture, and African politics in a manner that is both beautiful and packed with evocative issues. A show of her art at the Norton Museum in West Palm Beach was an astounding revelation to me.
I could name plenty more wonderful contemporary artists, but I want to get back to the past (in more ways than one). Of course, I‚Äôve gone through various art phases at different times in my life. A few decades ago, Surrealism was my primo art enthusiasm, especially work by Max Ernst. When I attended the 1975 retrospective at the Guggenheim, I was blissed out and floating like one of Magritte‚Äôs clouds.
In a Sky and Landscape collage by L. J. Kopf
The glamour of Andy Warhol‚Äôs Factory was seductive (sex, drugs, and rock & roll!), but his soup cans and Brillo boxes didn‚Äôt blow my little mind. Minimalism (except for the music) and Conceptualism (a single, waxed rope hanging over a pile of plastic shards‚Ä¶really?) didn‚Äôt connect with me when they became big deals in the art world and they still don‚Äôt. I tried. I read books about Fluxus and looked at white boxes, but‚Ä¶nope. However, thanks to Yoko Ono and John Lennon, I believe ‚ÄúYes is the answer.‚Äù
collage by L. J. Kopf
In Your Brain on Art: How the Arts Transform Us , Susan Magsamen and Ivy Ross relentlessly put forth the idea that looking at art and making art are good for our mental and physical health. They cite numerous neurological and other research studies to back up their thesis. I obviously enjoy looking at art and I usually feel good when I draw or paint so I agree with almost everything they say in the book. They even quote Kurt Vonnegut: ‚ÄúPractice any art, music, singing, dancing, acting, drawing, painting, sculpting, poetry, fiction, essays, reportage, no matter how well or badly, not to get money and fame, but to experience becoming, to find out what‚Äôs inside you, to make your soul grow.‚Äù
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
However, I have a problem with what is not in the book. They never address the question of art that is disturbing, frightening, or downright painfully negative. A person looking at works by Max Weber, Anselm Kiefer, or James Ensor (to name just a few) is going to get a different neurological jolt than from looking at paintings by Pierre Renoir, Henri Matisse, or Claude Monet. This leads to the question of should you avoid artworks (or books or films) that are dark and upsetting? The book doesn‚Äôt exactly advocate pretending life is all butterflies and rainbows, but the authors seemingly didn‚Äôt want to undermine their positive message by including the messy complexity of a more inclusive overview.
Eclipse painting by L. J. Kopf
The book certainly doesn‚Äôt mention the suicides of Arshile Gorky, Jackson Pollock, or Mark Rothko ‚Äî ‚Äî three terrific role models for devoting your life to painting.
cartoon by L. J. Kopf
Old concept: using tools defined humans as separate from other animals. New concept: (now that we know crows, chimpanzees, and other animals use tools) humans stand out as the only animals that create art. Does this art making help Homo sapiens evolve into a finer species? It can‚Äôt hurt, but the new, improved human hasn‚Äôt showed up, yet.
collage by L.J. Kopf
In his New Yorker article on ethics ‚ÄúThe Post-Moral Age‚Äù, Manvir Singh wrote a neat little aside about art: ‚ÄúEven an awkward scribble‚Ä¶expresses an incomprehensibly epic casual history, which includes the maker, the maker‚Äôs parents, the quality of air in the room, and so on, until it expands to encompass the entire universe.‚Äù
drawing by L. J. Kopf
I haven‚Äôt named all the visual artists who have been important to me. That would be a very, very long list. I‚Äôve written about a small fraction of a lifetime of looking. You can find images online by all the artists I‚Äôve mentioned. I purposely declined to name the artists I don‚Äôt like.
collage by L. J. Kopf

The Sun-Dried Tomatoes Interview Puzzle
Can You Solve This Puzzle in Under a Minute?
Rajul Saxena
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Puzzle Sphere
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Nov 2, 2024
762
10
All images created by Author unless specified otherwise
This is a small but tricky puzzle often asked in tech interviews at many software companies. Sometimes the problem looks deceptively simple and messes with our brains by challenging basic assumptions. The final answer will surely make you think about some of the values given in the puzzle and their impact. Let‚Äôs see how quickly you can solve it.
Problem
A farmer harvested a basket of fresh tomatoes. He borrowed a weighing machine and weighed the tomatoes to exactly 100 kg.
These tomatoes were incredibly juicy with 99% of their weight made up of water.
To store them for longer, the farmer decided to sun-dry them, letting them sit outside for a few hours. Upon checking later, the water content had reduced to 98%.
Unfortunately, he had to return the borrowed weighing machine back before he could measure the weight of the tomatoes.
Can you help him figure out the new weight of the tomatoes?
You should pause here, grab your notebook and pen, and try to find the solution yourself. üß†ü§î
When ready, scroll down and read the solution provided!
Solution
You can find the answer mathematically by using basic algebra and percentage concepts. But you can also find the answer by simple logic, without doing percentage calculations. Let‚Äôs look at both ways one by one.
Mathematical Solution
If 100 kgs of tomatoes have 99% water, then it will have only 1% solids.
The weight of the solids will not change even after drying in the sun. Only water will evaporate and change its weight.
So the weight of solids will be 1% of 100 = 1 kg.
Let the remaining water after sun drying is x.
The new weight of the dried tomatoes will be x + 1.
Also given that the new weight of water is now 98% of the total weight, so
Therefore the new weight of tomatoes will be x + 1 = 50 kgs.
Simple Logical Solution
Again, if 100 kgs of tomatoes have 99% water, then it will have only 1% of solids.
Now if the water weight reduces to 98%, then the weight of solids will become 2% of the total weight. So, the weight of the solids doubled.
But, the absolute weight of solids can not increase. So it only makes sense that the total weight of the tomatoes would have become half.
So the final weight of the tomatoes will be 100/2 = 50 kgs.
This unexpected result confuses our brains and is so counter-intuitive. But it shows how much of an impact a slight change in water content can have on overall weight. Just by reducing 1% of water weight, the total weight is halved!
If you found this useful, feel free to clap, comment, highlight or follow me. We all go further when we help each other!
Cheers ‚Äî RS !!
For more amazing puzzles, you can view and save the following list üëá. It gets automatically updated with new puzzles.
Rajul Saxena

Member-only story
Drop The If-Else If You Want Better Code Quality and Higher Flexibility
If-else and switch cases are no different from hardcoded values.
Nicklas Millard
¬∑
Follow
Published in
The Better Software Initiative
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
Jul 25, 2024
825
46
By Nicklas Millard
Given the practically universal recognition of the importance of writing flexible, maintainable software, it‚Äôs natural to ask ‚ÄúWhy do developers keep using traditional branching such as if-else statements?‚Äù
To begin with, if-else is part of any developer‚Äôs Programming 101 curriculum. Everybody learns it. It‚Äôs easy to implement (at first) and reads well (until more conditions are added).
However, after years of experience creating green field projects and maintaining other‚Äôs code, I‚Äôve felt firsthand what a mess traditional branching causes and its crippling effect on velocity.
In terms of velocity: never measure productivity by the number of features you complete. Measure it by the features that stay done. It‚Äôs not done if you go back to add more to it.
Writing if-else and switch cases is the active avoidance of the hard work of analyzing and anticipating how your system will change throughout its lifetime.
The only reason for using else if, and switch cases is to make code easier to follow for junior developers, which is a bad idea as well‚Äìand code optimizations that we‚Äôll never need.
Let‚Äôs look at some code that illustrates the issues and ways to solve them.
Link to the github repository at the bottom of the article.
Introducing the problem.
It‚Äôs easy to bash traditional branching and say a few words on why it‚Äôs such a poor practice. But, how about some examples to drive the point home?
Keeping things simple, yet illustrative, imagine you‚Äôd have to develop a service that can generate different output formats for a given object type in a web application. The users can pick which format they‚Äôd like to have displayed.
In our example, let‚Äôs go with an Employee class that, to start with, you have to output as either JSON or XML.
Keep in mind, that what we‚Äôre building here doesn‚Äôt matter. Only the concepts, techniques, and approaches matter.
The web application output format.
Easy enough.
You need the Employee class, an enum to select the OutputFormat and an EmployeeFormatter. Take a few seconds to read through the code below.

public class Employee
{
    public Employee() : this(Guid.NewGuid()) { }
    public Employee(Guid id) => Id = id;
    
    public Guid Id { get; }
    public required string Name { get; init; }
    public required DateOnly HiringDate { get; init; }
}

public enum OutputFormat
{
    Json,
    Xml,
}

public class EmployeeFormatter()
{
    // Used to get available formats in the front end
    public IReadOnlyList<string> GetAvailableFormats()
      => return Enum.GetNames(typeof(FormatOutput));

    public string Format(Employee employee, FormatOutput format)
    {        
        if (format == OutputFormat.Json)
        {
            JsonSerializerOptions jsonOptions = new()
            {
                PropertyNamingPolicy = JsonNamingPolicy.CamelCase,
                WriteIndented = true
            };
            return JsonSerializer.Serialize(employee, jsonOptions);
        }
        else if (format == OutputFormat.Xml)
        {
            XmlWriterSettings xmlSettings = new()
            {
                Indent = true,
                NewLineChars = Environment.NewLine,
                NewLineHandling = NewLineHandling.Replace,
                OmitXmlDeclaration = false
            };
            EmployeeXml employeeXml = EmployeeXml.FromEmployee(employee);
            var xmlSerializer = new XmlSerializer(employeeXml.GetType());
            
            using var writer = new StringWriter();
            using var xmlWriter = XmlWriter.Create(writer, xmlSettings);
            xmlSerializer.Serialize(xmlWriter, employeeXml);

            return writer.ToString();
        }
        else
        {
            return "";
        }
    }

    /// <summary>
    /// This type is only used in the format == OutputFormat.Xml branch.
    /// </summary>
    [XmlType(typeName: "Employee")]
    public record EmployeeXml
    {
        [XmlElement]
        public Guid Id { get; set; }
        
        [XmlElement]
        public string Name { get; set; }
        
        [XmlElement]
        public DateTime HiringDate { get; set; }
        
        public static EmployeeXml FromEmployee(Employee employee)
        {
            return new EmployeeXml
            {
                Id = employee.Id, 
                Name = employee.Name,
                HiringDate = new DateTime(employee.HiringDate, TimeOnly.MinValue)
            };
        }
    }
}
So, in the front end, we‚Äôll use the method GetAvailableFormats to display which options the user can choose from. The Format(employee, outputFormat) is producing our formatted result.
Stripping the Format method from the branch implementations, we‚Äôre left with this:
public string Format(Employee employee, OutputFormat outputFormat)
{   
    if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Json)
    {
    }
    else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Xml)
    {
    }
    else
    {
    }
}
At this point, it‚Äôs simple to understand and not causing too many problems. Now, try to add yet another format and see what happens‚Äìsay a PDF format.
public enum OutputFormat
{
    Json,
    Xml,
    Pdf // ‚Üê new
}

public string Format(Employee employee, OutputFormat outputFormat)
{   
    if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Json)
    {
      // json implementation
    }
    else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Xml)
    {
      // xml implementation
    }
    else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Pdf) // ‚Üê new
    {
      // pdf implementation
    }
    else
    {
    }
}
You had to modify code in multiple places, cyclomatic complexity increased, and you had to add more unit tests for the exact same method expecting wildly different output.
More importantly, this is an incredibly naive implementation approach. Guess what happens when you want to add another format, again, or, if you suddenly want to toggle formats on and off.
Attempting to reduce complexity with class extraction refactoring.
The slightly experienced junior developer might proclaim that there are some obvious refactoring techniques just begging to be applied, such as class extraction and refactoring to dependency injection.
So, let‚Äôs quickly attempt this and see how it affects our code quality. I‚Äôm not going to write out the full code but hopefully, the point comes across.
public interface IEmployeeFormatter {
  Format(Employee employee);
}

// Implementations omitted for brevity.
public class EmployeeJsonFormatter : IEmployeeFormatter {}
public class EmployeeXmlFormatter : IEmployeeFormatter {}
public class EmployeePdfFormatter : IEmployeeFormatter{}

public class EmployeeFormatter {
  public EmployeeFormatter(
            EmployeeJsonFormatter json,
            EmployeeXmlFormatter xml,
            EmployeePdfFormatter pdf) {
    // set fields
  }
}

public string Format(Employee employee, OutputFormat outputFormat)
{   
    if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Json)
    {
      return json.Format(employee);
    }
    else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Xml)
    {
      return xml.Format(employee)
    }
    else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Xml)
    {
      return pdf.Format(employee)
    }
    else
    {
      // something else
    }
}
Little has changed besides moving the actual formatting logic into separate classes ‚Äî which certainly helps to keep the EmployeeFormatter ‚Äúclean‚Äù and readable.
Have you noticed one very important characteristic of the code example above? Each dependency is only used a single time, in separate branches. We‚Äôve effectively refactored to branch-coupled dependencies.
Also, our tests are suffering from null dependencies:
[Fact]
public void FormatEmployeeAsPdf()
{
    // Arrange
    var formatter = new PdfFormatter();
    var employee = new Employee
    {
        Name = "Faxe Kondi",
        HiringDate = new DateOnly(2023, 5, 20)
    };
    
    var sut = new EmployeeFormatter(
                    null, // ‚Üê 
                    null, // ‚Üê
                   formatter // The only interesting dependency
              );
    
    // Act
    string result = sut.Format(employee, OutputFormat.Pdf);
    
    // Assert
    // some asserts
}
Notice that we‚Äôre passing two nulls to the EmployeeFormatter constructor. That‚Äôs for sure a code smell and makes some very brittle tests.
Collaborative scalability suffers as well.
I know many developers would be satisfied with this and claim the refactoring was a success.
However, think of the scenario where one developer has to add a new format and another developer works to allow formats to be toggled on and off without restarting the application.
Both developers decide to add new constructor arguments and new conditional requirements in the existing if-else statements. All tests that new up the EmployeeFormatter have to be adjusted and there‚Äôll certainly be merge conflicts.
Tackling rigid conditional execution.
Alright, so extracting each branch into separate classes was a move in the right direction. Now it‚Äôs just a matter of getting rid of the if, else-if, else to allow for flexibility and extensibility.
To begin with, we‚Äôll remove the enum OutputFormat and rather let each concrete ‚Äúformatter‚Äù tell us which format they can output.
Take a minute to read through the changes below.
public interface IEmployeeFormatter
{
    string Format(Employee employee);
    string FormattingType { get; } // ‚Üê new
}

public class EmployeeFormatterManager(ILogger<EmployeeFormatterManager> logger)
{
    private readonly Dictionary<string, IEmployeeFormatter> formatters = [];
    
    public IReadOnlyList<string> GetAvailableFormats() 
        => formatters.Select(kv => kv.Key).ToList();

    public string Format(Employee employee, string format)
    {
        bool hasFormatter = formatters.ContainsKey(format);
        return hasFormatter
            ? formatters[format].Format(employee)
            : throw new UnknownFormatException(format, GetAvailableFormats());
    }

    public EmployeeFormatterManager Add(IEmployeeFormatter formatter)
    {
        logger.LogEmployeeFormatterAdded(formatter.GetType(), formatter.FormattingType);
        
        formatters.Add(formatter.FormattingType, formatter);
        return this;
    }

    public EmployeeFormatterManager Add(IEnumerable<IEmployeeFormatter> employeeFormatters)
    {
        foreach (IEmployeeFormatter employeeFormatter in employeeFormatters) Add(employeeFormatter);
        return this;
    }
}

public class UnknownFormatException(string formatType, IEnumerable<string> availableFormats)
    : Exception($"Unknown type {formatType}. Available formats are: {string.Join(",", availableFormats)}");
Firstly, the ‚Äúformatters‚Äù are stored in a dictionary along with the format they can handle.
Secondly, the GetAvailableFormats is still used to ask ‚ÄúWhich formats do I have available?‚Äù. However, this time, we don‚Äôt examine an enum but the actual formatters that are available. This is a more solid approach since you can easily add values to an enum without actually providing an execution path for them.
Thirdly, when formatting an employee to a string output, we don‚Äôt know at design-time which ‚Äúformatter‚Äù is used, and frankly, the EmployeeFormatManager should not care anyway.
Adding new features without modifying existing code.
These changes allow flexibility and extensibility because you can add as many formats to the EmployeeFormatManager as you wish without modifying the code.
It‚Äôs so easy to add another feature (format) that it‚Äôs simply a matter if creating a new class and adding it to the EmployeeFormatManager.
public class EmployeeCsvFormatter : IEmployeeFormatter {
  public Format(Employee employee) {
    // implementation details
  }
}

// Some where else in the code
var csv = new EmployeeCsvFormatter();
manager.Add(csv)
manager.Format(someEmployee, "csv");
I know you‚Äôll probably not use it like this in practice, but rather get the manager from an IoC Container ‚Äî I‚Äôll address this later in the article.
An affordance of well-structured code is how pleasant testing is. Since the EmployeeFormatterManager no longer relies on concrete implementations, we don‚Äôt have to instantiate those leaving us with no null constructor arguments.
// EmployeeFormatterManager test
[Fact]
public void ContainAddedFormatters()
{
    // Arrange
    var first = Substitute.For<IEmployeeFormatter>();
    first.FormattingType.Returns("first");
    
    var second = Substitute.For<IEmployeeFormatter>();
    second.FormattingType.Returns("second");
    
    EmployeeFormatterManager sut = new EmployeeFormatterManager(NullLogger<EmployeeFormatterManager>.Instance)
        .Add(first)
        .Add(second);

    // Act
    IReadOnlyList<string> result = sut.GetAvailableFormats();
    
    // Assert
    result.Should().Contain(["first", "second"]);
}
Likewise, each ‚Äúformatter‚Äù is testable in its own right as it‚Äôs no longer an implementation detail of another class‚Äô execution paths (if, else-if, else).
// EmployeeJsonFormatter test
[Fact]
public void FormatEmployee()
{
    var employee = new Employee(Guid.Parse("f9e827ab-29aa-4a50-92a1-3688c6a4b9fe"))
    {
        Name = "Faxe Kondi",
        HiringDate = new DateOnly(2023, 5, 1)
    };

    var sut = new EmployeeJsonFormatter();
    
    // Act
    string result = sut.Format(employee);
    
    // Assert
    // language=json <- allows highlighting in JetBrains IDEs
    const string expectedJson = """ 
                                {
                                  "id": "f9e827ab-29aa-4a50-92a1-3688c6a4b9fe",
                                  "name": "Faxe Kondi",
                                  "hiringDate": "2023-05-01"
                                }
                                """;
    result.Should().BeEquivalentTo(expectedJson);
}
Touching on collaborative scalability, other developers can bring their format implementations that may reside in different projects as long as they implement the IEmployeeFormatter interface.
Toggling features at runtime.
Now, say there‚Äôs a new requirement from the business and we‚Äôre tasked to enable and disable specific formats at runtime without having to recompile and deploy the application.
The traditional branch-based approach would require modifying an existing class and updating all its associated tests.
The implementation would go something like this:
public class EmployeeFormatter(IOptionsMonitor<AvaiableFormatOptions> options)
{
    public IReadOnlyList<string> GetAvailableFormats()
    {
        return Enum.GetNames(typeof(OutputFormat))
            .Where(of => options.CurrentValue.EmployeeFormats.Contains(of))
            .ToList();
    }

  public string Format(Employee employee, OutputFormat outputFormat)
  {
      bool unknownFormat = !GetAvailableFormats().Contains(outputFormat.ToString());
      if (unknownFormat) return "";
      
      if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Json)
      {
         // json
      }
      else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Xml)
      {
        // xml
      } else if (outputFormat == OutputFormat.Pdf)
      {
        // pdf
      }
      else
      {
          return "";
      }
  }
}
Not too bad, but it‚Äôs easy to see how quickly this gets unmanageable. Also, we still allow formats that don‚Äôt actually have an implementation which may cause bugs that way.
There are no code changes to the updated version which relies on adding concrete formatters in contrast to the hardcoded execution paths. Everything stays the same.
Configuring the EmployeeFormatManager using Dependency injection Framework.
So, I promised to get back to how we enable this flexibility using an IoC Container. The approach is not unique to C# .NET and is easily replicated with other languages.
In dotnet, this is possible with Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection library which is already shipped with the aspnetcore framework.

// appsettings.json
{
  "EmployeeFormatterTypes": {
      "EmployeeFormats": [
        "Json",
        "Xml",
        "Pdf"
      ]
    }
 } 

// Program.cs (aspnetcore app)
builder.Services
    .Configure<EmployeeFormatterTypes>(
        builder.Configuration.GetSection(nameof(EmployeeFormatterTypes))
    );

builder.Services
    .AddSingleton<IEmployeeFormatter, EmployeeXmlFormatter>()
    .AddSingleton<IEmployeeFormatter, EmployeeJsonFormatter>()
    .AddSingleton<IEmployeeFormatter, EmployeePdfFormatter>()
    .AddScoped<EmployeeFormatterManager>(provider =>
    {
        var logger = provider.GetRequiredService<ILogger<EmployeeFormatterManager>>();
        var options = provider.GetRequiredService<IOptionsMonitor<EmployeeFormatterTypes>>();

        IEnumerable<IEmployeeFormatter> formatters = provider.GetServices<IEmployeeFormatter>()
            .Where(ef => options.CurrentValue.EmployeeFormats.Contains(ef.FormattingType));

        return new EmployeeFormatterManager(logger).Add(formatters);
    });
In this way, every time an EmployeeFormatManager is requested, we check which formats are available in the appsettings.json, find the concrete formatters and only add them to the manager.
We have changed the problem of adding another feature from being one of hardcoding a new execution path to effectively being a matter of configuration.

What is the Area of the Yellow Region?
A Tricky Geometry Puzzle 89.9% Failed!
Nnamdi Samuel
¬∑
Follow
Published in
ILLUMINATION
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Sep 24, 2024
388
12
Image by the author
This is another beautiful geometry puzzle!
How would you find the area of the yellow region?
If you find a side of the yellow square, you would easily find its area.
The beautiful thing here is that almost all of the shapes involved are squares. If you know the formula for the area of a square and a little algebra, then you should give this a go!
In this puzzle, a square is overlapped by three other squares ‚Äî blue, yellow, and purple. The area of the green region is 62 sq. units; the blue, and purple are 25 and 4 sq. units respectively. The area of the yellow isn‚Äôt known.
The challenge is to find the area of the yellow region.
Hint: 62 is the area of the green region, not the area of the large square.
Feel free to get a pen and a paper and shoot at this puzzle. If you got the area as 9 sq. units, high five! You‚Äôre a math rock star, but stick around and see if our approach matches. If you don‚Äôt get the answer right, don‚Äôt sweat it, just follow along!
Are you ready? Let‚Äôs dive in!
Let‚Äôs start by assigning a variable to a side of the yellow region. Let each side be x. This means its area would be x¬≤.
For the blue and purple regions, each side is 5 and 2 respectively (the square root of their areas).
With all of these, each side of the large square would be 5+x+2 = x + 7
The area of a square is the square of any of its sides.
Since each side of the large square is x + 7, then its area is (x+7)¬≤
Also, if we get the sum of the areas of the shapes within the large square, it gives us the area of the square.
Let‚Äôs do this!
The sum of the areas within the shape is 62 + 25 +x¬≤ + 4 = 91 + x¬≤
Remember, its area is also (x+7)¬≤.
This means we can safely say (x+7)¬≤ = 91 + x¬≤
From here, if we expand the brackets, we will have this:
x¬≤ + 14x + 49 = 91 + x¬≤
We are now left with
14x + 49 = 91
14x = 42
x = 3
We have found each side of the yellow square. Great!
Now that we have a side length, we can calculate the area of the square by squaring that side.
And there we go! The area of the yellow region is 3¬≤ = 9 sq. units üòä
Thank you so much for reading! I hope you enjoyed this puzzle.
I put a lot of thought and effort into crafting these articles to bring you great content, so if you found this valuable, don‚Äôt forget to give a few claps üëè and follow me.
By doing so, you‚Äôll stay updated with more fun puzzles and problem-solving tips that are on the way. You can also follow me on X (formerly Twitter) for even more exciting challenges.
Feel free to reach out to me here. Let‚Äôs connect!

Have you heard about the new Google Gemini Coder?

10 of the Best Anti-Patterns Ever
Renan Schmitt
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Software Design Concepts
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Nov 2, 2024
572
15
Why do it right the first time when you can do it wrong?
In this article, let‚Äôs have some fun revisiting anti-patterns that anyone with enough experience in the software development industry has likely encountered. So, I propose that we not only read through the anti-patterns below but gamify it by scoring points based on our experiences.
Generated by bing.com/images/create.
Here‚Äôs how the scoring works:
You score 5 points if you were responsible for implementing that anti-pattern in a project.
You score 3 points if you weren‚Äôt responsible but have worked with it.
You score 1 point if you‚Äôve only observed it but haven‚Äôt had the chance to work with it.
You score zero points if you‚Äôve never encountered it.
Let‚Äôs begin!
1. Nonsense Flag
The developer sprinkles a bunch of variables with sensational names like:
newCounter2
alreadySwitchedTabs
passedThroughHere
magicNumber
didNotFind
Previous5
Current5
previousOfPrevious5
fourInTheMorning
My score: 5.
2. An array is worth more than a thousand variables
It is much more efficient and easier to declare an array with enough elements to include all the variables the programmer things it is necessary:
public static void processData(Object[] data) {
    ((Product) data[23]).setPrice((Float) data[64]);
    ((Product) data[23]).setMargin((Float) data[25]);
    ((Product) data[23]).setCostPrice((Float) data[82]);
    ((Product) data[23]).setPromotion((String) data[47]);
    ((Sale) data[49]).addProduct((Product) data[23]);
    data[51] = data[44]; // If you don't do this, things break.

    // Mike disabled this line, and the product printing bug was fixed,
    // but the employee screen shifted to the right, and no one knows why.
    //data[88] = data[21];
}
My score: 3.
3. Temporary Code
It‚Äôs working, don‚Äôt touch it!
// TODO John Doe - 02/10/1990 - Temporary section (change as soon as possible)
 if (errorCode == -9887) {...}
My score: 5.
4. Magic Number
Numbers with unknown and mysterious magical properties. No one knows why or what they mean, but if they are changed, everything goes wrong.
if (x + y > 17) {
  a = 4;
} else {
  a = 9;
}

if (totalElements > 1200.0) h.x += 19;

int values[] = {-6, 12, 15, 16 - c, 3, 0, 9, a + h.x * 5, -1, 0, 4 * m, 28, 
                7 - (int) (d / 2.38), 31, 
                15 + (int) (h.shares.elements[17] * 3.227), 18};
My score: 5.
5. Bullet Proof
The goal is to ensure your system doesn‚Äôt show any errors. After all, users wouldn‚Äôt understand error messages.
So leave the errors to those who do understand!
In the production system, you will disable error display.
try { doSomething(); } catch (Throwable t) {}
try { doAnotherThing(); } catch (Throwable t) {}
try { doOneMoreThing(); } catch (Throwable t) {}
My score: 1.
6. BCDR ‚Äî Black Cat in a Dark Room
It consists of creating methods that receive only a Map or Dictionary as a parameter.
The argument you need is in there, in the Map, but you don‚Äôt know exactly where. This pattern allows you to pass as many arguments as necessary to a method without cluttering the code.
My score: 5.
7. Lone Wolf
Also known as Highlander (there can be only one), this is the good old ‚Äòdo-it-all class.‚Äô
The entire system is concentrated in a single, simple procedural class that does everything.
class Main{
  public static login(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static logout(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static process(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static calculateRate(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static formatDate(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static round(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static redirect(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static hasAuthorization(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static getName(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static findProduct(){ ‚Ä¶ }
  public static registerCustomer(){ ‚Ä¶ }
}
My score: 5.
8. Generic Processor
Some class, method, function, macro, or procedure that takes anything as a parameter and performs some generic action.
It often has more parameters than your screen can display, because every time a new feature is added, the Generic Processor gains one (or several) new parameters.
public static Object[] process(String file, String archive, int data, 
                               char variable, Object[] status, int lines, 
                               String query, String user, String password, 
                               String database, String host, int day, 
                               int month, int year, int soldProduct, 
                               boolean clickedInTheBlueTab, String fileRead, 
                               String fieldSaved, float version, int test1, 
                               int test2, int test3, 
                               boolean shouldChangeStatus, Object[] input, 
                               Object[] output, Object‚Ä¶ moreData)
  throws NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundException, SQLException, 
         IOException, OutOfMemoryError, FileNotFoundException, 
         SonOfABitchException, SocketException, MalformedURLException, 
         ArithmeticException, UnknownHostException, ShitHappensException, 
         BullshitFailure, SAXException, ParseException, 
         YourMommaIsFatException, ClassNotFoundException, StackOverflowError, 
         ExceptionInInitializerError, InvocationTargetException, 
         SecurityException, ClassCastException, NoSuchMethodException, 
         NoSuchFieldException, CrapException, UnsatisfiedLinkError, 
         InstantiationException, FuckedError, ArrayStoreException, 
         IllegalArgumentException, NumberFormatException, AssertError, 
         DoneByTraineeException, InternalError, RemoteException, 
         FuckYouException, GenericException, GenericException2, WTFException, 
         XPTOError, GenericExceptionWapperException3, RuntimeException, 
         Exception, UnknowError, Error, Throwable{
  // Creativity mode activated
  . . .
  . . .
  return something;
}
My score: 1.
9. Megazord
It‚Äôs the combination of the Lone Wolf pattern with the Generic Processor. Reason: creating multiple functions, each executing a step of an algorithm, slows down the system since it has to interrupt its flow to call them. This problem can be solved with a single, giant warrior function that takes several parameters to determine what it should do. Usually used together with the Nonsense Flag as well.
public static Object[] process(/* many parameters here */) 
     throws everything_you_can_imagine { 

  // Here you put a thousand lines of code, consisting of a ‚Äúsoup‚Äù of ifs, 
  // switches, whiles, fors, breaks, and continues.

  // If your language has no fuss or biases, don‚Äôt forget to savor the sweet 
  // taste of gotos.

  // Also, declare about 300 local variables of various different types and 
  // scattered in various places.

  // Note: Frequently, this procedure is recursive, with recursion in multiple
  // places and in different ways!
}
My score: 0.
10. Ostrich
Don‚Äôt worry about all 2,752 warnings the compiler emits when processing your code.
However, it‚Äôs not ideal to let these warnings appear every time someone builds the system.
public class MyClass {
 @SuppressWarnings("unused")
 private static int A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M; 
}
My score: 5.
