Linux: How to create self deleting files!
Konstantinos Patronas
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Towards Dev
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Jul 25, 2024
444
5
In this article i will show you how you can create self deleting files!, files that will be deleted them self after a defined number of minutes or a specific date! You might ask why you would need this? well in my case is because i wanted to create a mechanism that will not allow a script to sent an email with events from the system if the last email has been sent in the last one hour! but you might find use as well in your occasions!
Creating the command
Linux does not have any built in command to create self ‚Äî deleting files so we will create one! its much easier than you think :)
Create the following script an save it as sdelete.sh
#!/bin/bash

# Check if the correct number of arguments is provided
if [ "$#" -ne 2 ]; then
    echo "Usage: $0 <filename> <time>"
    echo "Example: $0 /path/to/your/file 'now + 5 minutes'"
    echo "Example: $0 /path/to/your/file '12:30 PM tomorrow'"
    exit 1
fi

# Assign arguments to variables
filename=$1
time=$2

# Check if the filename is a full path
if [[ "$filename" != /* ]]; then
    echo "Error: Filename must be a full path."
    exit 1
fi

# Create the file
touch "$filename"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "File '$filename' created."
else
    echo "Error: Failed to create file '$filename'."
    exit 1
fi

# Schedule the file for deletion using 'at'
echo "rm \"$filename\"" | at "$time"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "File '$filename' is scheduled for deletion at $time."
else
    echo "Error: Failed to schedule deletion with 'at' command."
    exit 1
fi
Make it executable with chmod
chmod +x sdelete.sh
Testing
Lets make some tests now to verify that the script works
Creating and Deleting a file after an amount of minutes
$ ./sdelete.sh ~/hello.txt 'now +1 minute'
File '/home/administrator/hello.txt' created.
warning: commands will be executed using /bin/sh
job 6 at Thu Jul 25 17:18:00 2024
File '/home/administrator/hello.txt' is scheduled for deletion at now +1 minute.

$ ls -l | grep -i hello
-rw-rw-r-- 1 administrator administrator          0 Jul 25 17:17 hello.txt
Checking after one minute we can verify that hello.txt does not exist
Creating and deleting a file in a defined time stamp
Also we can define a timestamp as parameter that the file will be deleted, in this case is 17:50
$ ./sdelete.sh ~/hello.txt '17:50'
File '/home/administrator/hello.txt' created.
warning: commands will be executed using /bin/sh
job 7 at Thu Jul 25 17:50:00 2024
File '/home/administrator/hello.txt' is scheduled for deletion at 17:50.
How it works?
The script relies in the at command. The at command in Linux is used to schedule commands to be executed at a later time. It reads commands from standard input or from a specified file and executes them at a specified time.
Here are some simple examples about the at command
Schedule a task in the future
echo "ls -l /tmp" | at now + 1 minute
Schedule a command to run at a specific time
echo "echo 'Hello, World!'" | at 10:30 AM
Schedule a Command to Run at a Specific Date and Time
echo "shutdown -h now" | at 11:59 PM 12/31/2024
Conclusion
Well.. self deleting files might not be super useful but i hope you enjoyed this short article!<|InputEnd|>Member-only story

Why Client-Side Rendering Is Making a Comeback in 2025
The web development trend you thought was outdated is blowing minds in 2025. Here‚Äôs why CSR is stealing the spotlight again.
Maxime
¬∑
Follow
Published in
ITNEXT
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Jan 13, 2025
71
4
Read this article for free HERE.
Client-Side Rendering ‚Äî by the Author
Remember when CSR was the go-to approach for web apps?
JavaScript did all the heavy lifting, and we built dynamic, interactive pages right in the browser.
It felt cutting-edge ‚Äî until SSR (Server-Side Rendering) came along and stole the spotlight.
Faster load times? Better SEO? CSR couldn‚Äôt compete, and SSR quickly became the standard for performance-first apps.
But here we are in 2025, and CSR is making a comeback.
Let‚Äôs take a closer look at what‚Äôs changed.
What Is CSR?
Client-Side Rendering ‚Äî by the Author
Quick refresher:
With CSR, the server sends a lightweight index.html and a big chunk of JavaScript.
The browser takes it from there‚Äîrendering the page, handling routing, and keeping everything interactive.
Why did it fall out of favor?
Two reasons:
Slow initial loads;
Poor SEO.
SSR offered a quick fix for both, which made it the default choice for a lot of projects.
But CSR has been quietly evolving in the background.
And now, thanks to modern tools and smarter browsers, its weaknesses aren‚Äôt holding it back like they used to.
Why CSR Is Back
CSR isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù again ‚Äî it‚Äôs solving problems and taking advantage of new tech.
Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs driving its resurgence:
1. Browsers got smarter
Modern JavaScript engines like Chrome‚Äôs V8 and Firefox‚Äôs SpiderMonkey are lightning-fast.
Chrome V8 ‚Äî Image from Google Developers Blog
They process JavaScript way more efficiently than they did a few years ago, turning CSR‚Äôs slow initial loads into smooth, fast experiences.
2. Frameworks stepped up
Frameworks like React and Vue have evolved to make CSR more efficient.
React‚Äôs concurrent rendering, for example, lets the browser handle rendering in smaller chunks, so apps stay responsive even during heavy processing.
Here‚Äôs a simple example of how concurrent rendering works in React with lazy loading:
React Concurrent Rendering example‚Äî by the Author
3. Hybrid rendering took off
Why choose between SSR and CSR when you can have both?
Hybrid rendering combines the best of both worlds:
SSR for fast initial loads,
CSR for rich interactivity.
Frameworks like Next.js make this seamless, giving developers more flexibility than ever.
4. SEO? Handled.
SEO ‚Äî Photo by Pixabay
JavaScript SEO tools have come a long way.
Pre-rendering, dynamic rendering, and improved crawling capabilities mean CSR apps are no longer invisible to search engines.
Problem solved.
5. PWAs and decentralized apps
Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) and decentralized apps (dApps) are driving CSR forward.
PWAs use CSR to deliver fast, dynamic, and offline-capable experiences, blurring the line between web and native apps.
Real-World Examples
Developers are embracing CSR again for apps where user experience and interactivity are top priorities.
For instance, Twitter Lite uses CSR to create a fast, lightweight app that works offline and feels snappy no matter where you are.
Twitter Lite ‚Äî Image from pakwired
This trend is especially noticeable in dashboards, interactive tools, and real-time apps where CSR shines.
Simplified architectures, faster updates, and responsive interfaces make CSR the perfect fit for these scenarios.
Why It Matters
CSR isn‚Äôt the right choice for every app, but it‚Äôs a great tool when used in the right context.
Need great SEO and quick initial load times? SSR or hybrid rendering is your best bet.
Building a highly interactive app where user experience is key? CSR has you covered.
The real win? You don‚Äôt have to pick one approach anymore.
Modern frameworks let you mix and match, giving you the flexibility to build apps that are both fast and dynamic.
Final Thoughts
CSR is officially back in the game.
Smarter browsers, better tools, and new use cases like PWAs are making it a must-have in the modern web developer‚Äôs toolkit.
So, if you‚Äôve been sleeping on CSR, it‚Äôs time to give it another look.
The web in 2025 is all about balance, and CSR is finally holding its own again.
Thanks for reading! If you‚Äôve enjoyed, feel free to clap and follow me for more content!

10 Habits of Great Software Engineers
Great developers tend to have a lot of little habits that they don‚Äôt teach in Computer Science courses or web development bootcamps, and these 10 habits will make you stand out.
Dr. Derek Austin ü•≥
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Career Programming
¬∑
11 min read
¬∑
Sep 12, 2024
2.1K
36
Photo by Hester Qiang on Unsplash
I‚Äôve been developing professionally since 2004, and there is a lot about working on a software engineering team that I didn‚Äôt learn until recently.
Over the last 5 years, I‚Äôve had the privilege of working as a lead frontend engineer and hiring manager for a lot of different teams, big and small.
That‚Äôs why I wanted to put together this article and share 10 little habits that have made the great developers on my teams stand out.
Habit 1 ‚Äî Create ready-to-work tickets.
Every professional software engineer has to write up tickets, or work items, even when you‚Äôre supported by a full-time product manager.
Usually, you (the engineer) know what the bug or feature request is, so it‚Äôs tempting to write a 1-line ticket: just the title, with nothing else.
Actual tickets need something called ‚Äúacceptance criteria,‚Äù which is another fancy term, this time meaning ‚Äúthe definition of done.‚Äù
You and your team need to agree in advance what the QA (testing) process is going to be for the ticket. That‚Äôs the acceptance criteria (or AC, for short).
One of the best ways to succeed as a software engineer at any level is to write up great tickets that are ready to work and ready to test.
Great tickets typically contain a user story (why you‚Äôre coding, from the user‚Äôs perspective) and some testing instructions, though depending on the work you may have a lot more additional details included in the ticket.
While it‚Äôs typically the product manager‚Äôs job to write up tickets, we always find bugs while coding, and so we should also write up tickets as needed.
And the best way to get on your product manager‚Äôs good side as an engineer is to write fantastic tickets, without needing to be asked.
Habit 2 ‚Äî Author ready-to-review PRs.
As a developer on a software team, you typically turn in your work by opening pull requests (PRs), requests to merge your code in.
10 Things You Should Include To Write Awesome Pull Requests (PRs)
Look, I get it; your current boss lets you leave your PRs blank. But if I‚Äôm your boss, I‚Äôm going to expect a little bit‚Ä¶
medium.com
The first thing any PR should include is a link back to the ticket being completed, even if that means just naming the PR the name of the ticket.
You can also include some additional details, like:
What was the old behavior, and what is the new behavior?
Do I need to actually test anything in the codebase?
Is there anything else I need to know about the code?
It only takes a couple of minutes to describe what you‚Äôre turning in as part of your PR, and it‚Äôs a big help to whoever‚Äôs going to review your code.
Habit 3 ‚Äî Write lots of code comments.
I write as many lines of code and as lines of code comments, because I think code comments are extremely important for every codebase.
27 Hilarious Code Comments Suggested By GitHub Copilot
GitHub Copilot is hilarious, and I love it. These are all real suggestions that I‚Äôve seen while using GitHub Copilot in‚Ä¶
levelup.gitconnected.com
Code comments are not a waste of time, and in fact they‚Äôre the single most important factor in my experience for the maintainability of a codebase.
While I definitely encourage you to write ‚Äúself-documenting‚Äù code where how the code works is clear, why it has to work that way is often less clear.
Let‚Äôs take a common scenario as an example.
You‚Äôre a new hire with professional experience in the tech stack being used at your new company. You‚Äôre assigned to fix a simple, easy-to-find bug.
You get to the relevant section of code, and you don‚Äôt have any code comments at all. You focus and read the algorithm line by line.
Nearly an hour later, you finally understand how the code works! Now you can start fixing the bug! That‚Äôs when you should write code comments.
All you need to do to write great code comments is explain why there was a bug, which is the same as explaining why the code is written the way it is.
Habit 4 ‚Äî Make atomic commits.
Speaking of technical documentation, an underrated approach to coding is to commit small changes, frequently, by using ‚Äúatomic commits.‚Äù
Developer Tip: Keep Your Commits ‚ÄúAtomic‚Äù ‚Äî Fresh Consulting
Source control is a developer‚Äôs best friend. The ability to share code with multiple developers, track changes, and‚Ä¶
www.freshconsulting.com
An atomic commit is a single, indivisible code change, just like how an atom was an indivisible piece of matter before the discovery of quarks.
Think about it this way: how often do you save an essay? As often as possible, preferably with an autosave feature. Maybe every 10 minutes?
You should be saving your code that often, just to be safe. Of course, it‚Äôs not typically necessary, but you‚Äôll be happy you saved when you do need it.
For example, in a recent refactor ticket I worked, I made 36 atomic commits to change 34 files, which took me 8 hours from start to finish.
The best thing I‚Äôve found from making atomic commits is that it‚Äôs exceptionally easy for me to revert a group of changes.
Instead of what I used to do ‚Äî save my work once a day, or maybe twice ‚Äî I‚Äôm able to fully implement a solution, saving several commits as I go.
If I want to try another solution, I‚Äôm able to revert just those commits, saving the first solution (via Git) in case the second solution doesn‚Äôt work.
5 ‚Äî Use semantic commit messages.
Speaking of Git commit messages, I‚Äôm a huge fan of semantic commit messages, meaning each commit is labeled with a type and a scope.
I find that having to write 20+ commit messages a day clarifies my thinking, making sure I understand exactly what I‚Äôm trying to do.
Even better, writing semantic commit messages for easy tasks (like docs(backend): improve code comments in api.tsx) helps me build momentum for harder tasks (feat(backend): implement new endpoint).
It takes me 30 seconds to make an atomic commit with a 10-word commit message. Writing WIP or chore: fix bug is fine when you‚Äôre a solo developer, but those commits aren‚Äôt useful for your team‚Äôs code review.
Let‚Äôs say I have to review your pull request, but you‚Äôre already done with work (East Coast) while I‚Äôm still here for 3 more hours (West Coast).
That‚Äôs another time when semantic commits shine, because I want to understand why the code changed, but you‚Äôre not at work for me to ask.
Code comments, atomic commits, and semantic commit messages are also excellent tips to make your portfolio projects ‚Äúprofessional-grade.‚Äù
And, while we‚Äôre on the topic of portfolio projects, please deploy your projects to a host (like Vercel) and write useful READMEs. Thanks!
6 ‚Äî DRY (Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself).
I don‚Äôt love pithy coding acronyms like ‚ÄúDRY‚Äù (Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself), but this particular acronym is a great one for maintainability.
You‚Äôve probably seen ‚Äúcopypasta code,‚Äù meaning code that‚Äôs been copy-pasted to different parts of the codebase with only minor changes.
Don‚Äôt Choose the Wrong Abstraction When You DRY Your Codebase
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Repeat Yourself‚Äù (DRY) is a truism in software engineering, but it can cause headaches if you choose the wrong‚Ä¶
medium.com
DRY just means you should be in the habit of refactoring, or rewriting your code to be easier for the whole team to maintain over the long term.
In particular, you want to refactor duplicate code, especially anything duplicated 3+ times in a codebase.
If you never refactor duplicated code, your codebase could be on its way to becoming an unmaintainable nightmare, so DRY.
7 ‚Äî WET (Write Everything Twice).
The flip side of DRY is WET (Write Everything Twice). Get it? Haha. üòÅAnyway, WET means that it‚Äôs faster to copy-paste once than to refactor.
The idea with WET is if you‚Äôre working on a similar feature for the 2nd time, then you want to take your time and do some thinking.
Usually by the time you‚Äôre copy-pasting the same line for the 3rd time, you have a pretty good sense of what it would look like to refactor.
However, as Kent C. Dodds says, you need to AHA (Avoid Hasty Abstractions) ‚Äî you don‚Äôt want to have to refactor again and again.
AHA Programming üí°
Watch my talk: AHA Programming DRY (an acronym for ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Repeat Yourself‚Äù), is an old software principle that‚Ä¶
kentcdodds.com
Not everything has to be abstracted away into a neat, reusable function in order to be maintainable. I find it‚Äôs best to start with WET: write it twice.
Once I‚Äôve written out similar code 2 or 3 different times, I‚Äôll be able to identify a useful abstraction for it.
However, if I try to guess at that abstraction on my first attempt at writing the code, I‚Äôm often completely wrong.
That ends up taking longer than if I had just avoided hasty abstractions (AHA) by writing everything twice (WET) before I refactor.
8 ‚Äî Write readable code.
I‚Äôm a huge fan of readable code as well as simple code because readable, simple code is much easier to maintain over months and years than hard-to-read, complex code that could have been simplified but never was.
Why You Should Make Your Code as Simple as Possible
You‚Äôll program faster if you try to make your code simple, even repititive, when you first write it
betterprogramming.pub
What is readable code, you say? It‚Äôs using things like index instead of i, or roundNumber() instead of r() for a JavaScript round number function.
I‚Äôd include always passing objects as function parameters as something that helps make my code more readable as well. Readability is important!
Of course, readability doesn‚Äôt replace writing code comments, nor does it replace making atomic commits with semantic messages.
Writing readable code is just another way of promoting maintainability in your codebase, whether you or another dev are the one to maintain it.
9 ‚Äî Fix ESLint warnings and errors.
Like many of you, I have a love-hate relationship with code linting, that tool in your code editor that‚Äôs always pointing out potential code problems.
I love catching bugs before they make it to production, but I hate having to fight the endless squiggly lines about things that aren‚Äôt bugs.
I get it, some ESLint rules suck.
(I‚Äôm looking at you, "react/jsx-no-bind": "off" ‚Äî I‚Äôm an adult, and I want to pass destructured functions as props.)
But, if you find yourself starting to type // eslint-disable-next-line, are you 100% sure you don‚Äôt need that rule?
Of course, every team is different, but I‚Äôve found that my productivity is best when I turn off the rule ‚Äúat the source,‚Äù in the .eslintrc.js configuration file, along with a code comment explaining why.
If that‚Äôs not an option, or you like the rule in general but not this time, then I suggest adding another code comment to // eslint-disable-next-line.
On the line before that, add a quick, one-line code comment explaining exactly that: why you have to turn the rule off this one time.
Since linting isn‚Äôt a built-in feature to GitHub‚Äôs pull request code review process, it‚Äôs easy to miss linting issues before the code gets merged.
Fixing your ESLint warnings and errors (when possible) and clearly commenting them out (when not) is also great for maintainability.
10 ‚Äî Meet the acceptance criteria.
As a developer, your job is typically to deliver a pull request (PR) to close a ticket with certain acceptance criteria (AC), a certain ‚Äúdefinition of done.‚Äù
Your code should meet that AC. Your code should work, even if you don‚Äôt have time to write automated tests (e.g. using React Testing Library).
Unfortunately, sometimes developers to send in a ticket where either they didn‚Äôt meet all of the AC correctly or they changed some of them.
It‚Äôs no problem at all if you need to change the AC, just communicate it to your team (asynchronously, such as using Slack, Teams, JIRA, or Linear).
But it‚Äôs also easy to forget to develop a bad habit of forgetting to communicate, resulting in people always thinking your work is ‚Äúwrong.‚Äù
Sure, stuff happens, but having to answer questions from your product manager or QA team about your code should be rare, not commonplace.
The more you ensure that your code meets all AC, including any AC that have changed since the ticket was written, the happier your team will be!
Conclusion: 10 Habits of Great Software Engineers
And there you have it! These are 10 habits that I‚Äôve seen firsthand over the last 5 years, things that make certain developers a pleasure to work with:
Create ready-to-work tickets.
Author ready-to-review PRs.
Write lots of code comments.
Make atomic commits.
Use semantic commit messages.
DRY (Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself).
WET (Write Everything Twice).
Write readable code.
Fix ESLint warnings and errors.
Meet the acceptance criteria.
Of course, great developers have many other habits that they‚Äôve developed over the course of their careers, so this isn‚Äôt an exhaustive list.
These are just some of the most common habits that have come up during real code review or team retros (‚Äúretrospectives‚Äù).
They‚Äôre also habits that I‚Äôve trained my own engineering employees on as a mentor and engineering manager.
I hope that you find these habits useful as you continue your own journey of continuous improvement (‚Äúkaizen‚Äù) as a software engineer.
And, if I missed any habits of great developers, I hope you‚Äôll respond to this article to let me know!
Happy coding! ü¶ê

MONEY
How to Become a Very Expensive Programmer
There are rules you need to follow.
Josef Cruz
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Dec 3, 2024
549
6
Photo by Alexander Grey on Unsplash
What I will describe here concerns, of course, not only programmers because we will talk about professional relationships in general.
Relationships are relationships, no matter where you are: they are built on simple laws of psychology that must be observed (if you want people not to run away from you in different directions).
My site was born in agony. Initially, my request was not very difficult. It turned out that it seemed so. Most of the difficulties arose (for me) not because the work still needed to be done but because of how the programmers behaved (by the way, they are very good people whom I treat very warmly and respectfully).
So, here are the rules that you should follow if you want your customer to be happy even if there are some flaws in the work:
1. Always promise less than you can deliver. And deliver more than you promised.
This is one of the most important rules. Human emotions do not depend on current events. They depend on the combination of expectations and reality.
The law is as follows: if expectations are greater than reality, the emotion is negative (waited and waited, but got nothing: it‚Äôs a shame). If expectations are less than reality, the emotion is positive (didn‚Äôt expect it, and then ‚Äî bam ‚Äî a gift! Super!). If expectations are equal to reality, the emotion is usually just as neutral. Well, what‚Äôs there to be happy about: what you expected is what you got.
How it looks in practice. Let‚Äôs say a customer asks you how long it will take you to launch a forum. You know that if you push yourself, you can do it in a day. If you do it calmly, without rushing, you can do it in two days. Well, and to have a reserve, you can do it in three or four days.
So, most programmers (probably out of a desire to please and generally appear super-professional) name the minimum deadlines ‚Äî i.e. those that they can meet with just sticking out their tongues, and that‚Äôs if there is no attack by enemy planes. And, unfortunately, they do not take into account various force majeures (mom came, the boss called, got stuck in a game, did not buy pelmeni, fell asleep on the keyboard, and other important and unexpectedly urgent things). And what is the result? ‚Äî He named a deadline of one day, and finished it in two. To the question ‚Äúdamn, so why don‚Äôt you fulfill your obligations‚Äù, he began to answer ‚Äúwell, I‚Äôm fast, others do it in a week!‚Äù I don‚Äôt give a damn what others do in a week! Why did you promise? Why did you create an expectation that you then trampled on? Why dig such a grave for your authority. If you know how long it will take you to complete the task, name a deadline twice as long. Then you will have some extra time, and the customer‚Äôs joy is also guaranteed if you complete the task earlier than you promised.
Remember: if you promised to save 1 million people, and saved 800,000, you will be reproached for, they say, ‚Äúpromised a million, but turned out to be a liar.‚Äù
But if you promised to save one person and saved two, you will be praised because you did more than you promised. No one looks at absolute numbers, people judge by expectations [for some, even a crust of stale bread is a feast (if they thought they would die of hunger, but then they brought a rusk), and for others, pineapples in champagne are a sucker‚Äôs meal (if they brought it late, and the champagne is already warm, and the pineapples are smaller than expected)].
In general, the world is ruled by a combination of ‚Äúexpectations/reality‚Äù rather than absolute numerical indicators. This is critically important to take into account both in trade and in services.
2. Check your work yourself. No need to make a glitch catcher out of the client.
Of course, it‚Äôs cool when a client can go through the site themselves, methodically check everything and then correctly describe ‚Äúhere‚Äôs such an error, here‚Äôs such an incorrect display, this thing needs to be 100 pixels to the right‚Ä¶‚Äù. But this means that you forced the client to do your work.
Go through the site yourself, look at it through the eyes of the user and figure out: is it convenient? can it be used? is it legible? does everything work as it should?
Otherwise, the client's tedious work of catching bugs on the site and the programmer on the network begins. Each time, you need to start with the words ‚Äúand here‚Äôs another glitch‚Äù, after which you need to remind ten more times, ‚Äúand I told you yesterday,‚Äù and once again ask to fix the glitch.
If you want to be paid much more money for your work than you ask for ‚Äî make the person feel under the wing of your care much more than he asked for. It would help if you told the client about glitches that he has not yet seen, but which may surface later. He is not a programmer, remember? Do you respect the time of a person who, before communicating with you, was not going to acquire a second specialty of a programmer? And if you respect it, prove it with action. And get a reward.
3. Don‚Äôt be afraid to report bugs.
It often happens like this: a programmer hasn‚Äôt finished something, or suddenly an unexpected glitch has arisen, due to which the deadline may be increased ‚Äî and he, for fear of ‚Äúsaying something unpleasant‚Äù, begins to ‚Äúhide‚Äù. Disappears from the radar.
And then says, ‚ÄúWell, sorry, I didn‚Äôt foresee this here‚Äù. If you look back in this situation, it sometimes turns out that he increased the deadline by two days, but hid for a week and did not do any work, did not correct the mistake, because, you see, the rising feeling of guilt caused hostility towards the project, and therefore, somehow, other important and urgent matters naturally appeared, and he did not dare to tell me about it.
Conscience is good. But tormented by a feeling of guilt is unlikely to help the matter. If you want to maintain a good relationship with the client, be able to talk about mistakes immediately, without delay, in order to quickly adjust the client‚Äôs plans and expectations (do you remember that they are the most important thing for you, as well as for the client?). And ‚Äî do the job, fix the glitches, and don‚Äôt engage in psychotherapy.
If you want ‚Äî come to me for ‚ÄúPsychological Antivirus‚Äù so that you no longer bother yourself and your clients with your worries about ‚Äúhow will I tell him about this mistake‚Äù (while doing another 100500 out of unwillingness to face an unpleasant situation face to face).
4. Remember that retaining a client is more important than attracting one.
If I like a programmer, I will recommend him to my friends and colleagues. Rest assured, you will be in great demand, because all the above-mentioned things are ‚Äúknown‚Äù to all programmers (and other professionals) only in theory, but in practice, few follow them, and ‚Äúclients leave for some reason.‚Äù
Word of mouth is one of the most effective forms of advertising. But most programmers neglect it: they think the main thing is to post information about yourself on a freelancer‚Äôs website, and clients will flow like a river. So, attracting one client is an expensive pleasure in itself. And if you do not keep this client, this ‚Äúpleasure‚Äù is even more expensive.
Why? ‚Äî Because good information generally spreads more slowly than bad information. And if someone does not like you, this person can find your contact information on message boards and write such a review that you will have to spend a long time washing off.
And if the client feels protected and satisfied with you, he may even agree to write a positive review. This will bring you even more clients than any third-party advertisements (the effectiveness of which is usually like the effectiveness of a cannon shooting at sparrows). And, of course, the best advertisement for your work will be a properly functioning website that everyone will enjoy looking at.
Remember: knowing the profession is half the battle. Knowing people and the peculiarities of perception is what you need to master first and foremost if you want to earn good money and not sit on your ass for an uncle‚Äôs salary or get by on bread and water as a freelancer.

I invented an AI time-machine for investing. I made it free.
‚ÄúIf I only knew‚Äù is no longer a valid excuse

All of my articles are free to read. Non-subscribers can read this article by clicking this link.
There are 100 excuses people use for why they fail to make money in the stock market. Most of it comes down to gambling ‚Äì treating stock prices like points in a video game. Some of it is also a lack of education ‚Äì people don‚Äôt understand that a stock represents a company, and that its price goes up when the company does well.
These excuses no longer hold up anymore. Not only have I made a tool that democratized access to financial knowledge, I‚Äôve also made a time machine to test out different investing ideas.
And I made it free. Let me show you how you can use it to extract real-world insights.
For a detailed technical article on how the AI in NexusTrade works, check out the following article:
I trusted OpenAI to help me learn financial analysis. I‚Äôm now a (much) better investor.
AI is better at financial analysis than professional analysts
medium.datadriveninvestor.com
A two-step process: identification and testing
This time-machine is a free investing tool makes it easy for everybody to make more money in the stock market. The process is simple and straightforward:
AI is used to help identify fundamentally strong stocks
A user creates a trading strategy using those stocks
A time machine is used to see how well that strategy performed in the past
Finding fundamentally strong stocks is the first step. It starts by having an idea. For example, because stocks are businesses and businesses that do well tend to have higher stock prices, you might want to try to look for stocks with high gross profit margins or higher incomes.
Then, after you‚Äôve identified some stocks, you want to test it out and see how well your theory performs across time.
For example, let‚Äôs say you believe in Mr. Wonderful (Kevin O‚ÄôLeary‚Äôs) philosophy ‚Äì cash flow is king.
Using AI to find the 5 tech companies with the highest increase in free cash flow
You can find stocks in any industry that have increased their free cash flow during a certain period. Then, you can see how it performs after that period to see if your idea holds real weight.
To be more precise, I typed the following into the chat:
Find me the 5 tech companies with the highest raw increase in free cash flow (not percent change) from 2016 to 2020. Sort by increase in free cash flow descending
The AI then fetches the companies that correspond to my request. Then, I can follow-up with creating a portfolio.
Create a portfolio with $10,000 with buy and hold for these 5 stocks
After creating a portfolio, I can use the time machine to test out my strategies. This process is called backtesting. Because I fetch stocked from 2016 to 2020, I didn‚Äôt want to bias my analysis with future data, a common problem called lookahead bias. Thus, I decided to perform backtests afterwards to reduce the chances of this happening.
For my analysis, I did backtests for the following years:
2021 ‚Äì Jan 1st 2021 to Jan 1st 2022
2022 ‚Äì Jan 1st 2022 to Jan 1st 2023
2023 ‚Äì Jan 1st 2023 to Jan 1st 2024
YTD (year-to-date) ‚Äì Jan 1st 2024 to Oct 6th 2024
Entire period ‚Äì Jan 1st 2021 to Oct 6th 2024
Backtests for this collection of stocks
This portfolio generally outperformed the market, achieving gains of 45% in 2021 (versus the market‚Äôs 27%) and 44% in 2023 (compared to 24%). It underperformed in 2022, falling by 31% (market decline was 20%). Year-to-date, it trails slightly, earning 16% (compared to 22%). Overall, the portfolio has outpaced the market, with a total return of 45%, compared to the S&P 500‚Äôs 28%
While it‚Äôs interesting to see that this particular strategy outperformed the broader market, what‚Äôs more useful is how easy it was to extract these insights, and how easy it would be to iterate and improve on them.
For example, instead of our fixed approach which looked for an increase in free cash flow from 2016 to 2020, we could do a rolling window approach‚Äî finding the stocks with the highest increase in free cash flow one year, and then re-fetching the stocks for the next year. This would allow us to better see if the increase in free cash flow is a reliable indicator of future stock prices.
Or, we can use other trading rules and indicators, such as relative strength index (RSI), moving averages, or fundamental metrics such as net income or gross profit margin.
With this approach, we can very easily find real patterns in the data and make better financial decisions.
And one of the most useful parts is that these insights are fully shareable!

Sharing a conversation makes it easy for you to collaborate on a strategy with a friend

Concluding Thoughts
Artificial intelligence gave retail investors access to advanced financial analysis tools. Saying ‚Äúif I only knew this stock would go up‚Äù is no longer a valid excuse.
There is no reason for you to not make better financial decisions using AI. You can now perform research, test ideas, and make more informed decisions.
None of this is theoretical ‚Äì it is real-life. Anybody can do it, and yes, that means you too. Despite all of the jargon you might read, it‚Äôs actually a lot simpler than you think, and what do you have to lose by trying out a free tool?
Or, you can sit back and miss the next big stock rally as you gamble away your life savings on poor stock choices.

Lol, stfu and stop this rubbish Tari. What is wrong with you? It‚Äôs just stupid AI hype for goodness sake, smh.
Oh really, you sure about that?
Because it‚Äôs already happening right now. Stage 1‚Ä¶
The basic generic-info apps/websites are already being destroyed.
The ones that do nothing more than display generic information ‚Äî like most of those question-answering websites.
In the past how did you get answers to general questions about life and the world?
Typically you searched on Google. Then you clicked on one of the blue links to a website that gave you the information.
I used to write articles for exactly this ‚Äî answering coding questions like ‚Äújavascript convert array to map‚Äù.
But now how do most people get answers for general knowledge like this?
ChatGPT. Gemini. Gemini in Google Search‚Ä¶ conversational AI.
It was painful for me to admit this once üòÖ ‚Äî but the fact is there is no contest here whatsoever between these websites and the AIs.
‚ùå Before:
A generic soulless bunch of pre-define text littered with ads and pop-ups. So much painful bloat to meet a word count and target certain keywords.
‚úÖ Now:
The other is a personalized AI that gives you the exact answer to your unique exact question ‚Äî and let‚Äôs you follow up with even more precise and context-specific questions.
This same thing is going to happen to mobile and web apps.
Think of an app like Duolingo.
‚ùå Before:
A predefined interface with a predefined flow and a predefined set of actions.
You can only learn a language the way the devs think is best with the built-in actions they let you take with the specific UI components they decide on the specific screens they created to put them.
‚úÖ After:
An ultra-personalized interface created by an AI agent connected to several APIs and tools.

It will automatically set phone and email reminders to help you stick with your plan ‚Äî and adjust this plan according to your changing schedule.
Now tell me, how could Duolingo or Babbel or whatever possibly compete against this.

The economic value in app development will drop drastically to almost nothing. Creating an app will become as easy as creating a Medium article.

For your app, the value will also be in what they can do in the physical world.
Uber and Lyft are not going anywhere no matter how powerful AI agents get. Their main value is the ride-sharing, not fancy app features.
It‚Äôs happening folks. Major value transfer is on its way and we‚Äôre only going to have to adapt.

Python‚Äôs functools Library: The Hidden Gem for Advanced Programming
Elshad Karimov
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
2 days ago
14
Photo by carole smile on Unsplash
When was the last time you used Python‚Äôs functools module? If your answer is "never" or "rarely," you‚Äôre not alone. Often overshadowed by flashier libraries, functools is a treasure trove of utilities that can transform how you write code. Today, let‚Äôs dive deep into this underrated library, uncovering its power and exploring how it can simplify, optimize, and enhance your Python programs.
What is functools?
functools is a built-in Python module offering higher-order functions and utilities for functional programming. If you‚Äôve ever worked with decorators, caching, or partial application, chances are you‚Äôve already used functools without realizing its full potential.
1. Supercharging Performance with lru_cache
Imagine you‚Äôre dealing with an expensive computation ‚Äî something like calculating Fibonacci numbers or fetching data from a slow API. Enter lru_cache, a decorator that automatically caches results of expensive function calls, saving you time and resources.
Example: Fibonacci with lru_cache
from functools import lru_cache

@lru_cache(maxsize=128)
def fibonacci(n):
    if n < 2:
        return n
    return fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2)

print(fibonacci(50))  # Blazing fast after caching!
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Eliminates redundant calculations.
Built-in least-recently-used (LRU) cache management.
Reduces memory overhead with maxsize.
2. The Magic of partial: Simplifying Functions
Sometimes, you have a function that takes multiple arguments, but you frequently call it with one or more fixed values. Instead of creating a new wrapper function, use partial.
Example: Pre-configured Functions
from functools import partial

# Original function
def power(base, exponent):
    return base ** exponent

# Pre-configure exponent to 2
square = partial(power, exponent=2)

print(square(5))  # Output: 25
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Removes the need for redundant wrapper functions.
Improves readability and reusability.
3. Writing Elegant Decorators with wraps
When creating custom decorators, one common issue is losing the original function‚Äôs metadata. This is where functools.wraps comes to the rescue.
Example: Preserving Metadata
from functools import wraps

def debug(func):
    @wraps(func)
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print(f"Calling {func.__name__} with {args} and {kwargs}")
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper

@debug
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))  # Output includes debug info
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Keeps the original function‚Äôs name, docstring, and other metadata intact.
Makes decorated functions easier to debug and document.
4. Function Composition with reduce
The reduce function, also part of functools, is perfect for combining elements of an iterable into a single value, step by step.
Example: Calculating Factorials
from functools import reduce

# Factorial using reduce
def factorial(n):
    return reduce(lambda x, y: x * y, range(1, n + 1))

print(factorial(5))  # Output: 120
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Simplifies complex operations on iterables.
A functional alternative to loops for aggregation.
5. Sorting Made Smarter with cmp_to_key
When sorting objects with custom comparison logic, cmp_to_key bridges the gap between Python‚Äôs key-based sorting and legacy comparison functions.
Example: Sorting by Custom Logic
from functools import cmp_to_key

# Custom comparison
def compare(x, y):
    return x - y

numbers = [5, 2, 9, 1]
sorted_numbers = sorted(numbers, key=cmp_to_key(compare))
print(sorted_numbers)  # Output: [1, 2, 5, 9]
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Provides compatibility with older comparison-based sorting methods.
Flexibility for complex sorting requirements.
6. Total Ordering with @total_ordering
Defining custom comparison methods for classes can be tedious. @total_ordering simplifies this by allowing you to define just one or two methods, and it generates the rest.
Example: Simplifying Class Comparisons
from functools import total_ordering

@total_ordering
class Employee:
    def __init__(self, name, salary):
        self.name = name
        self.salary = salary

    def __eq__(self, other):
        return self.salary == other.salary

    def __lt__(self, other):
        return self.salary < other.salary

emp1 = Employee("Alice", 50000)
emp2 = Employee("Bob", 60000)

print(emp1 < emp2)  # Output: True
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Saves you from writing redundant comparison methods.
Encourages cleaner, DRY-compliant code.
7. Single Dispatch with @singledispatch
Polymorphism in Python often involves writing multiple methods for different types of input. @singledispatch enables function overloading based on the type of the first argument.
Example: Type-Based Function Dispatch
from functools import singledispatch

@singledispatch
def process(value):
    raise NotImplementedError("Unsupported type")

@process.register
def _(value: int):
    return f"Processing integer: {value}"

@process.register
def _(value: str):
    return f"Processing string: {value}"

print(process(10))  # Output: Processing integer: 10
print(process("hello"))  # Output: Processing string: hello
Why it‚Äôs powerful:
Simplifies function overloading.
Encourages type-aware design.
Conclusion: Why You Should Explore functools
functools isn‚Äôt just a utility library; it‚Äôs a paradigm shift for Python developers who value efficiency, readability, and power. Whether you‚Äôre optimizing performance, simplifying function calls, or creating advanced decorators, this library has something to offer every developer.
Your Turn
Have you used functools in your projects? What‚Äôs your favorite feature or the most creative way you‚Äôve leveraged it? Share your thoughts and let‚Äôs uncover more hidden gems together!
Thank you for being a part of the community

See What Happened To Top Nazis Wives & Mistresses
Life after WWII
PinkHatHacker
¬∑
Follow
Published in
The Thought Collection
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Dec 6, 2024
695
10
Following World War II, the Nazi ideology declined sharply from various and obvious factors. However, for the women of Hitler‚Äôs inner circle, many of them continued to honor the deaths of these men, even in imprisonment.
Eva Braun: Hitler‚Äôs Wife
Eva Braun‚Äôs fate is arguably the most famous of all Nazi mistresses. Braun had shared a secluded life away from the business of the state and the interests of the public with Adolf Hitler for more than a decade. In the last days of the Third Reich she accompanied Hitler to his Berlin bunker and married him on April 29 1945, as Soviet troops closed in on the city.
The next day on April 30, Braun and Hitler killed themselves. The 33 Braun consumed cyanide as Hitler shot himself. Her body was burned by Hitler‚Äôs in the Reich Chancellery garden to stop the Soviets from putting on exhibition their bodies.
Gretl Braun
Eva Braun's little sister Gretl Braun also went through huge upheaval post-war. Gretl was married to SS officer Hermann Fegelein, her husband became a widow a few days before the war‚Äôs end when Fuhrer ordered Fegelein‚Äôs execution for trying to escape Berlin.
Gretl, who had married Otto Fegelein, gave birth to a daughter, Eva Fegelein, on May 5, 1945, a few days after the deaths of her sister and of Hitler.
The U.S. counterintelligence took her personal belongings, including letters and photographs from Hitler and Eva, and those became important historical treasures.
After the war, she married businessman Kurt Berlinghoff and lived in Munich.
Gretl‚Äôs daughter Eva Fegelein took her own life in 1971, at only 26. Gretl herself died of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease in 1987 at age 72.
Magda Goebbels
Magda Goebbels is also known for her chilling devotion to Nazi ideology and her husband, Joseph Goebbels was Hitler‚Äôs propaganda chief. In the last days of the war Magda and Joseph brought their six children to Hitler‚Äôs bunker in Berlin.
On May 1 1945, following Hitler‚Äôs death Magda and Joseph poisoned their children with cyanide and was convinced they would be unable to survive in a world without Nazism. Shortly after, the two committed suicide together. Magda‚Äôs actions stunned even battle-hardened Nazis, and she became a symbol of the fervent allegiance to Hitler‚Äôs cause.
Ilse Hess
Ilse Hess, the wife of Hitler‚Äôs deputy Rudolf Hess, stayed loyal to her husband and to Nazi ideology long after the war. When Rudolf was shot down and captured in 1941 while trying to fly to Scotland, Ilse defended him and the Nazi cause.
After the war Rudolf was convicted at the Nuremberg trials and sentenced to life in prison; Ilse raised their son alone.
Ilse insisted her husband was innocent and became a visible presence in far-right circles, supporting Nazi ideology long after Germany tried to forget.
Ilse survived until 1995 when she died at 95
Gerda Bormann (Martin Bormann‚Äôs Wife)
Gerda Bormann the wife of Hitlers private secretary and Nazi Party chancellor Martin Bormann shared her husbands fanaticism as a devout Nazi. They had ten children together whom they raised with strict Nazi principles.
After the war, As the Third Reich came crashing down, Gerda led her children to South Tyrol.
She was poisoned by mercury and died in 1946 at 36, orphaning her children.
A prominent Nazi official who unsuccessfully attempted to evade capture by fleeing Berlin. He was tried and convicted in absentia at the Nuremberg trials, but had indeed died during a failed escape attempt in 1945.
Gerda‚Äôs children were absorbed into foster families, and their lives bore the stigma of their father‚Äôs legacy.
Conclusion
The wives and mistresses of top Nazis were hardly passive; many played active roles in their husbands‚Äô ascent to power and the horrors wrought under the Third Reich. The women helped uphold one of history‚Äôs most savage regimes.
Their postwar lives reveal the difficulty of responding to those who supported or profited from a system of oppression and genocide with moral and legal accountability. Not all the complicity was punished in the public sphere, however; while some of their coevals suffered public disgrace or personal tragedy, others lived relatively quiet lives, their complicity ignored or minimised by society.
As more of history emerges the full scope of the crimes committed by the Nazi regime are being revealed. These stories of women serve as a reminder of the dangers of blind allegiance and of moral indifference.

Say Goodbye to 5 JavaScript Libraries in 2025 üëã
Xiuer Old
¬∑
Follow
Published in
JavaScript in Plain English
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Jan 11, 2025
230
8
As JavaScript evolves, some libraries inevitably fall behind, unable to keep up with the developer community‚Äôs expectations for the latest features, paradigms, and performance. It‚Äôs time to bid farewell to certain libraries that no longer meet our needs. This article will focus on five JavaScript libraries that may become obsolete by 2025 and the reasons why.
Why Replace JS Libraries? ü§î
We‚Äôve all heard about revolutionary breakthroughs in JS, like 18-year-old Aiden Bai creating Million.js to improve JS performance, or new methods for viewing documentation in React. But what about those that are being phased out or problematic?
1. jQuery: The Grandfather of Modern JavaScript Libraries üë¥
jQuery, once beloved for its cross-browser support, simple DOM manipulation, and concise syntax, is set to exit the stage by 2025. Native JavaScript APIs and modern frameworks like React, Vue, and Angular have rendered jQuery‚Äôs core functionalities obsolete.
JavaScript now natively includes methods like querySelector, addEventListener, and fetch, which were previously jQuery's domain. Moreover, modern browsers have standardized, making jQuery's cross-browser solutions redundant. Including jQuery in applications now only adds unnecessary bloat, slowing load times in today's speed-centric environment.
Pro Tip: If you‚Äôre still relying on jQuery, consider transitioning to modular, framework-based solutions or refactoring to native JS methods. The change may be substantial, but it will result in cleaner, faster, and more maintainable code.
2. Lodash: Redundant Utility üõ†Ô∏è
Lodash, once a Swiss Army knife for JavaScript projects, provided numerous utilities that simplified operations from deep object cloning to array manipulation. However, many of Lodash‚Äôs features are now either native to JavaScript or easily implemented with concise code.
Modern Approach: ES6 and later versions have significantly reduced the need for Lodash with features like Object.assign(), spread operators, and array methods. For the few edge cases where Lodash remains uniquely convenient, consider modular imports to minimize its impact on bundle size.
3. Moment.js: Time to Move On ‚è∞
Moment.js was the go-to date handling library for a long time, praised for its ability to parse, validate, manipulate, and display dates. However, compared to newer alternatives, Moment.js now seems bulky and inflexible, and has been deprecated. At a minimum size of 66 KB, it‚Äôs a significant load in an era where smaller packages mean faster speeds and better user experiences.
Alternative: Consider using date-fns or luxon, which offer modular imports, allowing you to include only what you need and significantly reduce bundle size.
Future-Proof Tip: Keep an eye on JavaScript‚Äôs evolving Temporal API, which offers efficient native solutions for date and time-related tasks without relying on third-party libraries.
4. Underscore.js: Living in Lodash‚Äôs Shadow üåë
Underscore.js, the predecessor to Lodash, has been living in the shadow of its more feature-rich sibling for years. It‚Äôs time to say goodbye for good.
Upgrade Path: Like Lodash, many of Underscore‚Äôs methods are now natively supported in JavaScript or can be more effectively implemented through smaller libraries or simple functions. Migrating from Underscore to ES6+ is a win for both performance and maintainability.
5. RequireJS: A Relic of Pre-ES6 Modularity üì¶
Before ES6 modules, RequireJS was instrumental in helping JavaScript manage dependencies. Its Asynchronous Module Definition (AMD) allowed for more efficient loading and helped developers manage scripts in a modular way before native functionality existed.
Modern Alternative: With the advent of ES6 modules and widespread support in modern browsers, RequireJS has become superfluous. ES6 provides a cleaner, standardized way of importing and exporting modules, making the additional complexity of RequireJS unnecessary.
Optimization Tip: Common bundling tools like Webpack, Vite, and Rollup offer simplified methods for handling dependency management, further replacing RequireJS. Additionally, cloud automation tools often work hand-in-hand with these modern bundlers, providing seamless deployment and scaling capabilities.
5 Modern Alternatives to Outdated JavaScript Libraries üÜï
As we bid farewell to these libraries, let‚Äôs look at more modern alternatives that not only simplify development but also keep your applications performant and up-to-date.
Native JavaScript (replacing jQuery)
ES6+ Native Functions (replacing Lodash)
Date-fns or Luxon (replacing Moment.js)
ES6+ Syntax (replacing Underscore.js)
Webpack, Vite, or ES6 Modules (replacing RequireJS)
Conclusion: Embracing the Future of JavaScript üåü
The JavaScript ecosystem evolves rapidly, and what was once indispensable can quickly become outdated. Continuing to use obsolete libraries can lead to performance issues, increased maintenance costs, and reduced code readability. Adopting native JavaScript functionality, modern libraries, or built-in browser APIs can lighten your stack, keep your applications performant, and ensure your development practices remain current.
It‚Äôs time to shed the old baggage of jQuery, Moment.js, Lodash, Underscore, and RequireJS. Modern alternatives are not only faster and more modular but also align better with current JavaScript development best practices, ensuring you stay ahead of the curve as we approach 2025.
Are you ready to modernize your JavaScript toolkit? What challenges do you foresee in transitioning away from these legacy libraries? Share your thoughts and experiences in the comments below! üí¨

As a senior software engineer with years of experience building enterprise systems, I‚Äôve watched the AI hype cycle with equal parts fascination and concern. The recent Devin AI controversy perfectly illustrates why we need to maintain a balanced perspective on AI‚Äôs capabilities in software development. Let me break down what happened and share some practical insights on where AI truly stands in our industry.
The Devin AI Situation: A Reality Check
When I first saw the viral video about Devin AI, marketed as the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs first AI software engineer,‚Äù my engineering instincts immediately kicked in. Having led teams through countless complex projects, I know firsthand that software engineering involves far more than just writing code. The claims about Devin completing Upwork tasks independently seemed too good to be true ‚Äî and they were.
The task in question was straightforward: provide instructions for running inferences using a specific model on AWS EC2. Any experienced engineer would approach this with a systematic checklist:
Determine the appropriate EC2 instance type and OS
Set up the environment with correct dependencies
Handle repository installation and updates
Document data I/O processes
Provide error handling guidelines
Breaking Down the Technical Reality
Let‚Äôs look at some actual code examples to illustrate the difference between efficient human engineering and AI-generated solutions. Here‚Äôs how Devin approached file reading:
# Devin's approach - unnecessarily complex
buffer = open(file_path, 'rb').read()
content = buffer.decode('utf-8')
A more Pythonic approach would be:
# Modern Python best practice
with open(file_path, 'r') as file:
    content = file.read()
This might seem like a minor difference, but it reflects a deeper understanding of language idioms and best practices that comes from real-world experience.
The Hidden Complexities of Software Engineering
What the Devin AI controversy really highlights is the vast gap between writing code and engineering solutions. In my years of leading development teams, I‚Äôve learned that successful software engineering involves:
Requirement Analysis: Understanding what clients really need, not just what they say they want. The Upwork task specifically requested AWS EC2 deployment instructions ‚Äî a detail Devin missed entirely.
System Design: Making architectural decisions that balance scalability, maintainability, and performance. These decisions require understanding business constraints and future growth patterns.
Code Quality: Writing efficient, maintainable code that follows established patterns and practices. The difference between code that works and production-quality code is massive.
Problem-Solving: When I reviewed the situation, I noticed that Devin spent hours debugging self-generated errors instead of addressing the actual task requirements. This is a rookie mistake that no senior engineer would make.
Real-World Implications for Development Teams
As someone who regularly makes hiring decisions and sets technical direction for projects, I see both opportunities and challenges in AI‚Äôs current state:
Where AI Shines:
Code completion and suggestions
Documentation generation
Repetitive task automation
Initial boilerplate creation
Where Human Engineers Are Essential:
Architecture decisions
Security considerations
Performance optimization
Cross-functional communication
Client requirement interpretation
Best Practices for Integrating AI Tools
Based on my experience leading engineering teams, here‚Äôs how to effectively integrate AI tools into your development workflow:
Use AI as an Assistant, Not a Replacement
Leverage AI for code suggestions but always review and understand the output
Use AI-generated code as a starting point, not the final solution
2. Maintain Code Quality Standards
# Instead of accepting AI-generated code as-is:
def process_data(data):
    # Add proper type hints
    def process_data(data: List[Dict[str, Any]]) -> Dict[str, float]:
        # Add input validation
        if not data:
            raise ValueError("Input data cannot be empty")
        # Add proper error handling
        try:
            # Original AI-generated logic here
            pass
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error processing data: {e}")
            raise
3. Document Design Decisions
Explain why certain approaches were chosen
Document limitations and assumptions
Keep track of AI-generated vs. human-reviewed code
Looking Forward: The Real Future of AI in Software Development
The Devin AI situation took 6+ hours to complete what an experienced engineer did in 36 minutes. This isn‚Äôt to diminish AI‚Äôs potential, but to highlight the importance of realistic expectations. In my experience managing large-scale projects, the most successful teams are those that embrace AI as a powerful tool while recognizing its limitations.
The future isn‚Äôt about AI replacing engineers ‚Äî it‚Äôs about engineers who can effectively leverage AI becoming exponentially more productive than those who can‚Äôt.
Conclusion
As someone who has weathered numerous technology hypes and transformations, I can say with confidence that AI will revolutionize software development ‚Äî just not in the way many think. The key is understanding its real capabilities and limitations, then building processes that maximize its benefits while maintaining the high standards our industry demands.
The next time you see bold claims about AI capabilities, remember the Devin controversy. Apply the same critical thinking you‚Äôd use in code review. The future of software development is exciting, but it requires a balanced, realistic approach to new technologies.<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
What Is the Sum of All Odd Numbers Less Than 100?
Fletcher Thompson

Legend says that a young Johann Carl Friedrich Gauss was asked by his teacher to sum the numbers 1 to 100. Almost instantly, Gauss came up with his answer, which was derived using a genius method.
Gauss went on to become one of the greatest mathematicians/scientists in history.
This puzzle is slightly different. We‚Äôll use the same method as Gauss for part of the solution.
I should mention that I‚Äôm only summing the positive numbers. Otherwise, the answer would diverge to -‚àû!
The solution is below, with some extra challenges at the end.
We can interpret the sum of the odd numbers less than 100 as the sum of all numbers less than 100 with the even numbers missing.
This means that we can find the solution by subtracting the sum of all even numbers less than 100 from the sum of all numbers less than 100.
It remains to calculate each of these sums. Let‚Äôs start with all the numbers.
How do we find the sum of a given amount of consecutive numbers? We call the given amount n and begin by drawing them as squares making up a triangle n tall.
This is 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5. I‚Äôm just using 5 as an example.
Flip it and attach it to itself, forming a rectangle.
The rectangle contains n(n + 1) squares. It consists of two triangles. This means that the sum of numbers 1 to n is given by:
So the sum of the first 100 numbers is 100 * 101 / 2 = 5050.
Now onto the sum of all even numbers less than 100. There‚Äôs something important to notice about this sum 2 + 4 + ‚Ä¶ + 98 + 100.
It‚Äôs double the sum of the numbers 1 to 50, which (from our formula) we know to be 50 * 51 / 2 = 1275.
Doubling it gives us 1275 * 2 = 2550.
To finish off, as stated earlier, the sum of the odd numbers less than 100 is 5050‚Äì2550 = 2500.
So 1 + 3 + ‚Ä¶ + 97 + 99 = 2500. ‚úÖ

Don‚Äôt share it.
People can use it against you.

How and when to stop
Don‚Äôt share your weakness.

Pleasing others?

Meditation can help you a lot. I tried it for 30 days.

Emotions

Be an active listener; let the other person do the talking part.
It‚Äôs absolutely fine to talk all the time.

When you overshare, you open up to criticism and judgment from others.

Renowned investor Jeremy Grantham recently said:
‚ÄúThe trouble with this bubble is it‚Äôs an everything bubble.‚Äù
I follow macro investors and so-called money experts, and one thing's for sure ‚Äî they're divided.
No one knows what's coming next. However, as Grantham puts it:
‚ÄúInvesting is not about precision, but probabilities.‚Äù
He sees himself as a "realist trying to see the world as it is, not how I'd like it to be. Sometimes I succeed, and sometimes I fail."
The 84-year-old pro, known for studying market bubbles, believes there's a 70% chance we're heading for a recession that could bring a further 50% correction in the S&P 500.
I haven't seen a single money manager without a rap sheet of bad calls, which only fuels the critics with their pitchforks.
His critics label him a "Perma-bear," a title he playfully brushes off with a twinkle in his eye, preferring to call himself a "bubble historian."
In 1999, he was fired, which put him on the map. During the dot-com boom and bust, he started pulling money from growth stocks too early while the market kept climbing, and his clients lost their minds.
Jeremy Grantham ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúWe fought the bubble all the way but were horrifically too early. That was a brutal two years. The market moved significantly from its all-time high in early ‚Äô98. It went straight up until March of 2000, and our clients disapproved of us being early and, to a very considerable degree, fired us.
People pulled money out, and then when the market finally did have its collapse, the so-called dot-com bubble burst.
Question ‚Äî So people called up and said, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre sorry, can we give you our money now?‚Äô Answer ‚Äî No solitary person who fired us returned for the same product they fired us for‚Äù.
His fund's performance was as sturdy as a tank during those chaotic times.
They sidestepped losses in 2000 and 2001 and narrowly avoided them in 2002, while the entire market plummeted like a lead balloon.
Even with the S&P suffering a 50% drop, the fund managed three consecutive years of growth, solidifying the firm's reputation and attracting a wave of investment.
Source ‚Äî Bloomberg
Opinions about the state of the market are all over the place.
The hottest topic I encounter daily is whether we're teetering on the edge of a recession or if we'll narrowly avoid it.
The market bubble guru argues it would be surprising if we didn't face an extended economic issue. "This tech bubble bursting is far from over. What happens after bubbles pop? There's always a recession right around the corner, and people just don't see it coming."
Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is singing a different tune, completely dropping its recession forecast because the economy is "resilient."
Jerome Powell ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúSo the staff now has a noticeable slowdown in growth starting later this year in the forecast, but given the resilience of the economy recently, they are no longer forecasting a recession.‚Äù
The Fed has reduced inflation from 8.2% to 2.4%, and unemployment is at 4.1%, with a slight increase but still the lowest since 2000 and below its target of 5%.
Hedge fund manager and popular television personality Jim Cramer best summed it up when he said, "If I speak in no gibberish, this economy is so hard to kill."
Source ‚Äî Fred.org: Unemployment rate
Grantham keeps it straightforward: "Low interest rates drive asset prices up, while higher rates bring them down. We're now entering an era where rates will average higher than they have over the last decade."
Jeremy Grantham ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúThe Fed‚Äôs record on these things is wonderful. It‚Äôs almost guaranteed to be wrong. They have never called a recession, and particularly not the ones following the great bubbles. They prided themselves on stimulating the bubbles ‚Äî they took credit for the beneficial effect of higher asset prices on the economy. They have never claimed credit for the deflationary effect of asset prices breaking, and they always do.‚Äù
A hidden indicator that confuses investors during every market bubble.
Grantham says:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like they‚Äôre reading a map in a different language.‚Äù
The stock market is rallying amid a banking crisis, a war in Europe, skyrocketing interest rates, and inflation rates that are squeezing disposable income.
Grantham's data shows rallies are commonly concentrated among blue-chip stocks right before a crash. One crucial indicator of a market peak is a "divergence in performance," where certain stocks start moving in opposite directions.
He points out that historical patterns show that "blue chips initially outperform during market bubbles," leading people to believe everything is hunky-dory.
Eight of the top ten performing stocks are tech giants touting a bright future in AI. These heavily concentrated stocks account for 28.30% of the market gains.
J. Grantham warns ‚Äî and I agree ‚Äî that this is a glaring sign that once the AI speculation cools down, there will be severe downward pressure on stock prices.
Source: Investopedia.
According to Grantham, divergence‚Äîthe separation in performance between "junior" stocks and blue chips‚Äîis a clear sign of a top signal.
We're in an AI bubble, with giants like Apple, Microsoft, and Amazon making up 15% of the market's gains.
The bubble historian points out that the same pattern occurred during the Great Tech Bubble in 1929, 1972, and 2000.
After bingeing more than 20 hours of his content, it's clear my fellow Brit takes pleasure in market bubbles ‚Äî you can see the delight on his face. Lol.
But this AI bubble is throwing people off.
Jeremy Grantham ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúYou get this divergence where, at the beginning of the bubble, the speculative leaders take a hit, sometimes a significant one, while the big blue chips keep climbing.
People wonder, ‚ÄòWhat are you talking about? It doesn‚Äôt look like a bear market ‚Äî the S&P is up 20%. The S&P was up a lot more than 20% in 1929. But the low-priced index, the speculative stocks, were down 35% to 40% the day before the 1929 crash. The low-priced index had even been up 85% in 1928.
Nothing resembled that divergence, where the high-beta stocks plummeted, and blue chips skyrocketed, until now.‚Äù
According to Grantham's investment firm's whitepaper on recessions, high-risk stocks typically take a nosedive during economic downturns.
Over the past 55 years, value stocks have performed better in recessions, while growth stocks usually struggle.
Growth stocks are linked to companies with high revenue expectations and earnings growth, often in innovative industries, whereas value stocks are established companies perceived as undervalued with stable business models.
The performance of value stocks is represented by the purple bar below.
Source ‚Äî GMO White paper on recessions
"It's a head fake."
GMO said this cycle would be notably different and could be worse than an ordinary recession.
‚ÄúThe sharp increase in interest rates, the likely persistence of inflation, and a corporate tax change in the US that seems to have gotten less notice than we believe it deserves. Those factors make us believe that a recession, when it occurs, will be harder to cushion and that highly levered corporations will fare worse in a recession than investors might assume from past cycles‚Äù.
Grantham sees AI as the party spoiler amidst already challenging circumstances, disrupting the deflation process from the tech bubble of 2021.
Jeremy Grantham ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúI wish it hadn‚Äôt arrived just now because the end of these great bubbles is hard enough without the elements of new bubbles to scramble the thinking.
And that‚Äôs what has happened here.
A dozen giant American stocks have had a hell of a run on the back of AI, which has undoubtedly created the impression that it‚Äôs game over (for a recession).
The problem is prices are still incredibly high, and basically, the economy is beginning to unravel, and it‚Äôs a head fake, but it‚Äôs a hell of a head fake.‚Äù
Closing Thoughts.
Grantham says:
"Humans always look for better outcomes than historically typical."
I agree, but now we‚Äôve got a magic genie in the form of a money printer that seems to grant endless wishes.
The ISM, a sentiment survey sent to 50,000 supply chain professionals, has nailed every market crash on 14 occasions and now looks like it‚Äôs bottomed out.
So, financial conditions appear to be improving, even if Grantham insists it‚Äôs a head fake.
Don‚Äôt get caught up in just the current ISM score. What you want to do is look at the direction it‚Äôs headed.
When it goes down, it tumbles into bear market territory, and when it goes up, it rockets straight into a bull market‚Äîso there‚Äôs not too much sideways movement.
A score above 50 signals positive momentum.
It bottomed at 46.8 and is now sitting at 47.2.
Source
While he claims not to be a doomsday fearmonger, Grantham says:
‚ÄúJust persuade yourself that the world is typically wrong ‚Äî the world is usually too optimistic and too eager to follow the crowd.‚Äù
I'm not a short-term trader, but the classic saying, "Time in the market beats timing the market," is something I firmly believe in.
The data never lies.
If you invested $6,400 ‚Äî a little over two months' salary in the USA ‚Äî a decade ago in Apple stock, you'd be looking at profits of $43,175, even when people claimed the stock was too high.
Source ‚Äî Investopedia Calculator
Amazon's market cap skyrocketed from around $100 million during its first bull run in the dot-com bubble in 2000 to over $1.3 trillion today, marking a staggering increase of 1.3 million per cent (1,300,000%).
It took ten years and two recessions for those stuck with Jeff Bezos's company since the bubble's peak to see significant gains, but their patience paid off handsomely.
The key isn't about being a Nostradamus ‚Äî it's about thoughtfully picking stocks you believe in for the long haul.
People like Grantham, who dedicate their lives to mastering a single skill set, are often right.
Over which time horizon, who knows?
One thing remains certain: how bad the next recession will be is anyone's guess.
