ChatGPT Can Now Access Mac Apps to Write Code for You
Jim Clyde Monge
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Generative AI
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Nov 15, 2024
668
14
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
The next big trend in AI is here‚ÄîAI chatbots controlling your PC.
Just three weeks ago, Anthropic introduced a feature on Claude called Computer Use, allowing it to control desktops with text-based commands. Soon after, Microsoft revealed Omniparser, a research preview for an AI agent that can parse your screen‚Äîlikely a hint on an upcoming feature to control a user‚Äôs desktop, most likely through Copilot.
While Apple and Google have been quiet about similar tools, it‚Äôs safe to assume they‚Äôre working on something behind the scenes.
Today, OpenAI released a new feature called ‚ÄúWork with Apps‚Äù on the ChatGPT desktop app for Mac. This feature lets ChatGPT control programming tools like Xcode, VS Code, and even terminal apps.
As a developer and an avid user of AI programming assistants, this is huge.
New ChatGPT ‚ÄúWork with Apps‚Äù Feature
Let‚Äôs get this out of the way ‚Äî this feature isn‚Äôt an AI agent yet.
However, OpenAI describes it as a ‚Äúkey building block‚Äù for creating agentic systems. The main challenge for AI agents right now is learning to interpret the entire computer screen, not just text-based prompts or their own outputs.
Here‚Äôs what ChatGPT‚Äôs new feature can do:
Access and read code in apps like Xcode or VS Code.
Write code based on the existing code in your project.
Commit changes in terminal apps like Terminal or iTerm2.
Debug and write unit tests for your project.
Here‚Äôs what the new feature looks like on the ChatGPT desktop app for Mac.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
The new desktop app control button is placed beside the internet search toggle, and clicking on it shows a list of compatible apps that you can enable/disable.
Before you can use the new desktop control feature, make sure to give ChatGPT permission to control your computer in the Accessibility settings.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Once ChatGPT is enabled in the Accessibility settings, you should see that Xcode is now enabled on ChatGPT‚Äôs dashboard.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
For this example, I asked ChatGPT to create a navigation menu for my product, Flux Labs AI. It‚Äôs a tool for generating high-quality images of products and portraits using trained image models.
Let‚Äôs try asking ChatGPT to write a code that will show a navigation menu at the bottom of the screen.
Prompt: Can you create navigation menu at the bottom of the screen?
1. AI Tools
2. Creations
3. Discover
4. Account
ChatGPT peeks at the code in my opened Xcode project and writes a code suggestion for me.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Here‚Äôs what ChatGPT suggested:
import SwiftUI
import SwiftData

struct ContentView: View {
    @Environment(\.modelContext) private var modelContext
    @Query private var items: [Item]

    var body: some View {
        TabView {
            // Tab 1: AI Tools
            NavigationView {
                List {
                    ForEach(items) { item in
                        NavigationLink {
                            Text("Item at \(item.timestamp, format: Date.FormatStyle(date: .numeric, time: .standard))")
                        } label: {
                            Text(item.timestamp, format: Date.FormatStyle(date: .numeric, time: .standard))
                        }
                    }
                    .onDelete(perform: deleteItems)
                }
                .toolbar {
                    ToolbarItem(placement: .navigationBarTrailing) {
                        EditButton()
                    }
                    ToolbarItem {
                        Button(action: addItem) {
                            Label("Add Item", systemImage: "plus")
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
            .tabItem {
                Label("AI Tools", systemImage: "wand.and.stars")
            }

            // Tab 2: Creations
            NavigationView {
                Text("Creations")
                    .font(.largeTitle)
                    .padding()
            }
            .tabItem {
                Label("Creations", systemImage: "paintbrush")
            }

            // Tab 3: Discover
            NavigationView {
                Text("Discover")
                    .font(.largeTitle)
                    .padding()
            }
            .tabItem {
                Label("Discover", systemImage: "magnifyingglass")
            }

            // Tab 4: Account
            NavigationView {
                Text("Account")
                    .font(.largeTitle)
                    .padding()
            }
            .tabItem {
                Label("Account", systemImage: "person.circle")
            }
        }
    }

    private func addItem() {
        withAnimation {
            let newItem = Item(timestamp: Date())
            modelContext.insert(newItem)
        }
    }

    private func deleteItems(offsets: IndexSet) {
        withAnimation {
            for index in offsets {
                modelContext.delete(items[index])
            }
        }
    }
}

#Preview {
    ContentView()
        .modelContainer(for: Item.self, inMemory: true)
}
I then have to copy the code from ChatGPT and paste it into Xcode. Here‚Äôs what it looks like:
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
It‚Äôs worth noting that ChatGPT can‚Äôt directly modify code in Xcode. You‚Äôll need to copy and paste everything manually, which isn‚Äôt ideal but gets the job done.
Nevertheless, I like the icons and the layout it created for me. I can even click on each tab, and it switches the pages for me. Pretty cool.
Next, I asked ChatGPT to create a dashboard for the user account page. I uploaded a screenshot of an example page and prompted ChatGPT to replicate it.
Prompt: In the Accounts page, can you create a nice looking dashboard with the information similar to the attached image?
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
It generated the code and even provided a step-by-step guide on where to place it. For someone unfamiliar with Swift, this was a lifesaver.
ChatGPT gave me the step-by-step guide on how and where to add the code.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Here‚Äôs what the dashboard looks like:
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
The dashboard wasn‚Äôt perfect but worked well enough. With more tweaks, it could easily become production-ready.
Finally, pair ChatGPT with the terminal and ask it to commit the code changes and push to the repository.
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
ChatGPT will provide the git commands, and all you have to do is execute them on the terminal.
git add .
git commit -m "Implement sticky bottom navigation and account dashboard layout"
ush origin main
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
If you want to see how it works, I posted a demo of ChatGPT‚Äôs new feature in an X post below.
How Does It Work?
OpenAI‚Äôs Work with Apps relies heavily on macOS‚Äôs accessibility API, which has been powering Apple‚Äôs VoiceOver screen reader. This lets ChatGPT read text from apps and process it.
Right now, the screen reader only works with text. It can‚Äôt handle other stuff on screen like images, object layouts, or videos.
Here‚Äôs how it processes code:
For some apps, the last 200 lines of code are sent to ChatGPT with every prompt.
For others, ChatGPT uses all the code in your active window.
You can highlight specific sections to guide ChatGPT, but it will still include surrounding text for context.
Note that this process uses a lot of input tokens.
The Next Generation of AI Agents
According to a Bloomberg report a few days ago, the speed of innovation in the AI landscape is slowing down.
The three biggest AI tech companies‚ÄîOpenAI, Google, and Anthropic‚Äîare now seeing diminishing returns from their costly efforts to build more advanced artificial intelligence systems.
With the introduction of AI tools that can access our computers, it opens up a plethora of possible use cases. I can‚Äôt even imagine the worst and best possible scenario these tools could make in a user PC.
Off the top of my head, here are some possible effects:
Software development could shift focus from skills to ideas.
Productivity could skyrocket as repetitive tasks are automated.
Automation might reduce jobs in some industries.
Expect a flood of AI-generated software on the internet.
Security concerns could become a bigger issue than ever before.
According to Harvard Business Review research, generative AI is already making a big impact in the labor market.
Image from Harvard Business Review
We find that the introduction of ChatGPT and image-generating tools led to nearly immediate decreases in posts for online gig workers across job types, but particularly for automation-prone jobs. After the introduction of ChatGPT, there was a 21% decrease in the weekly number of posts in automation-prone jobs compared to manual-intensive jobs. Writing jobs were affected the most (30.37% decrease), followed by software, app, and web development (20.62%) and engineering (10.42%).
Looking at this trend, I believe that the people who choose to adapt and learn to use AI tools will thrive and those who resists are likely to lose their jobs.
Is It Better Than Cursor AI?
After spending a few hours with ChatGPT‚Äôs new feature, it became clear to me that ChatGPT lags behind Cursor AI.
Cursor‚Äôs Composer interface can reference specific files and make targeted changes.
Cursor supports multiple language models, including Anthropic‚Äôs Claude, Meta‚Äôs Llama, and OpenAI‚Äôs GPT.
Code changes in Cursor are applied directly to your files‚Äîno copying and pasting.
For example, I wanted to add a new model called ‚ÄúArticle‚Äù to my database schema file. Here‚Äôs the full prompt:
Prompt: I have this base prisma schema. I have a feature called AI Article generator where user can generate an article by text prompt and the AI will generate an article based on the prompt. I want to save the article and the text prompt so that when user checks the history, the articles along with the prompt will be retrieved from the database. Can you update the schema to accommodate this request?
Image by Jim Clyde Monge
Cursor AI proposes the code changes, and all you have to do is decide whether you want to accept or not. See the highlighted code in green above? That‚Äôs the newly added code block in the database schema.
In ChatGPT, you would have to copy that code change from the chatbot on to the IDE, which is prone to mistakes if you copy it the wrong way.
Final Thoughts
Honestly, ChatGPT controlling Mac apps is something I didn‚Äôt see coming this soon.
It‚Äôs exciting to think about how far this could go in the future. Imagine ChatGPT creating files, writing code, running tests, and even pushing changes to GitHub.
Will everyone love it? Definitely not. The security concerns alone will make a lot of people skeptical. But as a developer, I think this has so much potential.
Is it better than Cursor AI? No.
Cursor is still ahead with more features, and it can even directly edit code. Plus, Cursor offers 500 prompts per month for free. That‚Äôs more than enough for smaller projects. ChatGPT‚Äôs free GPT-4 messaging credits feel really limited in comparison.
So far, it‚Äôs unclear how OpenAI will expand this feature to apps that don‚Äôt work with Apple‚Äôs screen reader. Competitors like Anthropic are taking a different approach by analyzing screenshots to understand what‚Äôs on the screen.

The Difference Between The Clever Developer & The Wise Developer
Avoiding problems is faster than solving them
Ben "The Hosk" Hosking
¬∑
Follow
Published in
ITNEXT
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Sep 6, 2022
8.3K
82
Devs
‚ÄúThere is no greater fool than he who thinks himself wise; no one wiser than he who suspects he is a fool.‚Äù Marguerite de Valois
Most developers are clever at writing code, in many situations the cleverness is a strength and a weakness.
Common sense, street smarts and experience can help developers avoid problems rather than solving them. Knowing when to reach for code and when to reject a requirement.
Knowing when to keep silent, when to fight and when to run and hide gives the wise (senior) developer the advantage over the clever (junior) developer.
What's the difference between clever and wise?
Developers spend only 50 percent of their time writing code
Junior developers take simple requirements and create complex code
Senior developers take complex requirements and create simple code
In general senior developers are wise and junior developers are clever but haven‚Äôt made the mistakes yet to be wise. The difference between junior developers and senior developers is experience, knowledge, and skill.
Experience is the difference. Once developers make a mistake, they (hopefully) avoid it by not making the same mistake in the future. This gives them the opportunity to make new mistakes and over time, developers know how to avoid more mistakes.
Mistakes in software development can be hard to see coming because the consequences and pain are far into the future. Simple mistakes give quick feedback, you find it and fix it fast.
Trickier mistakes are something like hard coding a value and there doesn‚Äôt seem any downside initially. Later, you need to do a complete release to change the value and you can pay for this decision many times.
Avoid problems don‚Äôt solve them
A clever person solves a problem. A wise person avoids it ‚Äî Albert Einstein
All developers want to write code. It‚Äôs what they are good at and it‚Äôs what they enjoy doing. The skill senior developers learn is when to write code, when to clarify and identifying when code doesn‚Äôt need to be written at all.
Junior developers are like a person with a golden hammer where everyone's requirement and problem seems like an opportunity to write code.
Writing code should be the last option because everyone line of code once created becomes a liability to the development team. Once you create code, it must be maintained and adds to the complexity of the code base.
In the short-term code is an excellent solution but in the long term it takes longer, increases complexity and adds to the maintenance overhead.
It‚Äôs more effective to write less code, which will reduce the chance of failure. Senior developers know you write code when you must and when you have validated the requirements.
The wise developer reduces the code created by including only the must have requirements and ignoring the nice to have requirements.
Requirements can be achieved by changing business processes instead of writing code. Don‚Äôt automate everything, sometimes the manual choice is the best choice.
When to create code
You gotta know when to hold ‚Äôem, know when to fold ‚Äôem, know when to walk away, know when to run. Kenny Rogers
The wise (senior) developers know when to write code, when to validate, check and not create code. Junior developers are skilled at writing code and they want to use these skills as often as possible.
This highlights the difference in output but there is a bigger a difference between junior (clever) developer and senior (wise) developers and it‚Äôs knowing when to write code.
Simplicity
Junior developers want to create code straight away, often before they understand why the business needs the code and what it needs to do.
Senior developers look for assumptions and validate requirements. It doesn‚Äôt matter how well you create code if it‚Äôs doing the wrong thing.
You create software faster by writing code with validated requirements. There is a lot overhead with code such as updated dependent code, related code, documentation, tests, builds, documentation. Sometimes developers go faster later by starting slower and creating the right software.
Talking when they should listen
The first principle is that you must not fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool. Richard P. Feynman
Carpenters measure twice and cut the wood once. Developers are rarely so careful.
The wise (senior) developers understand they are the expert in creating software and users are the experts in their business. Creating software is a collaboration between business and technical experts.
Junior developers forget and listen to some requirements, stop listening and move to creating a technical solution. The senior developers focus on the business goals and processes so they can understand the purpose of the software. It‚Äôs only once you understand the purpose of the business, team and individual role that you can create software to help them.
The common mistake happens when junior developers read the requirements enough to understand the happy path and create that. Later, when the unhappy path and exceptions appear, the junior developer has to keep changing the code to fix one bug after another.
What seemed like fast progress at the beginning, slowly bug by bug falls behind. A good senior developer creates the code once, and it glides through the environment.
Senior developers know when to ask questions, when to listen and when to talk.
‚ÄúSilence is a lesson learned from the many sufferings of life.‚Äù ‚Äî Seneca
Do your job
Software development needs a team to do it, and that needs everyone to do their job.
Being helpful is a double-edged sword, it can help the other person in the short term but hurt yourself in the long term. The more you do other people's work, the less time you have to do your own.
Wise developers make sure the people who handle areas of the project, do that work.
Developers need to protect their time and push the responsibilities and decisions for the people who handle that.
Junior developers get sucked into doing other people's work, get stuck and run out of time to do their work. If you do this enough and you keep working longer hours and are heading towards burnout.
Align with reality
‚ÄúYesterday I was clever, so I wanted to change the world. Today I am wise, so I am changing myself‚Äù ‚Äî Rumi
Things will go wrong, problems will happen, plans will go wrong and designs will change. You cannot fight reality. Adapt to the environment and change with it.
Junior developers fight reality, senior developers align with it.
You cannot stop problems, bugs and issues, but you can prepare for them and make sure they don‚Äôt end in disaster. Technical Disasters Should Not Catch Developers Unprepared
The difference between a clever person and a wise person is really not worth worrying about<|InputEnd|>Top highlight
Photo by Vlad Tchompalov on Unsplash

Tesla Has Officially Scrapped Its Best Project
Musk seems determined to destroy Tesla from the inside out.
Will Lockett
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Predict
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Nov 2, 2024
2.7K
52
Musk has developed several utterly moronic Tesla projects over the years. This includes the Tesla Solar Roof, the Tesla Bot, The Boring Company, Tesla lithium mining, the 4680 battery, FSD, the Robotaxi, the Cybertruck, and the second-gen Tesla Roadster, just to name a few. All were meant to solidify Tesla‚Äôs lead in the market and secure ample amounts of future revenue. However, they are all half-baked ideas that are nowhere close to hitting the market, and those that actually have hit the market are not what was promised and have failed to produce any serious momentum. But there is one zany project that stood out amongst the rest. If the Model 3 was Tesla‚Äôs Ford Model T moment, this would be their VW Beatle moment: the $25,000 Model 2. This would bring the EV revolution to the working classes, push sustainable transport to a new phase, and potentially make Tesla billions of dollars. Or, at least, it would have if Musk hadn‚Äôt officially killed it off. But why did Musk scrap this crucial project? And what does this mean for the future of Tesla?
Musk has been promising a smaller, cheaper model than the Model 3 for years, and plans to produce it have been leaked and announced numerous times. As such, we know it was going to cost $25,000 before tax, be approximately the size of a VW Polo, use a 53 kWh battery pack that was most likely going to be sourced from BYD, have 250 miles of range, and charge from 10% to 80% in around 25 minutes. We even know that Musk and Tesla were planning on selling over a million units of this vehicle a year and that it would potentially share the same platform as the upcoming Robotaxi.
But, back in April, when Tesla scheduled the Robotaxi ‚ÄúWe Robot‚Äù event that happened two weeks ago, Reuters reported that they had been informed by someone inside Tesla that the Model 2 project had been completely scrapped to save money and pay for the exuberantly expensive development of the Robotaxi. Musk, who has had a long-time feud with Reuters for accurately reporting faults at Tesla, lambasted them for this report, calling it a lie. And, as a result, for months, we didn‚Äôt know if the Model 2 was coming or not.
As Tesla‚Äôs sales and profit figures started to roll in, it looked like Musk would be a moron to scrap the Model 2 project. You may have seen Tesla‚Äôs share price recently increase as they announced their 2024 Q3 revenue is up 17%. But that figure is just glitter on a turd. In the US, year-to-date Tesla Model Y sales are down 41%, and year-to-date Model 3 sales are down 22%. What‚Äôs more, despite selling regulatory carbon credits galore, their operational profit is only 10.8%, down from a peak of nearly 30% in 2022. In short, Tesla is losing its advantage and is being slowly squeezed out of the market. Tesla needs a proper mass-market EV to plug these falling sales figures, fix their falling profit margin, and keep their spot as king of the EV world. Because of this, many believed Elon that the Model 2 was still coming.
Unfortunately, there is just one problem. The Model 2 has been in the making for so long that it is no longer revolutionary. Multiple manufacturers have already made cars with almost identical specs for the same price, such as the BYD Dolphin, VW ID.2, MG MG4, Peugeot e-208, Citro√´n E-C3, Kia EV2, Renault 5, and MINI Cooper SE.
In fact, the Peugeot e-208 is currently a better buy than the hypothetical Model 2. This awesome little EV has 249 miles of WLTP range and a 10% to 80% charge time of only 27 minutes, which is basically the same as the Model 2. Yet you can currently buy one in the UK for only ¬£22,136 after tax! If you take away the tax and convert that price into dollars, you will find the e-208 is actually the equivalent of $1,000 cheaper than the promised Model 2.
While the Peugeot is the best-selling small EV in the UK, it isn‚Äôt selling anywhere near as much as Musk predicted his Model 2 would. It is by no means a sales flop, as these things litter the roads of Europe and have helped Peugeot‚Äôs sales figures grow dramatically. The same is true for all the other Model 2 competitors already on the market.
There is no doubt that the Model 2 would have significantly helped Tesla, but Musk also knows they are far from first to the market and that even if they were, it wouldn‚Äôt sell in the volumes he was hoping.
So, Musk officially scrapped the Model 2. During the Tesla 2024 Q3 earnings call, Musk stated, ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôve made it very clear that the future is autonomous. I think having a regular $25,000 model is pointless. It would be silly. It would be completely at odds with what we believe.‚Äù He simply wasn‚Äôt satisfied with a solid incremental step forward; he wanted more, and his greed may have cost the company its future.
This is nothing short of an entirely dimwitted idea. Even the engineers behind Tesla‚Äôs own self-driving system have called it unsafe, and even if the Robotaxi can be manufactured by 2027, as Musk claims, it is practically impossible for it to get regulatory approval. In fact, many self-driving experts have raised questions if it can ever pass regulatory approval as it has no redundant systems (to find out more about this, click here). But, not only that, it also isn‚Äôt a replacement for a small mass-market car! It only has two seats and practically no luggage space, and it can only charge via induction, making long-haul trips impossible. It has no override function, so driving off-road or into unmapped areas is impossible. It has a tiny battery, so range isn‚Äôt going to be great. It‚Äôs also incredibly low to the ground and has scissor doors, making accessibility horrific.
It also costs more at $30,000, though with Tesla‚Äôs track record, it will likely cost far more than that in the end. Musk has claimed this isn‚Äôt an issue, as your car can autonomously act as a taxi when you aren‚Äôt using it, making you money.
But what if you live away from taxi demand? What if you have allergies and can‚Äôt risk someone eating peanuts in the car or being accompanied by a dog? What if you regularly need to store valuables in the car? What if your schedule requires you to have a car at the ready? There is also the issue of country-wide demand. If Musk does sell enough Robotaxis to make up for the lack of a Model 2, then there will be a huge number of these cars on the roads. This oversupply could crash the price of renting out your Robotaxi, meaning owners might only make pennies and not offset the higher cost of the vehicle.
Simply put, even in the best-case scenario, the Robotaxi is simply not a replacement for the Model 2 for the user or Tesla as a company.
But, at the Q3 earnings call, Tesla did announce that ‚ÄúPreparations remain underway for our offering of new vehicles ‚Äî including more affordable models ‚Äî which we will begin launching in the first half of 2025.‚Äù This is likely a cheaper version of the Model 3, however, it potentially isn‚Äôt coming anyway thanks to Musk‚Äôs actions. Lithium and other crucial materials for EV manufacturing are set to plummet in price over the coming year, and as such, a cheaper version of the Model 3 isn‚Äôt going to have any advantage, as costs will tumble across the entire industry. Again, for Tesla to keep its sales figures and profits high, it needs a new, cheaper, mass-market EV in a different sector than the 3 or Y.
In reality, it could be well after 2030 when the Robotaxi finally makes its way into customers‚Äô hands, if it ever does. There is simply no evidence that Tesla can deliver on its promises any sooner than that. There is also no evidence that Tesla can deliver a useable Robotaxi, as their vision-only approach to self-driving (read more here) has proven to be significantly worse and less safe than other self-driving systems that use a vast array of multiple sensor types. Sadly though, in officially scrapping the Model 2, Musk has cut off any other direction for Tesla to grow in. Tesla has to make the Robotaxi work or die a slow death as they fade into obscurity. Which is a shame, as they are now miles behind the leaders in automation, and the Robotaxi is a fatally flawed piece of design.

Why Obsidian Limits Your Brain and What to Use Instead
Why is it holding your brain back, and how can you break free?
Anshul Kumar
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Bouncin‚Äô and Behavin‚Äô Blogs
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Aug 29, 2024
1.5K
80
Photo by julien Tromeur on Unsplash
Here's the thing: If you've ever used Obsidian to try to organize your life, your job, or your thoughts, you may have cried out, "Hell yeah, this is it!"
But let me tell you something: Obsidian may be likened to attempting to use an awful fork to organize a spaghetti mess.
It may seem like a handy tool at first, but is it genuinely improving brain function, or is it simply playing tricks on you?
Here is how Obsidian manipulates your thoughts, and more importantly, here is what you should use in its place to accomplish things.
The Obsidian Seduction:
Photo by Angel Balashev on Unsplash
Obsidian is the note-taking software equivalent of the holy grail.
You've undoubtedly gone for it head over heels if you're anything like me. It has this whole "build your second brain" feel.
But first, let's stand back. It may seem like it will organize your disorganized ideas into a cohesive knowledge network, but is that true?
I was thrilled to discover Obsidian for the first time.
I was prepared for my mind to go on overdrive, piecing things together like a mind map pro.
However, after hours of trying to figure everything out, I concluded that Obsidian is just overthinking things.
Attempting to take notes with a Swiss Army knife is like having an assortment of tools, none of which fulfill their intended purpose.
Is Obsidian the Best Note-Taking Tool
Look for the best to be the best.
medium.com
The Overwhelm: Too Many Features, Not Enough Focus
Photo by Jakayla Toney on Unsplash
Let's focus on the number of excessive features.
You can find a plugin for whatever you need and for whatever you would like to have in Obsidian.
You may personalize the hell out of it, but that is the problem, right there. Instead of helping you to organize your thoughts, it pulls you into this vortex of adjusting and personalizing until you have no idea what the fuck you were trying to do in the first place.
It is like you were given a splendid spaceship but all that was required for you to get from one place to another was a damn bicycle.
I like alternatives.
However, when the situation appears as complicated as a maze, one must consider whether this is the most effective tool.
The Myth of Productivity and Obsidian
Photo by Girl with red hat on Unsplash
Obsidian makes you think you're working like crazy.
All those connections and backlinks should help you recall the content quickly.
But let me ask you this: when was the last time that you didn‚Äôt just compile your notes, your fucking notes, but spent more time creating or accomplishing something?
Here's the thing: Regarding productivity, it doesn't mean that every idea is coherent and logical.
It's about getting to the end of the bloody thing.
What about Obsidian? It gives you the impression that doing and organizing are the same thing.
Spoiler: It is not.
The Paradox of Choice
Photo by Letizia Bordoni on Unsplash
Do you know about the paradox of choice?
The concept is straightforward: it is a fact that the more choices are available, the more challenging it is to make a proper decision.
Obsidian is the best example of how this is done.
You discover that you spend more time trying to understand how to use the program than you do using it due to all of the options and possibilities.
It is like going to a 100-dish buffet.
Yes, that sounds great, but then you find yourself paralyzed by the sheer number of alternatives and trapped with your plate full.
By the time you have made your decision, you are too tired to enjoy the food.
The Debilitating Intricacy
Photo by Scott Webb on Unsplash
Not everybody needs to have a digital mind.
The main idea about Obsidian is the ability to link the notes in a way that reflects the structure of your mind.
Isn't it quite catchy?
However, let's not kid ourselves here‚Äîour mind is nothing but random chaos.
When this chaos is replicated in an app, it tends to enhance confusion rather than reduce it.
This transpires: It is always good to start making a few connections because everything works well.
After that, you produce more of it, and, in making more, you inevitably bring into existence something which is not it.
In no time, you are left with this massive network of contacts that is as useful as a bucket of old shoes. You're left with an almost impossible-to-navigate mess instead of clarity.
It is like having a drawer in your home with all sorts of items, and you will struggle to find the damn screwdriver when you need it.
Where Obsidian Falls Short: The Mental Load
One of Obsidian's main problems is the mental strain It puts you under.
It requires you to continually consider the connections between your notes, their placement, and the overall organization of the whole thing.
It is a work in itself, not just a tool.
You're overseeing a whole ecosystem, not just taking notes. This extra layer of thought can make you feel slower instead of faster.
You may discover that you spend more time keeping up with your system than on essential tasks.
That's when you realize something is wrong.
Customization in The Rabbit Hole As hell
Obsidian customization may need to be fixed.
You tell yourself, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just install this one plugin,‚Äù and it all begins innocently.
The next thing you know, you're deep in the forums, searching for the most significant themes, adjusting CSS, and attempting to figure out how to format your notes perfectly.
The worst part is that, despite all of that effort, you aren‚Äôt completing the task at hand. You‚Äôre only playing around with the actual gadget.
Obsidian is a huge distraction if you want to develop anything significant, but it could be fantastic to spend time playing with software.
The False Promise of Linking
The capacity to connect notes is one of Obsidian's main selling features.
By connecting your thoughts, you may build a knowledge network that facilitates concept recall and connections. This principle seems pretty wonderful.
However, in reality? It takes a lot of work.
The issue is that comprehension is only sometimes the result of connecting notes. Even though you may have notes connected left, right, and center, those connections could be more apparent if you review the content.
It would be like having a map without any damn labels ‚Äî sure, it looks good, but it won't help you find your way.
Obsidian isn't for Everyone in Reality
Although Obsidian is touted as a tool for everyone, let's face it ‚Äî that's not the case.
It is intended for an individual who enjoys making small adjustments and is willing to devote hours to setting up.
Obsidian is probably not for you if all you want is to get something done quickly and easily.
What to Use Instead: Simplicity Over Complexity
Now that I've ripped up another Obsidian let's discuss what you need to use in its place.
The response? Ease of use.
To get anything done, you only need a tool that allows you to concentrate on your ideas rather than a thousand features.
Here are several substitutes that won't cause cognitive damage:
1. Google Keep: The Note-Taking App with No Bullshit
Google Keep is similar to Obsidian in reverse.
It is a note-taking tool, nothing more, nothing less. It is easy to use and uncomplicated. Your notes are available to you whenever you need them.
Just plain, unfiltered notes ‚Äî no intricate connecting, no limitless customization.
When you need to rapidly record an idea without getting buried in the details, Google Keep is ideal.
Like a portable, digital Post-it note, Google Keep can be accessed from any location. It is like a fresh, blank piece of paper compared to Obsidian's messy workspace.
How "Google Keep" Keeps Me on Track
9 Ultimate Features To Hook Anyone.
medium.com
2. Notion: The One-Stop Shop
Notion is your best option if you need something more robust but easy to use.
In contrast to Obsidian, Notion has an easy-to-use interface that requires no computer science degree. It integrates databases, tasks, notes, and more into a single platform.
Notion is fantastic since it allows you to construct what you need without being overwhelmed by choices.
I Gave Up on Canva Templates for Notion Sales
You won't believe what I found.
medium.com
For your notes, you may make simple pages or go more fancy with databases and task management.
The finest aspect?
You don't need to adjust it constantly. Once you've set everything up, you're ready to go.
3. Apple Notes: The Apple Fan's Best Friend
Apple Notes is suitable if you work in an Apple-oriented environment and use other applications of the company's products.
It is available on all your devices, is user-friendly, and is accurate.
It is easy to use; you do not have to go through tutorials and other procedures; you are ready to go as soon as you begin typing.
Apple Notes is perfect for those who constantly need something in sync, easily accessible, and not a pain in the neck.
It doesn't have all of Obsidian's features, but for what it does, it does it without all the fluff.
Top 10 Features of Apple Notes You Cannot Ignore

4. OneNote by Microsoft
The workhorse was designed to provide efficient transportation to people not interested in the fancy cars produced then.
Microsoft OneNote is like an old reliable friend who is always around. It has been around for a very long time because it does its work effectively.
OneNote offers a satisfactory note-taking environment that does not become as monotonous and complex as Obsidian.
It is possible to organize the notes in sections, pages, and notebooks with the help of OneNote.
It is great for working professionals, students, and anyone in between who wishes to keep their cool without losing their marbles.
5. Simplenote: The Minimalist's Dream
Simplenote is your best option if you long for simplicity. It is capable of doing one task well: taking notes.
There's no experimenting, no plugins, and no fancy formatting. You only need to write.
That's all.
It is lightweight, quick, and free of extra features, fulfilling the minimalist's ideal.
This illustrates an elementary lesson: avoid making things too complicated.
Although Obsidian may seem like a sparkling toy, most people find it more hassle than worth.
Stick with non-obtrusive tools if you want to get anything done.
Your brain functions best when it is clear, simple, and focused ‚Äî not when it is overloaded with connections.
So stop using too sophisticated tools and stick to those that assist you in completing the task.

A Quirky Billionaire‚Äôs Unmissable Warning About the Stock Market‚Äôs Future.
He‚Äôs spotting what everyone else is missing.
Jayden Levitt
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑

¬∑

Image credit Micahel Burry YouTube.
The world holds its breath every time Michael Burry makes a power move.
The renowned investor and hedge fund manager has faced adversity from the start, losing his left eye to a rare form of cancer at just two years old.
At 37 ‚Äî the same age I am now ‚Äî Burry shot to fame during the 2008 housing crisis, making $725 million for investors in his firm, Scion Asset Management.
The impact was so profound that Hollywood turned it into a movie, The Big Short.
I‚Äôve lost count of how many times I‚Äôve watched it. What I love about the film, where Christian Bale plays Burry, is how it simplifies a complex subject.
The movie‚Äôs writer, Michael Lewis, explained, ‚ÄúThere were many people who made money out of the 2008 crisis, but I wanted to write about the ones who, if it didn‚Äôt work out, had it all to lose.‚Äù
Burry, indeed, had everything on the line.
The Big Short portrays him as a rare type of person who thrives in chaos and has a monk-like approach to managing risk. His bet against the booming housing market seemed destined to fail ‚Äî at first.
My favourite scene is when Burry, barefoot and blasting the heavy metal track ‚ÄúDarkest Hour,‚Äù calmly walks to a whiteboard and writes ‚Äúminus -11.3%‚Äù beside ‚ÄúScion‚Äôs Value‚Äù in bold.
Without a word, he returns to his office, shuts the door, and screams, ‚ÄúFuuuuuuuuck!‚Äù at the top of his lungs.
The crisis took two years to unravel. During that time, investors thought Burry had lost his mind. Even he doubted himself as Scion‚Äôs value dropped while waiting for the market to collapse.
The film dramatises him ignoring furious calls from investors about his $8.4 billion hedge against the housing market ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not far from the truth.
Burry, who is on the autism spectrum, rarely gives interviews. When he does, he admits his confidence in the trade ‚Äúticked off a few people.‚Äù He finds it ironic that despite making them tens of millions of dollars, ‚Äúthey‚Äôre still pretty upset.‚Äù
Now, the man who saw the 2008 housing crisis coming is making another bold move ‚Äî betting 93% of his fund‚Äôs portfolio against the entire stock market.
Investors see it as a chilling warning: the stock market might be headed for disaster.
The moral dilemma behind Michael Burry‚Äôs success.
After countless articles and over 65 hours of research on Michael Burry, one thing is clear: his expertise lies in short-selling.
At its core, short-selling involves betting against the market, and while the concept seems simple, it‚Äôs a bit of a moral grey area.
Here‚Äôs how it works: Imagine borrowing a toy from a friend (representing a stock). You sell the borrowed toy for $100 at its current value. Later, when the toy‚Äôs value drops to $80, you buy it back, return it to your friend, and pocket the $20 difference.
That‚Äôs essentially what Burry does with stocks, minus some fees.
But here‚Äôs the moral rub: making money by betting on something to fail doesn‚Äôt sit well with everyone.
The darker side of short-selling is one reason some of Burry‚Äôs investors stopped speaking to him. They reportedly questioned who was on the losing side of his trades.
Even Michael Lewis, the writer of The Big Short, pointed out the ethical quandary:
If Burry made $100 million when the subprime mortgage bonds he shorted defaulted, that meant someone else lost $100 million.
And that ‚Äúsomeone‚Äù wasn‚Äôt just a number on a balance sheet ‚Äî they were people losing their homes.
Yet, Burry‚Äôs knack for being right, even if it takes time, is undeniable.
More recently, his bets against Elon Musk‚Äôs Tesla and Cathie Wood‚Äôs Ark Innovation proved he‚Äôs far more than just Christian Bale‚Äôs doppelg√§nger.
Burry purchased 2,355 ‚Äúput contracts‚Äù against Ark Innovation, effectively betting the fund‚Äôs value would drop. His hunch paid off, with Ark Innovation‚Äôs stock price plunging by as much as 80% from its all-time highs.
While it was a massive win for Burry, it was a devastating blow for Cathie Wood and her investors.
Burry‚Äôs success comes with undeniable brilliance, but it also raises uncomfortable questions about the ethical cost of profiting from someone else‚Äôs losses.
Source ‚Äî Yahoo Finance
AI hype is walking to the tip of an icy ledge.
Despite this, markets are rallying ‚Äî not everyone is convinced the worst is behind us.
Cathie Wood is among the skeptics.
While the stock market has shown signs of recovery, she warns it‚Äôs narrowing dangerously, like walking toward the tip of an icy ledge. Only a handful of stocks are driving growth, and much of that is fueled by AI hype.
Cathie Wood ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúThere‚Äôll be a harder landing in the economy than most expect. The equity market has narrowed to just a few stocks, with mega-cap tech stocks accounting for 75% of the market‚Äôs move.
Narrowing tends to be, if sustained, very negative. It means we‚Äôre setting up for a bear market. We‚Äôre going into a harder landing than most expect.
It‚Äôll be uncomfortable enough for companies that are losing pricing power and experiencing margin pressure, forcing them to adopt these new technologies faster than otherwise would be the case.‚Äù
A closer look at the S&P 500 reveals the truth behind her warning: eight of the top 10 companies in the index are tech giants, and together, they account for 30.84% of the entire market‚Äôs value.
The data speaks for itself ‚Äî tech stocks, particularly those hyping AI, are driving the market, creating a widening gap between their performance and other sectors. Check the chart below to see just how stark the difference is.
Source ‚Äî www.investopedia.com
Something worse is on the horizon
While some worry the AI hype will fade, Michael Burry believes there‚Äôs a far bigger storm brewing: the return of inflation.
If inflation rises again, it could spell disaster. With current rates still at 2.6% ‚Äî no below the long-term average of 3.38%.
Michael Burry ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúInflation appears in spikes. When the spike resolves, it won‚Äôt be because of Biden or Powell. It will be because that is the essence, the nature of inflation. It resolves, fools people, and then comes back.
When it comes back, neither the POTUS nor the Fed will take credit.‚Äù
The $1.6 billion bet
Burry isn‚Äôt just talking ‚Äî he‚Äôs making headlines with a massive bet against the stock market.
His Scion Asset Management fund recently bought $866 million in ‚Äúput options‚Äù against the S&P 500 and $739 million in ‚Äúput options‚Äù against a fund tracking the Nasdaq 100. Combined, these bearish bets account for 93% of his portfolio.
To outsiders, this might seem outrageous, but Burry‚Äôs track record says otherwise.
If you‚Äôd followed his SEC filings over the past three years ‚Äî tracking every stock he bought or shorted ‚Äî you‚Äôd have generated an annualised total return of 38.4%.
For context, the S&P 500 ETF (SPY) delivered just 9.3% annualised returns in the same period.
Check out the 13F SEC filing below to see the scale of Burry‚Äôs $1.6 billion position.
Source ‚Äî SEC.GOV
Not everyone agrees.
While Michael Burry predicts doom, macroeconomic expert Raoul Pal takes a different view. After years of studying his work, I can see why. Pal believes the stock market is sensitive to M2 money supply.
Now financial conditions are improving we‚Äôll see a rise in assett prices.
According to his indicators, including the ISM (Institute for Supply Management) index, the business cycle is poised to shift. He predicts we‚Äôll enter what he calls the ‚Äúbanana zone‚Äù sometime during the Trump innaugauriton.
This is where prices go wild.
As Pal explains, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs simple: when there‚Äôs more money in circulation, the stock market goes up.‚Äù
He backs this up with data: when you overlay the S&P 500 with M2 money supply (all the money in circulation), they mirror each other almost perfectly.
Raoul Pal:
‚ÄúWhen liquidity changes, everything changes.‚Äù
Pal believes the chances of further catastrophic failure are slim. Why? Because the conditions for increased liquidity are already lining up.
Raoul Pal ‚Äî Source
‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm right in what I‚Äôve laid out, the economy is slow right now. We‚Äôre in a recession. It‚Äôll recover next year, and we‚Äôll be in the sweet spot where the economy is recovering, and earnings are coming back.
Earnings are coming back, inflation is falling, and unemployment is rising. That leaves the Central Bank injecting liquidity in an election year where the government will stimulate, creating a powerful boost for the markets.‚Äù
Final thoughts
As one YouTuber joked, Michael Burry has ‚Äúpredicted 60 of the last three recessions.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a funny quip, but it also underscores the reality: no one knows for sure what‚Äôs coming.
This is all calculated guesswork.
Personally, I think the worst is behind us. With excess pandemic savings dwindling, inflationary pressures are easing, and the economy is starting to stabilise.
The Federal Reserve Chair, Jerome Powell, has already signalled his intent to not reduce rates any lower than he needs to.
That plays directly into Burry‚Äôs thesis.
His recent $1.6 billion short position suggests he‚Äôs betting the stock market is heading for a significant collapse.
And when someone like Burry bets it all, it‚Äôs a warning that‚Äôs hard to ignore.

‚ÄúI do work outside of the office. I do work at home. It gives me extra money.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course! Of course! Everyone needs extra money, no?‚Äù

Administrative work during the day / Professional work in the evening

‚ÄúI like it. It brings in happy money! I used the money for weekend travel in the country and sometimes to Athens, Praha, or Sofia. Beautiful, pretty places!‚Äù

‚ÄúAh, nooo. Nooo. I don‚Äôt want to stress, ah. I cannot choose what to do if that is my day job. Even projects I find stupid, I must do. No, no. I do simple admin work. Easy. No stress. I want to choose!‚Äù

Nope. Why would Lucie be?
She is happy with her work and her total compensation.
And here‚Äôs the thing. There are many ways to achieve workplace happiness. So long as you think your path works for you, go ahead. Walk that road, ignore the naysayers, walk happy, and walk far.
Why not?
Remember this.
Your life is yours to live.

9 Must-Know Advanced Uses of Promises
Shawn Kang
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Nov 19, 2024
354
4
Overview
The Promise object represents the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value.
A Promise is always in one of the following states:
Pending: The initial state, neither fulfilled nor rejected.
Fulfilled: The operation completed successfully.
Rejected: The operation failed.
Unlike ‚Äúold-style‚Äù callbacks, using Promises has the following conventions:
Callback functions will not be called until the current event loop completes.
Even if the asynchronous operation completes (successfully or unsuccessfully), callbacks added via then() afterward will still be called.
You can add multiple callbacks by calling then() multiple times, and they will be executed in the order they were added.
The characteristic feature of Promises is chaining.
Usage
Promise.all([])
When all Promise instances in the array succeed, it returns an array of success results in the order they were requested. If any Promise fails, it enters the failure callback.
const p1 = new Promise((resolve) => {
    resolve(1);
});
const p2 = new Promise((resolve) => {
    resolve(1);
});
const p3 = Promise.resolve('ok');

// If all promises succeed, result will be an array of 3 results.
const result = Promise.all([p1, p2, p3]); 
// If one fails, the result is the failed promise's value.
2. Promise.allSettled([])
The execution will not fail; it returns an array corresponding to the status of each Promise instance in the input array.
const p1 = Promise.resolve(1);
const p2 = Promise.reject(-1);
Promise.allSettled([p1, p2]).then(res => {
    console.log(res);
});
// Output: 
/*
   [
    { status: 'fulfilled', value: 1 },
    { status: 'rejected', reason: -1 }
   ] 
*/
3. Promise.any([])
If any Promise in the input array fulfills, the returned instance will become fulfilled and return the value of the first fulfilled promise. If all are rejected, it will become rejected.
const p1 = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    reject(1);
});
const p2 = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    reject(2);
});
const p3 = Promise.resolve("ok");

Promise.any([p1, p2, p3]).then(
    (r) => console.log(r), // Outputs 'ok'
    (e) => console.log(e)
);
4. Promise.race([])
As soon as any Promise in the array changes state, the state of the race method will change accordingly; the value of the first changed Promise will be passed to the race method's callback.
const p1 = new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => {
        resolve(10);
    }, 3000);
});
const p2 = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    setTimeout(() => {
        throw new Error("I encountered an error");
    }, 2000);
});

Promise.race([p1, p2]).then(
    (v) => console.log(v), // Outputs 10
    (e) => console.log(e)
);
Throwing an exception does not change the race state; it is still determined by p1.
Advanced Uses
Here are 9 advanced uses that help developers handle asynchronous operations more efficiently and elegantly.
Concurrency Control
Using Promise.all allows for parallel execution of multiple Promises, but to control the number of simultaneous requests, you can implement a concurrency control function.
const concurrentPromises = (promises, limit) => {
    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        let i = 0;
        let result = [];
        const executor = () => {
            if (i >= promises.length) {
                return resolve(result);
            }
            const promise = promises[i++];
            Promise.resolve(promise)
                .then(value => {
                    result.push(value);
                    if (i < promises.length) {
                        executor();
                    } else {
                        resolve(result);
                    }
                })
                .catch(reject);
        };
        for (let j = 0; j < limit && j < promises.length; j++) {
            executor();
        }
    });
};
2. Promise Timeout
Sometimes, you may want a Promise to automatically reject if it does not resolve within a certain time frame. This can be implemented as follows.
const promiseWithTimeout = (promise, ms) =>
    Promise.race([
        promise,
        new Promise((resolve, reject) =>
            setTimeout(() => reject(new Error('Timeout after ' + ms + 'ms')), ms)
        )
    ]);
3. Cancelling Promises
Native JavaScript Promises cannot be cancelled, but you can simulate cancellation by introducing controllable interrupt logic.
const cancellablePromise = promise => {
    let isCanceled = false;
    const wrappedPromise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        promise.then(
            value => (isCanceled ? reject({ isCanceled, value }) : resolve(value)),
            error => (isCanceled ? reject({ isCanceled, error }) : reject(error))
        );
    });
    return {
        promise: wrappedPromise,
        cancel() {
            isCanceled = true;
        }
    };
};
4. Sequential Execution of Promise Array
Sometimes you need to execute a series of Promises in order, ensuring that the previous asynchronous operation completes before starting the next.
const sequencePromises = promises =>
    promises.reduce(
        (prev, next) => prev.then(() => next()),
        Promise.resolve()
    );
5. Retry Logic for Promises
When a Promise is rejected due to temporary errors, you may want to retry its execution.
const retryPromise = (promiseFn, maxAttempts, interval) => {
    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        const attempt = attemptNumber => {
            if (attemptNumber === maxAttempts) {
                reject(new Error('Max attempts reached'));
                return;
            }
            promiseFn().then(resolve).catch(() => {
                setTimeout(() => {
                    attempt(attemptNumber + 1);
                }, interval);
            });
        };
        attempt(0);
    });
};
6. Ensuring a Promise Resolves Only Once
In some cases, you may want to ensure that a Promise resolves only once, even if resolve is called multiple times.
const onceResolvedPromise = executor => {
    let isResolved = false;
    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        executor(
            value => {
                if (!isResolved) {
                    isResolved = true;
                    resolve(value);
                }
            },
            reject
        );
    });
};
7. Using Promises Instead of Callbacks
Promises provide a more standardized and convenient way to handle asynchronous operations by replacing callback functions.
const callbackToPromise = (fn, ...args) => {
    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
        fn(...args, (error, result) => {
            if (error) {
                reject(error);
            } else {
                resolve(result);
            }
        });
    });
};
8. Dynamically Generating a Promise Chain
In some situations, you may need to dynamically create a series of Promise chains based on different conditions.
const tasks = [task1, task2, task3]; // Array of asynchronous tasks

const promiseChain = tasks.reduce((chain, currentTask) => {
    return chain.then(currentTask);
}, Promise.resolve());
9. Using Promises to Implement a Simple Asynchronous Lock
In a multi-threaded environment, you can use Promises to implement a simple asynchronous lock, ensuring that only one task can access shared resources at a time.
let lock = Promise.resolve();

const acquireLock = () => {
    let release;
    const waitLock = new Promise(resolve => {
        release = resolve;
    });
    const tryAcquireLock = lock.then(() => release);
    lock = waitLock;
    return tryAcquireLock;
};
This code creates and resolves Promises continuously, implementing a simple FIFO queue to ensure that only one task can access shared resources. The lock variable represents whether there is a task currently executing, always pointing to the Promise of the task in progress. The acquireLock function requests permission to execute and creates a new Promise to wait for the current task to finish.
Conclusion
Promises are an indispensable part of modern JavaScript asynchronous programming. Mastering their advanced techniques will greatly enhance development efficiency and code quality. With the various methods outlined above, developers can handle complex asynchronous scenarios more confidently and write more readable, elegant, and robust code.

I Drank 3.78 Liters of Water Daily for 30 Days ‚Äî Here‚Äôs What Happened
4 things happened in 4 weeks
Sufyan Maan, M.Eng
¬∑
Follow
Published in
ILLUMINATION
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Dec 9, 2024
2.6K
72
Photo by Daiga Ellaby on Unsplash
Water is the meaning of life.
It‚Äôs often said that staying hydrated is the simplest way to take care of our health, but do we really give it the attention it deserves?
Last year, I jumped on a 30-day journey to drink 3.78 liters (1 gallon) of water daily to see what it would do to my body and mind.
Here‚Äôs a detailed account of what I experienced during this experiment.
Why 3.78 Liters of Water?
According to the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, the recommended daily water intake is:
15.5 cups (3.7 liters) for men.
11.5 cups (2.7 liters) for women.
Despite these guidelines, most people struggle to drink even close to the recommended.
For me, this challenge wasn‚Äôt just about hydration ‚Äî it was about building a habit that could improve my physical and mental health in the long run.
Getting Started
To keep myself on track, I invested in a 1-gallon motivational water bottle.
It had measurements and motivational quotes like:
‚ÄúKeep going‚Äù
and
‚ÄúAlmost there,‚Äù
Which were helpful visual cues throughout the day.
Week 1: The Struggle Begins
The first week was a rollercoaster.
Drinking so much water was harder than I thought.
Physical Effects: I felt like I spent most of my time in the restroom, and nighttime waking up in the middle of deep sleep was particularly challenging.
Mental Effects: I kept reminding myself that more urination was a sign my kidneys were being flushed and cleansed.
Hydration Goal: I barely managed 3 liters for the first few days but reached the full gallon by day 7. Yeah, it's not an easy task.
Week 2: Building Momentum
By week two, my body started adjusting.
Improved Consistency: I managed to hit the 3.78-liter target four times this week.
Changes: My skin began to feel more hydrated, and I experienced fewer cravings, likely because water made me feel full.
Week 3: Hydration
This was the turning point.
Routine: Drinking a gallon became second nature. I didn‚Äôt have to remind myself constantly.
Energy: My workouts felt more productive, and I noticed an overall sense of increased energy throughout the day.
Mood: I felt more cheerful throughout the day, possibly because hydration impacts cognitive functions and mood.
Week 4: A New Habit Is Born
By the final week, I wasn‚Äôt just meeting my hydration goal ‚Äî I was enjoying it.
Productivity: Keeping the water bottle at my desk encouraged me to sip regularly, even during work meetings.
Physical Improvements: My skin looked clearer, and I felt more refreshed.
Out of 30 days, I hit the 3.78-liter goal on 18 days and averaged around 3 liters on the rest. Not perfect, but a significant improvement!
Key Benefits of Drinking 3.78 Liters Daily
Staying hydrated helped me avoid midday energy. It felt like a natural caffeine substitute.
During workouts, I didn‚Äôt feel as tired or dehydrated, which made my sessions more effective.
By the end of the challenge, I noticed fewer breakouts and a brighter complexion.
Regular water intake improved my digestion and reduced bloating.
Challenges and Adjustments
Bathroom Trips: This was the hardest part. However, it lessened as my body adjusted.
Setting alarms and having a dedicated water bottle helped me stay consistent.
By stopping water intake two hours before bed, I reduced the need for midnight bathroom breaks.
Lessons Learned
Hydration Is a Journey: You don‚Äôt need to go from zero to 3.78 liters overnight. Gradually increasing your intake works better.
Quality Matters: I started filtering my water to avoid any potential contaminants.
Listen to Your Body: While hydration is essential, overhydration can be harmful. I learned to find my balance.
Would I Recommend It?
Absolutely!
This challenge made me realize how crucial hydration is for overall health.
While you don‚Äôt have to aim for 3.78 liters specifically, being mindful of your daily water intake can have transformative effects.
Takeaway Tips for Your Hydration Challenge
Invest in a Motivational Water Bottle: Choose one with measurements and time markers.
Set Small Goals: Start with an additional glass per day and gradually increase.
Hydrate Early: Drinking water first thing in the morning gives you a head start.
Track Progress: Use a hydration app or journal to keep yourself accountable.
The concluding thoughts
Hydration isn‚Äôt just about quenching thirst.
It‚Äôs about supporting every system in your body.
This 30-day challenge proved to me that small, consistent changes can lead to big results.
If you‚Äôre looking for an easy, low-cost way to boost your health, start with water.
It might just be the simplest yet most impactful change you make this year.
I‚Äôm building a community of like-minded people, and I‚Äôd love for you to be part of it. Sign up below ‚Äî it‚Äôs free!

Google to Replace C++ with Rust in Android, Rewriting Firmware in Rust is Too Easy?
Dylan Cooper
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Sep 11, 2024
556
11
Google recently rewrote the protected virtual machine firmware within the Android virtualization framework using the Rust programming language. Additionally, Google is encouraging developers involved in firmware projects to actively embrace this memory-safe language.
01 Rust Faces Challenges on Linux but Thrives on Android
In a recent blog post, Android engineers Ivan Lozano and Dominik Maier delved into the technical details of replacing legacy C and C++ code with Rust.
Lozano and Maier explained, ‚ÄúAs you can see, improving security using Rust code is actually quite simple. We even demonstrate how the Rust toolchain handles specific bare-metal targets.‚Äù
For a programming language known for its steep learning curve, describing Rust as ‚Äúsimple‚Äù might seem surprising. Moreover, getting C and C++ developers to adopt Rust‚Äôs perspective presents its own challenges. Just last week, a maintainer of the Rust for Linux project (which aims to incorporate Rust code into the C-based Linux kernel) resigned, citing strong resistance from Linux kernel developers.
Earlier this year, during a heated discussion at a technical conference, a Linux kernel contributor bluntly stated, ‚ÄúNo way, you‚Äôre not forcing all of us to learn Rust.‚Äù
Despite this resistance, Google remains patient and encouraging toward potential supporters. Lozano and Maier pointed out that traditional firmware, often written in memory-unsafe languages like C and C++, lacks advanced security mechanisms. Rust, on the other hand, offers a way to prevent memory safety vulnerabilities ‚Äî such as buffer overflows and use-after-free errors ‚Äî major sources of critical bugs in large codebases.
They emphasized, ‚ÄúRust provides a memory-safe alternative to C and C++ with comparable performance and code size.‚Äù Furthermore, Rust supports interoperability with C code without introducing any additional overhead.
Even the U.S. government has been emphasizing this topic, and with support from leading tech companies and nonprofit projects, they are exploring rewriting critical open-source projects and components using Rust. Last year, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) recommended that software vendors ‚Äúmake it a top priority to ultimately eliminate memory safety vulnerabilities from their product lines.‚Äù
Google has embraced this approach, concluding in March that its Rust developers are twice as productive as its C++ engineers.
Lars Bergstrom, Director of Programming Languages for Android at Google and Chair of the Rust Foundation Board, stated, ‚ÄúWe recognize that Rust plays an incredibly critical role in building secure and reliable software across the stack.‚Äù
‚ÄúAt Google, we are driving the adoption of Rust in platforms like Android and Chromium to reduce memory safety vulnerabilities. We are also committed to working with the Rust ecosystem to support the language‚Äôs growth and provide the necessary resources and training to ensure smooth adoption for developers. This push to bring Rust into embedded and firmware development addresses yet another key security issue in the technology stack.‚Äù
Some have pointed out that Rust‚Äôs smooth progress on Android can be attributed to Lars Bergstrom‚Äôs stance:
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs take a look at his title: Director of Programming Languages for Android at Google and Chair of the Rust Foundation Board. I believe that the adoption of Rust across the Android system might progress more smoothly than in the Linux kernel because he‚Äôs in charge, and has the authority to fire those who refuse to implement the Rust transformation.‚Äù
In the Linux world, Alex Gaynor and Geoffrey Thomas noted at the 2019 Linux Security Summit that about two-thirds of Linux kernel vulnerabilities stem from memory safety issues. Rust could theoretically prevent these problems through its inherently safer application programming interfaces (APIs).
What does Torvalds think of all this? A few years ago, he was in ‚Äúwait-and-see‚Äù mode ‚Äî ‚ÄúI‚Äôm interested in the project, but I believe it‚Äôs being pushed by people who are very enthusiastic about Rust, and I want to see how it works in practice.‚Äù
Torvalds also commented, ‚ÄúPersonally, I‚Äôm not in the ‚Äòpush Rust‚Äô camp, but given its promised benefits and potential to avoid some security issues, I‚Äôm open to it. However, I also know that sometimes promises don‚Äôt materialize.‚Äù
At the end of last year, during the Open Source Summit in Japan hosted by the Linux Foundation, Linus Torvalds and Dirk Hohndel (Verizon‚Äôs head of open source) discussed the use of Rust in the Linux kernel. Torvalds remarked, ‚ÄúRust usage is growing, but we don‚Äôt have any parts of the kernel that truly depend on Rust yet. To me, Rust is technically sound, but more importantly, we as the kernel and developers cannot remain stagnant.‚Äù
Some interpret this as meaning, ‚ÄúLinus personally doesn‚Äôt favor Rust much, but Linux always needs to try new things.‚Äù
On the other hand, some argue, ‚ÄúIf Linus didn‚Äôt fundamentally believe that Rust deserves a place in the kernel, it wouldn‚Äôt have gained support in the kernel.‚Äù
At this year‚Äôs KubeCon, Linus Torvalds and Dirk Hohndel once again discussed the introduction of Rust into Linux. Torvalds expressed disappointment that the pace of Rust‚Äôs adoption had not accelerated as expected, ‚ÄúI was hoping for more progress, but the issue is that many older kernel developers are more accustomed to using C and are less familiar with Rust. They are reluctant to learn a new language that, in some aspects, is quite different from the old ways. As a result, Rust‚Äôs adoption has encountered some resistance.‚Äù
Torvalds also commented, ‚ÄúAnother reason is that Rust‚Äôs own foundation isn‚Äôt entirely solid yet.‚Äù Compared to Lars Bergstrom, Torvalds has always taken a cautious stance toward Rust.
02 Rust‚Äôs Smooth Transition as Android‚Äôs New Default Language
In 2021, Google announced Rust as the default language for new contributions to the Android Open Source Project (AOSP).
Other memory-safe languages used by Google in the Android project include Java and Kotlin, which is compatible with Java. While C and C++ remain dominant in AOSP, Android 13 became the first version where most of the new code was written in memory-safe languages. Just one year after Rust was introduced to AOSP in April 2021, it accounted for about 21% of the new code contributions.
The goal of using Rust in Android‚Äôs new code is to reduce memory-related vulnerabilities. Android 10, released in 2019, had 223 memory safety vulnerabilities, whereas Android 13 saw a significant decrease to 85 known memory safety issues.
In 2022, Android security software engineer Jeffery Vander Stoep highlighted that memory safety vulnerabilities had dropped from 76% to 35% of Android‚Äôs total vulnerabilities. As these vulnerabilities decreased, Google also observed a reduction in critical and remotely exploitable issues.
Vander Stoep noted that this improvement wasn‚Äôt due to a sudden realization by code contributors but rather the adoption of better tools. While Android plans to increase its use of Rust, this doesn‚Äôt mean C and C++ will be entirely phased out in system programming.
In a tweet, Vander Stoep explained, ‚ÄúIf I had to sum up this achievement, it would be in one word: humility. Different teams within Android are consistently focused on the question, ‚ÄòHow can we do better?‚Äô They have the determination to implement system-wide changes.‚Äù
‚ÄúHumility goes both ways. Rust isn‚Äôt a silver bullet. C/C++ will remain the most practical choice in some areas of development for the foreseeable future, and that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe will work over time to reduce this reliance, continue expanding our use of Rust, and keep improving our C/C++ code.‚Äù
Vander Stoep also pointed out that correlation doesn‚Äôt always equal causation, but the percentage of memory safety vulnerabilities is strongly associated with the types of languages used for new code. Google mentioned that security tools like fuzzing have also played a key role in addressing memory safety issues.
‚ÄúWe will continue to invest in tools to improve the security of our C/C++ code. In recent releases, we‚Äôve introduced the Scudo hardened allocator, HWASAN, GWP-ASAN, and KFENCE on production Android devices. We‚Äôve also expanded fuzzing coverage in our existing codebase. These tools help prevent new issues and catch old vulnerabilities in the code. While these tools are crucial for our C/C++ code, they don‚Äôt fully explain the observed shifts in vulnerability trends. Other projects that use these tools haven‚Äôt seen such major structural changes, which leads us to believe that the shift from memory-unsafe to memory-safe languages is a core factor in improving Android‚Äôs security posture.‚Äù
At the time, Android 13 contained 1.5 million lines of Rust code, making up about 21% of all new code contributions (Android itself contains tens of millions of lines of code). Google also reported no memory safety vulnerabilities in Android‚Äôs Rust code.
‚ÄúThis shows that Rust is achieving its intended goal of preventing the most common sources of vulnerabilities in Android. In some Android C/C++ components, such as media, Bluetooth, and NFC, memory vulnerabilities historically exceeded 1/kLOC (one vulnerability per thousand lines of code). Using Rust has likely prevented hundreds of vulnerabilities from reaching production environments,‚Äù Vander Stoep explained.
Within the Android project, Google has used Rust to build user-space hardware abstraction layers (HAL) and to introduce Rust support in an increasing number of trusted applications. Last year, Google announced the reimplementation of Android‚Äôs Binder code in the Linux kernel using Rust. Binder is responsible for tasks like inter-process communication (IPC). Early benchmarks for Rust Binder showed promising results in IPC tests compared to the C version, though further testing is needed under real workloads. At least in IPC throughput benchmarks, the performance difference between Rust and C implementations was around ¬±2%.
Now, Google is deploying Rust further into existing firmware codebases.
According to Google software engineers Ivan Lozano and Dominik Maier, old firmware codebases written in C and C++ could benefit from being ‚Äúdirectly replaced by Rust‚Äù to ensure memory safety in the sensitive lower layers of the operating system.
‚ÄúWe aim to demonstrate that this approach is feasible for firmware, allowing memory safety to be achieved in an efficient and effective way,‚Äù the Android team stated.
‚ÄúFirmware serves as the interface between hardware and higher-level software. Due to the absence of standard software security mechanisms in higher-level software, firmware vulnerabilities can be dangerously exploited by malicious actors,‚Äù Google warned, noting that existing firmware comprises large, legacy codebases written in memory-unsafe languages like C or C++.
‚ÄúSimply writing any new code in Rust will reduce the number of new vulnerabilities and, over time, help reduce existing ones,‚Äù Android engineers suggested, advising developers to replace existing C functionality by writing a thin Rust shim, which would convert between existing C APIs and those expected by Rust codebases.
‚ÄúThe shim acts as a wrapper for the Rust library API, connecting the existing C and Rust APIs. This is a common practice when rewriting or replacing existing libraries with Rust,‚Äù they explained.
