I Became a Better Developer by Doing This One Thing (And It‚Äôs Not Coding)
Breaking Away From ‚ÄòCode-Only‚Äô Mindset for Career Growth
Crafting-Code
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Write A Catalyst
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Jan 2, 2025
287
8
Image Generated by FreePik AI
For years, I thought that the secret to success as a developer was to simply write better code, day in and day out.
But no matter how many frameworks I learned or how many algorithms I mastered, my career didn‚Äôt seem to accelerate the way I expected.
Here‚Äôs the hard truth: writing perfect code isn‚Äôt enough to make you stand out. In fact, it could be holding you back.
You can write the cleanest, most optimized code, but if you‚Äôre stuck in the ‚Äúcoding-only‚Äù mindset, you‚Äôre missing the bigger picture.
It wasn‚Äôt until I took a step back and focused on something else entirely that I saw real growth. And no, it wasn‚Äôt another JavaScript framework or a fancy new tool.
I realized that the key to becoming a better developer wasn‚Äôt about writing more code ‚Äî it was about understanding how to leverage the code you write to solve real-world problems in a way that connects to the people you‚Äôre working with.
Let me show you how making that shift changed my entire perspective, and how it can transform your career too.
The Trap of the ‚ÄúCode-Only‚Äù Mindset
You know the drill. You‚Äôre staring at a screen for hours, writing code that looks sleek and efficient, but there‚Äôs something nagging at you.
Your manager‚Äôs asking for results, your teammates need feedback, and the product‚Äôs deadline is looming.
Yet, despite all the perfect code you‚Äôve written, you still feel like you‚Äôre not making the impact you expected.
I was in this exact situation. I would write this elegant piece of code, say a function like this:
function calculateDiscount(price, discount) {
  return price - (price * discount);
}
It‚Äôs clean. It‚Äôs simple. It does exactly what it‚Äôs supposed to do. But there was a problem: this code was just the tip of the iceberg.
While my technical skills were solid, I wasn‚Äôt asking myself the right questions.
I wasn‚Äôt thinking about how my code fit into the overall business goals, how it impacted the user experience, or how it would be used by the rest of the team.
I was too focused on writing code that worked ‚Äî and not on writing code that made an impact.
The Game-Changer: Shifting Focus Beyond Code
One day, I made a shift that changed everything. Instead of obsessing over perfect code, I started asking a different question: How can my code make the life of my team, my stakeholders, and my users easier?
This realization led me to focus on how my code fit into the bigger picture ‚Äî and that was when I truly began to grow as a developer.
I started thinking less about how clean my functions were and more about how well I could communicate the impact of that code.
Here‚Äôs an example of what happened: I was working on a feature that calculated discounts for customers based on various criteria.
Instead of just writing the code and moving on, I took a moment to think about the business problem it was solving. I asked:
What if the discount logic changes in the future?
How can I make this code more flexible for future changes?
How can I explain this code to a non-technical stakeholder, so they understand its value?
The Real Breakthrough: Moving From Code to Business Value
This shift led me to start creating code that was both functional and adaptable.
But more importantly, it allowed me to communicate the value of that code effectively to non-technical colleagues.
I stopped thinking of myself as ‚Äújust a coder‚Äù and started thinking of myself as a problem solver.
For instance, instead of just writing the calculateDiscount function and moving on, I added comments explaining the purpose behind the code, so the next developer (or a non-technical team member) could quickly understand the logic.
Here‚Äôs how I might refactor the code with that in mind:
/**
 * Calculates the discount for a given price based on the discount rate.
 * This function is designed to be easily modified if discount rules change.
 * 
 * @param {number} price - The original price of the product
 * @param {number} discount - The discount rate (expressed as a decimal, e.g., 0.2 for 20%)
 * @returns {number} - The price after applying the discount
 */
function calculateDiscount(price, discount) {
  // Simple calculation, but flexible for future updates
  return price - (price * discount);
}
This wasn‚Äôt just about writing better code ‚Äî it was about writing code with a purpose and making sure others could understand the purpose behind it.
How This Transformed My Career
So, what did this shift in mindset do for me?
I Became a Better Communicator
By thinking about how my work fit into the larger picture, I started communicating better with non-technical stakeholders. I could explain complex code in simple terms and show how my work contributed to the company‚Äôs goals.
I Became a More Effective Collaborator
Understanding the bigger picture allowed me to collaborate more effectively with other teams. I could see how my code impacted the user experience, the product roadmap, and the business strategy, making me a more valuable team player.
I Started Solving Real Business Problems
By focusing on the problem my code was solving ‚Äî not just the code itself ‚Äî I was able to contribute to the success of the product and the business. This made me feel more connected to the product‚Äôs outcome and more invested in the company‚Äôs success.
I Moved Beyond ‚ÄúCode Monkey‚Äù Status
No longer just a person who writes code, I became a developer who understood the business and could deliver solutions that aligned with business goals. This shift was key in my growth, helping me move into leadership roles and take on more responsibility.
Stop Just Writing Code ‚Äî Start Thinking About Impact
If you‚Äôre stuck in the same cycle I was, it‚Äôs time to break free.
Writing great code is important, but understanding how your work impacts the business and collaborating effectively with your team will make you irreplaceable.
So, next time you‚Äôre writing code, ask yourself:
- How does this solve a real problem?
- How can I communicate this clearly to others?
- How can I make sure this is adaptable for future changes?
This shift in mindset won‚Äôt just make you a better developer ‚Äî it‚Äôll make you a better team member, a better communicator, and a more valuable asset to your company.
And, that‚Äôs the kind of developer every team wants.

I‚Äôm Now Terrified of AI, And You Should Be Too
Reality is hitting home for us all.
Will Lockett
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Predict
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
Oct 25, 2024
12.1K
255
I used to think the AI craze would naturally pass. Maybe cause a little economic trouble when the bubble inevitably burst. But I don‚Äôt think this anymore. Instead, I now see this AI frenzy as a symptom of something far more insidious, detrimental, and disastrous for society. Sound a little hyperbolic? Well, let me explain.
A few weeks ago, The Information revealed that OpenAI was facing potential bankruptcy, as they were set to post a $5 billion loss by the end of the year. Not only that, but their AI development program costs are set to soar from around $3 billion per year to well over $7 billion per year as they try to build larger, more capable models critical to their growth and survival. In short, OpenAI was bleeding out and waiting to die. But, soon after this revelation, OpenAI announced they were looking to raise $6.5 billion in investment, valuing the company at $150 billion, or nearly double what it was valued at the beginning of the year, and that it is attempting to secure $5 billion in credit from banks. If secured, this would only keep OpenAI afloat for another year, at most. To make matters worse, there is plenty of evidence that, even with these funds, OpenAI can‚Äôt manufacture these improved models and can‚Äôt reach profitability (which we will discuss further in a second).
Surely, you‚Äôd think no one would give OpenAI this huge sum of money, right? Wrong! OpenAI just announced they have raised $6.6 billion of investment from Nvidia, Microsoft, Softbank, and Thrive Capital at a valuation of $157 billion and secured $4 billion in unsecured rolling credit from the likes of JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Santander, Wells Fargo, SMBC, UBS, and HSBC.
So, why did some of the largest companies, investment firms, and investment banks pump such a colossal amount of cash into OpenAI? Is it the business opportunity of the century? Or is there something else at play?
Well, let‚Äôs take a look at OpenAI‚Äôs fundamentals and see if this is a good investment opportunity (hint: it‚Äôs absolutely not).
Firstly, as we briefly covered, OpenAI isn‚Äôt profitable. Again, not only were they set to turn a $5 billion operational loss by the end of the year, but their AI development expenditure for the year was around $3 billion. This means that even with their hundreds of millions of users and significantly exceeding every revenue prediction, they are still miles away from turning a profit. But even if they spent zero dollars developing better AI (which the valuation of their company is entirely based on), their current AIs are so damn expensive they would still post a loss per year of several billion dollars.
All in all, OpenAI‚Äôs business fundamentals are absolutely horrific. But if OpenAI has a route to making significantly more money and lowering costs down the line, then there is an argument that despite this shitty balance sheet, they are still worth investing billions of dollars into.
Unfortunately, this simply isn‚Äôt the case.
To begin with, as I covered in this previous article, AI development is hitting seriously diminishing returns. In short, for AI to keep improving at the same rate it has been, the amount of training data, infrastructure, and power usage have to increase exponentially. This means OpenAI and other AI companies are butting up against some serious limitations. But, by far the most prevalent limitation is expenditure, as this means that, for AI to continue developing at the same rate it has been, the cost to develop, build, and maintain AI will grow exponentially!
Now, companies like OpenAI have deep pockets, but not that deep. As a result, AI development is beginning to stagnate. You can see this in their ChatGPT models. From version 1 to 3.5, each version was a monumental leap forward. But the difference from 3.5 to 4, 4 to 4o, and 4o to o1 were minuscule. In fact, many of the changes weren‚Äôt actually improving the performance of the AI but improving the usability of the AI.
This is also why OpenAI is predicted to spend $7 billion per year on AI training; it has to dramatically expand its development just to keep taking tiny incremental steps forward.
And even if OpenAI was able to raise the mind-boggling amount of money required to develop their next-generation AIs, that still doesn‚Äôt solve the problem. Firstly, this will take them even further away from profitability as costs will soar, not shrink. And secondly, they also risk ‚Äúmodel collapse.‚Äù
When you train an AI on AI-generated data, it can rapidly destabilise the model to the point at which it produces nonsensical gibberish. This is because AI-generated content contains tiny, almost indistinguishable trends that human-generated content doesn‚Äôt have. As you train an AI on this content, it progressively gives more weight to these nonsensical trends, and eventually, the entire statistical model the AI is based on collapses.
OpenAI has gathered literally billions of lines of text from the internet to train its ChatGPT models, which, until recently, were a fantastic resource for human-created written content. However, as ChatGPT use has become more prominent, its use online has become more common. Presently, over 13% of Google search results are estimated to be AI-generated, and that figure is only set to grow. However, the vast majority of this AI-generated content isn‚Äôt labelled or obvious. As such, if OpenAI continues to scrape data from the web, it risks catastrophic model collapse.
To prevent this from occurring, OpenAI and other AI companies have turned to high-quality sources, like books or video transcripts. However, these bodies of work have larger corporate publishers and copyright holders to fight back against this.
These AI companies operate in a grey area when it comes to sourcing their training data. They claim they can take this data and train their models on it without permission or payment under ‚Äúfair use.‚Äù This element of copyright law claims a person or entity can use copyrighted material for commentary or if they transform it. However, training an AI on someone‚Äôs data essentially enables the AI to replicate that person‚Äôs work, sometimes exactly, at a near-zero cost, and as such, violates the meaning of copyright law. There is also an argument that using data in this way is ‚Äúunjust enrichment,‚Äù which is a law that stops someone or a corporation from profiteering off your labour or work without compensation. Consequently, some big-hitters like WB and Sony are suing AI companies to either stop using their copyrighted data or pay them millions of dollars for their material. In fact, the entire AI industry is facing an ever-growing mountain of lawsuits stacked against them.
Therefore, there is a decent chance that in a year or two, OpenAI will have to drop the vast majority of the data that powers their models as copyright law is finally wielded against them.
But, even if this didn‚Äôt happen, OpenAI‚Äôs products will never be reliable enough to deliver the unsupervised automation they claim. New data shows that as you train an AI on more data, it becomes better at specific tasks but worse at general tasks. In short, you can‚Äôt solve AI‚Äôs errors or hallucinations with more data. So, even if they did develop these next-gen AIs, they would still require huge amounts of human supervision to do even basic work, completely undermining the core promise that this technology will revolutionise every industry.
Take computer programming. This is meant to be one of the easiest industries for AI to disrupt. Yet it isn‚Äôt really. Sure, these AIs can code ten times quicker than even the fastest programmer. However, the code they do produce is so buggy and full of errors that it takes hundreds of times longer to debug it than it does to debug the human programmers‚Äô work. Overall, the human programmer is actually more efficient and cheaper.
Unless OpenAI can completely eradicate errors, which they and the entire AI industry currently have no way of doing, this will always be a fatal problem with their products and the AI industry as a whole.
So, if that is the case, what is the actual use of AI?
There are numerous cases of AI being advertised as completely automating a job, such as Cruise‚Äôs robotaxis or Amazon‚Äôs checkout-less stores. But these companies have to employ just as many human supervisors as jobs they have replaced to keep an eye on these AIs, and even then the quality of the service is worse, and the overall cost is greater than just hiring humans to do the job in the first place. When you actually get down to nitty-gritty business planning, there are basically zero use cases of AI in which the consumer, business, and AI provider receive a good service and remain profitable.
The companies and banks that have just poured billions of dollars into OpenAI know all of this. They hire some of the best market and technology analysts on the planet specifically to understand these sorts of details. So, why have they invested so heavily in such an obviously sinking ship?
It‚Äôs simple. All of my analysis of OpenAI relies on us living in a meritocracy. But we don‚Äôt. Our capitalist society is leaning more and more toward a monopolistic, power-hungry, plutocratic volumocracy.
They know robotaxis, AI journalists, AI HR bots, AI programmers, and the like do a far worse job than humans and aren‚Äôt profitable, but they don‚Äôt care. They can produce and deliver far more than any human, drowning out the competition by overloading the market with their subpar quality product. This will effectively enable them to secure boundless amounts of market shares by brute force rather than through meritocracy. This will embolden the near-monopolies of big tech and media that these banks and businesses love and are heavily invested in ‚Äî in fact, some of them are near-monopolies like Microsoft.
This is the reality of the AI push. It is caused by the dehumanising, power-hungry, fascistic tendency of our financial sector and near-monopolistic big corporations. They want more power; damn the consequences.
So, they have invested billions of dollars into a technology that removes the little meritocracy that our society and economy have thrived on over the past few centuries. It devalues and dehumanises work by drowning out the competition. This enables the near-monopolies these investors have gigantic stakes in to no longer have to work their arses off to keep offering better services to stay on top. Instead, they can spend their hoards of cash simply drowning out the competition and resting on their laurels. To these investors, it doesn‚Äôt matter that OpenAI isn‚Äôt profitable; it will give them even more power and market control.
In short, AI used in this way effectively mitigates the free-market forces that capitalists claim to love so much and instead creates an unjust consolidation of power.
Meanwhile, it‚Äôs us, the citizens of the world, who suffer. Our jobs are taken away or devalued, investment that is needed for more crucial sectors is poured into AI, the products and services we rely on degrade in quality to the point of being nearly useless, and our quality of life goes down.
This isn‚Äôt hyperbole; it‚Äôs already happening. Remember what I said about programmers? Well, thanks to AI, the number of job openings has fallen off a cliff over the past year. Meanwhile, there is a growing chorus of complaints as the quality of coding has dramatically declined during the same period.
This is why I am terrified of AI. It isn‚Äôt a revolutionary technology. It is a symptom of the rot at the core of our modern society. Companies like OpenAI can only exist when the giant corporations that already rule our lives are willing to dehumanise and fatally damage society in order to gain even a morsel more power and control. They want an all-powerful throne, no matter how broken the world is they rule over. Sure, this house of cards will eventually fall when these models collapse or their training data gets pulled. And sure, they will do immeasurable damage to many industries by pushing out talent or erasing skills and knowledge before they get stopped. But they don‚Äôt care as long as they wield that power.
Thanks for reading. Content like this doesn‚Äôt happen without your support. If you want to support content like this, or read articles early, go and follow me and my project Planet Earth & Beyond or follow me on Bluesky or X.

10 Essential VS Code Tips & Tricks For Greater Productivity
Tari Ibaba
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Coding Beauty
¬∑
10 min read
¬∑
Aug 20, 2023
4.1K
35
OpenConvo open in Visual Studio Code.
73%.
Did you know that 73% of developers worldwide depend on the same code editor?
Yes, the 2023 Stack Overflow Developer Survey results are in, and yet again, Visual Studio Code was by far the most used development environment.
‚ÄúVisual Studio Code remains the preferred IDE across all developers, increasing its use among those learning to code compared to professional developers‚Äù, survey.stackoverflow.co/2023
And we all know why: it‚Äôs awesome.
But are we fully exploring its potential? In this article, we unfold some compelling VS Code features that enhance productivity with local source control, animated typing, and rapid line deletion, amongst others. Let us start using them to achieve our coding goals faster than ever.
1. Timeline view: local source control
The Timeline view gives us built-in source control.
Many of us know how useful Git and other source control tools are, helping us easily track file changes and revert back to a previous point when needed.
So the Timeline view in VS Code provides an automatically updated timeline of important events related to a file, such as Git commits, file saves, and test runs.
Expand this view to see a list of snapshot of events related to the current file. Here it‚Äôs file saves, but also Git commits where the file was staged.
Hover over the snapshot item to view the date and time when VS Code made the snapshot.
Select a snapshot item to see a diff view showing the changes between the file at the snapshot time and the file presently.
2. Autosave: no more Ctrl + S
Can you count how many times you‚Äôve used this shortcut? You probably do it unconsciously now.
The Autosave feature automatically saves files as we work on them, removing the need for manual saving. With autosave, we eliminate Ctrl + S fatigue, save time, and gain certainty of always working with the latest changes to the files.
It‚Äôs not perfect though, and it‚Äôs up to you to weigh the pros and cons ‚Äî which we comprehensively cover here.
Stop Autosaving Your Code
This article looks at the pros and cons of autosaving your files and the trade-offs you'll have to make whether you‚Ä¶
codingbeautydev.com
No autosave.
Autosave enabled ‚Äî the unsaved indicator no longer shows.
Use File > Auto Save to enable the feature easily.
3. Do anything with Command Palette
Almost anything you do in VS Code apart from typing is a ‚ÄúCommand‚Äù.
Commands let us accomplish tasks within the editor, and they include file-related commands, navigation commands, editing commands, and terminal commands, each optimally designed to enhance different aspects of your editing experience.
So with Command Palette we simply search for a command and select to perform the associated action.
To open the Command Palette, use this keyboard shortcut:
Windows/Linux: Ctrl + Shift + P
Mac: Shift + Command+ P
As you guessed correctly, those keyboard shortcuts to the right are a faster way to run the commands with the keyboard.
The key benefit of the Command Palette over shortcuts is when there‚Äôs a command without a shortcut, or you‚Äôre looking for a command you‚Äôre not sure exists.
4. Go to file quickly
The mouse is too slow.
Yes, you can click on the file in the Explorer pane, but for a much faster alternative use Ctrl + P to search for and open a specific file in your project.
Hold Ctrl and press Tab to cycle through the list of files currently open in an editor instance.
You can even use Alt + Left and Alt + Right to quickly navigate between these open files.
All these are much faster ways to get to a file than using the cursor.
5. Go to line quickly
Jump, don‚Äôt scroll.
Quickly navigating to a line is invaluable during debugging when you need to encounter errors at specific line numbers. By jumping to those lines, you can examine the code in that particular context, evaluate variables, and troubleshoot the issue.
Use the Ctrl + G keyboard shortcut for this.
6. Delete line quickly
You‚Äôve got to the line now, what if you want to delete it?
Will you drag and drag to highlight and then press Delete? Will you tirelessly press Backspace until every character is gone?
Or, will you use the Ctrl + Shift + K shortcut to rapidly delete that and dozens more lines in a matter of seconds?
7. Enjoy typing with smooth cursor
VS Code has this smooth cursor feature that animates the cursor as it moves, like in MS Word. This makes typing feel more fluid and polished, as well as giving us a smoother and more natural feel as we navigate through the lines of code and place the cursor at different points.
To turn it on, open Settings UI in the Command Palette and search for ‚Äúsmoot caret‚Äù.
We are looking for the Editor: Cursor Smooth Caret Animation setting, which has 3 possible options:
off: No smooth cursor animation
explicit: Only animates the cursor when we explicitly place it somewhere in the code.
on: Smooth cursor animation is always enabled - including when typing.
Set it to on to get the full visual experience.
8. Format code rapidly
Formatting is all about improving code readability by organizing it in a structured and consistent manner.
And if you‚Äôve been doing this manually, you need to know that there‚Äôs a better way.
Yes, you need to start formatting code automatically with the Format Document command, easily accessible in the Command Palette. Depending on the current file's language, a particular "default" formatter will be used to format the code using various rules of indentation, line length, braces and brackets, etc.
While there‚Äôs a pretty decent built-in JS/TS formatter, for a more robust solution, I highly recommend the Prettier extension.
After installing, you‚Äôll set it as your default formatter.
When you use manual over autosave, there‚Äôs a feature you should enable to make formatting a bit easier:
Editor: Format On Save: "Format a file on save. A formatter must be available, the file must not be saved after delay, and the editor must be shutting down". It is disabled by default.
So with this setting on, VS Code will automatically format your code with the current default formatter when you save the file with Ctrl + S, as you saw in the above demo.
When you do autosave, Format On Save doesn‚Äôt work, and it can get tedious to continuously open the Command Palette when you‚Äôre formatting every now and then. And that‚Äôs what keyboard shortcuts are for:
Windows: Shift + Alt + F
Mac: Shift + Option + F
Linux: Ctrl + Shift + I
I‚Äôm on Windows and personally, I don‚Äôt like this default keyboard shortcut; autosave makes me format every now and then, and Shift + Alt + F got agonizing after a while.
So I changed it to Ctrl + D, Ctrl + D - a keyboard shortcut chord that's much easier to press and remember, and has no conflicting keybinding. I recommend you do the same.
9. Save time with multi-cursor editing
One of the wow moments in my earliest VS Code days, the multi-cursor editing lets you place multiple cursors at different points, and delete or insert the same text multiple times. This speeds up editing time and boosts productivity greatly, as we get repetitive tasks done efficiently with rapid code creation.
Of course, when editing, there‚Äôs always at least one cursor. Use Alt + Click to add more.
You can also easily add a cursor directly above or below the current line, with Ctrl + Alt + Down or Ctrl + Alt + Up.
These shortcuts run the Add Cursor Aboveand Add Cursor Belowcommands respectively.
10. Create new folder / file quickly
There‚Äôs no serious project where we don‚Äôt create new folders and files, and if there was a way to accelerate file/folder creation, all the time saved would add up to give us a significant productivity boost.
If you‚Äôve been creating new files and folders in VS Code with the new file and new folder button, then yes, there is a way.
Yeah, you don‚Äôt have to do this.
Instead of constantly moving your mouse to locate those small buttons, did you know you can just double-click on the Explorer panel to create a new file?
How about a new folder? Well, folders are nothing without files, and when you‚Äôre creating a new file, you can easily use the / character to indicate a hierarchy and create new folders and sub-folders to contain that file.
The utils folder is created to contain index.js.
It would be even more efficient to use keyboard shortcuts, which is what I did.
As a former Atom fan, I had quickly gotten used to the A and Shift + A shortcuts for creating new files and folders respectively; I knew what I had to do.
Since A and Shift + A are obviously keys we code with, I included the when values here to make sure they only create a new file/folder when the Explorer pane has focus and there's no active cursor in the current editor.
So to use these shortcuts when typing, you‚Äôll have to focus on the explorer pane first; click on it, or use Ctrl/Command + Shift + E.
Visual Studio Code is more than just a text editor ‚Äî it‚Äôs a powerful tool that, when mastered, can significantly boost your productivity and streamline your coding workflow.
So, keep exploring, keep learning, and remember: the key to efficient coding lies not just in the code itself, but also in the tools you use to write it.
More in this series
Part 2: 10 essential VS Code tips & tricks for greater productivity
Key takeaways
Enable local source control with Timeline view; available in Explorer pane by default.
Autosave files with File > Autosave.
Run commands in Command Palette with Ctrl + Shift + P or Shift + Command + P.
Go to a file with Ctrl + P, navigate between open files with Alt + Left/Right or Ctrl + Tab.
Go to a line with Ctrl + G.
Delete a line with Ctrl + Shift + K .
Enable smooth typing with Editor: Cursor Smooth Caret Animation setting.
Format code with Format Document command, use Prettier, change shortcut to Ctrl + D, Ctrl + D .
Use multiple cursors at once with Alt + Click. Ctrl + Alt + Up/Down adds a cursor above/below.
Move a line up or down with Alt/Option + Up/Down in Windows/Mac.
Create a new file by double-clicking the Explorer pane or set a custom keyboard shortcut. Create a new file in a new folder with ‚Äúfolder/file.ext‚Äù.
Check out the VS Code Key Bindings docs to learn more about keyboard shortcuts and how to customize them. It includes a complete list of all the default VS Code shortcuts in your operating system.

10 Browser Extensions Every Developer Should Be Using
Coders Stop
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Oct 30, 2024
433
4
Developers spend much of their time working within web browsers, whether it‚Äôs testing applications, debugging, or researching. Browser extensions can help streamline these activities by providing powerful tools and insights right from the browser. Here are ten must-have browser extensions that can significantly boost productivity, improve code quality, and simplify daily workflows for developers.
1. Wappalyzer
Purpose: Identify the tech stack of any website.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: Wappalyzer detects the technologies used by websites, from the framework and programming languages to CMS, analytics tools, and even e-commerce platforms. It‚Äôs ideal for developers who want to understand a website‚Äôs tech stack for competitive analysis or curiosity.
Key Features:
Detects over 1,000 technologies, including frameworks, CMS, and e-commerce tools.
Instantly reveals server software, JavaScript libraries, and more.
Compatible with major browsers (Chrome, Firefox, and Edge).
Use Case: Quickly check a client‚Äôs or competitor‚Äôs site tech stack without needing backend access.
2. JSON Formatter
Purpose: Beautify and format JSON data in the browser.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: JSON Formatter makes it easier to read JSON data, which can otherwise be difficult to parse in its raw form. The extension highlights syntax and presents JSON in a collapsible tree structure, allowing you to explore nested objects conveniently.
Key Features:
Highlights syntax for easy readability.
Collapsible tree view for better navigation.
Validates JSON against RFC 4627 and JSONLint standards.
Use Case: Perfect for REST API responses and handling complex JSON data structures.
3. Octotree
Purpose: Enhance GitHub‚Äôs code browsing experience.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: Octotree turns GitHub repositories into a more navigable file tree, making it easier to browse large projects. It‚Äôs particularly useful for quickly finding specific files and folders without endless scrolling.
Key Features:
Displays file trees for GitHub repositories.
Easy access to files and folders without navigating GitHub‚Äôs default layout.
Supports private repositories for GitHub Pro users.
Use Case: Ideal for reviewing codebases, especially large open-source or team projects.
4. React Developer Tools
Purpose: Debug and inspect React applications in real time.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: React Developer Tools allows you to dive deep into React components on any webpage, inspect component hierarchy, props, and state, and visualize how your application updates in real time.
Key Features:
Inspect the component tree and state.
Monitor component renders to identify performance issues.
Supports both React and React Native applications.
Use Case: A go-to extension for React developers to debug complex UIs and troubleshoot state issues quickly.
5. Redux DevTools
Purpose: Debug Redux state changes and actions.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: Redux DevTools provides an intuitive way to monitor changes in the Redux state, allowing developers to trace bugs and errors back to specific actions or state transitions.
Key Features:
Track dispatched actions and state changes.
Time-travel debugging: replay state changes for testing.
Integration with other Redux tools.
Use Case: Perfect for developers working on complex Redux-based applications, helping troubleshoot state issues with ease.
6. Postman Interceptor
Purpose: Manage API requests directly from your browser.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: Postman is a staple for API testing, and Postman Interceptor allows you to capture requests made by your browser and directly send them to the Postman app for testing and analysis.
Key Features:
Intercepts requests and sends them to the Postman app.
Ideal for debugging and simulating API requests.
Supports cookies and headers for detailed testing.
Use Case: Developers working with REST APIs or GraphQL, enabling quick and robust API testing within their workflow.
7. Web Developer
Purpose: Access an extensive toolkit for web debugging.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: This extension is packed with features to assist with testing and debugging front-end code, offering CSS manipulation, cookie management, and more directly from the browser.
Key Features:
View, disable, and edit CSS on the fly.
Resize browser window to test responsiveness.
Manage cookies and local storage.
Use Case: A powerful utility for front-end developers needing to test and tweak layouts or manage cookies without additional tools.
8. WhatFont
Purpose: Identify fonts used on websites.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: WhatFont makes font identification effortless. With a quick hover, you can identify any font used on a webpage, complete with style, size, and weight details.
Key Features:
Hover over text to instantly reveal font details.
Shows font family, size, color, and weight.
Links directly to font providers (like Google Fonts or Typekit).
Use Case: Handy for designers and developers seeking to replicate a particular font style or ensure font consistency.
9. Lighthouse
Purpose: Evaluate a webpage‚Äôs performance, accessibility, SEO, and more.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: Built by Google, Lighthouse is a comprehensive tool that analyzes key metrics affecting site performance and user experience. It‚Äôs invaluable for optimizing website speed, accessibility, and SEO.
Key Features:
Provides insights on performance, accessibility, SEO, and best practices.
Offers detailed reports with actionable improvement tips.
Runs audits for both mobile and desktop.
Use Case: Essential for developers working on website optimization, ensuring sites are high-performing and user-friendly.
10. ColorZilla
Purpose: Capture and analyze color details directly from web pages.
Why It‚Äôs Essential: ColorZilla offers a convenient way to pick colors from any website, generate color palettes, and analyze color properties. It‚Äôs great for replicating design elements and ensuring visual consistency.
Key Features:
Eyedropper tool for picking colors from any element.
Generates CSS color gradients.
Creates custom color palettes and saves frequently used colors.
Use Case: A must-have for UI/UX designers and front-end developers aiming to match brand colors or maintain visual consistency.
Conclusion
The right set of browser extensions can turn your browser into a powerful development environment. From identifying technologies and debugging React components to optimizing performance and managing colors, these ten browser extensions cover a range of essential tasks that can simplify your work, improve productivity, and enhance code quality. Whether you‚Äôre working on web development, API testing, or front-end design, incorporating these extensions into your daily workflow will help you code faster and smarter.

Don‚Äôt Retire in France Unless You Can Handle These 4 Things
It goes beyond the language barrier ‚Äî way beyond.

Win the E-book ‚ÄúWhat I Wish I Knew Before Sitting on a Plane‚Äù for free by subscribing to our list here.
If you enjoy our articles, please clap and comment. That will be a great motivator for me:)
This is the 8th country that most US expats prefer to move to ‚Äî with more than 61,000 American citizens living there, in the list of preferences, this nation is well above heavyweights like Spain or Italy!
Source: Investopedia
I am talking about France
But‚Ä¶
if you‚Äôre not careful, French idiosyncrasies can turn your dream life into an unexpected social and culture shock!
It is a beautiful, sunny place ‚Äî some of the people we talked with describe it as the best in the world ‚Äî as long as you can handle certain things
Today you will discover 4 of them, and also, I will tell you about a little mistake that many Americans do ‚Äî and they don‚Äôt even realize, and if you keep making this mistake, French people might not just dislike you‚Ä¶ they might avoid you altogether.
Ready?
The 1st thing to handle if you plan to retire in France is the French language.
If you‚Äôre coming to France for a short time, and to a large city, it is understandable if you don‚Äôt speak French.
But if you‚Äôre planning to stay longer, learning the local language is really important.
One man, married to a French woman, shared his experience with us:
‚ÄúLived in France with a French wife, from East Asia myself. Not having C1 level French is a huge disadvantage.‚Äù
In Paris, you can get by without speaking French, but it limits how much you can connect with locals.
In France, just 39% of the population speak English, and most of them are concentrated in big cities ‚Äî so if you are planning to move to a small village and you think you can get by just with English, THINK AGAIN.
Not knowing French also makes it harder to make friends or socialize. A French professional who worked with many American expats told us:
‚ÄúI am French and I used to work with thousands of US expats for years moving to Paris. All I can say is learning French should be your top priority. Over the years, the ones who learned the language are the ones who integrated without problems. Especially if you are not in Paris.‚Äù
But don‚Äôt let that frighten you ‚Äî there is a funnier and nicer way to learn a new language. The method I use to learn new languages is this one (by using this link you get a 40% discount after trying for free, and if you subscribe, you‚Äôll get a 40% discount!)
Now, the next thing that you must know how to handle if you live in France will create some polemics in the comment section Because for some, they are abusive, but for others, they are justified.
I mean the numerous strikes and protests in France
And no, the idea that there are a lot of strikes and protests in France is not just a stereotype. It is a fact!
Recommended book: Moving Out, Working Abroad, and Keeping Your Sanity
According to research conducted by the Hans B√∂ckler Foundation, Belgium and France have the highest strike rates in the world.
During an entire decade, Belgium had an average of 97 days lost per 1,000 employees due to strikes, and France came very close in second, with 93 days lost.
To put it into perspective, Spain had 48 days lost, and Germany had only 18 days lost per 1,000 employees due to strikes. So the chances of a worker‚Äôs strike starting on any day in France are over five times higher than in Germany.
The scariest thing is that the sector most affected by strikes is often the most needed, and the absolute champion of strikes is the health and social sector.
In this sector, 42.6% of all companies with more than 200 employees were affected by strikes
In other sectors, like the food industry and the transport industry, 1 in every 5 companies had their activities affected by strikes.
Americans are not used to that. In fact, just a few countries in the world are used to such high numbers of strikes ‚Äî Belgium, France, and maybe Canada.
A worker‚Äôs strike can affect your routine in many ways ‚Äî in the health sector, they are particularly tricky because they can directly affect your well-being.
Strikes in hospitals, clinics, or social services might mean delays in appointments, postponed surgeries, or understaffed emergency rooms.
But even in other sectors, the consequences can be very unpleasant for you.
Imagine you are flying today to attend your son‚Äôs wedding, only to find out that your flight is canceled because air traffic controllers or airline staff have gone on strike.
Of course, often these strikes don‚Äôt come without warning, so when there is even a possibility of a protest or a general paralyzation happening, it is essential for you to have a plan b or even a plan c.
Need to fly but there is a chance the airline staff will go on strike? Try to book an alternative route with a different company. The public transport in your city is going on strike tomorrow? Rent a moped today, and so on ‚Äî but get ready beforehand.
The 3rd thing you need to handle after moving to France is the Healthcare system.
It might look daunting at first, but to know how to navigate it is totally worth it once you get it.
France is world-famous for its healthcare system, ranked among the best globally by the World Health Organization, but for non-EU citizens, getting access to this system isn‚Äôt automatic-you‚Äôve got to put in the legwork.
First, you must secure health coverage before arrival because one of the retirement visa requirements is proof of private health insurance. This isn‚Äôt just any travel insurance; it needs to cover you comprehensively for at least your first year in France.
Make sure it‚Äôs valid across the European Union, because, hey, spontaneous trips to Italy are a thing.
Once you‚Äôve lived in France for three consecutive months, you can apply for PUMA (Protection Universelle Maladie), France‚Äôs universal healthcare system.
This system covers a significant portion of medical costs, usually 70%, and for major procedures, even more.
You‚Äôll need to visit your local CPAM office to start the process and bring your rental agreement, proof of residency, and a translator if your French isn‚Äôt up to par.
After that, you need to get a Carte Vitale, which is your golden ticket to reduced medical costs and streamlined reimbursements. You‚Äôll present it at every doctor‚Äôs appointment or pharmacy visit.
Remember that while PUMA covers a lot, it doesn‚Äôt cover everything. Many French residents, including expats, opt for a supplemental insurance plan called a mutuelle. These plans fill in the gaps, covering co-pays, dental care, and vision.
And here is a tip: Embrace the French Way of Healthcare
Don‚Äôt be surprised if your French doctor spends more time talking to you than typing into a computer. It‚Äôs all part of the charm. And yes, house calls are still a thing in some areas, especially rural France.
But fair warning: appointments can take longer to schedule than in the U.S., so plan ahead for routine care.
Another tip: Have a Backup Pharmacy
Strikes can disrupt not only hospitals but also pharmacies. Always know the location of a backup pharmacy or a pharmacie de garde (on-duty pharmacy), especially if you‚Äôre managing chronic conditions.
Navigating French healthcare may seem like a chore at first, but think of it as learning the ropes for a healthier, happier retirement-because who doesn‚Äôt want to enjoy an extra croissant guilt-free?
The fourth thing you must handle if you plan to retire in France is also quite dramatic.
Recommended book: Budget Travelers, Digital Nomads & Expats: The Ultimate Guide: 50 Tips, Tricks, Hacks, and Ways to Free Stuff & Cheaper
The huge differences between living in large cities or small towns in France
If you‚Äôre planning to retire in France, one of the most important decisions you‚Äôll make is whether to settle in a large metropolis or a quiet town.
Don‚Äôt Retire in France Unless You Can Handle These 4 Things (Americans, Watch This!)
On the surface, this might seem like a choice between excitement and tranquility, but the reality is more complicated -and not always as glamorous as the brochures suggest.
Large cities like Paris, Marseille, and Lyon are cultural hubs, offering plenty of opportunities for socializing, entertainment, and convenience. You‚Äôll find a wide variety of restaurants, theaters, museums, and events at your fingertips.
But living in these larger cities comes with a price ‚Äî literally and figuratively.
Paris is one of the most expensive cities in the world, with the average rent for a one-bedroom apartment in the city center costing an average ‚Ç¨1,886 per month. The costs of dining out, drinking at a local pub, or even having a haircut are much higher when compared to smaller cities.
And then there‚Äôs safety. Larger cities in France have higher crime rates, particularly for pickpocketing and petty theft.
I made an entire video explaining how dangerous some arrondissements of Paris are nowadays ‚Äî some of them have Latin American levels of criminality.
With other large cities is not much better ‚Äî in the ranking of the most dangerous cities in Europe, Marseille is in the top 10.
Check this video here.
One could say that one of the greatest advantages of larger cities is the public transport infrastructure, but remember: the entire system is one strike or protest away from complete chaos.
In contrast, small towns like Sarlat-la-Can√©da in Dordogne or Uz√®s in Occitanie offer a slower, quieter pace of life. There, you‚Äôll find charming markets, friendly neighbors, and a strong sense of community. The cost of living is much lower, with housing prices often a fraction of what you‚Äôd pay in Paris or Lyon.
For example, a countryside home in Provence can cost you less than ‚Ç¨200,000.
But rural living isn‚Äôt all lavender fields and serene sunsets.
Many small towns lack some infrastructure, like hospitals or even large grocery stores.
Public transportation is sparse or non-existent, so owning a car is a must.
While locals in smaller towns are generally more welcoming than their urban counterparts, you must speak decent French.
And even so, you might need to handle the feeling of isolation, at least in the beginning.
The key to choosing between a large city and a smaller town in France is knowing your priorities ‚Äî if you thrive on constant activity and social interaction, a city like Lyon or Bordeaux might suit you. But if you value peace, nature, and affordability, towns like Annecy or L‚ÄôIsle-sur-la-Sorgue could be your place.
So now you know the 4 things Americans must know how to handle if they decide to retire in France.
But remember at the beginning, when I said that I would also warn you of a mistake‚Ä¶ a mistake that many Americans do, without even realizing, and that might make the French avoid, or even dislike them?

How To Build A Web Dev Template Repo
Joshua Saunders
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
Jan 6, 2025
335
7
Back when we saw Valtteri Bottas (the name of my template repo!) at Monza, Italy 2023
One of the most useful things any full stack developer can do is to build a base template repo. This would be a minimal project that includes all your favourite tools and libraries that you‚Äôd want to use in a new project. I think this has two main benefits:
It‚Äôs an excellent way to solidify your knowledge of the tools like to/want to use
When you have a new idea for a project, you can quickly use your template repo as a starting point
I know for myself personally, when I have a new idea it‚Äôs a major hurdle to get started. Even though there are so many starter projects out there, I‚Äôd still have to sift through them and pick out which frameworks I want to use. Now that I have a base template repo, I can get a new project fully set up right away.
Being a senior software developer at an agency like Lazer, I may be assigned new projects every 3‚Äì6 months. Having a solid template repo means when I roll onto a new client, I can impress them with a fully set up project very quickly.
So what should include in your base template repo? I‚Äôd recommend the following:
A fun name
Your base project should have a fun name! I wanted to pick a name that made me think ‚Äúfast‚Äù, so I went with Valtteri after the one and only Valtteri Bottas (Formula 1 driver).
Monorepo
I‚Äôd highly recommend exploring using a monorepo for your base template repo. This will allow you to have a single repository that contains all your projects, and you can easily share code between them. I‚Äôve got a few reasons why I really like them, but here are my top three:
1. Better AI context
In the year of AI, this means that your AI tools can see your whole project at once. If you keep your various parts of your project in separate repositories, if you use AI in your frontend, you‚Äôll have to manually copy and paste code from your backend for it to have context.
2. More manageable CI/CD pipeline
Having a single repository means it‚Äôs more straightforward to create a CI/CD pipeline that will handle your whole project in one commit rather than coordinating between multiple repositories.
3. Shared dependencies
You can easily share and update dependencies between your projects without having to resort to linking packages or private packages.
I spent the last year or so using Nx as my monorepo of choice, but I‚Äôve recently switched to Turborepo. I‚Äôve heard good things about pnpm workspaces as well, but I‚Äôve yet to try it out.
Your foundational frontend/backend/fullstack frameworks
You have a few industry standard options at the moment. Firstly, you could go with a full stack framework like Next.js or Remix. These include both your frontend and backend, and are both great options. I‚Äôd recommend learning one of them if you haven‚Äôt already, if not only to see if you like it and also to be able to throw it on your resume.
If you forego a full stack framework that would include both your frontend and backend, you‚Äôll need to pick a frontend framework and a backend framework. For frontend, I‚Äôd recommend vanilla React, and my personal preference is Node.js using Fastify. You could definitely don‚Äôt have to stay in the JavaScript ecosystem for your backend, but I personally enjoy being able to share code between my frontend and backend.
Once you‚Äôve chosen your framework(s), there will be framework-specific decisions to make, eg. if you‚Äôll be using Next.js for server actions or not. For those decisions, check out the framework‚Äôs documentation.
I would also highly recommend using TypeScript. It‚Äôs industry standard and will make for a much more solid project. Never used TypeScript? Check out my zero to hero article.
Frontend state management
There are many ways to manage state in your frontend. I‚Äôd recommend learning one of the following in this order:
Zustand
MobX
React Context API
If you‚Äôve never heard of Zustand or MobX, they are both observable state libraries. What this means is that they do their best to minimize the amount of re-renders in your application, and also reduce boilerplate for managing state.
I would recommend staying away from older state management libraries like Redux. Feel free to give them a try for the purpose of seeing why they‚Äôre not as popular anymore, but I‚Äôd sticking to the ones above is best.
Backend: GraphQL or REST
If you‚Äôre using a traditional backend framework (eg. not Next.js or Remix), you‚Äôll need to decide if you‚Äôd like to use GraphQL or REST. My personal preference is GraphQL, but I‚Äôve REST is still very relevant. If you want to use GraphQL and you‚Äôve opted to use Fastify as your backend, you‚Äôll be looking at Mercurius for GraphQL. I also like using Pothos for building up the schema.
There are a few additional pieces you should include in the backend of your template repo:
Authentication/authorization (covered later)
Example queries including input validation
Rate limiting
Database
For databases, you‚Äôll need to make a few choices:
Which database to use
Which ORM to use
Where to host your database
For the database, relational databases are still highly relevant to most projects. I‚Äôd recommend PostgreSQL.
When it comes to ORMs, Prisma is fantastic, but Drizzle is also rapidly gaining popularity. I‚Äôd recommend trying both out and seeing which one you like more. I would recommend staying away from older ORMs like Sequelize.
For hosting your database, there are a ton of great options. So far the best free options I‚Äôve found for a development database are Neon and Xata. For a production database, I‚Äôd recommend looking into Google Cloud SQL.
You could also consider using a database that supports document-based data like MongoDB. You could even include both in your base template repo if you want! For myself, I‚Äôve primarily only needed a relational database.
If you don‚Äôt already have a favourite tool for exploring and managing your databases, I like using TablePlus.
Authentication
You‚Äôll need to choose an authentication platform. There are many who also suggest building out your own auth: this is not my view, but if you‚Äôre interested in doing so, I‚Äôd recommend looking into NextAuth.js.
For authentication platforms with generous free tiers, I‚Äôd recommend looking into Supabase Auth, Stytch and Logto. One thing to be aware of is that many of these providers cost quite a bit once you exceed their free tier, so mind your usage while you‚Äôre in development. Generally speaking, if you‚Äôre trying to build a paid product, you‚Äôll want to make sure that your pricing model is such that by the time you exceed their free tier, you‚Äôre making enough money to cover the cost.
End-to-end testing
You should 100% have an end-to-end testing suite in your base template repo. Playwright and Cypress are great choices.
Hosting
You‚Äôll need to host a few pieces of your project, and I‚Äôd recommend looking into the following:
Vercel if you‚Äôre using Next.js
Netlify or Vercel for your frontend
Google Cloud Platform for general hosting needs (eg. if you end up needing file storage or other services)
Neon for your development database
Google Cloud SQL for your production database
Vercel is always innovating, but I‚Äôve recently found Netlify to be really great for setting up preview deployments. Vercel also has preview deployments, but I‚Äôve just run into some issues with them.
Other cloud providers like AWS are also great, but I‚Äôve had the best experience with Google Cloud Platform so far.
CI/CD
If you‚Äôve not seen this term before, CI/CD stands for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment. Continuous integration is the process of automatically testing your code changes on each commit, and continuous deployment is the process of automatically deploying your code on each commit.
I‚Äôd recommend checking out the following:
CircleCI
GitHub Actions
CircleCI is my personal favourite: it has an excellent free tier and its paid tiers are also extremely reasonable.
Frontend component library
There are a ton of really fun frontend component libraries out there. I personally have been all in on Mantine, but many really love using Shadcn/UI. While it can be tempting to build out your own, I would start with one of these.
Try picking one that has good accessibility features and theming features. Those two are particularly tricky to implement after you‚Äôve already built out your project.
Sample pages
Your project should also include a few sample pages that you can use as a starting point. These pages should include a few things:
Home page
Login/signup flow
Dashboard page
Profile page
Settings page
404 page
These pages should be styled using your component library and should use your preferred navigation pattern (eg. side nav, top nav, etc.). Your authentication flow should be implemented using your preferred authentication provider.
Building out these pages will help you validate all the patterns you want to use across your stack. For example, in implementing the authenticated dashboard page, you might find that the authentication provider you chose doesn‚Äôt play as nice with your backend as you thought it would. It‚Äôs better to run into these issues in your template repo rather than in a real project.
Secret management
You‚Äôll be using API keys and secrets for your services, and will need to get those into your .env files in a safe way. I've really been loving using Infisical for this.
Error logging
Sentry is the industry standard for error logging. It has a generous free tier and straightforward integration steps, including uploading your source maps as a part of your CI/CD pipeline.
Payment processing and subscription management
If you‚Äôre building out projects, surely you‚Äôll try to make at least one of them a paid product. There‚Äôs a few great options with generous free tiers:
Stripe
ChargeBee
Like with the authentication providers, you‚Äôll want to make sure that your pricing model is such that by the time you exceed free tiers, you‚Äôre making enough money to cover the cost.
You can also skip this step to start off, because it can be a bit of a rabbit hole and is not relevant if you‚Äôre just trying to build up a portfolio of projects, learning, or building open source.
Lint rules
This one‚Äôs pretty easy, but everyone‚Äôs got a preference when it comes to linting. Take some time to look at some configs put together by various companies and see what you like, and modify them as you see fit.
Airbnb‚Äôs config is a great starting point, and I would also highly recommend including Prettier.
Documentation
You should also include a documentation page that explains how to use your base template repo. This should include a quick start guide, descriptions of the required secrets, as well as a reference for all the tools and libraries you‚Äôve included in your project. It could also be helpful to list out why you chose each tool and library, as you may forget some of the details later on.
Sound like a lot?
It is a lot, but consider that you‚Äôll only really do this once! It‚Äôll also save you a ton of time when you want to try out a new framework. For example if you went with Prisma to start, but you‚Äôre curious about Drizzle, you can just swap out the ORM and get your project fully set up again.
Give yourself time to build this out. It‚Äôs easy to go down a rabbit hole in some of these areas, but it‚Äôs all worth it. For myself, I built my first base template repo over the summer of 2023. Now that it‚Äôs been some time, I‚Äôm starting to build out my second one. I expect it‚Äôll still take a month or two, but I‚Äôll also be able to reuse a good chunk of my first one, especially the CI/CD pipeline.
Getting started
Creating a template repository on GitHub is the easiest way to create your template repo. You can follow GitHub‚Äôs guide here.
If you already have a repository that you‚Äôd like to turn into a template, you can do so in the repository settings. Once you have a template respository, it‚Äôs easy to create a new repository from it: just open it up and click ‚ÄúUse this template‚Äù.
Example
I‚Äôm still working on the latest version of my template repo, so rather than sharing that, I‚Äôll share one that was shared with me recently: SaaS Bold.
They offer a minimal set for free, but you can explore their site to see all the various pieces they‚Äôve included in their template repo.
When you‚Äôre done, share what you‚Äôve built if you‚Äôre open to it! I‚Äôd love to see what you end up with.<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
The Famous Camel and Banana Puzzle
Can You Come Up With a Strategy for This Puzzle?
Rajul Saxena
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Puzzle Sphere
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Dec 25, 2024
383
10
Image created by Author using Canva
In the mathematical world, some problems are deceptively simple and are intellectually stimulating to solve. The ‚ÄúCamel and Banana Puzzle‚Äù is one such problem.
This is because the puzzle setup is simple and straightforward. But while solving it, we discover layers of optimization, resource management and strategic planning.
So let me explain to you the setup of the puzzle first.
The Puzzle Setup
This is the classic version of the puzzle:
You have a camel and a plantation farm with 3000 bananas.
You have to transport the bananas to the market across a 1000 km stretch of desert.
The camel can carry up to 1000 bananas at a time.
And the camel eats 1 banana for every kilometre it travels.
Question: What is the maximum number of bananas that can be delivered to the market?
Puzzle Setup ‚Äî Image created by Author
If you want to solve the puzzle yourself, I would recommend that you pause here, grab your notebook and pen, and try to find the solution. üß†ü§î
When ready, scroll down and read the solution provided!
Solution
At first, the problem looks impossible to solve. Because the camel eats the bananas at the same rate as it carries them. If we simply load the bananas on the camel and start walking, the camel will eat all the bananas by the time we reach the market.
Clearly, a better strategy is required.
Breaking Down the Problem
The problem hinges on balancing two main factors ‚Äî
Carrying Capacity of Camel: the camel can only carry 1000 bananas at a time
Banana Consumption Rate: the camel eats 1 banana per km travelled
Now we need a way to somehow balance these two constraints in order to deliver at least some bananas to the market.
The Optimal Strategy
We can break down our path into different stages. The idea is to stockpile bananas at intermediate points and carry them forward in smaller, more efficient batches.
This begs the question, how many intermediate points do we need?
And what about the round trips? How many bananas will be lost in doing those? How to minimize this loss of bananas?
Let's start with the most basic case of moving all the 3000 bananas to just 1km ahead.
Base Case (moving 1 km) ‚Äî Image created by Author
We can see from the image above, that moving all bananas to just 1 km requires 5 trips or we can say the camel consumes 5 bananas/km from point A to C.
Let‚Äôs assume we repeat this process and reach an intermediate point where the bananas left are 2000. Now if we try to move 1 km from this point:
Mileage Improves ‚Äî Image created by Author
From the above image, we can see that our mileage or efficiency has improved. The camel is consuming 3 bananas/km now.
This is because now the total bananas are one less multiple of the maximum carrying capacity. This saves us one to & fro trip.
Earlier from A to C : it was 3000 = 3 * MaxCarryCapacity
Now from C to D: it is 2000 = 2 * MaxCarryCapacity
So, we can say that with every multiple of 1000 or the MaxCarryCapacity, we improve our efficiency and need fewer back trips. This means our intermediate points should be located at intervals of 1000 bananas. (It makes total sense to carry a full load every time in order to avoid unnecessary back trips)
And when the bananas at the intermediate point reach less than or equal to 1000 (MaxCarryCapacity), then the camel does not need to make any back trips at all. It can just keep on moving forward.
Going by the above logic, we can have 2 intermediate points in our journey which means 3 segments in total.
First Segment ‚Äî From A to C
First Segment: A to C (200 km) ‚Äî Image created by Author
The first intermediate point can be calculated by the following equation. Here x is assumed to be the distance travelled by the camel multiplied by the efficiency to have 2000 final bananas from the initial 3000 bananas.
3000 ‚Äì 5x = 2000
=> x = 200 km
So we have point C at 200 km from the beginning and we now have all our bananas (2000 of them) here.
We now look for our next intermediate point.
Second Segment ‚Äî From C to D
Second Segment: C to D (333 km) ‚Äî Image created by Author
Again making the same equation as above, we have:
2000 ‚Äî 3x = 1000
x = 333.33 km
=> x = 333 km [rounding off]
We have taken efficiency as 3 bananas/km here. Also rounding off here, assuming that the camel won‚Äôt eat part banana. And from the image, we see that even fewer round trips are needed this time.
So at point D, we have approximately 1000 bananas now, which is 200 + 333 = 533 km from the beginning.
Final Stretch ‚Äî From D to B
Because the total bananas we have at D are equal to the MaxCarryCapacity, we don‚Äôt need any round trips now. We can directly go to the market loading full capacity on the camel.
Last Segment: D to B (467 km) ‚Äî Image created by Author
At D, we are 533 km from the beginning and 1000 ‚Äî 533 = 467 km away from the market. During this trip, the camel will consume bananas equal to the distance it travelled. So 467 bananas will be consumed by the camel.
This leaves us with 533 bananas that we can supply to the market.
1 Missing Banana?
I know you must be wondering that from in the image above, we have 1001 bananas at point D. Then why have I taken 1000 bananas in my calculation?
The answer is that it is not feasible for us to make a round trip again for just 1 banana. That‚Äôs why we discard it. Or you can consume it :)
This can also be answered in another way. Remember I rounded off the distance 333.33 km to 333 km of point C above. If we assume that the camel can also eat part of a banana, then covering 0.33 km three times during the journey from C to D will equate to 1 banana being consumed by the camel. Then we will have just 1000 bananas at D.
Alternate Approach
Let's deal with a more generalized version of the problem for this approach. We have n bananas, c as the maximum carrying capacity of the camel and d as the distance to travel.
We can think of the problem this way ‚Äî
Assume the camel is going in a straight line. Then we can say:
For the first 0 to c bananas, the camel travels c km @ 1 banana/km.
For next c+1 to 2c bananas, the camel travels c/3 km @ 3 bananas/km.
For next 2c+1 to 3c bananas, the camel travels c/5 km @ 5 bananas/km.
‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶
camel continues to travel until bananas = total given bananas (n) i.e. it consumed all the bananas
So the total distance x, the camel can travel, given it has n bananas in total to consume, can be mathematically given by:
Mathematical Formula for Total Distance (x) ‚Äî Image created by Author
The summation term is when n mod c = 0. Here the camel will carry a full capacity load.
The second term is the mod term when n mod c ‚â† 0. This is when the MaxCarryCapacity is not a multiple of Total Bananas and there will be some leftover bananas.
Because we had variable rates of consumption of bananas for different segments of the path, it was complex to calculate using a formula. What we have done above is that we have reduced the problem to:
Calculate the maximum distance x that the camel can travel given it has n bananas such that the consumption rate is 1 banana/km.
For our case, if we plug in the values n = 3000 and c = 1000, we get
Total Distance (x) = 1000 + 333 + 200 = 1533 km
But in our case, d = 1000 km. So if the camel just travels 1000 km out the the maximum 1533 km it can travel, then it will have some bananas left. Then the bananas left will be equal to the distance left to travel as the consumption rate is 1 banana/km.
Bananas Left = 1533 ‚Äì 1000 = 533
Below is a Python program if you want to play around with the values and test different scenarios yourself.
import math

def compute_max_distance(n, c):
    t = math.floor(n / c)
    summation = sum(c / (2 * k - 1) for k in range(1, t + 1))
    mod_part = (n % c) / (2 * t + 1)
    result = summation + mod_part
    return result

n = 3000  # Total Bananas (n)
c = 1000  # Maximum Carrying Capacity of Camel (c)
d = 1000  # Market Distance

max_distance = compute_max_distance(n, c)
market_bananas = (max_distance - d) if max_distance > d else 0
print(market_bananas)

Can You Make ChatGPT Your Language Tutor?
My formula for learning a language with ChatGPT
Jane Carr
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Language Lab
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Aug 26, 2024
832
14
Image generated by ChatGPT with prompts by the author.
I am currently on a mission to find the best ways to learn languages for free, and I recently experimented with using ChatGPT as a free language tutor. While AI isn‚Äôt as good as getting a real-life tutor, it is a free resource that can be used to improve your language skills.
To begin, I watched a number of YouTube videos about learning a language through an AI chatbot. I discovered that to get anything out of it, you need to know your goals and be able to explain those goals to the AI tool.
After a lot of experimentation with different languages that I am learning, I have developed a formula to help you use AI as your language tutor. I‚Äôll discuss each step, and at the end, I‚Äôll provide you with an easy framework to use yourself.
Note: I used text-based ChatGPT and will be referring to ChatGPT in this article. I am still experimenting with voice-based ChatGPT.
1. Give ChatGPT context
The first thing you need to tell ChatGPT is that it is your language tutor and you can define what you like in a tutor. You also need to provide context on your current level and your language learning goals. I found that providing an overall goal (i.e. intermediate level), as well as specific goals (i.e. complex grammar structures), provided the most tailored experience. If you specifically want to learn conversational, academic, or business language, you should also mention that at the beginning.
2. Define the exercises
Then, you can either ask ChatGPT to determine a list of resources and exercises for you, or you can define the exercises yourself. For languages where I was a beginner, I found that asking ChatGPT for ideas and then tailoring that myself was helpful. However, for Chinese, which is my main focus language, I already knew exactly what exercises I wanted to practice.
If there are specific topics of conversation that you want to practice, this is also the time to mention that. You also need to define each of the exercises. Be as specific or vague as you want. Think about what you would want a ‚Äúgood tutor‚Äù to do for each exercise and provide that information to ChatGPT.
It can also be a good idea to mention the length of the exercises. For example, if reading comprehension is one exercise that you would like to do, you can ask ChatGPT for a certain length of text and a certain number of questions.
3. Define the review process
One benefit to using ChatGPT is that it can easily provide a review or summary of what you have studied. You can define a different summary for each exercise or provide a general review system. Once again, be as specific or vague as you want.
Formula
Copy and paste this formula and enter your specific details to use ChatGPT as your language tutor.
Hello. You are my [target language] tutor. Your goal is to help me practice [target language] in a way that is [language tutor personality]. I am currently a [current language level] level and I want to be able to reach a [target language level] level in [period of time]. I am learning [target language] to [overall goal], so I would like to focus on [type] language. Specifically, I want to improve the following aspects of my [target language] ability:
[first specific goal]
[second specific goal]
As my tutor, I want you to conduct the following exercises. Please ask me to choose an exercise upon the completion of the previous exercise. If you think that other exercises will improve my skills more, please suggest them at the end of an exercise.
[exercise 1] ‚Äî [definition of exercise 1]
[exercise 2] ‚Äî [definition of exercise 2]
At the completion of each exercise, please summarise and review the exercise in the following way:
[review 1] ‚Äî [define review 1]
[review 2] ‚Äî [define review 2]
Example
Here is an example of how I used this formula to ask ChatGPT to be my Chinese tutor:
Hello. You are my Mandarin Chinese tutor. Your goal is to help me practice Mandarin Chinese in a way that is kind and encouraging. I am currently a HSK 3 level and I want to be able to reach a HSK 4 level in 2 months. I am learning Mandarin Chinese to study academic texts, so I would like to focus on academic language. Specifically, I want to improve the following aspects of my Mandarin Chinese ability:
Expand vocabulary
Use more complex grammar structures
Understand academic language
As my tutor, I want you to conduct the following exercises. Please ask me to choose an exercise upon the completion of the previous exercise. If you think that other exercises will improve my skills more, please suggest them at the end of an exercise.
Articles ‚Äî I want you to find or create articles about visual art that are comprehensible for my current level. Please ask me how long I would like the article to be every time I choose this exercise. Please ask me if there is anything I would like to discuss about the article. Once I mention that I am finished discussing the article, please ask me comprehension questions in relation to the article. Please ask me how many questions I would like to be asked and the difficulty of the questions each time.
Conversations ‚Äî I would like to practice the types of conversations that I might have with fellow academic peers or lecturers. These conversations might be about academic topics or general life topics. Please provide me with basic context at the beginning of the conversation. Please let me know how I can better express myself in the most naturally spoken way when I respond to these conversations.
Writing ‚Äî I want to practice writing visual analysis of Chinese paintings. Please provide me with an image of a Chinese painting and prompt me with questions about the painting. I will then write a long-form response and you will mark the response in terms of academic writing, grammar complexity, and unique vocabulary.
At the completion of each exercise, please summarise and review the exercise in the following way:
Errors ‚Äî Please dot point the errors that I made during the exercise. Repeated instances of the same or very similar errors can be combined into one dot point.
New vocabulary ‚Äî Please list the new vocabulary that I learnt during the exercise
Future focus ‚Äî Please suggest what I should focus on in the future based on what I got right and wrong during the exercise.
Some general tips
It‚Äôs okay to completely change your requests if they are not working for you.
You can go off track, just as you would in a classroom. If you don‚Äôt want to get too off track, you can ask ChatGPT to bring you back to the exercises frequently.
The more you use ChatGPT as a language tutor, the better it will get as your language tutor (just like a real person, it will begin to find your particular areas of strength and weakness).
Personally, I have found AI to be a bit scary, but I think it is a wonderful thing to begin to engage with the resources we have available. I have had a lot of fun playing around with ChatGPT as a language tutor. Have you used AI to improve your language skills? What are your thoughts on this method?
As always, thank you for being here, and happy learning!

No, Henry always wants to talk to the latest large language models (LLMs).
This latest escapade into LLMs all started innocently enough, with Henry asking if he could text his friend, Claude.
‚ÄúOh, Aunt Claudine?‚Äù I asked, exuberant if a little confused because he had never mentioned Great Aunt Claudine. Plus, she died eight years ago.
‚ÄúNo! Claude!‚Äù Henry yelled, enraged. ‚ÄúClaude talks to me like a five-year-old! You talk to me like I‚Äôm fwee!‚Äù
