My Boss Laughed at Python‚Ä¶Then I Showed Him This
And Streamlined My Data Analysis Workflow
Builescu Daniel
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Mar 28, 2024
3.7K
41
Photo by Luke Chesser on Unsplash
Picture this: I‚Äôd just walked across that graduation stage, my Master‚Äôs diploma (Data Science & Analyst) burning a hole in my pocket. There is so much theory, algorithms, and the promise of making data dance. Cut to my first day as a data analyst at this small, cozy company ‚Äî the kind with mismatched office chairs and a coffee machine older than me.
My boss, bless his heart, was old-school tech all the way. He hands me a stack of printouts and grins, ‚ÄúWe need insights from this sales data. Welcome aboard!‚Äù Okay, maybe not the tech paradise I envisioned, but I was ready to impress.
Then, I opened the spreadsheet. Dear god, the spreadsheet. It was like a pixelated monster had vomited numbers everywhere. I spent the whole day wrestling with it, my brain aching. All those fancy machine learning models from school? Useless. It was Excel hell, and I was officially in over my head.
Task 1: The Monster Pivot Table
My first week went by in a blur of VLOOKUPs and pivot tables that stretched to the horizon. Then came the beast ‚Äî a report so critical it fueled the entire company‚Äôs strategy. The spreadsheet was a labyrinth ‚Äî tabs referencing color-coded cells with cryptic formulas that no one, not even my predecessor, fully understood.
Updating it was a nightmare. One wrong click could cause the whole fragile structure to collapse. The instructions even had a step that said, and I quote, ‚ÄúHold your breath and pray before hitting refresh.‚Äù
Then, a spark of rebellion hit me. All those Pandas tutorials couldn‚Äôt have been for nothing! I timidly opened a blank script. At first, it was a mess of trial and error. But lines started to come together:
import pandas as pd

data = pd.read_excel('monster_report.xlsx')  
pivot = data.pivot_table(index=['Region', 'Product'], columns='Month', values='Sales', aggfunc='sum')
pivot.to_excel('new_report.xlsx')
It was‚Ä¶simple ‚Äî almost laughably so. I hit run, heart pounding. A new spreadsheet popped up ‚Äî clean, readable, and, most importantly, accurate. The task that took days now took seconds. I might have done a tiny fist pump right there at my desk.
Task 2: Data Cleaning Nightmare
Task number two involved client addresses. You‚Äôd think something like an address would be standardized, right? Wrong. We had ‚Äú123 Main St,‚Äù‚Äù 123 Main Street,‚Äù and even ‚Äú123 Main St. (Apt 402).‚Äù Trying to sort or map this mess was impossible. My eyes glazed over, and I started to question my career choices.
Hours were wasted finding/replacing, fixing capitalization, and removing those pesky apartment numbers. Every time we got a new batch of data, the nightmare started again. Then it hit me ‚Äî this was a textbook case for regular expressions!
Hesitantly, I started crafting a short function:
import re

def clean_address(address):
    pattern = r'\d+\s+(?:[A-Z][a-z]+\s+)+'  # Match street address part
    match = re.search(pattern, address)
    if match:
        return match.group(0).title()  # Return it capitalized 
    else:
        return address  # Leave it as is if no match
It wasn‚Äôt the most elegant code, but it worked. Suddenly, with a few lines, the chaos transformed into a clean, consistent column. The feeling? Pure power. It was like I‚Äôd finally figured out how to speak the secret language of messy data.
Task 3: Visualization Woes
My boss loved his pie charts. Unfortunately, they loved him back with a vengeance. They had flashy colors, 3D effects that made them look like warped pizzas, and labels that overlapped so severely you couldn‚Äôt read anything. Deciphering them was less about insights and more about surviving a visual assault.
Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I respect the classics, but those charts were straight out of the Windows 95 era. One particularly gnarly report required visualizing sales trends across regions. I tried my best to tame Excel‚Äôs chart wizard, but it fought me every step of the way. The result was cluttered and borderline unusable.
Enough was enough. I remembered those clean, beautiful visualizations from my Python tutorials ‚Äî surely I could do better than this. It was time for Matplotlib:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

regions = ['North', 'South', 'East', 'West']
sales_data = [45, 70, 55, 30] 

plt.bar(regions, sales_data)
plt.xlabel('Region')
plt.ylabel('Sales')
plt.title('Regional Sales Performance')
plt.show()
The output was a breath of fresh air. It was a simple bar chart, yes, but readable, with transparent colors and labels. It wasn‚Äôt about fancy effects but about the data finally telling its story. The real win would be showing this to my boss‚Ä¶
The Boss Moment
After a few weeks, I felt bold. I‚Äôd automated a few smaller tasks and cleaned up some horrendous data sets‚Ä¶ baby steps, but it was building confidence. Then came the next Excel monster, and I decided this was my moment. I spent an evening carefully coding my solutions, not just for functionality but to make the output look polished.
I approached my boss the following day, ‚ÄúHey, I think I found a faster way to handle those reports‚Ä¶‚Äù His eyes glazed over slightly at the word ‚Äúfaster.‚Äù It probably envisioned me inventing a new spreadsheet formula.
‚ÄúSee, I used this thing called Python‚Ä¶‚Äù That‚Äôs as far as I got before he chuckled. ‚ÄúLook, I appreciate the initiative, but that coding takes forever. Just stick to Excel; you‚Äôll get the hang of it.‚Äù
Instead of arguing, I asked, ‚ÄúHow about I just‚Ä¶show you? It‚Äôll take two minutes.‚Äù Reluctantly, he agreed. I pulled up my scripts, hit run, and boom ‚Äî clean data, the pivot table practically assembled itself, and professional charts popped onto the screen.
His eyebrows shot up. No, he didn‚Äôt suddenly become a Python convert. But the dismissive attitude was replaced by a ‚Äú‚Ä¶huh, well, maybe there‚Äôs something to this.‚Äù That tiny flicker of possibility was my victory for the day.
Wrap-up
Let me be clear: I didn‚Äôt ditch Excel entirely. It‚Äôs still a powerful tool; sometimes, it‚Äôs the perfect one for the job. But Python became my secret weapon. That feeling when you finally automate a tedious task you‚Äôve been dreading for weeks? Priceless.
Was it all smooth sailing? Heck no. The learning curve was natural ‚Äî hours spent debugging code that wouldn‚Äôt run, wrestling with confusing error messages. But then came those ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moments when things clicked, which kept me hooked. The investment paid off big time ‚Äî the more Python I knew, the more problems I could solve, and the more efficient I became.
To all the other data newbies battling spreadsheets and feeling overwhelmed, you‚Äôre not alone! If a guy who started terrified of code can do it, you can, too. It‚Äôs about finding the tools that make you better at what you do, and sometimes, that tool is Python.
If you‚Äôre curious to learn more about automation, check out Travis, your AI-powered Python tutor. It‚Äôs totally free and a great way to get started.
And hey, if you enjoyed this little story from my life, give this article a few claps and follow me on Medium for more!

|RETRIEVAL-AUGMENTED GENERATION (RAG)| LLMS| RAG ALTERNATIVES|
You Cache Only Once: Cache-Augmented Generation (CAG) Instead Of RAG
Streamlining Knowledge Tasks with Cache-Augmented Generation: A Simpler Alternative to Retrieval-Based Approaches
Salvatore Raieli
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
4 days ago
749
13
image by the author using AI
Large language models (LLMs) have shown great capabilities but also have some limitations: hallucinations and knowledge updates. Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is one such technique that has been used to try to solve these limitations. RAG basically finds information in an external memory and provides it to the LLM before generation. RAG is one of the most popular techniques today, but it is not without its shortcomings: real-time retrieval introduces latency, it is not easy to identify relevant documents, it makes the system more complex, and system tuning must be conducted.
RAG is Dead, Long Live RAG
Is it really true that long-context LLMs are killing the RAG?
levelup.gitconnected.com
A Requiem for the Transformer?
Will be the transformer the model leading us to artificial general intelligence? Or will be replaced?
towardsdatascience.com
Therefore, considering that models can take more text as input (new models can have a much longer context length), this paper suggests preloading the LLM with all relevant documents in advance and precomputing the key-value (KV) cache. This way, no additional document search is needed and time is saved in inference:
This approach eliminates retrieval latency, mitigates retrieval errors, and simplifies system architecture, all while maintaining high-quality responses by ensuring the model processes all relevant context holistically. ‚Äî source
In this article, we discuss the details and why this idea is interesting.
Artificial intelligence is transforming our world, shaping how we live and work. Understanding how it works and its implications has never been more crucial. If you‚Äôre looking for simple, clear explanations of complex AI topics, you‚Äôre in the right place. Hit Follow or subscribe for free to stay updated with my latest stories and insights.
Why do we need the RAG?
LLMs once they have been trained and deployed have their knowledge frozen. Fine-tuning or other techniques can lead to degradation of LLM performance and are expensive (especially for models that have billions of parameters). RAG is an efficient solution because it does not require additional training of an LLM. In short, we augment an LLM with some sort of external memory (a library of documents that are embedded via a model called an embedder). Once the user query arrives, we search our library for the most relevant documents and append them to the query. LLM then receives both the query and the documents to answer it and thus generates a consistent response.
image source: here
Cosine Similarity and Embeddings Are Still in Love?
Cosine similarity is the most used method, but it is really the best?
levelup.gitconnected.com
In the past two years, the amount of text that an LLM can receive as input has grown. So with the advent of long-contexts, it has been suggested that there is no longer a need for RAG. The idea is to provide the entire text as input to the LLM, without the need to put it into an external library. Of course, this means more computation and therefore more cost.
The KV cache was considered to reduce the cost and computational time. In other words, when using an LLM the input is processed, and it goes through a series of attention blocks. For each block, the KV value of that text input is calculated. In simple words: if we reuse that text, why not save the model computation? Does it make sense that each time we recalculate the KV value for the same text?
The authors are convinced that this can replace RAG. The proposed solution, Cache-Augmented Generation (CAG), preloads relevant knowledge directly into the context of LLMs with extended context windows.
Having taken a collection of documents, we calculate the KV cache for all these documents and store it, and then use it during inference. The process is then divided into three steps:
External Knowledge Preloading. A curated collection of documents is preprocessed, after which we give it as input in LLM and obtain a KV cache. This KV cache is saved on a disk and will be used later. In contrast to RAG, the documents are used only once (the model processes them only at this time). Because it then sees them all together, the model has a holistic and more current view of the set of documents, which improves responses.
Inference. During inference (when a user question arrives), the KV cache and question are loaded. LLM then uses this cache to generate answers. In this way, there is no retrieval latency. The authors use a specific prompt so that the model has a unified understanding of both the external knowledge and the user query.
Cache Reset. The KV cache grows during inference (each time we are hanging new tokens, especially if we consider multiple interactions between a user and an LLM). To avoid saturating how much input our LLM can take (context length) we can use truncation as a simple method for resetting the system. In this way, we do not have to conduct cache reinitialization every time.
Comparison of Traditional RAG and our CAG Workflows. image source: here
In the picture, you can see the difference between RAG and CAG. For two user queries, in RAG we have to conduct document retrieval for the first query (Q1) and then for the second query (Q2). The model sees the retrieved documents K1 for Q1 and generates the answer A1, then does the same for the second query. In CAG, on the other hand, an LLM has already seen all the documents in the first step and can directly answer the questions. We hang Q1 first and produce answer A1, remove Q1, and answer with A2. In this way, we are avoiding redundancies because some documents found for Q1 and Q2 are the same.
Is it CAG better than RAG?
The authors use two widely recognized question-answering benchmarks:
Stanford Question Answering Dataset (SQuAD) 1.0. More than 100,000 questions on Wikipedia articles, where the answer is a snippet of text taken from the article.
HotPotQA dataset. More than 100,000 questions and answers require multi-hop reasoning across multiple Wikipedia articles. From these two datasets, the authors created three different sets to experiment with.
image source: here
The authors then used Llama 3.1 8B Instruction model (128K tokens of context length) and used BERTScore to verify that the model adequately answered the questions. They composed their system with two versions of the RAG (one using sparse vectors and the other using dense vectors).
CAG seems to get superior results to the two RAG systems for all experiments (all two datasets). According to the authors, CAG eliminates retrieval errors and benefits from a more holistic view. Therefore, this system appears to be more robust.
image source: here
Given that most of the computation was in the first step, CAG turns out to be faster in inference than RAG.
image source: here
As long-context LLMs evolve, we present a compelling case for rethinking traditional RAG workflows. While our work emphasizes eliminating retrieval latency, there is potential for hybrid approaches that combine preloading with selective retrieval. ‚Äî source
CAG is certainly an interesting approach, with the advantage that we pay the computational cost only at the beginning. Depending on the number of documents this is possible, but if we have a huge library it means we have to conduct retrieval on the cache. The authors are open to the idea that we can combine the two approaches. For example, in the future, we could conduct a search with RAG to retrieve the cache of documents we are interested in, and thus make inference faster.
Although the paper is interesting, the authors have conducted few experiments and do not provide examples of RAG errors. Also, today companies and researchers use much more complex pipelines than RAG so the advantage of CAG may not be maintained (note, that in the article CAG has one or two more BERTscore points than RAG). In fact, reranking and other components dramatically improve the performance of RAG, and the authors do not take that into account. It is not well understood how scalable this system is, especially if we have to load large datasets or conduct continuous knowledge updates.
If you are interested here is the code for CAG.

Nerds, Curdled
Why are modern business tycoons like this?
George Dillard
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Bouncin‚Äô and Behavin‚Äô Blogs
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Jan 12, 2025
4.3K
111
Screenshot from Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs Instagram
Say what you want about the robber barons, but at least they weren‚Äôt weird.
In the previous Gilded Age, men like John D. Rockefeller, Andrew Carnegie, and Cornelius Vanderbilt created immense business empires through often immoral means. They made their employees work in unsafe conditions, used violence to break strikes, and deployed their wealth to purchase political favors. They didn‚Äôt all behave well in their personal lives. But they did seem like adults.
I was thinking about the robber barons the other day when reading about Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs latest announcements about changes at Meta (in which he essentially agreed to a wish list of changes supported by Donald Trump and his supporters). In his announcement video, Zuckerberg sports the new look he‚Äôs been testing out in recent months. No more hoodie and jeans ‚Äî now he‚Äôs got a $900,000 watch, a gold chain, longer hair, and designer T-shirts.
Some see this transformation as Zuckerberg embracing a sophisticated style, but to me, it reads like he‚Äôs Going Through Something. Here‚Äôs a middle-aged man, one of the most wealthy and influential people in the world, dressing like a trust-fund frat boy out for a night at the club. Zuckerberg has, in addition to exploring new frontiers in style, beefed himself up and become fascinated with mixed martial arts. He speculated about fighting Elon Musk and told Joe Rogan that he wants to participate in a UFC bout someday. I‚Äôm not the only one who thinks it‚Äôs not really working:
Jamelle Bouie on Bluesky
It‚Äôs not just Zuck. It seems that all of the world‚Äôs richest, most powerful men are Going Through Something. While Zuckerberg‚Äôs wealth is estimated at $212 billion, he‚Äôs only #3 on the list of the world‚Äôs wealthiest people.
Above him is Jeff Bezos, who has spent the last few years transforming himself from the goofy geek who founded Amazon into a musclebound, workout-obsessed guy who loves to show off his guns. He ditched his seemingly very nice first wife (who has since devoted herself to giving away her wealth to worthy causes rather than buying yachts or building rockets) and started to live a much more ostentatious lifestyle with his new girlfriend. One press report described Bezos‚Äô transformation as ‚Äúthe midlife crisis to end them all.‚Äù
And, of course, the world‚Äôs wealthiest man, Elon Musk (net worth: over $400 billion), has been having a totally normal one over the last few years. The list of his erratic and immature behaviors is too long and too well-known for me to bother listing them here. But let me ask you this ‚Äî could you imagine John D. Rockefeller or Andrew Carnegie asking people to call them ‚ÄúKekius Maximus?‚Äù
So what‚Äôs the deal with these titans of industry? Why can‚Äôt our evil corporate overlords be like the top-hatted robber barons of yore, who were awful human beings but at least seemed like serious adults?
My theory is that this is what happens when nerdy boys get everything they want.
First, let me establish my bona fides. I know what it is to be a nerdy young man. Growing up in the 1980s and ‚Äô90s, I spent all my disposable income on computers and computer games. In middle school, I carried the thickest library books I could find (thanks, Stephen King) to let everyone know how smart I was. I filled out my share of role-playing game character sheets.
As a teacher, I‚Äôve taught generation after generation of bright, nerdy boys. Like I did at a young age, they love to show off their knowledge. Unable to dominate their peers physically or socially, they try to do so intellectually. This usually takes the form of volume and velocity: knowing more stuff and saying it more quickly than anyone else. These are the kids who race to finish a test first because they believe everyone will see them walk to the front of the room to turn it in and say to themselves: ‚ÄúJimmy‚Äôs done already? He must be smart!‚Äù (Pro tip, kids: this is probably not what everyone else is thinking)
There‚Äôs nothing wrong with this, of course. It‚Äôs a phase of development. These boys are just kids, and part of our job as educators and parents is to help them learn that there‚Äôs a difference between knowledge and wisdom, that the person who speaks the fastest and the loudest isn‚Äôt always the one with the most interesting things to say. Most nerdy boys have to grow up, often painfully, and realize that there are a lot of ways to be a smart and valuable person.
What if I had gotten insanely rich and powerful before I had the chance to learn these lessons? More importantly, what if I had come to believe that some of my worst nerdy instincts were the reason for my success?
Sometimes I look at these business tycoons and I wonder whether they‚Äôre stuck. They‚Äôre bright young nerds who never really had to grow up. They still believe that being quick and clever ‚Äî whether or not they‚Äôre wise ‚Äî is what matters.
Now, having become the richest people in the history of the world, they have the resources to indulge their fantasies. They want to go to space, of course ‚Äî a classic nerdy teenage boy fantasy. They openly cite as inspiration the type of science-fiction book that boys devour (but often outgrow in adulthood). They base their ideas about human history (which they now help to shape) on Civilization and the other video games of their youth.
For a while, this was enough, but now they seem to be devoted to making themselves into the cool guys they couldn‚Äôt be in high school. They use their resources to make themselves physically stronger, getting beefier than the bullies who may have tormented them in middle school. They slavishly court the popularity that may have been hard for them to enjoy as young men, with Musk going so far as to buy himself a social network and then tune its algorithm to make everyone listen to him.
It‚Äôs all so disappointingly shallow, like a lot of nerd culture. Erik Hoel has written about how adult nerds seem not to be embracing deeper intellectualism the way previous generations did:
That‚Äôs what some segment of nerds should be doing, metamorphosing from nerd into that more delicate but potent creature, the intellectual, but instead they are drawn to the easy honeypot of modern middlebrow culture because it is too nerdy, too attractive, too omnipresent, to ever leave. A key portion of nerds are supposed to complete a lifecycle and pupate into fancy-pants intellectuals, yet this natural process has been stymied by the very success of nerds in the first place. Looking around me at the rising ‚Äúthought-leaders‚Äù (what a term) of my generation, the millennials, I see mostly either overly-political academics or ex-academics, or, on the other side, anti-intellectual populists. I feel a certain lack, an empty space where a particular kind of person should be ‚Äî all those who used to read comic books but now want to do something more substantial culturally with their minds and their tastes.
These tycoons are proof of Hoel‚Äôs argument; they‚Äôre plenty smart but not that interesting or deep. They indulge in surface-level displays of intellectual prowess and cartoonish fantasies. They literally want to be astronauts or action-movie heroes or ultimate fighters the way a 12-year-old would. They never seem to have learned that depth is more important than speed, that kindness is more important than cleverness, that complexity is usually better than simplicity.
In many ways, they‚Äôre doing exactly what I would have done if I had become fabulously wealthy and powerful as a young nerd before I had to grow up.
It is possible for nerdy young business titans to grow up to be normal adults.
Bill Gates, who for many years exhibited many of the geeky attributes and ruthless business practices that these other guys have, doesn‚Äôt seem to have gone through a very public midlife crisis. In fact, he‚Äôs even found a way to make himself into a reasonably respected philanthropist and civic leader. His philanthropy isn‚Äôt perfect, but I‚Äôll take the sober, serious corporate overlord who takes climate change seriously and spends his money on mosquito nets for malaria-stricken areas over the guys who fantasize about Mars colonies and brag about their prowess at video games any day of the week.
So what happened to Bezos, Zuckerberg, and Musk? Is it the culture of the modern tech industry, where it‚Äôs considered clever to name things after Lord of the Rings and other books that most people read in middle or high school? Is it the internet, which allows wealthy people to bask in the adulation of millions of lonely, stunted fanboys? Is it the general decline of seriousness as an aspirational goal for American adults?
I‚Äôm not entirely sure, but I do know one thing: when I see Zuck in his expensive streetwear, Bezos flexing his biceps among the supermodels, or Elon engaging in late-night ‚Äúedgy‚Äù banter with his online fans, I see through the facade. I understand that they‚Äôre nerds who never really had to grow up and, instead, have curdled into a sort of self-parody.
I wouldn‚Äôt want the fate of the world to be in the hands of my teenage self, and neither would you, had you known me. But I fear that this is exactly what we‚Äôre in for in this age of the Nerd Robber Baron.

LINUX SECURITY 101 BY KARTHICK DKK
The Dangerous Linux Commands You Should Never Run in Production (Seriously, Don‚Äôt Do It)
Commands should be avoided in Production
Karthick Dkk
¬∑
Follow
Published in
devsecops-community
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Oct 10, 2024
1.3K
29
H
ey there! If you‚Äôre managing Linux systems in production, you know things can go from ‚ÄúEverything is awesome!‚Äù to ‚ÄúWhy is everything on fire?!‚Äù real quick with just one wrong command. I‚Äôve been there ‚Äî one accidental keystroke, and boom, chaos.
So, let‚Äôs chat about some Linux commands that you should never, ever run in production, unless you enjoy spending your Friday night restoring backups and explaining to your boss why the website is down. Spoiler alert: You don‚Äôt want that.
Ready? Let‚Äôs dive in ‚Äî and I‚Äôll toss in a few jokes to make it less terrifying.
Master DevOps in 90 Days
Master DevOps in 90 Days: Comprehensive Step-by-Step Course Series
karthidkk123.medium.com
1. rm -rf /
Ah, the infamous ‚Äúself-destruct button‚Äù. This command is the ‚ÄúI want to delete everything, including the operating system, and ruin my life‚Äù button. When you run rm -rf /, it recursively (thanks, -r) and forcefully (thanks, -f) deletes everything from the root directory. So, you‚Äôll be sitting there watching your entire file system disappear faster than your free time on a deadline day.
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
This is like setting your computer on fire ‚Äî except with fewer dramatic flames and more cursing.
It doesn‚Äôt just delete files, it obliterates them without asking, which is why the -f stands for ‚ÄúForget asking questions, just do it.‚Äù
Note: In the latest systems prevent this.
Ubuntu 24:
credits to: Brandon
How to avoid it:
Always double-check your path before running rm.
Use tools like safe-rm that will give you a friendly slap on the wrist if you try something this dangerous.
Fun Fact: There‚Äôs an XKCD comic about this. You‚Äôre basically a meme if you run this by accident.
Top 10 Dangerous Linux Configurations You Must Avoid for Secure Systems (Deep Dive)
Prevent Costly Mistakes: A Deep Dive into Risky Linux Configurations and How to Fix Them
medium.com
2. mkfs (AKA The ‚ÄúOops, I Wiped My Disk‚Äù Command)
The mkfs a command is used to format a disk, which sounds harmless until you realize that formatting in production is like repainting a house while it‚Äôs still on fire‚Äîeverything is gone.
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
Running mkfs on the wrong disk (like the one holding your precious production data) will make you wish you could turn back time.
It erases everything ‚Äî files, partitions, even the part of your soul that trusted your backups.
How to avoid it:
Triple-check the partition you‚Äôre formatting before hitting enter. Use lsblk or fdisk to make sure you‚Äôre targeting the right one.
Pro tip: Don‚Äôt use mkfs in production unless you really like explaining yourself to your team in the post-mortem meeting.
Advanced Linux Commands for DevOps Engineers: Part-1
For a DevOps engineer, understanding advanced Linux commands is crucial for handling complex system administration‚Ä¶
blog.devgenius.io
3. :(){ :|:& };: (The ‚ÄúFork Bomb‚Äù That Crashes Everything)
This is basically a fancy way of saying, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs turn my server into a hot mess by overwhelming it with processes.‚Äù The Fork Bomb creates a cascade of self-replicating processes until your system chokes and dies. Think of it as the Linux version of an office prank, except instead of TP-ing someone‚Äôs cubicle, you‚Äôre crashing the whole system.
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
This command will spawn processes so fast that your CPU will be screaming ‚ÄúNo more!‚Äù and everything will come to a grinding halt.
It‚Äôs funny‚Ä¶ until you realize you just took down production.
How to avoid it:
Put process limits in place with ulimit, so users (and you) can‚Äôt accidentally run commands like this.
Execution :
Execution of fork bomb
After command execution resources are used heavily. after some time it will break your system.
Bonus Joke: ‚ÄúWhy did the Fork Bomb fail? Because it just couldn‚Äôt process the situation!‚Äù
Mastering P1 Incidents: How I Tackled Critical Issues Like a Pro?
How did I Handle P1 issues like Pro?
medium.com
4. dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sda bs=1M
The dd command is super useful for copying data, making bootable drives, and other neat tricks. But when you see it like this‚Äîcopying zeros (/dev/zero) to your main disk (/dev/sda)‚Äîthat‚Äôs a problem. You‚Äôre essentially zeroing out your entire hard drive. This is the digital equivalent of wiping your hard drive with a blank canvas.
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
Running this command on your production system is like saying, ‚ÄúGoodbye, everything. Hello, irrecoverable data loss.‚Äù
It‚Äôs often used to securely wipe drives. So yeah, it‚Äôs very effective, just not the effect you want in production.
How to avoid it:
Always double-check the if= (input file) and of= (output file) parameters in dd.
Practice safe dd‚Äîtest it in a sandbox before even thinking about using it in production.
5. chmod -R 777 /
This command gives everyone ‚Äî yes, everyone ‚Äî full access to every single file on your system. It‚Äôs like leaving your front door wide open with a sign that says, ‚ÄúCome on in, free snacks, take whatever you want!‚Äù Not ideal.
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
Giving world-readable, writable, and executable permissions to everything? That‚Äôs just begging for a security nightmare. Imagine someone sneaking in and editing your system files because you left everything wide open.
How to avoid it:
Never use chmod 777 unless you really understand the consequences. And for the love of all things Linux, don‚Äôt use it recursively (-R).
Joke Break: Why did the sysadmin go to therapy? Because they couldn‚Äôt handle the chmod 777 stress!
6. shutdown -h now
Okay, so you want to shut down your server immediately. Fine. But doing this in production is like flipping the power switch while everyone‚Äôs still working. Data gets lost, services stop, and people (mostly your boss) start asking uncomfortable questions like, ‚ÄúWhy did you do that?‚Äù
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
Running shutdown -h now immediately halts your system without warning, potentially leading to data corruption or unhappy users.
How to avoid it:
Use something like shutdown -h +5 instead, which gives a 5-minute delay. That way, everyone gets a heads-up, and you can say, ‚ÄúHey, I warned you.‚Äù
7. find / -type f -exec rm -f {} \;
This one‚Äôs sneaky. The find command is great for finding files, but combining it with -exec rm -f {} from the root directory (/) means you‚Äôre finding and deleting every file on the system. Yep, every file.
Why it‚Äôs dangerous:
Imagine going file by file and deleting them all. That‚Äôs what you‚Äôre doing here ‚Äî just much faster. It‚Äôs like hiring a personal assistant to burn down your house file by file.
How to avoid it:
Be specific with your paths, and test your find command first with something harmless, like -print seeing what files it‚Äôs targeting.
Advanced Linux Commands for DevOps Engineers: Part-2
Welcome back, fellow terminal warriors! üó°Ô∏è. Advanced Linux Commands for DevOps Engineers: Part-2
blog.devops.dev
8. chmod -x /bin/chmod ‚Äî Breaking Command Execution
Explanation:
The chmod command itself is located in /bin/chmod. Removing its executable permission (-x) means you‚Äôll no longer be able to use it.
Example:
sudo chmod -x /bin/chmod
What Happens:
This effectively locks you out of modifying permissions on your system, including restoring chmod itself. Without chmod, fixing permissions issues becomes a nightmare.
Real-world scenario:
A sysadmin could accidentally remove the executable bit while trying to troubleshoot permissions, leaving them unable to resolve further issues without booting into recovery mode.
Safe Practice:
Never modify the permissions of essential system binaries. If necessary, use aliases to prevent accidental misuse of commands.
In Conclusion: Don‚Äôt Be ‚ÄúThat Guy‚Äù
We‚Äôve all made mistakes, but some mistakes in Linux can turn into horror stories ‚Äî like wiping out production, accidentally crashing your servers, or deleting everything on your hard drive. When in doubt, stop, breathe, and triple-check your commands. And if you‚Äôre feeling unsure, test it in a non-production environment first.
Remember: Linux gives you a lot of power, but with great power comes great responsibility. Or, in this case, with great power comes great potential for catastrophic downtime.
Step-by-Step Guide: Installing Zabbix on Ubuntu for Efficient Infrastructure Monitoring
How to Install Zabbix on Ubuntu? Ultimate Guide for Monitoring
medium.com

9 Python ‚Äúcollections‚Äù Things I Regret Not Knowing Earlier
Liu Zuo Lin
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Nov 30, 2024
372
4
Read Free: https://zlliu.medium.com/9-python-collections-things-i-regret-not-knowing-earlier-21ed463f37fa?sk=d337b7052275c153b40fb537c6fa33e7
1) collections.Counter For Counting
Let‚Äôs say we are given a list of strings, and we need to count the number of occurrences of each string in the list.
Using a dictionary is one basic way we could do this:
But did you know that we can also use collections.Counter to do this?
Using collections.Counter has the following benefits:
no need to deal with dictionary logic
resultant code is very readable
no need to install 3rd party libraries as collections is part of the Python Standard Library
2) collections.OrderedDict
collections.OrderedDict creates a dictionary that guarantees the order in which keys are inserted ‚Äî keys inserted first will come first in an ordered dict.
But doesn‚Äôt normal dictionaries do the same?
Kinda, but normal dictionaries are not built to maintain this order, and thus it might not be guaranteed that its keys are in the order in which they are inserted.
3) collections.defaultdict
I actually see this in production-grade Python code a lot.
A defaultdict is a special kind of dictionary that automatically initializes a default key-value pair if we attempt to use a key that does not exist.
^ notice that we pass in ‚Äúint‚Äù into defaultdict()
defaultdict() should take in a function.
this function should take in no parameters
whatever this function returns IS the default value of the defaultdict
in defaultdict(int), the default value is int() which is just 0
if we attempt to access a non-existent key eg dd[100], a default value is automatically created without us having to deal with this logic.
if we attempt to access an existing key, it behaves like a normal dictionary
Let‚Äôs say we have a list of domains, and want to group them by their top-level-domain eg ‚Äú.com‚Äù or ‚Äú.net‚Äù. Let‚Äôs use a normal dict first.
^ note that we need to deal with the key-value pair creation logic ourselves here.
Now, let‚Äôs use a defaultdict instead.
^ note that after using a defaultdict, we no longer need to manually create a key-value pair if a key does not exist.
In defaultdict(list), the default value is list(), which is an empty list
if we attempt to access a key that does not exist, an empty list is automatically created as the default value
Also, notice that the code is a lot shorter and more readable
Quick Pause

Here I‚Äôve compiled 101 cool Python tricks and facts that many (if not most) do not know about. Check it out if you wish to level up your Python knowledge!
Link: https://payhip.com/b/vywcf
4) collections.namedtuple
I also see lots of named tuples in production-grade Python code.
A named tuple is a special tuple where:
we can access values like normal tuples eg. mytuple[0], mytuple[1]
we can also access values like we would a class eg. mytuple.name mytuple.age
^ here, we‚Äôve created a named tuple Dog:
notice that we can access its values like a normal tuple eg. dog[0], dog[1], dog[2]
we can also access its values like an object eg. dog.name, dog.age, dog.breed
Why we use named tuples in production grade Python code so much?
dog.name is more readable and immediately obvious than dog[0]
but for smaller objects, we don‚Äôt want to deal with the overhead of creating an entire class just for this
as such, named tuples can serve as a balance between readability and convenience in the case
5) collections.deque
A deque is a double ended queue where adding/removing items from both left and right ends take O(1) time.
When we implement queues in Python, a more inexperienced programmer might use the built-in list.
^ notice that adding and removing from the left of our list takes O(n) time instead of O(1) time. Note ‚Äî O(1) is a lot more efficient than O(n)
Next, let‚Äôs use a deque instead.
^ now, notice that all 4 operations take O(1) time.
6) collections.abc
collections.abc is slightly different from collections.
collections.abc contains abstract base classes eg Sequence, Mapping, Hashable etc. We can use these abstract base classes to check whether a class provides particular functionality.
^ notice that the collections & collections.abc modules contain different contents.
7) collections.abc.Sequence
collections.abc.Sequence is a base abstract class for sequences eg. lists, tuples, namedtuples etc. We can verify this using the issubclass() method:
Note ‚Äî collections.abc.Sequence is the exact same as typing.Sequence ‚Äî in fact, the typing module imports Sequence from the collections.abc module.
We often use collections.abc.Sequence in type hints instead of list/tuple/etc. This is because function input parameter type hints are meant to be more general:
if we use list instead of Sequence as the type hint, users might get complaints from their linter or type checker when they use other sequences eg. tuples
if we use Sequence instead of list, users can use other sequences without worry
8) collections.abc.Mapping
collections.abc.Mapping is an abstract base class for maps ie anything that contains mappings eg dictionaries
Note ‚Äî typing.Mapping simply imports from collections.abc.Mapping
Similarly, it is often considered good practice in type hinting to use Mapping instead of dict or DefaultDict.
^ if we use Mapping instead of dict in our type hints, users of this function can use other mappings eg. defaultdict, mappingproxy etc without having to worry that the linter or type checker will complain.
9) Other abstract classes in collections.abc
I probably use collections.abc.Sequence & collections.abc.Mapping the most in production-grade Python code, but I still do see these abstract classes from time to time.
Hashable can be used to check if a value can be hashed. Note ‚Äî only hashable values can be dictionary keys, or added to sets.
Callable can be used to check if an object can be called like we would a function.
And so on and so forth.

You Won‚Äôt Believe What I Discovered About IP Addresses!
I am sure you will learn something new today!
Rahul Sharma
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Oct 4, 2024
2.6K
40
Feature Image Created in Canva
When you first look at an IP address (IPV4), such as 192.168.0.1, it‚Äôs easy to assume the dots are part of the IP address. We know that the definition of an IP address is:
An IP address is a string of numbers separated by periods. IP addresses are expressed as a set of four numbers ‚Äî an example address might be 192.158.1.38. Each number in the set can range from 0 to 255. So, the full IP addressing range goes from 0.0.0.0 to 255.255.255.255.
Source: www.kaspersky.com
As an example, when you see
8.8.8.8, you will comfortably say yes, it‚Äôs an IP that belongs to Google DNS.
But you see this 134744072 You will probably say it‚Äôs a string of numbers and may not be an IP address.
Understanding the Concept
Now, before we move forward and decide on whether this number is a large integer or an IP address, we need to understand that an IPv4 address is just a 32-bit number,
e.g. 00001010000010110000110000001101
To make the IP address space easy for people to use, both a standard number system and the smallest numbers possible had to be used. In terms of the first of these criteria, people think in terms of the Base10 number system, but computers are binary by nature (excluding quantum computing üòÖ ).
It is impossible for most of us to reliably remember the 32-bit address strings of binary numbers that computers and computer networks use to talk to each other.
It should be easier for people to understand any 32-bit string of binary numbers if they were turned into decimal numbers. After all, people are so used to the Base10 number system that it‚Äôs like second nature.
Unfortunately, a 32-bit binary number could turn into a decimal number that is so big that people can‚Äôt really understand it. Think about trying to remember the address of Google DNS: 13,47,44,072.
To fix this, the architects of the internet did something brilliant. They chunked that massive 32-bit number into four smaller parts, or octets, each containing 8 bits.
Here‚Äôs what that would look like:
1000 1000 1000 1000
Each octet is still a binary number, but we don‚Äôt see it that way in everyday life. Instead, each 8-bit chunk is converted into its decimal form (between 0 and 255) and separated by dots: 8.8.8.8
Now, suddenly, that massive 32-bit address is much easier to handle. Instead of one overwhelming string of numbers, we have four smaller, bite-sized chunks.
The dots serve as visual markers that divide these octets. They also help distinguish between class-full networks and network boundaries in subnetting. Without them, we would be staring at a string of numbers that would take forever to decode. They make IP addresses easier for humans to read, write, and remember.
Think of it like trying to remember someone‚Äôs phone number. You don‚Äôt memorise it as 134744072. Instead, you chunk it into sections:
13-47-44-072
The dots do exactly that for IP addresses.
The Million-dollar Question
Now, million-dollar questions: is this number 134744072 an IP? The answer is yes; as I mentioned above, it‚Äôs a 32-bit number that can represent an IP address, and that‚Äôs it. If you give this number to your browser (obviously with a proper context like HTTP), it can read it as an IP address. All devices and routers will also be able to understand it because they all work with 32-bit binary numbers.
How did I come to this number?
To convert an IP address like 8.8.8.8 into a single integer, we treat each octet as a separate value and multiply it by powers of 256 based on its position in the sequence (starting from the left). Here's how it works:
Image used to show the calculation
So, the calculation looks like this:
Image used to show the calculation
The result of this expression is 13474407
This process converts the familiar dotted-decimal format into a single, large integer.
You can try the same in your browser as well!
Image showing the integer as an IP address
Closing Thought
Understanding this concept can help you in various cases. For example, one of the use cases can be Database Storage: Putting IP addresses in databases as integers (like 134744072) instead of strings (like ‚Äú8.8.8.8‚Äù) can help them take up less space. When it comes to storage and retrieval times, integer operations are often faster than string operations.
Another one could be Sorting IP Addresses: To easily sort a list of IP addresses by number, you can convert them to integers first. This is very helpful in situations like checking firewall rules or access control lists (ACLs).
On the other side, this information is what I perceived from various sources, and one of the book references is IP Addressing Fundamentals by Mark A. Sportack, from where I understood that this is also another way of approaching the IPV4. I added my opinions in this, which you may or may not agree with. If you are a network expert, you may have your perfectly acceptable views.
If you found this helpful, don‚Äôt forget to give this article a clap üëè and follow me for more tips and insights! Your support means a lot.<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
Writing Clean and Future Proof Code: Tips I Wish I Knew Earlier
Learn popular software development approaches ‚Äî DRY, KISS, YAGNI, Code Smells, and TDD
Harendra
¬∑
Follow
Published in
With Code Example
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Nov 13, 2024
274
9
With almost 8 years of experience in software development, I have learned a lot about writing clean and future-proof code. A competent developer must write the code with proper guidelines to maintain the code quality. The best practices for writing quality code are as follows:
Writing Clean and Future Proof Code
DRY (Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself)
DRY (Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself)
Accordingly, we have to avoid code duplication by creating the components or functions. It is very hard to maintain the repeated code and fix the bugs; we have to change the code at every place in case of any fix or change. Let‚Äôs understand it with code examples.
Bad Practice (Violating DRY)
function calculateRectangleArea(length, width) {
    const area = length * width;
    console.log("Rectangle Area:", area.toFixed(2));
    return area;
}

function calculateCircleArea(radius) {
    const area = Math.PI * radius * radius;
    console.log("Circle Area:", area.toFixed(2));
    return area;
}

calculateRectangleArea(5, 10); // Rectangle Area: 50.00
calculateCircleArea(7);        // Circle Area: 153.94
Good Practice (Applying DRY)
function formatArea(area) {
    return area.toFixed(2);
}

function calculateRectangleArea(length, width) {
    const area = length * width;
    console.log("Rectangle Area:", formatArea(area));
    return area;
}

function calculateCircleArea(radius) {
    const area = Math.PI * radius * radius;
    console.log("Circle Area:", formatArea(area));
    return area;
}

calculateRectangleArea(5, 10); // Rectangle Area: 50.00
calculateCircleArea(7);        // Circle Area: 153.94
KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid)
KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid)
We need to keep our code as straightforward as possible and avoid complicating things unnecessarily. Simple code is simple to read, maintain, and test.
Bad Practice (Violating KISS)
function isEvenOdd(number) {
    if (number % 2 === 0) {
        return true;
    } else {
        return false;
    }
}

const number = 5;
if (isEvenOdd(number) === true) {
    console.log("The number is even.");
} else {
    console.log("The number is odd.");
}
Good Practice (Applying KISS)
const number = 5;

if (number % 2 === 0) {
    console.log("The number is even.");
} else {
    console.log("The number is odd.");
}
YAGNI (You Aren‚Äôt Gonna Need It)
YAGNI (You Aren‚Äôt Gonna Need It)
According to this, we need to write the code that is required right now. Avoid adding features or functionality that will be needed in the future. This helps to reduce the code and focus on current requirements.
Bad Practice (Violating YAGNI)
// Over-complicated function that fetches multiple details, although we only need the username
function fetchUserProfile(userId, fields = ["username", "email", "address"]) {
    // Mocked API response
    const userData = {
        username: "john_doe",
        email: "john@example.com",
        address: "1234 Elm St."
    };

    let result = {};
    fields.forEach((field) => {
        if (userData[field]) {
            result[field] = userData[field];
        }
    });

    return result;
}

const userProfile = fetchUserProfile(1);
console.log("Username:", userProfile.username); // Expected output: "Username: john_doe"
Good Practice (Applying YAGNI)
function fetchUserName(userId) {
    const userData = {
        username: "john_doe"
    };

    return userData.username;
}

const username = fetchUserName(1);
console.log("Username:", username); // Output: "Username: john_doe"
Code Smells
Code Smells
Code smells are indicators of bad code quality, such as long functions, duplicate code, too many parameters, large classes, etc. Always keep looking for these things to make your code more future-proof and reusable. Although there is no proper guide available for the count from my experience, you can follow the ‚Äî
Function Length ‚Äî 5‚Äì15 lines
Parameter Count ‚Äî 4 or fewer
Class Length ‚Äî 150‚Äì200 lines
Bad Practice (Code Smell: Long Method)
function calculateOrder(customer) {
    // Calculate total
    let total = 0;
    customer.items.forEach(item => {
        total += item.price * item.quantity;
    });

    // Apply discount
    if (customer.isPremium) {
        total *= 0.9; // 10% discount for premium customers
    }

    // Calculate taxes
    const tax = total * 0.08; // assuming 8% tax
    total += tax;

    // Log order details
    console.log(`Order for ${customer.name}:`);
    customer.items.forEach(item => {
        console.log(`- ${item.name} x${item.quantity}: $${item.price * item.quantity}`);
    });
    console.log(`Total after discount and tax: $${total.toFixed(2)}`);

    return total;
}
Good Practice (Refactoring to Eliminate the Code Smell)
function calculateTotal(customer) {
    return customer.items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price * item.quantity, 0);
}

function applyDiscount(total, isPremium) {
    return isPremium ? total * 0.9 : total;
}

function calculateTax(total) {
    const TAX_RATE = 0.08;
    return total * TAX_RATE;
}

function logOrderDetails(customer, total) {
    console.log(`Order for ${customer.name}:`);
    customer.items.forEach(item => {
        console.log(`- ${item.name} x${item.quantity}: $${item.price * item.quantity}`);
    });
    console.log(`Total after discount and tax: $${total.toFixed(2)}`);
}

function calculateOrder(customer) {
    let total = calculateTotal(customer);
    total = applyDiscount(total, customer.isPremium);
    total += calculateTax(total);

    logOrderDetails(customer, total);
    return total;
}
TDD (Test-Driven Development)
TDD (Test-Driven Development)
TDD is a software development approach where you have to write the test before writing the actual code. Behind this approach, the main idea is to define the behavior and expected output of the code in test cases; then we have to write the actual code that can pass those test cases.
Simple Example of TDD
Step 1: Write the Test (Red)
// isEven.test.js
function testIsEven() {
    console.assert(isEven(4) === true, "Test failed: 4 should be even");
    console.assert(isEven(5) === false, "Test failed: 5 should be odd");
}
testIsEven(); // Running this will throw an error because `isEven` is not defined yet.
Step 2: Implement Minimum Code to Pass Test (Green)
function isEven(number) {
    return number % 2 === 0;
}

// Run the test again
testIsEven(); // Test should pass now
Step 3: Refactor if Needed
Thank you for reading this article! If you found it helpful, a clap üëè would be greatly appreciated‚Äîit motivates me to continue writing. If you want to learn more about open-source and full-stack development, follow me on Twitter (X) and Medium.<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
Why I‚Äôm Finally Letting Go of the Repository Pattern
Shifting Focus to Data and Data Flow, Not Ceremony
Rico Fritzsche
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Jan 2, 2025
374
27
Image Credit:gorodenkoff
I remember the times when I was completely sold on the idea of the Repository pattern. I wrote about it, talked about it in meetups, and used it extensively in projects, especially when I was diving deep into Domain-Driven Design (DDD) and layered architectures. The core principle was always the same: keep the domain layer free of data concerns and push data interactions out to dedicated repositories. It sounded great in theory and worked well for a while in practice.
But along the way, I found myself spending more and more time mapping data between different layers ‚Äî database entities to domain objects, domain objects to DTOs, and so on ‚Äî without seeing much real value, especially for typical line-of-business applications. My ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù moment came when I realized how much simpler things could be if I just cut out the middleman, so to speak.
The Overhead Problem
One of the biggest issues I‚Äôve run into with repositories is the sheer overhead. Every small change in a feature would ripple through multiple layers:
Controller or Handler: Receives a request and validates it.
Service: Contains the business logic and calls the repository.
Repository: Transforms the data for the ORM.
ORM/Database: Executes the actual queries.
I‚Äôd have to juggle domain models, entities, DTOs, and sometimes specialized query classes ‚Äî just to store or retrieve some data. For many projects, this was simply overkill. The extra abstraction didn‚Äôt provide proportional benefit, and it slowed development.
When the Repository Pattern Holds You Back
Entity Framework Core, Dapper, Hibernate ‚Äî all these powerful ORMs take care of a lot of the complexity that the Repository pattern once promised to solve. By relying on an ORM directly, we get:
Simple data access.
Built-in tracking and change detection (if needed).
An abstraction that‚Äôs already well-tested and widely used.
In many cases, putting another layer in front of this just multiplies the interfaces and classes we need to maintain.
ORM solutions like Entity Framework already provide rich abstractions for data access, making an additional repository layer feel increasingly redundant. Instead of offering more clarity, it can introduce duplication and added complexity. Moreover, the generic ‚Äúone-size-fits-all‚Äù approach of a repository often fails to align with real business needs. Finally, because the repository pattern is deeply rooted in traditional layered architectures ‚Äî such as Clean Architecture, or Onion Architecture ‚Äî its insistence on strict separation of concerns on a technical perspective can clash with modern, use-case-driven strategies like Vertical Feature Slices. In these scenarios, focusing on domain specificity rather than rigid layering can yield more streamlined, effective solutions.
Layered Architectures and Their Pitfalls
Repositories go hand-in-hand with layered or so called ‚Äúclean‚Äù architectures: you‚Äôve got controllers, services, repositories, and then your database. I used to think this was an absolute best practice ‚Äî everything carefully stacked in horizontal layers:
Controllers
Services
Repositories
Database
It‚Äôs neat in theory, but in practice, I found it too rigid and prone to scattering related logic across different files and folders. You lose the sense that a feature is a cohesive unit because you have to open multiple layers to see how it all fits together.
It also encourages a certain ‚Äústatic‚Äù view of the system, where we think of models as timeless objects containing data and behavior. But real-world applications revolve around how data flows driven by messages. When we focus on data flow, it becomes clearer which components belong together to serve a particular feature. Layered architectures can obscure that by forcing everything into a rigid pattern of layers.
Focusing on Features
I‚Äôve come to prefer a more feature-focused (sometimes called ‚Äúvertical slice‚Äù) approach: put the logic, data, and any relevant business rules for a single feature in one place. If a feature is simple ‚Äî say, handling a POST request to store some data and optionally trigger an event ‚Äî then I don‚Äôt need a repository at all. A single request handler can:
Validate the incoming request.
Maybe check if the object already exists in the database.
Write the data directly via an ORM.
Publish relevant event(s).
No need for artificially bloated layers. If a feature needs more complexity ‚Äî like calculations, multi-step processes, or external integrations ‚Äî then yes, I might split some logic into a dedicated service class. But I do that only when the feature demands it, not by default.
How it works
Let me show how everything fits into a vertical feature slice for RegisterUser. It shows the request flow, where dependencies lie (e.g., DbContext and Outbox), and how the feature is self-contained ‚Äî meaning all logic for RegisterUser lives in this single slice rather than being scattered across multiple layers.
RegisterUser Feature Slice with Outbox and DbContext injected.
Key Points:
Vertical Slice: All functionality (validation, data access, event publishing) for registering a user is encapsulated in this one feature slice.
Dependencies: DbContext is injected directly into the handler, allowing immediate database access without additional abstraction layers. Outbox ensures that events (e.g., UserRegistered) are published reliably.
Flow: The request arrives, is validated, processed, persisted, and then triggers an event ‚Äî all in one place, resulting in a clear, cohesive feature implementation.
Process and Notifications: If registering a new user also requires creating a login, it‚Äôs a good idea to separate these concerns to adhere to the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP). For instance, after a UserRegistered event is published, another vertical slice ‚Äî CreateLogin ‚Äîcan listen for that event and handle the login creation process independently. By splitting these operations into feature slices, each slice focuses on a single responsibility, which keeps your code clearer, more maintainable, and easier to evolve over time.
Simplicity vs. Complexity: For small or straightforward features, this approach keeps code tight and easy to follow. For larger domains, additional organizational patterns (e.g., Aggregates) can be introduced within each vertical slice as needed.
About Transactions
If the databases for the data model and outbox are truly separate physical data stores (for instance, two entirely different databases on different servers), then writing the user entity to one and the UserRegistered event to the other in the exact same transaction would require a distributed transaction ‚Äî typically managed via two-phase commit (2PC).
However, in most implementations of the Outbox Pattern, both the entity data (User) and the outbox record (UserRegistered event) end up in the same physical database (just different tables). In that case, you can leverage a single local transaction (no 2PC needed). The outbox record is then picked up and published asynchronously to the message broker or another system, ensuring eventual consistency without incurring the overhead of a distributed transaction.
But What About CQRS?
Some people point to Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) as a scenario where repositories still reign. However, in a strict CQRS approach, commands might be writing to an event store directly, and read models are just flattened tables optimized for queries. In other words, you typically don‚Äôt use a classic repository for the event store side ‚Äî you‚Äôre just appending to the log of events. And for the read side, you‚Äôre querying simpler tables or views. This actually makes the overhead of a repository even less necessary, because CQRS more explicitly separates read and write concerns. So you don‚Äôt have that same ‚Äúwe need a single repository interface‚Äù for both operations.
It‚Äôs Really About Data Flow
In the last years I realized it‚Äôs all about how data flows ‚Äî where it comes from, where it needs to go, and how we transform it along the way. Classic layered architectures and the Repository pattern can bury that flow under a lot of ceremony, especially if the application isn‚Äôt all that complex.
By thinking of features first and seeing ‚Äúhow does data move?‚Äù we tend to build more direct pipelines: request in ‚Üí logic ‚Üí database/event ‚Üí response out. Everything is in one place, so it‚Äôs easier to see how a feature actually works. If we need more power later, we can add specialized services or classes as the need arises.
Avoid Overkill
A single request handler that injects database context and executes one clear action is all you really need. Adding extra layers or abstractions can feel like overkill, particularly for simpler applications where straightforward data flow does the job just fine. Of course, not every project is that simple‚Äîsome involve rich, complex business domains that justify more structure.
For smaller, straightforward use cases, going directly from the handler to the database often strikes the right balance of clarity and efficiency. By contrast, if your application deals with numerous rules and interdependent entities, you might benefit from domain-specific classes ‚Äî such as rich domain models, aggregates, etc‚Äî to keep logic organized and maintainable over time.
In short, it‚Äôs all about ‚Äúright-sizing‚Äù your architecture. If there‚Äôs only minimal logic to apply, layering things up can lead to unnecessary complexity. On the other hand, if you find yourself juggling intricate domain rules (not only input validation!), a more structured approach will likely save time and headaches down the road. The key is clarity: choose the simplest approach that still meets your project‚Äôs needs, ensuring your data flows remain transparent and your code stays maintainable.
Conclusion
Looking back, I see why I once embraced the Repository pattern. It seemed like a clear, textbook way to isolate database concerns and keep the domain clean. But with a better understanding of how data actually flows through an application, I find that repositories are just an unnecessary extra layer with no real-world benefit.
If you find yourself in a situation that truly needs a protective boundary around your domain (maybe you‚Äôre integrating with a complex legacy system), go for it. But if not, don‚Äôt cling to repositories out of habit. Cut out the middleman when it‚Äôs not adding value and focus on what matters: delivering features that solve real problems for real users ‚Äî without the overhead. Leverage the ORM directly for data access, especially when using advanced querying capabilities like LINQ in Entity Framework or raw SQL with Dapper.
The repository pattern‚Äôs focus on generalization often clashes with the need for specific, business-driven solutions in modern architectures. By moving toward behavior-oriented approaches, you can design solutions that are more focused, maintainable, and aligned with real-world requirements.
Cheers!<|InputEnd|>Member-only story

Link: https://www.chartjs.org/
Conclusion
The JavaScript ecosystem is vast, and the right library can significantly boost your productivity and streamline development.
By using these 15 JavaScript UI libraries in your projects, you can enhance your development workflow and create more powerful, efficient, and user-friendly web applications.
Happy coding! üöÄ

SOLID Coding. Why Squares Aren‚Äôt Rectangles: Liskov Substitution Principle
What every developer needs to know about substitution
Alina Kovtun‚ú®
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Women in Technology
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Jan 13, 2025
290
7
Programming is all about creating systems that work seamlessly and predictably, even as they grow in complexity. One principle that plays a crucial role in achieving this is the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP). As one of the foundational pillars of the SOLID principles, LSP ensures that your code is flexible, maintainable, and free from unexpected behavior.
So, today we‚Äôre diving into the ‚ÄúL‚Äù in SOLID, we‚Äôll keep it light, with some Ruby examples and the occasional tractor for good measure. (Yes, tractors üöú You‚Äôll see.)
Non-members can read this article for free using this link.
Before we start, if you‚Äôre new to SOLID, you might want to check out the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) first. It‚Äôs all about teaching your code to focus on one job at a time ‚Äî trust me, it‚Äôs life-changing.
The Single Responsibility Saga: One Job, One Focus
The programming world is still wild, unpredictable, and full of strange concepts. Whenever you think you‚Äôve got it all‚Ä¶
medium.com
A Quick History Lesson
Let‚Äôs rewind to 1987, when Barbara Liskov, a computer scientist, presented a talk at a conference. Fun fact: Barbara was the first woman in the U.S. to earn a Ph.D. in computer science. So, the next time someone tells you that women aren‚Äôt great at math or tech, just smile and send them Barbara‚Äôs Wikipedia page üíÖüèª
At this conference, Barbara gave a talk titled ‚ÄúData Abstraction and Hierarchy,‚Äù introducing what we now call the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP). This principle didn‚Äôt just pop out of nowhere. It was Barbara‚Äôs solution to a growing problem: the chaos that comes when object-oriented programming goes off the rails.
In the 1980s, object-oriented programming (OOP) was gaining popularity, promising a new way to build reusable and maintainable code. But as developers started inheriting everything under the sun, they realized something wasn‚Äôt quite right. Sure, inheritance sounded great in theory, but in practice, it often broke things in unexpected ways. Barbara saw this and said, ‚ÄúHold up. There‚Äôs a better way to do this.‚Äù
Her solution? A simple but profound rule:
If you have a parent class and a child class, you should be able to use the child class wherever the parent class is expected without breaking your code. In other words, subclasses shouldn‚Äôt mess with the core behavior of their parent classes.
Think about it like this: If you lend someone your car keys, you expect them to drive your car like a normal human. Now imagine they hand you back the keys and say, ‚ÄúOh, by the way, I rewired your ignition. You‚Äôll need to whistle ‚ÄòTwinkle Twinkle Little Star‚Äô to start it now.‚Äù That‚Äôs what happens when you violate LSP.
Barbara‚Äôs talk laid the foundation for what would become a cornerstone of OOP and part of the SOLID principles we know today.
Simplifying the Liskov Principle
To put it in simple terms, the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) tells us the following:
Objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of a subclass without altering the behavior of the program.
Subclasses should honor the contracts defined by their parent classes.
Let‚Äôs break it down with an analogy and some Ruby code.
Motorized Transport Example
Imagine motorized transport ‚Äî it has four wheels, an ignition, and a key slot. We create a car based on this motorized transport prototype. Our car comes with four wheels, an ignition, and a key slot. Perfect.
Now, let‚Äôs forget about the car for a second. Imagine we‚Äôre designing a tractor, also based on the motorized transport model. Boom ‚Äî it has four wheels, an ignition, and a key slot, too.
Here‚Äôs how that might look in Ruby:
As you can see, both Car and Tractor honor the contract of MotorizedTransport. If we swapped Car for Tractor, the program would still work as expected.
‚ú®The Key Insight
The cool part is, once we‚Äôve created a car and a tractor based on the motorized transport concept, we instantly know how to start either vehicle ‚Äî just put the key in the slot and turn. Even when someone hands us the key and points at the tractor, we know what to do because we expect it to work like motorized transport.
Therefore, we can‚Äôt:
Strengthen the preconditions: For instance, if we added a rule that to start the tractor, you first have to cross yourself ‚Äî we‚Äôd all be confused and stuck, digging through documentation.
Weaken the postconditions: Say you turn the key in the tractor, but it only inserts halfway instead of turning ‚Äî that‚Äôs unexpected and annoying.
Break invariants: The basic functions of motorized transport should hold true in both the car and the tractor. For example, turning the key halfway should activate the battery, and turning it fully should start the engine.
Introduce arbitrary limitations: If we‚Äôve decided the key is the only thing that fits in the ignition slot, then nothing else should work.
These same limitations should apply to both the tractor and the car.
Something Feels Off
It seems like there‚Äôs a deeper message behind these rules. Essentially, the tractor should add to motorized transport, not change how it works. Simple, right?
üë∑Mario Problem
So what‚Äôs the issue, then? The problem is that, mathematically, a square (tractor) is a rectangle (motorized transport). Now imagine we‚Äôre seasoned developers building a game, a clone of Super Mario. Instead of creating a detailed Mario, we settle for a simple rectangle, 50x100 pixels. We build a class that can draw rectangles on the screen, complete with properties like x and y coordinates, width, and height. We even add methods like stretchWidth (increasing the width by 25%) and stretchHeight (doubling the height). Everything‚Äôs going well ‚Äî Mario is rendered as a sad little rectangle.
But then, we want to add some enemies ‚Äî let‚Äôs say turtles, occupying 50x50 pixels. 50x50‚Ä¶ wait, isn‚Äôt that just a square? Exactly! We already have a name for that ‚Äî it‚Äôs a square! So, we create another class for squares, which inherits from the rectangle class. This makes sense because a square is just a special kind of rectangle. But now, the square also inherits the stretchWidth and stretchHeight methods.
Pause for a second ‚Äî do you see the issue?ü§®
Notice how the Square class has to override the stretch_width and stretch_height methods to maintain its invariant (both width and height must remain equal). This introduces complexity and breaks the principle that the Square class should seamlessly substitute the Rectangle class.
The Big Reveal
Here‚Äôs the catch: In the square, stretchWidth violates the Liskov Substitution Principle. If we want to enlarge our turtle boss to 100x100 pixels, this method will only increase the width, not the height ‚Äî but it‚Äôs a square!
The same issue occurs with circles and ellipses, as a circle is just a special type of ellipse.
What Should We Do?
Breaking the LSP is like breaking a promise ‚Äî it leads to confusion and frustration. So how do we avoid these pitfalls?
Favor composition over inheritance: Instead of forcing a Square to be a Rectangle, create a separate Shape class that encapsulates common behaviors.
Use interfaces or duck typing: In Ruby, duck typing ensures that any object can substitute another as long as it provides the required methods.
Be mindful of invariants: Ensure your subclasses don‚Äôt break the expected behavior of the parent class.
Switch to a different paradigm (like functional programming, but that‚Äôs a separate topic).
When you consider switching to functional programming to avoid LSP violations.
Why Does It Matter?
Violating the Liskov Substitution Principle isn‚Äôt just an academic problem. It has real-world consequences:
Bugs: Code that assumes all rectangles can be stretched might fail catastrophically when encountering a square.
Confusion: Future developers (including you!) will struggle to understand why the behavior is inconsistent.
Maintenance Hell: Fixing one problem might create two more.
Conclusions
In any case, this is a tricky issue. So what can we take away from this?
A square is not a rectangle, no matter how it looks.
Not everything needs OOP.
You need to be a fortune teller with years of experience to see such pitfalls during design (that‚Äôs why architects earn so much).
If you want to dive into the other SOLID principles, take a look at this collection. It‚Äôs equally mind-bending but totally worth it!
Alina Kovtun‚ú®

I Learned About a 1-letter Programming Language
I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶why didn‚Äôt I explore it before?
Kiran Maan
¬∑
Follow
Published in
The Deep Hub
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
2 days ago
187
5
I am always excited to know more about some exciting programming languages that are very different from what I have learned in Python, Java, C, C++, etc.
Not a medium member, yet? Read it FREE here.
Maybe some of you, know about this language. But I explore this language now and wanna write about my experience with it.
You will excited to know that this language has single letters only. If you are already familiar with it. You got it right‚Ä¶it‚Äôs J programming Language.
Image Generated by AI
I think it‚Äôs one of the most compact and efficient programming languages. Being a minimalist programming language, it does a lot with very little code.
But don‚Äôt take it too lightly‚Ä¶it can handle many advanced concepts like: data analysis, arrays and to be surprised even machine learning also.
This language, J, is created by Kenneth E. Iverson and Roger Hui in the early 1990s. It‚Äôs a successor of the APL programming language.
This language mainly relies on single-letter commands and operators.
For example: + means addition, * means multiplication, / is used to apply an operation to the entire array.
Why J is compact?
This language is designed specifically for people who think mathematically. In this language, we don‚Äôt write long loops or complicated functions, we just express concepts in few characters only.
For example ‚Äî
If we want to add all numbers in a list, we write like this in Python ‚Äî
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
result = sum(numbers)
print(result)
But in J, we write like this:
+/ 1 2 3 4 5
In the above example: + is the addition operator and / means ‚Äúreduce‚Äù ‚Ä¶this means it‚Äôs applying + to all elements of the array.
Arrays are everything in J
We can say, arrays to be the backbone of J. This language always assumes that we are always working with arrays, which is not the case in other languages like Python or Javascript. In Python, we always have to specify that we are working with arrays.
For example ‚Äî
Let‚Äôs suppose we want to multiply each number in an array by 2. Then in Python, we will write like this:
num = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
doubled = [x * 2 for x in num]
print(doubled)
In J, we simply write like this:
2 * 1 2 3 4 5
Pretty simple. We don‚Äôt have to write any loop or extra syntax.
Tacit Programming Concept of J
One of the advanced features of J is tacit programming. This is just a style or a way of writing the code in which we don‚Äôt explicitly name variables. We just define the operations directly.
For example ‚Äî
If we want to find the average of numbers in a list, then in Python, we write like this ‚Äî
def average(numbers):
    return sum(numbers) / len(numbers)

result = average([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
print(result)
But in J, we write like this:
(+/ % #) 1 2 3 4 5
In the above program, we use +/ to add the numbers, # is used to count the numbers (just like len in Python), and % is used to divide the sum by the count.
This is the main beauty of tacit programming‚Ä¶no variables...just operations.
We don‚Äôt learn J as a matter of curiosity. it‚Äôs used in serious applications. We use this language for data analysis, algorithm prototyping, mathematical modeling, etc.
I was also shocked to know it‚Äôs uses.
Just give this language a try and tell me in comments, what you feel about this language‚Ä¶ Just push your limits in Programming.
Happy Coding‚Ä¶
