Design Patterns in Swift 6: Mastering Singleton Alternatives with Practical Insights
Swift 6 offers better alternatives to the Singleton pattern for cleaner, more modular code
Ra√∫l Ferrer
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Dec 23, 2024
87
13
Photo by Daniel Lerman on Unsplash
This article is a fully revised take on ‚ÄúWhy Swift 6 Might Make the Singleton Pattern Obsolete‚Äù. It reflects reader feedback, addressing key points raised in the comments. The aim is to offer a balanced view, recognizing the Singleton pattern‚Äôs continued relevance while exploring practical Swift 6 alternatives.
The Singleton pattern has long served as one of the foundations of software architecture, offering simplicity and standardization.
However, it can be used in an incorrect way resulting in the formation of tight coupled code and scalability issues.
Since Swift 6 developers are now able to take advantage of a set of tools that trade simplicity for flexibility.
This article discusses such tools, contrasting their trade-offs and applications and revisiting the relevance of Singleton pattern.
Understanding the Singleton Pattern
The Singleton pattern ensures that one class instance and global single access to that instance are provided.
It is a result for when there should be only one, consistent instance (e.g., logging system, configuration objects, resource managers).
Here‚Äôs a typical implementation in Swift:
class Logger {
    static let shared = Logger() // A single shared instance

    private init() {} // Prevents additional instances

    func log(_ message: String) {
        print("Log: \(message)")
    }
}

Logger.shared.log("App started")
Singleton pattern reduce redundancy and simplify access to shared resources. However, their overuse can lead to tightly coupled code and limited testability.
Properly understanding their strengths and limitations is essential for making informed design decisions.
Design considerations
When implementing Singleton pattern, keep the following considerations in mind:
State management: Singletons with immutable state are inherently thread-safe, making them ideal for tasks like managing configuration or logging.
Access patterns: Consider whether global access is truly necessary. The concept of dependency injection may be able to provide increased architectural freedom without any performance compromises.
Testing: Design Singleton interfaces to support mock implementations. For example:
protocol Logging {
    func log(_ message: String)
}

class MockLogger: Logging {
    func log(_ message: String) {
        // Mock implementation for testing
    }
}
This allows you to simulate the global Logger instance from MockLogger in unit testing.
Common misconceptions
It‚Äôs important to address some common misconceptions about Singleton pattern:
Global state: Singleton pattern provide an entry point into the gloabl scope, but they do not provide aeurstic instantiation of global state. Correct encapsulation and immutability ensure they are deterministic and controllable.
Thread safety: Thread safety is not an issue that is limited to Singleton pattern but a problem for any such common resource. A well-designed Singleton can incorporate thread-safe mechanisms when necessary.
Coupling: While Singleton pattern can introduce coupling, this isn‚Äôt inherently bad. Intentional coupling, combined with type safety, can simplify code. The problem arises when coupling becomes unintentional or excessive.
Think of Singletons like the captain of a ship. The fact that the presence of one captain guarantees a degree of consistency in the actor-choice process can be seen, for instance, as giving rise to a temptation for a dependence and inefficiency trap in that, as long as all tasks are made to be the domain of the captain, nothing gets achieved, because nothing ever gets done.
Similarly, properly designed Singletons should encapsulate their role and not prescribe areas of the codebase which are not their concern.
Swift 6 alternatives and their trade-offs
While Swift 6 introduces Actors as a powerful new alternative to Singletons, it‚Äôs important to also consider longstanding design patterns like Dependency Injection and Module-Level Resources.
These approaches remain valuable tools in a developer‚Äôs arsenal, regardless of the Swift version used.
1. Actor-based implementation
Actors provide a natural co-ordination to concurrency in the problem of concurrent mutable state management, which can be viewed as a viable alternative to Singletons in multi-threaded environments.
actor LogManager {
    private var logQueue: [String] = []
    
    func log(_ message: String) {
        logQueue.append(message)
        processLog()
    }
    
    private func processLog() {
        // Process queued logs
    }
}
Trade-offs:
Built-in thread safety for mutable state.
Clear isolation boundaries.
Performance overhead from actor message dispatch.
Requires async/await at call sites
When to use:
Managing mutable state across multiple threads.
Resource management requiring serialized access.
When isolation boundaries are a key requirement.
For instance, consider a logging system within a multithreaded server application, such that multiple requests might write log messages concurrently.
The actor-driven Logger ensures that log messages are inserted in queue and processed without concurrency issues.
2. Dependency injection
Dependency injection provides flexibility and testability by making dependencies explicit:
protocol Logging {
    func log(_ message: String)
}

class FileLogger: Logging {
    func log(_ message: String) {
        // Implementation
    }
}

class AppManager {
    private let logger: Logging
    
    init(logger: Logging) {
        self.logger = logger
    }
}
Trade-offs:
Improved testability.
Explicit dependencies.
Runtime flexibility.
Additional setup complexity.
Potential over-abstraction for simple cases.
When to use:
When, for example, alternative implementations may be needed (e.g., ConsoleLogger FileLogger are not interchangeable).
For better unit testing support.
In larger applications where flexibility is valuable.
3. Module-level resources
In Swift, static variables provide simple global resources, without the baggage of Singletons:
enum AppResources {
    static let configuration = Configuration()
    static let logger = Logger()
}
Trade-offs:
Simpler syntax.
Namespace organization.
Still represents global state.
Limited initialization control.
When to use:
For truly application-wide resources.
When initialization is straightforward.
For immutable configuration data.
Be cautious, though‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääover-reliance on global resources can lead to hidden dependencies, complicating testing and maintenance.
Performance considerations
Performance should influence your choice of design pattern:
Actor overhead: In the situation of routine operation (e.g., logging function), it may compromise performance. Consider batching log messages in high-frequency scenarios.
Initialization costs: Lazy initialization of Singletons can improve performance when neither resource is needed all the time.
Memory usage: Memory consumption may be increased by dependency injection due to multiple instances, whereas Singletons ensure a maximum one instance.
For instance, if an actor-based Logger reads high-rate log messages in a performance-sensitive application, batching log messages can significantly reduce the overhead of message dispatch.
Best practices
1. Choose based on requirements:
Use Singletons for immutable, application-wide resources like configuration. Opt for actors for mutable state with concurrent access.
Leverage dependency injection for maximum flexibility and testability.
2. Design for change:
Create interfaces that hide implementation details.
Consider future requirements.
Make dependencies explicit.
3. Performance optimization:
Profile before optimizing.
Consider the impact of async/await.
Balance abstraction with performance needs.
Conclusion
Swift 6's behavior is such that it can be substituted to a reasonable extent for traditional (Singleton) constructs, but Singletons do not become irrelevant.
The important thing is to know the trade-off of each method, and select the tool which is suitable for your needs.
When deciding on an approach:
Consider my existing state management and access pattern requirements.
Evaluate performance implications.
Think about testing and maintenance needs.
Choose the simplest solution that meets your needs.
Remember that patterns are tools, not rules. The best design is right under your fingertips, tailored perfectly to fit your situation, while not degrading code quality and speed.
Give these substitutes a try in your next project and utilize the full control that Swift 6 provides to write clean, maintainable, and fast code.

And remember to subscribe my newsletter for insightful content about code, lead and grow.

The newsletter will position you as a thought leader, offering a mix of personal stories, practical advice, and‚Ä¶

Why I Keep Failing Candidates During Google Interviews‚Ä¶
Alexander Nguyen
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Apr 13, 2023
7.4K
203
They don‚Äôt meet the bar.
After joining Google in 2022, I got trained to interview candidates. I‚Äôve had a chance to meet candidates and saw how much they struggled. I‚Äôm ready to share some of their common mistakes (that I‚Äôm legally allowed to share).
Not knowing their data structures is NOT the #1 reason why I fail candidates.
Before we dig in, let‚Äôs go through what the interview process looks like today.
Online Assessment
Photo by Cl√©ment H√©lardot on Unsplash
(This article is now available as a youtube video)
If you‚Äôre a new grad, you‚Äôll likely be given an online assessment to solve a coding problem in whatever language you‚Äôd like. How well you do on this screen won‚Äôt affect your odds of getting an offer in the later interview stages.
What this screen is testing for is one thing:
Does the candidate know how to code?
If the candidate can‚Äôt solve the problem, then they wouldn‚Äôt do well on the phone screen or onsite. If they pass, congrats! They‚Äôll move on to interview in person.
Phone Screen
Photo by Jenny Ueberberg on Unsplash
The phone screen at Google will represent one of the onsite interviews. The candidate will join a Google voice chat and solve a coding on Google‚Äôs IDE with a Googler.
The candidate will be held to the same standards as an onsite interview. This is to assess if the candidate can really pass back-to-back onsite interviews. Some do, most don‚Äôt.
For those that don‚Äôt do well on the phone screen, here‚Äôs what they should know:
They can be given a second chance. Ask the recruiter and explain why you deserve another shot or didn‚Äôt demonstrate all your coding skills.
They‚Äôll have to wait again for at least 12 months to reapply.
If they make it onsite, then the candidate is in for some serious interviews.
Onsite Interviews
Photo by Rajeshwar Bachu on Unsplash
Making it to Google on-sites is a rare achievement in itself. For the few candidates that make it this far, here‚Äôs what they should know
It‚Äôs well known the candidate knows how to code
They may be assessed different scenarios and situations for each interview
Onsite candidates will be given 4‚Äì5 back-to-back on-site interviews. Most will consist of coding and a behavioral (Googliness) interviews as well as a system design interview for more senior engineers. Googliness is hardly an issue as long as the candidate can thrive in a professional workplace.
From the few candidates that make it this far, even fewer receive an offer. For the ones that don‚Äôt, Google legally will not provide feedback to candidates. If Googliness wasn‚Äôt the issue, then something went wrong in the coding interview.
Here‚Äôs what often goes wrong in the coding interviews
Coding Interview Mistakes
Photo by Maranda Vandergriff on Unsplash
(You can also watch my youtube video that goes over leetcode strategies)
Not clarifying the problem
Candidates jump straight into the problem without asking additional questions the moment the prompt is shared with them. The interviewer may correct them. But if they don‚Äôt, the candidate won‚Äôt realize they‚Äôre solving the wrong problem.
Focusing on unimportant details
If the problem is about using binary search, then focus more on the larger parts and come back to the smaller details. Some spend half the interview thinking about null exceptions or wrong input and never get to actually solving the question.
Staying quiet
Candidates are going to get stuck and the interviewers know this. What the candidate needs to do is know what questions to ask, think out loud, share their thoughts and take the interviewers input. Most candidates are dead silent and it‚Äôs usually because nobody teaches them how to communicate during a coding interview.
Assuming their code works
When the code is written, everyone wants to celebrate and be over with the interview. But the code most likely has bugs in it. That‚Äôs fine as long as the candidate goes through the example test cases and dry runs their code against it. Skipping this step isn‚Äôt professional.
Blurting the Running time
The candidate will absolutely be asked the running time of their algorithm. Most will just say it‚Äôs O(n) or O(nlogn) without any explanation. The better ones are the ones that explain why. The best ones are the candidates that explain the running time of different parts of their code and then reason where the bottleneck is.
Closing Thoughts
Most candidates who interview at Google do know how to code and likely practice their data structures and algorithms. The biggest difference between those who get an offer and those who don‚Äôt is how well they communicate their coding process.
Before You Leave

7 Horrors Faced by Female Slaves in Ancient Rome You Didn‚Äôt Know About
The brutal and degrading realities endured by women enslaved under the Roman Empire‚Äôs cruel system.
Faze
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Exploring History
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Nov 4, 2024
3.2K
66
Source: Wikimedia Commons
Historical Rome has been acknowledged for its technological innovations in civil, administrative, engineering, architecture as well as in arts.
However, the flip side of the history of civilization is very disturbing, and this is usually not taken into consideration.
Female slaves in the Roman Empire underwent most of the unimaginable mistreatment that even we in the modern world can hardly imagine or relate to.
For a second ‚Äî however, that can be attributed to the fact that they existed only to be captured, sold, and exploited.
Hence never knowing a moment‚Äôs peace, rarely experiencing the meaning of love and happiness, and never once experiencing what it felt to be free, having been the story of women slaves of ancient Rome.
7- Thrown Away Like Trash
Source: Wikimedia Commons
In ancient Rome, the life of a newborn girl was often discarded like yesterday‚Äôs waste. Families viewed daughters as financial burdens, leading many to abandon their baby girls in the streets.
These abandoned infants were easy prey for slave traders, who would collect them and raise them as slaves.
For these girls, their lives began with rejection and continued in chains. Once sold, their fates were sealed ‚Äî they became mere objects, used for labor or worse.
This was not an uncommon practice ‚Äî rather a chilling reminder of how little value was placed on female life.
6- Women Captured As War Prizes
Source: Wikipedia
As Roman armies expanded their reach, they didn‚Äôt just bring back spoils of gold and land. Women captured during conquests were paraded as trophies of victory.
These women, often taken from their homes and families, were auctioned off to the highest bidders.
Treated as nothing more than spoils of war, they were humiliated, their humanity stripped away. Once sold, their future was bleak, whether forced into labor or sexual exploitation.
The idea of conquest wasn‚Äôt just about territory ‚Äî it was about ownership of human lives, with women as the ultimate prize.
5- Sold By Their Own Blood
Source: Wikimedia Commons
In a world ruled by survival, desperation drove families to make unimaginable choices.
Poverty often forced families to sell their daughters into slavery to pay off debts or escape financial ruin.
Even more tragic were the instances when women sold themselves into slavery, believing it was their only chance at survival.
It was a cruel system where blood relations meant little if it could ease the burden of poverty.
These women, sold by their own families, were cast into a life of degradation, with no hope of escaping the chains that bound them.
4- Reduced To Property
By the Roman‚Äôs account women whose status in the community was enslaved were never allowed to enjoy their dignity. Their well-being was never about them but about their masters.
Whether it was an assault, rape, or forced labor, nothing was considered wrong in any way under the Roman legal system towards the women that was treated as a possession.
Day-to-day operations were full of hardship from dawn to dusk, depending on what the master wanted ‚Äî be it day-hard labor, sex, or pleasure.
The statutory system provided information and allowed them to be used as equipment and thrown away after they became ineffective on the system.
3- Forced To Serve In All Ways
Source: Picryl
In Roman households, women slaves were forced to perform endless domestic duties, but their suffering didn‚Äôt end there.
Many were also forced into sexual servitude, either for their master‚Äôs personal use or rented out in brothels for profit.
The abuse these women endured was constant, and there was no way out.
Their bodies were seen as another service to be offered, another way to satisfy the appetites of their owners.
It was a life of unrelenting exploitation, with no hope of dignity or freedom.
2- Even The Educated Were Not Spared
Education could not protect women from the brutal realities of slavery.
Many women from educated regions like Greece found themselves serving wealthy Roman families as teachers, musicians, or scribes.
Despite their talents, they were still slaves, their knowledge exploited for their masters‚Äô gain.
While they may have held higher roles within households, they were never free from the cruelty of their status.
Educated or not, they were trapped in a system that offered no escape, their intellectual gifts merely another resource to be mined by their owners.
1- The Illusion Of Freedom
Source: Wikimedia Commons
For some women, the idea of manumission ‚Äî a master freeing their slave ‚Äî offered a flicker of hope.
However, this ‚Äî freedom, was often an illusion. Many women were only freed when they were no longer useful, too old, sick, or broken to serve their masters.
Even after being freed, these women faced social stigma, financial hardship, and a life still defined by their former status as slaves.
Freedom did not erase their past, and for many, it was a new kind of prison ‚Äî one where they were no longer bound by chains but still trapped by the consequences of their servitude.
Points To Ponder
It is appalling to see how inhumane the treatment of female slaves was in ancient Rome, a place where human beings were viewed as instruments so that power, economic interests and desire to control could persist.
This made slavery, whether it be nurturing, caring, or violence would severely degrade the person.
Either being abandoned as kids, being captured in wars, or being sold by their own fathers or brothers, all of them had nothing but sufferings in their short years of existence.
Even the upper class did not escape the atrocities, and freedom and peace frequently turned out to be quite an opposite.
Though many historians greatly admire the Roman Empire for its rich history, the plight of these females offers a more negative narration.

12 Python Libraries for Free Market Data That Everyone Should Know
DataScience Nexus
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Towards Dev
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Jan 2, 2025
25
1
Access to accurate and timely market data is crucial for traders, financial analysts, and data scientists. Whether you are building a trading algorithm, analyzing economic trends, or just exploring stock data, Python has a wide range of libraries to make the job easier.
In this article, we‚Äôll explore 12 powerful Python libraries that offer free access to market data. These tools can help you fetch data about stocks, forex, cryptocurrencies, and economic indicators without spending a dime. Let‚Äôs dive in!
1. yfinance ‚Äî Yahoo Finance Data Made Easy
Best for: Stocks, Forex, Crypto, Options, and Fundamentals.
What it does:
The yfinance library lets you access market data directly from Yahoo Finance. It‚Äôs perfect for fetching historical prices, intraday data, and even financial statements.
Real-World Example:
Imagine you want to analyze Tesla‚Äôs stock price over the last year. With yfinance, you can download this data in just a few lines of code:
import yfinance as yf
data = yf.download('TSLA', start='2023-01-01', end='2023-12-31')
print(data.head())
2. pandas-datareader ‚Äî Flexible Data Fetching
Best for: Stocks, FX, Economic Indicators, and Fama-French Factors.
What it does:
Originally part of the pandas library, pandas-datareader now operates independently. It simplifies pulling data from popular financial platforms, including FRED, World Bank, and Yahoo Finance.
Real-World Example:
Let‚Äôs fetch data for the S&P 500 index:
from pandas_datareader import data as pdr
import datetime

start = datetime.datetime(2023, 1, 1)
end = datetime.datetime(2023, 12, 31)
sp500 = pdr.get_data_yahoo('^GSPC', start, end)
print(sp500.head())
3. IBApi ‚Äî Direct Access to Interactive Brokers
Best for: Professional Traders and Algorithmic Trading.
What it does:
IBApi is the official API for Interactive Brokers, a platform widely used by professional traders. It provides real-time data and tools to build and execute trading strategies.
Note: This library is best suited for advanced users who want to build custom trading applications.
4. Alpha Vantage ‚Äî Easy Financial Indicators
Best for: Real-Time Stock Data and Indicators.
What it does:
Alpha Vantage provides free APIs for stock data and technical indicators like RSI, MACD, and SMA.
Real-World Example:
Fetch Apple‚Äôs stock price:
import requests

API_KEY = 'your_api_key'
url = f'https://www.alphavantage.co/query?function=TIME_SERIES_DAILY&symbol=AAPL&apikey={API_KEY}'
response = requests.get(url)
data = response.json()
print(data)
5. Nasdaq Data Link (formerly Quandl) ‚Äî Millions of Datasets
Best for: Financial and Economic Data.
What it does:
Nasdaq Data Link offers access to millions of datasets. It‚Äôs ideal for downloading macroeconomic indicators, interest rates, and stock fundamentals.
6. Twelve Data ‚Äî Global Market Coverage
Best for: Stocks, Forex, and Indices.
What it does:
Twelve Data provides access to over 100,000+ symbols from global markets. It‚Äôs great for building trading dashboards and data analysis tools.
7. Polygon.io ‚Äî Real-Time Market Data
Best for: Stocks, Forex, and Crypto.
What it does:
Polygon.io provides both real-time and historical data for multiple asset classes. It‚Äôs widely used for algorithmic trading.
Real-World Example:
Streaming live price updates for Bitcoin:
import websocket
def on_message(ws, message):
    print(message)
ws = websocket.WebSocketApp("wss://socket.polygon.io/crypto", on_message=on_message)
ws.run_forever()
8. Tradier ‚Äî Trading API Made Simple
Best for: Building Trading Applications.
What it does:
Tradier provides APIs for streaming market data, placing trades, and managing accounts. It‚Äôs suitable for developers building custom trading platforms.
9. Alpaca-py ‚Äî Modern Algorithmic Trading
Best for: Automated Trading and Investing Apps.
What it does:
Alpaca is popular among quants and developers. It allows seamless access to market data, along with tools to execute trades programmatically.
10. Finnhub ‚Äî Real-Time RESTful APIs
Best for: Stocks, Forex, and Crypto.
What it does:
Finnhub provides APIs and websockets for fetching real-time financial data. It‚Äôs great for anyone who wants live updates for stock or crypto prices.
Real-World Example:
Fetching news headlines about Tesla:
import requests
url = "https://finnhub.io/api/v1/news?category=general&token=your_token"
response = requests.get(url)
print(response.json())
11. marketstack ‚Äî Historical Market Data
Best for: Historical and Intraday Data.
What it does:
With access to over 170,000+ tickers and 30+ years of history, marketstack is ideal for analyzing long-term market trends.
12. Tiingo ‚Äî Transparent and Reliable Data
Best for: End-of-Day Stock Prices.
What it does:
Tiingo provides accurate and well-documented end-of-day prices for stocks. It‚Äôs particularly popular for building financial models.
Whether you‚Äôre just starting your journey in finance or are an experienced developer building complex trading systems, these 12 Python libraries have something for everyone. From fetching historical stock prices to streaming real-time updates, you can integrate these tools into your projects and start making data-driven decisions today.
Quick Tip: Many of these libraries require an API key to access data. Be sure to sign up for free accounts and store your keys securely in environment variables!

I ditched Docker Desktop a while back, and honestly? I haven‚Äôt looked back. If you‚Äôve ever tried running multiple resource-hungry microservices locally, you probably know the pain. Docker Desktop eats up system resources like it‚Äôs on an all-you-can-eat buffet.
Even on my 16GB RAM MacBook, Docker Desktop would start to struggle when I spun up around 20 microservices. My machine crashed consistently, and just opening Brave Browser became a chore.
The Alternative: OrbStack
https://orbstack.dev/
Then I discovered OrbStack, a sleek, lightweight alternative to Docker Desktop. And wow ‚Äî why didn‚Äôt I try this sooner?
With OrbStack, my laptop breathes again. Brave opens effortlessly, and I can actually use my system while running containers.
So what makes OrbStack stand out?
‚ö° Lightning fast: Starts in seconds with turbocharged networking, smooth Rosetta x86 emulation, VirtioFS file sharing, and other optimizations for some workloads.
üí® Lightweight: Keep it breezy with low CPU and disk usage, minimal memory consumption, and a native Swift app. Battery drain is a thing of the past.
üç∞ Effortless integration: Enjoy seamless containers, plus CLI integration, file sharing, and remote SSH editing with Linux machines.
‚öôÔ∏è Powerful: Run containers, Kubernetes, and Linux distros all with robust integration. Manage containers & machines from anywhere with the menu bar app.
How to Get Started
OrbStack is only available on Mac. You can download the .dmg file directly from OrbStack official site or use Homebrew:
brew install orbstack
In case you have used Docker Desktop already, by installing OrbStack everything will continue to work like normal after you open OrbStack app.
After installation, OrbStack will offer to migrate your Docker Desktop data automatically, including containers, volumes, images, and more. This is optional and you can always migrate later from File > Migrate Docker Data, or from the command line:
orb migrate docker
If you have admin access, OrbStack will automatically update the /var/run/docker.sock symlink to point to its own Docker engine. This improves compatibility with some third-party tools.
In case, you just want to giev OrbStack a try, you can switch between OrbStack and Docker Desktop by using docker context
# Switch to OrbStack
docker context use orbstack
# Switch to Docker Desktop
docker context use desktop-linux
Key Takeaways
High Performance: OrbStack optimizes resource usage, speeding up container start-ups and execution for a smoother, faster experience on macOS.
Resource Efficiency: With drastically reduced CPU and RAM usage, OrbStack is perfect for running demanding projects without slowing you down.
Seamless macOS Integration: Built specifically for macOS, OrbStack runs efficiently and smoothly, with top-notch optimization for Apple Silicon.
Docker CLI Compatibility: You won‚Äôt need to learn anything new. OrbStack fully supports Docker CLI, meaning your existing Docker commands work seamlessly.
Easy Networking: OrbStack makes networking simple, so you can skip the hassle of complicated configurations and focus on building.
Sample Setup and Quick Commands
Once OrbStack is up and running, here are a few basic Docker commands you can use just like you would with Docker Desktop:
# Pull an image
docker pull nginx:latest

# Run a container
docker run -d -p 8080:80 nginx

# Check running containers
docker ps

# Stop a container
docker stop <container-id>
These are the same commands you‚Äôd run in Docker Desktop, but with OrbStack, you get faster performance and lower resource usage.
Ready to Level Up Your Development with OrbStack?
If you‚Äôre tired of the sluggish performance and excessive resource consumption of Docker Desktop, OrbStack could be the game-changer you‚Äôve been looking for. Whether you‚Äôre managing microservices, running Kubernetes, or simply testing locally, OrbStack provides the speed, efficiency, and simplicity that Docker Desktop can‚Äôt match.

The Glorious Art of Overengineering
A Software Engineer‚Äôs Guide to Creating Problems

Photo by Amy Elting on Unsplash
Welcome to the golden age of software engineering, where every problem must have a complex, convoluted solution!
Why fix it in five lines when you can flex your mental gymnastics by building an architectural maze of interconnected services?
If you‚Äôre a software engineer looking to leave your mark, you‚Äôve come to the right place. I‚Äôve listed a few examples below, from this glorious world of modern engineering mishaps.
Microservices ‚Äî Why Have One When You Can Have 500?
Image created by Author
Remember monoliths? Those ancient artifacts of simplicity where codebases were‚Ä¶ manageable?
Boring! Today, we chop our systems into hundreds of microservices because who doesn‚Äôt love debugging a production issue at 3 a.m. that spans seven continents and 12 time zones?
Pro tip: Never document how the services communicate. That‚Äôs a rookie move. Instead, let your future self play Sherlock Holmes trying to deduce how BillingService mysteriously calls UserOnboardingLambda .
Blockchain ‚Äî The Solution to Problems That Do Not Exist
Image generated by Author on makeameme.org
Does your grocery delivery app really need to be decentralized?
Who cares!
The mere mention of ‚Äúblockchain‚Äù and ‚Äúweb3‚Äù adds credibility and VC funding. Just sprinkle some words like ‚Äúimmutable‚Äù, ‚Äútrustless‚Äù and ‚Äúproof of work‚Äù and you are good to go.
Bonus points if you can invent a token that solves‚Ä¶ well, nothing.
Don‚Äôt forget to insist that everything must be on the chain. Does it slow down transactions? Absolutely. But hey, it‚Äôs the future.
Machine Learning ‚Äî More Data, More Problems
Image generated by Author on makeameme.org
Who needs domain expertise when you can throw random data at a black-box model?
Want to predict user behaviour? Feed the algorithm your logs, customer emails and that Excel file named Backup_2019_v2_FINAL_FINAL(1).xlsx.
When it fails catastrophically, blame the data quality. Never the model.
Never your understanding.
Always the data!
Cloud ‚Äî The Magical Land of Infinite Costs
Image generated by Author on makeameme.org
Cloud, a place where everything is scalable, except your budget!
It is marketed as the ultimate solution for flexibility, but what they don‚Äôt tell you is that it is also the ultimate exercise in playing ‚ÄúGuess the Monthly Bill.‚Äù
Want to store a few gigabytes? That‚Äôs cheap.
Need to retrieve it? Give me my ransom!
Of course, everyone loves to brag about ‚Äúmoving to the cloud.‚Äù But in reality, it‚Äôs more of a one-way ticket to a world where ‚Äúdowntime‚Äù is now your team‚Äôs problem instead of the hardware vendor‚Äôs.
Congratulations, you‚Äôre officially the proud owner of a ‚Äúmanaged service‚Äù that still breaks at the worst possible moment.
But hey, at least you get to tell people your project or startup is ‚Äúcloud-native‚Äù. Totally worth it, right?
Hiring Engineers ‚Äî They Must Be a Wizard
Image generated by Author on makeameme.org
To hire the best, you must filter the weak!
Your interview process should include algorithmic problems involving greek alphabets and Fibonacci trees. Nevermind that the actual job involves fixing CSS bugs.
Also, the ideal candidate must have 10+ years of experience in a framework that‚Äôs been out for 3 years. And if they can‚Äôt explain why your company‚Äôs overengineered solution is ‚Äúinnovative‚Äù, are they even a good fit for the team?
Debugging in Production ‚Äî Unavoidable, Really!
Image generated by Author on imgflip.com
Remember when QA used to exist? Now, everything goes straight to production because YOLO!
The thrill of fixing bugs live in production with thousands of users watching is unmatched. Bonus points for writing a postmortem that uses phrases like ‚Äúroot cause analysis‚Äù and ‚Äúlessons learned‚Äù, when deep down, you know you‚Äôll do it all over again.
Documentation ‚Äî A Useless Artifact of the Past
Image generated by Author on imgflip.com
Documentation is for quitters. Real engineers read the code to understand the system ‚Äî because nothing screams ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù like deciphering variable names like temp123 and functions called doThing().
When pressured to write documentation, create a 300-page Google Doc titled ‚ÄúAPI Guidelines‚Äù and ensure it is never updated.
Version Control ‚Äî Git Push and Pray
Image generated by Author on imgflip.com
Git is simple: until it isn‚Äôt. The sheer joy of resolving merge conflicts with 20 other developers working on main is unparalleled.
And let‚Äôs not forget the legendary commit messages like ‚Äúfix‚Äù or ‚ÄúWIP.‚Äù Future developers will thank you for the clarity.
The Ultimate Power Move ‚Äî Inventing New Frameworks
Image generated by Author on imgflip.com
Why use something tried and tested when you can invent your own framework? Call it ‚ÄúLightweight Modular Scalable Framework 2.0.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs just a wrapper over React. The key is branding.
And if by chance your framework becomes even a little bit popular, immediately try to rewrite it in Rust for ‚Äúperformance gains‚Äù that nobody needs.
Agile ‚Äî The Sacred Ritual of Standups and Sprints
Image generated by Author on makeameme.org
Agile is a gift that keeps on giving.
Need a framework to run your project? Agile.
Need to look busy? Agile.
Want to justify doing nothing for weeks while ‚Äúgrooming the backlog‚Äù? Agile!
Daily standups are the crown jewel of Agile. Gather around, exchange vague one-liners like,
‚ÄúStill on the API‚Äù ,
‚ÄúLooking into it‚Äù or
‚ÄúWaiting for Feedback‚Äù
and nod thoughtfully. Nothing says productivity like synchronized ambiguity. Meanwhile, the tickets labelled ‚ÄúBlocked‚Äù pile up. But don‚Äôt worry, the velocity charts look fantastic.
ChatGPT Can Replace You, but Your Manager Can‚Äôt Tell
Image generated by Author on imgflip.com
Your job isn‚Äôt to write code anymore. It is to copy-paste Stack Overflow snippets into ChatGPT and pretend you understand the output.
But don‚Äôt let your manager catch on! Say things like,
‚ÄúI‚Äôve architected a scalable, fault-tolerant pipeline for asynchronous processing‚Äù
while the AI silently judges your lack of syntax knowledge.
Insider tip: If ChatGPT writes code better than you, pivot to DevOps. No one understands it anyway.
In the end, I would like to conclude by saying:
Software engineering isn‚Äôt about solving problems; it‚Äôs about creating them, preferably ones so complex that only you can fix them.
So, embrace the chaos, worship the buzzwords, and always remember, ‚Äúthe more you overengineer, the closer you get to software immortality‚Äù.
If you liked this rant, don‚Äôt hesitate to clap, comment, highlight, or follow me. I love getting distracted by the endless notifications of your appreciation!
Cheers ‚Äî RS!!

Have you ever looked in the mirror and thought, I need a serious change? I did. At 170 pounds, I felt like I was trapped in a body that didn‚Äôt reflect my best self. The weight gain wasn‚Äôt just about appearance; it weighed down my confidence and energy. I was tired of feeling sluggish and uninspired.
When my close friend ‚Äî a seasoned athlete ‚Äî shared his secrets to cutting fat and staying fit, I knew I had to give it a try. Little did I know, it would become one of the most disciplined, yet rewarding, 30 days of my life. Here‚Äôs what I learned, from the emotional highs and lows to the science-backed strategies that transformed my body.
1. Rule #1: Cutting Out ‚ÄúWhite‚Äù Carbohydrates
The first big change was eliminating all ‚Äúwhite‚Äù carbs. We‚Äôre talking about bread, rice, potatoes, and pasta ‚Äî the kind of comfort foods that had become staples in my diet. I learned that these simple carbohydrates spike blood sugar levels, causing insulin to rise, which leads to fat storage. Instead, I focused on nutrient-dense, slow-digesting alternatives.
The Science Behind It
A study from the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition backs this up: people who replace refined carbs with whole, fiber-rich foods experience lower hunger levels and a 10‚Äì20% increase in fat loss efficiency. It‚Äôs not just about cutting calories but making smarter food choices.
My Experience
It was brutal at first. Bread and pasta are like old friends ‚Äî familiar, comforting, and hard to say goodbye to. But once I switched to healthier options, like black beans and roasted vegetables, my energy levels started to even out. No more afternoon crashes.
Key Tip: Make your meals simple yet balanced. My go-to was grilled chicken, a hefty serving of legumes, and saut√©ed spinach. Easy to make, filling, and packed with nutrients.
2. Rule #2: Simplify Your Meals
Have you ever spent hours meal prepping, only to get bored halfway through the week? I simplified things by sticking to proven meals and cycling them. Repetition works, and it keeps you from obsessing over what to eat next.
Why This Works
Eating the same meals may sound dull, but it reduces decision fatigue, helping you stay committed. Decision fatigue is a real psychological phenomenon: when you‚Äôre faced with too many choices, your willpower takes a hit. Psychology Todaynotes that sticking to routine meals can prevent dietary slip-ups, boosting overall diet adherence.
My Meal Plan
Proteins: Egg whites, chicken breast, or grass-fed beef
Legumes: Black beans, lentils, or pinto beans
Vegetables: Asparagus, spinach, and a rotating mix of roasted veggies
The consistency was surprisingly freeing. Plus, it gave me room to experiment with spices and herbs to keep things interesting. Even when dining out, I made smarter choices, like opting for a salad instead of fries.
3. Rule #3: Ditch Sugary Beverages
One of the most overlooked sources of empty calories is sugary drinks. That morning orange juice? It‚Äôs packed with sugar that spikes your insulin and makes fat loss harder. Instead, I stuck to water, black coffee, and the occasional unsweetened tea.
The Numbers Don‚Äôt Lie
Did you know that a single can of soda contains roughly 150 calories and 39 grams of sugar? Compare that to water, which has zero calories. Harvard Medical School found that cutting out sugary beverages alone can lead to losing up to 12 pounds in a year, even without any other diet changes.
How I Managed Cravings
At first, I missed the sweetness. But I discovered that adding lemon slices to water or brewing herbal teas helped. And honestly, the benefits of staying hydrated ‚Äî clearer skin, more energy, and reduced bloating ‚Äî kept me motivated.
Key Tip: If you crave something flavorful, try a cold-brewed hibiscus tea. It‚Äôs naturally tangy and refreshing without the added sugar.
4. Rule #4: The Power of a Weekly Cheat Day
Perhaps the most surprising (and satisfying) rule was having a cheat day. Once a week, I let loose. Burgers, pizza, ice cream ‚Äî you name it. This ‚ÄúDieters Gone Wild‚Äù day kept my cravings in check and my metabolism fired up.
The Science of Cheat Days
Leptin, a hormone that regulates hunger, gets a boost from cheat meals. Research in the International Journal of Obesityshows that periodic overfeeding can temporarily spike metabolism by up to 10%. The key is moderation and getting back on track the next day.
My Cheat Day Routine
I indulged guilt-free on Saturdays, and it felt incredible. But I also knew that come Sunday, I‚Äôd be back to my clean eating. This rhythm made the diet sustainable and enjoyable, not a punishing experience.
Supercharging My Routine: Exercise and Mental Discipline
Aside from diet, I committed to daily workouts ‚Äî 30 minutes of strength training followed by a 30-minute run. The discipline extended beyond the gym. I practiced mindfulness and set clear goals for each week, which helped me stay focused.
An Unexpected Benefit: Mental Clarity
Exercise isn‚Äôt just for physical health; it boosts your mood and cognitive function. The Journal of Psychiatric Researchhighlights that even moderate exercise reduces symptoms of anxiety and depression by up to 30%. As someone who battles self-doubt, this was life-changing.
Key Insight: Exercise taught me resilience. Every time I didn‚Äôt feel like working out but did it anyway, I became mentally stronger. This mindset bled into other areas of my life, from work to personal growth.
My Takeaway
This journey wasn‚Äôt about hitting a number on the scale; it was about proving to myself that I could commit to something difficult and see it through. Dropping 25 pounds in 30 days taught me discipline, resilience, and the importance of taking care of my body. If you‚Äôre considering a similar journey, remember: it‚Äôs not about perfection but consistent effort.
Believe me when I say this: You have untapped potential. Whether it‚Äôs weight loss, a career change, or any other challenge, you‚Äôre capable of more than you think. Stick to your goals, embrace the hard days, and take pride in every small victory.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

The Egg Dropping Interview Puzzle
Can You Devise a Strategy for this Puzzle in Time Pressure?
Rajul Saxena
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Puzzle Sphere
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Dec 4, 2024
427
14
All images by Author unless specified otherwise
This is a classic optimization problem and is considered moderately difficult because it is harder to work out the algorithm for it. It features a lot in the tech interviews of many software companies.
A more general case of this problem is also given as a coding question because it involves the concept of dynamic programming. But this version is simpler.
Try to think of a strategy and come up with the solution in under 5 minutes. Best of Luck!
Problem
You have a basket of eggs out of which you take out 2 eggs. You have to determine the highest floor in a 100-storey building from which eggs can be dropped without breaking.
The goal is to identify this ‚Äúsafe floor‚Äù using the fewest number of egg drops, even in the worst-case scenario.
Assumptions:
1. You have two eggs for testing.
2. If an egg survives a drop, it can be reused.
3. If an egg breaks, it cannot be reused.
4. If an egg breaks at a certain floor, it will also break at any floor above it.
5. If an egg survives a drop at a certain floor, it will survive drops from any lower floors.
6. The breaking point is consistent across all eggs i.e. all eggs will behave as the two testing eggs. They all will have the same ‚Äúsafe floor‚Äù.
How can you minimize the number of drops needed to find the ‚Äúsafe floor‚Äù using just these two eggs? Also, what will be the minimum drops required for the above scenario?
You should pause here, grab your notebook and pen, and try to find the solution yourself. üß†ü§î
When ready, scroll down and read the solution provided!
Solution
1 Egg Strategy
If we were given only one egg then the strategy would be simple. Drop the egg from the 1st floor and if it survives, drop it from the 2nd floor and so on until it breaks at some point.
In the worst-case scenario, this method requires 100 egg drops.
Expanding to 2 Eggs
But we are given 2 eggs. Our strategy should be to use the 2nd egg in a different way. Maybe we can skip some floors with it? Maybe use binary search to do some batch testing?
Or can we combine these strategies? Using the 1st egg to skip some floors and when it breaks, using the 2nd egg to do brute force drops upward, from the proven safe floor, till we reach the floor where the 1st egg broke.
So our strategy involves balancing the number of drops across the two eggs to optimize the worst-case scenario.
For this, we need to decide the floors from which eggs should be dropped so that the total number of trials are minimized.
Example with Uniform Intervals
Let‚Äôs say we fix an interval of 10 floors for the 1st egg. In the worst-case scenario, it will take 19 tries if the safe floor is 99. It can be seen from the table below:
EXAMPLE WITH UNIFORM INTERVALS
============================

+----------------------+------------------------------+
| 1st Egg Dropped from | Total Tries in worst case    |
| Floor Number         | (if it breaks at that floor) |
+----------------------+------------------------------+
| # 10                 | 1 + 9 = 10                   |
| # 20                 | 2 + 9 = 11                   |
| # 30                 | 3 + 9 = 12                   |
| # 40                 | 4 + 9 = 13                   |
| # 50                 | 5 + 9 = 14                   |
| # 60                 | 6 + 9 = 15                   |
| # 70                 | 7 + 9 = 16                   |
| # 80                 | 8 + 9 = 17                   |
| # 90                 | 9 + 9 = 18                   |
| # 100                | 10 + 9 = 19                  |
+----------------------+------------------------------+
We can clearly see from above that when we move at a higher floor, our number of tries with the 1st egg keeps on increasing, but the tries with the 2nd egg remain constant.
Optimizing the Intervals
With each interval, we add
+1 drop for the 1st egg
and if it breaks then
the gap in the interval becomes the total drops for the 2nd egg
We need to create the intervals in such a way that as we move up, with the increase in drops for the 1st egg, the drops for the 2nd egg keep on reducing.
So instead of going up in intervals of 10, we can increase the gap at the bottom and decrease the gap at the top.
And if we can ensure that the rate of increase (+1) is equal to the rate of reduction in gap size between intervals (-1), then we can achieve a constant number for any safe floor and it will also be the maximum number of tries needed to solve for any safe floor.
Verification of the Strategy
So let‚Äôs make an assumption that the maximum number of drops will x and test our theory by dropping the 1st egg from the # x·µó ∞ floor.
If it breaks, then we need to try all the floors below it x ‚Äî 1 times in the worst case.
This makes the total drops equal to:
+1 for [x]·µó ∞ floor [1st egg did break]
+(x ‚Äî 1) for floors in between [with 2nd egg]
Total = 1 + (x ‚Äî 1) = x
As we calculated, it takes a total of x drops in the worst case if the 1st egg breaks at the # x·µó ∞ floor.
But what if it doesn‚Äôt break? To make our total drops in worst case constant i.e. x, we need to drop it next from (x ‚Äî 1) floors above the # x·µó ∞ floor. (Reducing the gap size)
The calculation will be:
+1 for [x]·µó ∞ floor [1st egg did not break]
+1 for [x + (x ‚Äî 1)]·µó ∞ floor [1st egg did break]
+(x ‚Äî 2) for floors in between [with 2nd egg]
Total = 1 + 1 + (x ‚Äî 2) = x
Again the total drops even in this case comes out to be x.
We can continue it till 100 floors as shown in the figure.
Image for better explanation
We get this equation:
x + (x ‚Äî 1) + (x ‚Äî 2) + ‚Ä¶ + 1 ‚â• 100
This is the sum of the first x natural numbers:
x ( x + 1) / 2 ‚â• 100
x ‚â• 13.651
For the integer value, we take x = 14.
The table below gives you the strategy and tells you which floor to throw your 1st egg from. And if it breaks on that floor then how many drops of 2nd egg are required in the worst-case.
+-------------+-----------+-----------------------+---------------------+
| Times 1st   | Floor Num | 2nd Egg Drops (if 1st | Worst Case Total    |
| Egg Dropped |           | breaks at this floor) | Tries (Col1 + Col3) |
+-------------+-----------+-----------------------+---------------------+
| #1          |        14 |                    13 |                  14 |
| #2          |        27 |                    12 |                  14 |
| #3          |        39 |                    11 |                  14 |
| #4          |        50 |                    10 |                  14 |
| #5          |        60 |                     9 |                  14 |
| #6          |        69 |                     8 |                  14 |
| #7          |        77 |                     7 |                  14 |
| #8          |        84 |                     6 |                  14 |
| #9          |        90 |                     5 |                  14 |
| #10         |        95 |                     4 |                  14 |
| #11         |        99 |                     3 |                  14 |
| #12         |       100 |                     0 |                  12 |
+-------------+-----------+-----------------------+---------------------+
Final Answer
We can determine the ‚Äúsafe floor‚Äù even in the worst-case scenario in a maximum of 14 egg drops.
Concluding Thoughts
A more generalized version of the problem deals with k floors and n eggs. With the n = 1 egg strategy in mind, one can think of the solution recursively, making it the base case.
If we drop one egg from a floor x, there are 2 possibilities, either it will break or it doesn‚Äôt.
1. If the egg breaks, then only floors lower than x are needed to be checked with the remaining eggs. So the problem reduces to x ‚Äî 1 floors and n ‚Äî 1 eggs.
2. If the egg doesn‚Äôt break, then only floors higher than x needs to be checked. So the problem reduces to k ‚Äî x floors and n eggs.
You can code a simple recursive solution for this problem easily but a few optimizations are needed in order for it to accept large values of n and k. For that, we need Dynamic Programming Approach which is beyond the scope of this article. If you want a story on that, do let me know in the comments.
If you found this useful, feel free to clap, comment, highlight or follow me. We all go further when we help each other!
Cheers ‚Äî RS !!

What Does The Latest Tiobe Index Say About The Future Of Programming?
Not at all what some software engineers might expect, though there is one constant that will remain unchanged‚Ä¶
Attila V√°g√≥
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Oct 19, 2024
1.1K
31
Illustration made in Apple Freeform by author. Logos by (from left to right): Rust Foundation, Public Domain, Mark Anderson, Jeremy Kratz, python.org
T
here are two kinds of software engineers: those who care about programming languages, and those who don‚Äôt. If you ask me, neither of the groups are wrong or right. The former care about working on projects that use cutting-edge technology, the latter care more about sticking to the tried-and-tested. There‚Äôs no convincing me either of these groups is adopting the wrong career strategy. That said, regardless of how you set up your programming career, keeping an eye on progress has never hurt anyone. I tend to lean a bit towards the latter group, but find myself curious enough to check various programming trends once in a while and draw relevant conclusions. The Tiobe Index is one of my reliable sources of such trends, and this October‚Äôs numbers are worth taking a closer look at.
Tiobe Index of October 2024. Screenshot by author.
Let me preface my thoughts with a constant. Software engineering always had a shifting landscape. That said, changes also don‚Äôt happen overnight. No popularity index will change that, nor should it fuel any kind of hype or doom-and-gloom. Allegedly, PHP has been ‚Äúdead‚Äù for about a decade now, and TypeScript is the best invention since fire. Clearly, neither of those statements ever proved to be true.
Programming languages don‚Äôt just come and go. They also stay a while. Remember that.
Perhaps the most (un)surprising is the number one spot occupied by Python. Frankly, while the mainstream media seemed surprised about Python‚Äôs meteoric rise to the number one spot, it‚Äôs nothing new. C# might have won ‚Äúlanguage of the year‚Äù in 2023, but with AI still enjoying a hype phase, Python‚Äôs popularity was bound to shoot up like crazy again. It has actually been quite consistent at ruling one of the top five spots in language leaderboards. While I am often regarded as an AI-skeptic, this newfound universal love for Python proves yet again what myself and many have been saying for quite a while now ‚Äî generative AI is still just machine learning and machine learning is nothing new. I remember studying Human-Computer Interaction over 10 years ago, and Python enjoying a very similar popularity surge because of it.
What I think is far more useful to remember here, is that Python is a multipurpose language, so if you‚Äôre new to programming, it‚Äôs a great one to start with ‚Äî though certainly not my personal favourite. If you‚Äôre already a seasoned Python engineer, then it just confirms you‚Äôre on the right track and career-wise you‚Äôre all set, you don‚Äôt even have to wonder what else is out there.
Moving on from Python, another interesting language on the list is PHP ‚Äî the language that everyone keeps calling dead, all the while it keeps powering most of the web. Sure, it has fallen a fair bit on the leaderboard since last year, but still being part of the top 20 languages is no small feat when it has to compete with languages like Swift (20th place) and Rust (13th place).
PHP developers are in no danger whatsoever. It‚Äôs still a perfectly fine language, even for newbies.
But speaking of Rust, it‚Äôs undeniably on a rising trajectory. It‚Äôs popular enough that it overtook PHP and Ruby. Personally, I am neither for nor against the language. I do wish there was less hype around it, though, as it often feels pushed religiously rather than pragmatically as an option for building software products ‚Äî and that‚Äôs never a good thing. Rebuilding everything in Rust is most definitely a waste of resources and time. Many of us senior engineers know that simply rebuilding something in a new language doesn‚Äôt improve it, heck, it typically introduces new problems. That‚Äôs not to say, of course, that you should ignore Rust. On the contrary, if anything, perhaps you should pay attention to Rust instead of TypeScript, which brings me to my next point.
For a language that‚Äôs touted as being more transformative than the Industrial Revolution, year-after-year it ‚Äî TypeScript ‚Äî just seems to get way less traction than its hard-core fans would have you believe. At 37th place, it‚Äôs nowhere near the leaderboard, and it would have to climb 32 places to displace JavaScript from its very respectable 6th place. Look, I‚Äôm not hating on TypeScript, I use it almost daily as part of my job. I don‚Äôt see much value in it, especially when modern JavaScript does a lot of what TypeScript was invented for, but I don‚Äôt have a problem taking on TypeScript projects. For me, the cost-benefit ratio just doesn‚Äôt make sense, especially on the frontend.
Five years into my career, I stopped caring about programming languages. I care much more about building successful software products.
Years later, that sentiment still hasn‚Äôt changed, and therefore if I were to make a pragmatic choice as to which language will allow me to build more successful products in the future, I would not choose TypeScript, I would go with Rust instead. I even have a suspicion some of TypeScript‚Äôs waning popularity can actually be directly attributed to the rise of Rust. It‚Äôs but a theory. What do you think?
Speaking of rising stars, another one that made me feel all warm and fuzzy inside was seeing COBOL on 19th place. For such an old language, that‚Äôs pretty impressive. Can you believe it‚Äôs more popular than Swift? And Swift has all of Apple‚Äôs trillion-dollar muscle behind it. That said, it‚Äôs not entirely surprising to see COBOL doing so well. While it may have appeared first 65 years ago, it got a major update in 2002 when it became object-oriented. Many governments, administrative and business systems run on COBOL, and those all need maintenance. Since 2002 it has been getting periodical smaller updates, the latest version being COBOL 2023 that allows even for asynchronous messaging! I would not recommend it to new programmers, but those on the senior end might want to consider giving it a go, especially if there are COBOL jobs in their area, and they‚Äôre willing to commute to the office. While not all make this a requirement, and technically, one could argue there shouldn‚Äôt even be such a requirement in place to begin with, many COBOL jobs mean you‚Äôll have to work in the office.
Knock, knock. Who‚Äôs there? Long pause‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs me, Java.
Another language that‚Äôs been prematurely considered a dying language by many over the years is Java, but guess what? It‚Äôs only gotten more popular. Besides the fact that it‚Äôs now in 3rd place after Python and C++. Mike Melanson wrote an excellent article about the state of Java and some of its history, so give that a read, you‚Äôll learn more than I could ever squeeze into a paragraph. The TLDR of it is, though, as he put it in 2022:
After nearly 30 years of Java, you might expect the language to be showing some signs of wear and tear, but nothing could be further from the truth. Java in 2022 is not a language in decline, but rather a language preparing for the effervescent future of software development.
It‚Äôs clearly a language that many businesses, developers and open-source projects heavily rely on and encourage. The mid-2010‚Äôs definitely did a good job bringing back innovation in the Java space, so I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs going anywhere for a long time. In fact, I am about as certain about its bright future as I am about Python‚Äôs.
Finally, you might dismiss Scratch as a language ‚Äúnot for real programming‚Äù, but it‚Äôs not on the Tiobe Index for no reason, and I am delighted to still see it ‚Äî albeit on 14th place ‚Äî on the leaderboard. Teaching coding, programming, developing these skills early on in a child‚Äôs life is invaluable. I discovered Scratch as I was doing my Harvard CS50 course in my mid-twenties, and even so, I found it fascinating and an excellent first step in one‚Äôs programming journey. This is a good sign, especially in a world that hypes up generative AI as a ‚Äúcoder killer‚Äù.
Looking at the next decade
A decade is a long time, but if you look at the Tiobe Index, you‚Äôll quickly realise, programming hasn‚Äôt changed as much as some might have you believe. Even a quick glance tells you that apart from Rust, all the other languages were either getting started or were popular already 10 years ago.
Some languages that I would consider a great bet for the next decade are JavaScript, Python, Java, C in all its ‚Äúflavours‚Äù, PHP and even Swift as I don‚Äôt quite see Apple going anywhere either. And when it comes to all the others, just like I said before, programming languages don‚Äôt just come and go, they stay for a while. That ‚Äúwhile‚Äù will be enough to build solid programming muscles and start caring a lot less about the language, and a lot more about the things you build with them.
Take, for instance, Ruby. It fell from grace a while ago, but it‚Äôs still around. Sure, I just migrated dozens of end-to-end tests written in Ruby to a Java-based framework, but that decision was driven solely by not wanting to have code written in a language we had no skills in our company for. A more Ruby and Ruby-on-Rails focused business would have probably killed to have their Cucumber tests written in Ruby and not JavaScript.
The bottom line here remains mostly unchanged. Many languages stay around for a long time because we have invested in them, and often times you really don‚Äôt have to fix something that ain‚Äôt broken.
That, of course, doesn‚Äôt stop new languages from appearing and overtaking some older ones, and there will always be new businesses that will jump on that bandwagon and invest in them too. It‚Äôs perfectly normal. In the grand scheme of things, languages moving up and down the Tiobe Index leaderboard, or any other popularity index for that matter, means very little, especially to the seasoned engineer.
For everyone else, I‚Äôll suggest what I always do ‚Äî go for popular, multipurpose languages that offer good job prospects in your area. That will give you the runway to work on your career, work in that language for 5‚Äì10 years, and become the senior ‚Äî aka the category mentioned above ‚Äî who‚Äôll happily jump on any language, should the project require it.
You don‚Äôt have to use popular programming languages to be a successful engineer or build great products. You just have to love programming.

Zig‚Äôs New Masterpiece: HashiCorp Co-founder‚Äôs Latest Creation Takes the Programming World by Storm! Even Redis Creator Says It‚Äôs a Game-Changer!
Dylan Cooper
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
9 min read
¬∑
Jan 13, 2025
779
10
Recently, a terminal emulator written in Zig reached its official 1.0 release, making waves across the programming community.
Ghostty, since its debut, has garnered widespread attention ‚Äî not only due to its creator Mitchell Hashimoto‚Äôs impressive credentials but also because of its exceptional quality, which has breathed new life into the long-stagnant terminal emulator space.
As a co-founder of HashiCorp, Hashimoto played a pivotal role in creating flagship products like Terraform, Vagrant, Packer, and Nomad ‚Äî tools that have become indispensable for DevOps professionals worldwide.
Ghostty is a free, open-source application licensed under MIT, designed to offer a seamless, out-of-the-box experience with no additional configuration required.
Written in Zig, Ghostty boasts GPU acceleration, cross-platform support, and is available for Mac and Linux systems at launch.
For its cross-platform support, Ghostty uses platform-native GUI frameworks: SwiftUI on macOS and Zig with GTK on Linux.
Even antirez, the creator of Redis, couldn‚Äôt hide his excitement about Ghostty 1.0:
‚ÄúThis is a game-changing tool. I was just debugging some Redis work, outputting a huge volume of debug information and results. Normally, the terminal becomes the bottleneck, but this tool handled 500,000 lines of output instantly.
Plus, I could scroll back through the history effortlessly, with no performance drop. I absolutely love this! For systems development, this is a massive improvement.‚Äù
01 Why Choose the Zig Programming Language?
When asked why he chose Zig for his project, Mitchell Hashimoto gave a straightforward answer:
‚ÄúI chose Zig because I like it! Its language features are a perfect fit for this terminal project.‚Äù
Hashimoto‚Äôs interest in Zig dates back to late 2021 or early 2022. At the time, he shared his curiosity about the language on Twitter but couldn‚Äôt explore it deeply due to a busy schedule. However, Zig remained on his mind.
‚ÄúBy way of background, I used to be a professional C programmer for about a year or two. I‚Äôve always enjoyed low-level systems development and actually like C. In fact, all HashiCorp software was nearly written in C ‚Äî we were deciding between C and Go, and Go won in the end, but we came very close to choosing C.
I wanted to return to systems programming but was well aware of C‚Äôs shortcomings. So, I‚Äôve been searching for a ‚Äòbetter C.‚Äô From the start, Zig felt like that language to me. After using Zig for several years, my feelings haven‚Äôt changed ‚Äî they‚Äôve only grown stronger. Writing Zig code brings me joy every day‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs what really matters.‚Äù
Hashimoto also clarified why he didn‚Äôt choose Rust:
‚ÄúI have enough experience with Rust to know I don‚Äôt want to write it every day. From a philosophical and technical achievement perspective, I deeply admire Rust and think it‚Äôs outstanding. However, my personal experience has felt more surface-level. When writing or reading Rust code, I just didn‚Äôt find it enjoyable.
For me, the process of development should be fun ‚Äî writing code should be a source of happiness. This choice is entirely about style.‚Äù
Unlike most other programming languages, Zig offers true seamless interoperability with existing C code ‚Äî a feature of immense importance. As Loris Cro, Vice President of Community at the Zig Software Foundation, explained:
‚ÄúZig has essentially revolutionized traditional programming infrastructure, breaking conventions that have remained untouched for the past 40 years. C and C++ are renowned programming languages and the backbone of software development, providing complete hardware control. However, their toolchains are fraught with issues.‚Äù
Zig, on the other hand, retains the core functionality of these languages while offering a more powerful toolchain and enhanced feature set.
Additionally, Zig addresses a critical pain point in traditional C/C++ development: cross-platform compilation. For example, if you‚Äôre developing a small indie game and want to deliver it to Mac users, you‚Äôd typically face significant challenges compiling game code from Windows to Mac. With Zig, this process becomes seamless, regardless of whether the code is written in Zig, C, C++, or a combination thereof. Zig ensures smooth cross-platform compilation with excellent support for macOS and Linux.
As a relatively new programming language, Zig has gained increased visibility thanks to the success of Ghostty, which has become one of Zig‚Äôs flagships.
Other companies are also betting on Zig. For instance:
Bun, a competing alternative to Node.js.
Tiger Beetle, aiming to build a distributed financial database with precise resource control.
Uber, which uses Zig (not as a primary language) to build toolchains for C and C++ code, leveraging Zig‚Äôs powerful compilation capabilities.
With its unique strengths and growing adoption, Zig is quickly becoming a favorite for developers looking for low-level control with modern conveniences.
02 Surpassing C and Rust in Design Philosophy?
It is worth noting that, according to the 2024 Stack Overflow Developer Survey, Zig ranked as the highest-paying programming language of the year. This survey, which included 89,184 software developers from 185 countries, revealed that the average annual salary for Zig developers reached $103,000. This recognition has catapulted Zig into the spotlight, rapidly drawing attention from developers worldwide.
Among the surveyed developers, only 0.83% reported proficiency in Zig, highlighting its relative obscurity and scarcity in the talent pool. This rarity, combined with the rising demand for high-performance systems programming, likely contributes to the impressive salary figures for Zig developers.
Zig‚Äôs creator, Andrew Kelley, has a clear vision for the language: he aims for Zig to become the successor to C. Through an in-depth exploration of C‚Äôs foundational design, Andrew identified that many widely accepted features of the language were not always rooted in optimal design principles. This realization led him to fundamentally rethink programming language design. Andrew believes that Zig should not simply be an upgraded version of C but a fundamentally different language built on better foundational logic.
Andrew introduced the concept of ‚Äúglobal maximization‚Äù in language design, emphasizing a focus on optimizing the language as a whole rather than settling for isolated, localized improvements. He argues that while some of C‚Äôs design choices were reasonable at the time of its creation, they have imposed long-term limitations on its evolution. Zig aims to break free from these constraints, offering a language that is more scalable, adaptable, and future-proof.
To achieve this vision, the Zig team has revisited many traditional concepts in C. For instance, they have completely eliminated preprocessors and macros, which are extensively used in C. While this might seem radical, it simplifies the language design and ensures greater consistency. Zig also introduces a more intuitive memory management mechanism that is not only easier to understand but also outperforms C in terms of efficiency.
Zig‚Äôs design philosophy represents a fundamental transformation of C. Rather than merely modernizing legacy features, it reimagines the essence of systems programming, establishing Zig as a bold step forward in the evolution of high-performance programming languages.
2.1 The Practical Effects of Zig‚Äôs Design Approach
Andrew Kelley has always been relentless in questioning the principles behind programming languages. He challenges deeply rooted conventions in C, such as, ‚ÄúWhy use #define instead of constants?" While many programmers take such practices for granted, few stop to question their rationale. Andrew points out that this design choice is flawed because using constants in some scenarios can trigger compilation errors, even when it shouldn‚Äôt.
In Zig, he resolved this issue: ‚ÄúWe simply fixed the problem, allowing constants to be used where they should be. It‚Äôs that simple, and it‚Äôs also what defines Zig.‚Äù By adopting this design philosophy, Andrew discovered that fixing C‚Äôs logical inconsistencies made the preprocessor entirely unnecessary. Instead, Zig employs conditional compilation. This is a key difference between Zig and C: in Zig, what matters is whether the condition of an if statement is known at compile time. If a dead branch of an if statement contains a compilation error, it is simply not evaluated.
This approach enables Zig to discard certain C features while maintaining ‚Äî or even improving ‚Äî usability, safety, and performance. With its distinctive design philosophy, Zig introduces fresh perspectives on development.
Initially, Zig was created to ‚Äúfill the gaps in C,‚Äù but as the project evolved, it grew into a more powerful and flexible programming tool. Its unique advantages are particularly evident in memory management.
Unlike traditional memory allocation methods, Zig does not have a global allocator. Instead, custom allocators are passed explicitly wherever memory is needed. This allows Zig to function effectively in environments where standard libraries are unavailable, such as in kernels or on Arduino platforms.
This memory allocation approach eliminates hidden allocation mechanisms. Hidden allocations disrupt the intuitive flow of control and function calls, making it difficult for developers to reuse existing code without interference.
In Zig, memory allocators are optional features of the standard library rather than being built into the language. These allocators can be customized ‚Äî for instance, using malloc() for desktop runtime or a kernel allocator from the standard library for kernel environments. This flexibility prevents developers from having to rewrite data structures like HashMap. By convention, Zig does have a global allocator, which Andrew encourages developers to use in all unit tests. This ensures that if there are memory leaks, the unit tests can detect them before the code causes actual leaks in practice.
2.2 Speed and Safety Together
Photo by Rahul Mishra on Unsplash
Zig outperforms C in terms of speed. This is partly due to its data-oriented design approach, which enhances Zig‚Äôs performance and achieves execution speeds unattainable by other languages.
Andrew‚Äôs model of how CPU cache systems work is straightforward: the less memory occupied, the less strain on the CPU. Based on this observation, he focused on reducing the amount of memory used when creating objects in Zig‚Äôs self-hosted compiler. As a result, the compiler consumes less memory, relieving CPU cache pressure and accelerating code execution. Tests have shown that Zig‚Äôs performance advantage can be as high as 35%.
Andrew explained that this level of optimization is nearly impossible in languages like Rust. One of the key components behind Zig‚Äôs performance boost is its untagged union. By storing tags in a separate array, Zig reduces cache pressure. In contrast, in Rust, the lack of untagged unions impacts code safety if developers attempt similar optimizations.
The trade-off with Rust is this: to write faster and safer code, one must sacrifice the ability to fully leverage hardware capabilities. Conversely, to maximize hardware performance, some code safety must be compromised. Zig, however, avoids this trade-off. It allows developers to write faster-running code while also performing safety checks on untagged unions to ensure security.
Zig takes a more incremental approach to safety, avoiding the pitfalls of adhering to an ‚Äúall-encompassing safety model.‚Äù This deliberate design makes Zig a language that balances high performance with comprehensive functionality, offering a unique and powerful solution for modern programming challenges.
