5 Reasons No One Is Reading Your Writing
This is why I get 1000 reads a day
Derek Hughes
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Never Stop Writing
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Dec 24, 2024
7.8K
216
Photo by Clem Onojeghuo:
Writing can feel like a lonely struggle.
Self-doubt whispers in your ear. Numbers on a screen taunt you. And you can‚Äôt stop comparing your failures with the success of others. It drains your energy and drags you down.
But it‚Äôs not about you.
Get out of your own head. And spend more time hanging out in your reader‚Äôs head. The moment I shifted my focus from my insecurities to my audience‚Äôs needs. Everything changed. Suddenly, my words resonated. Now, 1,000 people show up to read what I write every day.
The secret to success is knowing the five things readers crave most. And deliver them consistently. It‚Äôs not easy to write with your reader in mind, but if you master this.
To make your writing dreams come true. Give readers these 5 things.
1. Solve my problems
Readers are like detectives looking for clues to make their lives better.
They want information they can use. Don‚Äôt start with your topic. Start with their pain point. Focus on what matters to them. Give them something valuable to take away. Solve their most pressing problems.
Their big three needs are:
something they can use
a new way of thinking
belief they can do it
Find a way to offer tangible solutions.
‚ÄúDescription begins in the writer‚Äôs imagination, but should finish in the reader‚Äôs.‚Äù Stephen King
When I stopped using vague advice and focused on my audience‚Äôs challenges, my engagement soared. Find out what frustrates your readers and create content that solves those problems.
Your writing will go from mere words to a valuable resource.
2. Let me see the real you
Your story keeps readers coming back.
Readers want to get a glimpse of you through your words. This is why generic listicles fall flat. Readers crave authenticity. They‚Äôre flooded with information. They want real stories that connect. So don‚Äôt be afraid to be yourself. This is your greatest weapon.
When you share your real experiences. You open the door and invite readers into your world. This is what forges a connection. And keeps them coming back for more.
When I started writing. I felt like an imposter. That I needed to pretend to be better than I am. I feared what I had wasn‚Äôt enough. I‚Äôd try to imitate the top writers. But no one was interested in my best Tim Denning impression.
So in desperation, I started sharing myself. It‚Äôs all I had. I celebrated my embarrassingly small triumphs. I was so excited to reach 100 followers and then there was the moment of earning $10.07 in month 4.
I even went a step further and wrote about my deep failures. How I honestly felt about them and what I‚Äôd learned. The response was surprising. These articles gained views and comments. I even started to pick up followers.
Be brave and be real.
3. Keep me enthralled
This is controversial. But all writing needs to entertain the reader.
Boredom is the enemy you need to dodge. Learn how to give enjoyment and intrigue. Think beyond words. Take your readers on an exciting adventure. (This doesn‚Äôt mean you only entertain ‚Äî see point 2).
Take a moment to imagine the moment. Your reader looks at your writing. Where are they? What are they doing?
waiting for a meeting to start
about to watch Netflix
avoiding their work
at the bus stop
in a queue
I hate to break it to you.
But they haven‚Äôt put aside all their distractions. Allocated some study time to read your gems. This means you need to use some clever tactics to keep their interest.
Anything can be entertaining. I recently drew writing lessons from a biologist‚Äôs description of ant behaviour. He used a metaphor comparing ants to humans. It was shocking (they engage in child labour and slavery) and amusing (they don‚Äôt watch TV). If he can do it so can you!
Make every sentence impossible to ignore.
4. Get to the point
Readers are impatient.
They have so many choices. They don‚Äôt want to waste their time. So do them a favour. Get to the point. They want quick, tasty and nutritious food. They don‚Äôt have time for a leisurely, drawn-out 7-course banquet.
This doesn‚Äôt mean they want fast food full of empty calories. Keep the substance but cut the fluff. Let‚Äôs be honest. This is hard. We get too attached to our words. We love the extra flourishes. Our points get an additional sentence because we feel they are so important.
Readers treasure brevity without compromising substance.
The best way to do this is to get clear on the problem. Then include elements essential to solving it. Drop everything else (no matter how insightful!). When editing ask yourself. What can I delete and still get the message across?
‚ÄúWhen your story is ready for a rewrite, cut it to the bone. Get rid of every ounce of excess fat.‚Äù Stephen King
One change I‚Äôm making is shorter introductions. I used to build up. Set the context. But I‚Äôve halved the length. This has boosted views and comments. increased. You‚Äôll lose your reader if you don‚Äôt respect their time.
Say more with less
5. Make it effortless to read
Readers want clear and simple stuff.
So make your paragraphs short. Cut the fancy words. Drop the long sentences. Break big ideas down into small pieces. Make everything easy to digest. This section could have been called Prioritize clarity and simplicity. But I practice what I preach.
Research shows why this works.
Professor Tsuyoshi Okuhara from Tokyo University did an experiment. He tested the effect of simple writing on people‚Äôs confidence to take action. He asked 400 people, aged 40‚Äì69 to read some exercise guidance. Half got the standard stuff and half got an ‚Äòeasy-to-read‚Äô version. The simplified content had shorter sentences and words. This change has a dramatic effect.
The simpler writing gave readers confidence they could act on the content. Brain scans show when words are easy to understand. The pleasure part of the brain lights up. Simple writing makes a reader‚Äôs brain smile.
‚ÄúSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication.‚Äù Leonardo Da Vinci
Clarity turns readers into fans.
Give readers what they want and they won‚Äôt be able to resist your content.
I‚Äôve gained 16,000 followers in 12 months. If you want my 5-step writing system. Join 4487 other writers and sign up for my free course here:
Free email course
Three minutes a day puts the tools you need in your hands. Use them to become a compelling writer and raise your game.

If you had to guess what the happiest state in America is, which would you choose?
And what would you base it on?
Everyone will have different answers to these questions, but it turns out someone has actually crunched some hard numbers to try and determine an objective answer.
And that answer might surprise you!
Actually, it won‚Äôt at all ‚Äî the happiest state in America is Hawaii thanks to its fantastic weather, incredible landscapes, and high living standards.
The only downside?
It‚Äôs expensive as hell to live there.
In fact, Hawaii has the highest average home price in America.
But if you can‚Äôt afford Hawaii, are there some better options a little further down the list of most joyful states that might interest you?
And what‚Äôs the ‚Ññ1 most depressed state you should avoid at all costs?
Read on!
It‚Äôs no surprise Hawaiians live in the happiest state, what with the high income, fantastic weather, and beautiful scenery. (Licensed by the author under the Unsplash+ License)
The happiest states in America
Each year, the personal finance website WalletHub ranks every state in America from happiest to saddest.
It does so using a wide range of criteria drawn from a wide range of sources, but effectively the rating comes down to three main categories:
Emotional & Physical Well-Being (life expectancy, rate of alcohol use disorder, depression statistics, food insecurity rate, etc.)
Work Environment (unemployment rate, average commute times, median credit score, etc.)
Community & Environment (ideal weather, volunteer and leisure time rates, divorce rate, etc.)
Using these criteria, WalletHub determined the three happiest states are:
Hawaii
Maryland
New Jersey
Here, according to the site, is why those Hawaiians are so darn happy:
‚ÄúHawaii is the happiest state, living up to its reputation as an island paradise, with residents reporting the highest levels of life satisfaction in the nation and the lowest depression rate.
‚ÄúHawaiians also enjoy great physical health, with 86% of adults reporting that they are in good or better health, the second-best percentage in the nation.
‚ÄúHawaiians also have the longest life expectancy in the U.S., and nearly 72% of adults in the state report being active and productive on a daily basis.
‚ÄúTo top things off, positive economic conditions help Hawaiians stay happy. Hawaii has one of the lowest unemployment rates in the nation, at 2.8%, as well as the second-highest share of households with an annual income above $75,000.
‚ÄúAnd while that means residents are working hard, they still get to enjoy the third-most leisure time in the country.‚Äù
Sign me up!
Jersey always surprises me when it ranks near the top of these types of things (probably because I‚Äôve only ever been to Newark), but it just keeps delivering.
Recently I wrote about another quality of life ranking, and the Garden State reached ‚Ññ3 there.
What finished last in that ranking?
Texas.
But WalletHub suggests there‚Äôs a worse option out there.
My recent YouTube video looked at another state to avoid.
The most depressed state in America
Does the low quality of life in Texas also make it the most depressed?
Not so fast.
Although Texas has room to improve in areas like healthcare and inclusion, CNBC ranked it as the Number 1 state for business friendliness.
Access to money tends to make people a bit happier, doesn‚Äôt it?
No, according to WalletHub, the saddest state in America ‚Äî and this one might actually surprise you ‚Äî is Louisiana.
Although the first thing that pops into most people‚Äôs heads when they think about Louisiana is Mardi Gras, evidently it‚Äôs less of a party if you actually live there.
Mardi Gras may be a fun time, but day-to-day live in Louisiana is much tougher. (Licensed by the author under the Unsplash+ License)
Terrible rankings across the board
In fact, it ranked terribly across the board:
Emotional & Physical Well-Being rank: 49th
Work Environment rank: 49th
Community & Environment rank: 40th
WalletHub isn‚Äôt alone in slamming Louisiana.
Earlier this year, U.S News and World Report ranked it as the overall worst state in America.
Crushing poverty, lots of violent crime, high obesity rates, and sometimes disastrous weather all play a part.

Where would you live if you had the choice?

How Reading Can Literally Change Your Brain Chemistry
The science behind books‚Äô brain-boosting powers
Margaret Pan
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Books Are Our Superpower
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
May 21, 2024
6.9K
242
Image generated via Lexica.art
Growing up, I was the only kid among my friends‚Äô cycle who liked reading books.
While I found my sanctuary in the world of literature, they preferred sports or video games and most of them viewed reading as a hobby for nerds. In high school, some classmates even mocked me for it: I was the bookworm, the one who‚Äôd rather spend Saturday nights with a paperback than at a crowded party.
I never let any teasing get to me because I knew my love for books was rewiring my brain in ways they couldn‚Äôt even imagine. What most people don‚Äôt realize about reading is that it‚Äôs much more than a nerdy pastime that helps you escape reality or pass the time.
When you read, your brain undergoes various neurological processes, which in other words means that reading is capable of literally changing your brain chemistry.
I‚Äôll explain how in this article. You don‚Äôt have to take my word for it of course ‚Äî everything is backed up by science.
The Release of Neurotransmitters
Whenever I‚Äôm feeling stressed or overwhelmed, I always reach for a book instead of my phone.
Nine times out of ten, getting lost in a good story and someone else‚Äôs narrative (and, you know, seeing there are far worse problems than mine) helps me calm my mind ‚Äî and it‚Äôs not even a placebo effect.
Science explains that reading can rewire your neural pathways and trigger the release of neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin, and endorphins.
These neurotransmitters are like the messengers of your brain, carrying important signals that can affect everything from your mood to your motivation. The specific trio I mentioned above are associated with feelings of pleasure, relaxation, and happiness.
I‚Äôve found reading to be particularly helpful whenever my depression flares up. I usually opt for fantasy books or feel-good novels ‚Äî they always manage to distract me from the heaviness of my thoughts. It‚Äôs empowering to know that it‚Äôs not just me: This study found that people who participated in a bibliotherapy program, which involved reading and discussing fiction novels, experienced significant reductions in symptoms of depression compared to a control group.
When you read something enjoyable or emotionally resonant, you‚Äôre literally changing your brain chemistry by giving your brain a powerful boost of feel-good hormones.
Your worries might not disappear entirely, but they sure won‚Äôt feel as heavy when you‚Äôre lost in a good read.
An Antidote to Stress
I know that when you‚Äôre feeling stressed, picking up a book might not be the first thing that comes to mind.
You might prefer to watch videos on TikTok, binge-watch a TV show or go for a walk. Obviously, everyone has their own ways of coping with stress, but here‚Äôs my advice: don‚Äôt underestimate the power of reading as a stress-relief tool.
Reading has been shown to reduce stress levels by activating the parasympathetic nervous system, which promotes relaxation and calms your body‚Äôs stress response. The levels of stress-related hormones such as cortisol also decline, contributing to a more balanced brain chemistry.
Now I know what you might be thinking: there‚Äôs no way reading a book can be compared with physical exercise or going out with a friend. Well, check this out: In this study, reading was found to be as effective as yoga and humor in reducing feelings of stress over a 30-minute period and it can even lower your blood pressure and heart rate.
Amazing, right? Now I have an excuse to go buy more books.
If you‚Äôre wondering what genre of book you should choose, I‚Äôve got great news for you: it doesn‚Äôt matter.
According to Dr. David Lewis, a cognitive neuropsychologist who conducted a study that found reading can reduce stress by as much as 68%:
‚ÄúLosing yourself in a book is the ultimate relaxation.It really doesn‚Äôt matter what book you read, by losing yourself in a thoroughly engrossing book you can escape from the worries and stresses of the everyday world and spend a while exploring the domain of the author‚Äôs imagination.‚Äù
Brain Bootcamp
Most people‚Äôs go-to place for knowledge is YouTube videos.
Short videos might help you understand a topic, but only on the surface. I think they‚Äôre a good starting point for exploring something, but they‚Äôre just that ‚Äîa starting point. They don‚Äôt allow you to dive deeper into a subject matter, not like a book can.
Even Elon Musk who, whether you like or hate him, is one of the most innovative minds in today‚Äôs business world, has said that growing up, he spent more than 10 hours a day pouring through science fiction novels.
I‚Äôm not surprised, because reading leads to better, well, almost everything, memory, critical thinking, language processing ‚Äî you name it. It‚Äôs exercise for your mental muscles.
Reading makes you smarter, or, to be more scientific, it enhances your cognitive functions.
Let‚Äôs skip the obvious part ‚Äî that books make you smarter by putting knowledge directly into your hands. When you read, you stimulate multiple areas of your brain, increasing brain connectivity (meaning that different regions of your brain communicate more effectively with each other) over time. These changes in your brain activity influence the balance of neurotransmitters and neurochemicals involved in cognitive processes.
As you engage with a book, your brain forms new neural connections and pathways, leading to improved cognitive function. Your brain is literally rewiring itself.
Empathic Resonance
Did you know that reading can rewire your brain in ways that make you a better person?
If you‚Äôve been reading fiction for a while, you‚Äôve probably witnessed it for yourself: how empathizing with fictional characters can make you more empathetic towards people in the real world.
Science backs this up as well ‚Äî reading fiction has been linked with increased empathy and understanding.
Here‚Äôs how it‚Äôs explained: reading fiction activates brain areas linked to sensory experiences in ways that mimic the neural activities of the experience you‚Äôre reading about. When you read, you‚Äôre absorbing experiences, perspectives, and emotions. Through books, you can basically experience the experiences of others, getting you neurologically one step closer to an understanding necessary for empathy.
It‚Äôs also been proven that reading evolves our theory of mind, which involves recognizing that others have thoughts, feelings, and perspectives that may differ from our own.
I know firsthand the transformative power of reading. I‚Äôve shared before how certain books have inspired me to be more kind toward others, by showing me characters with lives entirely different than my own and allowing me to walk in their shoes. I find it incredible how the stories we read can impact our understanding of the world and our relationships with others.
Reading truly transforms your brain ‚Äî and consequently, your character.
Every time someone tells me they don‚Äôt see the point in reading, that
they‚Äôd rather binge-watch TV, or that they ‚Äújust can‚Äôt get into it‚Äù, I just smile and nod and wonder how so many people are oblivious to the power books have.
And we‚Äôre talking altering-the-brain‚Äôs-chemistry power.
You don‚Äôt even have to be a bookworm to reap the rewards of reading. The simple act of engaging with a book consistently can have incredible effects on your brain.
Because reading isn‚Äôt just a hobby ‚Äî it‚Äôs the key to unlocking new worlds, expanding your mind, and yes, even changing your brain chemistry for the better.
Thank you for reading! If you liked these book recommendations, consider subscribing to my book newsletter! It‚Äôs free, and each month you‚Äôll get book reviews, book recommendations, and reading tips!<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

MATH
How Mathematics Was Useful for Me in Programming
Josef Cruz
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Oct 23, 2024
498
9
I‚Äôll explain.
Photo by Antoine Dautry on Unsplash
Mathematics. Yes, this is the same, completely unclaimed science, forgotten since graduation from university, suddenly became very popular with the emergence of such a direction as Data Science. The fact is that in 3D graphics, it is used almost continuously, and there is no need to mention it.
I‚Äôm quite a mathematician.
It just so happens that with a minimal set of mathematical functions, a good (and not-so-good) programmer can solve almost any problem. The same operation of raising to a power can be relatively easily replaced by a cycle of multiplications (at least as long as the power is an integer).
And, it would seem, we can finish here, that‚Äôs it, we‚Äôll go our separate ways. But, as in the joke, there is a nuance (although in the joke version that I know, it was about the nose). It‚Äôs all about productivity.
Even though for most relatively simple problems, you don‚Äôt have to know the mathematical apparatus (and no one will scold you for it), there are problems where trying to use sines or square roots too often leads to everything starting to slow down mercilessly and using the application becomes simply impossible (or rather, it is possible, but you need bottomless reserves of sedatives).
How I Converted to Mathematical Faith
About ten years ago, I applied for a job as a lead in a company, and, of course, they interviewed me. Since the company was working on machine vision, which was not very popular at the time, they also dragged me through math.
The question was simple: I have a deposit of 5% per annum. How can I calculate how much the bank should pay me in N years, given that interest is accrued on the last day of the deposit and carried over to the next day?
Of course, I suggested writing a cycle (since I‚Äôm such a mathematician), where the coefficient would be multiplied depending on the number of years. But the answer didn‚Äôt go over well. In the end, having remembered a little mathematics, I found an extremely simple solution: SUM = <INITIAL CONTRIBUTION> √ó Math.pow(1.05, <YEARS>).
There were more complicated problems there, but this case literally turned my perception upside down and made me look at mathematics more closely. Later, there were problems with derivatives and Bezier curves for plotting graphs and determining whether points belong to curves, but that was later, and for now, I decided that it was better to know mathematics.
How matrices and vectors came in handy
I didn‚Äôt need them until I encountered 3D graphics. And it was justified: all the problems where they could be used were easily solved without these mathematical primitives.
If anyone doesn‚Äôt know, a matrix and a vector simply organize data subject to certain rules. You can multiply matrices by vectors or matrices by matrices and get some results. It‚Äôs a fairly common operation developers often perform with arrays or other data sets.
The case with 3D graphics made me look at all this differently: there, we were talking about processing coordinate values, and we had to do them very often.
Let‚Äôs say rotating a figure in three dimensions: for this, we need to calculate the displacement of a point along the X, Y, and Z axes. It‚Äôs a trivial matter. The problem is that all these operations need to be performed on each point of the figure. If, say, our figure consists of 50 points (vertices), then it‚Äôs easy to calculate that 150 operations must be performed.
The trick was that if you take the rotation matrices (a specific data entry responsible for the rotation of a point relative to an axis) along each axis and multiply them, you get a matrix that will become the resultant one: if you multiply the vertex vector (think of it as just coordinates) with it, you get the final offset coordinates.
That is 2 matrix multiplication operations and 50 vertex transformation operations = 52 operations. Against 150. And we don‚Äôt even take into account that in addition to rotation, there are offsets, scaling, and much more. In short, using matrices and their capabilities allowed us to achieve a colossal increase in productivity.
Mathematics at the core
Nowadays, it is rarely remembered that mathematics laid the foundation for programming, although not in the form that might be expected.
Mathematics was originally intended to work with abstractions, functions, and the like. Programming quickly encountered the need to solve a problem ‚Äúin general,‚Äù which would allow using the solution not only for a specific case but for a whole set of cases. For example, different forecasting algorithms can be used for a set of data of the same type and kind.
Trigonometry in action
Oddly enough, I find it useful very often. The secret is in the relative smoothness of the functions that allow a certain type of smoothing, such as the function of the smooth acceleration of an object on the screen.
It should be said that for such purposes, you can use other, more useful functions, such as Bezier curves, but sines and cosines are already built-in, and the calculated values are quite sufficient to ensure smoothness.
By the way, sine and cosine, working together, allow us to calculate the coordinates of a point moving in a circle very smoothly.
It can be useful when it is necessary to implement some indicator of circular loading or waiting programmatically.
Random numbers
There are also many examples of their use. And this is also, oddly enough, mathematics. You can create a function that generates values by having some conditionally unique value at the input (for example, a date). Of course, these will be pseudo-random numbers, but this approach can be safely used if we are not talking about cryptography.
To be honest, I use only standard generators, but I use them quite often. There are plenty of tasks where uncertainty is needed. Say, falling snowflakes: the coordinates of the next snowflake's appearance, the direction of movement, the speed of fall, and the amplitude of vibrations are all random numbers.
Speed of operation
All existing algorithms, whether we like it or not, rely on some mathematical foundation that allows us to determine their ultimate efficiency conditions.
Let‚Äôs say, sorting ‚Äî quite a few different algorithms give roughly similar results when working with a small set of data. The advantages of using certain algorithms emerge when the set of values is large enough. And all this is evaluated exclusively mathematically.
It just so happens that I haven‚Äôt had to sort very large data sets, but my colleagues have. This is not so relevant for most tasks now because the performance of modern equipment is very high, but as the data set increases, the need for high-quality algorithms increases.
Instead of conclusions
I‚Äôll write a banality, but mathematics is useful in programming. It‚Äôs just a pity that there aren‚Äôt so many tasks where you need to show ingenuity and use numerical methods instead of solving problems head-on. But, as they say, you can know mathematics, you can not know mathematics, but it is better to know mathematics.

My Top 3 Tips for Being a Great Software Architect
My top tips for being a great Software Architect and making the best decisions for your teams and projects.
Matt Bentley
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
8 min read
¬∑
Jan 2, 2025
1.5K
18
Generated using Microsoft Image Generator
Being a great Software Architect takes time and experience learning from past mistakes. Knowledge of cutting-edge tech and patterns is brilliant, but depending on your team or project, it can also bog you down and make development miserable.
There aren‚Äôt any shortcuts to becoming an excellent Architect overnight, however, there are a few tips to help you make better decisions as an Architect.
In this article I‚Äôll talk you through my top 3 tips for being the best Architect that you can be.
#1 Make decisions as late as possible
Here I don‚Äôt mean making every day-to-day decision as late as possible and leaving everything to the last minute. I am specifically referring to large software architecture decisions.
Here‚Äôs a few examples of the types of decisions that I would categorize with this principle:
What type of database to use
General solution architecture e.g. Microservices/Microkernel/Event Driven
Microservices boundaries
High scale/performance optimization
Automated end-to-end testing strategies
Complex abstractions and patterns
By deferring these decisions as late as possible, we have more facts and can make the best decisions possible. Often, we don‚Äôt fully understand the problems that our end-users face until we start building or get something in the hands of our actual users. It‚Äôs important to start with something simple and flexible; we will usually have to pivot once we get feedback from users.
Can you get away with using data in-memory or using simple JSON files to start with? Do you really need a highly available, elastically scaling, mega performing, elegant solution when you only have a handful of users?
Big upfront design is one of the biggest killers of software projects! I have seen way too many projects kicked-off by ‚ÄúPowerPoint Architects‚Äù with complex upfront designs quickly turn into unwieldy rotten corpses which can‚Äôt be maintained by Developers. One of the biggest red flags that I come across is brand new solutions with multiple microservices already planned-out, before anything has even been built or validated with real usage of a product.
Should I stick clear of complex patterns and technologies?
Absolutely not! However, use them when the time is right, and you have the facts that lead you in that direction.
This principle even applies to writing code. I am a huge advocate of using well-known patterns when writing code, however, even the most experienced engineers do not knock-out perfectly abstracted code on their first attempt. Well written code is always a journey:
Write simple code to solve your problem. This often results in fairly procedural code with large methods and classes.
Write tests to validate that your code behaves how you want (this can of course be done as your first step if you want to follow TDD).
Reduce code duplication, optimize and abstract using functions, classes and patterns.
Use existing tests to validate that your code still behaves as you expect .
If we try to optimize or abstract too early, then we often find ourselves down a rabbit hole or in a mess which takes a long time to untangle.
Flexible Enablers
We know that we are unlikely to get things exactly right on our first attempt. Therefore, it‚Äôs important to aim for flexibility at the start of a project, so that we can change things easily when the inevitable happens. There‚Äôs lots of techniques that can be used to promote flexibility.
Bounded Contexts
Bounded Contexts can be used to breakdown your problem into smaller simpler areas. Bounded Contexts can even be used to organize your code within a project too. Rather than jumping straight into something complex like Microservices, first think in terms of Bounded Contexts; these can be broken out into Microservices in the future once they are better understood and more stable.
eCommerce Bounded Contexts
Modular Monolith
At the moment there is a trend towards using Modular Monoliths to isolate code by Modules in a single process, rather than deploying lots of independently hosted (micro)services. If you get your Module boundaries wrong initially, which is very likely, it is much easier to change. If you observe over time that some of your Modules have different scaling or performance requirements, then you can confidently invest your time in splitting them out into an independent Microservice.
Monolith vs Microservices vs Modular Monolith
Event Sourcing
Event Sourcing involves storing all events that have happened to an Entity in an immutable Event Stream. Events can be materialized into different Projections for your specific query requirements. If a new feature requires a new Projection of our data, we can simply use the Event Streams to generate them from all historic events. This is great because if we initially get our data model slightly wrong, we can just generate new Projections of it.
Bank Account Event Stream Example
#2 Quality over Quantity
We build software for our users and stakeholders. They care that they get their software on time; they don‚Äôt really care how it is architected or stitched together. As a Product team it is very easy to get in the habit of throwing out features as quickly as possible to delight our users and skimp on quality and testing. Unfortunately, this approach is a fool‚Äôs errand and will slow you down in the long run.
When quality is neglected on a project, the code base begins to rot as technical debt increases. Over time the code becomes unmanageable and team velocity (and happiness) declines rapidly. For this reason, experienced Architects will almost always prioritize quality over anything else.
Challenge Product and Design
Our Product and Design teams don‚Äôt have to work on our project code bases, so they will feel the effect of bad quality a lot less. As Architects it is important to challenge them on the scope of new features and make sure that quality is not neglected. Is there data or feedback from users to support the changes we are making?
I find that Product and Design teams can often prioritize gold-plating new features, before we have real evidence that it will make a difference to users. It is an Architect‚Äôs duty to ensure that the team is building lean and not wasting effort where possible. It is better to get something smaller out to our users first, which is built in a maintainable/flexible way and well tested, and then iterate once we have feedback from real usage patterns in Production.
You aren‚Äôt gonna need it (YAGNI)
This principle is usually promoted by programmers only. Don‚Äôt build code that you don‚Äôt need right now. If you have code that isn‚Äôt being used, delete it ‚Äì we have source control if we ever need it again! More code means more to maintain, more to test and more to go wrong. YAGNI should be embraced and advocated by Architects.
YAGNI still applies to our friends in Product and Design as well, and as an Architect it is important to remind them. Building feature that aren‚Äôt really needed, uses up valuable Engineering resources and creates more to maintain and test over time too. More features also means more chances for bugs and a larger attack surface for hackers to target.
Test Code Coverage
Code Coverage is not necessarily the most reliable metric, as it can easily be hijacked or lead to ineffective tests. However, measuring and tracking test code coverage is really important! It keeps our Engineers honest and forces them to make better decisions when writing code. If they are writing code which isn‚Äôt really needed for the feature that they are working on, they will still be required to write test for it ‚Äì this is often a strong reminder that they aren‚Äôt following YAGNI, and they will remove the unnecessary code.
As humans we are inclined to take the easy route. What harm can it do if I don‚Äôt write a unit test for this one new method?! As an Architect you should always enforce code coverage thresholds to stop these micro decisions snowballing into something much larger.
#3 Team-First Architecture
Many Architects fail to understand that your team setup should be one of the biggest drivers for software architecture.
Does your team have the expertise and experience to build and manage the architecture/technology being proposed?
Are your teams/squads setup to enable building the proposed architecture efficiently?
Obviously, team has a big impact on which technologies and patterns will work well for your project, however, team is also intrinsically linked to system architecture too.
Conway‚Äôs Law
The link between team and architecture is explained by Conway‚Äôs law, which should be understood and embraced by all Architects.
Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization‚Äôs communication structure.
- Melvin Conway
Small independent teams are naturally inclined to build service-based architectures, which are highly independent. Whereas large single teams are much more likely to build highly coupled monolithic architectures.
I see lots of teams complaining that microservice based architectures are not the holy grail that they thought they would be. These complaints are generally coming from large teams trying to build lots of Microservices using a single team. This usually culminates in huge inefficiency and the dreaded Distributed Monolith. Conway‚Äôs Law is the reason why this doesn‚Äôt work well at all. Mega companies like Amazon could never achieve what they have done so quickly without breaking their teams and architectures down into lots of independent microservices.
Inverse-Conway-Maneuver
If we want to build software as effectively as possible, we must couple architecture design with team design. By respecting Conway‚Äôs Law, we can pre-emptively organize our teams to reflect our desired system architectures to give us the best chance to succeeding: the Inverse-Conway-Maneuver. This will ensure that our team and system design is not constantly fighting against the communication patterns across our organization.
Understanding different technologies and patterns is extremely important to be a good Architect. However, understanding when and where to apply them is what separates a good Architect from a great Architect.
If you want to be kick-ass Software Architect, you also need to have a good understanding of team dynamics, team management and be involved in setting-up your teams, so that they can work as efficiently and effectively as possible with your proposed system architectures.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

5 Python Decorators That Will Transform Your Coding Workflow
Kevin Meneses Gonz√°lez
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Python in Plain English
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Dec 27, 2024
457
Photo by Kevin Canlas on Unsplash
In the realm of programming, efficiency often lies in how elegantly we can reuse and extend code. Python decorators are a powerful tool that allow developers to modify or extend the behavior of functions and methods. Yet, they remain underutilized or misunderstood by many developers.
As computer scientist Alan Perlis famously said, ‚ÄúA language that doesn‚Äôt affect the way you think about programming is not worth knowing.‚Äù
Decorators, when fully understood, can indeed reshape how you think about structuring your code. This article will delve into five custom Python decorators, crafted from scratch, that can enhance your projects and streamline your coding experience.
The Problem: Repeated Patterns in Code
In software development, it‚Äôs common to encounter repetitive patterns. Tasks like logging, error handling, and performance monitoring often require similar blocks of code repeated across multiple functions. This duplication increases the risk of bugs and makes maintenance harder.
The Solution: Python Decorators
Decorators offer a cleaner, more elegant solution. By wrapping additional functionality around a function, decorators reduce redundancy, promote code reuse, and improve readability.
1. Measuring Execution Time
Sometimes, you need to track how long certain functions take to execute, especially during performance testing. Writing timing logic repeatedly for different functions can be tedious.
Decorator: time_logger
import time
def time_logger(func):
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        start_time = time.perf_counter()
        result = func(*args, **kwargs)
        end_time = time.perf_counter()
        print(f"Function '{func.__name__}' took {end_time - start_time:.4f} seconds.")
        return result
    return wrapper
Usage:
@time_logger
def process_data(n):
    time.sleep(n)  # Simulate a delay
    return f"Processed {n} seconds of data."
process_data(2)
2. Retrying Error-Prone Functions
Imagine you have a function prone to transient errors, like API calls. Instead of writing retry logic every time, use a decorator.
Decorator: retry
import time
def retry(retries=3, delay=1):
    def decorator(func):
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            for attempt in range(retries):
                try:
                    return func(*args, **kwargs)
                except Exception as e:
                    print(f"Attempt {attempt + 1} failed: {e}")
                    time.sleep(delay)
            raise Exception(f"Function '{func.__name__}' failed after {retries} retries.")
        return wrapper
    return decorator
Usage:
@retry(retries=5, delay=2)
def fetch_data():
    import random
    if random.random() < 0.8:
        raise ValueError("Transient error!")
    return "Data fetched successfully."
print(fetch_data())
3. Enforcing Type Checks
Python‚Äôs type hints are informative but not enforced at runtime. This decorator ensures that functions are called with the correct argument types.
Decorator: type_check
def type_check(*expected_types):
    def decorator(func):
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            for arg, expected in zip(args, expected_types):
                if not isinstance(arg, expected):
                    raise TypeError(f"Expected {expected}, got {type(arg)}")
            return func(*args, **kwargs)
        return wrapper
    return decorator
Usage:
@type_check(int, int)
def add(a, b):
    return a + b
print(add(2, 3))  # Works
# print(add(2, "3"))  # Raises TypeError
4. Debugging Function Calls
Debugging involves understanding how and why functions are called. A debug decorator logs input arguments and return values, making the debugging process easier.
Decorator: debug
def debug(func):
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print(f"Calling '{func.__name__}' with args: {args} kwargs: {kwargs}")
        result = func(*args, **kwargs)
        print(f"'{func.__name__}' returned: {result}")
        return result
    return wrapper
Usage:
@debug
def multiply(a, b):
    return a * b
print(multiply(3, 4))
5. Rate Limiting
If a function, like fetching API data, should only run a certain number of times within a given timeframe, a rate limiter decorator is invaluable.
Decorator: rate_limiter
import time
def rate_limiter(calls, period):
    def decorator(func):
        last_calls = []
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            nonlocal last_calls
            now = time.time()
            last_calls = [t for t in last_calls if now - t < period]
            if len(last_calls) >= calls:
                raise RuntimeError("Rate limit exceeded.")
            last_calls.append(now)
            return func(*args, **kwargs)
        return wrapper
    return decorator
Usage:
@rate_limiter(calls=2, period=5)
def fetch_data():
    print("Fetching data...")
fetch_data()
time.sleep(2)
fetch_data()
# fetch_data()  # Raises RuntimeError
Final Thoughts
Python decorators provide an elegant way to enhance and extend the functionality of your code. They not only reduce redundancy but also make your codebase more modular and readable.
As Donald Knuth once remarked, ‚ÄúPrograms are meant to be read by humans and only incidentally for computers to execute.‚Äù
Decorators embody this philosophy by enabling cleaner, more maintainable code.
If you‚Äôre looking to deepen your understanding of Python and enhance your programming skills, I highly recommend DataCamp. Their interactive courses will help you master decorators and other advanced Python topics.

Can Flutter Take Over the Web?
Ferid Brkoviƒá
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Stackademic
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Jan 2, 2025
189
9
If you‚Äôve been around the tech world long enough, you know revolutions don‚Äôt happen overnight.
The web ‚Äî that vast, interconnected ecosystem of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript ‚Äî has dominated our digital lives for decades.
But every so often, a challenger appears, claiming to rewrite the rules.
Today, that challenger is Flutter.
Image created by author.
A Bold New Vision
Imagine a world where you can build one app and have it seamlessly run on iOS, Android, desktop, and yes, the web.
That‚Äôs the promise of Flutter.
Google‚Äôs ambitious cross-platform development framework.
Flutter doesn‚Äôt just aim to coexist with the web ‚Äî it wants to redefine how we think about it.
No more endless debugging sessions for browser inconsistencies.
No more piecing together a UI with duct tape and JavaScript.
Flutter brings its own canvas, rendering engine, and design language, saying, ‚ÄúHTML? Who needs it?‚Äù
But is it too bold a vision?
The Good, the Great, and the Limitless
Flutter‚Äôs superpower is its ability to create pixel-perfect UIs with a single codebase.
Need a sleek, interactive dashboard?
Done.
Want your app to look the same on Chrome, Safari, and Firefox?
Easy.
With Flutter, you‚Äôre not just building apps ‚Äî you‚Äôre crafting experiences.
And let‚Äôs talk about performance.
Flutter for the web renders using WebAssembly and its own Skia engine, bypassing the clunky layers of traditional web technologies.
The result?
Smooth animations, crisp visuals, and a level of responsiveness that can make even seasoned developers do a double take.
For startups and indie developers, the value proposition is clear: one team, one codebase, one beautiful app across platforms.
No silos, no duplication, just results.
The Rocky Road Ahead
But for all its strengths, Flutter faces a mountain of challenges.
The web isn‚Äôt just about looking good ‚Äî it‚Äôs about being discoverable, accessible, and fast.
Here‚Äôs where Flutter stumbles:
SEO and Accessibility
Traditional web technologies like HTML are deeply tied to how search engines and assistive technologies work.
Flutter‚Äôs canvas-based approach, while visually stunning, struggles to match the web-native stack in these areas.
File Size
Have you ever waited for a 5MB web app to load?
Neither has anyone else ‚Äî because they left after the first 2 seconds.
Flutter‚Äôs hefty payload can be a dealbreaker, especially on slower connections.
The Developer Ecosystem
React, Angular, and Vue didn‚Äôt just get here by accident.
They‚Äôve built massive ecosystems, tooling, and communities.
Flutter‚Äôs web story, by comparison, is still in its opening chapter.
A Niche or the New Normal?
The reality is, Flutter isn‚Äôt trying to dethrone traditional web frameworks outright.
Instead, it‚Äôs carving out its own niche.
Think dashboards, embedded apps, and highly interactive tools ‚Äî places where its strengths can shine without fighting the web‚Äôs deeply ingrained standards.
In these use cases, Flutter is already winning. It‚Äôs giving developers superpowers to create apps that don‚Äôt just work but wow.
And as the ecosystem matures, we may see its reach expand into more traditional web territory.
Where Flutter Fits in the Web Ecosystem
To understand Flutter‚Äôs potential, we have to appreciate the diversity of the web itself.
The web isn‚Äôt monolithic ‚Äî it serves as a platform for everything from static blogs to e-commerce giants to real-time gaming.
Flutter‚Äôs strengths align well with scenarios that demand rich interactivity and tight control over the UI. Think of online design tools, interactive education platforms, or real-time collaboration apps. These niches aren‚Äôt just growing, they‚Äôre setting new standards for what web experiences can be.
And then there‚Äôs the developer experience.
Flutter‚Äôs hot reload, intuitive widget system, and powerful state management solutions have won over countless mobile developers.
Bringing that same streamlined workflow to web development is a game-changer for those tired of juggling multiple frameworks and libraries.
The Future of the Web, Flutter Style
So, will Flutter take over the web?
Probably not in the way you‚Äôre imagining.
The web is a massive, multi-faceted beast that won‚Äôt be conquered by any one framework.
But that‚Äôs not the point.
Flutter‚Äôs mission isn‚Äôt domination ‚Äî it‚Äôs innovation.
And in that, it‚Äôs already a runaway success.
The real question isn‚Äôt whether Flutter will replace the web.
It‚Äôs whether you‚Äôre ready to embrace a future where boundaries blur, platforms merge, and the lines between mobile, desktop, and web disappear.
A Closing Thought
The web isn‚Äôt going anywhere ‚Äî but Flutter might just change the way we build for it.
And honestly?
That‚Äôs a revolution worth watching.
Are you ready to flutter into the future, or will you stay rooted in the past?

Palantir Software Engineer Interview Experience ‚Äî Can youü´µ crack it ?
Kumar
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Career Drill
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
5 days ago
5
1
Joining Palantir as a Software Engineer? Well, its tough. It‚Äôs not just about your coding skills, but also how you think, design systems, and solve problems in real-world scenarios. Main things to focus is DSA and System Designs Below is an experience that mimics their real interview process.
Read for FREE ( Non member link )
GO through to check out what it looks like. Below down.
Interview Process Overview
Recruiter Screening: A short and friendly chat about your background, skills, and why you wanna join Palantir. The recruiter also explains what to expect in the upcoming rounds.
Technical Phone Interview: A 60-minute coding session where they dive into your problem-solving skills. Questions range from medium to hard-level DSA problems.
Onsite Interviews (the real challenge):
Coding Round: Focused on algorithms and data structures.
System Design: You‚Äôre tested on designing scalable and maintainable systems.
Learning Interview: They throw something new at you and see how quickly you pick it up.
Decomposition Round: A test of how well you break down complex problems into manageable pieces.
Phone Interview
Question 1:
‚ÄúGiven an array of integers, find the length of the longest contiguous subarray where the elements are consecutive integers.‚Äù
Discussion:
This is one of those questions that at first seems simple, but the edge cases get tricky. The key is to figure out that you cant just check consecutive elements ‚Äî you need to consider sorting or using a set to track all unique elements. Sorting simplifies the task, but using a set helps in optimizing the time complexity.
Think about it this way: sorting takes O(n log n), and using a set can reduce it to O(n) with proper implementation.
Question 2:
‚ÄúWrite a function to detect a cycle in a linked list.‚Äù
Discussion:
This is a classic question that comes up often. The easiest way to solve it is using Floyd‚Äôs Cycle Detection algorithm (also called the slow and fast pointer method). But why use two pointers? Because a single pointer will loop indefinitely, and using two lets you ‚Äúcatch‚Äù the cycle when the fast pointer laps the slow one.
You need to be careful when handling edge cases like a null list or when the list contains only one node ‚Äî these wont have a cycle.
Question 3:
‚ÄúImplement a function to find the kth largest element in an unsorted array.‚Äù
Discussion:
This one‚Äôs a favorite because it can be solved in multiple ways, and the interviewer wants to see how you think. A naive approach is to sort the array and return the (n-k)th element. But if they want efficiency, you might need to use a min-heap or quickselect.
Sorting works in O(n log n), while a heap solution is O(n log k). Quickselect is a bit trickier but does it in O(n) on average. Be sure to discuss tradeoffs with the interviewer ‚Äî it shows maturity in your problem-solving.
Onsite Interviews
Coding Round
Question:
‚ÄúFind all paths from the root to leaves in a binary tree where the sum of the nodes equals a target.‚Äù
Discussion:
This problem is interesting because it combines recursion and backtracking. You need to traverse the tree, keeping track of the current path and sum. If you reach a leaf and the sum matches the target, add the path to the result. Edge cases? A null tree or negative values in the nodes can complicate things.
System Design
Scenario:
‚ÄúDesign an e-commerce checkout system.‚Äù
Discussion:
Here, you‚Äôre not just writing code ‚Äî you‚Äôre architecting a system. They wanna see if you can think at scale.
Key areas to cover:
Inventory Management: Track item stock in real time.
Payment Gateway Integration: Ensure smooth and secure transactions.
Order Processing: Handle cart, checkout, and order placement.
Scalability: Talk about caching frequently accessed items and using a load balancer.
The interviewer also checks how you handle edge cases, like when two users try to buy the last item simultaneously.
Learning Interview
Scenario:
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre introduced to a new database tool, and you need to write queries to fetch data from a complex schema.‚Äù
Discussion:
This is less about the queries and more about how you learn. The interviewer provides documentation and observes how you break it down. Be sure to explain your thought process out loud:
Identify the main tables and relationships.
Write simple queries first, then combine them.
Test for edge cases, like null values or duplicate entries.
Decomposition Round
Scenario:
‚ÄúBuild a ride-hailing app like Uber.‚Äù
Discussion:
This round is all about simplifying a huge problem.
Core Components: User registration, ride booking, driver assignment, and payments.
Key Challenges: Real-time tracking, surge pricing, and route optimization.
Scaling: Discuss how you‚Äôd handle high traffic during peak hours using load balancers and microservices.
The interviewer might ask follow-up questions like how you‚Äôd ensure data consistency or recover from a service crash.
This is a mock interview experience of Palantir for learning purposes. It simulates a real interview process and questions that candidates have encountered. Test yourself and see if you can crack Palantir! If you find this useful or have suggestions, drop them in the comments.
Final Thoughts
The Palantir interview process is not just about solving problems ‚Äî it‚Äôs about showing how you think, communicate, and handle challenges. Practice questions like these, and dont forget to brush up on system design and algorithms.
If you solved or know all the problems well, you can crack Palantir test yourself! Drop your thoughts in the comments below. All the best! üí™

Pyramids In A Cube Interview Puzzle
Can You Solve This Puzzle in 100 Seconds or Less?
Rajul Saxena
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Puzzle Sphere
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Nov 5, 2024
242
6
All images created by Author unless specified otherwise
This is a small geometry puzzle. Problems like these are often asked in quantitative aptitude tests and tech interviews at many software companies. The typical time to solve such a question is 100 seconds. Let‚Äôs see how quickly you can solve it.
Problem
Imagine a cube. We don‚Äôt know the side length of the cube.
Now imagine a point O located somewhere within it.
From this point O, imagine six pyramids, each using one of the cube‚Äôs faces as its base, while O serves as the common apex for all six.
You know the volumes of five out of these six pyramids.
They measure 3, 6, 9, 10, and 13 cubic units, respectively.
Can you find the volume of the sixth pyramid?
You should pause here, grab your notebook and pen, and try to find the solution yourself. üß†ü§î
When ready, scroll down and read the solution provided!
Solution
To solve this problem, we need to understand the relationship between point O within the cube and the volumes of the six pyramids. The cube‚Äôs entire volume can be seen as the combined volume of these six pyramids.
The volume of a pyramid is calculated by the formula:
The 6 pyramids each have the same base area B. These can be divided into 3 pairs whose bases (faces) are opposite to each other. For every such pair, the heights of both the pyramids sum up to the cube‚Äôs edge.
So, if we take two opposite pyramids, we can write:
So, if we sum up the heights of both pyramids, we get:
Because s (side length) and B (Base Area) are the same for each pair of opposite pyramids, the combined volume of the opposite pyramid pair is constant.
The volumes of the five given pyramids are 3, 6, 9, 10, and 13. We have to pair the 6 volumes in such a way that each pair has the same total volume.
Among the 5 volumes, (3,13) and (6,10) are the only pairs whose sum is equal. So if we need the last volume to pair up with the remaining volume i.e. 9 cubic units, their sum must be equal to 16.
Final Answer
The final pair would be (9,7), which means the final answer for the volume of the remaining pyramid will be 7 cubic units.
To solve it quickly, you just need to spot that the volume of a pyramid is proportional to its height. And the sum of the heights of opposite pyramids is equal to the side length. Therefore, all 3 pairs of opposite pyramids have equal combined volume.
Edit
As found out by David Carnochan, there exists one more solution. Going by the same logic as above, the volumes can be arranged in pairs summing to 19. So the answer becomes (9,10), (6,13) and (3,16).
If you found this useful, feel free to clap, comment, highlight or follow me. We all go further when we help each other!
Cheers ‚Äî RS !!

Use * and / to Make Your Python Function Parameters Look Neater
Learn a flexible way to pass function parameters in Python
Lynn G. Kwong
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Level Up Coding
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Feb 25, 2024
1.3K
11
Image by geralt on Pixabay
We can pass data to functions by positional or keyword parameters in Python. This makes functions very flexible to use in Python. However, it also has some limitations. For example, you may want some parameters to be positional-only and some keyword-only. Another common use case is to put parameters with default values before those with no default values to make the parameters look more organized and easier to use. These requests can be accomplished by the * and / symbols in Python.
https://youtube.com/@kwonglynn
Default behavior
As we already know, we can pass data to functions by positional or keyword parameters in Python. Let‚Äôs have this simple function as an example here:
def echo(x, y, z):
    print(f"{x=}, {y=}, {z=}")
We can call this function using positional or keyword parameters, as long as keyword parameters are put after positional ones:
echo(1, 2, 3)
echo(1, 2, z=3)
echo(1, y=2, z=3)
echo(x=1, y=2, z=3)
# x=1, y=2, z=3
All of them will work and will give the same result.
Specify positional-only parameters with /
Parameters placed before the / symbol in the function definition must be passed as positional arguments. Let‚Äôs update the echo() function to use /:
def echo(x, /, y, z):
    print(f"{x=}, {y=}, {z=}")
With this update, x can only be passed as a positional parameter, while y and z can still be passed by both positional and keyword parameters:
echo(1, 2, 3)
echo(1, 2, z=3)
echo(1, y=2, z=3)
# x=1, y=2, z=3
And if x is passed as a keyword parameter, a TypeError will be raised:
echo(x=1, y=2, z=3)
# TypeError: echo() got some positional-only arguments
# passed as keyword arguments: 'x'
Specify keyword-only parameters with *
Parameters placed after the * symbol in the function definition must be passed as keyword arguments. Let‚Äôs change / to * in the echo() function:
def echo(x, *, y, z):
    print(f"{x=}, {y=}, {z=}")
Now x can be passed by both positional or keyword arguments, but y and z must be passed as keyword arguments (even when x is passed as a positional parameter):
echo(1, y=2, z=3)
echo(x=1, y=2, z=3)
# x=1, y=2, z=3

echo(1, 2, z=3)
# TypeError: echo() takes 1 positional argument but 2 positional
# arguments (and 1 keyword-only argument) were given

echo(1, 2, 3)
# TypeError: echo() takes 1 positional argument but 3 were given
A very useful feature of the * symbol is that it allows you to put parameters with default values before those with no default values to make the parameters look more organized. For example, we can give a default value to y and still put z after y using the * symbol:
def echo(x, *, y=2, z):
    print(f"{x=}, {y=}, {z=}")
This is valid syntax in Python and is commonly used in third-party Python libraries with complex function parameters.
Now both y and z must be passed as keyword parameters and y has a default value:
echo(1, z=3)
echo(1, y=2, z=3)
# x=1, y=2, z=3
Combine * and / in function definitions
We can combine * and / to define a function with some parameters being positional-only and some keyword-only:
def echo(x, /, *, y=2, z):
    print(f"{x=}, {y=}, {z=}")
In this case, x is positional-only and y and z are keyword-only parameters:
echo(1, z=3)
echo(1, y=2, z=3)
# x=1, y=2, z=3

echo(x=1, z=3)
# TypeError: echo() got some positional-only
# arguments passed as keyword arguments: 'x'
In this post, we have introduced the use of the * and / symbols in function definitions, which have the following interesting utilities:
Make some parameters positional-only and some keyword-only.
Put parameters with default values before those with no default values to make the parameters look more organized and easier to use.
Related posts:
Special Python String Formatting in Logging and Unit Conversion
Use black, mypy, and pylint to make your Python code more professional<|InputEnd|>Member-only story
7 Top Trending GitHub Projects, #40
A Survey of Emerging AI Tools and Frameworks
C. L. Beard

Photo by Windows on Unsplash
The landscape of artificial intelligence tools and frameworks continues to evolve rapidly, offering innovative solutions across diverse domains from image editing to protein structure prediction. This comprehensive overview examines several cutting-edge open-source and commercial tools that showcase the breadth of AI applications in modern computing.
From local deployment options that prioritize privacy to specialized frameworks for scientific research, these tools represent the increasing accessibility and sophistication of AI technology. Each solution addresses specific challenges while contributing to the broader ecosystem of AI-powered development and research.
If you want more AI/Open Source news try my newsletter BrainScriblr.
Newsletters I like are FintechTakes, and EarthConscious, Core Updates.
Why try Green Web Hosting?
Attio is an incredibly powerful AI CRM tool.
If you use Notion check out this list of tools for building a website with Notion here.
I wrote an overview of Firecrawl for web scrapping.
I screenshot all images unless otherwise noted.
MagicQuill
MagicQuill is an intelligent, interactive image editing system designed to provide precise and user-friendly editing capabilities. Developed by researchers from institutions including HKUST, Ant Group, ZJU, and HKU, MagicQuill combines AI-powered suggestions with a user-friendly interface to facilitate detailed local edits.
Important Details:
The system intelligently predicts user intentions during the editing process, providing prompt suggestions to enhance efficiency and accuracy.
You can perform detailed local edits, allowing for fine-tuned modifications to specific areas of an image.
Installation and Setup:
MagicQuill requires a GPU for optimal performance, with a minimum of 8GB VRAM recommended. The installation process involves cloning the repository, downloading necessary checkpoints, setting up a Python environment, and installing required dependencies.
AlphaFold 3
AlphaFold 3, developed by DeepMind, represents a significant advancement in computational biology, extending the capabilities of its predecessors by accurately predicting the structures of protein complexes and their interactions with various biomolecules, including DNA, RNA, ligands, and ions. This enhancement facilitates a deeper understanding of molecular interactions, which is crucial for fields such as drug discovery and molecular biology.
Important Details of AlphaFold 3:
AlphaFold 3 can predict the structures of multi-protein complexes and their interactions with other biomolecules, providing insights into the assembly and function of these complexes.
The model demonstrates a minimum 50% improvement in accuracy for predicting protein interactions with other molecules compared to existing methods, effectively doubling the accuracy for certain key categories of interactions.
Coverage: It includes support for various ligands and covalent modifications, broadening the scope of molecular interactions that can be studied.
Installation and Usage:
The AlphaFold 3 codebase is available on GitHub.
To install and run AlphaFold 3, users need to clone the repository, set up the necessary databases, and configure the environment, which includes installing Docker and the NVIDIA Container Toolkit for GPU support. Detailed installation instructions are provided in the repository‚Äôs documentation.
ScenicFlow
ScenicFlow is an open-source, web-based application designed to facilitate the creation of engaging video presentations through a scene or slide-based approach. Built with Vite and React, it offers users the flexibility to manually add text and images or leverage AI capabilities for automatic scene generation via integration with Langflow.
Important Details:
Manual Scene Creation: Users can construct scenes by manually adding text and images, allowing for precise control over the content and structure of each segment.
AI-Powered Scene Generation: Through integration with Langflow, ScenicFlow can automatically generate scenes, streamlining the video creation process and enhancing efficiency.
Prerequisites before installation:
Node.js: Ensure that the latest version of Node.js is installed.
Package Manager: Choose one of the following for managing dependencies: npm, Yarn, pnpm, or Bun.
LocalAI
LocalAI is a free, open-source platform that serves as a self-hosted alternative to services like OpenAI and Claude. Designed for local-first deployment, it functions as a drop-in replacement for OpenAI‚Äôs API, enabling users to run various AI models on consumer-grade hardware without the need for a GPU.
Important Details:
LocalAI is compatible with multiple model architectures, including gguf, transformers, and diffusers. This flexibility allows users to perform a wide range of AI tasks such as text, audio, video, and image generation, as well as voice cloning.
The platform supports distributed and peer-to-peer inference, facilitating scalable AI deployments across various environments.
LocalAI offers a REST API that is compatible with OpenAI‚Äôs, making it easier for developers to integrate and transition existing applications.
Installation and Usage:
LocalAI provides several installation methods, including container images available on platforms like Quay.io and Docker Hub. These images cater to different environments, with options for GPU acceleration and CPU-only setups. The All-in-One (AIO) images come pre-configured with a set of models and backends, simplifying the deployment process.
DuckDuckGPT
DuckDuckGPT is an open-source browser add-on that integrates AI-generated responses into DuckDuckGo search results. Powered by GPT-4, it enhances the search experience by providing conversational answers alongside traditional search listings.
Important Details:
DuckDuckGPT utilizes GPT-4 to generate natural language answers, offering users a more interactive and informative search experience.
The add-on displays AI-generated responses directly within the DuckDuckGo search interface, allowing users to access enhanced information without leaving the search page.
DuckDuckGPT is compatible with various browsers, including Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Opera, Brave, and Vivaldi, ensuring a wide range of users can benefit from its features.
AI Logo Generator
UPT-Artist is a Python application that leverages OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-3.5 language model to generate logos and images based on user input. Developed by Umair Thakur, the tool allows users to select the type of logo they desire and provide a descriptive prompt for image generation. The application processes data locally to ensure security and utilizes the OpenAI API to produce the final logo or image.
Important Details:
You can choose the desired logo type from a dropdown menu, tailoring the output to specific needs.
The application accepts detailed prompts that describe the user‚Äôs requirements, enhancing the relevance of the generated image.
By handling data locally, UPT-Artist ensures that sensitive information remains secure during the generation process.
Generated images are displayed within the application‚Äôs interface and automatically saved to the user‚Äôs desktop with a timestamped filename.
You need Python 3 to use.
Polar
The Polar BLE SDK is the official Software Development Kit provided by Polar, enabling developers to create custom Android and iOS applications that interface with Polar sensors and watches. The SDK employs the ReactiveX API, facilitating efficient and responsive data handling within applications.
Important Details:
Access real-time heart rate data measured in beats per minute (BPM) and RR intervals in milliseconds.
Retrieve ECG data with a sampling rate of 130Hz, providing detailed cardiac information.
Obtain accelerometer readings at various sampling rates (25Hz, 50Hz, 100Hz, 200Hz) and ranges (2G, 4G, 8G), enabling activity and movement analysis.
Access PPG values and pulse-to-pulse intervals (PP intervals) extracted from PPG signals, useful for heart rate variability studies.
Manage offline recordings, including starting, stopping, listing, reading, and deleting stored data directly from the device.
Perform firmware updates on supported Polar devices to ensure access to the latest features and improvements.
Letta
Letta is an open-source framework designed to enhance Large Language Models (LLMs) by providing them with advanced reasoning capabilities and transparent long-term memory. Formerly known as MemGPT, Letta enables developers to build stateful LLM applications, allowing agents to recall past interactions and refine their behavior over time.
Important Details:
Letta facilitates the creation of agents that maintain state, enabling them to remember previous interactions and utilize this information in future engagements.
By incorporating memory management techniques, Letta enhances the reasoning capabilities of LLMs, allowing for more complex and context-aware responses.
Letta is designed to work with various LLMs, providing developers with flexibility in choosing the models that best fit their applications.
Repomix
Repomix is part of the emerging ecosystem of tools that empower developers to leverage AI for productivity, collaboration, and quality assurance in software projects. It simplifies interaction between human developers and AI by creating a unified, structured view of their codebases, making it easier for AI to deliver relevant insights and support.
Repomix is a tool designed to simplify and optimize the process of preparing codebases for analysis by Large Language Models (LLMs) and other AI systems. It addresses the challenge of AI‚Äôs context limitations by packing an entire repository into a single file, making it easier for AI tools to ingest and analyze code.
Purpose and Benefits:
By consolidating code into a single, well-structured file, Repomix enables AI tools to better analyze, understand, and interact with a project‚Äôs source code.
It provides token counts for files and the repository as a whole, helping manage AI context size restrictions.
Built-in linting for secrets ensures sensitive information is not inadvertently included in packed files.
CogVideo
CogVideo is an open-source project developed by Tsinghua University‚Äôs Data Mining Group (THUDM) that focuses on text-to-video generation using large-scale transformer models. The project has evolved through several iterations, with the latest being CogVideoX, which introduces enhanced capabilities for generating high-quality videos from textual descriptions.
Important Features:
CogVideoX enables the creation of videos based on textual prompts, allowing users to visualize concepts and narratives described in text.
The model supports generating videos from a single image combined with a text prompt, providing greater control over the content and style of the output video.
CogVideoX can extend existing video clips by generating subsequent frames that align with the initial content, facilitating seamless video continuation.
The diverse collection of tools and frameworks presented here illustrates the remarkable progress in making AI technology more accessible, efficient, and practical for various applications. From enabling sophisticated image editing to advancing scientific research, these solutions demonstrate how AI is being integrated into different domains while addressing key considerations such as local deployment, privacy, and user experience.
As these technologies continue to mature, they provide developers, researchers, and end-users with increasingly powerful tools for tackling complex challenges. The emphasis on open-source development and local deployment options particularly highlights a growing movement toward democratizing AI technology, ensuring that advanced capabilities are available to a broader audience while maintaining control over data and computing resources.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight
