The 100 Monks Puzzle
Can You Apply Logic to Solve This Brain Teaser?
Rajul Saxena
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Puzzle Sphere
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Oct 10, 2024
256
6
Photo by Shanthi Raja on Unsplash
Recently, I came across a very popular brain teaser that goes by the name of Blue ‚Äì Eyed Islanders. The following problem is based on the similar logic. It took me a few hours and a calm evening to solve this. It is a logical puzzle and requires you to think for some time. Are you up for this challenge?
Problem
In a secluded mountain monastery, 100 monks live peacefully. Each monk is a philosopher, well-versed in logic, and all follow the strict monastery rule that any monk who discovers they have a red mark on their forehead must meditate for 24 hours in isolation and leave the monastery permanently.
None of the monks know if they have the red mark on their forehead, but they can see all the other monks clearly during daily gatherings. No mirrors or reflective surfaces are allowed in the monastery, and monks are forbidden from speaking about the red marks. They can only observe each other, that too, silently.
One day, a wise old man visits the monastery and makes an announcement: ‚ÄúAt least one of you have a red mark on your forehead‚Äù.
The monks continued their daily gatherings and thought about the old man‚Äôs words in silence.
Question: Will the monks with the red marks eventually leave the monastery, and if so, after how many days?
You should pause here, grab your notebook and pen, and try to find the solution yourself. üß†ü§î
When ready, scroll down and read the solution provided!
Solution:
This is how the monks with red marks, will think and figure out whether they have to leave or not.
Step 1: Simplifying the Problem
We can start by taking a small number of monks for simplicity.
Case 1: One Monk with a Red Mark
If there is only 1 monk with a red mark, that monk will observe that no other monk has a red mark. Based on the old man‚Äôs announcement, the monk will immediately know that he must be the one with the red mark (because at least one person has it). Therefore, this monk will leave the monastery on the first day.
Case 2: Two Monks with Red Marks
Now consider, that there are 2 monks with red marks. Each monk will see the other monk with the red mark but will not know if they themselves have that mark.
Each monk will think: ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt have the red mark, then the other monk I see with the red mark, will see no one else with a red mark. And therefore, he will leave on the first day.‚Äù
When the first day passes and neither of the monks leave the monastery, both monks will realize that the other must have seen someone else with a red mark ‚Äî which can only mean they themselves also have a red mark.
On the second day, both monks will realize they have red marks and leave together.
Case 3: Three Monks with Red Marks
If there are 3 monks with red marks, each monk sees 2 others with the red mark. They reason in the same way as above.
Each monk will think: ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt have the red mark, then the 2 monks I see with red marks will realize, after two days, that they must have red marks themselves and leave.‚Äù
When the second day passes and none of the other two monks leave, all three monks will realize that they themselves must have the red mark. This is because if there were only two monks with red marks, the other two would have left by now.
So, on the third day, all three monks will leave.
Step 2: Generalizing the Solution
In the case where there are n monks who have red marks on their foreheads, the same reasoning applies:
Each monk sees n-1 monks with red marks.
They think: ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt have a red mark, the other n-1 monks will figure out their situation after n-1 days and leave.‚Äù
When n-1 days pass and none of the monks leave, they all realize that they must also have that red mark.
Therefore, on the n-th day, all monks with red marks will leave the monastery together.
Final Answer
So for this problem specifically, if we assume all monks have the red mark i.e. n = 100, then all the monks will leave the monastery on the 100th day. But if there are n monks with red marks out of total K monks, then they will all leave on the n-th day together.
Final Thoughts
When I searched for the correct answer to this problem online, many people were debating about whether the simple announcement of the old man added to any knowledge that the monks didn‚Äôt previously have.
According to the comments in that forum, the key to solving this puzzle is the idea of common knowledge.
Before the visitor‚Äôs announcement, even though every monk saw that many other monks had the red mark, but they didn‚Äôt know if everyone else had the same information or that everyone else is also thinking the same.
The old man‚Äôs simple statement that at least one person has the red mark, creates a shared piece of knowledge that is known by everyone.
Now everyone knows that there is at least one monk with the red mark and this shared knowledge becomes the key for each monk to eventually realize their own situation.
This puzzle beautifully demonstrates the power of induction (starting from small; to solve big), logical reasoning and how introducing new information (even very trivial) can change a situation.
If you found this useful, feel free to clap, comment, highlight or follow me. We all go further when we help each other!
Cheers ‚Äî RS !!

Rajul Saxena

Web Components Will Kill JavaScript Frameworks (Eventually)
Ferid Brkoviƒá
¬∑
Follow
Published in
JavaScript in Plain English
¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Dec 14, 2024
808
32
The year 2025 just started, and you‚Äôre building a web app.
Your first instinct is to reach for a framework ‚Äî React, Vue, Angular, Svelte.
It‚Äôs muscle memory at this point.
But what if, instead of pulling in thousands of lines of someone else‚Äôs code, you could do everything you need with just Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components?
No dependencies, no lock-in, no virtual DOM overhead ‚Äî just pure, browser-native power.
This isn‚Äôt a wild dream.
Photo by Jay Heike on Unsplash
It‚Äôs a growing reality, and it has the potential to reshape web development as we know it.
We‚Äôll explore why Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components are poised to challenge the dominance of frameworks, and why you might want to reconsider reaching for that npm install command.
Frameworks: The Double-Edged Sword
Frameworks have been a gift to developers. They‚Äôve standardized patterns, accelerated development, and allowed us to build complex apps with ease. But they‚Äôre not without their downsides:
Framework Lock-In: Switching from React to Vue? Good luck rewriting your entire component library.
Performance Overhead: Frameworks bring abstractions, and abstractions cost performance. For small apps, this might not matter, but scale it up, and those milliseconds add up.
Dependency Bloat: Every framework update risks breaking your app, and you‚Äôre at the mercy of maintainers to keep things compatible.
Learning Curve: New developers often spend more time learning the quirks of a framework than the fundamentals of JavaScript.
Pure JavaScript and Web Components
Vanilla JavaScript is the language we all love ‚Äî or love to hate. It‚Äôs the foundation of web development. When paired with Web Components, it becomes a powerhouse for building fast, reusable, and framework-agnostic components.
What Are Web Components?
Web Components are a set of browser-native technologies that allow you to create custom, reusable HTML elements with encapsulated styles and behavior. They consist of:
Custom Elements: Define your own HTML tags.
Shadow DOM: Encapsulate styles and logic, preventing CSS leakage.
HTML Templates: Create reusable markup for dynamic content.
Together, these features give you the tools to build modern, modular UI components without needing a framework.
Why They‚Äôre a Game-Changer
Here‚Äôs why Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components are shaking things up:
1. Freedom from Frameworks
With Web Components, you‚Äôre not tied to any particular framework or library. Your components can live happily in a React app, an Angular project, or a no-framework environment. Build once, use everywhere.
Imagine this: you create a <smart-dropdown> Web Component for a product catalog. It works flawlessly in the React-based admin panel, the Vue-based mobile site, and even the static HTML marketing page. No duplication. No rework. Just one component, universally compatible.
2. Performance Boost
Web Components are native to the browser. They don‚Äôt rely on virtual DOMs or extra layers of abstraction, making them faster out of the box. For apps where performance is critical ‚Äî think real-time dashboards or mobile-first experiences ‚Äî this can be a game-changer.
3. Simpler Maintenance
When you build with Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components, you‚Äôre working with standards, not trends. Your code isn‚Äôt at the mercy of a framework‚Äôs roadmap or breaking changes. It‚Äôs built on technologies that browsers support natively and evolve slowly.
4. Focus on Fundamentals
Using Vanilla JavaScript pushes you to master the core principles of the language. This knowledge transfers across any framework you choose to adopt later, making you a better, more versatile developer.
But‚Ä¶ Are Frameworks Dead?
Let‚Äôs not get ahead of ourselves.
Frameworks aren‚Äôt going anywhere ‚Äî at least not anytime soon.
They excel in large-scale applications, providing built-in solutions for state management, routing, and data fetching.
If you‚Äôre building the next Slack or Airbnb, a framework might still be your best bet.
That said, for many small-to-medium projects ‚Äî and even some enterprise use cases ‚Äî Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components offer a compelling alternative.
A Real-World Example
Let‚Äôs bring this to life with an example. Say you‚Äôre building a notification badge for a messaging app. Here‚Äôs how you‚Äôd do it with Web Components:
class NotificationBadge extends HTMLElement {
  constructor() {
    super();
    const shadow = this.attachShadow({ mode: 'open' });

    // Create the badge
    const badge = document.createElement('span');
    badge.setAttribute('class', 'badge');
    badge.textContent = this.getAttribute('count') || '0';

    // Add styles
    const style = document.createElement('style');
    style.textContent = `
      .badge {
        background: red;
        color: white;
        padding: 5px 10px;
        border-radius: 12px;
        font-size: 12px;
        display: inline-block;
      }
    `;

    shadow.appendChild(style);
    shadow.appendChild(badge);
  }
}

customElements.define('notification-badge', NotificationBadge);
Now, you can use <notification-badge count="5"></notification-badge> anywhere in your app. Want to update the count dynamically? Just modify the count attribute.
The Future of Frameworkless Development
The web is moving toward a future of interoperability and lightweight solutions. Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components are leading the charge, empowering developers to build apps that are fast, maintainable, and framework-independent.
But this isn‚Äôt about abandoning frameworks. It‚Äôs about rethinking when and why we use them. Instead of reaching for a framework by default, ask yourself: Can this be done with Web Components and Vanilla JavaScript? You might be surprised by the answer.
The future of web development is less about following trends and more about embracing standards. And with Vanilla JavaScript and Web Components, the possibilities are endless.
In Plain English üöÄ

M4 Pro Mac mini ‚Äî brilliant yet flawed
I am one of the biggest fans of Apple‚Äôs latest Mac mini ‚Äî but there is one glaring problem‚Ä¶
David Lewis
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Mac O‚ÄôClock
¬∑
12 min read
¬∑
5 days ago
345
9
image ‚Äî David Lewis
The M4 Pro Mac mini was, without a doubt, my best Apple purchase of 2024.
I bought two Mac minis ‚Äî the standard M4 version, which I returned and the M4 Pro Mac mini, which not only did I keep but has ended up becoming my daily machine. After three years of hard use, my M1 Max MacBook Pro has been eased to one side as the Apple new poster boy of the moment takes pride of place.
And let me be clear about this point ‚Äî there is nothing wrong with my MacBook Pro ‚Äî it‚Äôs simply that the M4 Pro Mac mini is better!
I‚Äôve written many pieces about what the M4 Pro Mac mini is like to use ‚Äî its many pros and a few cons, so I am not going to cover old ground with this story. It‚Äôs a brilliant machine, and if you want to start using a Mac, the Mac mini is a fantastic place to get into macOS.
This story, though, at the risk of sounding like an edition of Star Trek, will be about my little journey of discovery about storage and my Mac mini.
Not all is equal
Hopefully, when you read my stories, they come across as an honest recount of what I‚Äôve bought, how I use them and the problems I come up against.
Although I am a confessed geek and nerd, I am a fairly normal nerd, the everyman nerd as it were! What I mean by that is I don‚Äôt come from an IT background or electronics degree. I just like using tech and Apple gear.
Quite possibly, I am just like you, an average user muddling through and finding my way. The only difference is that I‚Äôve kind of stumbled into making videos and writing about Apple gear, and it has (oddly) become a full-time gig ‚Äî something else I happen to love doing, too!
So, as we are going to be talking about storage, I guess a good place to start would be to remind you of the details of the Mac I have on my desk.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
My M4 Pro Mac mini is spec‚Äôd like this;
Apple M4 Pro chip with 14‚Äëcore CPU, 20‚Äëcore GPU, 16-core Neural Engine
48GB unified memory
1 TB SSD storage
10 Gigabit Ethernet
Before buying the M4 Pro Mac mini, all the rumours were that the M4 Pro chip was going to be pretty damned special, so I spec‚Äôd and bought this M4 Pro Mac mini with the mindset that it would likely replace my M1 Max MacBook Pro.
Most of the tick boxes were pretty self-explanatory. I wanted the M4 Pro chip with the extra cores to handle my video, audio and photo workflow with a healthy dollop of memory to match. Apple silicon tends to be so efficient that I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd need more than 48GB ‚Äî and so far, I‚Äôve been proven right. The 10GB Ethernet port was simply a cheap, future-proofing luxury in case I should ever go the networked NAS drive route, or if full fibre ever comes my way.
This brings us neatly around to the last and most contentious option ‚Äî storage.
Apple‚Äôs onboard option is the most convenient and, until recently, the quickest form of storage. Although convenient, one of the downsides or risks with having everything on your Mac‚Äôs internal SSD is if it should die or get stolen, you‚Äôve suddenly lost everything. But, there‚Äôs no escaping the fact it is convenient.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
Of course, that is only one of the benefits of going the slightly less convenient external SSD route. Not only are you safe from having to spring out for a new Mac if the worse should happen but you can also swap what Mac you are working on by simply plugging that SSD into another workstation. So what you lose in convenience, you gain in flexibility. Swings and roundabouts!
You see ‚Äî even with storage, there are pros and cons.
So, naturally, when we get to the storage option as we are choosing a new Mac, we find ourselves hesitating, doubting & double-guessing ourselves. We may want those extra terabytes of storage, but by god, you‚Äôd best be ready to dig deep into your pockets to afford it.
And, with Apple painfully aware that these new breed of Macs are lasting longer than ever, the company has had to look to screw every last penny out of us at the checkout, which I‚Äôm sure is why they are charging so much for memory & storage upgrades ‚Äî although you could argue they always have!
So, to save a few pounds or dollars, many of us decide to go light on Apple‚Äôs storage and buy some kind of third-party external SSD.
But as I‚Äôve learned ‚Äî not all SSDs and storage are the same.
M4 Pro Mac mini ‚Äî going easy
I knew that the 1TB I‚Äôd chosen wouldn‚Äôt last me long, and with Apple silicon Macs, of course, you only get one bite at the storage cherry. What you spec will have to last you forever. There‚Äôs no swapping or upgrading. The possibility of buyer‚Äôs remorse has never been more real.
Although I‚Äôd say I‚Äôm pretty cautious with what I put on or keep on Mac, for the kind of work I do, 1TB was always going to be on the skinny side ‚Äî and I was aware of that ‚Äî but ¬£2300 was more than enough to pay for this mini.
Storage, for me, gets eaten up on a weekly cycle with that week‚Äôs video. For instance, the Final Cut Pro file that sits on my desktop during the week can often easily swell to 80GB or 100GB. That means I routinely get the message popping up telling me I‚Äôm low on storage.
Out of interest, before I started to write this story, I checked where I was at with storage after nearly two months of use, with the desktop now clear of this week‚Äôs video file.
So far, I‚Äôve nabbed around 250GB of the available 1TB SSD ‚Äî and that‚Äôs with me being careful! Storage has this nasty way of getting eaten up, which is why you can never have enough of it.
Although I have long-term plans of going the NAS route ‚Äî that is a costly choice and also one that I understand is pretty tricky to initially get set up. So, for now, I‚Äôve ruled it out.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
But, I knew I needed to address the elephant in the room and began to try and learn more about what my best options were for extra storage for my lovely M4 Pro Mac mini.
The learning curve
Until fairly recently, I thought that an SSD was an SSD ‚Äî I mean, how complicated could it be? One extra gigabyte was the same as the next, no?
As you‚Äôve probably gathered, I‚Äôd always been fairly ignorant about SSDs. I‚Äôd bought plenty over the year, but just either to dump backup files on, to store archives on or use as a Time Capsule.
I think it was only when the iPhones switched to USB-C, and we had LOG and ProRes video that I bought an SSD with any real care or thought. I noticed that the port on the iPhone had 10Gbps transfer speeds. I wanted to buy a dedicated SSD to record on, so I took time to check the specs carefully before buying, as I wanted to maximise the transfer speeds.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
I ended up getting a 1TB Samsung T7. It‚Äôs small, lightweight and has been ultra-reliable. I can often record for 30 or 40 minutes at a time, and even with those 80GB files, it‚Äôs never let me down.
It‚Äôs proven to be perfect for the purpose I bought it for. These small, portable SSDs are a great solution for transferring or storing files. I could happily build up a bank of these for keeping my archive files on, for instance.
But late last year, when I was testing between the M4 Pro Mac mini and the standard Mac mini, I used it to edit a video from, and that‚Äôs when I found its breaking point.
The T7 and, I‚Äôm guessing, similar alternatives overheated. My timeline froze in Final Cut, and I assumed, at first, it was the M4 Pro Mac mini complaining ‚Äî a fairly natural first reaction. But then I felt the Samsung drive, and it was boiling from all that read/writing that had been going on. I had to wait about half an hour for it to cool down before I could carry on working. Less than ideal.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
Lesson learned ‚Äî this wasn‚Äôt going to be my long-term storage solution for the M4 Pro Mac mini.
Options
After Apple announced that both the M4 Pro Mac mini and M4 MacBook Pro would come with Thunderbolt 5 ports, I said at the time it wouldn‚Äôt take long for third-party Thunderbolt 5 SSDs to flood onto the market. It‚Äôs no surprise that has played out, and now there are quite a few to choose from.
Could a Thunderbolt 5 SSD enclosure be the answer?
One name kept cropping up as being one of the best. Chatting with other creators in a similar position to me, they told me to take a look at Acasis.
The enclosure I chose was the latest from Acasis ‚Äî the 80Gbps TB501 enclosure. Remember I told you how fresh and naive I was about external SSDs? After it arrived I had no idea that all I was getting was the enclosure ‚Äî the memory isn‚Äôt included! At least you get the truth from me!
image ‚Äî David Lewis
So the enclosure costs about ¬£250 ($299), and the 2TB Samsung 990 Eco Pro Plus memory I have chosen costs ¬£140. That means I‚Äôve spent ¬£390 to add 2TB of, hopefully, usable and quick SSD storage to my M4 Pro Mac mini compared to Apple, which is charging ¬£600. That‚Äôs a pretty healthy saving, so long as it‚Äôs ok to use.
Now I‚Äôve got my head into these NVMe storage enclosures ‚Äî I‚Äôm starting to see the benefits of them. For starters, you can easily swap, upgrade and switch the SSD. I‚Äôve started with ‚Äòonly‚Äô 2TB, but I can easily change that at any time. I took Acasis‚Äô advice and went with Samsung this time, but I figured if I didn‚Äôt like that, I could try another kind next time ‚Äî maybe Crucial, for instance. I also like that this Acasis enclosure doesn‚Äôt need any power ‚Äî it‚Äôs powered via the Thunderbolt 5 cable, and no tools are needed to change the memory with this Acasis enclosure either.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
I‚Äôm not sure if that‚Äôs standard with other similar enclosures, but everything so far is leaning towards this being a fantastic choice for my storage solution. On the convenience front ‚Äî it‚Äôs ticking boxes.
And, having decided to use this TB501 also means that for the first time, I‚Äôll be tapping into the power of those Thunderbolt 5 ports on the back of my M4 Pro Mac mini.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
So, let‚Äôs look at numbers!
What‚Äôs all the fuss about Thunderbolt 5
There are a couple of tests I‚Äôm going to do in an attempt to give you a feel of what this Thunderbolt 5 enclosure is like.
I‚Äôll edit this week‚Äôs video from it ‚Äî from start to finish. That will give it a pretty thorough working over ‚Äî that will be the most stress I would ever put it through, so if it passes that test, I‚Äôll be on to a winner. At that point, I‚Äôll know if it‚Äôs going to be a viable alternative to working from Apple‚Äôs internal SSD and if this external SSD is actually a saving or a false economy. It could also mean I can delay longer the idea of introducing a NAS drive into my workflow.
I‚Äôve decided to use the Blackmagicdesign Disk Speed Test. Generally, I don‚Äôt like benchmark tests like this, but in this instance, the numbers will mean something. I‚Äôll use the 5GB test file on the Acasis/Samsung drive, the Samsung T7 drive and then on the Mac mini SSD via the desktop.
I‚Äôve used a 12GB LaCie 2big Raid for a few years now as my storage/archive solution ‚Äî but it‚Äôs started to feel slow. Now I know why ‚Äî when I bought that 12TB raid in 2020, it was ‚Äòstate-of-the-art‚Äô and considered quick. Looking at the box as I‚Äôm writing this, it‚Äôs telling me it has ‚Äòshocking‚Äô data transfer speeds of‚Ä¶20Gb/s. Yet here we are in 2025 with Thunderbolt 5 and 80Gb/s data transfer speeds! No wonder that raid seems slow and old now!
image ‚Äî David Lewis
I was going to try moving a large 52GB file from that LaCie raid onto both the Acasis enclosure and the desktop as part of this experiment, but even I realised that it would be limited by the USB 3 cable that it uses, so it would prove nothing.
Numbers talk
Firstly, the results of the 5GB Blackmagic Disk Speed Test. The Acasis was getting regular read/write speeds of around 5700MB/s, running the test about 10 or 12 times to get a good average feeling of what was going on. In the same test on the M4 Pro Mac minis desktop, I was seeing speeds of 6300MB/s write and 5000MB/s read. The Samsung T7 only recorded speeds of 860MB/s write and 720MB/s read ‚Äî which I guess was no surprise.
So, from what I‚Äôm seeing so far, the Acasis enclosure is behaving more or less, as well as the internal Apple SSD.
What I need to do now is get editing to see how it performs with that‚Ä¶I‚Äôll be back with my final thoughts‚Ä¶
Set up
Before I go and start testing what it‚Äôs like to edit on, though, a word about the set-up. When I first plugged in the Samsung 990 Eco Plus earlier today, I got an error message on screen telling me the ‚Äòdisk was not readable‚Äô.
It‚Äôs less sinister than it appears, though. All it means is that SSD, out of the box, is not formatted. The fix is super simple. Open Disk Utility, highlight the drive and click on erase. Then it‚Äôll give you the option to format it, and from what I‚Äôve learned, the best choice is APFS (Apple File System). APFS is journaled, efficient and designed if you only intend to use the drive on Macs. If you need to switch between Windows and Mac may be consider using ExFat as the format.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
Ok, I‚Äôll come back with my final thoughts in a few days after I‚Äôve spent some time editing on it.
Final thoughts and experiences
In short ‚Äî it‚Äôs brilliant!
I‚Äôm writing this on the back of having spent the best part of two 10-hour days editing a full YouTube video from the Acasis enclosure on my M4 Pro Mac mini, and it was faultless.
It was quick ‚Äî every bit as quick as editing from the Mac itself. I had no issues, and it was quiet the entire time. There is the tiniest of hums coming from it, but honestly, it‚Äôs barely noticeable. And it never got hot. It got warm, but only as warm as the Mac mini itself.
I entered into this test a little sceptical, but now I am starting to think that Apple may have shot itself in the foot by giving us Thunderbolt 5 ports. It now means that it is possible to buy quick, efficient, quiet storage after the point of purchase.
image ‚Äî David Lewis
And the best part is ‚Äî it‚Äôs so easy to set up and use. Literally, no knowledge is needed ‚Äî it‚Äôs simply plug-and-play. The best way for me to tell you how impressed I‚Äôve been by it is if I tell you that any day now, I‚Äôll be going all in and ordering either a 4TB or, more likely, an 8TB memory strip for the Acasis enclosure.
It turns out you can have your cake and eat it too!

7 Unbelievable Practices In Ancient Rome That Are Too Disturbing to Imagine
Disgusting truths about Ancient Rome that will change the way you see History.
Faze
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Exploring History
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Oct 4, 2024
4.7K
62
Source: Wikimedia Commons
Ancient Rome‚Äôs grandeur tends to overshadow the grim reality of everyday life. The empire had many achievements, but the daily experiences of the citizens were far from glamorous.
Filthy streets, unsanitary public baths, and bizarre remedies made survival in Rome a challenge.
Life in the Mighty Roman empire was replete with nauseating details that expose a much grimier aspect of Roman history, whether it be parasites or appalling meals they had it all.
7- Lavish Banquets And Messy Floors Of Roman Dinner Parties
Source: Wikimedia Commons
Roman dinner parties were lavish yet messy affairs. Guests reclined on sofas while indulging in lavish feasts, discarding bones, skins, seafood shells, and olive pits onto the floor.
The discarded refuse was left for slaves to clean up, reflecting a stark difference from modern dining etiquette.
While the myth of ‚Äî vomitoriums ‚Äî suggests that Romans purged themselves to eat more, the reality was that these gatherings prioritized excess and indulgence, often overlooking cleanliness in favor of opulence and comfort.
Despite all the Roman the glamor, the dining experience was far from refined by today‚Äôs standards.
6- The Womb, The Paunch, And Romans Taste Buds
Source: Wikimedia Commons
In Ancient Rome, one of the more unusual dishes was spayed sow‚Äôs womb, seasoned with pepper, celery seed, mint, laser root, honey, vinegar, and broth.
The dainty had been recorded by the celebrated Roman gourmet Apicius, who had created a cookbook based upon well-known recipes of the Empire.
The favorite dish was the ‚Äî paunch from a suckling pig ‚Äî stuffed with minced pork, brains and raw eggs.
Such dishes show the sumptuous uniqueness of the Roman culinary culture: there is nothing to prevent one from using meat bits even from not-at-all-usual animal parts.
5- Sweat, Oil, And Roman Community
Source: Wikimedia Commons
In ancient Rome, bathing was more than just a wash; it was a ritual.
Romans would visit public baths and, before entering the series of heated rooms, they‚Äôd coat their skin in olive oil.
This wasn‚Äôt just for luxury ‚Äî it helped remove dirt and sweat. Using a curved tool called a strigil, they‚Äôd scrape the oil off, along with dead skin.
The oil, however, didn‚Äôt go to waste. It was either reused for the next guest or, surprisingly, repurposed by women as a hair conditioner. This process blended practicality with personal care in a communal setting.
4- Urine And The Art Of Laundry
Source: Wikimedia Commons
In ancient Rome, laundering clothes was a rather unconventional process ‚Äî fullers used urine as a cleaning agent.
Though to the modern eye, it is repulsive, urine contains ammonia which acts like a good stain remover for togas.
Fullers would place pots around towns and plead with people walking by to contribute their urine to them, in this way securing their free supply.
Emperor Vespasian cleverly capitalized on this practice by instituting a ‚Äî urine tax, which generated substantial revenue from the public bins where urine was collected.
This tax proved beneficial during a financially challenging period for the Empire.
When Vespasian‚Äôs son expressed his disapproval of the initiative, his father humorously emphasized the irony of its value. He held a coin from the first payment to his son‚Äôs nose, pointing out its origins.
3- The Roman Sponge Stick
Source: Wikimedia Commons
In ancient Rome, hygiene took on a rather unconventional form. After a visit to the public latrines, Romans didn‚Äôt use toilet paper as we do today.
Instead, they reached for a tool called a ‚Äî Xylospongium ‚Äî a sponge attached to a stick. This sponge-stick was designed to clean those hard-to-reach areas after one squatted over a stone bench with holes.
Conveniently, these sponge-sticks were often attached to the latrine benches, saving Romans the trouble of carrying them around the bustling city.
However, there was a grim downside: the sponge was communal. Multiple people likely used the same sponge, possibly cleaned by attendants or rinsed in a trough of vinegar or saltwater between uses.
While the system might have been efficient, it‚Äôs hard to imagine the hygiene standards, making one grateful for modern toilet paper!
2- Sanitation That Could Literally Kill
Source: Wikimedia Commons
Ancient Rome‚Äôs sanitation was paradoxically advanced yet disturbingly inadequate.
While the city boasted a complex sewer system designed primarily for draining standing water, it largely neglected the removal of human waste and debris.
Romans accepted unsanitary conditions as part of daily life, exhibiting minimal concern for the excrement and decaying food littering their streets.
Roman feces from archeological excavations have shown concerning health risks, such as high concentrations of parasites like roundworm and dysentery that afflicted the populace.
Romans often used their waste as fertilizer, recycling excrement directly onto crops.
Their favorite condiment, garum ‚Äî a fermented fish sauce ‚Äî may have further exacerbated health issues, potentially allowing tapeworms to thrive.
1- Forced Labor Behind The Glory
Source: Wikimedia Commons
The Roman Empire heavily relied on slavery to build its cities, infrastructure, and economy. Slaves were captured in wars, bought from markets, or seized from neighboring communities.
These individuals constituted a significant portion of the population, making up between one-third to three-fifths of Italy‚Äôs total inhabitants ‚Äî about four million slaves.
They were used as serf labor to support the rapid expansion of the empire in the construction and agricultural industries, as well as in domestic work.
Probably the greatest example of this entrenched exploitation is the myth of the kidnapping of the Sabine women, whom they were kidnapped and taken to bear children for Rome.
Points To Ponder
Ancient Roman life was far from glamorous: the prevalence of practices to shock the modern sensibilities is boundless.
From lack of hygiene to violence and cruelties exercised daily, the life of the Romans reveals a society struggling with stark realities.
However, amidst such grossness, there were some outstanding developments in architecture, governance, and culture that formed the bedrock of the West.
Understand these sour truths to introduce the description of elderly Roman life as well as to throw an ominous reminder that history is a scarily balanced mix of the extraordinary and the repugnant which molds succeeding societies in any number of profound ways.

How to Get Great Pictures in Inclement Weather
Tips and Gear Suggestions for Seasonal Change
Derrick Story
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Live View
¬∑
7 min read
¬∑
Nov 27, 2024
892
9
The weather-resistant Olympus OM-D with 12‚Äì100mm f/4 zoom in Iceland.
Bears may hibernate in the winter, but photographers should not. Foul weather creates fantastic photo opportunities, as long as we make adjustments to accommodate the rain and snow.
Much in the same way stormy conditions require appropriate wardrobe, photo gear should also change with the seasons.
British author Alfred Wainwright said it best: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no such thing as bad weather, only unsuitable clothing.‚Äù And I extend his wisdom to photography.
Every enthusiast photographer I know, myself included, has multiple camera options. Some kits are better for summer portraits, others for events and family gatherings. Each rig has its own season. Think T-shirts for summer and parkas for winter.
The best camera for winter may not be your prized state-of-the-art device. That‚Äôs OK. Digital cameras have been capable for a long time. You don‚Äôt need the latest and greatest in a rainstorm. But you do need weather sealing.
So if your forecast looks anything like mine (rain, rain, rain), then it‚Äôs time to visit your camera closet for a seasonal changeover.
What I‚Äôm Putting Away
My prized state-of-the-art camera is the Nikon Zf full-frame mirrorless. It does have some weather resistance, but my 40mm f/2.0 Nikkor Z, Viltrox 20mm f/2.8, and Nikkor 24‚Äì85mm f/3.5‚Äì4.5G ED VR lenses do not. The first rule of storm photography is that both lens and body need robust protection seals.
I love my Nikon Zf with 40mm lens. But that optic is not weather resistant.
I also carry the super compact Fujifilm XF-10. Its lovely 28mm f/2.8 lens combined with an APS-C sensor is perfect for landscape photography‚Ä¶ in the summer. I‚Äôm afraid that cute little guy wouldn‚Äôt last 5 minutes in a Sonoma County downpour.
I love them both and will reach for them when appropriate. But I do have more robust options for winter.
What I‚Äôm Switching to For December
Two camera brands that come to mind for outdoor adventure are Olympus (OM System) and Pentax. They‚Äôre not as popular as Canon, Nikon, and Sony, but they are tough, and they have great glass.
OM System OM-1 Mirrorless
OM System OM-1 II with Olympus 12‚Äì100mm zoom lens.
The OM System OM-1 paired with the 12‚Äì40mm f/2.8 PRO II, 12‚Äì100mm f/4 PRO, and the 40‚Äì150mm f/2.8 PRO zooms deliver great images regardless of the environment. Not all Olympus optics are weather-resistant. But the ones that have that designation are stout.
My ultimate test for Olympus durability was a few years ago on a late October trip to Iceland. It was cold (very cold!), windy, and wet. If I were to come home with any sort of photo catalog, I had to forget about protecting my equipment. Otherwise, that‚Äôs all that I‚Äôd be doing ‚Äî wiping off gear and not taking pictures.
Photography in Iceland!
Once I got back in the car after a shoot, I would wrap everything in a towel and leave it out on the seat to dry. After one week of this environmental torture, the body and lenses were still performing as well as the day I arrived.
I also depend on this kit in the tropics. The next stop for the OM-1 will be Costa Rica in January. Warm rain is just as wet as cold rain.
Pentax KP DSLR
Pentax KP DSLR with Pentax 18‚Äì50mm WR zoom.
The other camera that I never worry about in bad weather is my Pentax KP DSLR. I‚Äôve dropped it on frozen trails and slung it over my shoulder in pouring rain, and it‚Äôs still clicking away without a hitch. This is the case for every camera in the Pentax DSLR lineup.
The Pentax KP survived the rugged Oregon Coast in November.
My favorite all-weather lens is the 70‚Äì210mm f/4 ED SDM WR. Any Pentax lens with the WR designation is a beast outdoors. Plus, the 70‚Äì210mm features internal zooming and focusing. That means the lens barrel doesn‚Äôt extend. This single-body construction is easy to wipe down and doesn‚Äôt create anxiety in the field.
Pentax 70‚Äì210mm f/4 WR zoom.
I often pair it with the Pentax HD DA 20‚Äì40mm f/2.8‚Äì4 WR zoom or the more compact 18‚Äì50mm f/4‚Äì5.6 WR. Again, great weather sealing combined with fabulous optics results in beautiful shots regardless of conditions.
Olympus Tough Compact Camera
The ultimate ‚Äúdon‚Äôt worry about the weather‚Äù compact camera is the Olympus Tough series. I‚Äôm still using the older TG-4. The current model is the TG-7.
The Olympus Tough TG-4 was my companion in Iceland‚Äôs famous Blue Lagoon.
Whether I‚Äôm snorkeling in Hawaii or relaxing in Iceland‚Äôs Blue Lagoon, this compact always gets the shot.
A Note About the Pentax and the Olympus Tough
My Pentax KP was released in January 2017. It has a 24-megapixel APS-C sensor, 5-axis image stabilization, 100 percent optical viewfinder coverage, and a 27-point AF sensor with 25 central cross-type points.
Olympus Tough with my snorkeling gear.
The Olympus TG-4 is even older, released in April 2015. It sports a 16-megapixel sensor and a 1/2.3" sensor.
Just like a pair of old jeans that may have faded a bit, but still feel great, these two cameras are very serviceable today. And thanks to great strides in post-processing software, I can use AI adjustments to upsample resolution and eliminate noise.
Modern software extends the life of our photography hardware, and both of these cameras are perfect examples of that.
Tips for Working Outdoors
Convict Lake, CA with the Olympus OM-1 and 12‚Äì40mm PRO zoom.
Regardless of how good your gear is, there are things you can do to maximize its performance.
For lenses, I always attach a high-quality protection filter on the front element. The main reason I do this is so I can use any soft cloth or my T-shirt to wipe off the glass in stormy conditions.
Since it‚Äôs a filter and not the front element of my lens, I don‚Äôt have to be overly meticulous about cleaning the surface. Microfiber cloths are not very absorbent. And if that‚Äôs all you have to use in a storm, it‚Äôs going to be a long day.
I also pack soft cloths to wipe down the lenses and camera bodies. I‚Äôve learned over the years to have at least three on hand. You can dry them back at the room each night.
Extra batteries and a battery grip extend your run time during long shoots. Grips are nice because you can usually double up your batteries, and they tend to be easier to access when changing in cold weather. Keep your extra cells warm, in a jacket pocket, so they‚Äôre ready to go when you need them.
Shower caps come in handy in pelting rain. They easily pull over your camera and can help extend the life of your drying cloths because you‚Äôre not using them as often. I usually have a one-gallon Ziploc bag too.
I am working in Iceland with my Olympus OM in plastic. Photo captured with the TG-4.
And finally, I recommend two camera bodies so you don‚Äôt have to change lenses in the field. You can keep a short-to-midrange zoom on one body, and your long telephoto on the other. The last thing you want is a wind gust blowing debris into the camera body while changing lenses. Save that task for inside the car.
Final Thoughts
Good camera equipment designed for outdoor photography will serve you well regardless of the conditions you‚Äôre working in. Don‚Äôt let concerns about your gear keep you inside during the winter months. Some of your best pictures may be captured during the worst weather.

5 Debugging Secrets That Made Me a 10x Better Developer
The Simple Guide That Will Change How You Fix Bugs Forever
Amaresh Adak
¬∑
Follow
Published in
The Syntax Diaries
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Dec 29, 2024
245
8
H
ey there, fellow developers! üëã
Let‚Äôs talk about something we all do but rarely discuss openly ‚Äî debugging.
You know, that thing we spend 50% of our time on but only mention in passing during stand-ups? Yeah, that one.
I‚Äôve been in your shoes, plastering console.log() statements everywhere like they‚Äôre going out of style. Don‚Äôt get me wrong ‚Äì we‚Äôve all been there! But after years of debugging and countless hours of hair-pulling sessions, I‚Äôve learned there‚Äôs a better way.
Actually, there are several better ways, and I‚Äôm excited to share them with you.
1. Breaking Up with console.log(): It‚Äôs Time to Meet Debuggers
Remember your first console.log()? Sweet and simple, right? But like any relationship, sometimes you need to grow. Modern debuggers are like console.log() after hitting the gym ‚Äì stronger, more capable, and ready to handle whatever you throw at them.
‚ÄúBut wait,‚Äù you might say, ‚Äúisn‚Äôt setting up a debugger complicated?‚Äù
Actually, it‚Äôs easier than you think! If you‚Äôre using Chrome, just:
Open DevTools (F12 is your friend)
Head to the Sources tab
Click on any line number to set a breakpoint
Reload and watch the magic happen
Pro tip from someone who learned it the hard way: Use conditional breakpoints when debugging loops. Trust me, your sanity will thank you later.
Instead of stopping at every iteration, just add a condition like index === 5 to your breakpoint. It‚Äôs like having a VIP pass to exactly where you need to be in your code.
2. Leveling Up Your Logging Game
Okay, I know what you‚Äôre thinking ‚Äî ‚ÄúBut I like my console.logs!‚Äù Fair enough. Let‚Äôs not throw the baby out with the bathwater. Instead, let‚Äôs give that baby some superpowers with advanced logging tools.
Have you ever tried to debug a production issue with basic console.logs? Yeah, it‚Äôs about as fun as finding a needle in a haystack‚Ä¶ while blindfolded‚Ä¶ in the dark. Enter structured logging tools like Winston.
Winston is a popular and versatile logging library for Node.js applications. It supports multiple transports, customizable log formats, and logging levels, making it an ideal choice for managing logs in both development and production environments.
What Makes Winston Special?
‚Ä¢ Multiple Transports: Log messages to various destinations such as files, consoles, or remote servers.
‚Ä¢ Customizable Formats: Use prebuilt or custom formats to tailor logs to your needs.
‚Ä¢ Environment-Specific Logging: Easily configure different logging behaviors for development and production.
‚Ä¢ Metadata Support: Enrich your logs with additional context like timestamps, service names, or user IDs.
Here‚Äôs a quick example that‚Äôll change your life:
const winston = require('winston');
const logger = winston.createLogger({
  level: 'info',
  format: winston.format.json(),
  transports: [
    new winston.transports.File({ filename: 'errors.log', level: 'error' }),
    new winston.transports.Console()
  ]
});

// Instead of console.log('User logged in');
logger.info('User logged in', { 
  userId: '123', 
  timestamp: new Date() 
});
See what we did there? Now you‚Äôre not just logging ‚Äî you‚Äôre telling a story with context!
For detailed documentation and advanced features, check out the official Winston Documentation.
3. Performance Profiling: Because Speed Matters
Let‚Äôs talk about performance. You know that feeling when someone says ‚Äúthe app feels slow‚Äù and your stomach drops? Yeah, we‚Äôre going to fix that.
Chrome DevTools‚Äô Performance tab is like having X-ray vision for your code. Here‚Äôs what I do:
Open up the Performance tab
Hit record
Do whatever‚Äôs running slow
Stop recording
Marvel at the beautiful flame graph that shows exactly where your code is spending its time
Fun fact: I once found a function that was running 1000 times more often than needed using this method. The fix? Two lines of code. The feeling of satisfaction? Priceless.
4. Linters and Static Analysis: Your Code‚Äôs Spell-Check
Think of Linters as that friend who always points out when you have food in your teeth. Annoying? Maybe. Helpful? Absolutely.
ESLint isn‚Äôt just about catching missing semicolons (though it does that too). It‚Äôs about catching potential bugs before they happen. Here‚Äôs a starter config that‚Äôll save you hours:
5. Production Monitoring: Because Bugs Don‚Äôt Stay in Development
Let‚Äôs face it ‚Äî no matter how much we test, some bugs will sneak into production. It‚Äôs like Murphy‚Äôs Law for developers. But don‚Äôt worry, tools like Sentry can help you catch them before they become a nightmare for your users.
Sentry is an error-tracking tool that monitors your applications for crashes, exceptions, and performance issues in real time. It provides detailed insights, including stack traces, user context, and breadcrumbs, so you can quickly diagnose and resolve problems.
Setting Up Sentry
Integrating Sentry into your project is straightforward. For a browser-based JavaScript application, here‚Äôs how you can get started:
Now you‚Äôll get notifications when things go wrong in production, complete with stack traces and user context. It‚Äôs like having a security camera for your code!
The Debugging Mindset: Think Like a Detective
Here‚Äôs something they don‚Äôt teach you in coding bootcamps:
Debugging is more about the mindset than the tools. It‚Äôs about being methodical, patient, and curious.
When I approach a bug, I:
Gather evidence (logs, error messages, user reports)
Form a hypothesis
Test it
Repeat until solved
Remember: every bug you fix makes you a better developer. Each one is a story to tell (preferably over coffee) and a lesson learned.
Wrapping Up
Debugging doesn‚Äôt have to be a nightmare. With these tools and techniques, you can turn it into a methodical process that might even be‚Ä¶ dare I say it‚Ä¶ fun?
What‚Äôs your go-to debugging technique? Have you had any debugging adventures that taught you valuable lessons? Drop a comment below ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear your stories!
Happy debugging! Remember: bugs are just features waiting to be fixed. üòâ

Python Radio 32: Old-Time Radio
Build a Time Machine
Simon Quellen Field
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Radio Hackers
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Jan 5, 2025
154
3
MidJourney
In the days before television, electronic entertainment meant radio.
Not just music and news, but comedy shows, mysteries, and adventure came streaming into homes through receivers that were often furniture. Fancy polished wood cabinets were centerpieces in the living room, with chairs arranged around them so the family could listen together.
Those were the days of Abbott and Costello, Jack Benny, Burns and Allen, Amos and Andy, and Fibber McGee and Molly. There was the CBS Radio Mystery Theater. There were dramas like Our Miss Brooks and Sherlock Holmes.
Thousands of these old radio shows are now collected on the Internet to be downloaded for free, as they are now out of copyright. Orson Welles‚Äô War of the Worlds caused a panic when people believed it was a true news program. The Lone Ranger brought the old West into living rooms.
Many of the older shows from the 1930s are poorly recorded, but by the 1940s the technology had improved greatly, and the sound quality is quite good.
My Receiver
I have a replica of an old-time radio. It has a nice polished wood cabinet and sits on the counter in the living room. Under it is a drawer where I have hidden an A.M. radio transmitter playing a mix of those old-time radio shows.
Visitors find this quite amusing.
My Transmitter
In keeping with the theme of this series, the transmitter is an ESP32 Lolin S2 Mini connected to an SD card reader and a PCM5102 stereo Digital to Analog Converter (DAC) board.
The ESP32 sends out a 3.3-volt 625-kilohertz square wave that acts as the carrier. A diode that amplitude modulates the carrier mixes it with the audio from the DAC.
Photo by the author
The connections for the SD Card Reader are as follows:
ESP32 Pin 5 ‚Üí SD Card Reader CS
ESP32 Pin 18 ‚Üí SD Card Reader SCK
ESP32 Pin 12 ‚Üí SD Card Reader MOSI
ESP32 Pin 11 ‚Üí SD Card Reader MISO
ESP32 Pin 3.3V ‚Üí SD Card Reader VCC
ESP32 Pin GND ‚Üí SD Card Reader GND
Photo by the author
The connections for the PCM51002 DAC are:
ESP32 Pin 40 ‚Üí DAC BCK
ESP32 Pin 38 ‚Üí DAC DIN
ESP32 Pin 36 ‚Üí DAC LRCK
ESP32 Pin 3.3V ‚Üí DAC VIN
ESP32 Pin GND ‚Üí DAC GND
Photo by the aurhor
Since the ESP32 only brings out one pin for 3.3 volts, I made a Y connector to power both of the other boards.
The PWM output for the carrier wave comes out on pin 3. This goes to a 1k ohm resistor. The audio output from the DAC comes out from the left output pin (marked L on one side of the board and LROUT on the other). This goes to another 1k ohm resistor.
The two resistors connect to one end of the diode (any silicon diode will work).
Photo by the author
The remaining end of the diode connects to a loop of wire whose other end connects to the analog ground pin on the DAC. This loop of wire is our antenna. You can make it as long as you like.
How the Hardware Works
We have two signal sources ‚Äî the 625-kilohertz carrier and the audio signal, which varies between perhaps 100 hertz up to at most about 20 kilohertz.
To get an amplitude-modulated signal from these, we need to multiply them together. You might think we would use the computer to do that, but instead, we use a five-cent diode.
How can a diode do multiplication?
When we apply a voltage to a diode, the current going through the diode rises exponentially with the applied voltage. The graph looks like this:
mmerevise.co.uk
When we add exponents, we get multiplication. We put our two signals in at one end, and their voltages add in the diode. The result is the product of the two. Since the signals are made up of waves, they interfere, and we get our amplitude-modulated signal out.
What, No Filter?
Our carrier wave is a square wave. It consists of the fundamental sine wave, plus all of the odd harmonics of that wave, in decreasing amplitude as they increase.
This means we could hear our old-time radio at 1875 kilohertz, but only one-third as far. We could hear the signal at 3125 kilohertz, but only 1/5th as far.
We could build a low-pass filter to remove these harmonics. But our signal is 3.3 volts, at about 10 milliamperes, into an antenna that is ten inches long. The wavelength at 625 kilohertz is over 1,500 feet long so that antenna is far from resonant.
How far does our signal go?
The best I‚Äôve seen is about a foot, after careful fiddling with the position of the antenna and the receiver.
The receiver picks up a beautifully clear signal when it is a few inches above the hidden transmitter. That signal and clarity would be the envy of any 1940s radio listener. But move the receiver a few inches, and the signal degrades quickly.
The Software
Our SD card reader can‚Äôt handle the 64-gigabyte microSD cards I first tried. It could probably handle 32-gigabyte cards, but I found a one-gigabyte card in a drawer that I‚Äôm sure no one will miss. It will hold over 300 radio shows of about ten minutes each. That‚Äôs two days of constant programming.
We will play WAV files since micropython has modules to do that. Many of the radio programs are in MP3 format, so we convert them to WAV before storing them on the microSD card.
Because the language has support for both boards, the program is actually fairly short:
from machine import I2S, SPI, Pin, PWM
from micropython import schedule
from os import mount, umount

spi = SPI(2, baudrate=100000, polarity=0, phase=0, sck=18, mosi=12, miso=11)
from sdcard import SDCard
sdcard = SDCard(spi, cs=Pin(5))
mount(sdcard, "/sd")

pin = Pin(3, Pin.OUT)
pwm = PWM(pin, freq=10, duty=512)

SCK_PIN = 40
SD_PIN  = 38
WS_PIN  = 36
I2S_ID = 0
BUFFER_LENGTH_IN_BYTES = 40000

wav = open("/sd/{}".format("WhosOnFirstAudio.Wav"), "rb")

audio_out = I2S(I2S_ID,
    sck=Pin(SCK_PIN), ws=Pin(WS_PIN), sd=Pin(SD_PIN),
    mode=I2S.TX, bits=16, format=I2S.MONO, rate=16000, ibuf=40000)

silence = bytearray(1000)
wav_samples = bytearray(10000)
wav_samples_mv = memoryview(wav_samples)



def i2s_callback(arg):
    num_read = wav.readinto(wav_samples_mv)
    if num_read == 0:
        pos = wav.seek(44)
        audio_out.write(silence)
    else:
        audio_out.write(wav_samples_mv[:num_read])

def freqs():
  print()
  print("Convenient reachable frequencies in the A.M. band:")
  guess = 0
  for f in range(540, 1700):
    try:
      pwm.freq(f * 1000)
      actual = pwm.freq()
      if actual != guess and actual % 1000 == 0:
        print(str(actual / 1000) + " kHz")
        guess = actual
    except ValueError as verr:
      pass
  print()


def main():
    pwm.freq(625 * 1000)
    audio_out.irq(i2s_callback)
    wav.seek(44)  # advance to first byte of Data section in WAV file
    audio_out.write(silence)

freqs()
main()
It would be even shorter, but I threw in a little routine to calculate convenient frequencies in the A.M. band that the ESP32 can reach using its PWM module.
The SD card reader talks to the ESP32 over the SPI bus. We mount it as a file system called /sd.
The PCM51002 DAC talks to the ESP32 over I2S, a streaming protocol we have not used before in this series. We read samples from the WAV file and stream them to the DAC using I2S. The hardware can thus do all of the heavy lifting, and our program is simple.
We start out by sending a buffer full of zeros for a moment of silence. This ‚Äúprimes the pump‚Äù, and we get an interrupt when the I2S module wants more data. That‚Äôs when we send the WAV bytes.
At the end of the file, we send more silence, rewind to the beginning, and start over.
In this program, I just play Abbott and Costello‚Äôs Who‚Äôs On First comedy routine over and over. But you can concatenate days‚Äô worth of old-time radio shows into one big WAV file if you like. Or you can read the files off the microSD card individually.<|InputEnd|>Top highlight

9 Naming Tricks Every Developer Should Know to Avoid Headache
Rufat Khaslarov
¬∑
Follow
Published in
JavaScript in Plain English
¬∑
3 min read
¬∑
Sep 16, 2024
1.9K
29
Code with poor naming is difficult to read, and hard-to-read code is like a ticking time bomb. Sooner or later, you‚Äôll have to revisit it to fix bugs or add new features. When that moment arrives, you‚Äôll likely face three frustrating scenarios:
Refactor everything: This increases the scope and complexity of the task, requires extra testing, and might introduce new bugs.
Use a workaround: Instead of refactoring, you patch things up. This leads to more complicated code and greater maintenance headaches, pushing it toward ‚Äúlegacy‚Äù status.
Cut corners: With tight deadlines, you might just slap on whatever works, ignoring edge cases and testing gaps ‚Äî creating tomorrow‚Äôs problem today.
Below is the continuation of the topic:
10 Practical Tips for Writing Functions Efficiently to Elevate Your Coding Skills
Let‚Äôs continue our discussion on code quality by exploring more best practices. Sometimes, we write code unconsciously‚Ä¶
javascript.plainenglish.io
What are the best practices for choosing an appropriate name?
Picking the right names for your variables, functions, and classes is key to writing maintainable and readable code. Here are some best practices to follow:
1. Show Clear Intention (Intention-Revealing Names)
The name should describe what the code does or what the entity represents. It should be self-explanatory, so you don‚Äôt need comments or deep exploration of the code to understand its purpose.
Bad: d = 100
Good: daysBeforeCreation = 100
A good example clearly shows intent right from the start.
2. Use Domain-Specific Terminology
Stay consistent with the terminology used in your codebase. This helps avoid confusion, especially when working in large teams or when multiple contributors are involved. Avoid spreading misinformation and use names that are easy to search.
Example: In an e-commerce app, use productList instead of something too generic like data.
Domain-specific language enhances clarity.
3. Avoid Misunderstanding
Before finalizing a name, imagine how someone unfamiliar with your code would interpret it. Avoid ambiguous names or names that could suggest multiple meanings.
Bad: data or result or list
Good: userTransactionData or paymentResult
Adding context to the name ensures that anyone reading the code knows exactly what it refers to.
4. Be Consistent
Maintain consistency in your naming conventions across the codebase.
Example: If you use isActive for a boolean variable, avoid using activeStatusfor another boolean variable.
5. Prioritize Readability and Grammar
Choose clear and straightforward English instead of using formal or overly complex language. If a name feels awkward or is hard to pronounce, it‚Äôs a signal to rework it. You want the code to be conversational.
Bad: isDataProcessed or isDataProcess
Good: hasProcessedData
6. Align Names with Data Types
Use nouns or noun phrases for variables, classes, or objects. For methods and functions, use action verbs. Boolean names should pose general questions, avoiding confusion about the type of data represented.
Bad: publish or published
Good: publishedArticle
7. Avoid Abbreviations
Using whole words instead of abbreviations makes your code more readable. Modern IDEs support autocomplete, so abbreviations are generally unnecessary.
Bad: p or dd
Good: post or deliveryDate
8. Eliminate Noise
Avoid using noise words like Data, Value, Info or data types like Arr, List and so on as suffixes. These are redundant and do not add meaningful distinction.
Bad: userDataValue or userArr
Good: userProfile and users
9. Avoid Misleading Names
Ensure variable names have a single, clear meaning. Avoid names that are easily confused or have double meanings.
Bad: userKey or userID (both might be seen as equivalent);
Good: userRecordKey or userIdentificationNumber
With these tips, your code will be easier to read, maintain, and extend. Remember, great code is written for humans to understand, not just machines to execute.
Adapter Design Pattern: Still Relevant or a Thing of the Past?
While paradigms may evolve, the essentials remain constant.

10 Things To Do In The Evening Instead Of Watching Netflix
Device-free habits to increase your productivity and happiness.
Aleid ter Weel
¬∑
Follow
Published in
Better Advice
¬∑
5 min read
¬∑
Feb 15, 2022
27K
456
Photo by MART PRODUCTION from Pexels
Anyone worried about spending slightly too many hours bingeing Netflix or watching TV, you're not alone.
British figures released in 2021 showed that adults spent a third of their waking hours watching TV and online video content at an average of five hours and forty minutes.
Now, you don't need to throw your TV out the window and force yourself into some complicated evening routine.
What you need is a set of tools and alternative activities that you naturally gravitate towards and can rotate between ‚Äî keeping your evenings fresh, flexible, and fun.
Just pick a few that spark your interest to replace (part) of your TV time. Then experiment, adjust, and add your own. With time, you'll learn what positively fuels your energy, brainpower, and relationships, so you go to bed with a rested mind and a smiling heart.
Tame Tomorrow's Triggers
Instead of fighting distractions during the day, manage your impulses ahead of time.
Take a few minutes before going to bed to prevent tomorrow's distractions. It can be as simple as cleaning your desk, preparing your work materials, taking five minutes to plan your day, or leaving your phone out of the bedroom.
Eliminating distractions in the evening makes focusing in the morning infinitely easier.
Clear Your Head Of 'Open Loops'
Your mind is for having ideas, not holding them.
‚Äî David Allen
Not all distractions are external. We probably keep our most distracting stuff in our heads.
Capture your personal concerns by writing a to-do list, planning appointments in your calendar, or doing a 5-minute brain dump in the evening.
Writing down your thoughts prevents the unresolved items from today from weighing on our minds tomorrow.
As Chris Bailey writes in Hyperfocus: ‚ÄúAn empty brain is a productive brain, and the more stuff we get out of our heads, the more clearly we think.‚Äù
Don‚Äôt Let Your Mind Eat Junk
Reality TV, talk shows, celebrity gossip, are like junk food for our brains. It‚Äôs low quality, highly processed, and despite knowing how bad it is, we consume it anyways.
One of the best decisions I made a few years ago is to stop consuming what author Paul Greenberg calls 'junk media'. Instead, I put on a good movie or documentary, and I follow a handful of creators on YouTube who make high-quality content.
If I do decide to watch something in the evening, this type of content leaves my brain in much better shape than if I‚Äôd stuffed myself with junk media.
Resist The Urge To Mindlessly Distract Yourself All Evening
Our evenings rarely involve enough rest as they should. As soon as we come home from a hard day of work, we busy ourselves again by checking social, scanning the news, and putting on the TV.
Instead of resting our brains, we‚Äôre distracting our brains with more input, more information, and more stimulation from our devices.
I know it‚Äôs not realistic to eliminate all devices from your evening, and I don‚Äôt think you should. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with blowing off steam and having some mindless fun.
However, low-quality leisure shouldn‚Äôt outweigh high-quality leisure. At the end of the evening, you want your mental clarity and energy to have moved forwards, not backward.
Introduce Board Game Night
If your family‚Äôs after-dinner routine is to withdraw into your separate domains of the house and disappear into your own virtual reality, try implementing one night a week in which you‚Äôll play a board game as a family.
According to Digital Detox expert Tanya Gooding, playing board games gets you into a flow state ‚Äî a meditative state in which your brain can restore, and your breathing and heart rate slow down.
In addition, your brain produces rewarding chemicals in a flow state ‚Äî making it a pleasurable experience and a joyful way to pass some time in the evening.
Call the Friend You're Texting
Research shows that while texting creates an illusion of closeness, it actually decreases a relationship‚Äôs stability and satisfaction.
Use texting for logistical purposes and save emotional conversations for phone calls or face-to-face communication.
Read Something Fun And Not Work-Related
Research shows that reading fiction is one of the most effective ways to reduce stress. Stress levels are shown to decrease by 68% after reading fiction ‚Äî which is more than listening to music, walking, or drinking tea.
Most of us see reading as a tool to become something ‚Äî more productive, more knowledgeable, more interesting.
But as bestselling author Matt Haig once wrote: "Reading isn't important because it helps to get you a job. It's important because it gives you room to exist beyond the reality you're given."
I‚Äôm currently re-reading The Mistborn Trilogy by Brandon Sanderson.
Let Them Wait
Platforms like Whatsapp and Messenger have made communication free, easy, and instant.
And with this ease, we‚Äôve developed the unhealthy expectation that you always have to be there ‚Äî to pick up the phone, get back to the text, answer the email, and update our social media.
Choose to free yourself from these unrealistic expectations of instant messaging and take back the power over your availability.
If your friends are friends, they‚Äôll understand when you need some time and headspace. And if not, they‚Äôre probably not worth getting back to anyways.
Remove The TV From Your Bedroom
Rooms serve purposes. Kitchens are for cooking, dining rooms are for dining, offices are for working, living rooms are for entertaining, and bedrooms are for sleeping.
The better we use each room for their purpose, the more productive they become. Use your bedroom for sleep and intimacy, and remove work items, laptops, and televisions from your sleeping environment.
Write One Line A Day
My favorite birthday present from last year has to be my One Line a Day journal. In contrast to having a complicated journaling practice, writing just one line a day feels manageable and attainable.
It‚Äôs a great way for me to put down a final thought before falling asleep at night, and it helps me focus on the small joys in my days.
I hope at least one of these activities inspires you to spend less time on your devices and more time investing in your relationships, rest, and focus.
Thanks for reading, and as always ‚Äî Stay kind! :)

The CSS Anchor API: A Game-Changer for Building Modern Web Interfaces
Digvijay Mahapatra
¬∑
Follow
Published in
JavaScript in Plain English
¬∑
6 min read
¬∑
Jan 13, 2025
466
8
TL;DR: The new CSS Anchor API revolutionizes how we position dropdowns, tooltips, and contextual menus. Say goodbye to complex positioning logic and hello to native, efficient solutions that just work.
Photo by Kelly Sikkema on Unsplash
Picture this: You‚Äôve just spent hours perfecting a dropdown menu for your web app. It works great‚Ä¶ until a user opens it at the bottom of the screen. Suddenly, your beautiful menu is cut off, trapped beneath the viewport‚Äôs edge. Sound familiar?
I‚Äôve been there. We all have. For years, web developers have wrestled with positioning contextual elements like dropdowns, tooltips, and menus. Our solutions? Often a maze of JavaScript calculations, scroll listeners, and edge-case handling makes our code more complex than it needs to be.
But things are about to change dramatically.
Enter the CSS Anchor API: Your New Positioning Superpower
The CSS Anchor API introduces a native solution to a problem that has plagued front-end developers for years. It‚Äôs like having a skilled navigator for your UI elements ‚Äî they always know exactly where to go.
The Basics: Anchors and Positioning
At its core, the Anchor API operates on a simple principle: establish reference points and position elements relative to them. Here‚Äôs how it works:
#anchor-button {
  anchor-name: --my-button-anchor;
}

#tooltip {
  position-anchor: --my-button-anchor;
}
In the above example, the tooltip will position itself w.r.t the button.
A tooltip positioned to the button anchor
Two Ways to Anchor: Implicit vs Explicit
The API offers flexibility in how you reference your anchors:
Implicit Anchor
#tooltip {
  position-anchor: --my-button-anchor;
  top: anchor(bottom);
}
Explicit anchor
#tooltip {
  top: anchor(--my-button-anchor bottom);
}
Unlike the former, the explicit anchor allows elements to be positioned to multiple anchors, achieved by using the names of the anchors inside the anchor function.
#positioned-elem {
  right: anchor(--first-anchor left);
  bottom: anchor(--second-anchor top);
}
Positioning Your Elements
Positioning an anchor is based on the existing absolute positioning. To position your element, add position: absolute and then use the anchor function to apply positioning values. Let‚Äôs modify the earlier example to place the tooltip at the bottom right of the button ‚Äî
#anchor-button {
  anchor-name: --my-button-anchor;
}

#tooltip {
  position-anchor: --my-button-anchor;
  position: absolute;
  top: anchor(bottom);
  left: anchor(right);
}
The tooltip positioned to the bottom right
You can also use the logical positioning values and the calc function to achieve the desired results.
The Features You Need to Know
1. position-area: The 9-Cell Magic
Forget complex calculations. The position-area property introduces an intuitive 9-cell grid system:
#anchor-button {
  anchor-name: --my-button-anchor;
}

#tooltip {
  position-anchor: --my-button-anchor;
  position: absolute;
  position-area: bottom right;
}
By default, providing singular positioning values(ex: position-area: top ) positions the element on the centre of the given side.
2. anchor-size: Dynamic Sizing Made Simple
Another useful function released as part of the anchor API is the anchor-size function that allows us to size or position the element relative to the size of the anchor. Say we want the height of the tooltip not to exceed twice the height of the anchor, we can do it using the following ‚Äî
#anchor-button {
  anchor-name: --my-button-anchor;
}

#tooltip {
  position-anchor: --my-button-anchor;
  position: absolute;
  position-area: right;
  max-height: calc(anchor-size(height) * 2);
}
3. The Secret Weapon: @position-try
This is where the API truly shines. Remember our dropdown that disappeared off-screen? Here‚Äôs the elegant solution: @position-try
For the moment, let‚Äôs follow the same button-tooltip example to keep things simple. I‚Äôll show you a full-fledged example later.
#anchor-button {
  anchor-name: --my-button-anchor;
}

#tooltip {
  position-anchor: --my-button-anchor;
  position: absolute;
  position-area: right bottom;
  max-height: calc(anchor-size(height) * 2);
  position-try-fallbacks: --button-fallback;
}

@position-try --button-fallback {
  position-area: bottom;
}
An example of @position-try
4. position-visibility: Now You See Me
You‚Äôve built positioned elements on your page and things look great! But, what if your anchor is inside a parent with a scroller? What happens to the positioned element?
The position-visibility property helps you deal with this exact case.
position-visibility: anchor-visible displays the positioned element as long as 100% of the anchor is in view. This means that the positioned element may overflow the parent element.
position-visibility: no-overflow displays the positioned element as long as it does not overflow the parent.
A real-world example
Let‚Äôs summarize with a practical example: the dropdown I mentioned earlier. Let‚Äôs see how you can now build dropdown components with native code and make things simpler.
:popover-open {
  inset: auto;
}

:root {
  --width: 200px;
}

#dropdown {
  background: white;
  border: 2px solid #05f;
  border-radius: 4px;
  color: #05f;
  padding: 10px 20px;
  anchor-name: --dropdown;
}

#dropdown-menu {
  width: var(--width);
  position: absolute;
  position-anchor: --dropdown;
  top: anchor(bottom);
  left: anchor(right);
  position-try-fallbacks: --dropdown-pos;
}

@position-try --dropdown-pos {
  left: calc(anchor(left) - 40px);
}
We‚Äôll build the dropdown using the popover API. You can read more in detail about the popover API here. We remove all the default styling for the popover using inset: auto . After creating and attaching anchors to the dropdown menu, and using everything we have learnt so far, we will have something like this ‚Äî
A dropdown component example
The Current State and Future
While the CSS Anchor API represents the future of web positioning, browser support is still evolving. However, don‚Äôt let that stop you from exploring this powerful feature. Thanks to polyfills like the one from Oddbird, you can start implementing these patterns today.
Browser Support
What‚Äôs Next
Start experimenting with the CSS Anchor API in your projects. Even if you‚Äôre using polyfills initially, you‚Äôll be ahead of the curve when native support becomes widespread. The future of web positioning is here, and it‚Äôs more elegant than we could have imagined.
Further Reading
CSS anchor positioning
Handling overflow
